webTitle: Comment:  Brown's pre-budget report

fields.headline: The future is Brown
fields.standfirst:
Given Britain's fiscal strength, the Chancellor can implement his five-point plan and give this country a decade of progress and prosperity

Special report: the Budget
fields.trailText: Given Britain's fiscal strength, the Chancellor can implement his five-point plan and give this country a decade of progress and prosperity.
fields.body:
Britain had a budget last week. The Chancellor may not have walked around St James's Park in the spring daffodils or waved his red box to the cameramen as he left Number 11, but this was no stocktaking or consultation exercise. This was the full Monty, deploying £5.7 billion in tax cuts and spending increases, as much as in a typical recent British budget.

Of course giving £2.25bn to the fuel lobby and another £2.5bn to pensioners was a political act, but that is only a term of abuse for the Government's enemies and for those who believe policy should be determined by technocrats operating a definition of the public interest that they make up themselves.

Strategically, the Government had to draw the sting from the petrol protesters in the short term while drawing up plans in the medium term that would better insulate the country from the effects of further picketing of fuel depots. As for pensioners, there is every reason that they should share in the rise in general living standards and, given the extent of the budget surplus, have a proper claim on the Government's largesse. The same principle should extend to all those on income support.

However, the big point stands. Elected governments, not unelected interest groups, must determine policy. It is better to make some concessions now to preserve that principle, at the price of partly validating the charge that you give in to whoever shouts loudest, than take a position which you might have to abandon, thus putting the principle at risk. The chances are that public support for the protesters is diminishing, but in a volatile climate nobody can be certain. It is better for the Government to take one step back and secure its position for moving forwards than to lose ground through intransigence.

The question remains as to whether the Government could have shaped its concessions better to protect the long-term public interest. The correct transport policy surely has to be to raise the capital cost of car and lorry ownership, to tax congestion, to provide high-quality public transport and to tilt fuel taxation to favour low pollutant fuels while not making the overall burden excessive. The Government is on firm ground on the last two elements. Public transport is to receive huge investment over the coming three years and on Wednesday the Chancellor focused his duty cuts on low-sulphur fuels. So far so good.

However, proposing to more than halve lorry excise duties while doing nothing to advance the cause of congestion charging was surely wrong, leading to a situation where an already over- large road-haulage industry will become larger, with nothing to deter lorry use of roads at peak times.

This was a bribe too far. It would have been better for the Chancellor to have spent the cash on cutting fuel duties further and to have held the line on vehicle excise duty if he felt that talking congestion charges at the moment (which I guess was the reason for avoiding the subject) was too inflammatory.

But on pensions, the Government has developed an almost unassailable interim position, closing down the argument for the time being from internal critics and the Tories alike. The increases in the basic state pension are long overdue, and lifting the minimum income guarantee (MIG) substantially while pledging to index its growth to earnings over the next parliament is hardly contestable. Pension incomes next year for the poorest 10 per cent who claim MIG (most do not, on principle, because it is means-tested) will rise by 8 per cent in real terms.

And this is the rub. Pensions, like the Schleswig-Holstein question, are understood by almost nobody - pensioners, policy-makers and commentators alike. For example, there is little recognition, even in the Treasury and the Department of Social Security, that individual saving for retirement has recently become a disaster. Returns on the equity market over the past three years have been derisory while annuity rates have plummeted, a conjunction that most actuaries expect to continue and which is dramatically lowering pension incomes from saving. In other words, every citizen has not only a right to expect a solid, easily understood, universal, protected-from-government-discretion, non-means-tested income in retirement ( the basic pension indexed to earnings growth ), but in future most pensioners will need it more rather than less. The argument will return again, but given the scale of the increases this year and next in the basic pension, not until after the next election.

As for the rest of the budget, it is full of small good things. SureStart has more cash. There are some innovative twists to employment policy, including more focus on coaching and mentoring the unemployed and a new agency to help them find and stay in work, two initiatives that the Industrial Society (I declare an interest as its chief executive) has been recommending. And there is a raft of useful interventions aimed at urban regeneration, notably exempting property from stamp duty in rundown areas and accepting the idea that there should be a tax credit for investment in depressed communities.

And yet. As you pick your way through the welter of well-intentioned initiatives and accompanying logos, you long for something that captures the imagination and is informed by an overarching idea of what the good society might be. 'Urban renewal' is a classic example. The new agency and coaching for the unemployed, the stamp duty exemption, the proposed tax credit - all are useful intermediate policy instruments. But they are not joined up in practice, nor informed by an inspirational vision. We need, as Richard Rogers and Anne Power argue in Cities For a Small Country, to revolutionise our entire conception of what urban life might mean. If we wanted, we could reinvent how we live in cities, how we associate, how we travel and how we work, a step-change in what urban life means, and which the budget's measures might serve. Instead, the measures seem micro and crabby, passing a sceptical Treasury official's test but not a citizen's. Equally, if you take some of the other great issues - the rise of corporate power or the need to reinvent the notion of public service - the Government has little to say.

But we should celebrate the good. What we are now witnessing economically is unique. Investment is the highest it has been for 30 years. Unemployment is set to drop below a million. Over 10 years - if the US does not go wrong - we could have the best run since before the First World War.

And as we brace ourselves for a probable Bush presidency featuring advisers such as Marvin Olasky, who wants mandatory welfare substituted by faith communities distributing voluntary charity, Britain does have a progressive government.

Gordon Brown declared five aims at the beginning of the pre-budget report which are worth repeating. By 2010, the government wants to have halved child poverty, enlisted a majority of children in higher education, achieved a faster rate of productivity growth than our competitors, got record numbers into employment and secured strong and dependable public services.

Given its fiscal strength, Labour just might achieve these five ambitions. The Chancellor could have done better, but it is still more than good enough.

'Urban renewal' is a classic example. The new agency and coaching for the unemployed, the stamp duty exemption, the proposed tax credit - all are useful intermediate policy instruments. But they are not joined up in practice, nor informed by an inspirational vision. We need, as Richard Rogers and Anne Power argue in Cities For a Small Country, to revolutionise our entire conception of what urban life might mean. If we wanted, we could reinvent how we live in cities, how we associate, how we travel and how we work, a step-change in what urban life means, and which the budget's measures might serve. Instead, the measures seem micro and crabby, passing a sceptical Treasury official's test but not a citizen's. Equally, if you take some of the other great issues - the rise of corporate power or the need to reinvent the notion of public service - the Government has little to say. But we should celebrate the good. What we are now witnessing economically is unique. Investment is the highest it has been for 30 years. Unemployment is set to drop below a million. Over 10 years - if the US does not go wrong - we could have the best run since before the First World War. And as we brace ourselves for a probable Bush presidency featuring advisers such as Marvin Olasky, who wants mandatory welfare substituted by faith communities distributing voluntary charity, Britain does have a progressive government. Gordon Brown declared five aims at the beginning of the pre-budget report which are worth repeating. By 2010, the government wants to have halved child poverty, enlisted a majority of children in higher education, achieved a faster rate of productivity growth than our competitors, got record numbers into employment and secured strong and dependable public services. Given its fiscal strength, Labour just might achieve these five ambitions. The Chancellor could have done better, but it is still more than good enough. webTitle: HSBC Capital Protected Isa

fields.headline: HSBC Capital Protected Isa
fields.trailText: Contact: 0800 299 299
fields.body:
Contact: 0800 299 299

Aim: To provide 75 per cent of the average change in both the FTSE 100 and Dow Jones Eurostoxx 50 indices over five years, while protecting all of the investor's original capital.

Closing date: 8 December.

Bells & whistles: The lowest average return for the two indices over any five-year period since December 1991, when the Dow Jones Eurostoxx 50 index was introduced, is 66.74 per cent, while the highest has been 211.43 per cent.

How it works: Investors' money is used to buy shares in a Dublin-listed investment company, HSBC International Equity Plus 8. This company uses complicated instruments called derivatives to protect investors' capital and provide the return. The change in performances of the two indices over five years will be added together and divided by two. This figure will be multiplied by 75 per cent to produce the amount paid out to investors. The start level of each index will be its closing level on 13 December. To guard against a sudden fall in the stock markets as the investment nears maturity in December 2005, HSBC will calculate the final levels by taking the average of the closing levels of each index over the last 12 months. Investors who withdraw money early may not get the full amount back.

Minimum: £3,000 to a maximum of £7,000.

Charges: Built in to the product.

Tax: Tax-free returns through HSBC's mini or maxi Isa.

Risk: Low

Should you buy it?: Ian Beestin of Nottingham based ISA Shop says: 'We think you should invest in something you can understand, and it's difficult to quantify the risk here. There's no opportunity to time your exit and 25 per cent of the return is a high price for capital protection. You would be better off with a cash Isa and a mini Isa tracking the FTSE All Share.' Donna Bradshaw of London-based Fiona Price & Partners agrees: 'This type of investment is popular with nervous investors dipping their toes in the equity market, but there are better ways to fulfil their need for security.'

Points out of 10: Beestin - 3, Bradshaw - 4.

webTitle: Parties vie for the black vote

fields.headline: Parties vie for the black vote
fields.standfirst:
Labour and Tories set up new units to target the 'buppies' - middle-class ethnic minorities

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: They are middle-class, comfortably off, independently minded and live neither in Brixton nor Bradford, but in Dorchester and Torquay. Welcome to a new political phenomenon: the black middle Englanders.
fields.body:
They are middle-class, comfortably off, independently minded and live neither in Brixton nor Bradford, but in Dorchester and Torquay. Welcome to a new political phenomenon: the black middle Englanders.

Research reveals that tens of thousands of black and Asian voters hold the balance of power in crucial seats across England and Wales. The three major political parties have now set up special units to target this increasingly powerful voting bloc at the next general election.

The findings, by the organisation Operation Black Vote, reveal that as many as 100 seats could be decided by ethnic minority voters. But far from being in areas thought of as predominantly black - such as the poorer parts of the inner cities - the seats include Torbay in Devon, the rolling hills of west Dorset and the country towns of Shrewsbury and Totnes.

Smart London residential areas, such as Putney and Harrow, are also on the list. Party officials now realise that whichever party woos black and Asian support most successfully will receive a huge boost at the polls. Labour and Conservative strategists have been struck by the strength of black voting patterns in America, where Al Gore received a huge majority of the African-American vote. Hillary Clinton personally thanked the black voters of New York for backing her.

Most of the British voters are professionals in medicine, the law or teaching. They have moved to rural locations because of work demands, setting new challenges for political parties which have been criticised for doing too little to reflect the multi-cultural make-up of Britain.

In the Eighties, when the growth of a new urban, black middle class was first recognised, they were termed 'buppies' (black, upwardly mobile) to go alongside the yuppies who were taking over the City. Now the buppies have moved to the countryside.

'It is a very different life to the one you might live in a big city,' said Dr John Oloo, a consultant anaesthetist who lives on the outskirts of Bournemouth. 'There are not the networks of people you would get in London, but there is less overt racism and people seem genuinely curious about where you are from, rather than the aggressive racism you get in cities.'

Oloo, who was born in Kenya, moved to London in the late Seventies before moving to Dorset in 1990. He set up the Dorset Africa and Friends Association, which regularly pulls in 250 people to meetings. 'We have an influence,' he said. 'We must use it. Yes, we are interested in racial issues, but we are also interested in standards in schools and the strength of the economy.'

Peter Green, who was born in Karachi, lives in Weymouth and teaches classics at the local college. 'I suppose we are part of the new Establishment,' he said. 'You can't get much more Establishment than teaching classics.'

Operation Black Vote discovered that, in 100 of the most marginal seats across England and Wales, black and Asian voters in effect held the balance of power.

In Torbay, the Liberal Democrats' majority is 12, while the ethnic minority voting population is more than 4,000. In Harrow, the Labour majority is 1,240, while the ethnic minority population is 20,000. In Dorset West, the Conservative majority is 1,840, half the ethnic minority population of 3,650. The picture is similar in St Albans, Norfolk South-West, Sittingbourne in Kent, Stafford and Weston-super-Mare.

Labour has now set up EQ, a body charged with connecting to the new, black middle England. Chaired by Barbara Follett and Sue Hollick, the wife of Labour peer Lord Hollick, it has been told to sell the message to black voters that Tony Blair is 'on their side'. The Prime Minister has been attacked for not doing enough to ensure that black and Asian candidates are placed in winnable seats. So far the party has selected one new Asian candidate, Parmjit Dhanda, who will fight the safe seat of Gloucester.

EQ has been told by senior Labour figures to start redressing the balance. In Britain nearly 30 per cent of black and Asian people are not on the electoral roll, compared with about 6 per cent of white people.

The Conservatives have set up the Cultural Unit to tackle the same problems. Earlier in the year it was revealed that a highly qualified barrister and former Conservative councillor, Mohammed Khamisa, had been turned down by every one of the 13 Tory constituencies to which he applied to stand as an MP. He wasn't given one interview.

webTitle: Robert Redford gets into his swing

fields.headline: Redford gets into his swing
fields.standfirst: His latest film, as director, features Hollywood's brightest young stars. The golfing fable also marks a return to form. Interview by John Anderson
fields.trailText: His latest film, as director, features Hollywood's brightest young stars. The golfing fable also marks a return to form.
fields.body:
Robert Redford enters the Manhattan hotel room smiling, blond, trim, casual, a bit craggy at 63 but pretty much as you expect. The legendary mystique is intact. His cultivated superstardom has made the actor-director-producer a kind of totem in the annals of Hollywood stereotyping. Redford, after all, always has been Redford - the way Gable was Gable, Cooper was Cooper, William Powell was William Powell.

Redford is his own man, and his own model, too - and he does not deviate from it much. Younger stars push the envelope: Tom Cruise has done Magnolia and Eyes Wide Shut, Brad Pitt 12 Monkeys and even Matt Damon - seemingly the most Redfordian of them all - was in The Talented Mr. Ripley, although his sexually ambivalent homicidal maniac was the most sympathetic sociopath you had ever seen.

Damon, not coincidentally, is the star of The Legend of Bagger Vance (pictured), Redford's sixth film as a director - the area of Redford's career where he has stretched himself. In the Oscar-winning Ordinary People (1980) or the much-honoured Quiz Show ( 1994) or even his last, The Horse Whisperer (1998), Redford exhibits more daring than he ever did in his choice of movie roles, although nobility, or a grasping for nobility, is afoot in all his work.

In Bagger Vance, a Jazz Age golden boy (Damon), a golfing sensation, goes off to the First World War, has his ideals shot out from under him and returns a broken man. With the aid of a mysterious caddie named Bagger (Will Smith), he strives to regain his swing, his soul and his girl (Charlize Theron).

Redford did fly fishing in A River Runs Through It ( 1992). Maybe a movie about golf is not so strange. And maybe golf isn't the attraction at all. 'No, that would not interest me,' he says. 'First of all, it's everywhere. It's ubiquitous. You turn on the Golf Channel. Airlines. It's everywhere.'

Some would suggest that's just the reason to do it. 'Yeah, but it wouldn't be mine,' he says. 'But golf as a metaphor for life does interest me.'

Bagger Vance is based on a novel by Steven Pressfield (screenplay by Jeremy Leven) and what Redford found in it was the way to create a story in a classic form: the hero's fall into darkness and his struggle to return to the light. Pressfield, Redford says, borrowed heavily from the Bhagavad-Gita and other Eastern sources, as well as Western mythology 'and the part that interested me was the part that related to the character's battle with himself, the idea of focus, concentration, centre, what we now hear of as "the zone" - the way an athlete gets into the zone.

'I was intrigued by that. And I saw that the book was full of wonderful raw material. That's how I saw it. I don't know that I would ever be so interested in doing a book verbatim. I'd have to make it my own somehow.'

He also needed a break after the gravity of The Horse Whisperer . 'I was looking for something uplifting, as much for myself as anything else. Because that was a heavy trip. Even though it had some positive aspects to it, it was about healing, it involved damaged animals, children, and was a hard, heavy movie to make.

'So I thought next time, I'd like to do something quirky. Entertaining but quirky... And also, the whole atmosphere up there at the festival, I could see things were getting darker and darker, more and more cynical. I thought, maybe it's not a bad idea to do something kind of uplifting.'

The festival, of course, is Sundance, with which Redford has been involved since the mid-Eighties, when his Sundance Institute (he was, after all, the Sundance Kid) took over the existing US Film Festival. His presence there has been erratic, almost shadowy; in an effort not to eclipse the filmmakers, he has become its resident phantom.

'It would be nice, just for my ego, for people to know how hard I work on it,' Redford says. 'I spend a lot of time on it, preparing for it every year, and we always have a post-mortem afterwards, taking a hard look at what went wrong, or what could have been better. Refining it.

'And, of course, starting it was not an easy thing,' he adds. 'For three years, nobody was even interested. For those years, I would literally stand out on the corner and collar people to get them into theatres. I remember going to David Puttnam when he was at Columbia and saying, "I want you to come see The Big Easy". I just liked [director] Jim McBride's early work and I knew McBride had had a really rough go, hadn't made a film in a few years. So I dragged Puttnam in there, literally forced him into the theatre.'

Puttnam bought the movie. 'And that was the first big buy at the festival,' he says. And almost immediately, Redford started taking a backseat 'because I thought, "If it's going to go it'll go on its own". And when it did I was really thrilled. I thought, "This is great. I can just go watch the movies". 'It's a great chance for me to watch movies, meet the filmmakers. That's the biggest joy for me.'

Redford is himself, of course, an independent filmmaker, one with carefully wrought ideas and a genuine cinematic palette: The opening sequence in Horse Whisperer, for example, is an elegiac daydream of half-tones and impressionism; Quiz Show recreates its era of early TV with effortless grace.

In Bagger Vance, the mood and tones change as fast and furiously as the story elements, which set up the film with a kind of ragtime staccato that suggests The Sting.

'I didn't think The Sting,' but you're right,' Redford says. 'I wanted to do it like an old Thirties movie, high-energy, fast-paced, full of life, very Chekhovian, the rug being pulled out constantly from people. "Oh, we're going this way? No, we're goin' that way..." That's fun for me and I wanted to do something with more humour.

'So I thought, "I have a hell of a deal here. I have to set up Bagger Vance, set up the narrator looking back on himself as a boy, the townsfolk, the conditions under which the hero falls into darkness, the First World War - can't spend much time there 'cause it's not about the war, but you have to have it." I thought, "How am I going to do it?" And I thought the only way was to compress it and have it almost like a title sequence, like a preface, where you say to the audience, we're not going to stop anywhere very long.'

The war sequence? 'Well, with [cinematographer] Michael Ballhaus, I shot in 8mm, step-frame, 16mm, 35mm, slow-mo. I threw everything in there to create an impressionistic feel for that war in one minute, which is all it lasts in the film.'

He also had to set up the characters of Bobby Jones (Joel Gretsch) and Walter Hagen (Bruce McGill), two of the greatest golfers of their age and polar opposites in temperament - Jones the Righteous, Hagen the Moral Reprobate, both of whom are pressganged into playing a benefit match for the Depression-besieged golf resort owned by Adele Invergordon (Theron). Under pressure from the town fathers, Adele also has to include a local entry in her tournament, Rannulph Junuh, Damon's tarnished golden boy, Adele's ex and a golfer who, according to Bagger, has lost his 'authentic swing'.

'What really got me, when I heard the story being told, was the phrase "the authentic swing",' Redford says. 'Somehow, it's this quirky thing, how you approach a piece of work: sometimes it's just a word, a phrase; sometimes it's the turning of a corner.'

Bagger Vance, Redford says, was a chance to get even more into visual storytelling, using single images that would carry a lot of story, like the comic strips he followed when he was a kid, growing up in Santa Monica, the son of a milkman. 'That was one of the few entertainments I had,' Redford says. 'Well, I had radio. But we were a pretty working, lower-class family where there wasn't a lot. We were in a Mexican neighbourhood. It was fairly grim. There were no class distinctions, because we were united by the war effort. These weren't happy times; nobody had much. The library's where I got into this mythology. But how the people came together was radio, or the funny papers. Sunday was a huge deal. You'd go racing for the funnies. Without knowing it, I was very connected to them.'

Redford has directed a few films, starred in scores more. But if you had to guess it would be directing that has his heart.

'Originally,' he says, 'when I first got involved in Bagger Vance I thought of it as something I would be in. But quickly I decided against that because when I started to read the book it had too many parallels to The Natural . I've sort of been there. And I was more interested in a younger cast because it might be more affecting to have this happen to a very young person. It reminded me of A.E. Housman's poem 'A Shropshire Lad', an ode to an athlete who dies young. I remembered being moved by the fact that this guy goes out in a moment of glory, and maybe that was the best time to go out, 'cause after that it's all downhill...'

Redford, the director

ORDINARY PEOPLE (1980)
Redford's directorial debut, a sombre drama about a grief-stricken family, won him an Oscar. It also marked him out as a major player behind the camera following a decade as one of Hollywood's biggest box-office draws.

A RIVER RUNS THROUGH IT (1992)
Brad Pitt looked suspiciously like the young Redford in this tale of fraternal friendship and fly fishing set in picturesque Montana. Pitt played the small-town rebel destined for a tragic end.

QUIZ SHOW (1994)
An intelligent morality tale based on the infamous Fifties' US television quiz scandals. Ralph Fiennes played the handsome patrician who cheated his way to fame and fortune before falling from grace.

THE HORSE WHISPERER (1998)
An epic melodrama based on Nicholas Evans's bestseller. Redford starred as the laconic cowboy with healing hands who is hired to help a horse and its traumatised teenage owner.

Bagger Vance, Redford says, was a chance to get even more into visual storytelling, using single images that would carry a lot of story, like the comic strips he followed when he was a kid, growing up in Santa Monica, the son of a milkman. 'That was one of the few entertainments I had,' Redford says. 'Well, I had radio. But we were a pretty working, lower-class family where there wasn't a lot. We were in a Mexican neighbourhood. It was fairly grim. There were no class distinctions, because we were united by the war effort. These weren't happy times; nobody had much. The library's where I got into this mythology. But how the people came together was radio, or the funny papers. Sunday was a huge deal. You'd go racing for the funnies. Without knowing it, I was very connected to them.' Redford has directed a few films, starred in scores more. But if you had to guess it would be directing that has his heart. 'Originally,' he says, 'when I first got involved in Bagger Vance I thought of it as something I would be in. But quickly I decided against that because when I started to read the book it had too many parallels to The Natural . I've sort of been there. And I was more interested in a younger cast because it might be more affecting to have this happen to a very young person. It reminded me of A.E. Housman's poem 'A Shropshire Lad', an ode to an athlete who dies young. A RIVER RUNS THROUGH IT (1992) Brad Pitt looked suspiciously like the young Redford in this tale of fraternal friendship and fly fishing set in picturesque Montana. Pitt played the small-town rebel destined for a tragic end. QUIZ SHOW (1994) An intelligent morality tale based on the infamous Fifties' US television quiz scandals. Ralph Fiennes played the handsome patrician who cheated his way to fame and fortune before falling from grace. THE HORSE WHISPERER (1998) An epic melodrama based on Nicholas Evans's bestseller. Redford starred as the laconic cowboy with healing hands who is hired to help a horse and its traumatised teenage owner.

webTitle: Rob Brydon

fields.headline: Rob Brydon
fields.standfirst: Lock Stock's 'unlucky traffic warden' who has become a cult hero
fields.trailText: Rob Brydon, Lock Stock's 'unlucky traffic warden' who has become a cult hero
fields.body:
Regular Tuesday night viewers of BBC2 may well have been captivated by a peculiar but compelling programme shortly before nine o'clock. Marion and Geoff is a 10 by 10-minute series featuring a Welsh cab driver who addresses his thoughts into a small camera on his dashboard. Not the latest in a long line of reality programmes, this is fine tragicomedy tucked into BBC2 primetime.

The man who plays Keith Barratt is not a familiar face. His sorrowful brown eyes and lugubrious features will haunt you, though, as will the details of his terrible life. Recently separated from wife Marion, who ran away with pharmaceutical salesman of the year Geoff, Keith pines for his two dysfunctional children, Rhys and Alun, while adjusting to life in a student house. Ferociously optimistic despite everything, he shares his medical, legal and emotional secrets with us.

Dreamt up and played by Rob Brydon, Keith is a work of comic genius who is as likely to have you in tears of sorrow as of laughter. Fans will be delighted to know there is now a chance to see more of Brydon's work in a new BBC2 six-part 'mocumentary' series Human Remains.

You may not have seen Brydon before, unless you remember the unfortunate traffic warden in Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels. Inadvertently kidnapped by the likely lads, his character was beaten up when they realised his occupation.

The 35-year-old Welshman, a graduate of the Welsh College of Music and Drama, had been making a living from presenting, voiceovers and small parts in TV dramas and sitcoms. His performance in Lock Stock was noted by Empire magazine, which described him as 'an extremely unlucky traffic warden'. Using this tag, he put together character-based comedy films that attracted the BBC's attention.

Collaboration with Steve Coogan's production company Baby Cow followed and Marion and Geoff was born. Winning huge critical praise and cult status, it is being overlapped by Human Remains which is co-written and performed by Julia Davis, veteran of Big Train, Jam and People Like Us. In it Brydon and Davis each assume six very different characters who are married to each other. Thus we have a dysfunctional upper class couple, a pair of swingers who run a bed and breakfast in the Black Country, religious zealots who never find the vicar at home and more besides.

While happy with his current success, he is not yet planning his next move. 'It's just been so busy this year filming one thing after another. I need a rest till at least the New Year but I definitely want to work with Julia again. It beats saying: 'And in store next week we have...'

 Human Remains starts on Monday, BBC2

Five things you should know about Rob Brydon

1 His first break after drama school was presenting the early morning radio show on BBC Radio Wales.

2 One of his earliest comic creations was a character called Tony Casino, a failed Welsh club singer who thought he was Tom Jones.

3 He is married with three children and lives in London.

4 He co-starred with Gwen Taylor in the first series of a sitcom called Barbara.

5 For each 10 minutes of Marion and Geoff that were shown, four hours of film were shot.

webTitle: It's Bond meets Barbie

fields.headline: It's Bond meets Barbie
fields.standfirst: America has fallen for the post-feminist Angels. They're tough, but they've all got great hair, writes  Melinda Wittstock
fields.trailText: Charlie's Angels have come a long way, baby!
fields.body:
Charlie's Angels have come a long way, baby!

No longer the 'three little girls who went to the police academy' of the Seventies television series, these 21st-century gumshoe Barbies kick serious butt. They've upgraded their firepower, mastered the most acrobatic of martial arts, speak Japanese, operate cutting-edge computer technology, drive racing cars, sky-dive and ride helicopter-launched missiles.

But don't despair - the new girls can still work that slow-motion hair toss and sparkling, toothy grin. What's more their butts are tighter and harder and the camera takes full advantage.

America is loving it and millions are flocking to see Cameron Diaz, Drew Barrymore and Lucy Liu flaunt their post-feminist, kitsch machismo. What better diversion from the all-American presidential election fiasco - these chicks could sort out George W. Bush, Al Gore and their teams of lawyers with their hands tied behind their backs. All those teenagers and twentysomethings who didn't vote on Tuesday were probably sitting in cinemas watching the three Angels focus minds with a few stiletto-heeled high kicks instead.

Charlie's Angels boasted a phenomenal first weekend at the box office, with a gross of $40.1 million. Sony launched its kick-butt Barbie flick in 3,037 cinemas nationwide - with an average return of some $13,213 per venue. After last November's Toy Story 2, it's the second best non-summer movie opening in American box-office history. But that's not all - the film has been boasting a $2.96m daily gross, even through the stranger-than-fiction ballot box turmoil.

'It's great, I loved it,' says Hannah Misol, a 23-year-old radio news producer. 'It's tongue-in-cheek - lots of cheeks - and very clever. It pokes fun at all the established cultural icons; sure, you have to check your brains at the door, but who says every movie has to be intellectual. This is just great, mindless entertainment.'

All the reviewers here seem to agree. 'This is schlock fun,' says the august Washington Post . 'It treads that fine line between clever parody and over-the-top exaggeration. Les gals are dynamic. They know the tongue-in-cheek rules of the game: look hot for the men (and sharp for the women) but use that "babular" exterior shell as a decoy for private investigation.'

Or this from Variety: 'It will be the rare viewer, male and female, who won't enjoy the sheer visual and visceral pleasure of watching Cameron Diaz, Drew Barrymore and Lucy Liu strut, slink, kick, dance and vamp their way through this splashy femme empowerment fantasy... the sassy chickpic appeal of this rambunctious, high-octane, latex-thin contempo take on one of the Seventies' most popular television series.'

Today's leather and gold lamé bikini-clad Angels make Farrah Fawcett, Kate Jackson and Jaclyn Smith look like disco-age Nancy Drews; the new breed are surefire James Bondettes, and like 007, they don't take themselves too seriously - even as they stop at nothing to get the bad guys.

Self-parodied feminine wiles somehow jiggle nicely with all those impossibly daring action sequences and Matrix -like kung fu manoeuvres, choreographed by Cheung-Yan Yuen, fight arranger on countless Hong Kong martial arts flicks. Directed by Joseph McGinty Nichol, a Hollywood newcomer known up till now for his dancing Gap ads and music videos, and written by too many people to credit (17 all told), the only thing you really need to know is that the babes regularly best the bad guys - and when they're not fighting the evil gun-toting, sword-wielding bad guys, they're focusing on their respective love interests.

The men, truth be told, provide the same decorative function as their female counterparts in traditional action-man flicks. Variety says: 'Gorgeous, sexy and fun [the Angels] can do just about anything but find men who are anywhere near their level'.

Toby Miller, Professor of Media and Cultural Studies at New York University, says: 'The genius of this movie is that it plays to both sides of the gender divide. The women I've spoken to love the sexiness. They are much more comfortable about using it, exploiting it to their own ends while parodying it at the same time. And it wouldn't work without having autonomy and power.'

Miller has been studying the Angels' phenomenon for the British Film Institute, for which he is writing the action-adventure segment of next year's BFI Handbook. He says: 'Everyone thought the original TV series was a "jiggle" programme, and it was scorned by feminists who thought it was stereotypical, exploitative. But Farrah, Jaclyn and Kate were strong, independent women, and the celluloid version is a 25-year update of the same thing.

'This time around, they can do stunts like the best of them [but] they still have to look hot. What was also appealing about the TV series is still in play now: there is a real bond between the women, it's almost like a Thelma and Louise girl-buddy flick in this way: what matters is their solidarity.'

In real life, the three actresses live up to the buddy image, hanging all over each other, playing with each other's hair and talking in unison, as they travel around the country, relentlessly plugging the movie. They are adamant that's how they behaved on the movie's mega-long and physically demanding shoot, too - despite the Hollywood gossip about angry flare-ups and bitchiness.

The three stars also have a lot more power in real life than the stars of the TV series. Farrah, Kate and Jaclyn were unknowns when the show premiered in September 1976. Cameron Diaz is a Hollywood power in her own right, after the success of There's Something About Mary and Being John Malkovich; Lucy Liu has made her name in the groundbreaking David E. Kelley series Ally McBeal; and Barrymore, who was only 18 months old when the world met the original Angels, is the co-producer of the movie

'I like jiggle! I do,' insisted Barrymore in an interview for E! Online. 'I'm not a torch-carrying feminist, but I love women... I think what's great is if you can have intelligence and capability as your foundation and be fun and sexy on top of it.'

That she also happens to be a movie mogul adds a new spin to the more than suggestive spread Barrymore has posed for in Rolling Stone magazine. There she is, pretty much naked, pouring milk down her back.

'She seems to be saying, 'I see no reason to hide my sexuality, my body - I want to celebrate it,' says Miller. 'And all the women I know, even those who thought such a spectacle was tragic in the Seventies, love it. It's a nudge-nudge, wink-wink parody.'

Co-producer Leonard Goldberg, who produced the TV series with Aaron Spelling of Dynasty and Beverly Hills 90210 fame, claims the original programmes were the 'beginning of the empowerment of women within popular culture'.

Some may disagree, but there's no disputing the fact that Charlie's Angels, the movie, has captured the Zeitgeist: today's America is intoxicated with female machismo - witness the following of Buffy the Vampire Slayer, Dark Angel and Xena: Warrior Princess .

Sony, which owns the worldwide rights to the Charlie's Angels franchise, says the film will hit the big screens in Britain this month.

webTitle: @ business: Make or break time for e-tailers

fields.headline: A not so festive gamble
fields.standfirst: It's make or break time for e-tailers, says  Jamie Doward
fields.trailText: Everyone knows buying Christmas presents is expensive. E-tailers are discovering how costly it is to sell them.
fields.body:
Everyone knows buying Christmas presents is expensive. E-tailers are discovering how costly it is to sell them.

'We were going to be in FHM with a double-page spread but it would have cost us £20,000. So instead we're going to work with the customers we've already got,' said Tom Hartley, marketing director with 9Feet.com, the outdoor wear e-tailer.

It is a familiar lament up and down e-tail land. In the run-up to Christmas, scores of e-tailers are having to confront an ugly dilemma. With money running out and little enthusiasm from banks or venture capitalists to give them more, e-tailers are having to choose between a big, expensive marketing push, a final blitzkrieg designed to suck in large volumes of consumers, or a low-key affair that will at least ensure they have cash in the bank for next year.

Hartley's company is selling around 100 items a day at an average price of £50-£70. In the run-up to Christmas, the company, which has halved its staff, is looking to double its sales.

If it doesn't pull this off, 9Feet, like many other e-tailers, faces huge problems. 'If we have a reasonable Christmas and can satisfy enough consumers, we'll be around this time next year,' Hartley said. 'We've got enough cash to last a few more months.'

'Christmas will be make or break time for many online businesses,' said Murray Hennessy, chief executive officer of Buy.com Europe, the e-tailer that specialises in selling computer equipment. The cake is huge. The Gartner Group is predicting that global online shopping in the run-up to Christmas will total nearly $20 billion this year. Considering the group is predicting that online e-tail sales will total $29bn for the whole of this year, the need to make a success of the Christmas period is paramount.

Having seen a number of high-profile failures such as Boo and Boxman, many e-tailers are now following 9Feet's example and cutting back, on both staff and marketing, in an attempt to hit the profitability mark sooner. But this approach also brings problems.

'We've heard time and again how dotcoms are reducing costs in order to become profitable. But what we've learned is that, rather than help the company, cost-cutting reduces sales growth so drastically that profitability becomes nearly impossible,' said Brian Mittman, vice-president of Getzler & Co, a New York-based turnaround firm.

Getzler's firm compared the performances of dotcom firms which pared back their spending with those that continued with their original strategies. The growth rate for those that cut costs was 19 per cent year on year. But those that continued to spend enjoyed a growth rate of nearly 150 per cent.

The rewards for the e-tailers that make the right call are huge as more and more people gain the confidence to shop online. According to research firm eStats, 14 per cent of internet users bought something online in 1998. Two years on and this figure has risen to 45 per cent.

To put this into a UK context, the number of people visiting internet retail sites in the UK has increased by 72 per cent since the start of this year, according to MMXI Europe. The number of unique visitors to retail sites has increased from around 2.4 million in January to nearly 4.5 million in September.

But this explosion in the number of customers has brought new problems. The simple fact is that more e-tailers are now competing for custom. A report by research firm Jupiter suggested that there are now a staggering 1.4 million websites dedicated to e-commerce in the UK alone.

The result: squeezed margins or faster burn rates as e-tailers look to spend their way out of trouble.

Unfortunately the e-tailers don't have the deep pockets of their 'clicks and mortar' counterparts - those high street firms that have an online presence - and are suffering as a result.

The e-tailers now find themselves having to cut their prices faster than the established re-tailers just to stay in the game.

The Goldfish e-tail price index, issued last week, showed that pure e-tailers cut their prices by 2 per cent in September. In contrast the clicks and mortar firms reduced prices by 1.4 per cent over the same period. This means that the pure dotcom firms are now undercutting their established rivals by 4 per cent on average.

Of course, this model works only if the e-tailers can sell in such huge volumes that they can afford to cut their prices. And it is clear that many online firms are now finding the move to get big fast - like Amazon - impossible. Some, like online cosmetics firm ClickMango, simply disappear; others sell themselves for a song to a high street firm looking for a bit of dotcom kudos. Electrical e-tailer Jungle went to GUS and online music firm AudioStreet is now majority- owned by Woolworths.

'The market has shaken out a lot this year. The number of independent companies has greatly reduced. They've found out that you need big volumes and a big product range,' said David Windsor-Clive, a director of Boxman.com, the pan-European music e-tailer which ceased trading last month.

But, in addition, it is vital that the e-tailers sort out their fulfilment systems - the boring old backroom stuff that ensures you can order easily and that what you order gets to you on time.

During the previous two Christmases the sector was heavily criticised for failing to deliver on its promises. It cannot afford to get it wrong this time.

'After two online holiday-buying seasons of lost orders, late deliveries and broken promises, consumers have little patience for late or lost orders and poor customer service,' said Geri Spieler, research director for Gartner's e-Business Services.

But the sector is still failing to address this issue. A global study released last week by AT Kearney, the management consultancy, found that an astonishing 80 per cent of online purchases abort because consumers are bombarded with too many requests for information, are scared to enter credit card de-tails, or encounter problems with the website.

The consultancy estimates that firms are missing out on an extra $6.1bn in sales as a result.

In addition, the smaller e-tailers are having difficulties scaling up their businesses in response to increased demand before Christmas. 'A lot of dotcoms will run into problems with fulfilment. They're trying to meet demand but the end result is horror stories such as the MD driving the forklift or bringing in his family to package the products,' Hennessy said.

The irony is that, despite these problems, online customers can be far more attractive to retailers than those who shop in the high street. 'Once you've taken the time to give details such as your address and your credit card numbers you will come back - if the company fulfils your order. Online shoppers are far more loyal than offline,' said Joe Dickinson, a partner at AT Kearney. But only a few dotcom retailers are going to benefit from this loyalty. Many e-tailers are just for Christmas, not for life.

According to research firm eStats, 14 per cent of internet users bought something online in 1998. Two years on and this figure has risen to 45 per cent. To put this into a UK context, the number of people visiting internet retail sites in the UK has increased by 72 per cent since the start of this year, according to MMXI Europe. The number of unique visitors to retail sites has increased from around 2.4 million in January to nearly 4.5 million in September. But this explosion in the number of customers has brought new problems. The simple fact is that more e-tailers are now competing for custom. A report by research firm Jupiter suggested that there are now a staggering 1.4 million websites dedicated to e-commerce in the UK alone. The result: squeezed margins or faster burn rates as e-tailers look to spend their way out of trouble. Unfortunately the e-tailers don't have the deep pockets of their 'clicks and mortar' counterparts - those high street firms that have an online presence - and are suffering as a result. The e-tailers now find themselves having to cut their prices faster than the established re-tailers just to stay in the game. The Goldfish e-tail price index, issued last week, showed that pure e-tailers cut their prices by 2 per cent in September. In contrast the clicks and mortar firms reduced prices by 1.4 per cent over the same period. This means that the pure dotcom firms are now undercutting their established rivals by 4 per cent on average. Of course, this model works only if the e-tailers can sell in such huge volumes that they can afford to cut their prices. And it is clear that many online firms are now finding the move to get big fast - like Amazon - impossible. Some, like online cosmetics firm ClickMango, simply disappear; others sell themselves for a song to a high street firm looking for a bit of dotcom kudos. Electrical e-tailer Jungle went to GUS and online music firm AudioStreet is now majority- owned by Woolworths. 'The market has shaken out a lot this year. The number of independent companies has greatly reduced. They've found out that you need big volumes and a big product range,' said David Windsor-Clive, a director of Boxman.com, the pan-European music e-tailer which ceased trading last month. But, in addition, it is vital that the e-tailers sort out their fulfilment systems - the boring old backroom stuff that ensures you can order easily and that what you order gets to you on time. During the previous two Christmases the sector was heavily criticised for failing to deliver on its promises. It cannot afford to get it wrong this time. 'After two online holiday-buying seasons of lost orders, late deliveries and broken promises, consumers have little patience for late or lost orders and poor customer service,' said Geri Spieler, research director for Gartner's e-Business Services. But the sector is still failing to address this issue. A global study released last week by AT Kearney, the management consultancy, found that an astonishing 80 per cent of online purchases abort because consumers are bombarded with too many requests for information, are scared to enter credit card de-tails, or encounter problems with the website. The consultancy estimates that firms are missing out on an extra $6.1bn in sales as a result. In addition, the smaller e-tailers are having difficulties scaling up their businesses in response to increased demand before Christmas. 'A lot of dotcoms will run into problems with fulfilment. They're trying to meet demand but the end result is horror stories such as the MD driving the forklift or bringing in his family to package the products,' Hennessy said. The irony is that, despite these problems, online customers can be far more attractive to retailers than those who shop in the high street. 'Once you've taken the time to give details such as your address and your credit card numbers you will come back - if the company fulfils your order. Online shoppers are far more loyal than offline,' said Joe Dickinson, a partner at AT Kearney. But only a few dotcom retailers are going to benefit from this loyalty. Many e-tailers are just for Christmas, not for life.

webTitle: Food and drink special: beer

fields.headline: Lager than life
fields.standfirst: With bottles of beer now available from all over the world, we're spoilt for choice. Roger Protz opts for anything but the usual
fields.trailText: With bottles of beer now available from all over the world, we're spoilt for choice. Roger Protz opts for anything but the usual
fields.body:
Any day now, China will overtake America as the world's biggest producer of beer. Both countries have had a turbulent brewing history: Prohibition stopped beer making in its tracks for more than a decade in the US, while war, revolution and state control closed many Chinese breweries and drove out the gweilos or foreigners who had built and run most of them.

Now the gweilos are back and the likes of Anheuser-Busch - the brewer of American Budweiser - Beck's, Carlsberg, Foster's, Guinness, Heineken, Holsten, Miller, San Miguel, South African Breweries, Tennents from Scotland, and the Japanese giants Asahi, Kirin and Suntory are either building breweries or running existing ones in partnership with the locals. Rising living standards are leading to greater consumption and soon the 1,300 breweries in the US will pale into insignificance as China surges into the lead.

Chinese breweries are so busy feeding the internal market that few of their products are exported. The only regular beer to appear in Britain is China's oldest and biggest brand, Tsingtao. The pale lager (4.2 per cent) was first brewed by Germans in 1903 in the town of the same name in Shantung province. The Tsingtao brewing company has around 20 plants throughout the country and has enjoyed considerable investment from Anheuser-Busch. Its main product has a malty aroma and more character than most beers in the Far East.

Guinness is popular in China, where the colour black signifies quality. The Anglo-Irish giant brews a version of its ubiquitous Foreign Extra Stout there. For the Irish in Britain, along with other lovers of the 'dry Irish' style, ethnic beer shops often sell the African, Caribbean and Belgian versions of Foreign Extra Stout. All foreign versions of FES, as it's known, are based on the bottled Dublin original - a palpable link with porter and stout brewing in the late-18th century, when dark beers were a blend of young and mature or 'stale' brews.

On sale in Britain, FES is highly complex at 7.5 per cent, with roasted barley giving colour and character to a beer that has a toasted, winey and woody aroma, a full bittersweet palate with great hop character, and a finish that becomes dry and hoppy with hints of bitter chocolate, licorice and sour fruit. Guinness is brewed under licence in the West Indies, where stouts are popular not only for their taste but also for their alleged ability to enhance sexual performance. Dragon Stout, brewed by Desnoes & Geddes in Jamaica, promises 'to put it back', though at 7 per cent it's more likely to send drinkers to sleep. This sweetish, full-flavoured beer with a heavy, yellowish head, is available in Britain, as is the quenching Carib lager (5.2 per cent) from Trinidad. The biggest-selling beer from the region, Red Stripe from Jamaica, is brewed under licence here by Charles Wells of Bedford and doesn't count as a true ethnic beer. The same problem confronts India's two leading beers, Kingfisher and Cobra. Kingfisher has been brewed for years by Kent brewer Shepherd Neame. Cobra was imported until recently, but is now brewed here by the energetic Charles Wells.

On the American mainland, Mexico is a brewing giant, best known in Britain for Corona and Sol lagers. The 4.6 per cent beers are often derided as 'cheapies', but this overlooks the fact that they are made with large amounts of rice as well as barley to cut costs and bring them within the reach of poor peasants. American tourists turned the beers into fad drinks sold at exorbitant prices. Both breweries produce dark lagers, Negro Modelo (5.3 per cent) and Dos Equis (4.8 per cent).

France and Italy have both seen a rebirth of brewing. In France, the revival is due to the determination of people in the Flanders region to emphasise their traditions. The beer style known as bière de garde - 'keeping beer' - has enjoyed spectacular growth in recently, as any visitor to the bars of Lille can testify.

The best-known brewer of bière de garde is Jenlain in a village of the same name, south of Valenciennes. In common with many brewers in the region, the brewery, run by the Duyck family, started life on a farm and produced strong ales for the family and farm labourers. It is represented in Britain by Jenlain Blonde (6 per cent) which bursts with rich malt and perfumy hop character.

In Italy, beer drinking has been fuelled by a young generation anxious to distance itself from the wine-drinking habits of its parents. You will find not only British beers on sale in Italy, but English-style pubs as well. The mainstream lagers of Italy's biggest producers, Moretti and Peroni, are available in Britain and are pleasant if undemanding beers. Look out for Peroni's Gran Riserva (6.6 per cent), based on the strong Bavarian style known as Bock. Launched to mark 150 years of brewing, this flagship brand has a malty/nutty aroma with a good dash of Saaz hops in the rich, warming finish.

 Most of the beers mentioned are available from The Beer Shop, 14 Pitfield Street, London N1 (020 7739 3701). Sol and Moretti are on sale at Oddbins. Peroni and Guinness FES are available from Tescos. Charles Wells can be contacted on 01234 272 766

webTitle: Food and drink special: wine

fields.headline: National service
fields.standfirst: With a head-spinning range of wines on offer, there's something to be said for one-country specialists
fields.trailText: With a head-spinning range of wines on offer, there's something to be said for one-country specialists.
fields.body:
Ours is a world which finds it hard to respect boundaries, where supermarkets sell pension plans, football clubs have their own credit cards and the Pope has a website (no doubt with a link to www.supremebeing.com). What price specialism in such an age? Most wine merchants are generalists these days, with lists that run the gamut from Australia to Uruguay (they draw the line, quite sensibly, at Yugoslavia and Zimbabwe). But there are a few companies out there who dare to be 'ethnic', who import all or most of their wines from a single country. These are my favourites.

Australian Wine Club (020 8538 0718)

An operation which promises 'a better class of insult', the customer-friendly AWC is the mail-order offspring of the original Australian Wine Centre beneath the Strand. Craig Smith, brilliantly assisted by office cat and human resources director Mr F Luff, imports wine from some of the best operations Down Under, including Torbreck, St Hallett, Chapel Hill, Tim Adams and Primo Estate. Smith, the self-styled founder of the 'Australian Pinot Noir: Why do they bother? Society' is mad about Rhne varieties, which makes this the place to come for a glass of Shiraz, Grenache or Mourvèdre. And the odd insult, of course.

1997 The Willows Vineyard Shiraz, Barossa Valley (£9.99).
A dark, plummy, spicy, tobaccoey red with silky tannins and considerable elegance for a wine with 14.5 per cent alcohol. This wine will age for at least a decade.

Fine Wines of New Zealand (020 7482 0093)

Master of Wine Margaret Harvey was working as a hospital pharmacist when she decided to set up Fine Wines of New Zealand in 1985. Originally from Auckland, she reckoned New Zealand had 'the potential to make people sit up and think', long before anyone had heard of Cloudy Bay. She still goes home once a year to source new wines and 'keep abreast of what's hot'. The result is a small, but extremely well-chosen list from some of the country's best estates, including brilliant wines from Ata Rangi, Te Motu, Rippon, Stonyridge and Kumeu River. The most interesting Kiwi wine list in the country.

1998 Ata Rangi Célèbre, Martinborough (£14).
An intense, blackberry and cassis-like blend of Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot and Syrah from the stunning 1998 vintage. This is a wine that has real class, balance and length.

Moreno Wines (020 7286 0678)

Moreno Wines was originally set up by two refugees from the Spanish Civil War. Today, the company is run by their son, Manuel, who started life as a sociology lecturer before deciding that he preferred Rioja to Max Weber. A self-confessed 'regionalist eccentric', Moreno has assembled a brilliant Spanish (and South American) list with particular strengths in out-of-the-way areas and fine wines, especially in Rioja, Priorato and Ribera del Duero. A favourite with hispanophiles, Moreno Wines runs its own popular wine club, with tastings- cum-fiestas on a regular basis. The ideal place to order something to go with your tapas or leg of lamb.

1998 Guelbenzu Navarra (£6.99).
New wave Navarra at its best, this is a blend of Tempranillo, Cabernet Sauvignon and Merlot, showing sweet oak and notes of raspberry, mulberry and nutmeg spice.

The South African Wine Centre (020 7903 8311)

Run by ex-pat South African Michael Shevelu, who is 'sole buyer and writes every page in the list', the South African Wine Centre has assembled the best selection of Cape wines this side of Earls Court. Shevelu describes the SAWC as a 'one-stop shop for all the best private winery and estate wines, with no identikit, mass-produced products', and it's hard to disagree with him. If you want to drink something from traditional wineries like Meerlust or Kanonkop, or from modernists such as Thelema, Grangehurst or Mulderbosch, this is the place to come.

1998 Clos Malverne, Pinotage Basket Pressed (£7.49).
From a winery with a reputation for producing stylish, modern Pinotages, this is a sweet, sensuous wine with flavours of liquorice, vanilla and summer pudding.

The Vine Trail (0117 9211770)

Nick Brooks was a reluctant chartered accountant who always wanted to follow his father into the wine trade. In 1989, he decided to take a 'massive, massive gamble' and swap his calculator for a spittoon. Importing only French wines, he has created one of the most idiosyncratic lists in the UK, with super bottles from every corner of that wonderful country. Brooks buys all his wines from estates, with not a co-op or négociant to be seen. His policy is that 'if I can't work with someone who puts his heart and soul into every wine, then I'm not interested'. I'm not sure what Mr Brooks was like as an accountant, but he's an exemplary wine merchant.

1998 Domaine du Trapadis Rasteau, Ctes du Rhne Villages (£8).
A classic, Grenache-based southern Rhne red from a great vintage, redolent of Mediterranean herbs, sunshine and ripe fruit. A hand-crafted beauty.

Vino Vino (07703 436 949)

I'm grateful to the 2000 edition of the Which? Wine Guide for alerting me to the existence of Derek Dornan's brilliant operation. Dornan's road to Damascus - or Alba perhaps - came two years ago when he attended an Italian tasting in London, but couldn't find anywhere to buy the wines afterwards. His aim was to assemble a list containing 'blue-chip wines as well as established and up-and-coming wines of every conceivable style, to show people what is great about Italy'. The result is a fascinating read, as well as a palate-watering selection of 360 wines. Most of the top names are here, but if you're feeling adventurous, go for a mixed case.

1999 Verdicchio dei Castelli Jesi Classico, Sartarelli (£7).
Apples and ripe pears are the dominant flavours here, with undertones of nut, apricot and acacia honey. If only all Verdicchio tasted as good as this.

The Wine Barn (01962 774102)

Selling German wine in the UK is like pushing a pallet of Liebfraumilch up a steep hill, so well done Iris Ellmann for having the courage to try. This talented business and economics graduate has set herself the aim of 'changing the views of the British nation on German wine'. To do so, she has secured exclusive distribution for some of the best new style, dry wines from her native Germany, focusing on Baden and the Rheingau. Her list is small, focusing on only half a dozen growers, but the wines are intelligently chosen and a welcome antidote to the dilute, sugary flavours of most mainstream German wine.

1998 Nierstein Pettental Riesling Trocken, Freiherr Heyl zu Herrnsheim (£11.74). A subtle, floral, minerally Rheinhessen Riesling in which acidity, alcohol and fruit flavours are beautifully melded. This is one of the best dry Rieslings I've had in years.

webTitle: Food and drink special: Nigel Slater

fields.headline: We say potatoes...
fields.standfirst: But we also say patatas bravas, fritters, samosas, hashes and caldo verde. The humble spud is an international star
fields.trailText: But we also say patatas bravas, fritters, samosas, hashes and caldo verde. The humble spud is an international star.
fields.body:
This week alone, I have managed to consume Chinese dim sum, Japanese sushi (albeit from Marks & Spencer), Italian-made mushroom tortelloni and a Vietnamese noodle salad. I drank French water, Italian and American wine and Belgian beer. And, of course, I cooked in metric.

Before I am lynched by the little-Englanders, I should add that, except for some pink grapefruits, all the fruit and vegetables I munched, baked or juiced were grown within a few miles of home, as was some of the cheese, the chocolate and a heavenly, ozone-scented crab. Even so, the score goes something like England 2, the rest of the world 10. Which, I suspect, sums up most open-minded Brits' diets.

Culinary kleptomaniacs we may be, but what about the treasure that gets left here by those who visit or settle. Those who found themselves living and cooking here have enriched our national diet more than we have theirs. We can only thank the Indians, Bangladeshis, Spanish and Turks who have set up shop here and brought their recipes with them for adding a bit of spice and sunshine to our warming but ultimately bland cold-weather food.

As much as we like to think the world links us with roast beef and apple hat, the truth is more mundane. To the Indians, Americans and Europeans, the British are linked with nothing more strongly than the potato. Forget our fruit puddings and our stately roasts, gloss over our heritage of meat pies and top-notch tracklements: we are, in most people's eyes, a spud culture. We roast, mash, boil, bake, fry and steam our beloved potato, and to those who will have no truck with 'foreign muck', a meal is not a meal without a reassuring tattie on the side.

With the exception of the Chinese, who seem not to have taken much of a shine to our Solanum tuberosum, almost every culture's cooks have left their culinary calling card: the humble spud.

The Spanish, who set up their tapas bars - now often run by wide boys born much closer to home - put patatas bravas on our culinary map. On the rare occasion it is properly made, patatas bravas are crisp, light chips with a tomato sauce made interesting by chilli and vinegar. A more devilish version of our chips and tomato ketchup, this classic tap has become a bit of soak-up-the-beer special here. A shame, because it can be a true pepper and potato treat. The Spanish omelette, if made with love and understanding, can become a quivering, tender slice of tiny yellow potatoes and sweet onions rather than the familiar fridge-cold wedge of cold egg and spuds.

The Turkish community who have opened up restaurants here will almost certainly offer us potato fritters as part of our mezzo. Cypriot chefs, too, will hopefully have brought with them their own mezzo recipe for potatoes antinaktes - new potatoes lightly smashed then fried in hot oil with red wine, coriander root and its lush green leaves. While neither of these ideas has become staple fare in British kitchens, they are secrets waiting to get out.

Every Indian restaurant flier that falls through my letterbox pedals its sag or Bombay alto - spuds with spinach or spice - but Indian cooks have a formidable collection of potato recipes. Batata dada, the fritters flavoured with turmeric, coriander and chilli, have opened up British cooks to the possibilities of spicing their potatoes and potato cakes. The classic British recipe for roasting potatoes is unlikely to feature anything spicier than the knee-jerk 'salt and freshly ground black pepper', yet the Indian way of roasting potatoes with turmeric, chilli and cumin is a recipe that deserves to be better known.

The most famous Indian potato import must be the samosa. In my experience, this is a recipe which does not travel. Peas, diced potato, ginger, coriander, mint and chillies wrapped in wafer-thin pastry sound like they could win anyone over, yet this triangular pasty is invariably more akin to eating cumin-flavoured cardboard. The Indians who brought the recipe here seem to have for- gotten the first rule of samosa eating - that of the straight-from-the pan crispness that makes the whole thing worth eating.

Irish cooks have taught us a thing or two when dealing with our staple ingredient, the most famous of which is to make Colcannon, where mashed potato is given a bit of interest with chopped cabbage or kale, spring onions and plenty of pepper.

Moroccan potato stews, French gratins, American hashes and Portuguese caldo verde are recipes that we are more likely to have met on our culinary pillages and make on occasion in our own kitchens. The rest we should see as gifts. Presents brought to us by those who set up their kitchens here and have shown us that there is more to a potato than peeling and boiling it.

When Indians bake potatoes, they tend to add spices and some liquid such as water or yogurt, but I see no reason why you cannot add the yogurt afterwards, which allows the potatoes to crisp nicely. A moderate heat is needed to stop the spices from burning in the oven. Serves 4 as a side dish.

4 medium-sized potatoes

vegetable or groundnut oil

2 fresh red chillies, as hot as you like

2 cloves of garlic, peeled and crushed

tsp cumin seeds

tsp ground turmeric

to finish

4 tbsp natural yogurt

a little ground, mild chill

a palmful of young mint leaves

Peel the potatoes, cut them into the sort of pieces you would for normal roasting, then bring them to the boil in deep water. Add salt to the pot and simmer for 10 to 15 minutes, until the potatoes are approaching tenderness. You should be able to slide a knifepoint through them with almost no pressure. Drain them thoroughly, then very gently shake the potatoes in their pan, so the edges fluff and 'bruise'. Set the oven at 180 C/gas mark 4.

Heat enough oil to make a thin film in the bottom of a roasting tin. The thicker the base, the less likelihood there is of the spices burning. As the oil warms, add the chopped chillies, garlic and cumin and let the m warm through, stirring (and watching like a hawk) so they do not burn. Add the potatoes to the hot oil, add the turmeric, then slowly stir and toss the potatoes so they are covered with the seasoned oil.

Roast the potatoes in the preheated oven until they have started to crisp (30 to 35minutes or so). You don't want them to be as brown as classic roast potatoes. They should be golden and flecked with spice. As the potatoes come from the oven, grind over a seasoning of salt, then spoon over the yogurt and sprinkle with a very little mild ground chilli and scatter with the chopped mint leaves.

Patatas bravas

You could use a home made tomato sauce or, if you prefer, a ready-made one from the supermarket chiller cabinet. The bottled stuff tends to have too much tomato purée in it. Traditionally this is served as tapas - here, it is what I call a Monday evening dish. Just the job for brightening up Sunday's leftovers. Serves 4 as a side dish.

3 large to medium potatoes

olive oil

250ml tomato sauce

2 tbsp white-wine vinegar (to taste)

several shakes of Tabasco sauce

Peel the potatoes, then cut them into thick chips or, as I have eaten them in Bilbao, small cubes. Pour 2 or 3 tbsp olive oil into a large frying pan and cook the potatoes in it till they are lightly coloured. This will take less time if you take the cube route.

Meanwhile, heat 1 tbsp of the oil in a deeper pan, add the tomato sauce, vinegar and Tabasco - check for seasoning, adding salt, pepper and more vinegar or chilli sauce as you think fit.

Pour a little of the sauce into the pan with the potatoes and toss gently to cover with the sauce. To be at their best, the potatoes need only a little tomato sauce - the rest can be served in a dish for those who want more.

Colcannon

An Irish way. Enough for 4 as side dish.

500g large potatoes

half a small January King cabbage

a little hot milk for mashing the potatoes

50g butter

Peel the potatoes and boil in salted water. When they are tender, drain them and mash them with the butter and enough hot milk to make a creamy mash, stiff enough to stand in peaks.

While the potatoes are boiling, wash, shred and boil the cabbage. Drain, then season with pepper and salt. When the potatoes are ready, fold the cabbage into the mashed potatoes, pile into a warm bowl, and - this is important - serve with a lump of melting butter in the middle.

webTitle: Food and drink special: restaurants

fields.headline: Fusion, schmusion
fields.standfirst: Kosher restaurants have their peculiarities, but when plain old chicken soup becomes consommé de poulet, you know something is stirring in Anglo-Jewish circles. By Jay Rayner
fields.trailText: Kosher restaurants have their peculiarities, but when plain old chicken soup becomes consommé de poulet, you know something is stirring in Anglo-Jewish circles.
fields.body:
A couple of years ago, I published a novel about the rise and fall of a great Anglo-Jewish restaurant and hotel business. As trade flourishes, the two partners find themselves craving acceptance beyond the confines of the Jewish community from which they sprang, and so they rewrite their menus. Accordingly, chicken soup becomes consommé de poulet. Because, of course, putting it in French makes it glamorous and refined, and if it's glamorous and refined it ain't too Jewish.

Here's the thing: it was a joke. Not the best joke in the world, perhaps, but a joke all the same. And yet, just a couple of years later, I am sitting in Six-13, Britain's 'first-ever kosher-fusion restaurant' - like we needed one - and there, listed among the starters, is chicken consommé. Apparently it's the same as chicken soup, only it costs £5 a bowl. Next time I attempt to make jokes about the pretensions of Anglo-Jewry, I'll have to aim a little lower.

Before the arrival of Six-13 (named after the 613 commandments the observant Jew must follow), if you had asked me to define kosher-fusion I'd have said it's what would happen if Vanessa Feltz and Jerry Seinfeld ever ended up in bed together. As far as the management is concerned, however, it simply means that religious Anglo-Jewry - the ones who keep kosher - should not be locked away in some mittel-European culinary ghetto of salt beef and lockshen pudding while the rest of the nation pleasures itself at the global larder. They, too, should have the right to eat crispy ginger and coriander pesto. Except, of course, if they happen to like salt beef and lockshen pudding because, significantly, both are on the menu here.

Regardless of the grand claims that Six-13 makes for its concept, its core audience seems to like it. The roads leading from Hendon to the sleek, modern premises on London's Wigmore Street must have been bumper to bumper with Volvos on the week night we visited. It was packed. I hadn't seen this many Jews in one place in London since my Bar Mitzvah.

As for the food, given the constraints it must work to, there's not much to kibitz* about - which is a shame, because it's what Jews do best in restaurants. As well as the obvious things such as no pork or shellfish, the most striking limitation on a kosher restaurant is that milk and meat must never be mixed. Those kosher restaurants that do use dairy products will serve only fish; Six-13 goes the other way, serving meat but no dairy. We went with Jonny, who keeps kosher, and his wife Sarah. Jonny took one look at the menu and said, 'Almost no one will be ordering the fish here. Fish they can eat at home. They'll all be eating the beef.' He was right. Platefuls of red meat were piling out of the kitchen as quickly as the waiters could schlep** them.

For my starter, I tried to order the pan-fried foie gras, but the waiter told me it was off. Actually, he said, it hadn't yet come on. The Beth Din, the rabbinical court that passes foodstuffs as kosher, had thrown a broigus*** and refused to approve their supplier of liver. He gave a big 'what can you do' shrug. Instead I went for the seared tuna with pickled vegetables, at £7.50. The fish had barely been on nodding terms with the heat and was, to all intents and purposes, a great, purple chunk of sashimi. That was fine by me. It was fresh and the pickled ginger on the side suitably sharp. Pat's grilled provençal vegetables with salsa verde (£5.50) was well executed. But the chicken soup - sorry, consommé - got the thumbs down from Jonny and Sarah: it was, they said, a rather polite affair. You could barely tell a chicken had died for it. In short, nothing like any of our mothers could make.

For our main courses we all had the meat. Here, as we had begun to suspect it would be, the fusion thing was suddenly forgotten. There is nothing controversial about steak and chips, or roast rack of lamb, or roast duck breast with pickled red cabbage. But they were all fine cuts of meat, despite the kosher law requiring flesh to be drained of blood before cooking. At an average of £18 a shot for each, though, they were damned expensive.

It was in the puddings that the absence of dairy really showed itself. My pavlova was crying out to be smothered in cream, Jonny's tarte tatin came with a scoop of very strange-tasting ice cream, and Pat's coconut rice pudding, clearly made with coconut milk, was simply odd. But that was OK, because finally we got to kibitz about them and that made us very happy.

Six-13 is rather less than it claims to be. It's a modern and expensive take on the kosher restaurant which proclaims innovation and yet does absolutely nothing that might frighten its target audience. And its target audience seems to love it.

*kibitz - like complaining, but with much more shrugging.
**schlep - carrying things around while kibitzing about it.
***broigus - an angry outburst, often occasioned by being asked to do too much schlepping.

 Six-13, 19 Wigmore Street, London W1 (020 7629 6133). Dinner for two, including wine and service, £95. Contact Jay Rayner on jay.rayner@observer.co.uk. His Day of Atonement is available from Amazon.co.uk
