webTitle: The worst run place in Britain?

fields.headline: The worst run place in Britain?
fields.standfirst: A lack of political will has left Hackney bankrupt and unable to provide its citizens with services.
fields.trailText: It was, all too appropriately, a march to absolutely nowhere. The 500 Hackney residents and council workers, who joined last Monday's demonstration against proposed emergency cuts to council services, trudged through the wind and the rain on a long, circuitous route that took them only from Hackney Town Hall all the way back to Hackney Town Hall.
fields.body:
It was, all too appropriately, a march to absolutely nowhere. The 500 Hackney residents and council workers, who joined last Monday's demonstration against proposed emergency cuts to council services, trudged through the wind and the rain on a long, circuitous route that took them only from Hackney Town Hall all the way back to Hackney Town Hall.

For the poor benighted citizens of this poorest of London boroughs - a place that should serve as a warning to us all about what can happen when local government goes pitifully wrong - it just reinforced what they had always thought: in Hackney, nothing ever seems to move on.

It was there, even in the style of the protest. Had it been shot in black and white by Pathé it could not have looked more like a relic from an earlier age.

There were the Socialist Workers' Party placards. There were the fluttering union banners and the votes of support from striking health workers from distant corners of the nation. And there, too, were the rousers of the rabble with their rhythmic call-and-response chants by megaphone and their insistence that the solution was to 'Tax the rich. Make them pay'.

This is the borough described by one resident as 'Britain's North Korea. It's the place modern politics forgot'. The protesters' chants at least had the virtue of simplifying the situation down to a failure of leftist will by local councillors. But it is not that straightforward, however much you might wish it to be so. True, the crisis is down to a failure on the part of councillors but, as with everything in this deprived corner of East London, there are lots of other people more than deserving of blame.

Last month the Borough Treasurer, George Jenkins, announced that Hackney did not have enough money to meet the commitments it had made up to the end of this financial year. In short, like New York in the Seventies, it was going bust. Under the terms of local government legislation Jenkins was forced to issue a Section 114 order, which immediately barred the council from spending any money until it had agreed budget cuts, which means finding savings of around £4.5 million this year and £18m next.

Coming in the same week as Chancellor Gordon Brown was opening up his bulging exchequer to buy off pensioners and fuel protesters, the proposed cuts made Hackney look like the council that New Labour had left behind.

The effect of the 114 order was almost immediate. Headteachers across the borough passed a vote of no confidence in their education service - already part-privatised due to previous failures - and wrote to parents informing them that, because they would not be able to employ supply teachers, their children might not have classes to go to. Parks and gardening trucks ran out of fuel and were told not to fill up. Council work men were given orders to do the minimum work possible.

In one instance, a council tenant had a new bath fitted but was told he couldn't have any taps because that would mean extra expense. Another was told they could fix the stopcock in his toilet cistern but not the leaking pipe to it, leaving him unable to flush.

Wetherell Day Nursery closed because of a leaking roof nobody could afford to fix. Then a manager in the council's waste service dismissed all the temporary staff, and rubbish collections, always erratic, stopped. This weekend the streets overflow with rotting garbage. The rats, at least, are getting fatter.

It was supposed to be so different. In June, Hackney gained a new managing director, Max Caller, former chief executive of Barnet council, who answered an advert looking for somebody willing to take on 'the job from hell'. It was by no means underselling the challenge: there had been damning Ofsted reports on Hackney schools and part of the social services department had already come under direct central government control.

The month Caller started work, proclaiming a commitment to give the people of Hackney 'a better deal and a joined-up council doing the right things for them', the District Auditor issued a report that uncovered widespread mismanagement and inadequate accounting on a vast scale. Last week, just as the council was meeting to discuss the latest cuts, there was yet another damning report, this time by the new Best Value Inspection Service set up under recent local government legislation.

'Hackney is not a well-run council and is letting down the people who live in the borough,' said Wendy Thomson, director of inspection at the Audit Commission. 'It is simply not delivering best value in council tax collection, payment of housing benefit, refuse collection, street sweeping or children's services.' No fewer than 17,000 people, she said, were awaiting payment of housing benefit.

At the same time, Caller issued his own report, stuffed full of staggering allegations. Almost nothing at all, he said, was known about who was spending what. Local managers would hide the true costs of their services or would tell democratically elected members what they thought they wanted to hear instead of the truth. As a result, a £5m contract with a private company for rubbish collection had to be delayed when it emerged that the cost of running the service was double that. Managers were also ignoring orders.

When the council passed a resolution insisting no more permanent staff be employed, managers simply employed temporary ones, who turned out to cost more. It was clear, Caller announced, 'that the various moratoriums that were imposed were either not understood, ignored or subverted'.

Ask the political classes of Hackney how it got to be this way and they will sigh and tell you it is a very long story. Partly, they will say, it is simple economics. The borough has few pockets of wealth and receives the fourth-highest central government grant in the country - £1,220 per head of population. There are deep, dark pools of unemployment and poverty and areas where crime and drug abuse are rife.

It was not always like this. Though there has long been poverty here, it was once a thriving borough with big department stores on the high streets and fine Georgian and Regency Squares now left isolated in the midst of dilapidated council estates.

Throughout its history, those with money who have soaked up its rich diverse culture have eventually moved out. (In the Eighties, for example, a young married couple with promising careers as barristers lived in the Mapledene area of Hackney. In time they, too, decided to move to up-and-coming Islington and never looked back. Their names were Tony and Cherie Blair.)

But economic deprivation does not explain all or, at least, not the most recent problems. 'There's simply been a failure of political culture in Hackney,' says Jules Pipe of the Labour Group who, with his Tory colleague Eric Ollerenshaw, now leads the council. He points at a split in Labour in 1996, when more than a dozen Labour members left the party. 'You will never get to the bottom of that split. It was just two groups of people who mutually hated each other. But the moment it became a hung council the idea of an administration with a scrutinising opposition went out the window. In short, there was an absence of administration.'

Councillors busied themselves with feverish infighting to such a degree that the then chief executive, Tony Eliston, said he would install traffic lights in the council chamber to control floor-crossing by members. (One councillor, David Phillips, has sat as Labour, Hackney New Labour - nothing to do with the Blair-Mandelson version - Conservative, Independent, LibDem and now Green Party.)

Meanwhile, without any scrutiny by councillors to trouble them, unelected managers set about creating fiefdoms within the council.

In 1997 a new plan, 'Transforming Hackney', placed budgets in the hands of individual managers in an attempt to get council services closer to residents. Without any central financial management at all, Hackney council was at the mercy of legions of incompetent council officials.

The question Hackney residents are now asking themselves is whether the severe cuts announced last week - up to 500 jobs may go, employees are being given new working terms and conditions, council trading units are being closed down, services are being withdrawn - are merely a symptom of the chronic disease or the cure.

Pipe is in no doubt they are curing their ills. Labour and the Conservatives have decided to co-operate - shoving the Lib Dems into opposition - and so there is now a form of political stability for the first time in four years. 'Under Max Caller and his new team we also have management in place which has finally been able to identify the problems,' he says.

Caller agrees. 'We have been able to take the decision that needed to be taken. We have introduced management controls which make it possible to handle the finances. The 500 Hackney residents and council workers, who joined last Monday's demonstration against proposed emergency cuts to council services, trudged through the wind and the rain on a long, circuitous route that took them only from Hackney Town Hall all the way back to Hackney Town Hall. For the poor benighted citizens of this poorest of London boroughs - a place that should serve as a warning to us all about what can happen when local government goes pitifully wrong - it just reinforced what they had always thought: in Hackney, nothing ever seems to move on. It was there, even in the style of the protest. Had it been shot in black and white by Pathé it could not have looked more like a relic from an earlier age. There were the Socialist Workers' Party placards. There were the fluttering union banners and the votes of support from striking health workers from distant corners of the nation. And there, too, were the rousers of the rabble with their rhythmic call-and-response chants by megaphone and their insistence that the solution was to 'Tax the rich. Make them pay'. This is the borough described by one resident as 'Britain's North Korea. It's the place modern politics forgot'. The protesters' chants at least had the virtue of simplifying the situation down to a failure of leftist will by local councillors. But it is not that straightforward, however much you might wish it to be so. True, the crisis is down to a failure on the part of councillors but, as with everything in this deprived corner of East London, there are lots of other people more than deserving of blame. Last month the Borough Treasurer, George Jenkins, announced that Hackney did not have enough money to meet the commitments it had made up to the end of this financial year. In short, like New York in the Seventies, it was going bust. Under the terms of local government legislation Jenkins was forced to issue a Section 114 order, which immediately barred the council from spending any money until it had agreed budget cuts, which means finding savings of around £4.5 million this year and £18m next. Coming in the same week as Chancellor Gordon Brown was opening up his bulging exchequer to buy off pensioners and fuel protesters, the proposed cuts made Hackney look like the council that New Labour had left behind. The effect of the 114 order was almost immediate. Headteachers across the borough passed a vote of no confidence in their education service - already part-privatised due to previous failures - and wrote to parents informing them that, because they would not be able to employ supply teachers, their children might not have classes to go to. Parks and gardening trucks ran out of fuel and were told not to fill up. Council work men were given orders to do the minimum work possible. In one instance, a council tenant had a new bath fitted but was told he couldn't have any taps because that would mean extra expense. Another was told they could fix the stopcock in his toilet cistern but not the leaking pipe to it, leaving him unable to flush. Wetherell Day Nursery closed because of a leaking roof nobody could afford to fix. Then a manager in the council's waste service dismissed all the temporary staff, and rubbish collections, always erratic, stopped. This weekend the streets overflow with rotting garbage. The rats, at least, are getting fatter. It was supposed to be so different. In June, Hackney gained a new managing director, Max Caller, former chief executive of Barnet council, who answered an advert looking for somebody willing to take on 'the job from hell'. It was by no means underselling the challenge: there had been damning Ofsted reports on Hackney schools and part of the social services department had already come under direct central government control. The month Caller started work, proclaiming a commitment to give the people of Hackney 'a better deal and a joined-up council doing the right things for them', the District Auditor issued a report that uncovered widespread mismanagement and inadequate accounting on a vast scale. Last week, just as the council was meeting to discuss the latest cuts, there was yet another damning report, this time by the new Best Value Inspection Service set up under recent local government legislation. 'Hackney is not a well-run council and is letting down the people who live in the borough,' said Wendy Thomson, director of inspection at the Audit Commission. 'It is simply not delivering best value in council tax collection, payment of housing benefit, refuse collection, street sweeping or children's services.' No fewer than 17,000 people, she said, were awaiting payment of housing benefit. At the same time, Caller issued his own report, stuffed full of staggering allegations. Almost nothing at all, he said, was known about who was spending what. Local managers would hide the true costs of their services or would tell democratically elected members what they thought they wanted to hear instead of the truth. As a result, a £5m contract with a private company for rubbish collection had to be delayed when it emerged that the cost of running the service was double that. Managers were also ignoring orders. When the council passed a resolution insisting no more permanent staff be employed, managers simply employed temporary ones, who turned out to cost more. It was clear, Caller announced, 'that the various moratoriums that were imposed were either not understood, ignored or subverted'. Ask the political classes of Hackney how it got to be this way and they will sigh and tell you it is a very long story. Partly, they will say, it is simple economics. The borough has few pockets of wealth and receives the fourth-highest central government grant in the country - £1,220 per head of population. There are deep, dark pools of unemployment and poverty and areas where crime and drug abuse are rife. It was not always like this. Though there has long been poverty here, it was once a thriving borough with big department stores on the high streets and fine Georgian and Regency Squares now left isolated in the midst of dilapidated council estates. Throughout its history, those with money who have soaked up its rich diverse culture have eventually moved out. (In the Eighties, for example, a young married couple with promising careers as barristers lived in the Mapledene area of Hackney. In time they, too, decided to move to up-and-coming Islington and never looked back. Their names were Tony and Cherie Blair.) But economic deprivation does not explain all or, at least, not the most recent problems. 'There's simply been a failure of political culture in Hackney,' says Jules Pipe of the Labour Group who, with his Tory colleague Eric Ollerenshaw, now leads the council. He points at a split in Labour in 1996, when more than a dozen Labour members left the party. 'You will never get to the bottom of that split. It was just two groups of people who mutually hated each other. But the moment it became a hung council the idea of an administration with a scrutinising opposition went out the window. In short, there was an absence of administration.' Councillors busied themselves with feverish infighting to such a degree that the then chief executive, Tony Eliston, said he would install traffic lights in the council chamber to control floor-crossing by members. (One councillor, David Phillips, has sat as Labour, Hackney New Labour - nothing to do with the Blair-Mandelson version - Conservative, Independent, LibDem and now Green Party.) webTitle: Mariella Frostrup reflects on her year as a Booker judge

fields.headline: Blonde and proud
fields.standfirst: Can a slave to her hair colour really judge a literary prize and present Panorama?  Mariella Frostrup reflects on her year of sexism and success:  'It seemed I embodied the rot at the heart of broadcasting'
fields.trailText: Can a slave to her hair colour really judge a literary prize and present Panorama? Mariella Frostrup reflects on her year of sexism and success.
fields.body:
Well, it's certainly turned out to be an exhausting year. My worries that I'd find myself at a very loose end having given up my regular arts show on television proved unfounded. Instead, I've been incredibly busy, devoting myself to the dumbing down of two great British institutions: the Booker Prize and the BBC's Panorama .

March

It was early March when I got a call from a publisher friend warning me that I'd be receiving a letter from the Booker Prize committee asking me to join this year's judging panel. Obviously, I laughed down the line and demanded to know what medication he was on. A further five minutes of conversation convinced me that this was not a joke at my expense.

It was an exciting moment, I must admit, and marked a personal triumph after years of having my hair colour dictate the sort of work I was offered. It was also the beginning of an at times torturous eight months during which I was to read 120 novels in my spare time.

My first encounter with this year's chairman, the charming and - as I was to discover - inspirationally diplomatic Simon Jenkins proved less intimidating than I'd imagined. Simon and I dined in a small Greek restaurant in Regent's Park and discovered we had much in common, including favourite books. In fact, so convivial was lunch that I left besotted. Lunch with the Booker's administrator, Martin Goff, was a more glamorous affair in the Meridian Piccadilly but proved equally enjoyable and both left me feeling confident that I was capable of rising to the task ahead.

It was lucky that they were so encouraging, because while I set about cancelling all social engagements until November and organising to spend as much time as possible buried in books down in Sussex, the papers had a field day. First, Jerry Hall is brought in to judge the Whitbread, they thundered, and then Mariella Frostrup is asked to sit on the Booker jury. Armageddon must surely be just around the corner. Pencil sharpeners were working overtime. The furore was as outdated and misogynistic as it was hilarious.

What on earth was the world coming to? I mean, Jerry Hall and I were women who were seen out and about at 'parties', had probably never worn a tweed skirt in our lives and might possibly be interested in 'popular music' and fashion. What on earth could we possibly know and understand about literature?

May

The books started arriving weekly in boxes of 10 and by early summer I was floundering in a murky pool of despair. First of all, there were none of my favourite authors like Jackie Collins and Jilly Cooper. But frankly neither would have been much worse than some of the initial entries and I took to phoning Simon Jenkins on a daily basis to express my fears that we were never going to find one good book, let alone a shortlist of six. He dealt with my panicky whingeing with a mixture of fatherly reassurance and practical good sense. 'Better books will come' became his catchphrase and luckily they did.

June

I was away for the social meeting set up for the judges so my initial encounter with the rest of the panel was at the first in a series of whittling-down sessions suggested by Simon. I arrived filled with trepidation at his Albany apartment, having spent all morning trying to decide what a 'Booker judge' should wear. I reluctantly put my ra-ra skirt and sequinned bodice aside until after 7 November and set out, neutrally dressed, stomach churning.

Putting a defiant face on for the media was all very well, but for these members of the intelligentsia I was surely going to be a bite-sized snack. My fears couldn't have been less justified. The rest of the panel - Caroline Gascoigne, Rose Tremain, and Roy Foster - were delightful and we spent a fascinating lunchtime tiptoeing through each other's literary likes and dislikes. Indeed, during the first months we tended to concur on the same books and I frequently wondered how so many Booker years had ended in catfights.

July

The reading may have been going well but it was playing havoc with my private life. Reading has become such an obscure hobby that declining invitations because you've got to 'finish a book' appears the least convincing of excuses. I heard rumours of friends saying I'd obviously fallen out with them, my phone gradually stopped ringing and by July only my nearest and dearest were prepared to brave the ranting hysteric they invariably found on the end of the receiver. 'I can't talk now I've got 12 books left from the last shipment and another box has just arrived,' I'd screech before slamming down the phone. Eventually, they, too, decided to leave me to my own devices.

August

The request to front the Edinburgh Festival shows on BBC2 throughout August came as a relief. Unlike the thousands of others who descend on the Scottish capital for its annual celebration of arts and comedy, I find relocating to Edinburgh a wonderful opportunity to cut myself off from the world. In a lovely flat in the city centre, I took up daily yoga classes, visited the shows I was reviewing for the programme and hunkered down for some serious reading. By the end of August, I was enjoying a period of relative calm and feeling that finally I was actually ahead of the game. I'd finished about two-thirds of the books I had to read and had taken September and October off to complete the task.

Early September

Then came the second offer of this millennium year that I just couldn't turn down. A request from Panorama , following the publication of a diary I'd written on the subject in the Spectator , to front a show on the phenomenon of reality TV as evidenced by the nation's mass addiction to Channel 4's Big Brother . Knowing that yet again I was laying my neck on the chopping block, I had my hair cut shorter in preparation and did what anyone would have done in my position - said yes.

The press was once again outraged, or at least the Daily Mail was. I was quivering with nerves by the time I arrived for my first meeting in the Panorama offices. Not only had the new controller of BBC1 been quoted in the Mail as viewing my appointment as 'a joke' but a mysterious Panorama 'insider' was said to be 'horrified' at my appointment. It seemed I embodied the rot at the heart of public service broadcasting.

When I slunk in to meet the acting editor Clive Edwards and the team I would be working with, I tried to distinguish my enemy's face from a sea of welcoming ones. Despite my emerging investigative talents, I failed to locate Deep Throat. I presumed he was off in some war zone doing his manly thing. Instead, I met with my producer Toby Sculthorp and assistant producer Judith Ahern who informed me that they would expect me to work like any other reporter, ie coming into the office, writing the script, doing my own research. Surely some mistake. We all know that TV presenters are the living embodiment of ventriloquists' dummies. We're not supposed necessarily even to understand what we're given to read on autocue, let alone write it, unless of course we read the news.

After the meeting, Toby offered to walk me around the offices and I must say I was relieved. The dumbing-down process seemed already to be in full swing. The walls were covered with pictures of Brad Pitt, there were Beatles screensavers in evidence and even a comic strip attached to the noticeboard. In the distance, I could hear a football discussion getting very heated. This was going to be a lot easier than I'd imagined. A collection of serious news-hounds who actually knew what was going on in the world of popular culture: unthinkable.

Late September

Florida was the first spot we were to hit in our pursuit of the makers and victims of 'reality TV'. It was clear we'd landed in real America. Anything edible came in a bun, the beer was weak and tasteless and shopping malls spread like a virulent fungus across the towns. This was the world of obesity, anorexia and dysfunction that provides the human fodder for the US's endless steam of 'reality entertainment' shows. The 'entertaining' element proved hard to uncover while interviewing the drug addicts and tragic freaks from whom Jerry Springer and his ilk make their millions.

Early October

Back in London, I tried desperately to hide my suntan from Panorama colleagues working undercover and risking their lives in Northern Ireland. As I headed out to interview Nasty Nick, the most 'evil' man in Britain, whose life was apparently in danger as a result of his Big Brother antics, the reporter on the adjoining desk was receiving death threats from the Real IRA. Nobody was offering to take messages. I felt vindicated in my suspicion that the national addiction to 'reality TV' had got dangerously got out of hand. The most 'evil' man in Britain? Who says serious journalism is under threat?

The Booker judging process was racing toward its first hurdle; the shortlist nominations. My dumbing-down was going so well that we had actually started to tell jokes at judging meetings. While we all agreed on four of the books on the shortlist, we were totally divided on Matthew Kneale's English Passengers and Margaret Atwood's The Blind Assassin . I pleaded Kneale's cause as passionately as I could. In the end, Simon's skilful arbitration resulted in both books making it on to the list and all of us claiming victory. I wondered if those would be the self-same books that would cause the greatest dissent when we reconvened to select a winner.

Late October

Still the jibes continued to flow about my 'dumbing-down' crusade. At Nigella Lawson's book launch, a female journalist stuck a tape-recorder into my face and said: 'I suppose you're off to the West Bank next?' 'No, the Left Bank's more my scene,' I retorted before being made part of a paparazzi sandwich with Nicola Formby and Penny Smith. They just love those blonde shots. I'd wanted to say South Bank but I didn't want to make Lord Bragg nervous.

On Panorama , things were getting a little fraught. We'd interviewed a very disgruntled participant from BBC1's Castaway and it seemed the corridors of TV Centre were awash with angry controllers. We were supposed to be wagging the finger at commercial television, not going for our own jugular. Faced with the gathering storm Judith and I were happy to escape and head for Chicago where we'd managed to obtain an interview with the king of tabloid TV, Jerry Springer.

Jerry's producer, Richard, informed me during a preparatory chat that, given the opportunity, he'd leap at being able to include on-screen executions in the show. Still reeling from that encounter, I listened while a slightly sweaty Jerry insisted that his programme was 'pure entertainment' and then popped into the studio to make a show about an incestuous father and daughter. What a laugh, eh? I couldn't wait to get out of the NBC studios and back on the plane. I just wished I'd been able to shower off the residual slime from my encounter en route to the airport.

November

Tuesday the 7th. The Booker judging has reached its conclusion. The five of us, along with Martin Goff, sat closeted in an intimidating mayoral room in London's Guildhall with just three hours to the announcement. As my favourites fell like skittles before Atwood's Blind Assassin my heart sank. I was disappointed that with such an unusual shortlist we were going to end up with a regular Booker name stealing the prize. Also, I'd grown incredibly attached to my two personal favourites - English Passengers and The Keepers of Truth by Michael Collins.

Nevertheless, democracy rules and taking comfort in the fact that we'd already decided to look on the shortlist as our Booker winners I reluctantly went with the otherwise unanimous vote. We toasted the conclusion of our endeavours and then Caroline, Rose and I set off for a tiny room on the fourth floor to change into our finery. The good news for me was that we spent 30 minutes discussing make-up, our outfits and the benefits of a touch of hairspray. I'd triumphed at last and brought Rose and Caroline down to my level. All that reading had been worthwhile.

Now, as the week draws to a close, there's only Panorama left to worry about. Have I succeeded in dumbing it down? Well, I did catch two researchers reading the tabloids yesterday afternoon. As a final test, I've left a couple of copies of Hello! and OK! magazine hidden in the office between the broadsheets. If I find them well thumbed when I rise early today - my thirty-eighth birthday - to put the finishing touches to tonight's show, my mission will be complete.

 Panorama is on BBC1 at 10.15 tonight.

My dumbing-down was going so well that we had actually started to tell jokes at judging meetings. While we all agreed on four of the books on the shortlist, we were totally divided on Matthew Kneale's English Passengers and Margaret Atwood's The Blind Assassin . I pleaded Kneale's cause as passionately as I could. In the end, Simon's skilful arbitration resulted in both books making it on to the list and all of us claiming victory. I wondered if those would be the self-same books that would cause the greatest dissent when we reconvened to select a winner. Late October Still the jibes continued to flow about my 'dumbing-down' crusade. At Nigella Lawson's book launch, a female journalist stuck a tape-recorder into my face and said: 'I suppose you're off to the West Bank next?' 'No, the Left Bank's more my scene,' I retorted before being made part of a paparazzi sandwich with Nicola Formby and Penny Smith. They just love those blonde shots. I'd wanted to say South Bank but I didn't want to make Lord Bragg nervous. On Panorama , things were getting a little fraught. We'd interviewed a very disgruntled participant from BBC1's Castaway and it seemed the corridors of TV Centre were awash with angry controllers. We were supposed to be wagging the finger at commercial television, not going for our own jugular. Faced with the gathering storm Judith and I were happy to escape and head for Chicago where we'd managed to obtain an interview with the king of tabloid TV, Jerry Springer. Jerry's producer, Richard, informed me during a preparatory chat that, given the opportunity, he'd leap at being able to include on-screen executions in the show. Still reeling from that encounter, I listened while a slightly sweaty Jerry insisted that his programme was 'pure entertainment' and then popped into the studio to make a show about an incestuous father and daughter. What a laugh, eh? I couldn't wait to get out of the NBC studios and back on the plane. I just wished I'd been able to shower off the residual slime from my encounter en route to the airport. November Tuesday the 7th. The Booker judging has reached its conclusion. The five of us, along with Martin Goff, sat closeted in an intimidating mayoral room in London's Guildhall with just three hours to the announcement. As my favourites fell like skittles before Atwood's Blind Assassin my heart sank. I was disappointed that with such an unusual shortlist we were going to end up with a regular Booker name stealing the prize. Also, I'd grown incredibly attached to my two personal favourites - English Passengers and The Keepers of Truth by Michael Collins. Nevertheless, democracy rules and taking comfort in the fact that we'd already decided to look on the shortlist as our Booker winners I reluctantly went with the otherwise unanimous vote. We toasted the conclusion of our endeavours and then Caroline, Rose and I set off for a tiny room on the fourth floor to change into our finery. The good news for me was that we spent 30 minutes discussing make-up, our outfits and the benefits of a touch of hairspray. I'd triumphed at last and brought Rose and Caroline down to my level. All that reading had been worthwhile. Now, as the week draws to a close, there's only Panorama left to worry about. Have I succeeded in dumbing it down? Well, I did catch two researchers reading the tabloids yesterday afternoon. As a final test, I've left a couple of copies of Hello! and OK! magazine hidden in the office between the broadsheets. If I find them well thumbed when I rise early today - my thirty-eighth birthday - to put the finishing touches to tonight's show, my mission will be complete.  Panorama is on BBC1 at 10.15 tonight.

webTitle: BSkyB is about to offer betting

fields.headline: It's a winner for Murdoch if punters take to their sofas
fields.standfirst: BSkyB is about to offer betting via the television screen. Daniel Whitaker considers the odds
fields.trailText: BSkyB is about to offer betting via the television screen. Daniel Whitaker considers the odds
fields.body:
A rainy lunchtime in Camden Town and Ladbrokes is full of punters completing slips for the 1.20 at Lingfield with their free red pens.

Rupert Murdoch has himself got money at stake; his bet is that in a few months' time, many of these men will be sitting at home. It's not that they will be giving up gambling - it's that the bookies are coming to their television sets.

Though the project remains wrapped in secrecy, News International's BSkyB now has the technology to offer on-screen betting along with its live broadcast sporting events. As Arsenal's Thierry Henry receives the ball and heads towards Manchester United's goal, a strip down the side of the screen might offer odds against him scoring. All viewers would need to do would be to press a button on their remote controls to place the bet, the stake being taken through a separate account they have with Sky.

With the crowd's televised roar swelling and a few cans of lager consumed, many viewers will find such a flutter hard to resist. Sources at Sky say the service may start by the end of this year.

Of course, this only represents the latest step in the continuing spread of betting opportunities that has taken place in Britain over the past decade. 'There's no doubt - we are becoming a nation of gamblers,' says Paul, on duty on the other side of London at Gamblers' Anonymous.

Up in West Bromwich, consultancy Global Betting and Gaming will next month publish a review of the world gambling industry, estimating that we will have bet more than £43 billion this year through officially registered channels alone, with £36bn of this paid out as winnings.

The internet has grabbed most of the headlines. More than a third of UK households are now net-connected and gambling - 'g-commerce' - has become one of the two most profitable online industries. (The other is pornography.) Peter Shea at stockbroker Daniel Stewart reckons that the internet will account for 20 per cent of world betting by 2005. With half of us now using mobile telephones, internet-connected wap phones represent another way of accessing online betting.

Sky, along with rivals NTL and OnDigital (which last week announced a deal with online bookies Blue Square), all already offer access to the internet and online betting.

But the digital live television-based betting that BSkyB plans is a breakthrough because it will bypass the internet. This could be key in the battle with the bookmakers, as few betting shop users have internet connections at home or at work, and are likely to be Sky television customers.

'Online betting may be growing quickly,' says Warren Bartlett, chairman of the British Betting Office Association (BBOA), 'but from a small base, and it appeals to quite different customers from those that use betting shops.'

And Sky, like the internet sites, has a big advantage over high street bookmakers on the cost side. With no shops to maintain and far fewer employees to pay, BSkyB should find it easy to undercut the odds offered in a betting shop. Once punters know this, they will have a strong incentive to stay at home.

Sky believes people would rather sit on their own sofas to watch televised sporting events. Bartlett thinks gamblers may want to get out of the house, and points out that most British gamblers are males, who start at age 28-30. 'Marriage seems to bring it on,' he claims. 'The pub has become a family institution, but betting shops are a male preserve, and sometimes that is what men want.'

But Shea is convinced that BSkyB has stolen a march on the industry: 'Placing a bet will become a normal part of any sporting event, adding something to the experience.'

Sky gained some useful expertise last May when it bought Sports Internet for £301m, though at the time the financial press speculated that its main interest was websites. Sports Internet itself had acquired second-tier bookmaker Surrey Racing the year before, and through Surrey, BSkyB has a bookmakers' permit, a legal requirement for any company accepting bets.

Before the Sports Internet deal, Sky was thought to be negotiating with Ladbrokes to find a way to bring betting into live television, but the talks fell apart. There is speculation that this may have been because Ladbrokes was not prepared to undercut its own betting shops.

The ability to take bets during televised events builds on existing interactive Sky products, such as Sky Sports Extra, which allows viewers to select their preferred cam era angle, and Fan Zone, which lets them choose their commentator.

However, while the commercial implications of onscreen betting look rosy, Sky may face regulatory and political hurdles. The ITC says that as long as BSkyB does not promote the service through TV advertisements, it will not fall foul of the rules. It would not be a problem to market the service by direct mail, or to provide information about it on televised pro gramme guides. Customs and Excise would expect to collect 6.75 per cent betting duty, although Gordon Brown has suggested he may reduce this in the Budget.

Critics say that making gambling so accessible at home could be devastating to some families. Gambling is as much of a potential addiction as alcohol. There are also concerns that whatever parental controls Sky puts on the service, children will gain access. Oona King, Labour MP for Hackney, says allowing such a service in the home would be 'a retrograde step' to the current limits on juvenile entry into betting shops.

Onscreen betting is something the Home Office will look at in a wide-ranging review of gambling in the UK. But it could be years before this results in any new legislation. In the meantime, Murdoch's bet on the nation's gambling tendencies looks like being a winner.

2,000 years of gambling? You bet

Organised gambling in the UK dates back to a Roman taste for betting on cards. But bookmaking took off in the eighteenth century, when the gentry began to race horses at Newmarket.

On-course bookies travel ling out to racecourses today with their stepladders are in what is one of Britain's best-preserved craft industries.

Off-course betting shops were legalised as recently as 1961, when Home Secretary Rab Butler decided it was so prevalent that there was a danger of the police being corrupted, as well a much of the population being criminalised.

Today there are about 8,100 betting shops. Some 70 per cent of their income comes from horseracing, and 20 per cent from greyhounds. The fastest-growing segment is football.

Ladbrokes is the largest bookmaker, with 1,880 shops, followed by William Hill with 1,530 and Coral with 870. All have online gambling sites offshore.

webTitle: British plan offensive in Sierre Leone

fields.headline: British plan offensive in Sierre Leone
fields.trailText: British artillery and helicopter gunships will be thrown into combat against the Sierra Leone rebel forces within weeks under plans being drawn up by Whitehall and defence chiefs.
fields.body:
British artillery and helicopter gunships will be thrown into combat against the Sierra Leone rebel forces within weeks under plans being drawn up by Whitehall and defence chiefs.

The plan, which senior diplomatic sources confirmed yesterday, would see a massive escalation in British involvement in the war-torn West African state and possibly result in the fiercest combat involving UK forces since the Gulf War nearly 10 years ago.

The British plan involves deploying helicopter gunships and artillery. The helicopters - Sea Kings from the Royal Navy warships currently off the Sierra Leone shore - would attack rebels of the Revolutionary United Front in support of a government offensive to secure the crucial diamond fields in the south-west of the country which provide the finance for the rebels' war effort.

On the ground, the commandos' light artillery batteries - equipped with 105mm guns - would also be used. Such a weapon has only a limited range and gun crews would be vulnerable. It is likely that infantry units would also have to be deployed to protect them.

A key component of the offensive will be the 1,000-strong brigade of government soldiers that has been trained by British advisers at a base near Freetown, the capital. At least 400 British soldiers are already in positions in and around the city.

Informed sources in Sierra Leone told The Observer last week that forces from the RUF - the main rebel group - had started taking up positions closer to Freetown in recent days. It was the imminent capture of the capital - and the apparent collapse of the UN force protecting the city - that precipitated the British intervention in May which successfully stopped the rebel advance.

British troops have already taken casualties in Sierra Leone. One was killed and 17 injured while freeing a group of soldiers held hostage by a renegade militia three months ago. British troops were involved in some fierce firefights with rebel forces when they first landed in the country.

There were reports yesterday that a ceasefire negotiated on Friday between the Sierra Leonean government and the RUF was still holding, though analysts were pessimistic about its long-term chances. Peter Hain, the Foreign Minister, told The Observer yesterday that the truce vindicated the Government's policy.

'[The truce] could be a very significant breakthrough. Any ceasefire agreed with the RUF has to be treated with considerable caution, but does reflect the success of the strategy that Britain has helped to drive forward since May,' he said.


jason.burke@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Jeff Randall is set to upend the BBC's cosy world

fields.headline: Does Auntie mean business?
fields.standfirst: Iconoclastic newspaperman Jeff Randall is set to upend the BBC's cosy world.  Paul Farrelly  reports.
fields.trailText: Iconoclastic newspaperman Jeff Randall is set to upend the BBC's cosy world.
fields.body:
There's a saying about Jeff Randall. He's the guy who wakes up in the morning, wonders what dream job he's going to next and promptly lands it. But the BBC? Has Sunday Business's editor gone barking mad? He loathes woolly liberals, loves free markets, hates the BBC's business-bashers and hardly craves a gong for services to public broadcasting.

Yet last Monday, Randall took the plunge: from March he will become the BBC's first-ever business editor, with a seat at the news and current affairs top table and a six-figure salary to match.

'I've been a Sunday journalist now for 15 years,' Randall says. 'We all like a new challenge. If I can get the BBC to treat business more seriously, it will be a job well done. I'll have made my contribution.'

The prospect already had the suits fretting long before Randall, sipping a quiet beer on Spain's Costa Blanca 10 days ago, decided to take up new director-general Greg Dyke's offer after six months of talking. How would the stuffy Corporation cope with the outspoken, 46-year-old Essex market trader's son, who'd debunked them all as 'patronising, middle class, guilt-ridden, do-gooders' in an excoriating editorial six months ago?

What the BBC bureaucrats had barely reckoned with, however, was Dyke's own personal indictment of the BBC's business coverage - and that of the rest of British television - which he delivered to the Confederation of British Industry's annual conference last week.

'Last month, on a busy day, on what was then the Nine O'clock News, we did something unusual: we produced an informative piece on what was happening at British Telecom,' Dyke told Britain's business elite. 'Editors of our general news and current affairs programmes will have to find space to make sure we improve further_ Up to now we thought it was good enough to have the economics editor also being responsible for business coverage on the side. It was wrong.'

Charged with finding the real stories and boardroom personalities behind the glib headlines, Randall will split economics editor Peter Jay's empire at Television Centre. But Jay, the UK's former ambassador to the US and one-time bag carrier for Robert Maxwell, is not long for the BBC. 'Barely disguised contempt' is how insiders sum up Dyke's attitude to his economics pontificator-in-chief. The antipathy dates back to 1983, when Dyke rescued TV-am from its founding intellectuals, led by Jay, with a little help from his furry friend Roland Rat. After a decade with the Corporation, 63-year-old Jay's contract will not be renewed when it ends next year.

Randall's appointment means three of the BBC's five specialist editors now have a definite print background. Andrew Marr, brought in as political editor to shunt out the affable Robin Oakley, edited the Independent, and Niall Dixon, social affairs editor, ran the Nursing Times .

Auntie's public broadcasting types may sniff, but the print bias is hardly shocking. Dyke, who made his reputation and his millions in TV, is a former tabloid journalist. Also, TV news often feeds off newspapers' exclusives - nowhere more so than in business. The BBC's new economics and business unit, brought under one roof last year, employs 100 journalists, yet insiders are hard-pushed to recall a single big scoop.

'When you look at the firepower we have, a lot of our output is purely on-diary,' one critical BBC insider said. 'The business world is as much about exclusives as any other. Jeff lives and breathes scoops. ITV is even worse, and we really must do better.'

A devourer of 24-hour business channels such as CNBC and Bloomberg News, Dyke is already putting licence-payers' money where his mouth is. Last month, the BBC's 30-year-old business flagship, The Money Programme , switched from a formulaic, presenter-led magazine on a Sunday night to a single-issue format broadcast in midweek. In December, BBC2's Working Lunch, will trial a 60-minute midday slot, against half-an-hour now. BBC Online , fighting umpteen internet news rivals, is about to double its business staff.

Next autumn, the Beeb launches its new BBC3 and BBC4 digital TV channels. 'BBC4 will be current affairs, arts and definitely a daily business programme - a sort of Radio 4 agenda for TV,' one BBC executive said. 'BBC3's 18-35 audience will also have youngsters aspiring to be internet zillionaires. But the real battleground is getting more into the Rolls-Royce: the bulletins on BBC1.'

The combative Randall is hardly classic Beeb material. A tough taskmaster, though said to be fun to work for, he won't stand for meetings about meetings, paranoid navel-gazing or the 'on the one hand, on the other' school of dull reporting. He made his name as City editor of the Sunday Times under Andrew Neil in the Eighties, cultivating personalities - self-made tycoons such as Gerald Ronson, Alan Sugar and George Walker - to produce a string of business scoops.

Sunday Business , where Neil is again his boss and the secretive Barclay brothers his paymasters, has been a sur prising success since Randall relaunched maverick publisher Tom Rubython's discredited title three years ago. On sales of 60,000 a week, losses have fallen sharply and the paper is now heading for the black, insiders say.

But Randall is not just a reporter in the business game; he is now very much a player. He was instrumental, for example, in the £550 million break-up of the Sears retail empire, which included Warehouse and Miss Selfridge: he persuaded the Barclays to stump up the cash for his pal Philip Green. And he used his contacts with Rupert Murdoch last year to broker a settlement of Belize billionaire Michael Ashcroft's libel suit against the Times.

There's no doubt that the straight-talking, sports-mad Dyke and Randall hit it off like a stadium on fire. 'It's all part of Greg getting his team around him: all blokes, all mates and no bullshit,' said one BBC insider. But, like Terry Venables with the Football Association, can Randall resist the player within and put up with stuffed shirts at the BBC for the full five years of his contract?

Four big business stories the BBC screwed up

Vodafone/Mannesmann:

Worth a record £90 billion, the mobile phone bid - creating Britain's biggest company - was missed by BBC News when it was announced before Christmas last year.

The supermarket inquiry:

The BBC led its news bulletin on the DTI's whitewash of 'Rip Off Britain' last month. But its coverage - with reporters filling grocery baskets at checkouts around Europe - was lazy, missed the point, and embarrassed Dyke.

The BBC treated Rover's divorce from BMW like a 1970s industrial relations story, even dragging out 'Red Robbo' for his views. The crippling effect of Rover on its German parent and the bust-ups throughout at BMW received scant emphasis.

Ford's price cuts

The BBC gave great play to Ford's discounting this summer from a consumer angle. But, typically, it failed to give any perspective on Ford's tough market position, low UK profits and the growing pressure on the car giant in the US.

Sunday Business , where Neil is again his boss and the secretive Barclay brothers his paymasters, has been a sur prising success since Randall relaunched maverick publisher Tom Rubython's discredited title three years ago. On sales of 60,000 a week, losses have fallen sharply and the paper is now heading for the black, insiders say. But Randall is not just a reporter in the business game; he is now very much a player. He was instrumental, for example, in the £550 million break-up of the Sears retail empire, which included Warehouse and Miss Selfridge: he persuaded the Barclays to stump up the cash for his pal Philip Green. And he used his contacts with Rupert Murdoch last year to broker a settlement of Belize billionaire Michael Ashcroft's libel suit against the Times. There's no doubt that the straight-talking, sports-mad Dyke and Randall hit it off like a stadium on fire. 'It's all part of Greg getting his team around him: all blokes, all mates and no bullshit,' said one BBC insider. But, like Terry Venables with the Football Association, can Randall resist the player within and put up with stuffed shirts at the BBC for the full five years of his contract? Four big business stories the BBC screwed up Vodafone/Mannesmann: Worth a record £90 billion, the mobile phone bid - creating Britain's biggest company - was missed by BBC News when it was announced before Christmas last year. The supermarket inquiry: The BBC led its news bulletin on the DTI's whitewash of 'Rip Off Britain' last month. But its coverage - with reporters filling grocery baskets at checkouts around Europe - was lazy, missed the point, and embarrassed Dyke. The BBC treated Rover's divorce from BMW like a 1970s industrial relations story, even dragging out 'Red Robbo' for his views. The crippling effect of Rover on its German parent and the bust-ups throughout at BMW received scant emphasis. Ford's price cuts The BBC gave great play to Ford's discounting this summer from a consumer angle. But, typically, it failed to give any perspective on Ford's tough market position, low UK profits and the growing pressure on the car giant in the US.

webTitle: On broadcast: Steve Barnett

fields.headline: I'm no do-gooder. I love ads. But is nothing sacred?
fields.standfirst:
On broadcast: Steve Barnett

Special report: the future of the BBC
fields.trailText: On broadcast: Steve Barnett
fields.body:
There was a time when 'commercial' was a dirty word at the BBC. Not so long ago, and many years after the puritanism of Lord Reith had been watered down, the sight of a branded cereal packet on a fictional BBC kitchen table or the accidental filming of a car manufacturer's name during a dramatic police chase was enough to send the prop handlers scurrying off for plain cardboard boxes or masking tape. Blue Peter had nothing on the creative inventions of BBC programme makers determined to protect the untainted name of the non-commercial BBC.

One might be charitable and say that BBC producers were demonstrating an admirable determination to protect their public funding. After all, many of their public-service counterparts around the world were slipping into that dangerous mixed economy which eventually saw the demise of the licence fee.

I suspect, however, that the attitude had less to do with preserving the sanctity of the licence fee and more with a patronising distaste for all things commercial. Advertising was grubby. Worse, it smacked of trade. It was sales manship, the kind of thing those horrid, spotty youths in white nylon shirts indulged in at your front door, trying to get you to buy an insurance policy or encyclopaedia.

One didn't enter a career in distinguished public service - even if it was making soap operas or sitcoms - to have it sullied by the tacky practice of feeding on other people's greed. As George Orwell once said: 'Advertising is the rattling of a stick inside a swill bucket.'

Things have changed since then. Nevertheless, there is still a sneaking suspicion of ambivalence towards all things commercial at the BBC. This, presumably, is what lies behind Greg Dyke's critical comments about the BBC's business coverage, not to mention the words of his new business editor elect, Jeff Randall, about patronising, middle class, guilt-ridden do-gooders at the BBC. We haven't heard such unstinting praise since Norman Tebbit chaired the Tory Party.

I'm therefore reluctant to condemn unconditionally Dyke's idea of putting ads on the BBC s internet services. Nevertheless, it is a thoroughly lousy idea. This is not just because of the now well-trodden arguments about tips of icebergs, domino effects, or being-a-little-bit-pregnant - though I have no doubt that the principle, once breached, would be hard to sustain on other services. It is also because we ought to be interested in keeping a little cultural haven across all electronic media which is not steeped in the language of salesmanship.

Before I'm accused by Randall of indulging in the worst kind of guilt-ridden do-gooding, I should explain that I love advertising. Not only are some of the country's most ingenious and creative minds employed in producing some thoroughly entertaining commercial content, advertising is also the engine-room of a dynamic economy. It creates and sustains demand; it provides jobs. At its best, it is an art form.

Moreover, it offers vital information. Without advertising, I would never have known that my seven-year-old craves a Teksta interactive robotic puppy for Christmas. Nor, for that matter, would she - or the hundreds of other parents who have piled down to their local toy shops in the past few weeks, making it impossible to find a Teksta and, presumably, creating in the process one very successful toy manufacturer (not to mention one potentially very miserable seven-year-old).

Every media platform, every kind of content, almost every tangible surface has been given over in some form to brand names, symbols or outright pleas to buy. Advertisers are racking their brains to think of new ways of insinuating their messages into our lives. (The most novel idea I heard was for pubs to sell the space on men's urinals to makers of beer and hangover cures.) As media proliferate, so does the need for commercial ingenuity.

There's nothing wrong with that. Equally, there is nothing wrong with wanting to maintain a small public space - be it on television, radio or the internet - where we know we are not being targeted by people who want to sell us something. In a week when a former Goldman Sachs partner spent £40 million in New Jersey to advertise himself into the American Senate, we should think very carefully before surrendering our last remaining commercial-free public space to the salesmen.

The pro-advertising lobby usually consists of free-market enthusiasts who believe that a commercial environment guarantees greater sensitivity to the needs and wishes of consumers. But those who argue for consumer choice must accept that in Britain many people choose to watch TV or radio without interruptions from advertisers or sponsors. Dyke should accept that the same applies to the internet.

webTitle: The day the protest ran out of steam

fields.headline: The day the protest ran out of steam
fields.standfirst:
Jeers greet the petrol lobby's Jarrow convoy as the roads stay clear... but our trains grind to a halt

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: The mood was angry as Andrew Spence, leader of the Jarrow convoy, clambered on top of the trailer and addressed a handful of drivers. Holding up a yellow piece of paper with a black square in the middle, he did not pull his punches.
fields.body:
The mood was angry as Andrew Spence, leader of the Jarrow convoy, clambered on top of the trailer and addressed a handful of drivers. Holding up a yellow piece of paper with a black square in the middle, he did not pull his punches.

'The police have said we have to put this on our windscreens. That to me is a Jewish star. That is the way I feel about it,' he said.

Harried by police and environmental protesters, the self-styled Jarrow crusade of about 30 vehicles, each bearing a yellow badge, yesterday trundled slowly through the rain across the North of England from Leeds to Manchester. They feel the country has turned against them, but are still determined to take their call for lower fuel prices to London.

'It is not the number of drivers that is important, it is the message we are carrying that matters,' said Mark Francis, a leader of the People's Fuel Lobby, which is behind the protest.

The drivers feel the police have discouraged people from joining the convoy and have treated them like pariahs. As Spence made his speech, a haulier shouted: 'This is a police state.'

'There is no intimidation. We want a peaceful protest,' said police spokesman Sergeant Francis Habgood.

But the police have a highly visible presence. They swarm around the protest in cars and on bikes. A police car, not a protest vehicle, sets the speed of the convoy. Officers have told the drivers that if they stray from their formation and attempt to block traffic they will be arrested and the convoy has been barred from going near the city centres of York, Leeds, Manchester and London. They must keep to main roads. Police cameras film the unlikely revolutionaries as they pass beneath motorway bridges, infuriating the protesters. 'Are we such a threat to Tony Blair? Are we really that dangerous?' fumed Spence.

At the moment they are not. But more drivers may join them as they head south through the Midlands, protesters claim. The convoy is still aiming for London, and even if they have to leave their vehicles outside London they are determined to have their day of protest at the heart of the capital. 'It doesn't matter how we get there, the last 25 miles will not be a problem. We will walk if we have to,' said John Coxon, one of the convoy's leaders.

According to Francis, London taxi drivers have offered to ferry protesters to Hyde Park from the police-designated parking areas. But it is all a far cry from the hundreds of trucks bringing chaos to London and jamming the M25 that the protesters originally hoped for.

Only days ago, the Government portrayed them as barbarians at the gate, threatening the country with a series of blockades of refineries and food depots. In reality the convoy has seemed to blend with the already heavy traffic on the road and segments towards the rear have become lost. On Friday one group ended up heading towards Hull before a flurry of mobile phone calls brought them back on to the correct path. Now the talk is of peaceful protest and a quiet dispersal after London.

Minor government concessions have contributed to the disappointment. Some would-be protesters may also have been deterred by fears that the public, already beset by flood and rail chaos, would not tolerate more disruption.

The convoy got off to an inauspicious start. The first group left Berwick on Thursday with just six vehicles. Only two, a cement mixer and a four-wheel-drive Toyota, arrived in Newcastle for the gaggle of television cameras. By Friday there were 70 trucks for the drive through Newcastle, but they included the eccentric as well as those genuinely threatened by the high cost of fuel.

One retired haulier was just there for the day. He had missed the September protests, he explained, because he was yachting in Spain. Elsewhere was a leather-clad biker on a Harley; another man brought an ageing school bus, and a farmer on a tractor hauled a load of manure on which had been spiked a blow-up plastic alien - apparently intended as a reference to Gordon Brown. 'We are going to London,' Spence told them all. 'It is London or bust for us, because a lot of us will be bust if things go on like they are.'

They were matched in number by protesters who were demanding an end to the convoy. Some were from Greenpeace, others from Friends of the Earth, and a group of elderly women were from Jarrow, outraged at the perceived hijacking of the name of the 1936 hunger march. 'Jarrow marched for need, not greed,' called one pensioner as a heavy lorry thundered by.

Police cars and bikes led the convoy and followed it. In Newcastle, hundreds more police held up traffic and ushered the convoy quickly over the Tyne and then back again.

No one went to Jarrow.

webTitle: Comment: Petrol blackmailers dare to hijack Jarrow

fields.headline: Now they even dare to hijack Jarrow
fields.standfirst:
The memory of the hunger marchers of 1936 has been traduced by the petrol blackmailers of 2000

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: The memory of the hunger marchers of 1936 has been traduced by the petrol blackmailers of 2000.
fields.body:
To a Geordie working-class boy growing up in the Fifties, knowing a man who had been on the Jarrow March was the equivalent of a Sloane Ranger knowing a man who once knew a girl who danced with the Prince of Wales.

I was fortunate enough to know Sammy Rowan, the man with the cigarette in the foreground of that defining picture taken as the rain-soaked marchers arrived in London in 1936, after 291 miles and three weeks on the road.

My father, who was a friend of Sammy, took me to meet him when I left school in Hebburn-on-Tyne hoping to get into journalism. For someone who had been the administrator on a crusade to find work for 8,000 men in the year I was born, Sammy was in an appropriate job when I met him in 1952. He was the youth employment officer for Jarrow and Hebburn.

He couldn't help me directly, for his skills were deployed mainly in placing boys in the shipyards or engineering factories that were then booming on Tyneside. But he was a kind man, and his knowledge of how the press worked - gleaned from the hours he had spent briefing them during the march - enabled him to give me some good advice. I should write to the news editor, not the editor, of the local newspaper, and I should enrol in evening classes for shorthand and typing so that I could mention it in my letter.

His advice must have helped, for I got the job and I'm now able to pay tribute to the late Sammy Rowan. I want to put on record that he would be dismayed and angered at the way the ethos of the Jarrow March has been hijacked and traduced by the hauliers and the farmers who set out on their drive from his town on Friday.

Sitting in the warm cab of a lorry with country and western on the radio and a Yorkie on the dashboard is so far removed from the ideals and experiences of the Jarrow marchers that it's almost obscene.

The haulier is not leaving behind him children who have rickets or who are so undernourished that they don't have the stamina for a full day at school. I doubt, too, if he leaves behind a wife getting thin, unintentionally, because she apportions more food to her man and her children than she does to herself.

The farmer in his four-wheel-drive has never known the humiliation of spending 15 years without work, unable to support his family, which was the experience of many Jarrow workers who joined that march in 1936.

Even if every haulier and every farmer went bankrupt, the Government they vilify would not let them go hungry. Many people in Jarrow did go hungry in the Thirties, though the organisers of the march went to great lengths to stress that it was a crusade to bring work to the town and not a hunger march.

Seebohm Rowntree, the leading social scientist of the day, and founder of the Rowntree Trust, calculated that the bare necessity for survival for a man with a wife and three children required an income of 53 shillings a week (£2. 65 in today's money). But unemployment benefit for such a family was 32 shillings (£1.60) a week.

'There is no escape anywhere from the prevailing misery,' wrote J.B. Priestley, visiting Jarrow for his book, An English Journey. 'Wherever we went there were men hanging about, not scores of them, but hundreds and thousands of them. The whole town looked as if it had entered a penniless bleak Sabbath.'

Yet Jarrow had been one of the greatest industrial centres in the world. The Palmer steelworks and shipyard could take in iron ore at one end of its river frontage and turn out battleships and liners at the other. When Palmer's closed in the world slump between 1920 and 1931, 74 per cent of all the workers in Jarrow became unemployed.

Grass grew over the launching ways. The enforced idleness of the men on the street corners was like an indefinite prison sentence. To try to end this despair the whole town got together behind the idea of the march on London - a unique initiative, for it was organised by the town council and had the support of all the political parties in Jarrow, and all the churches.

It was truly a town march, to present a petition to Parliament asking for work. And just in case anyone doubted this, two of the 200 men on the march were chosen each day to carry the box containing the petition, slung reverentially between them on silken cords as if it were the Ark of the Covenant.

In thinking of the late Sammy Rowan and what the Jarrow marchers did then compared with what the fuel protesters are doing now, I'm reminded of David Dougan's definition in his history of the march: 'It did not represent a faction or a dissatisfied segment of society. It represented all the people of Jarrow, irrespective of political party, religion or position, acting together for their common good.'

The hauliers and farmers could argue that the objective of their drive from Jarrow to London is also for their common good. But the fuel protest is against a tax that only diminishes the quality of their life. The marchers of 1936 were appealing for work so that they could sustain life itself.

webTitle: Comment: Cutting fuel by 10p in four (fairly) easy steps

fields.headline: Cutting fuel by 10p in four (fairly) easy steps
fields.standfirst:
Open it up: Andrew Oswald

Related special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Serious trouble lurks. According to one version, favoured particularly by cyclists with PhDs, it goes like this.
fields.body:
Serious trouble lurks. According to one version, favoured particularly by cyclists with PhDs, it goes like this.

Britain should stand firm. We must hope that Radio 4 does not go off the air; that would hurt. A month should do it. With luck, any death toll would be low. We must be prepared to let the fuel protesters eat cake while they block our streets. We can, and should, out-sit them. Eventually they will go home and Britain will start to work again: all we need is a large supply of Evian and home-made bread. Pass the Camembert.

Maybe. There is certainly a sound intellectual case for high fuel taxes. And it is not the job of economists to solve political problems. But protesters now believe that high fuel taxes, this week's pre-Budget statement notwithstanding, have broken a law of natural justice, and fairness is in the eye of the beholder and not in the bibliography of an economics textbook.

It is our job to offer options to politicians - to suggest possibilities to those interested in listening to alternatives. If we cannot make high fuel taxes stick because of taxpayer revolt, here is a sensible compromise plan.

1. Eliminate inequitable comparisons.

Call together the leaders of the main European nations, and agree to harmonise the rates of fuel tax. This does not make sense in an economics textbook but would in the real world. Currently, for instance, Britain's fuel duty is far higher than in the rest of Europe. This is important: when notions of fairness matter, it is necessary to stop people making unfavourable comparisons.

Globalisation means people now think it perfectly natural to compare their lives with the lives of citizens of other nations. We need to stop protesters from being able to say 'But fuel duty is only 25p a litre in Luxembourg' (which it is, by the way). To begin to do this in Britain may mean bringing the tax on fuel down by at least 10p a litre, thereby creating a pump price of around 70p rather than 80p. This would lead to a loss in tax revenue of about £5 billion.

2. Tax air travel more.

We would have to find the missing £5bn of tax revenue from somewhere, and it would be important strategically to make Opec bear the cost. So we could agree, in a coordinated way across the European nations, to levy steep air taxes. Tax on plane travel is currently remarkably low, which makes no sense when large amounts of aviation fuel are consumed, when burning that kind of fuel produces the same proportion of carbon dioxide as petrol, and when motoring taxes are so high that Western Europe's society is apparently in danger of not functioning peacefully.

We use about 22 million tonnes of petrol a year, about 15 million tonnes of DERV for trucks, and about 10 million tonnes of aviation fuel. We could also remove the current VAT exemption on international passenger transport. This loophole costs approximately £2bn a year in lost tax revenue.

Coal is the West's worst polluter. Unit for unit, it is a much more important source of greenhouse gases than any other source, especially compared with unleaded motor fuel. Currently Britain charges a reduced rate of VAT on domestic fuel and power, and the loss from that to the Exchequer is approximately £2bn. If we fix that, we have closed the £5bn gap.

Arithmetically at least, there is thus a way to pay for a 10p per litre reduction in motor fuel tax. This does not make it right, merely feasible.

And let's face facts. Large-scale civil disobedience ultimately corrodes the quality of a society. Democracy means having to find a middle ground between the plane of economic sense and the plain of commonsense.
