webTitle: Petrol - who needs it?

fields.headline: Petrol - who needs it?
fields.standfirst:
Ultra low-sulphur fuel is not green enough. But manufacturers are now looking seriously at developing cleaner cars. Joanna Walters reports

Special report: the Budget
fields.trailText: Ultra low-sulphur fuel is not green enough. But manufacturers are now looking seriously at developing cleaner cars.
fields.body:
Anyone proclaiming that cars should run on vegetable oil or batteries is normally regarded as at best 'alternative', at worst eccentric.

But these are anything but normal times.

How many people, caught up in panic-buying last week and now braced for more queues at filling stations as another round of fuel protests looms, are thinking: 'I wish my car ran on electricity, hydrogen...apple juice - anything but petrol or diesel'?

With fist fights on the forecourts and flood waters swirling as we melt the planet, the days when we can rely on fossil fuels for power and transport are surely numbered. Will the 'green' car idea finally have its day and, first and foremost, does it actually exist?

Nick Reilly, chief executive of UK-based carmaker Vauxhall, says: 'Nations are making commitments to reduce carbon dioxide levels and I am sure once we reach those levels, further targets will be set. There is only so far you can go with the internal combustion engine, and it is very important that we explore different directions.'

The good news is that whereas five years ago these issues were hardly on the industrial radar screen, now all the world's major motor manufacturers have huge 'green' programmes and boast senior executives with titles such as 'vice-president, environment'.

The prize for the company that cracks the formula for the green car of the future before its rivals will be measured in trillions of dollars. The prize for the human race will be cleaner air.

The bad news is that those same companies have found that solving the technology problem of alternative fuels is taking more time and money than they expected.

And Britain has a poor track record for both running green cars, and for subsidising green schemes and encouraging wind and wave power. This is despite the UK having some of the worst congestion and pollution, the highest level of car dependency - and more wind and waves than anywhere in Europe.

But while the most obvious alternatives to the car are still public transport, two-wheelers or working from home, alternative-fuel vehicles are moving up the agenda - especially with the railways in chaos.

Leading car makers such as Ford, General Motors (Vauxhall's parent), Honda, Toyota and Daimler-Chrysler are all busy researching what they see as the most likely future alternatives to petrol and diesel - and some are greener than others.

Most agree that the long-term solution will be cars powered by fuel cells that run on the electrical current generated when you combine hydrogen and oxygen through a catalytic membrane. It's likely to be the winning technology because it is the most efficient and will give the most power for the lowest emissions.

But fuel cells are proving devilishly difficult to perfect at anything like an affordable price, and are some way off entering the mainstream.

Other avenues of exploration are battery power, bio-diesel made from vegetable oil and methanol, liquid petroleum gas, liquefied natural gas, compressed natural gas and hybrid engines that supplement fossil fuel power with electric power. Prototype vehicles running on any of these alternatives are already in evidence here and there around the globe.

Matthew Spencer, energy campaign director for environmental group Greenpeace, says: 'Until these vehicles are delivered to car showrooms, you have to remain a bit sceptical about the manufacturers' claims to have seen the light. We don't want prototypes any more; we want the real thing. But these companies are much keener to sell huge, gas-guzzling off-road cars and people-carriers than the smallest, most fuel-efficient cars.'

At the British Motor Show in Birmingham last month, Japan's Honda claimed it would have fuel cell cars on sale by 2003, narrowly beating Ford and GM to market.

Honda's general manager of car sales in the UK, Mark Davies, says: 'That's a pretty steep target. It is not so much the technology that's hard to crack; it is making it cost- effective. At the moment a fuel-cell Honda Civic would cost £150,000, and no one is going to buy that.'

But Honda has made something to bridge the gap. In September it launched the hybrid-engined Civic, which so far has sold about 60 in the UK. Each one costs £24,000 to make but has a retail price tag of £17,000. If they were more popular this would be a substantial loss but with the price of a regular Civic averaging £14,000, the company is forced to subsidise the hybrid. Even at that price, it is only for the dedicated.

The hybrid looks like a regular Civic except that half of the boot space is taken up by a battery. The four-cylinder engine has effectively had one of its cylinders chopped off and replaced by an electric motor that supplements the normal engine power.

When the car decelerates, the frictional energy that creates is drawn off the engine and stored in the battery. When the car speeds up that stored energy is released to boost the power of the petrol engine - giving the three-cylinder, 1,000cc engine the equivalent power of 1,600cc and four cylinders.

Honda claims it feels like a normal car to drive and gives a typical 83 miles per gallon, compared with its regular Civic cousin's 42mpg.

Davies says: 'I drove one for two weeks during the last fuel crisis and thought it would feel like a milk float, but it was nippy and enormous fun to drive.'

It must have been particular fun to drive past the filling station queues.

Davies says: 'I believe that fossil fuels will be firmly with us for the next 10 to 15 years while we are developing the fuel cell and experimenting with electricity. I still believe the internal combustion engine will be around, but we must strive for virtually zero-emissions vehicles.'

Some leading car makers have contracted out the work of researching alternative fuels to smaller, specialist companies, or have formed partnerships with those companies.

Westport Innovations, based in Vancouver, is working for Ford on switching diesel engines to run on natural gas, which is half the price of diesel and about one- twentieth as 'dirty'. It is focusing its research on Ford's diesel engine plant at Dagenham, Essex, and with German truck maker Mann.

Westport chief executive David Demers says the rewards for the companies that produce the most successful alternatives to petrol and diesel vehicles for the future are enormous. The worldwide annual sale of new vehicles is worth about $1 trillion, and sale of fuel to power them around $2 trillion.

Demers says: 'I think the majority of new car sales will still be powered by traditional methods in 20 years' time, although they will be much more efficient and probably totally recyclable. But even if that means almost half the market is taken up by alternative-fuel vehicles, that is huge potential.'

The motor manufacturers have based their business on petrol engines for more than 100 years and it is hardly surprising that they and the big oil companies have been reluctant to sing from the green song sheet.

Demers concludes: 'All the innovations are very exciting, but I do not think we will be getting away from the internal combustion engine for at least another 50 years.'

webTitle: Comment: Don't tax the petrol, tax heavy road users

fields.headline: Don't tax the petrol, tax heavy road users
fields.standfirst:
Pin it down: David Begg

Related special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: If the car had been invented in today's world rather than that of 100 years ago we would never have started where we are now with motoring taxation.
fields.body:
If the car had been invented in today's world rather than that of 100 years ago we would never have started where we are now with motoring taxation.

While the car has evolved into a technologically efficient machine to meet today's conditions, the tax regime has not even begun to come to terms with its role in juggling demand with resources.

This is true for all countries - indeed the UK has made comparatively positive steps forward with powers for congestion-charging and hypothecation (raising tax for a specific purpose).

Motoring taxes are unpopular with drivers, penalise rural motorists, encourage congestion, hit haulage companies and don't deliver an efficient and smoothly flowing road system.

While there is little any Chancellor can do at a stroke to correct these historic mistakes we are at last beginning to make some headway.

At the moment the Exchequer each year takes £28 billion in VAT on new vehicles, annual vehicle excise duty and fuel duty, of which only £5bn is spent on our roads network. Up to £16bn in lost productivity annually is attributed to congestion on those roads.

The Government's room for manoeuvre is limited, though. With the British loathing for any increase in direct taxation, motorists are going to have to continue to help subsidise the education, health and social services of our nation.

But the Government's 10-year plan for transport is a major step in the right direction, with a larger share of tax on road use going back into transport investment and new powers for congestion-charging and hypothecation.

At the same time, although the motoring public has vetoed any major roadbuilding programmes as environmentally unacceptable, we are all continuing to drive further.

So in the future we will be competing with each other more often for the same piece of road space. Lower fuel duty would only encourage us to drive further still.

It sounds a bleak picture but it doesn't have to be. Already the Government has made some change at the margins in switching taxation from car ownership to car use.

By leaning on car manufacturers the Government has helped to achieve a reduction of up to 19 per cent in new car prices. Meanwhile the Government has reduced the level of excise duty for smaller, more environmentally friendly cars.

However, for the longer term much more needs to be done. A good starting point would be to examine how the same overall tax take could best be re-targeted to achieve some core objectives.

Some obvious priorities might be to:

* Introduce a taxation regime that helps offer the road haulage and public transport industries the predictable, congestion-free, journey times that customers need for a just-in-time delivery service.

* Provide tax relief for rural and marginal motorists dependent on cars for both shopping and employment.

* Offer incentives to companies and services that locate near their customers rather than on greenfield sites.

* Promise premium long-distance road services at premium prices.

* Deliver congestion-free city centres for both public transport and the motorist at a price/benefit ratio that drivers recognise as fair.

But none of this is going to be achieved with the tax on petrol, which takes no account of where and how people are using their cars. For example, someone in the country using his or her car to go to the village shop has precious little impact on the environment or congestion compared with a city dweller taking thecar to work through the rush hour.

The Adam Smith Institute has estimated that the external costs in terms of congestion and pollution of a car in a rural area run at 8p a mile while in a city the figure rises to 48p.

Fuel duty is a blunt charge on the number of miles we each drive, offering none of the sophisticated charging mechanisms we see with other public utilities. However technology now makes it feasible to offer our motoring taxation the same degree of sophistication. We now have the ability to charge motorists via a 'meter' in their cars for the amount of road space they consume - a version of gas, electricity and water meters. It can vary charges by the day of the week, the time of day we drive and where we are going - matching demand to price.

On our motorways, charging higher prices for using them at peak times would encourage people to spread their journeys - getting the most out of the network - and to consider other travel options. Similar charging on our trunk roads would discourage drivers from looking for a cheap option elsewhere.

The benefits would be enormous. We would once again be able to plan our journey times with a degree of certainty. Journey times would become shorter and less stressful. And motorists would feel they were getting something for their money. As a result the cost of motoring could drop dramatically for rural motorists while peak-time users would have to pay more - but get better journeys as a result.

Meanwhile, drivers would start to consider the true cost of motoring - something our European neighbours have been doing for years on their tolled motorways. The alternatives of an intercity train or internal flight suddenly wouldn't seem so out of balance.

The same principle would apply in our cities, where motorists have more choice already in their journeys - but where the pressures on our roads are already higher.

Here opinion polls have shown that motorists would be prepared to pay far more for city congestion charging than they are paying in fuel duty now to retain the opportunity to drive in our cities. A Mori survey for the Commission for Integrated Transport earlier this year found 81 per cent of people opposed to any petrol price rise while just 35 per cent opposed congestion charging in certain circumstances.

Congestion-charging revenue will boost the quality of public transport, although many or most motorists will stick to their cars. Still, at least that will be their choice. Part of the problem is that under our historic taxation system drivers don't feel they have any options.

 Professor David Begg is chair of the Commission For Integrated Transport.

webTitle: Brown trades favour now for future deficit

fields.headline: Brown trades favour now for future deficit
fields.standfirst:
William Keegan on the consequences of moves to tackle the political emergency over fuel and pensions

Special report: the Budget
Related special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: William Keegan on the consequences of moves to tackle the political emergency over fuel and pensions.
fields.body:
The conservatives were right to dub Gordon Brown's Pre-Budget Report a 'Post-Budget Report' - post-Budget 2000, that is, rather than pre-Budget 2001 (as New Labour likes to call these things.) Last March the Chancellor had no intention of making concessions to pensioners. He was aware of the pensioners' history, Lady Barbara Castle and Jack Jones, but dismissive of it.

The trick he missed at the time was to emphasise that it was because of the Government's success in controlling inflation that the adjustment for prices was only 75p. But the mere fact that the rise was so low would in any case have drawn attention to how low the basic state pension is - at the lower end of the cost of dinner for Tony Blair and Gordon Brown at Islington's Granita restaurant.

The Chancellor's new 'pensioners' package' is a recognition of political reality - of the fact that the pensioners' lobby gathered strength during the spring and summer, turning up in force at the Labour Conference. The 'short-termism' of boasting that he is 'giving away' more than would be required by indexing pensions to earnings is pretty barefaced. There is no long-term commitment to indexing pensions to earnings, except for those qualifying for the minimum income guarantee and 'low- and modest-income pensioners'. Qualifying requires filling in vast forms, whose complexity has been known to defeat doctors of philosophy.

When Brown came to office, he promised the biggest welfare reforms since Beveridge and the 1945-50 inception of the welfare state under the Attlee government. The whole idea of the welfare state was that it offered decent state provision when necessary 'from cradle to grave'. It was a system of national insurance under which people paid their contributions and got their legitimate reward in time of sickness and in old age.

Despite the electoral goodies being offered to pensioners in the Pre-Budget Report - and the money is certainly a lot more generous than originally envis aged - New Labour has now basically accepted the Conservative plan to erode the value of the state pension over time and make private pensions a necessary precaution of old age.

There is no doubting Brown's good intentions, nor his and his strategists' desire to do as much as they can within the narrow confines of what they think their focus groups will permit, to 'redistribute' income and heal the poor. But it is interesting that it took a pensioners' revolt to push them this far, and the fact is that after all these years, there is a lot of ground to make up. Nevertheless, all pensioners do well in the short term, and the Conservative plan to remove their perks is just bad politics.

Which brings us to the other revolt, that of the fuel protesters. Despite the scorn that has been poured on the Chancellor from all sides, it is pretty obvious that in the world of practical politics he had little alternative but to demonstrate that, while not being prepared to cave in completely to their demands, he had to show he was listening. What happened during the protesters' first revolt gave the Government a bigger fright than it was ever prepared to admit. Ironically, it had been on to the general movement for some time; indeed the last Budget demonstrated that it knew the point of resistance to fuel taxes had been reached. It was the degree of resistance that took Ministers unawares. So more concessions had to be made.

Chancellors are sometimes credited with inventing new taxes; to judge from the reactions, Brown has almost been credited with inventing a new fuel. Few people seemed even to have heard of 'low-sulphur petrol' on 'Budget day'. Now, no doubt in return for a distinct absence of a windfall levy on their profits, the oil companies will be serving it to all and sundry by Easter.

Contrary to what some sceptics have claimed, there is indeed an environmental aspect to the fiscal incentive to shift to low-sulphur fuels. Scientific research indicates that sulphurous emissions can damage your health and your forests. On the other hand there appears to be precious little connection with that great concern of our time, global warming. This is not a Budget to eliminate or even reduce floods.

The pensioners' package and the relief for road hauliers were the main constituents of what it is fair to describe as a 'mini-Budget'. When Brown came to office he tended to deride the old-fashioned practice of 'mini-Budgets'; but he has deemed it judicious, rightly in my view, to bow to 'events, dear boy, events'.

But this is not a mini-Budget in the old sense of being introduced in an economic emergency to boost or rein back demand and economic activity. It is a mini-Budget because of a political emergency. The cost of the pensions and road haulage packages is put at £4 billion a year; but it so happens that because of the buoyancy of the economy, income and other tax receipts are running at over £4bn a year more than expected at the time of the March Budget. There is very little change in fiscal balance.

This is in accord with the Chancellor's philosophy, which is to leave economic management almost entirely to the Bank of England, once he has set out his spending priorities. These have been simple: to freeze and save in the early years of his chancellorship - to gain a reputation for fiscal prudence; and to increase public spending more rapidly than gross domestic product during the second phase - to do something about the nation's obvious discontents.

Time and time again the Chancellor has emphasised that he has a 'golden rule' for the nation's finances. To quote the Pre-Budget Report: 'The Government will borrow only to invest and not fund current spending.' Many observers are under the impression that he aims to balance the current Budget over the economic cycle. But he goes further than that. The report states that 'it [the golden rule] is met when, over the economic cycle, the current budget is in balance or surplus '.

Contrary to the popular impression, he cannot 'spend' much of any surplus at a time of near full employment without prompting the Bank of England's monetary policy committee to raise interest rates to keep the economy in balance. There was careful consideration between Treasury and Bank before the Pre-Budget Report was launched, and the committee made its no-change decision on interest rates last week.

But over the next few years the current surplus is forecast to halve from 1.5 per cent of GDP this financial year to 0.7 per cent in 2004-05, while the overall finances move from a surplus of 0.8 per cent of GDP in 2000-01 to a deficit of 1.1 per cent in 2004-05 (as measured by what the Treasury calls cyclically adjusted public-sector net borrowing). This reflects the fact that public spending is due to rise at some 3.5 per cent a year, against an estimated 2.5 per cent average growth rate for the economy as a whole.

The Chancellor's report takes pride in the state of the finances, buoyancy of the economy, approach to full employment and low level of inflation. But it reflects a continuing concern with the UK's low levels of productivity, and once again many of the proposed micro tax measures are aimed one way or another at improving productivity.

Beneath the upbeat pre-election tone of much of the presentation lie other sources of unease. The report notes that 'business investment has decelerated significantly since early 1999' - from 7.5 per cent growth to a mere 1.75 per cent this year.

This reflects 'weaker output growth and declining profitability'. It says firms 'have responded to sterling's overall strength by cutting export prices significantly'. Even so there has been a loss of market share.

What prevented the overvaluation of the pound from having a much greater impact than it has had so far was a dramatic doubling in the rate of the world trade growth between 1999 and this year, to 11 per cent. Our export markets are estimated to have grown at 9.25 per cent, but exports at only 8 per cent, while 'import penetration has risen significantly'. The Pre-Budget Report forecasts, on present trends, a rising trade deficit in goods and services, reaching a cumulative £112 bn. over the five years 1999-2003 inclusive.

It is difficult to see how a trade deficit of this magnitude can be sustained indefinitely, but this will be a problem for the next parliament. The Chancellor has done everything he can to make sure he personally inherits that crisis.

webTitle: O'Reilly's new paper falls prey to virus

fields.headline: O'Reilly's new paper falls prey to virus
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Media tycoon Tony O'Reilly's latest acquisition - the Belfast Telegraph - has fallen foul of a computer virus.
fields.body:
Media tycoon Tony O'Reilly's latest acquisition - the Belfast Telegraph - has fallen foul of a computer virus.

Northern Ireland's only evening paper lost two editions and had to send staff home early after an email from Colombia was opened in the systems department.

The Telegraph , which O'Reilly bought for £300 million earlier this year, normally produces four editions six days a week. But the virus crashed all 400 computers at the paper's headquarters off Royal Avenue on 1 November.

The paper's journalists were sent home early around lunchtime as systems managers ordered all the computers to be switched off. They then worked overnight to search for the viruses.

A spokesman for the Telegraph denied that the virus had disrupted production at the paper.

'We did have a virus on November the first and we did have a problem with it,' he said. 'But we produced what was necessary and steps were taken to eradicate the problem.'

But sources at the paper insist production was badly affected by the virus, which was traced to a computer in the Telegraph's systems department, the section that runs all computers in the building.

The systems crash came just a few days before the Belfast Telegraph , the most successful of the Province's three daily papers and the only one read by both sections of the community, won a major award for its internet website.

Tony O'Reilly's bid to buy the paper from the Trinity Mirror group led to an investigation by the Monopolies and Mergers Commission. A rival consortium which included the Ulster Unionist deputy leader John Taylor, who owns a raft of regional newspapers in Northern Ireland, failed to take control of the Telegraph .

O'Reilly's purchase tightened his grip on the Irish newspaper market north and south. He owns the Irish Independent , the Sunday Independent , the Irish Star and the Sunday Life . The former Irish rugby international also has a large stakeholding in the London-based Independent and Independent on Sunday .

The Belfast Telegraph board is headed by his right-hand man in Northern Ireland Brendan Hopkins and also includes Lord Denis Rogan, a senior member of the Ulster Unionist Party, and former Irish rugby star Trevor Ringland.

webTitle: Glossies go to war as editors launch battle for women readers

fields.headline: Glossies go to war as editors launch battle for women readers
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Britain's glossiest magazines are getting in shape, glamming up, and talking dirty in a trans-Atlantic fight for the UK's young, fashion-conscious, sexually-aware women.
fields.body:
Britain's glossiest magazines are getting in shape, glamming up, and talking dirty in a trans-Atlantic fight for the UK's young, fashion-conscious, sexually-aware women.

Two new US titles, soon to hit British news-stands, have shattered the ice-cool demeanour of London's established fashionable monthlies.

Time Warner last week poached some of the biggest names in UK women's magazines to export its glossy In Style to Britain. Dee Nolan, the magazine's editor, raided the manicured ranks of Vogue, Elle, She, Harpers & Queen, Tatler, Zest, Marie Claire and Red, and declared: 'I am the luckiest editor.'

Nolan, a 47-year-old Australian, predicted In Style 's starry mix of fashion, beauty and interiors, wildly successful in the US, would be an instant hit when the first issue hits the newsstands early next year.

'It will be beautiful, fun, fresh, upbeat and indispensable,' she beamed. 'We have got all the strength of In Style in the US and a team here which can translate the essence of the magazine in a UK context.'

Days later another American import unveiled its shock troops in slingbacks. Glamour is the first mass-market women's magazine from the New York-based Condé Nast group - publishers of Vanity Fair and Vogue. Jo Elvin, the magazine's editor who is also Australian, has - like Nolan - poached her key staff from London-based titles, including Cosmopolitan, Marie Claire, Nova, New Woman, Elle and the Femail section of the Daily Mail .

The two editors' battle for talent - dubbed 'Struggle of the Sheilas' - has frayed nerves at Britain's established glossies. Alarmed by the exodus of staff, managers have offered key writers and editors City-style bonuses to carry on doing their jobs.

'We have not seen anything like it,' one senior writer on a leading British title says. 'Everyone is talking about who is leaving, who is staying, who is being offered the most cash.'

The arrival of In Style and Glamour heralds the biggest shake-up in women's magazines since the launch of British Marie Claire and New Woman more than a decade ago. It is more than the usual staff merry-go-round. The two magazines promise to bring a new style to the crowded women's market.

Nolan insists In Style 's celebrity focus will win over a generation reared on Posh 'n' Becks, soap opera and Big Brother. The recent success of People and Heat magazines shows that far from being 'starred out' readers want even more celebrity. ' In Style has a single focus on style and celebrity. We are not trying to be all things to all people,' she says.

For Glamour, size matters. It is the first A5 pocket-sized glossy and will be sold for up to £1 less than its competitors. Elvin insists it will become a necessary accessory, stuffed into countless Prada bowling bags.

'We are going to change the way women's magazines are read. Women do not want to lug around big, heavy titles. What they want is a portable companion. There will be dip-in dip-out, on-the-hop reading, alongside longer, meatier pieces. That means you will get your curl-up-on-the-sofa moments as well as bits that you can read in a minute or two.'

They may not be out yet, but the two titles are already changing the face of British glossies. Most are shifting the centre of editorial gravity away from 'heavier' pieces to frothier content. Vogue has upped its coverage of celebrities, with features on who's got what look and where readers can get it.

Marie Claire has ditched supermodel covers and its serious coverage of women's issues around the world in favour of instant celebrities like Mel from Big Brother. Red editor Sally Brampton resigned last week following criticism that her decision to run political features, including interviews with Tony Blair and Mo Mowlam, was to blame for a circulation slump. Cosmopolitan is rumoured to be introducing new pocket-sized supplements.

Nolan loftily dismisses her rivals' efforts. 'They are trying to anticipate and imitate what they think we will be, but there is nothing I have seen yet that gives me any concern. They are missing the point, but I don't want to give away yet what the point is. I am concerned about In Style 's launch, and not other people's problems. I don't lose a moment's sleep.'

Elvin is equally self-assured. 'Oh, they are all going round changing things and saying Glamour is going to be crap, but I say that about everybody else as well. It is such a competitive nightmare. I am nervous about giving things away but I can say we will offer a more rounded package. We will be sexy and glamorous, not raunchy.'

In public - they turn up at the same do's all the time - Nolan and Elvin affect affection. 'Dee's really nice. Really. There are no daggers or bitchiness,' says Elvin. ' Glamour is an interesting idea,' insists Nolan. Behind the scenes Glamour staff dismiss In Style as ' Hello! magazine with "Stay Slim!" celebrity recipes'. In Style staff describe Glamour as 'the poison dwarf'.

But it is the existing titles that have most to worry about. Glamour and In Style are successes in America already. Their UK marketing budgets are bigger than the editorial budgets of some of their rivals, and they will keep spending until they succeed. Condé Nast is investing £15 million in promoting Glamour over four years, with £5 million earmarked for the first year.

'It is not like the launch of totally new titles that could go under within a few months. Both magazines are strong brands and they will be made to work,' one observer says.

To make matters worse, the new titles will capture a large chunk of the money fashion advertisers spend in Britain, threatening the revenue of UK-based titles. 'Women's magazines live or die by advertising,' one insider says. 'Britain is a small market and everyone is petrified that the advertising pile will be divided up into smaller and smaller bits.'

The past two years have seen a flurry of launches - IPC Media's Nova , Dennis Publishing's PS , BBC Worldwide's Eve , John Brown Publishing's Bare, Eve Pollard's Aura, and Frank, dubbed 'the thinking woman's glossy'. The women's market is more crowded than ever, and behind the upbeat covers the mainstream monthlies are hurting. Aura and Frank have already gone under.

In Style is the fastest-growing women's magazine in the US, trebling circulation since its launch there six years ago. Glamour now sells 2.2 million copies in the US, nipping at the kitten heels of Cosmopolitan, and is number two in Italy.

British women, who spend £230m on magazines each year, have never had so much choice. How they use it next year will determine the future of Britain's style icons. Editors are tightening their La Perla, zipping up their Miu Miu, and fixing their hair. It is going to be a bumpy ride.

fields.headline: Debt fears put boot in to Wembley
fields.standfirst:
Spiralling costs put controversial project in danger

Wembley crisis - Observer special
fields.trailText: 12 November 2000: Spiralling costs put controversial project in danger
fields.body:
The £660 million redevelopment of Wembley stadium is likely to be scaled down in a bid to stop its spiralling costs lumbering the showpiece project with huge debts.

A wide-ranging review of the entire scheme is imminent because of growing fears that English football's new home could turn out to be a financial disaster.

The four-star hotel and office block, which critics claim are unnecessary and expensive add-ons, are the most likely features to be ditched as owners Wembley National Stadium Ltd are forced to justify every element of the 'controversial' project.

The Football Association, which is WNSL's parent company, has decided to scrutinise separately each piece of its subsidiary's business plan. Approval for any element that threatens to be a drain on WNSL's already-precarious finances will be withheld.

Observers fear WNSL may have problems making the £30m annual profit needed to repay interest on the £410m loan that Chase Manhattan bank is currently trying to raise for it in the City. It may now borrow less than that as a way of keeping the project viable. 'Just because someone is happy to give you that amount of money doesn't mean you have to take it all,' said a project insider.

The FA's move is a humiliating blow for Chelsea chairman Ken Bates, who is also chairman of WNSL. He has been determined all along that the new Wembley follow the model he pioneered with Chelsea Village, where a football ground becomes the centrepiece of a major commercial development, including hotel, restaurants and bars.

Three restaurants and three banqueting halls are likely to survive at Wembley, allowing it to host corporate functions and conferences - and reduce its reliance on live events.

webTitle: Showbiz row rages over The Contender

fields.headline: White House blues
fields.standfirst: Never mind the US election fiasco. A showbiz row is raging over political drama  The Contender, which stars Joan Allen, after her co-star Gary Oldman attacked its liberal stance.  Joe Neumaier  hears both sides of the argument
fields.trailText: Never mind the US election fiasco. A showbiz row is raging over political drama The Contender, which stars Joan Allen, after her co-star Gary Oldman attacked its liberal stance. Joe Neumaier hears both sides of the argument.
fields.body:
While Americans were glued to the climax of the election last week, with presidential hopefuls jabbing and sparring in soundbites, the most magnetic candidate was on movie screens, not on the campaign trail. But in an added twist, the movie has led to a heated dispute among the filmmakers that threatens to upstage its success.

The candidate was the fictional Senator Laine Hanson, a Democrat from Ohio, and, as played by Joan Allen in The Contender, she personalises the hot issues, including abortion, religion in schools, adultery, and pre-marital sexual shenanigans. Yet Allen, one of today's most talented and respected actresses, did not want her first leading role to be overly preachy.

'I wanted Laine to be real, to be grounded and multi-dimensional,' says Allen. 'I didn't want her to be sanctimonious; maybe she did have a sex scandal, maybe not; maybe she did steal her friend's husband away, as her rivals claim. I liked the flaws.'

In the film, written and directed by Rod Lurie, Laine is chosen by the President (Jeff Bridges) as his deputy after the Vice-Presi dent dies unexpectedly. But amid backroom machinations and Washington wheeling and dealing, her confirmation hearings quickly go negative. A fire-and-brimstone Republican congressman, Shelly Runyon (Gary Oldman, also one of the film's executive producers, effecting a perfect Midwest accent), dislikes Laine from the start and when sexually explicit pictures from her college days turn up, they give him ammunition. The problem is, Laine refuses to open her life up for dissection.

The synopsis may sound like a Movie of the Week but Lurie, a former Los Angeles film critic with a taste for Seventies political films like The Candidate and All the President's Men, wisely keeps Allen's quiet dignity at the heart of the engrossing drama. She has unsurprisingly emerged as an early Oscar favourite.

'I have a certain paranoia that people might be so fed up with politics they don't want to see a political film, but I think [the elections] feed into it,' says Allen. 'We all know how politicians conduct themselves. Having a sense of that, it was important to make the character as human as we could, by sticking a camera inside her life, almost in a documentary way.'

Despite being played by Oldman, she says the congressman is not necessarily the villain. 'There will be people who come down on his side of the debate. It's not his politics, but his method of undoing her that is his flaw.'

Two such people would be Oldman and his manager and co-producer, Douglas Urbanski. Oldman has been at the centre of a bitter row about the film's political soul, which has almost overshadowed the film's positive critical reception. It began with a magazine interview in which he implied that Lurie altered the political tone of the film while editing to appease Dreamworks, the studio that distributed it, and its Democrat-supporting co-chairmen Steven Spielberg, David Geffen, and Jeffrey Katzenberg.

Oldman believes Runyon, the film's villain, was presented much more sympathetically in the original script and Lurie subsequently betrayed the film's principles after Dreamworks agreed to distribute the film. Since Dreamworks, the studio behind American Beauty and Gladiator , is often praised for its laissez faire attitude towards filmmakers, the accusations have caused a stir in Hollywood especially after Oldman failed to appear at the movie's premiere.

Oldman says: 'I am a little disappointed that you have a company that waves the flag for artists and champions filmmakers such as Woody Allen, and it can't honour something that actually doesn't cost them anything.' Hollywood's liberal bias is hardly new. Election year has seen a procession of starry Democrats backing and funding Gore so Oldman's stance against such powerful figures seems brave and anomalous.

He also complained that Lurie wrongheadedly called his character the villain in press material, and disputed Lurie's theory that he had experienced a type of 'Stockholm syndrome', supposedly oversympathising with his role.

Urbanski has been more forthright, referring to the film as 'almost a Goebbels-like piece of propaganda', posing and answering what he regards as the crucial question. 'Would a publicly left-leaning company, which has made its politics an issue, release a left-leaning film?' he says. 'That's a fair question, but it's loaded. Gary and I stand behind the film; we've never said anything else. But the politics of the film as it ends up are quite different from the film we set out to make. But that's not down to Dreamworks - that's Rod Lurie.

He adds: 'Neither Gary or I saw Runyon as the heavy of the film. Joan's character is an atheist and Gary's is the bad guy? But we were making a film that was in shades of grey, a Rorschach test; in the marketing and press material, Rod became contradictory. Was he influenced? I believe he just morphed. And he developed diarrhoea of the mouth. He began to talk about heroes and villains. He made a horrible comment about Stockholm syndrome, implying that one had to have a mental disorder to see a conservative as sympathetic. That's horrible.

'And he reopened this idea from many years ago that Gary is cantankerous. Gary's a wonderful actor, and a terribly sweet man. He isn't cantankerous - he produced the film!'

Lurie has held his corner but concedes: 'If this was an anti-Clinton film, I don't know if it would have ended up in Dreamworks.' But he stresses that nobody put pressure on him to change the political tone. 'I am a liberal. I have always been a liberal. Douglas thinks all intelligent people must be conservative.'

Lurie may have changed how he saw Oldman's character, but he reportedly wrote the title character specifically with Allen in mind. She joined Chicago's Steppenwolf Theatre Company in 1977, working alongside actors such as John Malkovich and Gary Sinise. She won a 1988 Best Actress Tony Award co-starring with Malkovich on Broadway in Burn This, and early roles in films including Tucker: A Man and His Dream and Ethan Frome led to back-to-back Best Supporting Actress Oscar nominations for Nixon (1995) and The Crucible (1996), and critically lauded performances in The Ice Storm and Pleasantville. In the latter, she adroitly played a Fifties TV sitcom character who discovers desire and sensuality.

'There's always a subtext to everything Joan plays,' says Gary Ross, the writer and director of Pleasantville. 'A depth to the character that isn't in a moment or in a line, it's something that she creates underneath. That's what makes her such a remarkable actress. Joan not only finds the big idea, but the depth and the resonance in that idea.

'For Pleasantville , she had to experience things as if they were entirely new. This was a character who was really more Eve in the garden than June Cleaver. So I needed someone with incredible acting chops, and she was my first and only choice. I begged her to do it, I didn't know anyone else who could bring that complexity.'

Though she's direct and polite with a Middle-American blonde prettiness, one of Allen's specialities is women whose tough sexual and moral choices drive the plot. In addition to Pleasantville , she played a principled woman accused of witchcraft in The Crucible, a wife struggling with changing social mores in The Ice Storm and now she's The Contender, who won't play public games at the expense of her private life.

'One commonality seems to be that they're the moral centre of the films,' says Allen. 'There is a sexuality operating, yes, though it's not overt. In The Contender, Laine has a confidence in herself that you don't ordinarily see; I mean, there's not much sexuality oozing out of female politicians. Laine believes that sex has no place in the political arena, but she is not unaware of its power.'

Despite the fact that Lurie wrote the screenplay with her in mind, Allen, 44, knows that as far as power in Hollywood goes, actresses in their forties still have little of it. 'The older you get, the more difficult it is to find good roles,' she says.

'I might have, I hope, a little easier time of it because I'm basically a character actress, and The Contender has now taken me into the central role. But when Rod shopped the script around to some studios, they wouldn't go along if I was attached. It's not that they don't respect my work - I do feel that I'm respected - it's about bankability. Rod raised the money independently. Maybe after The Contender it'll change, but it is frightening. There's a short list, and I'm not quite on it yet.'

Allen, who lives in New York with her husband, actor Peter Friedman, and their six-year-old daughter Sadie, says that going back to the stage doesn't appeal to her at this point. 'I'm just not hungry for it,' she says. 'I keep hoping I'm going to get hungry for it again, but I'm not.'

Is she hungry for a Best Actress nomination? Asked if she thinks she'll be the contender to beat at next year's Oscars, Allen smiles, looks skyward and shrugs. 'We'll see. People have mentioned it. If there's talk about nominations, it's a nice reflection that the performance is working and that the whole film is working.'

Whether she gets an Oscar nod or not, Allen doesn't kid herself about the lack of good roles for women. Considering that, she says she might be hungry for something different. She'll next be seen as the sorceress Morgause in the TV mini-series The Mists of Avalon about the women in King Arthur's Camelot.

'I liked playing John Travolta's wife in Face/Off because it was so different, though I didn't have any action scenes,' says Allen. 'In Mists of Avalon I got to cast spells! So it might be fun to do an Alien -type movie.'Whichever type of movie she chooses, Allen will surely be voted one of the best things in it.

 The Contender screens at the Regus London Film Festival (020 7928 3232) next week, before going on general release.

webTitle: Charmian 'Liesl' Carr has written a book on The Sound of Music

fields.headline: Caught in a von Trapp...
fields.standfirst: Charmian ‘Liesl’ Carr has had to make a career out of The Sound of Music. Now the tills are alive with sales of her book
fields.trailText: Charmian ‘Liesl’ Carr has had to make a career out of The Sound of Music. Now the tills are alive with sales of her book.
fields.body:
The Sound of Music industry seems to grow in inverse proportion to the careers of the film's stars. Contrast the fortunes of Julie Andrews, now unable to sing and languishing on Hollywood's D-list, or Christopher Plummer, eking out a living in straight-to-video releases, with the cult status enjoyed by the celluloid tale of the von Trapps. The latest in a long line of renaissances has been The Sing-a-Long Sound of Music, a karaoke version doing brisk business in London, Dublin and New York.

The film has developed a life of its own but, in the process, has devoured its cast. Plummer now speaks scathingly of 'the Sound of Mucus', while some of the minor characters are permanently trapped in their alter egos of 1965.

Dan Truhitte, the Nazi telegram boy, Rolf, still reprises his 15 minutes of fame on the American cabaret circuit, complete with blond wig, and is currently trying to find a record label for Gazebo Songs, a shameless play on the location where he sang 'I am Sixteen Going on Seventeen' with the oldest von Trapp child, Liesl. Truhitte is a tragi-comic figure. His opposite number in that scene, Charmian Carr, is harder to place. Now in her late fifties, this week she publishes her autobiography, Forever Liesl. As the title suggests, 99 per cent of it is about the movie, as well it might be since she has had no acting career to speak of since and instead has taken on the mantle of a global ambassador for the film. Wherever there has been a Sound of Music festival in the intervening 35 years, Charmian Carr has been the guest of honour.

Despite innumerable Christmas viewings of the film over the years, I fail to pick Carr out from the half-a-dozen middle-aged women in the dining room of the hotel where we have arranged to meet. The maitre d' has to direct me. Even as I sit down, I am not convinced. My recollection of Liesl is as a strapping lass in a pinafore dress. In front of me is Nancy Reagan's younger sister - tiny, bird-like and trussed up in tight-fitting clothes. It is only when she speaks that I am sure. Her voice is instantly recognisable as the one that announced to Fraulein Maria early in the film: 'I am 16 and I don't need a governess.'

'They made me put on weight to play the part,' she explains. 'I was 21 playing 16 anyway and they thought if I was heavier it would make me look younger.' As she relives those few weeks of shooting almost four decades ago, there is no hint that she ever wearies of a story that she must have told a thousand times before. Commercially such an attitude undoubtedly makes sense. Her warm, sincere, self-deprecating style hits the perfect note, but there is, I sense, something more. For in talking about those times in Salzburg (where 70 per cent of the city's visitors now come to see the Sound of Music sights), she is also recounting her coming of age. 'It was my first time away from home, when I became an adult and drank my first champagne.'

With Plummer, in particular, there was sexual chemistry as he tinkled on the hotel's piano late at night and poured her brandies. 'He was terribly handsome and dashing, and as flirtatious with me as I was with him. If I was too old to be Liesl, he was only 34 and too young to be the Captain.'

Carr has a sure touch in tapping into the on-going public affection for the film. Her book brims with anecdotes: Plummer turning up in tights and ballet shoes for rehearsals of the folk dance he performs with Andrews on the night of the ball; Plummer (again) refusing to carry Gretl as they set out for the hills because child actress Kymmie Karath was too heavy; Nicholas Hammond who played Kurt growing so fast during the filming that he shot up past his father; and Marni Nixon (Sister Sophia) revealing that she had dubbed Audrey Hepburn's singing in My Fair Lady.

Of her own role, Carr tells how, just before she filmed the gazebo scene with Rolf, she fell and sprained her ankle. It had to be wrapped in a bandage that had been dyed the same colour as her tights.

To the millions of people who have seen the film more times than is probably good for them, such stories will be manna from heaven, but for a wider audience Carr manages cleverly to bring the whole thing to life by including both personal revelations and rather acid asides, albeit sweetly wrapped.

The question she's asked most often, she says, is what was Julie Andrews like. The answer appears to be not very nice. For all her love of children on screen, she had little to do with them off camera. 'Julie didn't go to Salzburg to make friends,' says Carr, 'she went there to make a movie.'

She seems unsurprised by The Sound of Music's staying power with audiences. The Sing-a-Long Sound of Music has, she says, outed a camp, gay element amongst its fans. 'At another event in New York, I had to judge who had the best costume. There was one guy who was wearing a small gazebo over his face. When he turned one way, he was made up as Liesl. When he turned the other, he was Rolf.'

Given the reverence with which she talks about her own experiences - the film, she writes, has made her 'wealthy spiritually' - I wonder whether she ever takes offence at such efforts. 'Not at all. Its not sacrilegious. If they didn't love the film so much, they wouldn't go to all that trouble.' And how does she feel about suddenly finding herself a gay icon? 'I feel great. I think of Judy Garland and I think of Bette Midler and then I think, gee that's good company to be in.'

Another major fan of the film is the singer Michael Jackson. In between her tours, Carr settled in Encino, California, with her dentist husband (they are now divorced) and set up an interior design business - no doubt inspired by Fraulein Maria's 101 things to do with a pair of curtains. One day she was contacted for professional advice by the singer whose Neverland Ranch was nearby. 'He came by and recognised me at once as Liesl. We became good friends. Michael and I were very close. I picked him up from hospital when he'd had his skin bleached, although he now denies he had that done. And I took him there when he had his first nose job. When he wanted to have another straight afterwards I tried to talk him out of it, but he wouldn't listen.'

They have drifted apart and now when she sees photographs of him, she says that she feels revolted.

'It's a terrible thing to say but he had such an adorable face, he was so adorable. That he could have done to himself what he has done makes me sick to my stomach.'

For the time being, however, interior design is off the agenda. Her book has already been a bestseller in the States and there are plans for another tour as it is published around the world. She is a survivor, gently milking her good fortune of 35 years ago. She has no great yearning to move on. 'There have been times when I have wished I could just be me, or even as an actress be other characters. If I'd played other parts, though, I wouldn't be just Liesl. I would have spoiled that and I would prefer people to think of me always as her.'

 Forever Liesl is published by Sidgwick and Jackson, price £9.99. To order for £7.99, call Observer CultureShop on 0800 3168 171 Charmian Carr's website can be found at www.CharmianCarr.com.

Where are they now?

The original cast: Gretl, Liesl, Brigitta, Friedrich, Kurt, Marta and Louisa.

Reuters Friedrich (Nicky Hammond) lives in Australia where he writes and directs in the theatre.

Louisa (Heather Menzies) worked in sitcoms and on Broadway but gave up when she started a family.

Kurt (Duane Chase) is a petroleum geologist in Seattle. His wife was once an Austrian nanny.

Brigitta (Angela Cartwright) was a child star who, aged four, played Paul Newman's daughter in Somebody Up There Likes Me. She played Penny Robinson in the TV sci-fi series Lost in Space. Now concentrates on her dotcom business and photography.

Marta (Debbie Turner) is a mortgage broker and florist in Minnesota.

Gretl (Kym Karath) had parts in The Brady Bunch and All My Children, then studied art history in Paris.

Dan Truhitte, the Nazi telegram boy, Rolf, still reprises his 15 minutes of fame on the American cabaret circuit, complete with blond wig, and is currently trying to find a record label for Gazebo Songs, a shameless play on the location where he sang 'I am Sixteen Going on Seventeen' with the oldest von Trapp child, Liesl. Truhitte is a tragi-comic figure. His opposite number in that scene, Charmian Carr, is harder to place. Now in her late fifties, this week she publishes her autobiography, Forever Liesl. As the title suggests, 99 per cent of it is about the movie, as well it might be since she has had no acting career to speak of since and instead has taken on the mantle of a global ambassador for the film. Wherever there has been a Sound of Music festival in the intervening 35 years, Charmian Carr has been the guest of honour. Despite innumerable Christmas viewings of the film over the years, I fail to pick Carr out from the half-a-dozen middle-aged women in the dining room of the hotel where we have arranged to meet. The maitre d' has to direct me. Even as I sit down, I am not convinced. My recollection of Liesl is as a strapping lass in a pinafore dress. In front of me is Nancy Reagan's younger sister - tiny, bird-like and trussed up in tight-fitting clothes. It is only when she speaks that I am sure. Her voice is instantly recognisable as the one that announced to Fraulein Maria early in the film: 'I am 16 and I don't need a governess.' 'They made me put on weight to play the part,' she explains. 'I was 21 playing 16 anyway and they thought if I was heavier it would make me look younger.' As she relives those few weeks of shooting almost four decades ago, there is no hint that she ever wearies of a story that she must have told a thousand times before. Commercially such an attitude undoubtedly makes sense. Her warm, sincere, self-deprecating style hits the perfect note, but there is, I sense, something more. For in talking about those times in Salzburg (where 70 per cent of the city's visitors now come to see the Sound of Music sights), she is also recounting her coming of age. 'It was my first time away from home, when I became an adult and drank my first champagne.' With Plummer, in particular, there was sexual chemistry as he tinkled on the hotel's piano late at night and poured her brandies. 'He was terribly handsome and dashing, and as flirtatious with me as I was with him. If I was too old to be Liesl, he was only 34 and too young to be the Captain.' Carr has a sure touch in tapping into the on-going public affection for the film. Her book brims with anecdotes: Plummer turning up in tights and ballet shoes for rehearsals of the folk dance he performs with Andrews on the night of the ball; Plummer (again) refusing to carry Gretl as they set out for the hills because child actress Kymmie Karath was too heavy; Nicholas Hammond who played Kurt growing so fast during the filming that he shot up past his father; and Marni Nixon (Sister Sophia) revealing that she had dubbed Audrey Hepburn's singing in My Fair Lady. Of her own role, Carr tells how, just before she filmed the gazebo scene with Rolf, she fell and sprained her ankle. It had to be wrapped in a bandage that had been dyed the same colour as her tights. To the millions of people who have seen the film more times than is probably good for them, such stories will be manna from heaven, but for a wider audience Carr manages cleverly to bring the whole thing to life by including both personal revelations and rather acid asides, albeit sweetly wrapped. The question she's asked most often, she says, is what was Julie Andrews like. The answer appears to be not very nice. For all her love of children on screen, she had little to do with them off camera. 'Julie didn't go to Salzburg to make friends,' says Carr, 'she went there to make a movie.' She seems unsurprised by The Sound of Music's staying power with audiences. The Sing-a-Long Sound of Music has, she says, outed a camp, gay element amongst its fans. 'At another event in New York, I had to judge who had the best costume. There was one guy who was wearing a small gazebo over his face. When he turned one way, he was made up as Liesl. When he turned the other, he was Rolf.' Given the reverence with which she talks about her own experiences - the film, she writes, has made her 'wealthy spiritually' - I wonder whether she ever takes offence at such efforts. 'Not at all. Its not sacrilegious. If they didn't love the film so much, they wouldn't go to all that trouble.' And how does she feel about suddenly finding herself a gay icon? 'I feel great. I think of Judy Garland and I think of Bette Midler and then I think, gee that's good company to be in.' Another major fan of the film is the singer Michael Jackson. In between her tours, Carr settled in Encino, California, with her dentist husband (they are now divorced) and set up an interior design business - no doubt inspired by Fraulein Maria's 101 things to do with a pair of curtains. One day she was contacted for professional advice by the singer whose Neverland Ranch was nearby. 'He came by and recognised me at once as Liesl. We became good friends. Michael and I were very close. I picked him up from hospital when he'd had his skin bleached, although he now denies he had that done. And I took him there when he had his first nose job. When he wanted to have another straight afterwards I tried to talk him out of it, but he wouldn't listen.' They have drifted apart and now when she sees photographs of him, she says that she feels revolted. 'It's a terrible thing to say but he had such an adorable face, he was so adorable. That he could have done to himself what he has done makes me sick to my stomach.' For the time being, however, interior design is off the agenda. Her book has already been a bestseller in the States and there are plans for another tour as it is published around the world. She is a survivor, gently milking her good fortune of 35 years ago. She has no great yearning to move on. 'There have been times when I have wished I could just be me, or even as an actress be other characters. If I'd played other parts, though, I wouldn't be just Liesl. I would have spoiled that and I would prefer people to think of me always as her.'  Forever Liesl is published by Sidgwick and Jackson, price £9.99. To order for £7.99, call Observer CultureShop on 0800 3168 171 Charmian Carr's website can be found at www.CharmianCarr.com. Where are they now? The original cast: Gretl, Liesl, Brigitta, Friedrich, Kurt, Marta and Louisa. Reuters Friedrich (Nicky Hammond) lives in Australia where he writes and directs in the theatre. Louisa (Heather Menzies) worked in sitcoms and on Broadway but gave up when she started a family. Kurt (Duane Chase) is a petroleum geologist in Seattle. His wife was once an Austrian nanny. Brigitta (Angela Cartwright) was a child star who, aged four, played Paul Newman's daughter in Somebody Up There Likes Me. She played Penny Robinson in the TV sci-fi series Lost in Space. Now concentrates on her dotcom business and photography. Marta (Debbie Turner) is a mortgage broker and florist in Minnesota. Gretl (Kym Karath) had parts in The Brady Bunch and All My Children, then studied art history in Paris.

webTitle: Sounding Off: Ken Loach on a film about train troubles

fields.headline: I was making a film on train troubles. Then Hatfield came along
fields.standfirst:
Sounding Off: Ken Loach

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Ken Loach Sounding Off: Working with railway workers, we have found that many of them will not even use their free travel vouchers because they don't want to travel on the train any more. These are men who really know what is happening. The trouble is, they realise just how fragile the whole structure is.
fields.body:
When news of the Hatfield train crash broke last month, I was staging my own derailment in the railway sidings near Doncaster. I was with a team of actors working on a film which is set in the mid-Nineties, the time when the railways were being privatised. The crew and I already had a good idea of the dangers from talking to the screenwriter, my friend Rob Dawber, and to the other guys we met on the tracks. The crash, though, and the fact that tons of metal are thundering past us everyday as we film, has made it much more real.

An incident like this one, and Paddington, had been so obviously coming that it's not really even a coincidence that the system has collapsed while we are filming the story. To say it is a disaster that has been waiting to happen does not really cover the situation. Working with railway workers, we have found that many of them will not even use their free travel vouchers because they don't want to travel on the train any more. These are men who really know what is happening. The trouble is, they realise just how fragile the whole structure is.

And for the rest of us, are we really to assume that the rails were just not being checked before? Perhaps it is barely worth saying, but the point surely is that private companies exist for their shareholders and so corners are inevitably cut.

At the moment cheap contractors are being hired by the big contractors, who in turn pick up people they meet in the pub or friends of friends. As a result, all the safety procedures get cut back.

The idea for the film, which at the moment we are calling The Navigators, came from a conversation I had with Rob two or three years ago. He had worked on the railways until his early forties and then he managed to get a writing commission after he learned he had mesothelioma, which is asbestos-related cancer. The story is about signal workers, because that is what Rob did, but is really about the wider question of how the nature of work has changed. There has been a move away from what is still considered 'real' work, towards casual, agency and temporary work.

It is going to be quite a big film, in its way, because it touches on all these issues. The screenplay deals with things that a large number of people are struggling with and so it feels substantial.

Competition has killed the traditional integrity of the railway system, but it is equally devastating for the guys who work on it. The film is about the people who kept the railway safe, and how their working life has been destroyed.

It is clear to me from talking to workers that there is a whole raft of procedures that they were once expected to follow that have now gone out the window. So many men have been made redundant and, as a result, all that custom and practice has gone with them.

There are all kinds of things they are now asked to do that compromise their own safety. Workers are asked to work without lookouts, for example.

The workers are also supposed to have track safety cards in order to take a job, but in fact you can buy these cards for a small amount of money. Contractors turn a blind eye. I believe that, now these disasters have actually happened, that clown John Prescott should go. The Labour Party had a mandate to bring the railways back into public ownership, but they haven't done it because they are so ideologically committed to the free market.

Ken Loach, the director of Kes, Riff-Raff, Raining Stones and My Name Is Joe, is making The Navigators with Channel 4. Filming is taking place in Sheffield and south Yorkshire and it is scheduled to be screened next year.

 Ken Loach was speaking to Vanessa Thorpe.

webTitle: Just wild about Harry

fields.headline: Just wild about Harry
fields.standfirst: Dominik Moll's disturbing new thriller is a superb homage to Hitchcock
fields.trailText: Philip French: ...it's the best European movie in a Hitchcockian vein since George Sluizer's The Vanishing and is made with a confident grace and ironic wit
fields.body:
As a film-maker, an influence and a physical presence (the only non-acting director to be recognisable the world over), Alfred Hitchcock has loomed over moviegoers for 70 years. The fascination with his life and work shows no signs of abating. When he was 60, there was just one book about him, written in French by Claude Chabrol and Eric Rohmer. There were half-a-dozen or so by the time of his death in 1980, and there's now a little library of studies, with extra space to be found on the shelves each year.

The massive publicity attending the centenary of his birth in 1999 did little to stem the flow of interest. Last month saw the publication by the BFI of Susan Smith's Hitchcock: Suspense, Humour and Tone, and the release of Robert Zemeckis's What Lies Beneath, a homage to Rear Window.

Later this month Faber will publish Peter Conrad's perceptive The Hitchcock Murders, and this week Dominik Moll's thriller Harry, He's Here to Help arrives in our cinemas, confirming that Hitchcock's legacy is in good hands down in the Auvergne.

The film begins with an edgy casualness. One hot summer day, the 34-year-old Michel Pape (Laurent Lucas), a good-looking teacher of French to Japanese students, is driving south from Paris in his clapped-out saloon with his sensible wife, Claire (Mathilde Seigner), and three fractious little daughters. Their destination is the dilapidated old farmhouse on the foothills of the Monts du Cantal that they've bought with the help of his overbearing dentist father and his querulous mother and are doing up a little at a time.

Like various Hitchcock characters, their lives are inviting intervention. In the men's lavatory at a motorway café, a good-looking, slightly flashy man introduces himself to Michel as an old friend he's not met for 20 years and who remembers their schooldays in astonishing detail. This stranger by a drain is called Harry Balestrero (Sergi Lopez), a name designed to set off alarm bells in the viewer's mind. Balestrero is the name of the innocent victim in The Wrong Man; Harry is the corpse that causes trouble in Vermont in Hitchcock's most extended exercise in rural mayhem in The Trouble With Harry.

Harry, like Bruno in Strangers on a Train, is idle, aesthetically poised and independently wealthy, having inherited large sums from a despised father. Accompanied by his simple, sexy, patronised girlfriend (Sophie Guillemin), he insinuates himself into the lives of Michel, Claire and their children, sensing faultlines in their relationships and creating new ones. It begins with lollies for the kids, a lift in his air-conditioned Mercedes and a flattering concern for Michel having given up on the literary career that seemed to lie before him as a precocious schoolboy.

Harry's one of those people who knows more about you than you know yourself and is solicitous to an embarrassing degree. He believes 'every problem has a solution' and sets about reorganising Michel's life with advice and manipulative acts. Because Michel and Claire don't present a united front, he's able to become a murderous cuckoo in their nest.

As with Hitchcock and Fritz Lang, there's a deadly logic in the way one act leads plausibly to another on the escalator of will and desire, and with considerable subtlety Moll draws us into Harry's scheming mind. In the way he coolly thinks the unthinkable, Harry is as insidious and seductive as Patricia Highsmith's psychopathic Tom Ripley.

Harry, He's Here to Help is superbly performed by its central quartet, and by the actors playing Michel's somewhat disagreeable parents and his louche brother. A profoundly disturbing work, it's the best European movie in a Hitchcockian vein since George Sluizer's The Vanishing and is made with a confident grace and ironic wit. It also has one of the best mobile phone jokes, which will remind many viewers of a famous scene involving a corpse in Frenzy.

Two other motifs that Conrad's book draws attention to turn up in the film. Hitchcock found eggs abhorrent, but Harry eats them raw to improve his orgasms and Michel, when he resumes writing, produces a story called 'Les Oeufs'. Hitch also had a thing about teeth and Henry Fonda's troubles in The Wrong Man begin with his dental bills. The bridge Harry needed as a schoolboy after a sporting collision with Michel was fitted by Michel's father and had to be replaced in America after turning black.

webTitle: A History of Britain by Simon Schama read by Timothy West

fields.headline: A History of Britain by Simon Schama read by Timothy West
fields.trailText: Simon Schama rises to the challenge to make history 'not just instruction, but a pleasure'
fields.body:
A History of Britain 3000 BC - AD1603
Simon Schama
Read by Timothy West
Running time 8hrs
BBC Radio Collection £14.99

In his preface, where he concludes that history should be 'as all her most accomplished narrators have promised, not just instruction, but pleasure', Simon Schama sets out his brief. This is narrative history which does indeed make instruction a pleasure - his coverage of the Black Death, from the Mongols throwing their plague-infected corpses over the wall at Caffa in 1346, to the cows 'swollen and lowing for want of being milked', is riveting.

His use of detail makes for enormous vitality (the lice found in Thomas à Beckett's hair shirt after his death); vigorous prose makes battles and massacres horrifyingly immediate; he also has a good ear for the alliterating phrase, like the 'silks amid the seaweed' in the drowning of Henry I's son on the White Ship along with much of the Norman nobility in 1120.

For this accomplished narrative, Timothy West's voice is eminently suitable. His presentation recalls a good, old-fashioned, storytelling history teacher, with the listener his avid pupil. Schama's many anachronistic solecisms stand out more starkly in his narration: St Patrick is 'an Irish teenager'; Anne Boleyn's death is 'pure Viagra' to Henry VIII. The concluding second volume, The Fate of Empire, will be on audio in May 2001.

webTitle: Children's choice: The Eclipse of the Century

fields.headline: Children's choice
fields.trailText: Sci-fi, thriller, adventure story - Jan Mark weaves a terrific story out of the strange mix of people at the edge of the old Soviet empire
fields.body:
The Eclipse of the Century
Jan Mark
Scholastic £5.99, pp442
Buy it at BOL

Sci-fi, thriller, adventure story. This gripping novel is all of those. Keith suffers a head injury in a road accident and has a near-death experience in which he has a vision of a city and people promising to meet him 'here in Kantoom, under the black sun, at the end of a thousand years'. He takes the timing to refer to the eclipse and the end of the millennium.

When he recovers, he determines to find the city, which turns out to be in one of the most far-flung outreaches of the old Soviet empire. He finds a strange mix of people living there; a small community of misfits, ex-pats and ex-soldiers who congregate in the museum for social evenings and a tribe of inscrutable people called the Sturyats who claim originally to have come from the stars.

The tension begins to mount as others start arriving in the city, having picked up a flippant email sent by Keith to his friends referring to the 'black sun'. Weird cults, ranging from tree-huggers to the downright dangerous, settle themselves in, upsetting the uneasy balance between the Sturyats and the city-dwellers. The Sturyats have been waiting for 500 years for a sign to move on and when it comes they must liberate their ancestors' soul-stones from the museum. Violence is inevitable and the presence of sinister, slimy, sac-like creatures doesn't help. Great characters. Good dialogue. Terrific story. 14 up.

webTitle: Paperbacks: 12 Nov

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: William Sutcliffe jumps straight into twentysomething matchmaking, plus Burger's Daughter, Several Strangers, Mandelson and It's What He Would Have Wanted
fields.body:
The Love Hexagon
William Sutcliffe
Penguin £5.99, pp304
Buy it at BOL

After tackling sixth-form angst and the hypocrisy of gap-year travels in his two previous novels, Sutcliffe has skipped a book on university pretensions and graduated straight to twentysomething matchmaking. The Love Hexagon is a twist on the traditional love triangle, ensuring that all the individuals end up with a partner. We follow the sexual mishaps and flirtations of a group of six stock characters: the bitch, the comic, the stable, the siren, the neurotic and the dope. Sutcliffe begins with an epigraph by Freud, and the book's psychological insights and observations are particularly astute and often uncomfortably recognisable. The banter is banal and authentic, and intermittently chuckleworthy. A good alternative to a bad TV drama.

Burger's Daughter
Nadine Gordimer
Bloomsbury £6.99, pp374
Buy it at BOL

As the daughter of a white South African communist activist, Rosa Burger's childhood consisted of prison visits, political activism and the deaths of her parents for acting according to their conscience. Gordimer's seminal novel traces Rosa's development towards realisation that fighting for the struggle was a necessity rather than simply a normality. Accepting that in South Africa 'to be free is to become almost a stranger to oneself', Rosa gets involved in the struggle, leading to the inevitable imprisonment.

Gordimer's language is oddly both direct and opaque; an almost journalistic attention to detail is used in her account of South African political anti-apartheid activity, but Rosa is a hazy heroine. Despite Rosa's pivotal role, Gordimer denies total access to her, giving the novel an ethereal quality that is compelling but at times frustrating. Although the political urgency of Burger's Daughter is less directly relevant 11 years after the end of apartheid, this is, none the less, a fascinating and evocative historical portrait.

Several Strangers
Claire Tomalin
Penguin £7.99, pp256
Buy it at BOL

This is acclaimed biographer Claire Tomalin's first collection of reviews and broadcasts, spanning the three decades of her career as a critic and literary editor of the New Statesman and the Sunday Times. Her reviews cover a range of literary characters like Oscar Wilde, Mary Wollstonecraft and Virginia Woolf, and Claire Tomalin possesses an acute insight into her subjects, presenting them with subtlety and sensitivity.

The book is divided into three sections - apprenticeship, editorship and her own writing career - and these are linked by an autobiographical thread; we hear of her difficult first marriage, the death of her daughter, and meet a virtual parade of literary London a generation ago: Martin Amis and Julian Barnes jostle with Clive James and Marina Warner.

Donald Macintyre
HarperCollins £6.99, pp649
Buy it at BOL

Peter Mandelson's common role as the 'Prince of Darkness', a modern Machiavelli and a 'greasy pole politician' are dispelled in Donald Macintyre's considered and very readable biography. The Secretary of State for Northern Ireland is presented as the ultimate schmoozer, a comfort craver and a passionate politician. Spontaneity and enthusiasm have been his assets but also his downfall, as his continual efforts to create spin left him little time to plan his own direction.

Macintyre's surprisingly soft treatment of his subject seems justified when put in the context of New Labour's haphazard 'modernising' project. The biography is also a detailed and lively history of a party which long ago realised it had to slicken up. Macintyre suggests that neither New Labour nor Mandelson had a highly planned strategy. We are left unsure about the mind and motivation of Mandelson, but far clearer about the disorganisation and the human comedy that lies behind New Labour.

Sean Hughes
Scribner £9.99, pp290
Buy it at BOL

Hughes surveys the senselessness of his surroundings with a flattened humour, thoughtful and often touching observations, and a crudeness which seems increasingly fitting and understandable as Shea's character is revealed.

We follow the sexual mishaps and flirtations of a group of six stock characters: the bitch, the comic, the stable, the siren, the neurotic and the dope. webTitle: Paperback of the week: Dutch

fields.headline: Paperback of the week
fields.trailText: Edmund Morris' memoir is full of peculiar insights into the phenomenon that was Ronald Reagan
fields.body:
Dutch: A Memoir of Ronald Reagan
Edmund Morris
HarperCollins £8.99, pp874
Buy it at BOL

In 1938, Ronald Reagan tried to join the Communist Party, but they wouldn't let him in. Those American commissars who decided he was 'too flaky' to be considered for membership did Reagan a great favour and he emerged unscathed from the McCarthy hearings after the war, when he was still suspected of dangerously liberal Democrat leanings.

Dutch is full of this kind of peculiar insight into a far more complex man than his later, self-made caricature ever suggested. Reagan's father called his second son 'the little bit of a fat Dutchman' in a reference to his lineage on his mother's side and the nickname 'Dutch' stuck.

As the title suggests, this is as much Morris's memoir as it is a biography of Reagan and in the hands of a lesser writer the personal reminiscences would be an unwelcome intrusion. At times, when Morris is at his most sycophantic, it does descend into hagiography. But for the most part, the interweaving of the lives of the two men, who first met in 1926, works well.

Best of all are the sections where Morris discusses Reagan's political rise in California in the 1960s with his student-activist son, Gavin. 'He kids you and coaxes you and suddenly you're hearing that intellectuals, poor people and black people are living off the rest of us,' says the younger Morris of Reagan's early rhetoric. 'Quick, strong, funny - dangerous as hell.'

Having just watched the American electorate struggling to decide between two shades of bland, it is easy to slip into a dangerous nostalgia for the big political personalities of the past. Sometimes, it's hard to imagine now what it was like during the Thatcher-Reagan years. It seemed as if the world had gone mad when two of the world's great democracies had elected these grotesques as leaders. This deeply sympathetic biography acts as a welcome reminder of just how scary it was.
