webTitle: Stargazers? But of course

fields.headline: Stargazers? But of course
fields.standfirst: Even princesses and poets consult their stars, so who are we mere mortals to gainsay the zodiac?
fields.trailText: Even princesses and poets consult their stars, so who are we mere mortals to gainsay the zodiac?
fields.body:
When I saw two poems by Ted Hughes on the front of the Times in January 1998, I was as surprised as any other reader. These were trailers from Birthday Letters, a cycle of poems addressed to his long dead first wife, Sylvia Plath. Irrespective of the poems' literary merit (and they were very fine), their publication was a sensation, an unexpected finale to an infamous romantic tragedy.

There was another reason for my surprise. One of the poems, 'St Botolph's', an account of the first, intense encounter between Hughes and Plath, was dense with astrological imagery, impenetrable to anyone unversed in deciphering a horoscope. 'The conjunction combust my natal Sun/ Venus pinned exact on my midheaven,' it chattered, commenting on the planetary positions that attended that fateful meeting, before concluding, remarkably, that the two poets had that night been 'married by the solar system'. Other poems in Birthday Letters - 'Horoscope', '18 Rugby Street' - likewise suggested that a writer celebrated principally for his nature poetry had an unsuspected life as a star-gazer. The poet laureate had outed himself as an astrologer!

As much was confirmed by Hughes's publishers, Faber and Faber, who informed me that Hughes always stipulated the exact publication dates of his books. Birthday Letters, it turned out, was published on the day of a new moon, 29 January 1998. Its US edition followed on the next new moon.

What would the literary establishment make of Ted the planeteer? Disappointingly little, it transpired. Out of embarrassment or indifference, the critics avoided comment on the astrological references. There was the odd remark about the poet's 'dottier beliefs', and Seamus Heaney described Hughes and Plath as 'mythopoetic' writers, but otherwise nothing. Ariel's Gift, a 'comprehensive guide' to Birthday Letters by Times critic Erica Wagner, managed to avoid addressing astrology anywhere in its 200 pages.

I was not altogether surprised. Astrology, for all the popularity of newspaper sun sign horoscopes, remains beyond respectability, the province of the potty. Look at the derision heaped on Ronald Reagan and Princess Diana when their consultations with astrologers became public knowledge. The case of Hughes and Birthday Letters is a paradigm of the way astrology and kindred 'irrationalist' systems help shape culture while going unacknowledged or belittled.

Over the last century, astrology has seeped into poetry, music, film, psychology and even science, and enchanted titans such as Yeats and Jung, yet it remains a renegade and ridiculed subject. Remarking on Yeats's passion for esoteric ideas, W.H. Auden wondered: 'How on earth could a man of Yeats's gifts take such nonsense seriously?' His question can as justly be inverted; if a man of Yeats's gifts took this nonsense seriously, maybe it has something to tell us. It is a delicious irony that Yeats is the favourite poet of astrology's fiercest and most eminent critic, Richard Dawkins, whose last book, Unweaving the Rainbow, included a thunderous attack on Keats, Blake, Yeats and other poets of genius for their lack of scientific rigour and 'prejudice against reason'. Dawkins certainly knows about prejudice. For him, astrology is a wicked fraud, 'an aesthetic affront' whose 'pre-Copernican dabblings demean and cheapen astronomy'. Astrologers, whom he 'detests', should be prosecuted. 'We should learn to see the debauching of science for profit as a crime,' rasps Dawkins, transformed from Beacon of Reason to Chief of Thought Police.

The scientific model of the universe upheld by Dawkins does, indeed, present astrologers with a problem. There is simply no known mechanism which might link human character and behaviour to the movement of planets and the position of stars, though the 'holographic universe' posited by quantum physicist David Bohm, an associate of Einstein, offers one explanation of how such a link might function.

Such objective proof as exists to support the astrologers' age-old adage 'as above, so below' is patchy and contested. The exhaustive research of French statistician Michael Gauquelin, who found, for example, a powerful correlation between sports champions and the position of Mars in their birth charts, remains the subject of bitter disputes. Here, the prevailing scientific attitude to Gauquelin's findings was summed up by psychologist Hans Eysenck as: 'Don't confuse me with facts when my mind is made up.'

Proof, however, comes in many shapes, not least in the guise of personal experience. Symbols are, in their way, just as 'real' (a favourite Dawkins adjective) as the constructs of hardhat science. Symbolism challenges consciousness and nourishes imagination, inviting us to uncover deeper levels of meaning. Astrology's richly symbolic language, resonating with the myths of the ancients, is a major part of its appeal, not least for artists and others seeking to understand what Jung termed the 'archetypes' of the human psyche.

Among poets, it occurs in the work of Ted Hughes, Louis MacNeice (who wrote a book on astrology), and Rudyard Kipling (who perhaps learnt something of it through his freemasonry). Then there is Yeats himself, whose most famous poem, 'The Second Coming', has part of its genesis in the astrological concept of the 'great ages'. I suspect Yeats's 'rough beast, slouching towards Bethlehem to be born' was in part his 'new age', a version of 'the Age of Aquarius' which had become a fashionable catchphrase in astrological circles at the time he wrote the poem.

While Yeats was writing 'The Second Coming', Gustav Holst was composing The Planets . Holst based his masterpiece on the astrological meanings of the heavenly bodies, though he kept this concealed at the time, no doubt mindful that the astrologer on whose work his suite was modelled, Alan Leo, had recently been prosecuted for 'fortune-telling'.

Later musicians felt able to express their interests more openly. Jazz colossus John Coltrane wrote several works with astrological themes late in his life, among them 'Saturn', 'Jupiter', 'Venus' and 'Leo', and according to his widow, Alice, used a scheme 'with 12 tones correlating to the 12 zodiac signs'. Pop music is littered with cosmic references, whether you want to 'Breakfast on Pluto' with Sinatra or were 'Born Under a Bad Sign' with Albert King.

More surprising was the realisation that the century's most celebrated love story, Gone With the Wind, is a thinly disguised astrological allegory. Margaret Mitchell based the characters of her torrid epic on the zodiac, leaving a blatant trail of clues which were only picked up in 1978 when US astrologer Darrell Martinie was shown photocopies of notes from Mitchell's library.

Scarlett O'Hara proves to be a dashing Aries, named after the colour of her ruling planet Mars. Her father is a Taurus who owns a farm in earthy Taurean fashion, the Tara plantation. Scarlett's twittering aunts, Prissy and Pitty Pat, are a pair of Geminis whose names comply with the sign's love of wordplay. Rhett Butler is a passionate Leo. Bonnie is the third fire sign, Sagittarius. Being born under the sign of the centaur, she meets her end in a horse-riding accident. The list goes on ...

In the Harry Potter books, our hero is reluctantly learning star lore from cranky professor of divination, Sybill Trelawney, and this turns out to be a refreshingly accurate reflection of real-life astrology. Is Joanna Rowling another secret stargazer?

Such outcrops of influence in popular and high culture alike testify to astrology's vigorous, unruly character. Having survived the edicts of emperors and popes, it is not surprising that it continues to defy scientific rationalism today. Accordingly, it comes in many guises; as newspaper horoscopes, as psychology, as agony aunt, as adviser to the rich and powerful. Charles de Gaulle, seemingly a model of the man of will, is the latest president to be named as taking astro-advice ,though contrary to popular legend, Adolf Hitler was uninterested in the subject.

If science and astronomy really do want to win popular respect, as their champions claim, they might begin by admitting astrology's role in their own history. Instead, science airbrushes out the interests of astronomical pioneers like Johannes Kepler, who wrote exten sively on the links between numbers, music and astrology, and whose ideas on reforming astrology reveal an approach strikingly akin to that of modern astrologers, disliking predictions and favouring character analysis.

Galileo, hailed as the first man of modern astronomy, had a lifelong interest in astrology, and even science's most potent figurehead, Sir Isaac Newton, while no astrologer, was a closet alchemist. Robert Boyle, one of the founding fathers of modern chemistry, was also fascinated by alchemy.

Astrology has flourished in recent decades partly because it offers an escape from a cold, purposeless cosmos into a universe charged with symbolic meaning and individual significance. For most of its followers, the approval of physics doesn't matter. Despite the tremendous successes and insights of physics, biology and other branches of science, these remain unable to supply the answer to the questions that hang over numerous heads: 'What am I doing here? What is my life for?'

Astrology is not a religion, but large parts of its practice assume there is a spiritual dimension to human life, a mystical connection to the universe, which it can help clarify. Richard Tarnas, a bestselling US intellectual, has described astrology as 'the most feminine science', which is why male-dominated hard science is so scornful.

Astrology promises self-direction through self-knowledge and co-operation with the wider tides of the cosmos, an escape from nihilism and a return to psyche, to soul. Of course, for self-respecting physicists, there is no such thing as spirit, let alone 'cosmic tides'. Most of the world's people, however, continue to disagree with them.

 Neil Spencer's True As the Stars Above is published by Gollancz. To order it for £7.99, call Observer CultureShop on 0800 3168 171. His article, 'Harry Potter and the Astrologer's Chart', is published in the December issue of the Astrological Journal.

webTitle: Life's hard - and then you're pulped

fields.headline: Life's hard - and then you're pulped
fields.trailText: The grim, half-acknowledged truth about British publishing is that most books will not sell even as many as 5,000 copies, while others will struggle to clear a paltry 1,000.
fields.body:
The grim, half-acknowledged truth about British publishing is that most books will not sell even as many as 5,000 copies, while others will struggle to clear a paltry 1,000.

A number of commentators have made much of the unconfirmed report that Anthea Turner's ghosted autobiography, Fools Rush In, has sold just 451 copies. Actually, that's not so unusual. For the majority of published writers, life is hard - and then you're pulped. Compared to the United States, ours is a very small market, with correspondingly small returns.

So when publishers hear the word 'television', a strange light flickers across their homely features. At last! Sales! A mass audience! The jackpot! Television, they believe, is the philosopher's stone that will transform their dross into 24 carat gold. Bingo!

Even a cursory look at the bestseller list confirms the view that books and writers associated with television do much better than their fellows. Bernard Cornwell, Catherine Cookson, and Terry Wogan have this in common: their work has been widely promoted on the small screen

So when an author, let us say, Simon Schama or Richard Eyre, produces a book that's not merely associated with television, but comes attached to a full-blown television series, their publishers naturally assume that Christmas has come early.

Schama's History of Britain is a widely admired television series. Richard Eyre's Changing Stages has just begun. Both, in their different ways, are enthralling.

Both came with a book. Schama's is a classic of the genre and will take its place alongside Civilisation and The Ascent of Man. Eyre's, as you might expect from an original and audacious theatrical director with a sure popular touch, is rather different.

In the first place, the book (Changing Stages, Bloomsbury £30), co-written with the playwright Nicholas Wright, apparently predated the TV series, and exists not merely as a jumped-up script. In the second, it is rather good, replete with telling insights into the process you'd expect from two professionals. I particularly liked the literary critical zingers scattered through the text. For example, 'Recreating the Globe is a sort of aesthetic anaesthesia' or, of David Hare, that he has 'the pen of a polemicist but the soul of a romantic'.

Eyre and Wright address their subject as men of the theatre. They also nail their colours to the mast. For them, English is the 'language of the world' and their book is thus unashamedly about English language theatre (Irish, American and British) in the twentieth century, prefaced by the near obligatory obeisance to Shakespeare, whom they describe as 'the DNA of British theatre', with another nod to Brecht along the way.

After its Shakespearean curtain-raiser, the book takes off in a number of directions loosely linked by the chronology of the last century, from Wilde to Coward to Rattigan, to Osborne to Bond, Hampton and beyond. It's an excellent text, impressionistic, vivid, and provocative.

Without the TV series (which I have not yet viewed in its entirety), it could well have seen publication as a handsome tour d'horizon of twentieth-century theatre, probably priced at about £15 and presented in a printed form that did justice to its literary merits.

And what have the publishers done? The short answer is that they have pursued the will o' the wisp of mass sales. In an attempt to appeal to a television audience, who may or may not buy this volume as a souvenir of the TV series, the book has been tricked out with theatrical portraits, the dullest form of illustration known to man. Far worse, presumably to appeal to the Mastermind market, the titles of plays and the names of playwrights have been picked out in a bold type that gives the whole production the air of an educational text for first-year college students in the dumbed-down American Midwest.

I hope I'm proved wrong. I hope Changing Stages will sell better than choc ices at a matinée of Cats. I also hope that Bloomsbury comes to its senses and eventually publishes the book in the way that it deserves - as a serious book for serious theatre-lovers, with a proper bibliography.

A number of commentators have made much of the unconfirmed report that Anthea Turner's ghosted autobiography, Fools Rush In, has sold just 451 copies. Actually, that's not so unusual. For the majority of published writers, life is hard - and then you're pulped. Compared to the United States, ours is a very small market, with correspondingly small returns. So when publishers hear the word 'television', a strange light flickers across their homely features. At last! Sales! A mass audience! The jackpot! Television, they believe, is the philosopher's stone that will transform their dross into 24 carat gold. Bingo! webTitle: Observer review: Bellow by James Atlas

fields.headline: Saul's flaws writ large
fields.standfirst: Despite his best intentions, James Atlas can't find much to commend Saul Bellow
fields.trailText: Despite his best intentions, James Atlas can't find much to commend Saul Bellow
fields.body:
Bellow
James Atlas
Faber £25, pp686
Buy it at BOL

In his introduction, James Atlas refers to the importance of an affinity between biographer and subject. Saul Bellow (born 1915, Nobel Laureate 1976, triumphant producer of both a novel and a child this year) was bound to seem a rich prospect to a biographer whose parents came from the northwest-side Jewish Chicago milieu that was Bellow's human material ('he was experience-near').

Atlas has aspired to the unslavish penetration of Boswell on Johnson, Ellmann on Joyce, biographies 'imbued with profound sympathy for their subjects' foibles and failings - imbued, to put it plainly, with love'.

The resulting book, though, without quite being a blot on the biographer's art, makes a mockery of that high intention. If anything can be said to imbue it, it is an admiration mysteriously shot through with rancour.

Saul Bellow, like any biographical subject, has feet of clay, knees of clay, hips of clay, but there is an incongruous element of resentment in Atlas's recording of his flaws. Balanced literary judgments alternate with a sort of character assassination by degrees.

Bellow's third novel, The Adventures of Augie March (1953), is recognised as having brought a particular appetitious vitality into American fiction. That vitality could be claimed as distinctively Jewish in its earthy sublimity, but Bellow was no more in a hurry to be defined than his hero.

This was a founding father who refused to become an institution: his preferred formulation was (to quote the title of one of his talks) 'Americans Who Are Also Jews'. It argues against a narrow agenda that his novels should have for their protagonists (as Philip Roth has pointed out) physically large and confident Wasps and smaller, less forceful Jews, more or less in alternation, much as Alfred Hitchcock cast assured Cary Grant and vulnerable James Stewart in roles that represented different intensities of wish-fulfilment.

Bellow's private life is spectacularly messy, with four failed marriages, three compromised relationships with sons, periods of cranky therapy and plentiful adulteries. A fair-sized volume could be compiled exclusively from his vengeful fictional versions of ex-wives. His most successful book commercially, Herzog (1964), based on his third wife's affair with his best friend, had the grace to include his self-portrait in the satire.

Atlas has a simple explanation for his subject's failures as a husband: the early death of Bellow's mother, before he had achieved independence from her, prevented him from forging mature relationships. This is a peculiarly reductive analysis, quite apart from the fact that the death of a boy's parent when he's 17 doesn't exactly qualify as childhood trauma.

It requires that Bellow learn absolutely nothing from his entanglements, until things go mysteriously right with Janis Freedman, whom he married in 1989. The other part of the picture is that Bellow was driven to such prodigies of literary effort by the need to prove himself to his worldly elder brothers.

In his acknowledgements, Atlas thanks his assistant, Adam Kirsh, for having 'laboured to make my somewhat impressionistic citations credible'. 'Impressionistic' in a biography sits next to 'citations' as comfortably as 'juggling' next to 'nitroglycerine'. And if this is after the labour, it's hard to imagine before - how much labour would it take to check if T. S. Eliot really described himself as a Roman Catholic?

It's often hard to tell how far Atlas is paraphrasing someone's opinion, and how far he is drowning it out with his own: 'To Adam Bellow [son of the second wife], Janis Freedman was the last in a succession of mother figures, the legacy of his father's overly dependent relationship with a mother who died before he achieved independence from her. "My father needed to be taken care of," said Adam - and that need accounted for his many marriages.' Without a reference of any kind, it's impossible to verify if Adam Bellow said more than the eight quoted words (or even those) - unsurprising testimony from a man whose father has married at the age of 74.

Bellow's 1970 novel Mr Sammler's Planet (or 'dramatic essay,' as he once described it) marked a turning point. By opting for a hero older than himself, a Holocaust survivor, he treated the culture of the 1960s as a problem in itself, rather than engaging with the issues that bedevilled the decade. His sense of grievance remained constant - he seems to have needed to feel embattled - but he metamorphosed from an unpredictable radical (once a Trotskyite) into an entrenched conservative. His hostility to the spread of free love was perhaps puzzling in someone who had so long claimed that privilege for himself.

Early and late he mined other people's lives for material, from Augie March (where he borrowed from a Saturday Evening Post article about training eagles in Mexico) to Ravelstein, published this year, whose hero was closely modelled on Bellow's flamboyant friend and colleague Allan Bloom. Atlas has some damaging points to make about this practice: when Bellow dramatised two notorious Chicago crimes for The Dean's December, they merely became part of his cultural indictment, and he came close to blaming the victim in each case.

Atlas has objections to the general legitimacy of appropriating the lives of others (oddly, since so much of his own book is devoted to tracing the originals of portraits). He quotes in full a 1974 letter of Bellow's to Dave Peltz, an old friend from whose experiences he had lifted an incident for Humboldt's Gift, and describes its 'condescension' and 'total lack of empathy'.

In fact, there is something magnificent about what is almost a literary credo: 'The name of the game is Give All. You are welcome to all my facts. You know them, I give them to you. If you have the strength to pick them up, take them with my blessing. Touch them with your imagination and I will kiss your hands.'

How else is an artist to attempt the portrait of his neighbourhood and his age? If Atlas didn't know before he started out that he was dealing with a transmuter of genius rather than a wholesale inventor, he was as misinformed as Humphrey Bogart's Rick when he visited Casablanca for the waters.

webTitle: Observer review: Get Happy by Gerald Clarke

fields.headline: Punch and Judy
fields.standfirst: Fed pep pills by her mother, given electric shocks by MGM. Gerald Clarke tells the story of Judy Garland's journey to self-destruction in Get Happy
fields.trailText: Fed pep pills by her mother, given electric shocks by MGM. Gerald Clarke tells the story of Judy Garland's journey to self-destruction in Get Happy
fields.body:
Get Happy: the life of Judy Garland
Gerald Clarke
LIttle Brown £20, pp528
Buy it at BOL

Judy Garland is remembered now for her end and her beginning. The dewy ingénue with the soft features and the melting voice is regularly contrasted with the ignominy of her drug-fuzzed final years. The middle of her career, while no less dramatic, is often forgotten.

Clearly, there is a Kenneth Anger-style horror story to be told about the rapid decline of Garland and there have been quite a few schlocky takes on her life already, each following the reductive line reserved for doomed female celebrities from Monroe through to Paula Yates. Garland's own ill-fated daughter, Liza Minnelli, will inevitably one day receive the same retrospective comandeering.

It is a hackneyed journey to self-destruction, but at least in Garland's case we are talking about the collapse of a really big talent. Not 'big' simply in the sense of 'a big voice that belts them out', but big because she was a transcendent and versatile performer.

Her latest biographer, Gerald Clarke, reminds us of the words of James Mason, Garland's funeral eulogist in 1969 and her co-star in A Star is Born. Mason said at the graveside that posterity did not remember entertainers, but Clarke disagrees. Garland is still everywhere, he argues, and he is probably right. While some of the sordid details have been blurred, her voice has permanently informed the idea of how a popular song should be sung.

Back in 1951, when she arrived in Plymouth by boat for one of her first 'comeback' dates at the London Palladium, her British fans were aware of the support she would require. Thousands of them turned up to welcome her, Clarke tells us, while all the ships in the harbour spelled out her name in nautical signals.

And the singer really did need her public. She had no inner resources at all. Her ambitious mother, Ethel Gumm, had fed her youngest daughter Frances, or Baby, on pep pills from the age of 10 - the gruelling studio schedule demanded it. The MGM starlet grew up in front of the cameras, taking school lessons with Deanna Durbin on the lot in between takes for the series of teen movies she was making with Mickey Rooney.

By the time she was a young woman, Garland had learned to judge herself by the harsh standards of screen beauty. Like her daughter, she always had trouble believing she was attractive. David Shipman's earlier biography of the star, Garland, has the producer Joseph Pasternak comment tellingly: 'She wanted to be Lana Turner and it didn't occur to her that Lana Turner might have liked to be Judy Garland.'

In spite of this insecurity, or perhaps because of it, Garland married five times and had many affairs. She felt complete, she said, only when she was in love, yet her titanic emotional demands exhausted all-comers. 'She lives in four dimensions,' complained one boyfriend. Garland also tended to choose men who were bisexual, if not actually gay. Possibly it was a naïve search for the kind of sanitised romance that her musicals portrayed.

The most glamorous of these lovers was the darkly beautiful matinée idol Tyrone Power. Clarke has more information on this affair than previous biographers and describes how their intense passion faltered only when Power signed up for military service. Like Garland's later marriage to Liza's father, film director Vincente Minnelli, the relationship was marred by Power's attraction to men.

The enduring male figures in Garland's life were altogether more macho. The early death of her father, Frank Gumm, had thrown a long shadow, and although he had been secretly homosexual too, for Garland tough guys such as the producers Sidney Luft and Joseph L. Mankiewicz seemed to be cast in his capable mould. A recent book by Lorna Luft, Garland's daughter by the producer, has claimed that he was the only man her mother ever truly loved, but here Clarke decides to stick to an older story. According to him, it was the married and charismatic Mankiewicz of whom Garland continued to dream whenever she sang the Gershwin/Arlen ballad 'The Man That Got Away'.

The fall into barbiturate and amphetamine dependency was quick. She managed to abstain during pregnancy in 1946, and two years later, while working on The Good Old Summertime - in which the baby Liza makes a first screen appearance - Garland responded well to the tender care of cast and crew. As a result, the film confounded expectations and came in on time. But by now the star's hair had started to fall out and she was unceremoniously dropped from Annie Get Your Gun.

At this point, MGM actually administered electric shocks to try to arrest the eclipse of one of their brightest stars. As the film roles dried up, Garland ricocheted from one 'caretaker' to another. Even her elder daughter was pushed into this role. Clarke notes that Liza was the only little girl in Hollywood with her own stomach pump. More than once, she saved her mother's life with it.

The title of this biography is taken from Garland's memorable screen number, 'Get Happy', one of the original 'let's do the show right here!' routines from Summer Stock, in which she starred with Gene Kelly and Phil Silvers. It turns out that this great celluloid moment, now central to the Garland cult, nearly didn't happen. Filming was postponed at the last minute because the star was incapable. Unexpectedly, though, Garland dragged herself to the set on time the next morning and her performance earned her an immortal place as a kitsch siren of the screen.

For Clarke, Garland is a genius, but a genius who, for most of her life, knew she was an addict. He tells us that as a child, Liza had secretly studied her mother's extraordinary singing technique by watching from the top of the stairs as she entertained at parties. Sadly, the daughter seems to have picked up more than performance tips. Minnelli's own struggle with addiction is bleakly prefigured when the dying Garland explains to a boyfriend why she can't 'bounce back' once more. 'The spring is shot,' she says.

webTitle: Observer review: Promises, Promises by Adam Phillips

fields.headline: Analyse this
fields.standfirst: Can you use literature and language to understand the workings of the mind? Adam Phillips appeals for more 'good sentences' in Promises, Promises
fields.trailText: Can you use literature and language to understand the workings of the mind? Adam Phillips appeals for more 'good sentences' in Promises, Promises
fields.body:
Promises, Promises: Essays on Literature and Psychoanalysis
Adam Phillips
Faber £10, pp240

It seems only five minutes since Adam Phillips published his last book: there's no stopping him. Promises, Promises is a collection of reviews, essays and lectures, but if it looks more mixed and patched than some earlier books, then that's part of the point.

Promises, Promises relishes the miscellaneous; characteristically, and appealingly, it avoids dogma, certitudes and authority. But it does have a strong and absorbing theme, which is the relation of psychoanalysis and literature. Which is better? Or, which is better for you? What are their languages good for? And, what good might they do you? 'Words alone are certain good,' Phillips quotes Yeats. But whose words and what is 'certain good'? The words good, better, best run through this book like a plot, or an obsession.

Psychoanalysis, though it is a science, often uses or invokes literature, especially poetry. Why? Because psychoanalysis has to work in and with language, and the language of poetry demonstrates the 'best' possibilities of language, and thereby sustains confidence in the value of words. But there may also be unease and ambiguity in this relationship, and Phillips explores this with interest, care, and considerable scepticism.

(He spends his own writing life in a balancing act between the two. Some of his heroes - Jonathan Lear, Leslie Farber, Lacan, Winnicott - are analysts, but you often feel he would rather be reading T.S. Eliot, John Clare or Hart Crane. As he says at the end of this book: 'Why have an analysis when you can read?')

As if putting his dual allegiance to the test, he asks, are psychoanalysis and literature in competition, or collaboration? You could describe the analyst as a kind of poet. When he (though Phillips often uses 'she') makes a 'good interpretation' of the patient's material, he changes the punctuation and the form: 'The patient's sonnets are turned into free verse, his limericks are turned into elegies.'

Or you could say that the analyst turns the patient into a better writer, the 'good-enough poet of his own life'. (But then, how does the analyst arrive at his sense of 'what a good life for a person is'? 'How do we know what is good for ourselves and someone else?')

Or you could see psychoanalysis in rivalry with the poets. For Freud, creative writers are, enviably, the ones who get away with it, who can make their shameful desires acceptable in public. 'Poetry is the smuggler's art, repackaging contraband so that it can be available on the open market.'

What makes Phillips sceptical is the use of poetry as a means to a 'cure' or as a form of self-knowledge. 'Poets, after all,' he remarks with typical wryness, 'are not famous for their mental health.' Literature should be useful to analysts not as an information kit about human nature, but as an example of words that are good, better or best because they are not propaganda - they are 'hospitable to interpretation'.

Phillips wants analysts not to be cult figures or teachers or propagandists, but to be more popularising and democratic. They should value truthfulness but not Truth; the contingent, the small, and the messy, rather than the visionary or the schematic. (One of his best pieces here is on 'clutter', and he does believe there is such a thing as a 'good mess'.) They should want to be 'interesting', rather than 'right'.

He likes writers who allow in terror, chaos, irony and melancholy: Pessoa, Housman, Hart, Crane, Trilling, Melville (a brilliant essay on Bartleby and anorexia), Patrick McGrath, Frederick Seidel. Couldn't biography, I would ask here, be a way of suggesting the inconclusiveness and messiness of a life? This will have to join the army of unanswered questions raised in, and by, Promises, Promises. Phillips loves questions and quibbles, and he defends the analyst's maddening habit of not answering questions by suggesting that this could encourage the patient in a game of asking without expecting an answer - or without expecting 'that there will be answers at all'.

This hopeful uncertainty is also applied to 'the culture of complaint', in which we are 'forever aggrieved about being misunderstood'. Might it be more interesting not to take offence, but to listen to the ways other people describe us, and work out why we think this might be a mistranslation? Thus we could be 'endlessly fascinated by what people make of us'. Phillips does go on to say that the history of oppression has been a history of people 'having translations imposed upon them by a dominant class or group'. Even so, there seems something theoretical and unreal in suggesting that, say, a black boy set upon by white hoodlums might pause to consider, with endless fascination, how he is being mistranslated.

webTitle: Observer review: The Assassin's Cloak

fields.headline: Those were the days...
fields.standfirst: The Assassin's Cloak is a judicious selection from the diaries of the great, the good, the corrupt and the bitchy
fields.trailText: The Assassin's Cloak is a judicious selection from the diaries of the great, the good, the corrupt and the bitchy
fields.body:
The Assassin's Cloak: An Anthology of the World's Greatest Diarists
edited by Irene and Alan Taylor
Conongate £25, pp684
Buy it at BOL

Diarists today write to be published; to help fulfil a modern need for knowledge - intimate or factual but, crucially, not interpreted by a third party - left somehow vacant by novels and journalism.

So potent has the form become that we now use it ironically as a hyper-real substitute for actual novels or journalism, reaching for truths without restrictive literary conceits or political spin. Adrian Mole, Bridget Jones or Bel Littlejohn... we lap up the diary, even when we know it's fake (or most do. I still cherish a letter, from the early days of Mrs Blair's Diary, which began: 'Why are you letting this stupid woman write? It's only because of who her father is', which missed the point on an endearing number of levels).

How much more potent still, then, to find a huge, eclectic array of real and revealing extracts, kept by the great and the good and the corrupt and the bitchy over four centuries - and many, if not most of them, according to the editors, not written for publication.

Here, in the intricacies of life as it is shared with silent notebooks in all its flavours - shared pompously (Harold Nicolson, Malcolm Muggeridge), drily (Alan Bennett, Stephen Spender, Eleanor Coppola), hilariously (Evelyn Waugh, Kenneth Williams) or devastatingly factually (Victor Klemperer, Queen Victoria, Josef Goebbels) - we learn a million truths and want to go on learning more.

Some truths are little, some huge, but all of them compelling, for one of the joys of this intensely readable book is that the commonplace can seem as crucial to life and its truths as the earthshaking. The sublime and the ridiculous for once co-exist rather marvellously, letting us take insight from the mundane, or the momentous or simply from unique moments in time - Captain Scott's 'very terrible day' or Noël Coward patronising the Beatles.

The book's format helps; borrowing Simon Brett's device from the Faber exercise in the Eighties, the editors have anthologised the entries into 365 'days'. Thus the inclusions for a single date will span - take 7 February, for instance - the ageing John Evelyn's hot-milk baths in 1682, Dawn Powell on Perelman and Thurber bickering over royalties at a 1943 cocktail party, Hugh Casson at Joyce Grenfell's 1980 memorial service, and the wonderful single-line entry from Tolstoy for that day in 1856: 'Quarrelled with Turgenev, and had a wench at my place.'

All the greats are here, and the editors, a zesty Edinburgh couple with a lifelong love of libraries and literature and a grand sense of intellectual fun, have included a catholic, left-field selection and cleverly left out the great but boring (Gissing, Kierkegaard) while joyfully leaving in the plain wrong, such as Virginia Woolf growing 'puzzled, bored, irritated and disillusioned by a queasy undergraduate scratching his pimples...' while reviewing Ulysses.

A labour of love which will sit as happily in the bathroom as in the reference shelf; a fine and a delightful book.

webTitle: Observer review: Chester Himes by James Sallis

fields.headline: From a life of crime to watching the detectives
fields.standfirst: James Sallis's biography circles round the life of the novelist Chester Himes, but is his approach too clinical?
fields.trailText: James Sallis's biography circles round the life of the novelist Chester Himes, but is his approach too clinical?
fields.body:
Chester Himes
James Sallis
Payback Press £18.99, pp385
Buy it at BOL

I was first introduced to Chester Himes aged around 12 or 13. My English teacher had decided that since her class was made up of mostly black students, it was logical that we would find black writers more interesting. This gentle step of logic became a catalyst which changed my life. From my initial reading of Himes, a book called The Real Cool Killers, I was sold. By the end of the term, I had read almost every Chester Himes detective novel published.

Chester Himes was born 29 July, 1909, in Jefferson City, Missouri. His family were well educated, his father, Joseph, teaching mechanical arts, while mother Estelle was a housewife, who previously studied music at a Philadelphia conservatory. As Joseph was dark skinned, and Estelle light enough to 'pass for white', their relationship was a rocky testament to the times they lived in. Somewhat ironically, Himes's father believed that 'White people know best... Blacks should accept white's offer... Count their blessings...' In stark contrast, Estelle, who 'looked white... Was the opposite... Hated condescension from white people...'

At 17 Himes graduated from high school and worked as a busboy in a hotel. Himes studied at Ohio State University, but became disillusioned and was expelled. He turned to crime and was eventually sent to prison for armed robbery, aged 19. While there, he saw violence of unimaginable proportion. Urged by his mother, he wrote about these things, in short stories that were published in a multitude of literary magazines, including Esquire. Eight years after his release, Himes wrote If He Hollers, Let Him Go - in my view, the only novel I have read which honestly deals with the anger, outrage and irrationality racism can bring.

As a biographer, James Sallis, himself an author of some note, has taken a rather clinical, academic view of Himes's life. His first chapter, exactly 40 pages long, details the history of Himes's parents and his life up until internment in prison. While this was all interesting stuff, I would have rather delved straight into the writer's own history, especially since a great deal of the stories are repeated later.

Sallis often speaks about the confusion of Himes' psyche, which bleeds into his work, and ultimately it seems, the biographer's. We are given dates, titles and extracts from books published (especially The Harlem Cycle) as an aid to Sallis's opinion of the author. This happens again when we get to points where they were actually written and published, and once more when Sallis and others who also studied Himes's writings critique them. A more linear, 'storyteller's' feel might have lessened this confusion, although this in no way detracted from my interest.

My only other bone of contention is that, for all of the research done, all of the speeches and books Himes wrote, James Sallis seems to miss the point of Himes's life perspective, as fully and consciously as he details precise facts. No more is this more evident than when he ponders over Himes's differing views concerning his time in New York - the first a CBS interview, 26 years after his stay, extolling his love of Harlem street life - the second, an autobiography published four years later, in which Himes writes: '...I knew... I was sick. But New York excepted me as normal, and that made me sicker...'

Sallis describes this hypothetically as '...two Chesters sitting across a table... debating...' I would present this as another infuriating reaction to racism. You can love a city culturally for what it gives in terms of your people, while on the other hand, hating that other side - the invisible 'tracks' we all cross in these modern times. Sallis, I feel, fails to comprehend just how confusing those times were for black people - and still are.

Sallis's enthusiasm and genuine respect for the man far overshadows these admittedly minute factors. Although long, the opening chapter does much to help us understand the events that made Chester and his work what they were.

I loved the discussions on satire and dark humour in Himes's Harlem Cycle and earlier books. When Sallis deals with Himes's attitude to the work, the book becomes revealing, honest, and sometimes very sad. Chapters come alive in a manner more flowing than academic; more instinctive than researched - more raw and undiluted Chester than you could imagine. I found myself liking this imperfect genius as well as his work, feeling real pain when I came to the end of his biography and life.

webTitle: Observer review: The New Penguin Book of English Verse

fields.headline: Scott, Byron, Keats, Shelley, Blake. And the winner is...
fields.standfirst: 1819 proves a very good year in the chronological anthology, The New Penguin Book of English Verse
fields.trailText: 1819 proves a very good year in the chronological anthology, The New Penguin Book of English Verse
fields.body:
The New Penguin Book of English Verse
edited by Paul Keegan
Penguin £20, pp1,139
Buy it at BOL

The solid shape and glowing cover of The New Penguin Book of English Verse set beating a pulse of excitement. Seven hundred years of language, distilled into its sharpest and brightest forms, are here to be discovered. The poems, like jewels, have to be reset for new admiration.

The reader is very much at the centre of Paul Keegan's enterprise. He has chosen to arrange the poems not by date of composition, or by the order of their authors' births, but as they were first published in volume form. As Keegan points out in his preface, his method of structuring an anthology makes quite a difference to how we view the poems. What a year 1819 was for the reader, for instance. He or she might first have encountered Scott's The Bride of Lammermoor, Keats's The Eve of St Agnes, the first Canto of Byron's Don Juan, Shelley's The Mask of Anarchy or Blake's To the Accuser Who is the God of This World. A reader in 1611 might have looked into Chapman's Homer for the first time, as well as the Authorised Version of the Bible.

Keegan's decision on chronology is justified by the vibrancy of communication between one poem or the next. It is fascinating, for example, that two poems that make such deep but different appeals to public emotion as Kipling's 'Recessional' and Wilde's 'The Ballad of Reading Gaol' were published within a year of each other, and are set side by side in this anthology.

Kipling and Wilde, strangers in many things, share a confident sense of audience which today's poets can only wonder at, and perhaps envy. Both poets believe in their hold on the public, and that poetry must use this hold to enlighten and instruct. 'By each let this be heard,' urges Wilde, as he forces his readers to contemplate their own kinship with the condemned man in prison. Kipling, too, warns against insular complacency as he addresses the British Empire at its zenith:

Far called, our navies melt away;

On dune and headland sinks the fire:

Lo, all our pomp of yesterday

Is one with Ninevah and Tyre!

Again and again, the reader comes across such thoughtful, thought-provoking juxtapositions of poems.

Keegan's respect for the contemporary reader's experience of these poems as they were published has also led him to leave spelling and punctuation unmodernised. The risk that this may make some poems more difficult is balanced by the gain of a certain frisson of strangeness, as the rind of familiarity is stripped away:

They fle from me that sometyme did me seke

With naked fote stalking in my chambre.

I have seen theim gentill tame and meke

That nowe are wyld and do not remembre

That sometyme they put theimself in daunger

To take bred at my hand...

(Sir Thomas Wyatt)

Such a well-known poem can only gain from this slight linguistic estrangement. The royal court Wyatt describes here is no haven of trundling Germanic protocol, but the court of Henry VIII, foreign by more than four centuries, a place of danger, rumour and execution.

Keegan follows tradition in calling this a book of verse, rather than a book of poetry. Hymns, carols, street cries, epitaphs, ballads, adages, nonsense verse and rhymes thicken the brew. The plangent, poignant voice of Anonymous is among the strongest. Here again, Keegan's emphasis on chronology comes into its own. It's easier to appreciate the influence of the traditional ballad on Coleridge, for instance, when 'Dejection, An Ode' faces 'The Wife of Usher's Well', which was published the same year in Scott's edition of Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border.

The delight of any poetry anthology lies not only in finding new facets to well-known poems, but also in being introduced to less familiar work. John Davidson's 'Thirty Bob a Week' describes the grind of a clerk's life in the 1890s. At first it seems conventional enough in its touching detail, but then the voice grows stronger. Suddenly the poem takes fire from the defiant sweep of this clerk's imagination, and his claim for justice:

It's a naked child against a hungry wolf;

It's playing bowls upon a splitting wreck;

It's walking on a string across a gulf

With the millstones fore-and-aft about your neck;

But the thing is daily done by many and many a one;

And we fall, face forward, fighting, on the deck.

When it comes to the twentieth century, Keegan makes clear that his coverage is not inclusive. Poets born later than the outset of the 1950s do not qualify. This seems reasonable, bearing in mind that the poems and the reputations of younger poets are still very much in the making.

But there are other exclusions which are more surprising and more questionable. Keegan devotes 279 pages, out of 1,100-odd, to twentieth-century poetry. Fewer than 30 poems by women feature on these pages, and none is a long poem. There is nothing by Fleur Adcock, U. A. Fanthorpe, Liz Lochhead, Selima Hill, E. J. Scovell, Elizabeth Jennings, Wendy Cope, Gillian Clarke, Anne Stevenson, Carol Rumens, Ruth Padel, Pauline Stainer, Kathleen Raine, Patricia Beer, Elaine Feinstein, Ruth Fainlight, Vicki Feaver, Penelope Shuttle, Gillian Allnut; many other fine women poets born well before 1950 come to mind. You will not find Jenny Joseph's 'Warning' here; it has been much anthologised, it's true, but surely no more than Heaney's 'Personal Helicon', which is included.

All this is such a loss to the reader. Vital registers and qualities of late twentieth-century poetry are missing. There's none of Cope's formal wit and play, Hill's ferocious originality, or Fanthorpe's Janus-faced monologues. Their absence is baffling and the anthology's representation of the twentieth century is diminished by it, as is the reader's pleasure.

Anthologies are built on arguments and will always provoke them. But, as The New Penguin Book of English Verse demonstrates, we have the good fortune to live in the English language, perhaps the richest, most supple, promising, sharp-tongued and rule-breaking playground for poetry. Argument will only find its answer in more poems.

He or she might first have encountered Scott's The Bride of Lammermoor, Keats's The Eve of St Agnes, the first Canto of Byron's Don Juan, Shelley's The Mask of Anarchy or Blake's To the Accuser Who is the God of This World. A reader in 1611 might have looked into Chapman's Homer for the first time, as well as the Authorised Version of the Bible. Keegan's decision on chronology is justified by the vibrancy of communication between one poem or the next. It is fascinating, for example, that two poems that make such deep but different appeals to public emotion as Kipling's 'Recessional' and Wilde's 'The Ballad of Reading Gaol' were published within a year of each other, and are set side by side in this anthology. Kipling and Wilde, strangers in many things, share a confident sense of audience which today's poets can only wonder at, and perhaps envy. Both poets believe in their hold on the public, and that poetry must use this hold to enlighten and instruct. 'By each let this be heard,' urges Wilde, as he forces his readers to contemplate their own kinship with the condemned man in prison. Kipling, too, warns against insular complacency as he addresses the British Empire at its zenith: Far called, our navies melt away; On dune and headland sinks the fire: Lo, all our pomp of yesterday Is one with Ninevah and Tyre! Again and again, the reader comes across such thoughtful, thought-provoking juxtapositions of poems. Keegan's respect for the contemporary reader's experience of these poems as they were published has also led him to leave spelling and punctuation unmodernised. The risk that this may make some poems more difficult is balanced by the gain of a certain frisson of strangeness, as the rind of familiarity is stripped away: They fle from me that sometyme did me seke With naked fote stalking in my chambre. I have seen theim gentill tame and meke That nowe are wyld and do not remembre That sometyme they put theimself in daunger To take bred at my hand... (Sir Thomas Wyatt) Such a well-known poem can only gain from this slight linguistic estrangement. The royal court Wyatt describes here is no haven of trundling Germanic protocol, but the court of Henry VIII, foreign by more than four centuries, a place of danger, rumour and execution. Keegan follows tradition in calling this a book of verse, rather than a book of poetry. Hymns, carols, street cries, epitaphs, ballads, adages, nonsense verse and rhymes thicken the brew. The plangent, poignant voice of Anonymous is among the strongest. Here again, Keegan's emphasis on chronology comes into its own. It's easier to appreciate the influence of the traditional ballad on Coleridge, for instance, when 'Dejection, An Ode' faces 'The Wife of Usher's Well', which was published the same year in Scott's edition of Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border. The delight of any poetry anthology lies not only in finding new facets to well-known poems, but also in being introduced to less familiar work. John Davidson's 'Thirty Bob a Week' describes the grind of a clerk's life in the 1890s. At first it seems conventional enough in its touching detail, but then the voice grows stronger. Suddenly the poem takes fire from the defiant sweep of this clerk's imagination, and his claim for justice: It's a naked child against a hungry wolf; It's playing bowls upon a splitting wreck; It's walking on a string across a gulf With the millstones fore-and-aft about your neck; But the thing is daily done by many and many a one; And we fall, face forward, fighting, on the deck. When it comes to the twentieth century, Keegan makes clear that his coverage is not inclusive. Poets born later than the outset of the 1950s do not qualify. This seems reasonable, bearing in mind that the poems and the reputations of younger poets are still very much in the making. But there are other exclusions which are more surprising and more questionable. Keegan devotes 279 pages, out of 1,100-odd, to twentieth-century poetry. Fewer than 30 poems by women feature on these pages, and none is a long poem. There is nothing by Fleur Adcock, U. A. Fanthorpe, Liz Lochhead, Selima Hill, E. J. Scovell, Elizabeth Jennings, Wendy Cope, Gillian Clarke, Anne Stevenson, Carol Rumens, Ruth Padel, Pauline Stainer, Kathleen Raine, Patricia Beer, Elaine Feinstein, Ruth Fainlight, Vicki Feaver, Penelope Shuttle, Gillian Allnut; many other fine women poets born well before 1950 come to mind. You will not find Jenny Joseph's 'Warning' here; it has been much anthologised, it's true, but surely no more than Heaney's 'Personal Helicon', which is included. All this is such a loss to the reader. Vital registers and qualities of late twentieth-century poetry are missing. There's none of Cope's formal wit and play, Hill's ferocious originality, or Fanthorpe's Janus-faced monologues. Their absence is baffling and the anthology's representation of the twentieth century is diminished by it, as is the reader's pleasure. Anthologies are built on arguments and will always provoke them. But, as The New Penguin Book of English Verse demonstrates, we have the good fortune to live in the English language, perhaps the richest, most supple, promising, sharp-tongued and rule-breaking playground for poetry. Argument will only find its answer in more poems.

webTitle: Observer review: War of Nerves by Ben Shephard

fields.headline: And they called them cowards
fields.standfirst: Ben Shephard explores the relationship between soldiers and psychiatrists in the 20th century in War of Nerves
fields.trailText: Ben Shephard explores the relationship between soldiers and psychiatrists in the 20th century in War of Nerves
fields.body:
War of Nerves
Ben Shephard
Jonathan Cape £20, pp500
Buy it at BOL

In the summer of 1917, at the gargantuan Victorian military hospital at Netley on the banks of Southampton Water, the Pathé Brothers were hired to make a film. It must have been summer, because the light on the huge nineteenth-century building is sharp as it falls on the quivering figures that stagger in front of its elegant façade. They are soldiers, but their movements are as far from military drill as it is possible to be. Twisted into baroque shapes by the memory of the war they have left behind, their bodies cannot forget what their minds have already tried to erase.

On Remembrance Sunday 2000, the memory of the First World War as a British Holocaust remains as vivid as ever. To anyone who has seen that footage shot at Netley, the horrific reach of war beyond the physical wounds of shells and bullets is terrifyingly clear. Yet as Ben Shephard shows, 'the pity of war' of which Wilfred Owen wrote was also a problem for the cure of such men; their doctors despaired of the 'wave of sentimentality' which 'made the sane treatment of shell-shock' almost impossible. In his admirable study, Shephard seeks to look beyond our 'counselling culture' and tendency to 'project backwards', to examine the true nature, and treatment, of these neuroses of war.

His early chapters are a wonderful scene-setting of Edwardian 'neurasthenia', patent medicines for 'brain fatigue' and 'railway spine' - the neuroses of a new industrial, consumerist age in which fears of racial degeneration went hand-in-hand with the notion that war was still the ultimate test of manhood. Armageddon threw all this into question, not least for the military medical authorities. Military hospitals had one overriding and paradoxical function - to cure men so that they could return to battle. As Shephard shows, shell-shock was a modern complication for these old certainties.

Coined by the Jewish Cambridge psychiatrist Charles Myers in 1915 - although the term was already being used by soldiers - the public response to shell-shock would force the Army to acknowledge the condition; while its drafted-in psychiatrists soon realised that shell-shock had less to do with explosions and more with the entire process of modern war.

For the soldiers themselves, the physical symptoms were visible proof that they were not 'swinging the lead'. Even Myers decided that you had to be 'cruel to be kind', that soldiers were best treated as near to the frontline as possible, and sent back there. The brutality and stupidity of a war that ordered men to fight in such conditions, then denied them proper care for their blasted nervous systems, is still unbelievable.

As the war ground on, it seemed the Army was eating itself, like Goya's anthropophagous Saturn devouring his children. Generals miles behind the line talked of 'wastage', just as their modern counterparts speak of 'collateral damage', and had even less time for 'alienists' from universities intent on proving their strange theories.

More to their taste were the physical treatments which used another modern development - electricity - and what to modern ears sounds like out-and-out torture. One dumbstruck patient was 'strapped in a chair for 20 minutes at a time while strong electricity was applied to his neck and throat; lighted cigarettes had been applied to the tip of his tongue and "hot plates" had been placed at the back of his mouth. Hypnotism had also been tried.'

The 1920s' post-mortems on the war concluded that public sentimentality actively stood in the way of curing these men. In the next war, the Army attempted to control mental casualties by restricting their diagnoses - breakdowns were not 'rewarded'. 'Shell-shock' had evolved from 'war neurosis' into 'combat fatigue', and new drug therapies developed to deal with them, just as modern conflicts saw the 'invention' of post-traumatic stress disorder. In his concluding chapter on 'the culture of trauma', Shephard quotes one psychiatrist who believes that 'men today are incapable of fighting war without psychological damage'. It is one of the wonders of this fine book that anyone ever believed otherwise.

webTitle: Observer review: Abyssinian Chronicles by Moses Isegawa

fields.headline: Amin was his saviour. Until reality set in
fields.standfirst: Moses Isegawa's spectacular debut, Abyssinian Chronicles, is an angry epic which follows the fortunes of a rich cast of characters in the turmoil of Idi Amin's Uganda
fields.trailText: Moses Isegawa's spectacular debut, Abyssinian Chronicles, is an angry epic which follows the fortunes of a rich cast of characters in the turmoil of Idi Amin's Uganda
fields.body:
Abyssinian Chronicles
Moses Isegawa
Picador £16, pp462
Buy it at BOL

Not many novels begin with the narrator's father disappearing into the jaws of a crocodile. It's an opening that's textbook attention-grabbing, but also one to cause a sigh of anxiety that the reader's in for a heavy dose of whimsical, magic-realist adventures.

In this case, however, such anxiety proves profoundly misplaced. Moses Isegawa's opening does set the tone for some of what's to follow: the unfamiliar quirks of a country full of snakes, crocodiles and scorpions and a culture combining tribal traditions and superstitions with fanatical Catholicism, Protestantism, despotism and Islam. But it can't begin to hint at the scope and ambition of his bewitching bildungsroman, set in Uganda over the past 30 years.

In the tradition of Tristram Shandy, Isegawa's narrator, Mugezi, has no hesitation in offering intensely detailed descriptions of incidents that precede his own existence. He describes the childhood of his father, Serenity, who was the son of the local clan chief and a mother who ran off with a shopkeeper. Serenity's faith in women remains extremely shaky until the day he learns that the blushing ex-nun he has picked as a bride has, after 'nine consecutive novenas to St Jude Thaddeus' agreed to go ahead and marry him.

Mugezi's account of his parents' wedding is extremely funny, packed with layer upon layer of vivid detail: the virgin bride's prudish horror at the deeply suggestive pelvic gyrations of the dancers; the near-disastrous wedding night, in which Serenity finds that erections 'seemed to be manufactured in a factory far away', but is baled out by the helpful interventions of a bridal aunt who subsequently becomes his mistress; the rivers of vomit and diarrhoea flooding the village after the wedding feast. It's all done in a verbose, polysyllabic style, teeming with colourful and at times far-fetched similes and metaphors, but is rescued from pomp by a gentle, pervasive irony and regular disarming doses of the abruptly colloquial and down-to-earth.

In this vein, Mugezi spends his early years 'in the baby business' with his great-aunt 'as a midwife's mascot-cum-assistant'. Following her death in a fire at just the time Idi Amin seizes power, he joins his parents at their bungalow in the city and finds that he has 'become the family shitman. Every morning,' he confides, 'my olefactory glands were bombarded with a string of scatological blasts, my eyes smothered with scatalogical disasters in different gradations of colour and sordidity.' His mother, whose nickname appears to have switched from Virgin to Padlock, delegates all the washing, wiping and nappy-laundering to her eldest son. For the rest of the book, Mugezi refers to his siblings only as 'the shitters'.

Mugezi's excremental duties are an apt metaphor for the punishing regime in which he finds himself trapped. Padlock proves more power-crazed than any dictator, forcing Mugezi to kneel before her for hours on end and rewarding every minor and imagined misdemeanour with savage thrashings. Serenity colludes in the despotism, only rarely emerging from his silent communion with Dickens or Waiting for Godot to add his own words of chastisement.

When his childhood fantasy comes true, and the nation's shopkeepers, indeed all Indians, are expelled by Amin, he wins his bet that the West won't intervene. All are delighted that these agents of British colonial oppression have been forced out. As Mugezi struggles to survive the parental dictatorship, he finds his admiration for Amin swelling by the day. 'Amin had exhorted every citizen to walk tall, to act proud and not to let anyone deny them their rights, their dignity or their self-worth.'

Mugezi eventually engineers his own expulsion from the family home and into another dictatorial regime, that of a Catholic seminary. Here he discovers the age-old cycle of bullying, how the victims become the perpetrators. He is mesmerised by the power machinations of a rich, white European priest and adept at making his own Machiavellian manoeuvres in order to prosper and survive.

As Uganda lurches into the horrific aftermath of the Amin regime, he realises that he had 'dammed his disgust' with the reality of the political situation 'just to keep fighting in my corner'. Mugezi finds his grandfather's maimed body on a street corner, hears that his Aunt Kasawo has been gang-raped and witnesses his Aunt Lwandeka's excruciating, lingering death from Aids. Wrung out by the sufferings of his country, he flees to Amsterdam and embarks on a whole new life as a black man in the land of the colonisers.

Abyssinian Chronicles is, in every sense, a big book, exploding with big themes and a rich cast of colourful characters. Giles Foden's superb 1998 novel The Last King of Scotland offered a convincing glimpse of Amin's torturous regime, but Isegawa's work suggests a passionate immersion in his country's history that few Europeans could match. Now living, like his narrator, in Amsterdam, he has clearly been called on to explain to white Europeans at parties the violence, starvation, civil wars and corruption of Rwanda, Sierra Leone and Sudan. This funny, gripping, angry epic is his response, a snapshot of a tiny corner of Africa and its complex history: the impossible legacy of colonial powers who 'had parcelled out Africa among themselves at the Berlin Conference in 1884 without even stepping foot on the continent'.

Isegawa's novel is, as some American reviews have pointed out, reminiscent of Rushdie and Marquez. It is also reminiscent of another recent debut, Zadie Smith's White Teeth. Smith famously attacked her own work for self-indulgence and excess, criticisms which could be judiciously applied here. Isegawa does have a tendency to overwrite, use two or three metaphors where one might do and a slightly irritating fondness for certain words and phrases: 'die-hard', 'hydra', 'gobbled virginity' and even 'locusts in the thorax'.

He occasionally lapses into clumsiness and some of his rhetorical devices - such as repeating a phrase throughout an entire paragraph - can get a little tedious. These minor flaws do not detract from the vibrancy and power of a spectacular debut, and one which makes a significant contribution to the literature of Africa.

webTitle: Comment: Amos Oz; conscience of Israel

fields.headline: The desert conscience of Israel
fields.standfirst:
When the Palestinian leader spurned the Israeli leader last month, he lost an ally in the Jewish state

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: When the Palestinian leader spurned the Israeli leader last month, he lost an ally in the Jewish state.
fields.body:
Built on sand, topped by three inches of imported soil watered with rigid economy, the Israeli city of Arad clings on to the Judean desert. Fifteen years ago, the country's leading writer, Amos Oz, resettled there, where last weekend I met him to talk about his latest novel, The Same Sea, a remarkable work which comes out in the UK next spring.

After the interview we left his home in mid-afternoon and, on the edge of the desert in sight of the multiplication of small mountains - bare, home for jackals and wolves and even, it is rumoured, the occasional leopard - and mesmerising desert-scape, talked of the crisis in his beloved country.

Oz is about to have a knee transplant and he walks with a stick and with difficulty, but neither complaining nor clumsy, still the steady bearing of the soldier he once was. It must have been hard to endure for such a man that again and again over the years there have been those in Israel who have called him a traitor.

Fearless in taking up the cause of Arabs and the Palestinians when he believed they were right, Amos Oz has played a pivotal role in the peace movement. He has cultivated friendships and alliances with writers from 'the other side', although his love of his own country was never in doubt.

Like many friends of Israel, and like many Jews and Israelis, I have found the information about the current state of the conflict, particularly as presented on television, to be both confusing and disturbing. And I am aware that coming to Oz as if he were a touchstone could be thought naïve. Political commentators in the Middle East enormously more informed than I am make their judgments on a mass of material and experience which I do not possess. But I have followed the history of Israel for more than 50 years, followed it with admiration. I have ranged over the place, read its writers, spoken about it with those who live there and those living here in the UK who feel connected historically and by kin. This does not earn me an informed opinion but it does, I hope, explain why, like so many others, I feel a need to get to the root of what is happening, to find a way through the clutter.

I do not think that 'need' is too dramatic a word. The fate of Israel matters beyond its borders. The country has an infinite attraction for those like myself whose childhood was saturated in Christianity and part of whose adolescence was defined in the battle against it. For Christians, Israel is some sort of home.

This I think helps me to understand the passion Israelis have for their land. But this is the rub. Is it theirs? I agree with Amos Oz here when he says that we have a case of two rights - the Palestinians have a right to be there and so do the Israelis. That, Oz hoped, could have been the basis for unity. Instead it has proved the trigger for tragedy. The fundamental point made by Oz in recent weeks is that sooner or later there will be a recognition of these two rights. There are more than five million Israelis and almost three and a half million Palestinians. Neither population is going anywhere and talk of pushing the Israelis into the sea or sending the Palestinians elsewhere is unrealistic madness.

As Oz sees, it a line will now be drawn. The attempt, which he worked for, to be 'one happy family' (his phrase) is lost. And as he sees it Arafat is the man to blame for the end of a unity which seemed within sight.

There are commentators who believe that the offer made to Arafat was unacceptable. They even say that had he taken it back to the Palestinians he would have been killed. The view of Amos Oz, which I share, is that Israel's Prime Minister, Ehud Barak, went further even than the peace movement dared hope. Barak gave, gritted his teeth, and gave again, testing the democratic support of his constituency beyond any previous limit. Arafat spurned him.

It was then that Amos Oz wrote a passionate attack on the Palestinian leader and argued, convincingly I think, that the Israelis could not in real terms at this stage do anything more than Barak had offered. That was the limit and Arafat knew it.

Oz still retains an extraordinary roundedness about these confrontations - deploring the casualties, wry about the media's power to organise events here as in other conflicts, keeping his lines open to his friends 'on the other side'. But he has nailed his colours to, ironically once again, an unfashionable mast.

It is easy to lash the Israelis. Partly because they seem so impregnable - though the armour without may not reflect the insecurity within, as we know from Freud - and partly because Israel is a democratic society like our own and we are very good at skinning our own. Fundamentalist societies leave us rather baffled and we tend to stand off from them.

For years I have regarded Amos Oz as the conscience of Israel. After our talk in the desert I am once again gladly reinforced in that conviction.

Like many friends of Israel, and like many Jews and Israelis, I have found the information about the current state of the conflict, particularly as presented on television, to be both confusing and disturbing. And I am aware that coming to Oz as if he were a touchstone could be thought naïve. Political commentators in the Middle East enormously more informed than I am make their judgments on a mass of material and experience which I do not possess. But I have followed the history of Israel for more than 50 years, followed it with admiration. I have ranged over the place, read its writers, spoken about it with those who live there and those living here in the UK who feel connected historically and by kin. This does not earn me an informed opinion but it does, I hope, explain why, like so many others, I feel a need to get to the root of what is happening, to find a way through the clutter. I do not think that 'need' is too dramatic a word. The fate of Israel matters beyond its borders. The country has an infinite attraction for those like myself whose childhood was saturated in Christianity and part of whose adolescence was defined in the battle against it. For Christians, Israel is some sort of home. This I think helps me to understand the passion Israelis have for their land. But this is the rub. Is it theirs? I agree with Amos Oz here when he says that we have a case of two rights - the Palestinians have a right to be there and so do the Israelis. That, Oz hoped, could have been the basis for unity. Instead it has proved the trigger for tragedy. The fundamental point made by Oz in recent weeks is that sooner or later there will be a recognition of these two rights. There are more than five million Israelis and almost three and a half million Palestinians. Neither population is going anywhere and talk of pushing the Israelis into the sea or sending the Palestinians elsewhere is unrealistic madness. As Oz sees, it a line will now be drawn. The attempt, which he worked for, to be 'one happy family' (his phrase) is lost. And as he sees it Arafat is the man to blame for the end of a unity which seemed within sight. There are commentators who believe that the offer made to Arafat was unacceptable. They even say that had he taken it back to the Palestinians he would have been killed. The view of Amos Oz, which I share, is that Israel's Prime Minister, Ehud Barak, went further even than the peace movement dared hope. Barak gave, gritted his teeth, and gave again, testing the democratic support of his constituency beyond any previous limit. Arafat spurned him. It was then that Amos Oz wrote a passionate attack on the Palestinian leader and argued, convincingly I think, that the Israelis could not in real terms at this stage do anything more than Barak had offered. That was the limit and Arafat knew it. Oz still retains an extraordinary roundedness about these confrontations - deploring the casualties, wry about the media's power to organise events here as in other conflicts, keeping his lines open to his friends 'on the other side'. But he has nailed his colours to, ironically once again, an unfashionable mast. It is easy to lash the Israelis. Partly because they seem so impregnable - though the armour without may not reflect the insecurity within, as we know from Freud - and partly because Israel is a democratic society like our own and we are very good at skinning our own. Fundamentalist societies leave us rather baffled and we tend to stand off from them. For years I have regarded Amos Oz as the conscience of Israel. After our talk in the desert I am once again gladly reinforced in that conviction.
