webTitle: Profile: Dennis Malamatinas

fields.headline: Dotcom price was right for burger king
fields.standfirst:
Ronald McDonald's arch enemy couldn't resist the lure of the internet

Net news
fields.trailText: Ronald McDonald's arch enemy couldn't resist the lure of the internet...
fields.body:
When he was 17 Dennis Malamatinas spent Christmas alone in a strange city. It was 1972 and the teenager had arrived in Chicago from Greece a few months earlier with $300 in his back pocket - cash earned from working on building sites over the previous two years.

'My dream was always America. I loved to play basketball. I still do. America to me was a dreamland. I had a problem convincing my parents who at first wouldn't let me go,' Malamatinas says with more than a hint of flamboyance.

On his first day in the Windy City, Malamatinas knocked on restaurant doors. Eventually he was taken on as a kitchen hand, starting at 5am. It was the start of a long career in the food and drink industry. Indeed, at the start of this year Malamatinas was still in the restaurant business. Only by then he was the boss of Burger King, having cut his teeth working for the likes of Procter & Gamble, Pepsico and Smirnoff.

But sitting by his dormitory bed during the festive season 28 years ago, a lonely Malamatinas was close to throwing in the towel. 'I thought "what am I doing here?" I went through a period of about six months when I thought I'd make some money and then just go back. It was depressing - when you're a young kid on your own.'

But he hung on and earned enough cash to help fund his way through two university courses, ending up with an MBA from the University of Chicago School of Business.

Malamatinas enjoys talking about his humble origins. 'I'm very proud of my background. You name it - I've done it. It makes you a better person - you appreciate people from all walks of life. You get a different perspective.'

Malamatinas boasts a truly cosmopolitan background. Born to Greek parents who owned a plantation in Tanzania, he ended up moving back to Greece at a few years old. As well as the US, his work has taken him to Italy, France, Asia and the Soviet Union. Somewhere along the line he lived in Switzerland. As a result Malamatinas speaks four languages and has Greek and Swiss passports. The English accents of his three children vary according to which country they were brought up in.

So what nationality is he now? 'I'm Mediterranean, a southern European,' he says in an accent which is a fusion of Greek and Italian. 'I think that's what the world is moving to. The internet is eliminating those barriers, those mental blocks. Who cares what nationality you are?'

It is a revealing comment, one which helps explain why Malamatinas, having risen to being Ronald McDonald's public enemy number one, shocked the business world this year by suddenly jacking everything in to launch an internet venture.

News that Priceline, the name-your-price internet company, had managed to secure the services of Burger King's head honcho, came as a surreal surprise - even in the weird world of the web. Admittedly, Malamatinas signed up to head Priceline's European operations in March - just before the bubble started to deflate so dramatically ('My timing may not have been that good'.

Burger King's owner, Diageo, was in the middle of floating off the company, giving Malamatinas a massive new challenge and a chance to make a global impact. His position had already earned him an audience with the Pope and a job advising Bill Clinton as a founding member of the President's Welfare to Work initiative. And besides, what did he know about the wired world?

What he did know about was branding. 'You ask the same questions: What does my brand stand for? What are its core values? What is my creative strategy? How do we communicate with consumers? You build teams - that's what I've done all my life. I understand consumers.'

When he took the job, Priceline had a market capitalisation of around $10 billion, having dropped from a high of $17bn. The company was seen as one of the best examples of a dotcom company, a business which used the internet intelligently to bring huge new benefits to consumers. Users would click on the site and have the chance to say just how much they were prepared to pay for things like car rental or air tickets. The more flexible consumers were prepared to be, the greater the savings. Mala matinas, having met the company's founder, Jay Walker, was hooked.

'The power of allowing the customer to name their own price is, I think, fantastic. It's unique. It benefits both suppliers and customers. Consumers enjoy significant savings, while the suppliers - the airlines or the car rental companies - regenerate significant revenues.'

Today, however, Priceline.com is worth less than $1bn, and many wonder whether its business model is sustainable. Earlier this month the company's chief financial officer, Heidi Miller, resigned. At the same time an investor filed a lawsuit against three of the firm's directors, alleging that they used inside information to sell shares before the company issued a raft of bad news.

Priceline Europe, which soft-launched last month but will go on a PR blitz in the new year, is understandably keen to distance itself from the financial shenanigans of its transatlantic sibling. The company is a joint venture, backed by its US namesake and venture capital firm General Atlantic Partners.

But the European operation is Malamatinas's baby. He is responsible for the site's launch, its look, everything. This was certainly one of the main attractions of the job.

'I've been fascinated by the world of the new economy. The fact is that the internet is here to stay and it's going to fundamentally change our lives. I wanted to be part of that. I didn't want to be a 50-year-old businessman looking back and thinking "wow, how did I miss this revolution?".'

He says it was the challenge of nurturing a start-up that attracted him when he was approached in March. By then he was already sick of the mad commute between his London home and Burger King's Miami HQ.

Having made enough money to ensure he would no longer have to worry about it, Malamatinas, who says he intends to stay with Priceline for 'about five years', felt he could afford a gamble in keeping with his entrepreneurial streak. 'The number one rule in life is to have fun. I'm a self-made man. I didn't have my daddy paying for school. A lot of people joined the new economy to make a fast buck. I don't believe in fast bucks. I've worked hard enough in my life to get where I am.'

But 'fun' will not be a byword for dotcom excess. 'There's a lot of bullshit, a lot of hype. People create this myth about the dotcom sector. As far as I'm concerned the same disciplines and processes apply to any business. I dearly want to create a culture which is a nice blend of the old economy and the new: the processes and disciplines of the old economy, but the speed of the new. I'm impatient - I move fast.'

Which is no more than you would expect from a burger king.

webTitle: Lottery help for seaside towns

fields.headline: Lottery help for seaside towns
fields.standfirst: Special report: the lottery
fields.trailText: It's famous for kiss-me-quick hats, donkey rides and tacky amusement arcades. Visitors are struck by its rainswept promenade, boarded-up town centre and grittily determined cheer.
fields.body:
It's famous for kiss-me-quick hats, donkey rides and tacky amusement arcades. Visitors are struck by its rainswept promenade, boarded-up town centre and grittily determined cheer.

But this week Margate - the home of Tracey Emin and J.M.W. Turner - will relaunch itself as the cultural capital of the South-East, with galleries, recording studios, a media centre and an arts festival.

'The only thing people know about Margate is the donkey rides and the arcades. We want to create something new,' said Michael Etherton of the Margate Artists' Forum, which is opening a gallery in the Kent town. 'We have to play on the kitsch factor of modern art.'

The Government views seaside resorts as national black spots on a par with mining communities and steel towns. They have a large proportion of elderly people with little spending power, and struggle to attract many visitors from Britain, let alone abroad. Earlier this year an inquiry was launched into how the resorts can be saved and a task force set up to address the issue.

This week the National Lottery Heritage Fund will give millions of pounds to Margate, Morecambe, Cromer and Hastings.

In Cromer, the lottery money will be used to restore the moulded Georgian façades that have been ruined by the sea air. In Morecambe the money will be used to revitalise many of the town's vacant historic buildings.

But the most dramatic reinvention is in Margate. The town is modelling itself on St Ives in Cornwall, which jumped from fishing village to cultural centre with the opening of the Tate Gallery. In Margate, the council is hoping the £10m Turner Centre, due to open in 2002, will have the same effect.

Turner spent many years in the town, painting some of his most famous sunsets in the area. Talks have been held with Tate Britain in London about borrowing paintings, and the architectural models will be unveiled next month.

'Now they think of Margate and think of arcades,' said Etherton, 'But in five years' time everyone will think of Margate and think of the Turner centre.'

anthony.browne@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Dotcom world's wizards are in the pink

fields.headline: Dotcom world's wizards are in the pink
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: The new economy is a pink economy. A study has found a link between dotcom success and the number of homosexuals a company employs.
fields.body:
The new economy is a pink economy. A study has found a link between dotcom success and the number of homosexuals a company employs.

New research has uncovered the unexpected connection between hubs of hi-tech success and unusually high concentrations of gays. According to experts, if a business relies heavily on information technology, it will be most successful if it is located in a town with a large gay community.

Professor Richard Florida, of the Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, created a computer programme of areas across America with booming hi-tech industries and found a perfect match with areas of high concentration of homosexuals.

British millionaire Ivan Massow is a prominent gay businessman who has gained a reputation for running his Soho-based financial advisory company with a unique disregard for the more common prejudices of financial institutions.

'It's a familiar idea that there is an unusually large concentration of gay people in the IT business, and we have certainly noticed a correlation. Because of the kind of work we specialise in, we attract a far higher than average number of gays and lots of our clients work in IT,' he said.

Ian Elwick set up the Brighton Media Centre eight years ago and has seen the town boom from a handful of companies located there to a total of 250 last year. The town is regarded as a gay centre.

'Brighton does without doubt have one of the highest concentrations of gays in the country and certainly has a high concentration of new media. A lot of the gay people I meet who have come down here from London say it is a much more ghettoised gay community there and things are a lot easier here.'

Lisa Honon was the brains behind Eye Network, organising international video conferencing, and chose to base her business in Brighton because it was a freer atmosphere for a gay businesswoman.

'My feeling is that there is a higher propensity for gay people to work for themselves away from the often homophobic atmosphere of offices,' she said.

In the US, companies are embracing the idea of gays playing leading roles in new media.

'Hi-tech companies would seem to be more flexible because they are so focused on finding great talent,' said Sergey Brin, of the fastest growing search engine, Google.com.

tracy.mcveigh@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Crime can pay - but grassing pays more

fields.headline: Crime can pay - but grassing pays more
fields.standfirst:
The failed Dome diamond robbery has highlighted the importance of informants in the fight against the underworld, Tony Thompson reports

Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: The failed Dome diamond robbery has highlighted the importance of informants in the fight against the underworld.
fields.body:
Daniel, a small-time petty criminal from Kent was drinking in his local pub when he felt a tap on his shoulder. 'I know you, you're a drug dealer,' said a man behind him.

Daniel turned and recognised a local police detective: 'He had this stupid smirk on his face,' he said. 'He knew he had me bang to rights, but I didn't know what he wanted. I just denied it and walked away.

'A couple of days later he phoned me at home and told me my house was under surveillance from the drug squad and that I was about to be raided. He read out some details from a note on their operations board. I started to panic because I had a load of puff in the house and I was worried I'd end up back in prison. He said he'd see what he could do. Then he told me I owed him a big favour.'

And so Daniel agreed to become a police informant. Within two weeks he had collected a reward of £400 for 'grassing up' the location of a small cannabis shipment. After that he found it difficult to turn back. 'For the most part it was just a question of keeping my eyes and ears open,' he says. 'Because I was moving around in that circle, people were always coming up to me and asking if I wanted a cheap video or some designer clothes. You'd soon learn that they'd knocked off a lorry load or some warehouse, and I'd just pass it all on. Sometimes it would end in a couple of arrests, sometimes not. No one ever suspected anything. People get caught all the time. That's just the risk anyone involved in crime takes.'

In a world where tens of millions of pounds of drugs, stolen goods and stolen cash are changing hands on a regular basis, informants are often the only people consistently managing to make crime pay. Last week's attempt to stage the world's biggest robbery and steal £350 million of diamonds from the Millennium Dome may have ended in dramatic failure for the gangsters, but the shady underworld character who provided the tip-off is set to be rewarded handsomely.

In the case of major robberies, rewards average 10 per cent of the value of the goods involved in the theft - often amounting to tens of thousands of pounds or more. But according to John Wagstaff, of the Association of British Insurers, the amount can vary enormously. 'As a rule, insurance companies don't like paying rewards,' he says. 'Imagine if we offered a £200 reward for every car stolen and recovered, we would have people queuing up.'

Like insurance companies, the police do not encourage large rewards, but Customs routinely pay up to £1,000 per kilo of heroin or cocaine recovered. Payments of £250,000 or more are relatively common. 'It sounds an enormous sum of money,' says one seasoned investigator, 'but a good tip-off will tell you when the drugs are coming in, who is picking them up and where they are taking them to. The amount of manpower, the number of hours and the huge cost of the operation you would have to put in place to find all that information on your own makes even a quarter of a million pounds seem like a bargain.'

Despite controls being introduced to clamp down on the practice, a number of professional villains still manage to make a respectable income by informing on colleagues and twisting the system to their best advantage. Law enforcement officials are well aware that the only people with access to information about who has been involved in the planning of a crime, or who is helping to dispose of the proceeds, are the criminals themselves.

Every bank raid of more than a few thousand pounds will generate the offer of a substantial cash reward which can often outweigh the cut a low-ranking member of the gang could expect to earn. The pages of Trace, a monthly magazine covering valuable stolen goods, are filled with details of rewards offered for rare items of furniture, clocks and other objets d'art which amount to far more than an unsophisticated thief could ever hope to make by selling the item on the black market. According to a spokesman for Lloyd's insurance, high-value paintings stolen from country homes will never find buyers at serious prices. Rewards of £50,000 or so can prove tempting at least to one member of the gang.

Although the pitfalls are many, the Audit Commission has repeatedly recommended that police increase their use of informants, as the most cost-effective method of tackling crime. Indeed, without information being provided by criminals and, to a lesser extent, members of the public, a phenomenal amount of crime would go unsolved. Between January and September this year, the charity Crimestoppers received 43,000 calls and provided information leading to nearly 4,000 arrests and the recovery of £2.5 million of property, and in September alone £3 million worth of drugs were recovered. Although rewards of £5,000 are regularly paid out by the charity, only 6 per cent of those eligible bother to claim them.

The informant network is able to operate because real-life criminal gangs are nothing like those portrayed in film or on television. There are few families or firms where every single member will be willing and able to take part in every venture that crops up. Sometimes one key team member will be in prison or simply unconvinced about the viability of the job. On other occasions they will not have the necessary skills to ensure the operation can run smoothly.

It is then that those in charge of the forthcoming job will put the word out among underworld pubs and clubs that they are looking for a getaway driver, a fork-lift truck operator or someone with inside knowledge of telecoms or a specific building. It is during these inquiries that informants gather as much information as they can, hoping for a big pay day or simply to store up credit should they themselves be arrested. The man responsible for grassing up the Dome raid gang is believed to have been offered a role in the robbery but declined, choosing to pass on the information instead.

Although informants and grasses are despised throughout the underworld, few of the villains at the top of the criminal tree can operate effectively unless they are also working as registered informants. Not only does such status give them access to hints about what activities the police are most keenly looking at, but it also provides a handy element of mitigation should they ever find themselves before the courts.

Few can resist. According to documents obtained by The Observer, even David, the son of Mad Frankie Fraser - the notorious gangland legend famed for his hatred of grasses - has provided information to the police as an informant. 'All self-respecting villains in the underworld find such people contemptible,' Mad Frankie said on numerous occasions, yet during the mid-Nineties his 52-year-old son held dozens of meetings with members of the South-East Regional Crime squad, often close to his home in Streatham, south London, during which he provided tip-offs about Ecstasy and cannabis imports.

Double killer Kenneth Noye, a man linked to the Brink's-Mat bullion robbery who once stabbed a policeman to death and was more recently convicted of the road-rage murder of Stephen Cameron, also had a long career as a police informant. He collected large sums for pointing the Flying Squad in the direction of villains, many of whom were rivals he simply wanted out of the way.

The history of informers is littered with cases of detectives getting too close, often with messy results. Nurturing an informant requires a close relationship between detective and criminal open to abuse by both sides. Detectives have been known to give informants free rein in their criminal careers, so long as the information continues. Others insist on splitting rewards. Many informants, Kenneth Noye for example, use the system as a way of getting rid of the competition.

The temptations and opportunities for corrupt practices are everywhere. In the early Nineties, finance company American Express was asked by officers from the Midlands Regional Crime Squad to provide upfront rewards of up to £100,000 to be paid to informants who had provided information about the forging of £17 million worth of travellers' cheques.

In fact, at the time the first payments were made, no cheques had been produced: The money was needed by the crooks and their police counterparts to purchase the printing equipment.

Inside facts

On average, each of Britain's 43 police forces pays out £20,000 to informants each year. There are around 1,200 active registered informants in the country at any one time. A survey of CID officers found that 43 per cent had no registered informants, 22 per cent had one and 17 per cent had five or more.

He was so prolific that many crooks attempted to use a 'Norris defence' to get themselves out of trouble, claiming in court that Norris had set them up. Daniel turned and recognised a local police detective: 'He had this stupid smirk on his face,' he said. 'He knew he had me bang to rights, but I didn't know what he wanted. webTitle: Teen inmates live in fear as attacks spiral out of control

fields.headline: Teen inmates live in fear as attacks spiral out of control
fields.standfirst:
Extreme violence at Britain's young offenders institutions prompts calls for closures
Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: An investigation by  The Observer  has revealed that last week's damning report into conditions at the young offenders institution at Feltham, Middlesex, is merely the tip of the iceberg. Two more reports by Sir David Ramsbottom, the Chief Inspector of Prisons, are due out later this month, one into Stoke Heath in Shropshire and the other into Brinsford in Wolverhampton, revealing conditions as bad, if not worse, and prompting calls for all such institutions to be closed down as a matter of urgency.
fields.body:
For the boys at Castington young offenders institution, it was simply accepted practice. An inmate, one of the weaker ones, had fallen behind with repayments to his tobacco baron. He had been warned the night before of what would happen.

As he came out of his cell on recreation break, he was felled with a vicious blow to the head from a snooker ball concealed in a sock. The blows continued and the pool of blood around him grew until a guard eventually intervened.

'It happened regularly,' says 20-year-old former inmate David Rudd, who witnessed the incident. 'It was just part of life there. Sometimes people would get a beating, sometimes they would get cut up in the showers. I only managed to avoid it because I kept myself to myself and never got into debt.'

An investigation by The Observer has revealed that last week's damning report into conditions at the young offenders institution at Feltham, Middlesex, is merely the tip of the iceberg. Two more reports by Sir David Ramsbottom, the Chief Inspector of Prisons, are due out later this month, one into Stoke Heath in Shropshire and the other into Brinsford in Wolverhampton, revealing conditions as bad, if not worse, and prompting calls for all such institutions to be closed down as a matter of urgency.

All three jails are hotbeds of extreme violence. The rate of assaults at Brinsford is 68 per cent, while both Stoke Heath and Castington are running at more than 55 per cent - nearly three times worse than the very worst adult prison. The Home Office target for assaults in all prisons is just 9 per cent. Last month, during three separate days of mass rioting, inmates at Castington caused hundreds of thousands of pounds worth of damage, wrecking more than 30 cells. Staff elsewhere have reported an increase in violence and disobedience since numbers held started to climb. Wetherby in Yorkshire is said to be out of control and even Huntercoombe in Oxfordshire - an institution with a reputation for tolerance and low levels of assaults - is now reporting problems.

Sir David, who has yet to inspect Castington, told his staff last week that if he saw just one more hellhole for young offenders he would demand that the Home Office explain why such institutions continued to exist.

According to Rudd, the entire regime for young offenders encourages an atmosphere of intimidation. 'It starts from the day you get there. The bullies want to find out who is most susceptible, identify the weakest. They know how to spot an easy target. They tell people that they have to salute the guvnor when he appears, that they have to collect milk tokens. A lot of people fall for it. If you stand up for yourself, you're usually okay. As soon as you let people take advantage of you, you're finished. It's a game but some people just can't handle it. Some people get suicidal and try to top themselves.'

Rudd also reported problems with unsuitable pairings of inmates, both at Castington and elsewhere. 'When they stick you in a double pad, they don't have a clue who they're putting people in with. There is no doubt whatsoever that there are racist people in jails and that is a real problem when it is so chaotic.'

The most recent criticisms at Feltham followed the murder of Zahid Mubarek, a 19-year-old inmate who was bludgeoned to death by his cellmate Robert Stewart in a racist attack hours before he was due to be released. Last week Stewart was sentenced to life imprisonment for the murder.

Stewart had written dozens of letters praising the killers of Stephen Lawrence and stating that he intended to murder his cellmate. All correspondence is supposed to be monitored but this was not done.

Juliet Lyon of the Prison Reform Trust observes: 'The average amount of purposeful activity that inmates at Feltham indulge in is 15.2 hours a week - the worst of any young offender institution. Drug use is at 21 per cent compared with the prison service average of 14.2 per cent. In the past five years there have been six different governors in charge at Feltham. If Feltham had been a failing school instead of a failing prison, no one would have tolerated as many as two changes of headship,' she says.

Other factors which may have contributed to Murabek's death are also being explored by the Chief Inspectors. Feltham has a policy of preventing the build up of cliques by not housing black or Asian prisoners together. There is also 'wind up' - prison officers house certain inmates together, knowing they will not get on, simply for their own amusement, a practice which will be made public next week in a report on Birmingham prison.

There are growing calls for YOIs to be abolished. Last year, Northampton and Hampshire abolished all custodial sentences for under- 18s, except in extreme circumstances. There was no increase in the level of offend ing. In Massachusetts in the United States, all juvenile prisons were closed overnight and replaced with a sophisticated system of mentoring and counselling, with no rise in youth offending rates. At present, 77 per cent of inmates from young offender institions go on to re-offend.

'All the young offenders institutions are untenable,' says Harry Fletcher of the National Association of Probation Officers. 'They're just warehouses.

'At least a quarter of the people kept in these places do not need to be there at all. It's not surprising that they become centres for racism, bullying and assaults. We need an urgent inquiry into the role and purpose of these jails.'

webTitle: 'Lost children' to be saved from a life of crime

fields.headline: 'Lost children' to be saved from a life of crime
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: David Blunkett will this week unveil a new children's unit charged with rescuing a 'lost generation' from crime, disaffection and social exclusion.
fields.body:
David Blunkett will this week unveil a new children's unit charged with rescuing a 'lost generation' from crime, disaffection and social exclusion.

It will oversee a £450 million drive to help troubled primary school children before they are locked into a spiral of classroom disruption, educational failure, truancy, juvenile offending and unemployment.

Older teenagers - reformed offenders and their victims - could be recruited as mentors to children at risk, while a wider network of children's clubs will offer group activities and advice for parents.

The move follows criticism from children's charities that the Government has failed to co-ordinate efforts to tackle child poverty, raise pupils' expectations and prevent juvenile offending. Experts say children aged between five and 13, the 'lost years' when much of the damage may be done, are falling through the gap.

The Children's and Young People's Unit to be launched by the Education Secretary and the Chancellor on Wednesday will oversee the spending of the Children's Fund on this age group.

Ministers want to build on the success of organisations such as the National Pyramid Trust, a charity that works in more than 85 schools offering group therapy to children in Year Three who are withdrawn, have difficulty making friends, struggling with work or disruptive in class.

'We are looking at the kind of children who in adolesence will drop out of school, will fall into depression, get into trouble with drugs or the police,' said the trust's chief executive Allan Watson.

'For decades people have focused on pre-school children and older teenagers but they have forgotten about the primary school years.'

Studies by Guildford University researchers had shown children who had been through the Pyramid increased their social skills, and also produced better creative work.

The cash from the Children's Fund, whose creation was announced in last year's budget, will be concentrated on voluntary agencies, health workers and schools, largely bypassing local authority social services departments.

The Children and Young People's Unit will be based in the Department of Education and Employment, but will work closely with the Home Office and the Treasury.

'The key is early intervention, before children get caught in these traps. The earlier they can be identified the better they are likely to do,' said one DfEE source.

'It will be about building on projects already known to be successful. It could be mentoring, such as older peers talking to children at risk of becoming involved in crime, or it might be parent education on communicating with children and resolving conflict, or out-of-school activities.'

The Children's Fund is meant to plug the gap between Surestart - the scheme targeting under-fives from deprived backgrounds to prepare them better for school - and the Connexions system of mentors to help older teenagers stay on in education.

webTitle: Britain faces BSE claims by French

fields.headline: Britain faces BSE claims by French
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: Britain could face huge compensation claims from families of French victims of the human form of mad cow disease as doctors predict that thousands might die across the Channel.
fields.byline: Antony Barnett and Stuart Jeffries,  Paris
fields.body:
Britain could face huge compensation claims from families of French victims of the human form of mad cow disease as doctors predict that thousands might die across the Channel.

Last month Tony Blair announced a multi-million pound no-fault compensation package for families of victims but set no guidelines as to who would be eligible.

With most British and French experts agreeing that BSE was a disease 'exported' from the UK to France, lawyers believe there would be a case for French families of variant CJD victims to sue the British government.

The French organisation offering support to CJD victims' families - the Association for the Struggle Against Prion-related Diseases - said: 'It is not inconceivable legal action could be taken against the British government.'

The association said it would be contacting David Body, the lawyer representing families of British victims, who has said that he believes there is a case that they could be eligible for compensation.

Frances Hall, of the Human BSE Foundation which supports variant CJD victims in Britain, said: 'The early cases in France seem to come from the same source as those in Britain and I think it would be morally difficult for the government to rule out compensation for families just because they are not British.'

A Department of Health spokeswoman did not rule out paying families of non-British victims but said it was 'too early to say'.

So far, only three French people have contracted variant CJD compared with 82 in the UK, but this weekend some French doctors predicted the figures could soar to several thousand. Two French victims have already died, and last week French television screened a documentary about a third victim, Arnaud, 19. The family is taking action against the French state but legal experts believe Britain could be held responsible.

In the past fortnight, the number of cases of BSE in French herds has tripled, but so far the epidemic is concentrated around Normandy and Brittany - the region that imported animal feed from Britain.

The Philips BSE report published last month confirmed that the spread of the disease was most probably caused by animal feed made from meat and bone meal which contained infected cattle. Britain banned the practice in July 1998, but figures from Customs and Excise reveal that in 1989 France imported more than 15,000 tonnes of meat and bone meal (MBM). By 1990, the amount had dropped to just over 1,000 tonnes and to practically zero the year after.

Several cases of BSE in Switzerland are also thought to have come from contaminated British animal feed.

French health secretary Dominique Gillot said: 'With the rise of the number of cases of mad cow disease in France it is probable that we will have several tens of cases of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.'

But doctors such as Dr Martine Pérez believe that there could be a much larger epidemic of variant CJD in France. Writing in yesterday's Le Figaro, Pérez argued that this would primarily be caused by consumption of contaminated British beef between 1980 and 1986, rather than BSE-infected French beef. Some estimates say this could mean as many as 7,000 cases of CJD in France.

This weekend other European governments have been urged to step up testing for mad cow disease. A plea from David Byrne, the European Commissioner for Health and Consumer Protection, advised member states to speed up the introduction of random testing on targeted animals, which will become compulsory from the start of next year.

Some estimates say this could mean as many as 7,000 cases of CJD in France. This weekend other European governments have been urged to step up testing for mad cow disease. A plea from David Byrne, the European Commissioner for Health and Consumer Protection, advised member states to speed up the introduction of random testing on targeted animals, which will become compulsory from the start of next year.

webTitle: Milburn targets £120m to end lifespan lottery

fields.headline: Milburn targets £120m to end lifespan lottery
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Ambitious targets to help stop early deaths among Britons will be set this week in a £120 million campaign.
fields.body:
Ambitious targets to help stop early deaths among Britons will be set this week in a £120 million campaign.

For the first time, hospitals and GPs in areas with the highest number of so-called 'years of life lost' - patients cheated of a ripe old age when compared with their peers - will receive extra cash.

At the top of the premature deaths league is Manchester, whose citizens have the worst chances in the country of surviving to their golden years. They are three times as likely to die from heart attacks before they reach 65 than their peers in Oxfordshire.

In his three-year allocations for all health authorities, Health Secretary Alan Milburn will announce a doubling of cash, from £60m to £120m, to stamp out such health inequalities.

The cash will be targeted on black spots where disease claims victims unnecessarily young, identified under the new 'years of life lost' formula. Milburn will also set targets for faster, more effective care.

'We will target resources at areas where people are dying sooner than they should,' said a source close to Milburn. 'We will ensure that the choice is no longer between an NHS that simply treats illness and one that is able to do more prevention.

'Services will be built up where demand is greatest, such as in the North-west, where for things like coronary care the service profile is among the weakest, even though death rates are high.'

The new allocations risk attack from the Tories, since they are likely to focus new money on Labour's inner-city heartlands. The top ten worst in the premature deaths league are all in the North, including Milburn's own backyard of County Durham, the fifth worst. The best off, such as Berkshire and East Surrey, are largely Conservative fiefdoms.

But the Department of Health insists the shift will not mean richer areas having their budgets cut. 'Because there is extra money in the system now, nobody will lose out. It will just reflect that people are dying younger in some areas than others,' said a source.

Although doctors say smoking is the biggest preventable cause of dying young, social class is also a major factor. While the average man can expect to live to 74 and a woman to 80, men from the two lowest socio-economic classes on average do not even make it to 70.

Infant mortality rates in the worst black spots for babies are more than three times as high as in the healthiest areas.

Previously, NHS budget allocations have been skewed towards retirement areas with large numbers of very elderly people, since they are the most likely to fall ill and therefore make the most expensive patients. The new system encourages spending on disease prevention as well as treating the chronically ill.

Meanwhile, the South-east will cash in through a £60m scheme announced last week to help nurses cover their housing costs in London and other expensive areas.

The worst five health authorities for longevity are listed as Manchester, Liverpool, Gateshead and South Tyneside, East Lancashire and the West Pennines.

The best chances for a long life are in Barnet, Kensington and Chelsea, Kingston and Richmond, Oxfordshire and Berkshire.

webTitle: Grossman to be hospital food tsar

fields.headline: Grossman to be hospital food tsar
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: The American food expert and television presenter Loyd Grossman is to be made the first NHS 'food tsar' in an attempt to improve the standard of hospital meals across the country.
fields.body:
The American food expert and television presenter Loyd Grossman is to be made the first NHS 'food tsar' in an attempt to improve the standard of hospital meals across the country.

Officials from the Department of Health last month approached Grossman, the man known as much for his American drawl as for his recipes, to ask him to tour the country and check standards.

A panel of chefs, including Mark Hix, head chef of the restaurant group which owns the prestigious Ivy and La Caprice restaurants in London, and Anton Edelmann, head chef at the Savoy, will advise Grossman on blackspots.

They will come up with new recipes for hospital food which has long been stained with the reputation for over-cooked meat and cold mashed potato.

Grossman, who presents TV's Master Chef and Through the Keyhole , has been given a budget of £40 million over four years to tackle the problem.

He is set to recommend hotel-style service for patients, including 'hospital waitresses' who will take room-service style orders 24 hours a day.

Ward housekeepers will also ensure that the standard of food is maintained and that patients are able to choose from a menu of choices similar to a restaurant rather than ticking boxes against 'potatoes' or 'cabbage' on a form. An approved list of hospital caterers who can hit high standards will also be drawn up.

'I want to come up with some fairly simple measures which will make the patients' experience of food in hospital a decent one,' Grossman said. 'This seems to be a genuine effort by the Government to improve standards. It will benefit a lot of people.'

Government officials said that £45m a year is wasted on food that is thrown away because it has been left by patients.

A report by hospital dieticians earlier this year revealed that patients were only getting between 50 per cent and 75 per cent of the nutrition they needed from the food they were served. Some food is so poor it actually puts back people's recovery.

Research has also shown that the low standard of food is cited as one of the public's biggest complaints about hospitals. Department of Health sources said that patients do not feel they are getting a professional service and often find cold plates of food left on their bed.

Families, particularly with children in hospital, are forced to bring in food from places such as McDonald's

The elderly are often not asked about their dietary requirements and are given inappropriate food for their illness.

'Public consultation has told us it is about getting the basics right that means the most to patients,' said Health Minister Gisela Stuart. 'There are no quick fixes but we can begin by making the whole patient experience better by improving the basics of care, starting with the food that they eat.

'The NHS provides over 300 million meals each year at a cost of over £500m. It is fair to say that the food is of variable quality, it is not provided when patients want it and too much of it is wasted as a result. This is simply not good enough. Diet is an integral part of patient care and recovery.'

Hospitals have told the Government that although they support efforts to improve food standards, over-stretched budgets means that money for patients' meals is often the first to be cut.

A recent survey revealed some hospitals spend less than £2 per patient per day on food.

webTitle: Kashmir killings fuel fires of hate

fields.headline: Kashmir killings fuel fires of hate
fields.standfirst:
The death count soars as India hunts 'infiltrators', but amid calls for revenge a desire for dialogue survives

Special report: India and Pakistan
fields.trailText: Major Rahul Pande's moustache is as carefully clipped as his accent. 'He's desperate. He wants to infiltrate more and more men before the snow comes. It's been pretty intense.'
fields.body:
Major Rahul Pande's moustache is as carefully clipped as his accent. 'He's desperate. He wants to infiltrate more and more men before the snow comes. It's been pretty intense.'

The major smoothes his moustache with a thumb and forefinger, raising binoculars towards the mountain peaks ahead of him, where 'he' has his positions.

'He' is the way Indian officers describe the Pakistan army, whose mountain positions surround the major's post on three sides at this point on the line of control, above Uri, in Indian-controlled Kashmir.

Rarely a day goes by without an exchange of shelling across the line, the de facto border dividing the two nuclear-armed neighbours. Pande says he's never known the shelling to be so heavy, increasing sharply since the collapse in August of a short-lived ceasefire by the main insurgent group fighting Indian rule.

The major's post is a warren of tunnels, trenches and bunkers. As we spoke, it was bathed in warm afternoon sunshine. By the end of the month it will be under 10ft of snow, and the men on the frontier will hunker down for the winter.

In the valley below, the major's sentiments are echoed by his boss, General John Mukherjee, the commander of Indian forces in Kashmir: 'All our intelligence reports indicate that Pakistan under [General Pervez] Musharraf's orders is trying to upgrade the level of violence.'

Even by Kashmir's grisly standards, this month has been particularly violent: more than 60 people have died in clashes with the army, most described as Pakistan-backed 'infiltrators'. A senior Shia Muslim cleric - a supporter of Indian rule - has been assassinated. 'The number of terrorists killed in encounters is approaching the highest ever this year. It's an indication of Pakistan's efforts,' says the general. With a hint of pride, he calls up a colourful bar chart on a computer, drawing deeply on his cigarette.

To the general, the Kashmir conflict is now little more than a proxy war waged by Pakistan. But that's not the way it's seen among many of Kashmir's Muslims. Outside the army's fortified Srinagar headquarters, the city is saturated with edgy security forces. Grenade attacks have become an almost daily occurrence. Any youngster is regarded as a potential bomber or gunman. There are reckoned to be between 200,000 and half a million security personnel in Indian-controlled Kashmir - about the highest soldier/civilian ratio in the world. About 50,000 people are estimated to have been killed in a decade of insurgency.

In a rundown part of old Srinagar, close to one of the countless army bunkers, two sisters meet and embrace. One wears a burqa, the black veil, the other a colourful scarf. They laugh and kiss. But the story of these two strong-willed women is one of tragedy and struggle. They, like most of the Muslims of the Kashmir Valley, will never accept Indian rule.

Parveena, in the colourful scarf, has become a thorn in the side of the Indian authorities for her struggle on behalf of families whose sons have disappeared. In 1990, soldiers took her 18-year-old son away for questioning. Even though she named the soldiers, there has been little sign of justice, or information.

She now has 350 cases. She says that earlier this year a government official offered her 1,000 rupees (about £1,500) to drop her case and persuade others to do likewise. 'I'm not going to give in to the government. We don't want any money. If they've been killed, give us their bodies back. I will fight to my last breath. As a mother I have to do this. I shall not rest until I get my revenge on India.'

Her sister, who uses the codename Madam Bakhtavar, heads a women's separatist group that agitates in villages and provides support to families whose sons have been killed or arrested by the security forces. She has been arrested four times, and wears her burqa partly out of religious conviction, partly to give her anonymity.

'We've suffered a lot at the hands of the security forces,' she says. 'Being a Muslim country, Pakistan's our sympathiser and brother. But we want to be separate. We want independence.'

Nevertheless, the sisters were among the millions of Kashmir's brutalised and exhausted people who welcomed July's ceasefire by the Hizbul Mujahideen, the biggest of the armed groups fighting Indian rule. But those hopes were dashed when it collapsed amid an orgy of bombings and shootings after India refused demands that Pakistan be included in any peace talks.

Yet the desire for dialogue remains stronger than at any time in the past decade. Indian officials have continued to talk informally with recently released leaders of the Hurriyat Conference, the umbrella organisation of separatist groups, and those leaders have accepted that talks are the only way forward.

'If we are genuinely interested in peace, we've got to engage,' says Abdul Ghani Bhat, the chairman of the conference. 'We have to put the past behind us.'

Even India's new military chief said on taking office that only a political solution could ultimately solve the Kashmir problem. But what sort of solution? India remains opposed to any Pakistani role in talks, at least to begin with. Hurriyat leaders, many of them no friends of Musharraf, say Pakistan has to be included because it is involved. Islamabad is unlikely to rein in the militants if it is not at the table.

One Hurriyat leader said that Indian officials had again raised the possibility of a three-way split of the state between the Muslim Kashmir Valley, the Hindu-dominated Jammu, and the Buddhist-inclined Ladakh.

American politics is another factor. Pressure from Washington helped gain the release of Hurriyat leaders and played a part in the summer's ceasefire. But American attention is likely to remain elsewhere for a while.

Ian Williams is Asia Correspondent of Channel 4 News

webTitle: Repair bungles add to chaos on the railways

fields.headline: Repair bungles add to chaos on the railways
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Britain's shambolic railways are likely to remain in chaos because engineering work to repair cracks on the lines is unco-ordinated and many workers have not been earmarked jobs,  The Observer  can reveal.
fields.body:
Britain's shambolic railways are likely to remain in chaos because engineering work to repair cracks on the lines is unco-ordinated and many workers have not been earmarked jobs, The Observer can reveal.

Staff brought in to repair the damage spoke last week of how they have been standing idle for days awaiting decisions or equipment. 'It's like the old days of British Rail, but worse. This is chaos,' said one employee of a major Railtrack contractor.

'I've spent most of the last week sitting in a wagon drinking tea while all the time passengers are being told this work is being done at top speed. The chain of command on this job is as long as the bloody track.'

Insiders fear that the delays break the back of businesses dependent on the railways - including some of the train-operating companies.

Railtrack claims that the safety work identified as essential after last month's fatal Hatfield crash is being carried out efficiently and as quickly as possible.

But The Observer has discovered that, in the past few days, Railtrack has called in US construction management company Bechtel to help. It has also, for the first time, employed someone to oversee maintenance. Andrew McNaughton was appointed to the new post of chief engineer on Thursday. 'He will be responsible for an overall view and organisation of infrastructure maintenance,' confirmed a Railtrack spokeswoman.

Both moves will be welcomed by the 25 train operators struggling to cope, not only with the works programme but also with the flooding that has afflicted many lines. It is seen by some as a sign of Railtrack's increasing desperation at the task it faces to restore the railways after years of neglect.

Yesterday a senior source at one train company said some operators were already 'staring bankruptcy in the face', and that the disorganisation of the track maintenance work is making a bleak situation worse.

'We are beyond anger at Railtrack's utter bungling,' he said. 'A lot of companies are going to the wall. It's the blitz, the biggest cock-up this country has ever seen.

'What we really cannot forgive is that, for the first time since the war, we had a growth trend and now that is being destroyed,' he said.

His view was backed by Alan Galley, managing director of container transport company Freightliner: 'We're looking at losing about £1.1 million a month, so the time Railtrack takes is vital,' he said. 'Obviously we're more than upset. Over the past four-and-a-half years we have built this business up by 40 per cent. That's in jeopardy.

'Things are not helped by Railtrack's Gerald Corbett suggesting the rail problems are caused by heavy freight trains, which is utter bunkum.'

One railway engineer ech-oed the view of the rail unions when he highlighted the use of sub-contractors by Rail track's main eight contractors as a major hindrance.

'You hear of signals being about to be erected the wrong way round, and I've seen enough examples of shoddy work to believe it could well be true. Everyone wants to pull out the stops and get this done, but the management structure is pulling the opposite way. People would be scandalised to know how much time is being wasted.

'Every replacement rail needs ordering, and then we wait for the delivery trains to bring one overnight. There are only nine of these trains across the whole country, and if they are still talking about 250 miles of track to be re-placed, then you can imagine what the timescale is going to be on this.'

A spokesman for the train drivers' union Aslef said drivers were reporting broken rails which should have been spotted by sub-contractors. 'Very clearly this work is about safety but one of the scandals which has come to light is the extent to which Railtrack relies on sub-contractors and sub-sub-contractors. Clearly this is going to cause confusion on the ground as well as raise very serious safety issues in itself.'

The issue was highlighted by the death last month of 22-year-old student Michael Mungovan. An Irish athletics champion, Mungovan was working with Balfour Beatty after being recruited by its sub-contractor McGinley Recruitment. He died when he stepped into the path of a train and his friends have since said the student had only nine hours of tuition, a third of which was a video, before being allowed to work near speeding trains.

Beatty denies the claim and says Mungovan had a full track safety certificate - at least 22 hours of training.

'The contractors being used by Railtrack are simply cutting back and back to save costs,' said Vernon Hince, assistant general secretary of the Rail, Maritime and Transport Union. 'They are also saving money by turning to sub-contractors, where workers are not familiar with or trained in the work they are being ask to do. This all leads to serious time delays, as well as safety issues.

'Six years ago there were 31,000 trained people working on Britain's railway infrastructure. Today there are 15,000. Is it any wonder that this straightforward repair work cannot be organised and carried out?'

Only 4 per cent of workers use the train, but the economy is feeling the effect - to the tune of at least £6m per day.

'Although rail counts for only a small proportion of travel, it is important and the disruptions will have a noticeable impact on the economy,' said Mark Pragnell, director of the Centre for Economics and Business Research. 'Six million pounds is a conservative figure. Clearly, if the disruptions continue into the Christmas period, the impact on revenues will be very significant.'

Railtrack told The Observer it would be keen to speak to workers who feel mainten-ance work is not going ahead as smoothly as it might. 'If our contractors are not doing their job properly, then we would like to be told.'

There are only nine of these trains across the whole country, and if they are still talking about 250 miles of track to be re-placed, then you can imagine what the timescale is going to be on this.' A spokesman for the train drivers' union Aslef said drivers were reporting broken rails which should have been spotted by sub-contractors. 'Very clearly this work is about safety but one of the scandals which has come to light is the extent to which Railtrack relies on sub-contractors and sub-sub-contractors. Clearly this is going to cause confusion on the ground as well as raise very serious safety issues in itself.' The issue was highlighted by the death last month of 22-year-old student Michael Mungovan. An Irish athletics champion, Mungovan was working with Balfour Beatty after being recruited by its sub-contractor McGinley Recruitment. He died when he stepped into the path of a train and his friends have since said the student had only nine hours of tuition, a third of which was a video, before being allowed to work near speeding trains. Beatty denies the claim and says Mungovan had a full track safety certificate - at least 22 hours of training. 'The contractors being used by Railtrack are simply cutting back and back to save costs,' said Vernon Hince, assistant general secretary of the Rail, Maritime and Transport Union. 'They are also saving money by turning to sub-contractors, where workers are not familiar with or trained in the work they are being ask to do. This all leads to serious time delays, as well as safety issues. 'Six years ago there were 31,000 trained people working on Britain's railway infrastructure. Today there are 15,000. Is it any wonder that this straightforward repair work cannot be organised and carried out?' Only 4 per cent of workers use the train, but the economy is feeling the effect - to the tune of at least £6m per day. 'Although rail counts for only a small proportion of travel, it is important and the disruptions will have a noticeable impact on the economy,' said Mark Pragnell, director of the Centre for Economics and Business Research. 'Six million pounds is a conservative figure. Clearly, if the disruptions continue into the Christmas period, the impact on revenues will be very significant.' Railtrack told The Observer it would be keen to speak to workers who feel mainten-ance work is not going ahead as smoothly as it might. 'If our contractors are not doing their job properly, then we would like to be told.' tracy.mcveigh@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Chaos costs Railtrack £300m

fields.headline: Chaos costs Railtrack £300m
fields.standfirst:
Train operators stop all payments  Dividends will still rise  Pressure mounts on Corbett

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Rail disruption will wipe more than £100 million off Railtrack's profits when the privatised company unveils first-half results tomorrow.
fields.body:
Rail disruption will wipe more than £100 million off Railtrack's profits when the privatised company unveils first-half results tomorrow.

The Hatfield rail crash is also expected to hit Railtrack for another £200m. The further blows to the firm's beleaguered chief executive, Gerald Corbett, comes as InterCity train operators are now withholding all payments from Railtrack follow ing the chaos caused by the Hatfield rail crash.

The train companies - which include Virgin, GNER and GWR - are demanding that Railtrack pays compensation for severe delays re-sulting from its emergency speed restrictions before they end the stand-off, industry sources told The Observer .

The chaos, exacerbated by severe flooding, will hit Railtrack's final results next year. 'The train operators are on strike and Railtrack's compensation bill will be mas sive,' one source said.Tomorrow's grim figures - profits are expected to drop to just £150m from £236m last time - will put further pressure on Corbett to quit. Railtrack's board refused to ac-cept his resignation when he offered to go after the Hatfield crash.

Ministers, including deputy prime minister John Prescott, are understood to want him replaced and the view is shared by many in the City. 'It would be better if he were not there,' said one leading transport analyst.

When repeatedly asked on BBC Radio 4's Today programme, Prescott refused to say that Corbett enjoyed his confidence.

Corbett is expected to come under further fire tomorrow because Railtrack is expected to increase its dividend. The move will fuel charges that the firm is putting shareholders before safety, track re-pairs and rail investment.

Passengers have suffered huge delays and cancellations since a broken rail caused last month's Hatfield derailment in which four people died. Railtrack has imposed speed restrictions at 500 sites on the network as it needs to replace 250 miles of worn track, forcing train operators to draw up emergency timetables.

Last week prime minister Tony Blair demanded Railtrack speed up its inspection and rail replacement plan after the company indicated repairs could continue until May. Blair is anxious the programme is finished by next spring and hauled Corbett into Downing Street on Friday to reinforce his view. Sir Alistair Morton, head of the Strategic Rail Authority, has also been drafted in to bang heads together.

Sources close to Railtrack say compensation for late-running of trains, plus lost performance bonuses, will cost Railtrack more than £100m in the first six months to the end of September. The company may also take further exceptional charges to cover the extra costs of the rail replacement programme.

Railtrack was already facing problems with penalties after it failed to meet targets set by the rail regulator for improving performance.

The Hatfield crash, the third major accident in as many years, has already wiped nearly £1bn off Railtrack's value. But the City nonetheless expects Railtrack to cough up more dividends, pencilling in a 10p interim payout against 9.3p last time. 'If they don't raise it, shareholders will just walk away,' one analyst said.

webTitle: Tube plans 'unworkable' - Kiley

fields.headline: Tube plans 'unworkable' - Kiley
fields.standfirst:
Special report: transport in Britain
Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: Robert Kiley, the world-renowned US transport guru appointed by London mayor Ken Livingstone to run the capital's Underground, now recognises that the Government's Public Private Partnership (PPP) financing system for the Tube is 'unworkable'.
fields.body:
Robert Kiley, the world-renowned US transport guru appointed by London mayor Ken Livingstone to run the capital's Underground, now recognises that the Government's Public Private Partnership (PPP) financing system for the Tube is 'unworkable'.

The news will spark a furious war of wills between Livingstone and the Government over how the Tube is financed - a war that could end in the High Court.

'Kiley came to London with an open mind,' said a source close to the former chief executive and chairman of New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority. 'But he now thinks it's unworkable. It's not ideological; it's on a pure operational basis. He says it's impossible to run a railway in such a fragmented way. You can't split operations and maintenance. And you can't have such a fragmented management structure.'

Last week, it emerged that deputy prime minister John Prescott had refused to allow Kiley, who rescued the New York subway, access to PPP contractual information.

Conservative shadow transport minister Bernard Jenkin will tomorrow open a debate in parliament demanding that Kiley be given access to all PPP financial information.

Last week Kiley and Livingstone met with PPP representatives for the first time. The bidders were said to 'have sat in silence' while Kiley and Livingstone outlined their position.

Privately, many companies within competing PPP consortia know they will gain huge revenue streams if Liv ingstone succeeds in implementing his bond-financed structure. London's mayor wants to inject more than £10 billion into the capital's transport system.

PPP consortia will submit their bids to run the Underground in eight days. PPP allows private sector consortiums to carve up the network into three bundles and run it for 30 years.

webTitle: New family tax credit not child's play

fields.headline: New family tax credit not child's play
fields.standfirst:
Claiming the allowance may prove tricky, says Neasa MacErlean
Special report: the Budget
fields.trailText: Claiming the allowance may prove tricky, says Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
Families expecting to qualify for the new Children's Tax Credit should be sorting out their paperwork with the Inland Revenue now. The credit, which starts in April, is expected to be available to about 5 million working households and could be worth up to £520 to some families.

In the pre-Budget statement last week, Chancellor Gordon Brown said he would increase the maximum benefit from the £442 which is currently planned to £520. Although he did not say when he would do this, it is highly likely - with an election looming - that the increase will come through when the credit is launched. The credit replaces the old Married Couples Allowance and the Additional Personal Allowance, which were stopped last April. Only the self-employed will receive the credit as a lump sum payment: for others it will merely reduce the tax that is deducted at source.

'Because it is like a tax allowance, it doesn't help the very poorest families who aren't working,' says Mike Brewer of the Institute for Fiscal Studies.

One disadvantage is that it is not straightforward to understand. Claimants need to consider several issues:

 It is available to married and unmarried couples and to single parents equally. To qualify they need to be taxpayers and to have at least one child under 16 at the start of the tax year. The child needs to be living with them for at least some of the tax year. Only one credit is available per household.

 Claim forms were sent out to people who used to get Married Couples Allowance and the Additional Personal Allowance in June. But many other people now eligible may not have received a form. You should contact your tax office to ask for a claim form.

You will need to tell the Inland Revenue how much you - and your partner if you are in a couple - earn. If just one of you is working, that one will make the claim. If both are working, and both are basic-rate taxpayers, then you can split the credit between you. If one of you is a higher-rate taxpayer, that one has to claim. If you are both higher-rate taxpayers, the higher earner claims.

 A self-employed claimant will have to apply at the end of the tax year for a repayment of the credit. The application can be done through the tax return or through a repayment claim form.

 Although families will be able to save up to £442 (or probably £520) in tax a year, the credit is formulated in a slightly more complicated way. The actual credit is set at £4,420 a year; an allowance which is set against the claimant's earnings. It will reduce the tax rate on those earnings by 10 per cent ; hence it produces a maximum reduction in the tax bill of £442. For higher-rate taxpayers, their total allowance is reduced by £1 for every £15 of income that they earn over the higher-rate threshold.

 Claimants will also be able to get Child Benefit, Working Families Tax Credit and any other benefits or allowances they qualify for.

Copies of Inland Revenue booklet 'CTCR/1 - Children's Tax Credit' are available on 0645 000 404 or on www.inlandrevenue.gov.uk.

webTitle: Don't choke on your latte

fields.headline: Don't choke on your latte
fields.standfirst:
Talk about tax relief on intellectual property could turn out to be so much froth, writes Faisal Islam

Special report: the Budget
fields.trailText: Talk about tax relief on intellectual property could turn out to be so much froth, writes Faisal Islam.
fields.body:
If you take the Pre Budget Report as your model, UK inflation is spiralling out of control. Its price and its size have increased by a frankly unsustainable 20 per cent over the past year. On current trends the PBR may become bigger than the Budget itself.

The PBR may now be Giant Economy Size, but it does not do exactly what it says on the box. The Chancellor of the Exchequer, Gordon Brown flagged up talk of 'tax relief on intellectual property'.

'Fantastic!' exclaimed advertising executives in coffee bars all over Soho. They get not only tax credits for research and development, but 'relief' on their intellectual property (IP) investments. As some brands, patents, and media rights are worth billions of pounds, tax relief on the acquisition or development of IP could represent a significant fillip to the UK's new economy.

But on closer inspection the moves seem to be aimed at reforming tax accounting. Hardly the stuff to divert creatives from their cappuccinos. Indeed the possibility that IP companies may lose out in any reforms should have them choking on their lattes.

It used to be simple. Businesses invested in machines. Those machines manufactured good. Governments keen to encourage investment in modern machines devised capital allowances and tax relief against companies' tax to help businesses think long term.

But vast investments in the world of intellectual property - brands, trademarks, sports media rights and patents - have complicated the matter. There is nothing much to show for these assets other than pieces of paper or information and, as intangibles, they do not qualify for tax concessions. Nor, given their classification as capital, can their cost be written off against current spending. Intangibles tend to get the worst of both worlds. There are exceptions - tax allowances are made for certain types of patent, for films and industrial know-how, for example - but the system is a hotchpotch of individual measures, rife with disincentives to invest in intangibles.

The mobility of intangible capital also leads to a high degree of sensitivity to different international tax regimes. In the US, relief for the cost of investment in such intangibles is available over 15 years. Multinationals that have bought British brands or patents can purchase through a US subsidiary and license back to the UK to take advantage of this relief. Not only does this reduce the tax take for the Inland Revenue; it also pushes income flows and R&D out of the UK.

Step in the Government in 1998 with a first stab at reform. Last week a third consultation paper was released, having taken on board representations from companies. The net result is that: 'intellectual property' has been defined to include goodwill; relief will be based on accounts-based depreciation rather than capital allowances; and special relief for films and science research will remain separate.

The spirit of any new legislation has been seen this year. Special laws were passed for companies buying 3G mobile phone licences. Standard UK practice grants no relief for the purchase of such intangible assets. The new measures will result in a total of £7bn relief on any corporation tax paid by the licence holders over the 20-year lifetime of the licences.

Similarly, the thrust of reform seems to allow tax relief based on allocating an annual value to IP over a specific lifetime. So if a company buys 10-year football broadcast rights for £1 billion, it would, under current proposals, be amortised at £100 million a year and receive relief against corporation tax of £30m a year.

So is this an overlooked tax bonanza for weightless industries? Possibly. But we won't know until March's Budget. The main thrust of the reforms was on simplification. By more closely attaching relief to the appropriate investments, investors may be better informed about returns. 'Because tax relief is not given to IP, there is no need to separate it out, and it tends to be wrapped up with other things in the balance sheet,' says David O'Keeffe of KPMG.

Some intellectual property companies feel that these moves are more important than sorting out share options. 'Handling intellectual property from the accounting perspective is a tangible recognition of the value of biotechnology, and of IP,' says Paul Murphy, chief executive of Cambridge-based Gemini Genomics. 'If the appropriate moves are made, this would be by far and away the greatest financial benefit.'

Originally the Inland Revenue insisted that any changes would be revenue-neutral - any bonanzas would be offset by capital gains tax on companies that sell IP assets. That provision has been quietly dropped.

Costing such measures is extremely difficult, and this is a reflection of the more general complications inherent in measuring intellectual property. Brand valuation, for example, is the most developed form of IP valuation, but a contro versial issue. So assessing who will lose out if current proposals are implemented is a tricky question.

'There may well be losers in moving from the old system of capital gains,' says O'Keeffe. Those companies that benefit from tapering, relief from inflation effects, and the rollover relief for goodwill may suffer..

The Revenue would gain from companies selling their IP assets to other companies. Profits on disposals of IP would be subject to tax as income, and the question is whether, for individual companies, such new taxes would be balanced off by the new reliefs.

The Treasury is very sensitive about the possibility of these new measures exacerbating the perennial problem of companies depressing profits to pay less tax. But tax specialists point out that listed companies do at least have to prove their profitability to the stock market and would have few reasons to make such moves.

Potentially more worrying for the Treasury is the fact that some analysts doubt whether the changes will make much difference to entrepreneurial culture. Startups are more likely to be making losses, and therefore would not benefit from tax relief; R&D tax credits on the other hand, can be cashed if companies are making losses.

Perhaps the Treasury should consider a similar system for IP, but that would cost money. That, as one might suspect, is not the Government's plan.

webTitle: Wildlife die in African crossfire

fields.headline: Wildlife die in African crossfire
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: George Hulme surveys the dead animal booty, spread at his feet like some ghoulish picnic in the hot morning sun. Two poachers, handcuffed to each other amid the seized remains of a giraffe, two eland and a kudu, seem resigned to their fate after being arrested by game scouts. The police will be along 'shortly' - as soon as they have found a lift.
fields.body:
George Hulme surveys the dead animal booty, spread at his feet like some ghoulish picnic in the hot morning sun. Two poachers, handcuffed to each other amid the seized remains of a giraffe, two eland and a kudu, seem resigned to their fate after being arrested by game scouts. The police will be along 'shortly' - as soon as they have found a lift.

'We are only finding about a third of what is being poached,' says a weary Hulme, chairman of the Chiredzi Wildlife Conservancy. 'Sometimes we find snared animals which have been dead for months.'

The conservancy's land and animals are being targeted by President Robert Mugabe's war veterans, by squatters and by what he refers to as 'opportunists' taking advantage of the new lawlessness which has swept the Zimbabwe countryside.

According to Hulme, poaching in the 250,000-acre conservancy area, in the low veld south of Harare, has hit critical proportions. A handful of unarmed game scouts are sent out daily, but with such a vast area to patrol their efforts are often in vain. 'We find the snares, the snared animals, but rarely the poachers,' he says.

It is an uphill battle, as more and more squatters arrive each day, buoyed by Mugabe's anti-white rhetoric and illegal land seizures, bringing further wanton destruction to a fragile eco-system. The police are of little use, seemingly reluctant to be drawn into the war of attrition between landowners and government-backed squatters.

'There has always been a poaching problem, but nothing on this scale,' says Style, whose farm was served a compulsory acquisition order in August. 'But what can you do when the local MP tells the squatters the land and the wildlife belongs to them now and they are free to take what they want?'

'We are losing all sorts of animals, but we are particularly concerned about our key species - elephant, rhino, sable and waterbuck,' says Style, whose game wardens have been regularly assaulted and intimidated.

Once they have planted, they will not want to leave. If they are eventually ordered to move off, that's when the trouble will start. webTitle: Mugabe defies farm ban

fields.headline: Mugabe defies farm ban
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe President Robert Mugabe's government has proceeded with seizures of white-owned farms, contemptuously flouting a Supreme Court judgment that its land resettlement policies are unconstitutional and must stop immediately.
fields.body:
Zimbabwe President Robert Mugabe's government has proceeded with seizures of white-owned farms, contemptuously flouting a Supreme Court judgment that its land resettlement policies are unconstitutional and must stop immediately.

The Supreme Court ruled on Friday that Mugabe's chaotic, often violent occupations of more than 1,600 white-owned farms were illegal. The court ordered police to remove the President's supporters from the farms.

But yesterday the government moved its supporters onto more than 50 new farms, including that of Tim Henwood, president of the Commercial Farmers Union (CFU) which represents white farmers.

Mugabe said he would not heed the court decision. 'Whatever the courts might say, the land is ours and we will take it,' said the President last week.

Nevertheless, the court ruling added pressure on Mugabe, who was also confronted with anti-government riots in the eastern city of Mutare.

The rioting erupted on Friday evening after a policeman accidentally shot and killed an eight-month-old baby. Angry crowds blocked traffic, burnt the mayor's residence and other state-owned property.

The riots highlight the animosity towards Mugabe's continued rule. Harare was rocked by an anti-government riot last month.

'The people say Mugabe must go,' said Wilfred Mhanda, a veteran of the war against Rhodesian minority rule and now an officer of the Zimbabwe Liberators Platform.

'The atmosphere is highly charged and a small spark could set the country on fire. We fought for democracy and freedom in our country. Now Mugabe and his thugs are working to destroy that.'
