webTitle: Second-home owners are why the country is going to the dogs

fields.headline: Country going to the dogs
fields.standfirst:
Second-home owners are the true culprits, says Graham Norwood
Special report: the countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: Second-home owners are the true culprits, says Graham Norwood.
fields.body:
Countryside protesters will later this month renew their campaign for more financial support on issues ranging from farm subsidies to fuel tax.

High property prices and the destruction of rural communities feature strongly on the protesters' list of complaints, but are these really caused, as rural activists claim, by an urban-centric government committed to high indirect taxation?

Britain's rural problems are well-documented. Many country communities are losing their indigenous population because people have low-paid jobs, seasonal unemployment is high, and running costs for transport are high because of the distances involved. The latter problem is exacerbated by the closure of local schools and sub-post offices.

This means local people often cannot afford homes in rural areas, where second-home ownership is high - so they move to towns. Planning controls on green-belt land and village resistance to government proposals for more homes mean supply is continually outstripped by demand - and house prices rise even higher.

A severe lack of council and housing association properties in rural areas is a further, but hidden, cause of higher prices. Add to that the trend for turning traditional non-residential rural properties into homes: this denudes the areas of shops and makes the local economy less viable for permanent, low-income residents.

According to Alexander Hunt, who heads the country department of estate agency Cluttons, entire small farms in prime locations near to London are being snapped up as country retreats. In the village of Twyford in Hampshire a small shop built in the late nineteenth century has served as a bakery, a cafe and an antiques store - but is now on the market through agent Lane Fox with planning permission to be turned over to residential use, helping to boost its price to£265,000.

So although the roots of many rural problems lie in the cities, it is better-off second home owners, not the Government, who are to blame for high property prices. 'Farming budgets and incomes have dropped massively. In some parts of the country - notably Cornwall, Wales and some of the less affluent counties - there is real hardship that will have an effect on property values,' says Henry Holland-Hibbert of Lane Fox.

'But much of the country property we sell is bought by an urban buyer or someone working in an urban-based economy such as banking or commerce. These are the people who are causing the value of country properties to increase. Meanwhile the value of agricultural land, even in the Home Counties, has dropped from an average of £3,000 per acre in 1997 to around £2,000 now.'

For genuine farmers the writing may be on the wall in terms of properties. A year ago Knight Frank, another estate agency with a countryside portfolio, made waves when its Scottish office said farmers might have to consider selling their farmhouses to meet debts, while keeping their land.

The agency has returned to the theme in its annual agricultural briefing, saying it may be time for change. 'Landowners must adopt a more businesslike approach, maximising turnover from every part of the asset,' says Sandy Douglas of the agency's Hungerford office.

'Opportunities exist from development potential, maximising cottage rentals, advertising, film locations, leisure, sporting, telecommunications masts and cables, and converting buildings to offices and workshops,' he says.

Knight Frank's figures on rural property prices show the profits that can be made from selling farmhouses, although organisations such as the Countryside Alliance and National Farmers' Union insist rural communities can function only if farmers have homes as well as workplaces on the farms themselves.

The issue is unlikely to go away. January will see the next round of City bonuses, and an expected reduction in interest rates during 2001 will see a further drive towards second homes. The countryside is indeed under siege - but fuel blockades and marches may be directing rural anger in the wrong direction.

Who's snapping up those rural properties?

 About 47 per cent of people living permanently in rural areas are originally from cities

 Around 1,700 town and city dwellers move to villages every week

 The 1990 census showed 92,000 second homes in England and Wales - that figure is now believed to be nearly 300,000

 Around 90,000 low-rent council houses and flats were bought under right-to-buy legislation in the Eighties and Nineties

 Just under 60 per cent of all second homes are in the countryside

 Around 13 per cent of all second homes are in Wales - even though only 6 per cent of all homes are there

 Owners of second homes pay only 50 per cent of the relevant council tax on their second property

 In the Isles of Scilly, 31 per cent of properties are second homes; in some parts of south Wales the figure is 30 per cent; in Windermere it is 16 per cent; North Cornwall is over 10 per cent

 Around 30 per cent of second homes cost more than the owner's first, because they are being lined up as a permanent residence for when the owner leaves the city

Sources: Country Illustrated magazine; Countryside Agency

webTitle: Russians launch crackdown on 'sex slave' traffickers

fields.headline: Russians launch crackdown on 'sex slave' traffickers
fields.standfirst:
Campaigners attack 'risk-free' trade in women, reports Amelia Gentleman

Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Had it not been for the long queue for tickets at St Petersburg's central railway station, Lara Matveyeva might never have found herself working in a German brothel - one of hundreds of thousands of East European women unwittingly sold into prostitution in the West.
fields.body:
Had it not been for the long queue for tickets at St Petersburg's central railway station, Lara Matveyeva might never have found herself working in a German brothel - one of hundreds of thousands of East European women unwittingly sold into prostitution in the West.

As it was, the slow movement of the queue provided an ideal forum for recruitment. The tedium of waiting was lifted by the appearance of a friendly, well-dressed woman behind her.

Enticed into conversation, Lara told her that she was returning home to a job and a town that bored her. The woman replied that she had a friend in Germany who was looking for help with the housework for a few months, and that if Lara was eager for a change she could put them in touch. The money would be bad, but she would be required to do little except water the plants and feed the pets; most importantly, it would be a chance to travel.

Only mildly surprised by this stranger's desire to be kind, Lara accepted. A few days later she was travelling by bus to Hamburg. A Russian woman was there to meet her at the bus stop, accompanied her to a flat nearby and took her passport from her - for safekeeping. After three days she told Lara, then 24, that there was no housework to be done, so she would have to work as a prostitute.

Intelligent and well-educated, it nevertheless took her six months to escape from imprisonment in a series of bars and nightclubs in Hamburg and its suburbs. Most of the other Russians she met there had given up even trying to return home. Even now that she is back in her small provincial town on the southern border with Ukraine, she remains so anxious about reprisals from the people who organised her trip that she refuses to reveal her real name.

Her horror at her own experience and at the scale of the problem in Russia motivated her - in spite of the dangers - to start tackling the problem. She was one of the participants at a conference of 43 anti-trafficking organisations from 25 regions of Russia and six former Soviet republics that finished last week.

These groups hope to combat a phenomenon that, according to the Organisation for Security and Co-operation in Europe, has swept up something like 500,000 Russian women in the past decade (although the trade's clandestine nature makes it impossible to estimate accurately the numbers). Activists say that, despite its scale, human trafficking is still not treated seriously by the Russian government.

'There is a great reluctance to recognise and address this problem,' said one of the conference organisers, who also requested anonymity. 'The reality is that it is a modern slave trade, just as profitable as it was 200 years ago.'

The trade stems from a mixture of poverty, naivety, a weak legal system and a prevalence of well-organised criminal groups. Ignorance lies at the heart of the problem. According to MiraMed, the charity that organised this month's conference, around 90 per cent of the women trafficked abroad are unaware that they are headed for a career in the sex industry.

The small ads columns of provincial newspapers are filled with adverts encouraging young, attractive women to apply for work as waitresses in Italy or barmaids and nannies in Germany.

With the economy in Russia's remote regions deeply depressed, many women are desperate for an escape. The novelty of travel in the West remains high, while awareness about life there is low. Not suspecting any possible threat, the women - mostly in their teens or early twenties - are easy prey.

For the groups organising the trafficking there are few obstacles. Compared with selling drugs or weapons abroad, trade in women is highly profitable and relatively risk-free. Unlike guns or drugs, women can be sold over and over again, acting as a regular, long-term source of income. And, crucially, in Russia there is still no specific legislation which decrees illegal the trade in humans . The few women who make their way back to Russia have no recourse to the law. Even now, two years after her return, she has told none of her friends or family about what happened in Germany; they believe she spent an uneventful few months as an au pair.

The memory of those months remains painful. 'I'm not scared of anything any more because the worst thing that could possibly happen to me already has. Very few of the women I met had willingly become prostitutes. Most were tricked. Most alarming was the sense that there was no way out. Our passports had been taken; we spoke no German and knew nothing about the country, so we didn't know what punishment would face us if we went to the police. We were illegal immigrants involved in an illegal activity - we didn't expect any sympathy.

'To begin with I refused to do the work, but later I had to - there was no other way of feeding myself, and by that time I had seen the beatings other women got when they refused to co-operate.'

Each of the new recruits was presented with instant debts to their pimps of around $1,000. The bar's exits were monitored by security cameras, heightening the sense that there was no escape.

When the woman who had first pushed her into prostitution decided she was no good at it, Lara was sold on to a man for $1,000, the sum of her 'debts'. It was only when his bar was raided and she was arrested that she realised the police were not as terrifying as she had anticipated. They spoke no Russian, so she was never able to explain her situation, but they handed her a deportation order and she was able to leave.

The main conclusion to come out of this month's anti-trafficking conference was the need for greater information. A privately sponsored advertising campaign showing pretty young fish being ensnared by evil fishermen is soon to run on regional television, and lectures in schools are being organised to warn girls to be wary of offers of casual labour abroad.

webTitle: Was reporter killed by Putin's secret service?

fields.headline: Was reporter killed by Putin's secret service?
fields.standfirst:
Antonio Russo, found dead near a Caucasian mountain pass, may have discovered too much about atrocities in Chechnya

Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Slumped by the side of the road, a speck amid the fields yawning into the horizon, there was something odd about the contorted, frozen corpse. Antonio Russo had been murdered, and his killers made sure they left not a mark, not a scratch on his body.
fields.byline: Amelia Gentleman in Moscow and Rory Carroll in Rome
fields.body:
Slumped by the side of the road, a speck amid the fields yawning into the horizon, there was something odd about the contorted, frozen corpse. Antonio Russo had been murdered, and his killers made sure they left not a mark, not a scratch on his body.

On the other side of the Gombori Pass in the republic of Georgia friends were waiting at the village of Mirzaani. Russo was to join in the anniversary celebrations of Nico Pirosmani, a nineteenth-century local artist. They did not know a large, blunt object was being applied to Russo's chest until four ribs cracked and internal bleeding caused him to die of shock.

They did not know his satellite telephone, digital camera, laptop computer and video cassettes were vanishing. An Italian journalist who spent a lifetime chasing secrets was leaving behind some of his own. Who killed him, and why?

Snaking from the roadside, 30 miles north east of the Georgian capital, Tbilisi, is a trail of fact and suspicion that some claim leads to the Kremlin and its onslaught in Chechnya. Russo's friends believe he was assassinated by the Russian secret service after discovering unconventional weapons were being used against children. It would have been a scoop in keeping with a reporter who risked his life countless times in Africa, Bosnia and Kosovo.

Employed by the Rome-based Radio Radicale, an affiliate of Italy's Radical Party, he stayed in Pristina when all other Western journalists pulled out during Nato's bombing. It brought him an award and fame, but Russo, 40, was never flashy. Glory he left to others. A shoestring budget and avoiding the pack was his style.

Last November he moved to Tbilisi. Criss-crossing the mountains into Chechnya, he befriended the rebel leader, Aslan Maskhadov, who was waging war against Russian troops. Both sides were committing atrocities.

Last month Russo phoned his mother, Beatrice, a pharmacist in Tuscany. He had obtained a videotape. Dead children, unimaginable horror, war crimes. The world would see when he returned to Italy on 18 October.

His body was discovered on 16 October. Nearby was a sheet police suspect was used to tie him up. Friends found the door to his city centre apartment unlocked. Belongings were in disarray, documents and car gone. The coroner said the injuries were almost certainly not the result of a road accident. It is not known whether his chest was crushed by a rock, a piece of metal or human pressure.

Mamuka Areshidze, an ex-parliamentary deputy who helped Russo in Georgia, said he did not know which side might have instigated the murder, but was convinced it was not simply a criminal attack. He said: 'I think he was killed because someone wanted to conceal the material he had gathered - this is why the videos disappeared. I understand security forces know how to apply pressure to crush people to death without leaving any trace of violence.'

That is one of several the-ories the murder inquiry is examining, said police. An environmental organisation in Tbilisi, and colleagues in Rome, alleged Russo had evidence of a new Russian weapon that killed people slowly.

There is no proof and sceptics point out higher-profile journalists were filing reports of atrocities. The Radical Party says the timing was significant. For a year President Putin had been lobbying the United Nations to end its status as a non-governmental organisation. He accused the Radicals of paedophilia, terrorism and drug-trafficking. The final UN vote, which rejected the request, was scheduled for 18 October.

Breezing through the studios of Radio Radicale is another theory. Russo was killed because he had a videotaped interview with a Georgian woman claiming to be the President's mother, refuting his claim she was dead. As a murder motive that seems fanciful. The story emerged last spring and was followed up by the international media before being discredited.

Others say the journalist, who on the day of his death was seen with Chechen acquaintances, was killed for money. 'But why would they have left his passport and golden crucifix? And why kill him in such a strange way? It makes no sense,' said a colleague, who asked not to be named.

Human rights groups want the West to query Putin over Russo and two other journalists who wrote about Chechnya: Alexander Yefremov, killed by a remote-controlled explosion in the separatist region in May, and Iskander Khationi, who focused on human rights abuses in Chechnya, found battered to death in September.

Within hours of the news of Russo's death colleagues in Rome were flooded messages. The ponytailed activist had made many friends on his travels.

'We never knew the half of it. Stories of him taking 30 kids to a burger restaurant, saving people's lives,' said a colleague. The liberal, freethinking Radicals promised neither fame nor decent salary, but Russo signed up because 'they're crazy, just like me', he used to say.

The party's attacks on Left and Right alike may explain the minimal coverage in Italy's partisan press. 'They're snobs. It has received more attention abroad,' said the colleague.

Little fanfare accompanied Russo's burial in the family tomb in Francavilla, deep in the Abruzzo countryside. Beatrice Russo, 75, believes her son's killers will never be identified. ' It's all so murky. The only thing that consoles me is it was a death consistent with his life.'

webTitle: Secret plan devised to mothball 'dark Dome'

fields.headline: Secret plan devised to mothball 'dark Dome'
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Secret plans to leave the Dome standing empty for a year are being drawn up by the Government in a last-ditch attempt to save Ministers' from the embarrassment of having to demolish it.
fields.body:
Secret plans to leave the Dome standing empty for a year are being drawn up by the Government in a last-ditch attempt to save Ministers' from the embarrassment of having to demolish it.

The 'dark Dome scenario' is being planned after the Government was told it had five days to save the attraction. Robert Bourne, the millionaire Labour donor who wants to build a 'knowledge park' on the Greenwich site, has said that, if a deal is not finalised by Friday, he will pull out.

Officials hope the £102 million Bourne deal will be given the green light this week, but said they needed a fall-back position. One admitted this was the Dome's 'crisis week'.

Sources said that there were 'financial issues' for Bourne to tackle before the Government would give his plans for a British Silicon Valley the go-ahead.

The dark Dome option is the latest twist in the shambolic running of the Greenwich attraction. Last week a damning report by the National Audit Office criticised the management of the Dome and said original estimates of 12 million visitors were wildly optimistic.

John Prescott, the Deputy Prime Minister, has ordered English Partnerships, the government body selling the Dome, to supply an emergency report about what to do with the Dome if Bourne's Legacy plan is dumped.

The leading option is to mothball the troubled attraction, allowing other bidders still interested in reopening the Dome to come forward. The site would be cleared, secured and left standing.

Officials at the Millennium Commission said that there were other organisations they could talk to about buying the Dome, if Bourne abandons his bid.

'The Government is not in the same no-choice situation that Legacy seems to think,' said a senior Commission source. 'One gets the impression that there are other options if they had more time to look. If anyone is panicking here, it is Legacy.'

The second option would be to demolish the site and sell it as a business park, a route supported by some in the Government. One senior source said that an argument between the two camps would be the 'mother of all battles'.

Critics of knocking down the Dome say that it would cost up to £40 million and could leave the embarrassing spectacle of a half-completed demolition at the time of the general election, expected in May. The dark Dome option would be cheaper.

The Prime Minister has put his personal reputation on the line over the Dome, saying that it would be a monument to New Labour. Prescott is concerned that getting rid of the structure would be a public relations disaster.

'The last thing anyone wants to see is the Dome standing empty while Ministers twiddle their thumbs over what to do with it,' said Peter Ainsworth, the Conservative culture spokesman.

'If the Legacy deal falls through then they should have another competition, but they don't have to take a year over it. The option should be there to demolish it if that is going to maximise the value. I warned, when they started the original competition to sell it, that they had done it too late. There was a danger we would end up with the Dome sitting idle after 31 December. That is now threatening to become a reality.'

webTitle: Focus: The Dome's last chance

fields.headline: The Dome's last chance
fields.standfirst:
Millionaire Robert Bourne has given the Government until Friday to accept his second offer to save the structure. The alternative is the 'nuclear option', report Kamal Ahmed and Gaby Hinsliff

Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: Millionaire Robert Bourne has given the Government until Friday to accept his second offer to save the structure. The alternative is the 'nuclear option'.
fields.body:
Cheyne Walk is one of London's smartest streets. Most evenings at about midnight a man emerges from one of the houses with a spaniel. The man, with the tan of someone who looks after himself, marches off around the block, deep in thought. The spaniel trots along behind, sniffing lampposts.

The man's name is Robert Bourne - millionaire, Labour donor, friend to the rich and influential. He has just faced one of the toughest weeks of his life. For the past five days Bourne has been locked in delicate negotiations with the Government over the most significant deal Labour will ever have to secure. If this goes wrong, the Prime Minister, and the whole New Labour project, will be horribly damaged.

Bourne is the head of Legacy plc, the company bidding to run the Millennium Dome after 31 December. If the bid fails, the Government is considering what senior officials describe as the 'dark Dome scenario' - moth-balling the place for a year while a new competition to run it is launched.

It would be a last, desperate throw of the dice. The other option is to level the structure to the ground. But that would take months and cost millions of pounds, a lengthy reminder of the Government's failure. If the Prime Minister calls an election in May as expected, the last pieces of the failed attraction would still be standing at Greenwich. The metaphor would be clear.

Last week the National Audit Office's report on the financial management of the Dome was a scathing analysis of a project that has lurched from one mismanaged crisis to another. The Government hoped that would be the end of the matter, the last negative blow. But this week will see another chapter in the crisis. Lord Falconer, the Cabinet Office Minister in charge of the Dome, has ignored calls for him to resign. If the Government fails to sell the Dome to Bourne, those calls will become louder.

Bourne is starting to lose patience. He has just given the Government a deadline - if he and English Partner ships, the official agency charged with selling the Dome, have not completed the deal by Friday, he's off.

Senior Government sources have told The Observer the settlement is very close. One other thing is close: the end of the year, just seven weeks away. If the Government doesn't succeed with Bourne, then Plan B is rightly seen as the 'nuclear option'. The thing is, all this could have been sorted out more than a year ago.

Bourne was brought up in Kensington, west London, the son of a cloth dealer who had a shop called Tracy in Bond Street. He made his fortune from property - providing affordable office space to small firms struggling to get a toehold in the capital.

He is married to Sarah Greene, the former actress who runs the Old Vic Theatre. The couple make regular appearances in the Court and Social columns of the Times. Greene over lunch persuaded Kevin Spacey to become a director of Old Vic Productions and Lord Attenborough to be its chairman. Dame Judi Dench and Jeremy Irons are also investors.

It was through acting that Bourne and Greene first came across Chris Smith, now Secretary of State for Culture, Media and Sport, the government department responsible for the Dome. Smith is also chairman of the Millennium Commission, which has overseen the running of the attraction.

This most useful of friendships began before the last general election. Greene was interested in launching a new theatre in north London, a redevelopment of the old Collins Music Hall on Islington Green. Smith was the local MP and keen to support the project. Bourne donated £2,000 to Smith's constituency funds. The two have been friends ever since.

It was the start of Bourne's close relationship with Labour. Reports say he has given at least £66,000 to the party and some estimate it is more like £1 million.

In December last year the first reports about his involvement with the Dome appeared. The attraction had not even opened, but Ministers were already concerned about what to do with the structure on its closure 12 months later.

Bourne announced that he was offering an initial fee of £50 million to take the Dome off the Government's hands. He was one of nine consortia interested in buying into Greenwich.

His idea was for an environmentally friendly 'knowledge park' - a vast expanse of e-business offices separated by an indoor forest of trees and hedges. Holes would be cut in the roof to let in more daylight for the 10,000 people he predicted would work in the high-tech casbah. It would be London's very own Silicon Valley, a place where entrepreneurs could hone their skills and pop out for a quick sushi between multi-million-pound deals.

'What we are looking at here is the possibility of nurturing tomorrow's wealth and of creating the next Bill Gates,' he said.

His arrival on the scene produced cries of cronyism. Peter Ainsworth, the Opposition spokesman for culture, said the announcement that Bourne had been shortlisted along with Japanese banking conglomerate Nomura to bid for the Dome earlier this year had a 'tediously familiar air about it'.

'Finding a significant donor to the Labour Party on the shortlist is exactly the kind of thing we have come to expect,' he said.

Bourne denies the charges, pointing out that in the Eighties he was very close to the Thatcher-supporting Saatchi brothers and still plays tennis with Charles Saatchi every Sunday. Lord Bell, the Thatcher-supporting public relations figure, advised him on defeating Nomura and Lord McAlpine, the Conservative donor, and is a friend and supporter of the Old Vic.

When Bourne was told in July he had lost out to Nomura, he was desperately disappointed. Guy Hands, who led Nomura's bid, said he would still run it as a visitor attraction, something the Government was keen on.

Bourne went away to lick his wounds. But the fight was not over. Hands became increasingly worried at the messy state of the Dome's finances. In a private letter to Falconer, he said the Dome's management had repeatedly misled him and that trust had been 'severely undermined'.

'We have been misled on the visitor figures,' Hands said. 'Misled on ticket price reductions, misled on properties owned by NMEC (the company that runs the Dome) . . . and on safety and repairs and on the state of the contracts.' Financial information provided to Hands, he said, was 'materially incorrect'.

In the first week of September, Hands wrote to Falconer again, saying the deal was effectively off. Four days later Nomura officially withdrew.

Falconer was desperate. What the hell could the Government do now to save the Dome? He rang Bourne and asked him to a meeting. Falconer was blunt: he would like Legacy to re-enter the process.

Such was the importance of Falconer's message a meeting was set up between Blair and Bourne. It worked - Bourne decided to re-enter the bidding, now the only person who could possibly save the Dome before the end of the year.

If his resolve has ever wavered, it must have been tested to breaking point by last week's NAO report. Buried in Sir John Bourne's account is the revelation that Mike O'Connor, the Millennium Commission's accounting officer, recommended the Dome should be shut in October as it would not constitute 'value for money' to keep it open. The attraction was obviously in a desperate state.

The report also revealed the Government's constant trumpeting of the fact that more than 80 per cent of visitors thought the Dome 'a good day out' masked internal polling by NMEC which revealed a far bleaker picture.

Surveys commissioned from NOP in April and August show how ambivalent the public was about visiting the Dome. Asked in April if they were interested in visiting the attraction, 61 per cent of the public said they were not. That figure rose to 68 per cent in August. Only 26 per cent said they had either 'already visited, are likely to visit or could be persuaded to visit'. The public's feelings of animosity towards the Dome were clear. The Government had kept quiet about it.

As Falconer stood sipping champagne in the elegant River Room at the Savoy last Tuesday night, his natural bonhomie was not forced.

While all around him guests at CNN's all-night American election party were frantically trying to work out the fate of Al Gore and George W. Bush, Falconer, who unlike most of his fellow party-goers had already seen the NAO report into the Dome, knew his own political future was secure. For now.

The battle will be rejoined this week. Tomorrow, the Tories will lead a debate on the Dome in the House of Commons which will raise many of the issues contained in the NAO report.

On Wednesday, Robin Young, the Permanent Secretary at the Department of Culture, will be called before the Public Accounts Committee to give his version of events. O'Connor will also be called.

Bourne will keep up the constant round of meetings at the Old Queen Street offices of English Partnerships as the two sides try to close the deal.

Insiders say the sticking point is whether Legacy has sufficient financial clout to raise the £102 million needed to buy the Dome and the £250m needed to run it.

'There is still an issue surrounding the solidity of the financial side and they are the same issues as the first time around - how definite was the money,' said one source close to the negotiations.

Others point to emerging tensions between Downing Street, which wants to be shot of the disaster as soon as possible, and John Prescott, who is anxious to ensure the building is left in competent hands. Bourne has told the Government that if he is successful, he will keep the Dome operating for another 30 years. The Government has said it wants the tent to last even longer.

'This is make-or-break week,' said a senior Whitehall source. Break, and the Government has a new crisis on its hands. Make, and the man with the spaniel from Cheyne Walk will be Blair's own private hero.

It worked - Bourne decided to re-enter the bidding, now the only person who could possibly save the Dome before the end of the year. If his resolve has ever wavered, it must have been tested to breaking point by last week's NAO report. Buried in Sir John Bourne's account is the revelation that Mike O'Connor, the Millennium Commission's accounting officer, recommended the Dome should be shut in October as it would not constitute 'value for money' to keep it open. The attraction was obviously in a desperate state. The report also revealed the Government's constant trumpeting of the fact that more than 80 per cent of visitors thought the Dome 'a good day out' masked internal polling by NMEC which revealed a far bleaker picture. Surveys commissioned from NOP in April and August show how ambivalent the public was about visiting the Dome. Asked in April if they were interested in visiting the attraction, 61 per cent of the public said they were not. That figure rose to 68 per cent in August. Only 26 per cent said they had either 'already visited, are likely to visit or could be persuaded to visit'. The public's feelings of animosity towards the Dome were clear. The Government had kept quiet about it. As Falconer stood sipping champagne in the elegant River Room at the Savoy last Tuesday night, his natural bonhomie was not forced. While all around him guests at CNN's all-night American election party were frantically trying to work out the fate of Al Gore and George W. Bush, Falconer, who unlike most of his fellow party-goers had already seen the NAO report into the Dome, knew his own political future was secure. For now. The battle will be rejoined this week. Tomorrow, the Tories will lead a debate on the Dome in the House of Commons which will raise many of the issues contained in the NAO report. On Wednesday, Robin Young, the Permanent Secretary at the Department of Culture, will be called before the Public Accounts Committee to give his version of events. O'Connor will also be called. Bourne will keep up the constant round of meetings at the Old Queen Street offices of English Partnerships as the two sides try to close the deal. Insiders say the sticking point is whether Legacy has sufficient financial clout to raise the £102 million needed to buy the Dome and the £250m needed to run it. 'There is still an issue surrounding the solidity of the financial side and they are the same issues as the first time around - how definite was the money,' said one source close to the negotiations. Others point to emerging tensions between Downing Street, which wants to be shot of the disaster as soon as possible, and John Prescott, who is anxious to ensure the building is left in competent hands. Bourne has told the Government that if he is successful, he will keep the Dome operating for another 30 years. The Government has said it wants the tent to last even longer. 'This is make-or-break week,' said a senior Whitehall source. Break, and the Government has a new crisis on its hands. Make, and the man with the spaniel from Cheyne Walk will be Blair's own private hero.

webTitle: Professionals binge on crack

fields.headline: Professionals binge on crack
fields.standfirst:
Clubbers' taste for designer drug drives up treatment figures. Investigation by Jason Burke, Nick Paton Walsh and Tracy McVeigh

Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: At closing time last Thursday night, Vic Taylor, a 34-year-old businessman, left his local in the quiet, respectable, middle-class area of Sale in Manchester. With four good friends, he went back to a comfortable, semi-detached house to smoke some crack.
fields.body:
At closing time last Thursday night, Vic Taylor, a 34-year-old businessman, left his local in the quiet, respectable, middle-class area of Sale in Manchester. With four good friends, he went back to a comfortable, semi-detached house to smoke some crack.

For the first hour, they smoked intensely, quickly building up the levels of the drug in their bloodstream. Then they relaxed into a cycle of drink, cannabis and the small, off-white 'rocks' that give one of the most powerful and psychologically addictive highs of any drug known to man. 'We pile it on to start with for the first few, and then ease off as it takes effect,' says Vic. 'We pass round the same pipe. But it always seems longer and longer between each of your turns.'

By tonight, Vic will have spent £1,000 and not slept for three nights. Twice a month, he goes on a binge. His wife looks after his four children and, on the Friday, his staff take care of his business.

'Every so often I have a think how serious it's getting,' he said. 'Then I try to drink myself into a stupor to stop. I've never considered myself a drug person - I don't fit into that scene. I've never done heroin, Ecstasy's not for me, and neither's speed. Crack's becoming a designer drug. It's not the low-life drug it used to be.'

An Observer investigation has revealed that crack is becoming the drug of choice for a growing legion of middle-class users. The days when its use was limited to the worst of the inner-city ghettoes are over. At one London drug treatment centre, more than 60 per cent of crack addicts are in employment.

Last week drug workers spoke of civil servants, solicitors, film and video workers, small businessmen and local authority managers who had all sought help from public drugs centres in the past few months. And, they said, these were 'the tip of the iceberg'.

Adam Frankland, a worker with Turning Point, the largest drink and drugs mental health charity in the UK, said his unit in west London had dealt with six chefs and four estate agents in recent months. Chefs are said to like the drug because it allows them to keep going late into the night after an evening's work. The new brand of users is helping to boost crack figures in Britain to record levels. Police figures show that more arrested drug offenders report using crack than heroin - a historic first.

Drug workers confirm that in some areas they are treating more cocaine and crack users than opiate addicts. Figures from the Home Office's British Crime Survey reveal that one in 30 British men aged between 19 and 24 has used crack - twice as many as in 1996 and four times as many as in 1993.

When crack cocaine - which is made by heating powdered cocaine to make concentrated 'rocks' - first appeared in Britain nearly a decade ago, there were apocalyptic prophecies of mass addiction and social devastation. Many dismissed such forecasts as alarmist. Now such optimism is looking misplaced

Dr Michael Donmall, of Manchester University's Drug Misuse Research Centre, said: 'Many said that what happened in the USA could not happen here. But we have not avoided significant elements of their problems.'

The majority of crack users are still living in deprived and disenfranchised urban areas. The paranoia, violence and crime associated with the drug - crack users can easily get through £500-worth of 'rocks' in a day - causes huge, and well-documented, damage.

But the 'white-collar crackheads' are a new and different phenomenon. Many can finance their habit without recourse to theft, fraud or prostitution and are often unapologetic about their habits. Paul, an Oxbridge arts graduate, is a 37-year-old corporate communications manager with a major company in London. He has held down a successful career, married and become a father, all the while maintaining what he calls 'a recreational class-A drug habit'.

'I started smoking heroin about nine or 10 years ago with two friends, because I liked the feeling it gave me. Other people were dabbling with Ecstasy and cocaine, but I preferred something which eased my mind, not sent it racing. I didn't want to be a babbling idiot,' he said.

'I switched to crack because my regular dealer did last year. People think you have to be an addict, but that is nonsense. I have a pipe, but it comes out once every few weeks. This is something I enjoy and I have the money to indulge myself, so why the hell not?'

Such use is increasingly common. Smoked in cigarettes or with cannabis, crack is difficult to detect in a crowded nightclub.

Aidan Gray, national co-ordinator of Focus, a specialist crack research and support agency, said crack is now the drug of choice for many clubbers. In central London, smaller 'clubbing rocks', half the price and half the size of normal, are sold for around £10 each. 'Crack is more and more popular on the dance scene,' Gray said. 'There are clubs in London - and elsewhere in Britain - which are known for crack use.'

Gray said that the vast bulk of recreational crack use is undetected. 'The statistics don't reflect the scale of it at all. If wealthy people are in trouble, they will usually go to private clinics or doctors. Or they just keep using and no one ever knows.'

Nor is the problem restricted to London, Manchester and Merseyside. In the North-West, there has been a tenfold increase in cocaine use - mainly crack - in the past 10 years. In Scotland, according to some reports, the number of new crack addicts has risen twelvefold in the past four years. The police say they have detected people travelling into London from throughout the Home Counties to buy crack.

Many fear that, with the numbers of affluent crack users growing every day, the drug may lose its stigma and its dangers will be forgotten.

'You can go into work on a Monday and say you took a lot of Ecstasy last night, and these days your colleagues may not give you any grief,' said Tim Bottomley, manager of a drugs project in Manchester. 'Currently you can't do the same with crack. If crack becomes acceptable, that's when it will be most dangerous.'

Some names have been changed in this article.

webTitle: Comment: Northern Ireland and the Hume doctrine

fields.headline: A time for honesty
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: John Hume, prophet of the Irish peace process, is threatening to surpass Moses. Having led his tribe and their recalcitrant first cousins out of the wilderness, he has finally glimpsed the Promised Land.
fields.body:
John Hume, prophet of the Irish peace process, is threatening to surpass Moses. Having led his tribe and their recalcitrant first cousins out of the wilderness, he has finally glimpsed the Promised Land.

But like the liberator of the Israelites, the SDLP leader has forbidden himself the milk and honey of power sharing at Stormont, preferring to bless the land from the far away summits of Strasbourg, Westminster and Washington. The trouble is that the faithful tribe he bravely led since the late Seventies - that curious coalition of social democrats, rural nationalists and ambitious young wannabe Fianna Failers - is not quite out of the wilderness yet. In fact, his party may end up marooned with him on the mountaintop rather than inherit the Earth below.

No one can question Hume's commitment to peace, which almost cost him his life and has inflicted serious damage on his health. But the price of peace for the SDLP may yet be electoral eclipse.

As the party prepares for its annual conference next weekend, it is time for them to reflect on whether the Hume doctrine is still serving their interests and those of the North's political centre. The Hume doctrine was founded on the principle of inclusivity: better to have the wandering tribes of terrorism who once worshipped the false gods of armed struggle relieving themselves from inside the tent rather than outside it. In the early to mid Nineties this strategy worked as Hume confounded the critics who claimed he would never deliver an IRA ceasefire, let alone produce a major shift in republican thinking.

The sell-by date on the tablets of stone on which the Hume doctrine was carved may now be long passed. Yet rather than move on the SDLP appears to cling to a commandment which is no longer an article of faith but rather a shield to protect their electoral rivals, Sinn Fein.

There is evidence that the SDLP, instead of marking out a new distinctive identity from Sinn Fein, seeks to mimic their lean and hungry partners from that earlier stage of the peace process. When, for instance, the Provisional IRA shot dead Real IRA's Joe O'Connor in Ballymurphy, Alex Attwood's only reaction was to call on people not to jump to conclusions about who was responsible. Recently the PIRA have stepped up punishment attacks and expulsions. There has been no response from party representatives in these constituencies. The SDLP has kept mum about the punishment shootings and beatings despite them being blatant breaches of the Agreement and the Mitchell Principles. The party seems more exercised over David Trimble's refusal to nominate Sinn Fein Ministers to the North/South Ministerial Council than the IRA's 'internal housekeeping' in nationalist areas.

It is surely one of the most ironic twists of modern Irish history that it is left to the Trimbleite section of the Ulster Unionists to defend the human rights of Catholics who fall foul of the IRA rather than their natural defenders, the SDLP. The party was founded on the precepts of peace, democracy and respect for human rights. The Hume doctrine and the dictates of Stormont realpolitik should not be cause for retreat from these principles.

Moreover, the SDLP is rightly quick to criticise state forces in the North, whether the British Army or the RUC. However, since the Executive was formed the party has failed time and again to point out to its pan-nationalist partners their mistakes, failings, hypocrisies and abuses.

For Seamus Mallon, defending the Agreement therefore should not only mean opposing Trimble's unilateral ban on Sinn Fein at the NSMC but also pulling up republicans over their ongoing breaches of peace, including some of his own Ministers, and not being afraid to speak publicly about them. The SDLP - the party of democratic nationalism and peaceful progressive change - has become an uncertain trumpet at a time when some in their own constituency cry out for a voice to defend them and the integrity of the Agreement.

webTitle: Comment: The Catholic church is not above the law

fields.headline: Rid us of these abusive clerics
fields.standfirst:
The Roman Catholic Church needs reminding that the secular law of the land is above all other law

Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: The Roman Catholic Church needs reminding that the secular law of the land is above all other law.
fields.body:
The hamburger has been excommunicated. Father Massimo Salani, a Roman Catholic theologian, urges the faithful to spurn McDonald's on the grounds that fast food is an expression of the Protestant ethic and therefore 'unCatholic, perhaps even atheist'. Salani's statement, in a newspaper interview, is the culinary equivalent of Dominus Iesus, the papal declaration which recently threatened to make ecumenism as disposable as Kentucky Fried Chicken cartons.

According to the document, Protestant denominations are not proper churches. Now burgers and pizzas aren't proper meals. This seems curious, given the Bible's adherence to instant dining. A profusion of Fillet-o-Fishes in sesame baps is a closer approximation to the original miracle than pumpkin risotto, or whatever Salani deems suitable fodder for the soul. One might easily dismiss his book on the link between food and religion (How To Be A Domestic God?) as eccentric posturing. Instead, the ingress of dogma into the kitchen seems a small symbol of the broadening reach of the Roman Catholic Church.

Last week's operation to separate the conjoined twins, Jodie and Mary, was followed by a vigil organised by the faithful. Some who came to clack rosary beads outside St Mary's Hospital in Manchester said they were there to support the children's Catholic parents. Others were protesting against surgery previously described as 'morally impermissible' by the Archbishop of Westminster, Cormac Murphy-O'Connor.

On the next day, the Royal Society published its endorsement of the Donaldson report's call to use embryo cells to treat degenerative diseases. This breakthrough, a beacon for sufferers and for science, has already been castigated by the Pope as 'a violation which would stain the blood of innocents'. The heavy defeat of a private members' bill on stem-cell research, introduced by the Liberal Democrat MP, Evan Harris, is a bleak early omen. The offer of a free vote in the autumn suggests both Government bet-hedging and the fear that groups opposed to cloning may prevail.

Last week, the Pope repeated his edict that politicians must tailor civil law to that of God. The greater problem for the Catholic Church is posed by those among its own flock who disdain both legislatures. On Thursday, Robert Deadman, a Cistercian monk who offered counselling and spiritual healing to women, was convicted of indecently assaulting four of them by a Leicester jury which heard that he often carried out the attacks in the confessional.

Earlier in the week, John Ward, the Archbishop of Cardiff, was offered the public confessional of Panorama to repent of ordaining Joe Jordan, a paedophile priest now serving eight years after assaulting two nine-year-old boys. Ward maintained that no penance was required on his part for omissions undertaken in 'good faith'. These included ignoring repeated warnings, plus a written demand from a fellow bishop that Jordan posed a danger to children and should be vetted by a paedophile expert. On learning, predictably, that the police were on to Jordan, Ward suspended him, so enabling him to hide a computer stacked with child pornography.

This flagrant disregard for church rules and the interest of the law followed Ward's ignoring complaints about his former press secretary, Father John Lloyd, now serving eight years for indecent assault, rape and buggery. Should Ward resign? Certainly not, he said, until summoned to tea with the Apostolic Nuncio, after which he suddenly decided to request that the Pope appoint a successor 'when the time is right'.

The horror that Ward's conduct has attracted reflects the anger of the decent majority of priests. It also contains a whiff of scapegoatery. For all Ward's culpability, two things grate. The first is that his case reflects not only one man's arrogant folly but also the faults of an unaccountable system in which whistleblowers go unheard. The second, more material caveat is that Ward's deafness over paedophilia was hardly more profound than that of the head of the Catholic Church in England and Wales.

Murphy-O'Connor's mishandling of the case of Father Michael Hill culminated in moving him to be chaplain at Gatwick Airport after complaints about his behaviour. Hill, who was subsequently convicted of nine sex attacks, assaulted a boy with learning difficulties who had missed his flight. The scandal facing the archbishop was damped down on two grounds. First, the nature of paedophilia is better understood now. In addition, the 1994 church guidelines on child abuse were not in place to inform Murphy-O'Connor. These excuses, according to a leading Catholic commentator, 'just about cover the midriff'.

Do they? The cynical might think the difference between the two men is also measured by outcome. Ward, who appeared more stupid and pitiful than malign, is broken on the wheel of church contempt. Just after conceding last week that he must go, he was admitted to hospital with a thrombosis. Murphy-O'Connor, by contrast, is perceived as the engine of change, following his sanctioning of Lord Nolan's ongoing inquiry into paedophile priests, of whom 21, or one in 266 of the total priesthood, have been convicted in the last five years. Although Nolan has no assurances his recommendations will be acted on, the mood now is for debate.

Should celibacy rules be abolished when half the priesthood of the Western world (and 100 per cent in the Third World) is supposed to be sexually active at any one time? Perhaps, but altar boy sex is not the refuge of those deprived of the normal sort. Rather, the suspicion is that some ordinants may choose the priesthood not as a renunciation of normal desires but because of the difficulty of fulfilling abnormal ones in the secular world. This is a tiny minority, the church's defenders say. Beware, lest the ministry be unfairly branded 'institutionally paedophile' (a charge that seems irrefutable, given the lapses by the hierarchy) and lest witch-hunts ensue.

But the Catholic Church is hardly averse to witch-hunting of its own. Neither falling congregations nor scandals have offered a brake on its lustre or stridency. Catholicism is fashionable. We have a Catholic Speaker in the Commons and the prospect of a Catholic monarch, according to Prince Charles's musings to Paddy Ashdown. We have a Prime Minister who attends Mass. All that is fine. Obviously, no stained-glass ceiling should apply.

Equally, there is something surreal about a church which believes that public policy is decreed by private faith and which strives to impose its views on a secular law regularly flouted by its own criminal tendency. Such quibbles have not halted the outspoken. In Scotland, Cardinal Thomas Winning rails against revoking Section 28, the shortcomings of the Parliament and the lack of tax breaks for married couples.

In England and Wales, scientific advance opens up a new vista of influence. Whether or not one approves of the result of the Siamese twins operation - the prospect of a healthy life for a baby the church wanted to let die - ecclesiastical eagerness to dictate what is 'morally permissible' looks almost impertinent in the light of current travails. That will not hinder the forthcoming opposition against embryo research. Expect outrage on the drift towards eugenics and euthanasia and a veil drawn across the obvious irony.

As church sex scandals prove, science is a mere novice in the art of destroying innocent lives.

This flagrant disregard for church rules and the interest of the law followed Ward's ignoring complaints about his former press secretary, Father John Lloyd, now serving eight years for indecent assault, rape and buggery. Should Ward resign? Certainly not, he said, until summoned to tea with the Apostolic Nuncio, after which he suddenly decided to request that the Pope appoint a successor 'when the time is right'. The horror that Ward's conduct has attracted reflects the anger of the decent majority of priests. It also contains a whiff of scapegoatery. For all Ward's culpability, two things grate. The first is that his case reflects not only one man's arrogant folly but also the faults of an unaccountable system in which whistleblowers go unheard. The second, more material caveat is that Ward's deafness over paedophilia was hardly more profound than that of the head of the Catholic Church in England and Wales. Murphy-O'Connor's mishandling of the case of Father Michael Hill culminated in moving him to be chaplain at Gatwick Airport after complaints about his behaviour. Hill, who was subsequently convicted of nine sex attacks, assaulted a boy with learning difficulties who had missed his flight. The scandal facing the archbishop was damped down on two grounds. First, the nature of paedophilia is better understood now. In addition, the 1994 church guidelines on child abuse were not in place to inform Murphy-O'Connor. These excuses, according to a leading Catholic commentator, 'just about cover the midriff'. Do they? The cynical might think the difference between the two men is also measured by outcome. Ward, who appeared more stupid and pitiful than malign, is broken on the wheel of church contempt. Just after conceding last week that he must go, he was admitted to hospital with a thrombosis. Murphy-O'Connor, by contrast, is perceived as the engine of change, following his sanctioning of Lord Nolan's ongoing inquiry into paedophile priests, of whom 21, or one in 266 of the total priesthood, have been convicted in the last five years. Although Nolan has no assurances his recommendations will be acted on, the mood now is for debate. Should celibacy rules be abolished when half the priesthood of the Western world (and 100 per cent in the Third World) is supposed to be sexually active at any one time? Perhaps, but altar boy sex is not the refuge of those deprived of the normal sort. Rather, the suspicion is that some ordinants may choose the priesthood not as a renunciation of normal desires but because of the difficulty of fulfilling abnormal ones in the secular world. This is a tiny minority, the church's defenders say. Beware, lest the ministry be unfairly branded 'institutionally paedophile' (a charge that seems irrefutable, given the lapses by the hierarchy) and lest witch-hunts ensue. But the Catholic Church is hardly averse to witch-hunting of its own. Neither falling congregations nor scandals have offered a brake on its lustre or stridency. Catholicism is fashionable. We have a Catholic Speaker in the Commons and the prospect of a Catholic monarch, according to Prince Charles's musings to Paddy Ashdown. We have a Prime Minister who attends Mass. All that is fine. Obviously, no stained-glass ceiling should apply. Equally, there is something surreal about a church which believes that public policy is decreed by private faith and which strives to impose its views on a secular law regularly flouted by its own criminal tendency. Such quibbles have not halted the outspoken. In Scotland, Cardinal Thomas Winning rails against revoking Section 28, the shortcomings of the Parliament and the lack of tax breaks for married couples. In England and Wales, scientific advance opens up a new vista of influence. Whether or not one approves of the result of the Siamese twins operation - the prospect of a healthy life for a baby the church wanted to let die - ecclesiastical eagerness to dictate what is 'morally permissible' looks almost impertinent in the light of current travails. That will not hinder the forthcoming opposition against embryo research. Expect outrage on the drift towards eugenics and euthanasia and a veil drawn across the obvious irony. As church sex scandals prove, science is a mere novice in the art of destroying innocent lives.

webTitle: Farewell to a friend in high places

fields.headline: Farewell to a friend in high places
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Power is slipping away, admittedly rather slowly, from Bill Clinton. As the recount continues in Florida, politicians in Dublin and Belfast are waking up to the fact that, whoever wins, Northern Ireland is unlikely to be a priority on the new President's agenda.
fields.body:
Power is slipping away, admittedly rather slowly, from Bill Clinton. As the recount continues in Florida, politicians in Dublin and Belfast are waking up to the fact that, whoever wins, Northern Ireland is unlikely to be a priority on the new President's agenda.

Bill Clinton's departure from the White House will mean an end to the late-night phone calls to Belfast, urging politicians on both sides to make the necessary compromises for peace.

The annual celebrations for St Patrick's Day, when the White House has been decked out in all shades of orange and green, will be more low-key next year. It's been suggested that the party may be moved to New York where Hillary Clinton, who has visited Northern Ireland five times, has just been elected a US senator.

Before Clinton rides off into the sunset, the British and Irish Governments hope that he may be able to work one last bit of magic for the peace process. The President is to make a trip to Ireland next month, visiting Belfast and Dublin.

It will be primarily a lap of honour recognising the contribution he has made. But Northern Ireland's politicians are once again in difficulties over the decommissioning of IRA weapons. An appeal by President Clinton could provide an opportunity for the IRA to move on the issue by re-establishing contact with General John de Chastelain's commission. This will allow David Trimble to lift the ban which he has placed on Sinn Fein members of the power-sharing Executive attending meetings of cross-border bodies.

Such a resolution of the present impasse will get the Belfast Agreement back on track; it would also be a graceful recognition of Clinton's involvement in the process. It is an achievement of which he himself is keenly aware. Earlier this month at a fundraising event for his wife's campaign in New York, the President told the Irish-American audience: 'I want to tell you how grateful I am that somehow, some way when I first started running for President the Irish found me.'

In return the Irish-American community has stood loyally with him through all the scandals. On the night that Ken Starr delivered the impeachment document to Congress, 800 Irish-Americans gathered at the White House. Not a word of criticism was heard, and this was something for which Clinton thanked his supporters earlier this week.

Niall O'Dowd, editor of the New York-based Irish Voice newspaper,was one of a small group of Irish-Americans who sought out Bill Clinton when he was running for President in 1992. He promised that, if elected, he would try to further the search for peace, perhaps by appointing a special envoy to Northern Ireland.

His decision to become involved caused shock waves, not only at Westminster but in the higher reaches of his own administration. It had long been the policy of the State Department that Northern Ireland was a matter for the British Government and that any interference by the United States could damage Anglo-American relations.

Some of Clinton's early decisions, particularly the move to give Gerry Adams an entry visa before the IRA called its first ceasefire, caused real strain between Washington and London. Many Unionists have long believed that the President's policies are heavily tinged with green.

In the intervening years, as peace has put out fragile roots, Clinton has shown himself to be determinedly even-handed in his approach; David Trimble and other Unionists have been made welcome at the White House.

The President has persuaded some of his own colleagues, most notably Senator George Mitchell, to devote their skills to the negotiations in Northern Ireland. Just as importantly, he has given Ulster's own politicians a new sense of confidence in their own ability. If the leader of the most powerful country in the world is so concerned with their problems, it must be worth having another try to achieve peace.

Bertie Ahern, the Irish Prime Minister, described Clinton's attitude last week. He told the Irish Times 'You never had to worry about contacting him. If there was a crisis in the peace process he'd be on the phone immediately from the presidential jet.' All that is going to change, Northern Ireland has not figured in the presidential campaign.

The Irish Government would probably like to see Al Gore win, mainly because that would represent continuity with Clinton. Ironically, it was George W. Bush who expressed generous praise for the outgoing President's involvement with Northern Ireland. For many people, one of the most poignant moments of the whole peace process came in November 1995 when Clinton switched on Belfast's Christmas lights and Van Morrison sang 'Days Like This.'

Hopes were dashed soon afterwards when the IRA bombed Canary Wharf. Bill Clinton was one of those, along with Tony Blair, who set about picking up the pieces. Once again the politicians in Northern Ireland are facing difficulties in taking the Belfast Agreement forward. But there is a growing belief that the problems will be resolved. This will be reflected when people on both sides of the community turn out to welcome the American President who, whatever his personal shortcomings, never lost confidence in the ability of Northern Ireland's politicians to secure peace.

webTitle: Maguire fury after IRA shoots brother

fields.headline: Maguire fury after IRA shoots brother
fields.standfirst:
Call for inquiry after punishment squad puts bullets through victim's wrists and ankles
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The IRA has shot the brother of Donna Maguire, one of the organisation's most notorious female activists.
fields.body:
The IRA has shot the brother of Donna Maguire, one of the organisation's most notorious female activists.

The shooting has provoked anger and dismay among Maguire's family, with the convicted bomber herself calling for a top-level republican inquiry into the so-called punishment attack.

Malachy Maguire was abducted from his car outside his girlfriend's home at Meigh in South Armagh last Saturday evening. He was dragged from the car by a number of gunmen and taken to a nearby children's play area.

According to republican sources in the area, Maguire was beaten with iron bars and then shot with a handgun in both his wrists and ankles.

The 35-year-old spent most of last week being treated for his injuries in Belfast's Royal Victoria Hospital. He has now been transferred to Newry's Daisy Hill Hospital.

Locals said the Provisional IRA was responsible for the attack and that among the gunmen was one of the South Armagh Brigade's most seasoned activists who once worked with Donna Maguire inside the terror group. Maguire and her father, Malachy senior, are understood to be 'furious' over the shooting.

They have demanded a meeting with the IRA leadership and Sinn Fein.

One republican source in the area said: 'Donna is going mad about her brother. She's accusing those involved of not really being republicans, of being more interested in lining their own pockets.'

The incident received virtually no coverage in the local press despite the relationship between the victim and one of the IRA's most feared and infamous female volunteers.

Donna Maguire was part of an IRA unit behind a series of terror attacks on British military personnel in northern Europe during the early Nineties. In June 1990 Maguire, along with Gerard Harte, Sean Hick and Paul Hughes (all from the Newry/South Armagh area) was acquitted of the murder of Major Michael Dillon Lee in Germany. But the German judge, Wolfgang Steller, said it was 'clear they are members of the IRA and trained as IRA volunteers'. The AK-47 rifle that killed Dillon Lee was also used to murder Mick Islania, an RAF corporal, and his six-month-old daughter.

Six years after she was released, Donna Maguire received £13,500 compensation for twisting her ankle after tripping on a Newry footpath in 1985.

In a strange twist of fate, Donna Maguire's cousin witnessed the murder of the last British soldier in Northern Ireland, Stephen Restorick. He was shot dead by an IRA sniper in South Armagh three years ago.

Maguire's cousin, Lorraine McElroy, suffered a slight head wound from the same bullet that killed the soldier. L/Bdr Restorick was handing back McElroy's driving licence at a checkpoint in Bessbrook when he was cut down. She had to leave the Bessbrook area after incurring republican wrath for condemning the killing and sending a wreath to the soldier's funeral.

'I don't speak for Donna and she doesn't speak for me,' said McElroy, 'I have about 60 cousins and I have had no real contact with her for a long time. We don't necessarily share the same views about any subject.'

webTitle: Palestinians set new conditions for peace talks

fields.headline: Palestinians set new conditions for peace talks
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Palestinian officials yesterday set out tough new conditions they say Israel must meet before the stalled peace process can be resumed and the current violence end. The conditions include the deployment of a UN protection force - already rejected by Israel and the US - and a complete end to all settlement building in the Occupied Territories.
fields.body:
Palestinian officials yesterday set out tough new conditions they say Israel must meet before the stalled peace process can be resumed and the current violence end. The conditions include the deployment of a UN protection force - already rejected by Israel and the US - and a complete end to all settlement building in the Occupied Territories.

The announcement was made before a meeting in Washington between Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak and President Bill Clinton, aimed at bringing an end to a month and a half of clashes in which almost 200 have died. It also came as Israel came under renewed criticism for its use of 'excessive force' from both Amnesty International and UN Human Rights Commissioner Mary Robinson.

In a statement yesterday, Ahmed Korei, speaker of the Palestinian Legislative Council or parliament, said a new blueprint was needed to revive peace talks.

'These include a complete halt to all [Jewish] settlement activities [in the West Bank and Gaza Strip],' said Korei, better known as Abu Ala. 'In these clashes, we saw these settlements were not used as residential areas but military bases and the settlers are armed militias attacking Palestinians daily.'

The international community considers the settlements on land captured by Israel in the 1967 Middle East War to be illegal and the Palestinians say they must be dismantled as a condition for any final peace agreement.

Korei said that, given Israel's 'use of excessive force' by international standards against Palestinians, the Palestinian leadership would insist on deployment of an international protection force in Palestinian areas.

'There is no trust in Israel and we will not sit down to negotiate under the threat of combat helicopters bombarding our towns or a siege suffocating us. We need international protection,' he said.

Israel has already rejected Palestinian President Yasser Arafat's calls for a UN protection force. Arafat met Clinton in Washington on Thursday but found him cool to the notion of an international force.

Palestinian officials said Arafat gave Clinton a document outlining the set of requirements to be met before talks can be resumed. It also stressed Israel must implement a US-brokered understanding to end the violence reached in Egypt last month.

Korei said Washington had shown complete bias in favour of Israel so Palestinians would insist in future on the participation of the UN.
