fields.headline: The Longest Night
fields.standfirst:
The Bush dynasty is gearing up for the presidency but Al Gore will not go down without a fight. Ed Vulliamy in Austin, Texas, reports on a week of unprecedented tension when politics went down to the wire and beyond
Special report: the US elections Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Al Gore's limousine was pulling up at the War Memorial plaza in Nashville in the early hours of a sodden Wednesday morning, the Vice-President of the United States braced for the worst moment of his political life.
fields.body:
Al Gore's limousine was pulling up at the War Memorial plaza in Nashville in the early hours of a sodden Wednesday morning, the Vice-President of the United States braced for the worst moment of his political life.

A few thousand soaked supporters were gathered to cheer him, as best they could, through his public concession of defeat to the man who had just stolen Gore's lifelong dream, his election rival George W. Bush.

Gore had already placed the call to Bush at the Governor's mansion in Texas, and now he had to tell the world in a short and, he was determined, gracious speech . As the limo braked, a Skytel pager belonging to an aide, Michael Feldman, vibrated in another car, several vehicles behind in the Gore motorcade.

The message told Feldman to call Michael Whouley, a leading campaign strategist monitoring returns in Florida. Florida had caused enough tribulation for everyone already that night, thanks to a series of gaffes by the mass media, and the willingness of the real world of politics to go along with them.

Indeed, all the emotional agony and ecstasy of the night so far among the electorate, the rival camps and even the candidates themselves had been in response not to hard-and-fast results, but to phantasmagoria, to media predictions based on scanty 'exit polls'. Florida had initially been called for Gore, sending his camp into premature celebration as a juggernaut of Democrat red apparently set out westwards across the map of America.

Some aides were so heartened they went to get dinner in the steakhouse at the Lowes Hotel, where they could not watch television. Then to the media's shame Florida was withdrawn, undeclared.

The withdrawal detonated a sudden surge of state victories for Bush, and a surge of blue across the map. And at 1.12am Central Time, the crucial state had been conclusively called (by those same TV networks) for Bush. At 1.20, Gore's campaign manager Donna Brazile had sent him a message on his Blackberry pager: 'Never surrender' but Gore was too downcast to give it credence; there was nothing for it but to make the speech.

Feldman returned Whouley's message, to be told that the Florida Secretary of State's web page indicated that Bush, rather that winning the state by a 15,000 majority, led by only 5,000 votes, with precincts still to count.

And there was a message from Bill Daley, Gore's heavy-hitting campaign manager: 'Don't let him concede. It's not over yet. 'Five minutes later, Gore was on the telephone to Austin for a second time that night. 'Circumstances,' he said, once through to the Governor of Texas, 'have changed. I need to withdraw my concession until the situation is clear'. 'Let me make sure I understand, Mr Vice-President,' said Bush. 'You're calling me back to retract your concession'. 'There's no need to get snippy about it,' said Gore. Bush replied that his brother Jeb was the Governor in charge of the Florida ballot. Gore's voice retorted: 'It may surprise you but your younger brother is not the ultimate authority on this.' 'Mr Vice-President,' said BushÍs voice, 'You need to do what you have to do.'

At 6pm that evening, the Bush family had sat down to a dinner of parmesan-crusted chicken in a private dining room at the campaignÍs informal headquarters, the Shoreline Grill and Bar at the Four Seasons Hotel on a bend in the slow-rolling Colorado River.

It was a grey, damp evening, perfect for the heron which glide across the river reaches at the foot of the sweeping sawgrass lawn down which the Texas governor looked as he ate. While his rival had spent a punishing 30 hours campaigning without sleep, Bush had taken Sunday off, and was full of beans.

His campaign aides had told him privately they expected him to win 320 electoral college seats 50 more than required. Father George and mother Barbara had come to join him for the big night, as had brother Jeb whose Florida state Bush Snr had carried in his elections of 1988 and 1992.

Apparently George almost choked on his steak when the CBS punditocracy called Florida for Gore. Jeb got up from his seat, walked over to his brother, hugged him and said, in tears: 'I'm sorry.' Then he left the room. The dinner broke up, Bush retiring with and his wife Laura and his parents but no Jeb to the Governor's mansion.

A proposed gathering with selected guests was cancelled. Some 20 minutes later, Bush allowed in the cameras to show his drawn, stunned face. Meanwhile, on the ninth floor of the Four Seasons, 'you could hear a pin drop', says one aide. O

Only Karl Rove, Bush's indefatigable campaign strategist, was buoyant; he immediately spotted problems with the media forecast, and telephoned them to say so. An hour later, the Florida prediction was indeed withdrawn. And shortly after 1.10am Texas time, the networks delivered it the other way.

Again, based on nothing more than the word of television, the street party began outside the hotel and pink marble statehouse. The phone rang shortly afterwards: it was Al Gore, conceding defeat. Dubya was just preparing to go to bed, thinking he was President of the United States, when it rang again.

'Circumstances have changed,' said the voice on the other end. Despite the call, campaign chairman Don Wilson went to address the crowds: 'We believe we have elected the next President of the United States'. Dubya went to bed at 3.30, and when he awoke, he went downstairs, fed the cats and made Laura her coffee, as usual.

He had a bit of a chat with one of the cats. Bush said: 'She understood.' 'I've been in politics a long time,' he said on Thursday, 'but I don't think I've had a night like this one.' The Bush brigade, albeit not the family, have since been re-visiting the Shoreline Grill, prowling the carpet and hotel reception like palace guards ready to fend off a coup d'etat.

Be it brazen confidence or bluster the Bush entourage of Austin isready to assume power. On Friday, when Bush made his first appearance for 48 hours, the strain of the strange week was obvious. His eyes were tired, his speech was halting and faint.

Sitting near him were Dick Cheney, his would-be Vice-President, and Andrew Card, the likely Chief of Staff in a Bush White House. Both were to meet him at his ranch near Waco over the weekend. Bush said: 'I am mindful that there are still votes to be counted.' But he added: 'I think it's up to us to prepare the groundwork for an administration that will be ready to function on day one.' Outside the mansion, a group of protesters drew attention to what Democrats have claimed were irregularities in the Florida voting. Bush was asked what he would say to those Americans who would deem his presidency illegitimate. 'I would say we have a Constitution,' he said.

'I will live by the Constitution. We've had two vote counts already, and I'm pleased with what's happened.' Bush seemed utterly spent and got confused about the name of a reporter whom he knew well. There was a large adhesive bandage on his cheek, covering what his campaign's communications director, Karen Hughes, said was a boil-like infection but not serious.

Bush stopped short of announcing Cabinet appointments or staging any sort of celebration. 'We're taking our time,' he said. We're in a very low-key manner.' But low-keyed or not, the entourage of Austin is poised to make the move to Washington.

Comparisons with Bill Clinton's Little Rock are irresistible. Clinton was despised by a large slice of his state capital, by the lifelong Republicans and racists who would hound him for his eight years of office, to dramatic effect.

Bush is similarly isolated within Austin, which is an anomaly in Texas, a liberal university town with its famous and historic Sixth Street, now home to neo-grunge rock.

But as with Clinton, there is also a considerable segment of the population who think they know Dubya as a friend, and as with Clinton, a little empire has built up around him. Only there the comparison ends, for in Austin (and in its main power base of Houston, down the road) there is a big difference: family.

The Bushes operate as a dynasty, its enemies use the 'M' word, with George Bush Snr as the Godfather. Every step of the way, in business and in politics, for all his cocaine frat-brat boozing, Vietnam draft-dodging and drunken driving,the sonÍs fortunes have been nurtured by the former President.

Austin is full of recollections of how Dubya's early ventures into his father's business, oil, were invariably bailed out of disaster by friends of the then Senator Bush, tycoons eager for influence with the older man heading for the White House.

It was friends of George Bush Snr who opened the floodgates of money through which this most expensive campaign in all history first surged. President Bush the First has been the silent senior partner guiding his sonÍs progress.

He bequeathed him running mate Dick Cheney (a close member of the big oil cabal) and often consulted directly with the man last week busily motorcading to and fro under AustinÍs blue sky, the Merlin behind Dubya's victory if there is one: Karl Rove. Rove is the man who is meeting rock with rock against GoreÍs challenge.

'In America,' he said on Thursday, 'we vote on election day. We do not go on re-voting and re-counting until we get the result Al Gore wants.' Rove is the man who has devised a strategy which could turn the election's denouement into a never-ending tit-for-tat, telling journalists on Friday he would counter the recount in Florida with demands for the same in Iowa and Wisconsin, where Gore's lead is between 5-6,000.

In New Mexico, Rove did not have to bother, Governor Gary Johnson announced on Friday night that the race in his state, declared by the media for Gore, would recount and could go either way by one vote.

A recount was also probable in Oregon. Rove knows the Four Seasons, and many others, well. He has run almost every Republican campaign in Texas for 20 years from here, 'bullying, bristling, laughing when he really has to', one insider told The Observer. He has known Bush for all those 20 years, but still calls him Sir.

Now Rove waits to become the backstage Svengali, the George Stephanopoulos of the next White House. Rove's finest hour, they say on the Austin grapevine (and he has never denied it), came when he assumed a false identity to break into the Democrats' Illinois headquarters in 1970 in order to steal letterheads to print invitations to a binge featuring 'free beer, free food, girls and a good time for nothing'.

Rove learnt his craft from Lee Atwater, the strategist who put Dubya's father in the White House. Commuting like a relay runner last week between the GovernorÍs mansion, the Shoreline Grill, the State Capitol and the bar at the Driskill Hotel was the huge frame of Joe Allbaugh.

'It's a flat top,' he says of his hair, which he wears in a military buzz, 'not a crew cut'. A rare and obligatory display of bombast from the usually press-shy Allbaugh, caught in the Driskill bar. He is, they say, privately dreading the glare of Washington. An 'Okie', he has been Bush's chief of staff, enforcing the Governor's will as effectively as he hopes to brand that of the next President, 'I'm the heavy,' he says, 'in the literal sense of the word'.

The third side of the Austin 'iron triangle' is Karen Hughes, now hoarse from speaking for her boss and confidant. Hughes, an army brat born in Paris, started the campaign looking like a sprightly businesswoman on springs but has ended up by perfecting her apparatchik's robotic strut.

And no wonder: this has been one of the most tightly managed political campaigns ever, as would be the Presidency, no paper bags on heads when she takes the White House podium. It's even said in Austin that Bush said to Hughes: 'If you're not running, 'I'm not running.' The whisper in Austin is that she and Rove do not get on, requiring frequent umpiring by Allbaugh.

Don Evans, the campaign chairman, is the scary one: cold-eyed, hard-faced and slipping behind the curtain before anyone has time to ask the questions he will not answer about anything other than the fact that he filled the biggest election coffers of all time.

Unlike Bush, these people owe nothing to rhetoric about 'uniting America'. As they prepare to run the White House, they owe nothing to consensus politics and have no investments anywhere other than in hard, Conservative politics as practised in the state of Texas, under the man who now seeks to elevate the values and subjects of his fiefdom to the national plane.

For three days after Tuesday's vote, and the dramatic 3am drive to give the concession speech that wasn't, Gore stewed in the ninth floor Swan suite of Loews hotel in downtown Nashville. It was an ignominious fate: after nearly two years of campaigning and the exhausting final cross-country push, Gore and his family were virtual prisoners in a hotel ringed by the world's media in a state that he calls home but had turned against him and voted Republican.

Aides said he spent the days on the telephone and watching news broadcasts like everyone else. In the bars and honky-tonks of Nashville, few had sympathy for their native son. 'He was an idiot,' remarked one man. 'If he hadn't lost Tennessee he would have won the election.

And he lost because he didn't campaign here and he wouldn't let Clinton off the leash to campaign for him.' Only once did he face the press, preferring instead to direct his aides and a gathering army of lawyers into a total war of spin and counter-spin over the Florida vote unseen.

The decision to withdraw and let others, including former Secretary of State Warren Christopher and aggrieved West Palm Beach voters, fight his battle was calculated to avoid risking the appearance that heÍs not abiding by the rules of the game.

But while maintaining that as winner of the popular vote he should be President, Gore may have lost precious time in failing to counteract Bush's presumption of winning office by setting up transition teams. Asked how long the Vice-President would explore avenues to establish that he won Florida, one adviser said: ïHow can you put a deadline on democracy?'

Before abandoning Nashville for his home in Washington on Thursday, Gore went out for a jog with his daughters, Kristin and Kareena.

When a reporter asked him whether he had won the election, Gore ducked the question, saying only: 'We're having a great run here, thank you.' When he travelled from Nashville to Washington on Friday, he did not make any public comments but allowed television cameras to film him and his family playing touch football in the grounds of the Vice-President's house.

His aides insisted they were adamant in their resolve to make sure that there were not flaws in the voting process. Daley said: 'I hope that our friends in the Bush campaign will join us in our efforts to get the fairest and most accurate vote count here in Florida.'

There is little chance of such amity. Indeed, Gore was coming under intense pressure to concede in the interests of national unit and national stability. And the truth is that, in the words of the veteran commentator R. W. Apple, neither Bush nor Gore 'closed the deal' with the people of America. Al Gore not only won the popular vote but polled more votes than Bill Clinton in either of his victories in 1992 and 1996, running on a programme at least two steps to the left of Clinton, which recalled Truman or even Roosevelt more than it did his mentor's 'Third Way'.

Conversely, although Bush's packaging managed to file down the sharp edges of his ideological parcel, its ultra-conservative kernel was unmistakable. He campaigned on a manifesto that was brazen in its divisiveness as his rhetoric was in its appeal to 'unite' America. Whoever assumes the highest political office in the land, he represents his half only, his half of a nation divided. Divided more evenly and, at the and of this week more bitterly, than any American can remember, politically, culturally, demographically, racially and in terms of gender.

There seems little doubt that the celebrated 'First 100 Days, by which incoming administrations are usually measured, will be a matter of bluster by the new President and deadlock.

On paper, Bush enjoys a hegemony that the Republicans have not enjoyed since 1953, command of the White House, Senate and House of Representatives, but the drama of last week renders that hegemony a bluff.

It seems unreal, for the moment, that a man elected on either such a slim mandate or no mandate at all could, in Bush's case, at least 'implement tax cuts so brazenly beneficial to one section for society (in his case, the super-rich), revolutionise and privatise the social security system, assail such rights as abortion and tick off the items on a shopping list left by the National Rifle Association (NRA). But Bush, if he takes office, will owe his election to the big backers of the Republican Party who desperately wanted power at any cost.

The oil magnates will want their return, as will the NRA. Those who reap the harvest of mass health insurance will expect a consideration, likewise the tobacco giants.

The Christian coalition and its allies will take the narrow victory not as a signal for restraint, but as occasion to demand a reward for their priceless loyalty. Already, in Austin last week, the demeanour, the bullish retorts and combative mood of the Cabinet-in-waiting suggests that conciliation will soon pass its sell-by-date.

The only recent election remotely comparable to this was John F. Kennedy's razor-edged victory over Richard Nixon in 1960, after which Nixon made a point of not wanting to 'put America through the pain' of a contested result and recount.

Some moderates in Al Gore's Nashville camp, and the op-ed barons of the East Coast media, who loathe any sign of combat over what the revered Founding Fathers might have meant by democracy in America, are urging Gore to behave and concede defeat.

But we have seen many sides to polyhedron Gore of late, and it has been a blend of two which has proved most effective (indeed, if left un-spun by his team, it might have won him the election): his tough-guy Sopranos act and his 'voice-of-experience-and-respect-for-history' act.

When he emerged to speak during Wednesday's crisis, he did so in deep, sombre tones about his respect for the sanctity of AmericaÍs democracy and its institutions, including the Electoral College. Then, behind the scenes, Gore rolled his sleeves up and, with Daley, donned his gloves to face his foe.

Additional reporting by Ed Helmore in New York

Every step of the way, in business and in politics, for all his cocaine frat-brat boozing, Vietnam draft-dodging and drunken driving,the sonÍs fortunes have been nurtured by the former President. Austin is full of recollections of how Dubya's early ventures into his father's business, oil, were invariably bailed out of disaster by friends of the then Senator Bush, tycoons eager for influence with the older man heading for the White House. It was friends of George Bush Snr who opened the floodgates of money through which this most expensive campaign in all history first surged. President Bush the First has been the silent senior partner guiding his sonÍs progress. He bequeathed him running mate Dick Cheney (a close member of the big oil cabal) and often consulted directly with the man last week busily motorcading to and fro under AustinÍs blue sky, the Merlin behind Dubya's victory if there is one: Karl Rove. Rove is the man who is meeting rock with rock against GoreÍs challenge. 'In America,' he said on Thursday, 'we vote on election day. We do not go on re-voting and re-counting until we get the result Al Gore wants.' Rove is the man who has devised a strategy which could turn the election's denouement into a never-ending tit-for-tat, telling journalists on Friday he would counter the recount in Florida with demands for the same in Iowa and Wisconsin, where Gore's lead is between 5-6,000. In New Mexico, Rove did not have to bother, Governor Gary Johnson announced on Friday night that the race in his state, declared by the media for Gore, would recount and could go either way by one vote. A recount was also probable in Oregon. Rove knows the Four Seasons, and many others, well. He has run almost every Republican campaign in Texas for 20 years from here, 'bullying, bristling, laughing when he really has to', one insider told The Observer. He has known Bush for all those 20 years, but still calls him Sir. Now Rove waits to become the backstage Svengali, the George Stephanopoulos of the next White House. Rove's finest hour, they say on the Austin grapevine (and he has never denied it), came when he assumed a false identity to break into the Democrats' Illinois headquarters in 1970 in order to steal letterheads to print invitations to a binge featuring 'free beer, free food, girls and a good time for nothing'. Rove learnt his craft from Lee Atwater, the strategist who put Dubya's father in the White House. Commuting like a relay runner last week between the GovernorÍs mansion, the Shoreline Grill, the State Capitol and the bar at the Driskill Hotel was the huge frame of Joe Allbaugh. 'It's a flat top,' he says of his hair, which he wears in a military buzz, 'not a crew cut'. A rare and obligatory display of bombast from the usually press-shy Allbaugh, caught in the Driskill bar. He is, they say, privately dreading the glare of Washington. An 'Okie', he has been Bush's chief of staff, enforcing the Governor's will as effectively as he hopes to brand that of the next President, 'I'm the heavy,' he says, 'in the literal sense of the word'. The third side of the Austin 'iron triangle' is Karen Hughes, now hoarse from speaking for her boss and confidant. Hughes, an army brat born in Paris, started the campaign looking like a sprightly businesswoman on springs but has ended up by perfecting her apparatchik's robotic strut. And no wonder: this has been one of the most tightly managed political campaigns ever, as would be the Presidency, no paper bags on heads when she takes the White House podium. It's even said in Austin that Bush said to Hughes: 'If you're not running, 'I'm not running.' The whisper in Austin is that she and Rove do not get on, requiring frequent umpiring by Allbaugh. Don Evans, the campaign chairman, is the scary one: cold-eyed, hard-faced and slipping behind the curtain before anyone has time to ask the questions he will not answer about anything other than the fact that he filled the biggest election coffers of all time. Unlike Bush, these people owe nothing to rhetoric about 'uniting America'. As they prepare to run the White House, they owe nothing to consensus politics and have no investments anywhere other than in hard, Conservative politics as practised in the state of Texas, under the man who now seeks to elevate the values and subjects of his fiefdom to the national plane. For three days after Tuesday's vote, and the dramatic 3am drive to give the concession speech that wasn't, Gore stewed in the ninth floor Swan suite of Loews hotel in downtown Nashville. It was an ignominious fate: after nearly two years of campaigning and the exhausting final cross-country push, Gore and his family were virtual prisoners in a hotel ringed by the world's media in a state that he calls home but had turned against him and voted Republican. Aides said he spent the days on the telephone and watching news broadcasts like everyone else. In the bars and honky-tonks of Nashville, few had sympathy for their native son. 'He was an idiot,' remarked one man. 'If he hadn't lost Tennessee he would have won the election. And he lost because he didn't campaign here and he wouldn't let Clinton off the leash to campaign for him.' Only once did he face the press, preferring instead to direct his aides and a gathering army of lawyers into a total war of spin and counter-spin over the Florida vote unseen. The decision to withdraw and let others, including former Secretary of State Warren Christopher and aggrieved West Palm Beach voters, fight his battle was calculated to avoid risking the appearance that heÍs not abiding by the rules of the game. But while maintaining that as winner of the popular vote he should be President, Gore may have lost precious time in failing to counteract Bush's presumption of winning office by setting up transition teams. Asked how long the Vice-President would explore avenues to establish that he won Florida, one adviser said: ïHow can you put a deadline on democracy?' Before abandoning Nashville for his home in Washington on Thursday, Gore went out for a jog with his daughters, Kristin and Kareena. When a reporter asked him whether he had won the election, Gore ducked the question, saying only: 'We're having a great run here, thank you.' When he travelled from Nashville to Washington on Friday, he did not make any public comments but allowed television cameras to film him and his family playing touch football in the grounds of the Vice-President's house. His aides insisted they were adamant in their resolve to make sure that there were not flaws in the voting process. Daley said: 'I hope that our friends in the Bush campaign will join us in our efforts to get the fairest and most accurate vote count here in Florida.' There is little chance of such amity. Indeed, Gore was coming under intense pressure to concede in the interests of national unit and national stability. And the truth is that, in the words of the veteran commentator R. W. Apple, neither Bush nor Gore 'closed the deal' with the people of America. Al Gore not only won the popular vote but polled more votes than Bill Clinton in either of his victories in 1992 and 1996, running on a programme at least two steps to the left of Clinton, which recalled Truman or even Roosevelt more than it did his mentor's 'Third Way'. Conversely, although Bush's packaging managed to file down the sharp edges of his ideological parcel, its ultra-conservative kernel was unmistakable. He campaigned on a manifesto that was brazen in its divisiveness as his rhetoric was in its appeal to 'unite' America. Whoever assumes the highest political office in the land, he represents his half only, his half of a nation divided. Divided more evenly and, at the and of this week more bitterly, than any American can remember, politically, culturally, demographically, racially and in terms of gender. There seems little doubt that the celebrated 'First 100 Days, by which incoming administrations are usually measured, will be a matter of bluster by the new President and deadlock. On paper, Bush enjoys a hegemony that the Republicans have not enjoyed since 1953, command of the White House, Senate and House of Representatives, but the drama of last week renders that hegemony a bluff. It seems unreal, for the moment, that a man elected on either such a slim mandate or no mandate at all could, in Bush's case, at least 'implement tax cuts so brazenly beneficial to one section for society (in his case, the super-rich), revolutionise and privatise the social security system, assail such rights as abortion and tick off the items on a shopping list left by the National Rifle Association (NRA). But Bush, if he takes office, will owe his election to the big backers of the Republican Party who desperately wanted power at any cost. The oil magnates will want their return, as will the NRA. Those who reap the harvest of mass health insurance will expect a consideration, likewise the tobacco giants. The Christian coalition and its allies will take the narrow victory not as a signal for restraint, but as occasion to demand a reward for their priceless loyalty. Already, in Austin last week, the demeanour, the bullish retorts and combative mood of the Cabinet-in-waiting suggests that conciliation will soon pass its sell-by-date. The only recent election remotely comparable to this was John F. Kennedy's razor-edged victory over Richard Nixon in 1960, after which Nixon made a point of not wanting to 'put America through the pain' of a contested result and recount. Some moderates in Al Gore's Nashville camp, and the op-ed barons of the East Coast media, who loathe any sign of combat over what the revered Founding Fathers might have meant by democracy in America, are urging Gore to behave and concede defeat. But we have seen many sides to polyhedron Gore of late, and it has been a blend of two which has proved most effective (indeed, if left un-spun by his team, it might have won him the election): his tough-guy Sopranos act and his 'voice-of-experience-and-respect-for-history' act. When he emerged to speak during Wednesday's crisis, he did so in deep, sombre tones about his respect for the sanctity of AmericaÍs democracy and its institutions, including the Electoral College. Then, behind the scenes, Gore rolled his sleeves up and, with Daley, donned his gloves to face his foe. Additional reporting by Ed Helmore in New York

fields.headline: In the eye of the storm
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText:
In West Palm Beach, Peter Preston finds that the thrill of being at the heart of the race is giving way to anxiety over its shambolic conduct


  In West Palm Beach, Peter Preston finds that the thrill of being at the heart of the race is giving way to anxiety over its shambolic conduct


  In West Palm Beach, Peter Preston finds that the thrill of being at the heart of the race is giving way to anxiety over its shambolic conduct
fields.body:
Here in West Palm Beach is global crisis centre, otherwise known as the Palm Beach Judiciary Facility, a shining legal temple in beige and brown marble somewhat larger than the Palace of Westminster.

This is Veterans Day weekend. The facility is closed for three days. Never let the end of the world get in the way of a statutory holiday. Down the road, the veterans of wars past are preparing for their annual stiff-backed, pot-bellied march, led this year by General Alexander Haig, who never got enough votes to become President himself.

Even further down the road, at Democratic Party headquarters, a squad of lawyers are taking affidavits from a chattering queue of the old, infirm and blue-rinsed. Across at the City Hall car park, dozens of TV vans with dishes pointed to the sky stand ready to flash the news as it happens.

But, apart from six rota protesters on interview duty by the car park, there is no news. The news, like George W. Bush and Al Gore, will have to wait; at least until Tuesday, when a circuit judge hears the first case about befuddled balloting, and probably rather longer.

Some people are working. The same groaning gang which brought the first count and the recount are counting again, this time a random sample of one per cent of the ballot forms plus a hand count from the three most contentious precincts.

They, like other Florida counties staging a re-recount, will report by Tuesday (though Broward, just to the south, has been treading water because the supervisor of elections went on holiday on Thursday and didn't leave a telephone number).

Carl Hiassen, the barbed chronicler of Florida absurdity, couldn't have invented a script like this. What is West Palm Beach? The dowdier partner, across the bay, of Glitz City. If the Palm Beach Post hadn't had the future of the White House to write about, it would have been stuck with 'Boy unhurt after riding bike into car's path' or possibly Jupiter town council's efforts to confer 'historic status' on the Burt Reynolds Dinner Theatre which, at 21, is more threatened and slightly less historic than Burt's toupee.

The big TV boys, down from Atlanta or New York, can stage their town meetings, full of earnest confrontations, but essentially this is a sleepy little hollow of a place, a stretch of communities, Lake Worth, Boynton Beach, Delray Beach, Boca Raton, where nothing much is intended to happen because there are guards on the condominium gates and the sweltering sun drains energy away.

'They're making us look like fools,' says Dave at the drug store counter. He's talking about the Lenos and Lettermans of the late, jokey television shows. Leno: 'Who's counting the vote down there? Don King.' Letterman: 'This is what happens when elections aren't fixed. They're this close.'

Too many sketches about doddery OAPs holding the nation to ransom. Palm Beach County doesn't altogether like the heat. It quite enjoyed the first couple of days when Clematis Street and Banyan Boulevard were full of camera teams eager for every last soundbite, but now the thrill, like Wall Street, is subsiding.

Something was clearly wrong last Tuesday. Pat Buchanan, the candidate of right-wing oblivion, got 3,407 votes, far more than anywhere else in Florida. That was strange, especially when most of his votes came from Jewish and black precincts.

Equally mystifying, some 19,120 votes, about four per cent, were ruled invalid because the antiquated election machines had punched a vote for two candidates, not one. How could that be? Delray Beach residents wave copies of their 'butterfly', or two-sided, voting slips, which are indeed pretty confusing, ranging the Buchanan punch hole just below Bush and just above Gore. Some mistake here, surely?

The blue rinses outside Democratic HQ echo Ovadia Rechtman, who is 77 and legally blind. 'I punched the wrong one and it worries me to death,' she says. The interviewees in the car park all say they punched the right hole, for Gore, but speak about the difficulties on the night: 'These machines are 50 years old. You have the card and it doesn't fit exactly. It wasn't easy: it was damned difficult.'

Enter Jesse Jackson, leading a TV rally on the steps of the judicial facility. Enter the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, beginning, yesterday in Miami, to collect more horror stories from other Florida counties (of which there are plenty). You don't need to believe there was rigging here: you would find it difficult to believe something wasn't seriously wrong with a machine that produced nearly 20,000 dud votes in Palm Beach and 18,000 in Miami's Dade County, but only 54 in Citrus County, where they put crosses on a piece of paper.

Part of the problem with the punching is that sometimes it doesn't make a proper hole, the 'chad' (the piece of paper that has been punched) hangs loose and the counting mechanism discards it. That's the point for the manual recounts, trying to assess what the voter intended.

Sometimes humans are full of error. When Bush's narrow lead over Gore dropped in the first recount from more than 1,000 to 327, part of the gain for the Vice-President was because a computer operator had simply pushed the wrong button.

Florida's 25 electoral college votes, and the presidency, seem to hang on lousy machines that there's no cash or will to replace, butterfly forms which may, or may not, contravene state law, voting systems designed to repel rather than encourage voters from the minority communities, plus a fat slice of human fallibility.

The protesting few outside Palm Beach court house have 'Banana republic' scrawled on their placards. And that, in a malign way, is the real difficulty for Florida today. There's no doubt what the great and good of Washington and the New York Times would have it do. Stop making difficulties: stop giving the Gore camp, and the legions of Democratic lawyers descending on the state, the legal opportunity to keep dragging out 'the proces'. It is not only the election supervisor in Broward County who's due a holiday: the TV anchormen and pundits want one, too. Florida is being muscled to conform.

But Florida has a mind and an identity of its own. Miami is Little Havana where English is an alien language and the shop signs offer 'Dinero. Al instante'. Miami is Little Haiti, where nearly 200,000 exiles from the Duvalier dictators and their dubious heirs cluster in Caribbean hovels and a guy in red bathing trunks walks through the streets with a seven-foot python wound round his neck.

Miami is art deco hotels and yuppies thronging the cafes on Ocean Drive, and Brazilian quarters and Argentine restaurants and the poor blacks who live in fly-blown suburbs like Opa-Locka, queueing to find a cot in the dank gloom of Tucker's Rooming House. We are not, in short, talking about the view from Seventh Avenue or Georgetown. Jeb Bush, Florida's governor, is George's younger, more personable, brighter brother.

When you take opinion on the streets of Miami, the cynicism is corroding. 'It's just so shady. It makes me sick, says one man. 'What's he [Jeb Bush] going to do? Not now, but before all this. He's got his men. What are they doing on election day?' he asks. 'Am I surprised? How could that be?'

There's a sense in which Florida has become a mirror of America. Split, down the middle. The big city, Miami, dominated by Democrats, whether poor blacks and immigrants or the moneyed young who came out on the day for Gore. Condominiums crawl up the Atlantic seaboard filled with winter-fleeing New Yorkers in their retirement.

Go higher, though, and Jacksonville is more of a real city filled with more real Florida people. It went Republican, like Tampa over on the Gulf of Mexico and the Panhandle out to Pensacola, which is Alabama and Georgia continued by other means.

The South, the East, the industries, the holidaymakers, the fruit farmers, the immigrants pouring in, the old folk sleeping in the sun: this is America. It is also a reason to be careful. Bill on the Palm Beach City Hall placard line has it pretty much right. A judge will sit on Tuesday: other judges will ponder that decision for as long as a case survives.

'But people in this country can pick the judges to suit the circumstances because they know where those judges are coming from,' says Bill. Of course. Gore fought a campaign which warned that Bush would pack the Supreme Court with anti-abortion judges.

Is Florida going to persevere with an interminable round of hearings which keeps the White House twisting in the wind? For all the sound and fury, the recounts will be over this week and the vital tallying of absentee ballots, maybe 3,000 or 4,000 of them, will end on Friday.

After that, it will either be lawyers in suits or, probably, a concession from Gore: and lawyers here are more despised, more feared for their cupidity and wiles, even than journalists. West Palm Beach and Delray and the rest aren't primed for that kind of struggle.

Thanksgiving is coming. The signs for 'Pumpkin Cream Whip Pie' are hanging out already. In the bars and cafes, you can already sense a kind of incredulity that this can be happening. 'Have I won my bet on the presidency, Freddie?' 'Gee, I didn't know it was over yet.'

Small (retired) town America won't fight this one through if Al Gore pulls out the legal eagles and pulps the affidavits. Only more genuine glitches in the counts, more significant chads, and maybe an absentee surprise, will keep America and Wall Street and the world (in no particular order) in limbo.

But a resolution is not an end. It will not convince the blue-rinse queues that Tuesday was fair. It will not convince the young activists on the placard line that justice has been done. In particular, it will leave the poor of Miami, the Cubans, the Guatemalans, the refugees from Haiti, believing that this America, the shining city on the hill for which they fled their flyblown countries, is just another Third World slum of slime.

Florida is the gateway state, one step from the continent to its south, and sometimes less than a step. It will succumb in the end as Washington (and political reality) calls the shots. But it will not, I think, go happily. It knows in its heart that Palm Beach County was a shambles, and it knows of too many other shambles all around. But arenÕt there shambles everywhere, ask anxious Republicans. Sure, but not as public, not as visceral, as this one. President Bush, if it is he, may not have much of a national mandate. In Little Haiti and Opa-Locka and Delray Beach, make that no mandate at all.

fields.body:
This is so perfect. This year"s US election campaign began with Al Gore shamelessly pandering to Florida, weighing in against his own administration (and, perhaps, the law) to suggest that the Cuban boat-boy Elian Gonzalez receive special dispensation to stay in the US. It ended with both George W. Bush and Gore relentlessly pandering to Florida - concentrating so totally on the poll-proven, senior-citizen vote-getters of Medicare prescription drug benefits and Social Security "lockboxes" that the rest of us started to wonder when the real campaign might begin.

Now, as proof that comic payback exists, even if karmic payback doesn"t, these candidates spent countless anxious hours last week waiting for their place in the history books to be determined by some possibly rotten precincts in Florida.

The Sunshine State was deemed to be crucial early on for the same reason that it"s heart-attack serious now: 25 electoral votes, enough to put either man over the top, as it turns out. (Of course, had Gore won his home state of Tennessee his wife Tipper would be picking out White House china patterns right now, and nobody would care about Florida except Walt Disney.)

You probably already know more about the Electoral College than the majority of American citizens, but the short version is it"s a neat way to avoid having the mob choose the ruler. The mob chooses distinguished delegates who exercise their wisdom to pick a leader. That"s the way the system was designed, before political parties, before exit polls, before there was television, for God"s sake.

Even before the phantasmagorical ending - the election night that wouldn"t end, the serial network embarrassments, the concession phone call that was hastily withdrawn (Gore telling Bush: "You don"t have to be so snippy about it") - this was a goofy election campaign. The Vice-President"s moment of greatest popularity, for example, came at the Democratic convention, when he planted a seven-second kiss on Tipper"s lips on his way to deliver his acceptance speech. That"s when people thought he was being real.

Gore"s peak campaign moment, in other words, occurred when he had his mouth shut. Bush"s finest hour of the campaign was probably when he brazenly insisted that, by not having revealed his drink-driving conviction, he had been forthright about his past.

Both candidates routinely avoided what we might quaintly call serious journalists, opting instead to campaign on the David Letterman, Jay Leno and Oprah Winfrey shows. The toughest questioning they faced all campaign was when Larry King asked them who they thought would win the baseball World Series.

Clearly, they both relied on polls that reported the public"s disgust with the news media. There was no price to be paid for each candidate to feast on a steady diet of softballs.

Ralph Nader was not tipped to be the third-party spoiler as the year began. That role was assigned to right-winger Pat Buchanan, who staged a bloody bar fight on the floor of the Reform Party convention to wrest the nomination away from John Hegelin, who believes the world"s problems can be cured by Transcendental Meditation (Hungry? Just say "Ommm").

The prize in that fight was $12 million in federal government campaign funding - the same prize Nader vainly sought in this campaign - and we still don"t know how Buchanan managed to misspend that money so thoroughly that he garnered only the mistaken votes of some confused Florida retirees. Perhaps he gave $2,000 to each Mexican immigrant he could find with instructions to "Go home, Jose". Federal money hasn"t been this profoundly wasted since the Pentagon used to order $600 toilet seats.

The conventional wisdom was more than usually wrong this year. It was widely assumed Gore would destroy Bush during the debates, that the tongue-tied Texas governor was afraid of tangling with the master debater. In the event, Gore"s performances in the three encounters were woeful and Bush passed the minimal standard set for him by the punditocracy: he managed to seem vaguely plausible.

George W. wasn"t even supposed to be his family"s chosen vehicle of revenge for the defeat of Bush pere in 1992. His younger brother Jeb, the clan"s straight arrow, was being groomed for the task, but his first run for governor was rejected by - here they are again - the voters of Florida.

And, for downright wrongitude, you can"t beat the widely peddled poll-derived proposition, the mantra of the primary season, that what American voters really craved this year was "authenticity". What we ended up with, just to remind our late tuner-inners, was a Democrat who changed wardrobe and personality every week, and a Republican whose twofold approach to issues was cramming followed by a nap. So, of course, the margin is razor-thin. When offered a dining choice between two varieties of vaguely grey luncheon meat, a population would be crazy not to split right down the middle.

What"s supremely edifying is that, after all the poll-pushed lurching to the centre and conflict avoidance, the campaigns are now, in the epilogue, taking off the gloves and going at it with all the vituperation and vitriol they really feel for each other.

What"s also nice to know is the dirty little secret of American politics: you can re-count any race in any district and come out with different numbers. Politicians and mediacrats here have been filling the endless cable news hours with repetitions of the bromide that what this close election proves is that every vote counts. They neglect to say it doesn"t count every time. Finally, since the candidates spent so much of their time vying for the title of entertainer-in-chief, a show-business verdict is in order. We, in the politically attentive public, spent almost a year being stupefied by a breathtakingly bad presidential campaign. Now that the race ends up in a wonderfully chaotic period where nobody in presumed authority knows anything, we"re finally getting a decent show. We earned this.

Harry Shearer is the voice of Charles Montgomery Burns in "The Simpsons". He is also the voice of Waylon Smithers, Ned Flanders, Principal Skinner, Kent Brockman and Lenny (to name just a few). When not being a Simpson, he has enjoyed a long career as a comic actor and writer, including stints writing for "Saturday Night Live" and the part of bassist Derek Smalls in "This Is Spinal Tap".

webTitle: And now it all comes down to the few...

fields.headline: And now it all comes down to the few...
fields.standfirst:
Their ballots are not yet in but the presumed loyalties of US Jews and the military cannot be taken for granted, reports Virginia Quirke in Jerusalem

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Their ballots are not yet in but the presumed loyalties of US Jews and the military cannot be taken for granted.
fields.body:
For a change, it was her husband who got up first that morning. She decided to stay in bed - unable to bear the excitement. Last Wednesday, Debra Inbar's husband rose early to catch the news, eager to learn who would be the next President of the world's most powerful nation. When his wife heard how the voting was progressing she was dumbfounded. 'I suddenly came to realise that my one modest vote could, in fact, be a key decision maker,' says 42-year-old Inbar.

An American Jew with Israeli citizenship, Inbar has lived in the northern coastal town of Haifa for more than 20 years. She was born in New York, but raised in Florida. West Palm Beach is where she calls home. Inbar is proud to think that her vital ballot paper, along with the hundreds of others at the Florida elections office, might determine whether Florida - and the Presidency - goes to Al Gore or George W. Bush.

She had no doubts about her choice. 'I was really excited about Joe Lieberman when I heard he was Gore's running mate,' says Inbar, an executive secretary in a hi-tech company. 'Israel has had a good relationship with the Clinton administration,' she claims, and she voted for Gore in order to continue that. Strong Jewish connections link Florida, where Inbar's mother lives, and the state of Israel. Those family members who left America in search of the Promised Land can still nominate whom they want to run their country.

Officials estimate that there could be between 100,000 and 200,000 Americans in Israel, including children. Some live here on a permanent basis, some temporarily. Political activists in America attempt to root out every potential US voter in Israel, while party supporters on the ground try to register them and coerce each citizen into completing an absentee ballot. Between 120 and 200 US citizens with Florida voting rights live in Israel, and Democratic Party activists believe the vast majority of those voting by absentee ballots chose Gore.

Eliyahu Weinstein, a Republican spin doctor living in Israel, figures on a different number of potential voters. 'I estimate there are about 2,000 American voters here from Florida, but I have only registered 1,000 of them,' he says. 'Unfortunately, the last man that I gave a register form to posted it too late. That, I'm afraid, is a victory for Al Gore,' he sighs. In Florida, officials allow 10 days to receive and count overseas votes and a large portion of them come from military personnel who are stationed abroad. 'Voting overseas can sometimes be a complicated matter,' says David Froehlich, a political activist for the Democrats abroad. According to Inbar, the absentee ballot she received one morning was very confusing. In fact, she received two. 'The first envelope I opened had a yellow form in it,' she says. 'And although it was rather unclear, I filled it out as I saw fit and mailed it off.'

She gave what she thought was an identical envelope to her young child who promptly tore it to shreds. Picking up the tattered pieces of paper, she was shocked to discover the second form was a different colour. 'It was bright pink and marked 'For special attention', she shrieks, 'I did not know what to do. I had already mailed the first yellow ballot. If I sent off the second ballot, my vote would have been annulled, right?'

Miles away, in a different time zone, things were not so crystal clear either. According to Inbar, the large elderly community who live at West Palm Beach, including people like her mother, complained that the ballot was not particularly user-friendly. 'You never know! People could have made mistakes or they could have been too embarrassed to ask for explanations,' Inbar points out. 'I myself didn't know who to call when I received two different colour ballots. I felt foolish.'

So as the agitation and confusion grows over voting irregularities, the US voters in Israel can only sit around sipping iced coffees and cringeing at America's electoral system, which has been near fatally wounded in this circus of a campaign. But it is not only Americans in Israel who will make up the equation that seems likely to settle a presidency. Several thousand ballots are expected from overseas absentees, who include a large concentration of military personnel and businesspeople. They must have their ballots postmarked by 7 November and received for counting by 17 November.

Yesterday the absentee vote looked to be plunged into the controversy over electoral inconsistencies in the Florida vote when servicemen based in Britain claimed they had received duplicate ballot papers. Military voters have historically favoured Florida Republicans and in 1996 gave Republican nominee Bob Dole 54 per cent of their vote, compared with the 43 per cent he received statewide. Republican officials cited these trends when they predicted that Bush would take most of the overseas absentee ballots. Yet Democratic campaign officials and some other analysts noted some other facts that could make the outcome less certain.

Florida has a heavy concentration of military personnel and installations, including seven major navy and five large air force bases. But Florida is also frequently chosen as a legal residence by military personnel who live in other states, because it lacks a state income tax. The US Air Force includes 5,200 personnel from Florida assigned in Europe and an additional 4,300 in the Pacific. Despite the suggestion that many of these may vote Republican some analysts believe the troops may be more sympathetic to Democrats than it appears. They note that the military has a disproportionately large number of minority members, who lean Democratic. About 37 per cent of the active-duty force is non-white.

According to the LA Times, Charles Moskos, a Northwestern University sociologist who specialises in military studies, surveyed army enlisted personnel in September who were deployed in Kosovo. He found that 32 per cent described themselves as liberal, 44 per cent as 'middle of the road' and 24 per cent as conservative. Indeed one US airman from Florida at the Ramstein Air Base in Berlin - quoted in the LA Times - said that, among the airforce personnel he knew, the split was 'about 50-50.' 'The older guys are more Bush; the younger guys are more Gore,' said airman Cedric Clark.

webTitle: Sex in America after Bill

fields.headline: Sex in America after Bill
fields.standfirst:
Gore won "waitress Moms" with his stand on education and abortion. The new President must address a third, equally tough issue

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Gore won "waitress Moms" with his stand on education and abortion. The new President must address a third, equally tough issue.
fields.body:
In 1992, it was new and rather sexy. By 1996, it was a concept no politician could afford to overlook. Now, in the US at least, it's almost too obvious to mention - the gender gap.

The voting patterns of American women are different from the voting patterns of American men. According to the latest figures, 54 per cent of women voted for Al Gore last week, against only 42 per cent of men. If men alone had voted, Gore would not have won in 16 of the 20 states he carried. George W. Bush would have won the national popular vote hands down - and taken Florida with a 53 per cent lead.

Of course, there's more to the gender gap than meets the eye. For example, while it is true that Bill Clinton has women voters to thank for his time in office, it's African-American women voters he should be thanking most. Race still matters. As does religion, and education and annual income. When you look at the voting patterns of white suburbanites, married mothers, and "mainline Protestants', the gender gap is so narrow it almost ceases to exist.

Last Tuesday, for example, exit polls found that white women were almost evenly split between the two main candidates. There is no shortage of high-powered, outspoken women in the upper echelons of the Republican Party. Women make up 65 per cent of the activists in the party. So to speak about "the issues that women most care about' is not necessarily to brandish a left of centre agenda. But to a large degree, the gender gap is still something Democrats worry about more than Republicans.

It is unlikely that a Republican-dominated Washington would be a hub of gender activism over the next four years. Where does that leave women and the issues they care most about? In the left-of-centre Washington Non Governmental Organisation world, the consensus is that the situation is worrying, but not hopeless. The greatest immediate concern is the Supreme Court. There are no vacancies there at present but the various women's caucuses and lobbying organisations have already announced a plan to work together to keep Bush, if he gets in, from filling the Supreme Court and the back benches of the judiciary with "ideological dinosaurs'.

They've also just initiated a Women's Appointment Network that will aim to put pressure on the next President to increase the number of women political appointees. They're not merely targeting the top jobs: they also want to see more women Under Secretaries, general counsels and policy analysts.

However, only certain kinds of women need apply. The Wan group has made it clear that it will only be lobbying for women who are pro-choice. And here we come to the issue at the very heart of the gender gap: abortion. A large number of American women still identify themselves as pro-life, and the Republican Party is officially anti-abortion. But there is also broad pro-choice support inside the party, which is why Bush went out of his way to avoid the issue during his campaign.

The abortion issue is seen to be the single most important issue leading women to vote Democrat more than men do. And it's more than simply a moral stance: one of the first things the new President will have to do is make a decision about the abortion drug, RU486. It has just been passed by Clinton's Food and Drug Administration. But it will be up to the new President to either reconfirm the licence or veto it. The educated guess is that Bush will opt for a veto - if not willingly, then under pressure from his right wing.

There is also concern that he will appoint an "unsympathetic' Attorney General, who will put women and the employees of abortion clinics at risk by failing to provide them with a "buffer zone'. If the new administration does too little to protect women and their reproductive rights, Democrat Party fundraiser Shanti Fry expects abortion to grow in importance as a women"s issue.

Right now, though, the primary issue for women voters in both parties is education. Fry believes that the fall in education standards has been a "subterranean concern' for decades, but, until very recently, it was (largely because of the way in which schools are funded) viewed as a local issue. Now (partly because Bush has taken it up in a big way) it's suddenly become a national disgrace. According to Evelyn Murphy, former Lieutenant General of Massachusetts, the catalyst was the internet.

Once parents in less privileged situations had versed themselves in the mantras of the information revolution, they became increasingly aware that their children were being left behind, and why. Bush's taking up of the issue could be seen as his way of pandering to the gender gap, for it is mothers more than fathers who have expressed concern.

There are other issues that women are more statistically likely to care about, which Bush will be unable to touch. His dependence on money from the tobacco and pharmaceutical industries and the gun lobby will keep him from taking firm action on gun control, smoking, or the high cost of healthcare. But, according to Murphy, the issue that may replace abortion as the single most important gender issue come the next election is something far larger, and far more difficult to address. This is the "women-and-work" question. It's just about to peak, Murphy says, because the US has just reached the stage when just about every adult woman who can work, does work. But not for pin money.

Increasingly they and their families depend on their salaries for sustenance, and their frustration at the pay inequities is growing just as fast. White women earn on average 74 cents for every male dollar. African-American women earn 64 cents and Latinas 54. While little was said on the issue during the election, there is, says Murphy, a growing militancy among women, an increasing number of whom have been taking their employers to court. This has led in turn to an upturn in union interest, and a nervousness in many companies that unfair wage structures might make them "vulnerable'.

So the groundwork has already been done. All that's needed is a politician to swoop in and take all the credit. In Murphy's view, Gore was seeking to do just this at the end of the campaign, when he began to many pointed comments about wage discrimination. She believes that it was this more than anything that gained him such strong support from working women. While the overall gender gap in this election was 10 or 11 per cent, analysts are putting the gap for working women at 18 or 19 per cent.

If the new administration does nothing to address their concerns, things can only get worse. But one day, a charming prince will arrive to work their disaffection to his advantage. In 2004, perhaps?

Bush's taking up of the issue could be seen as his way of pandering to the gender gap, for it is mothers more than fathers who have expressed concern. There are other issues that women are more statistically likely to care about, which Bush will be unable to touch. His dependence on money from the tobacco and pharmaceutical industries and the gun lobby will keep him from taking firm action on gun control, smoking, or the high cost of healthcare. But, according to Murphy, the issue that may replace abortion as the single most important gender issue come the next election is something far larger, and far more difficult to address. This is the "women-and-work" question. It's just about to peak, Murphy says, because the US has just reached the stage when just about every adult woman who can work, does work. But not for pin money. Increasingly they and their families depend on their salaries for sustenance, and their frustration at the pay inequities is growing just as fast. White women earn on average 74 cents for every male dollar. African-American women earn 64 cents and Latinas 54. While little was said on the issue during the election, there is, says Murphy, a growing militancy among women, an increasing number of whom have been taking their employers to court. This has led in turn to an upturn in union interest, and a nervousness in many companies that unfair wage structures might make them "vulnerable'. So the groundwork has already been done. All that's needed is a politician to swoop in and take all the credit. In Murphy's view, Gore was seeking to do just this at the end of the campaign, when he began to many pointed comments about wage discrimination. She believes that it was this more than anything that gained him such strong support from working women. While the overall gender gap in this election was 10 or 11 per cent, analysts are putting the gap for working women at 18 or 19 per cent. webTitle: Cut Why Britain holds its breath

fields.headline: Cut Why Britain holds its breath
fields.standfirst:
It's an open secret that Tony Blair would rather be congratulating Gore than Bush, says Andrew Rawnsley

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: It's an open secret that Tony Blair would rather be congratulating Gore than Bush.
fields.body:
At breakfast time on Wednesday, Tony Blair prepared himself to make the call congratulating George W. Bush on his election as American President. The words to be used, expressing the hope that the relationship between Downing Street and White House would remain as special and as strong as always, had been worked on in advance.

The telephone number which would connect No 10 to Austin, Blair to Bush, was ready to dial. This was not a call that Blair wanted to make. Though careful not to express any public preference between the candidates, it has never been a secret that he would much prefer to see the Oval Office occupied by Al Gore, fellow traveller of the Third Way, than Bush, a man whom Blair has never met.

Precisely because of that, it was felt that there should be no suggestion of grudgingness towards the Republican by Britain's Government. By eight on Wednesday morning, Jacques Chirac, the French President, had already tendered his congratulations to the Governor of Texas, and Robin Cook had telegraphed felicitations via the Today programme. Gore himself had phoned Dubya to concede defeat. Blair was about to address himself to the distasteful task - 'it was quite close,' says one No 10 official - when the American TV networks reported that the White House might not, after all, fall into the hands of the Republican.

The Prime Minister did not lift the phone and a brief exhalation of relief could be heard around Downing Street. The identity of the next President of the United States matters to few countries more than Britain, and to few people more than the British Prime Minister.

Politicians over here have gnawed their nails to the quick over the extraordinary cliffhanger over there as if their own futures were at stake. At the election night shindig thrown by the US ambassador in London, Tory and New Labour MPs, sustaining themselves into the small hours on bottles of Bud and hot dogs, gathered around a TV set in the basement "smoke-filled" room. When the US networks first gave Florida - and with it, apparently, the election - to Gore, the Labourites wearing his campaign buttons cheered for the Democrat. A Tory MP, poring over a sheet of numbers, despaired to another Conservative that it was "all over" for their candidate.

When the networks then moved Florida back into the too-close-to-call column, the Tories were wreathed in smiles, while the Labourites fell glum.

America has long mesmerised the British political class, and never more so than today. New Labour looted many of the techniques, replicated much of the rhetoric and borrowed large numbers of ideas from the Clinton-Gore New Democrats. There is a transatlantic taste to many of the Government's policies from the New Deal to the use of tax credits: a disability credit has just been added this past week to the credits for pensioners and working families. William Hague, attempting reverse engineering, has tried to rebuild the Tories with body parts donated by the Republicans. From 'free' schools to a new-found interest in the inner cities, many Tory policies are a pretty shameless attempt to ape the so-called 'Compassionate Conservatism' of George W. Bush.

Hague is even endeavouring to model his personal approach on Dubya. The Tory leader's conference speech this October contained many riffs which were rip-offs from Bush's speech to the Republican convention. For the down-home boy from Texas read the down-home boy from Yorkshire. To jump from such a tight election in America to conclusions about Britain is evidently dangerous. That will not stop British politicians doing exactly that.

If the Republicans wind up in control of not just Congress, but the White House too, a hat-trick they have not achieved in nearly 50 years, then it will be highly suggestive to the British political class that the tide of ideas has turned back in favour of the Right. At its lowest, it will be a psychological setback for New Labour and a morale booster for the Tories.

The Reagan-Thatcher revolution of the Right which dominated the Eighties was brought to an end by the victories of Bill Clinton there in 1992 and Tony Blair over here in 1997. What the progressive forces in Washington and London have not yet had time to do is establish a period in power of similar depth and longevity. It will look less like an era, and more like a brief interruption of right-wing rule, if the Democrats lose the White House. One of the Prime Minister's closest advisers, speaking to me from Washington, expressed the combination of anger and distress common among Blairites. 'No one can be sure, but you've got to think that Bush is going to be President. It's deeply shocking. It's a stolen election.'

New Labourites blame Gore for not exploiting America's sustained period of prosperity. 'Somehow the Democrats gave away the economy as an issue,' comments one senior figure at No 10. 'All the American campaign was really about was who you would rather have a drink with and what would you spend the surplus on: tax cuts or more public spending. We won't make that mistake.'

The choice of America's chief executive will have profound implications for British foreign policy. A Bush America will be, if not isolationist, certainly more unilateralist. The Foreign Office is trying to reassure itself that, under the tutelage of General Colin Powell and old man Bush, Bush Junior will not be the disaster that some British diplomats fear. This desperation to sound calm betrays some inner panic. A Bush America will be even more reluctant to pay its dues to the United Nations.

Condoleeza Rice, Dubya's foreign policy guru, has made noises about withdrawing American troops from peace-keeping in the Balkans. In the long term, a Bush Presidency could usefully goad Europe to take proper responsibility for its own backyard. In the short term, American disengagement is alarming, not least to the British. Bush's determination to press ahead with an anti-missile umbrella for the United States, an enthusiasm not shared by Gore, would present the Government with a choice that it would prefer not to make. Providing British facilities for the system will be inflammatory within the Labour Party and set Britain against many of its European partners.

Blair likes to portray Britain - and himself - as 'the bridge' across the Atlantic. Bridging a social democratic Europe and a Republican American would stretch even this Prime Minister's legendary suppleness to the limit. As the world waits for the identity of the next US President, few are monitoring developments more anxiously than Blair. When he is finally in a position to make that congratulatory call, the Prime Minister clings to the hope that he might yet be dialling Al Gore while fearing that next time he really will have to pick up the phone to George W. Bush.

webTitle: International: US election

fields.headline: After four lean years, wait for Hillary
fields.standfirst:
America"s most celebrated political commentator and historian spies one long-term winner from the fiasco
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: In a country of a quarter of a billion people, 19,120 invalidated ballots in Palm Beach County, Florida, may decide who shall be the next global emperor, sovereign de facto if not de jure (not to mention by default) of the planet"s six billion biped humanoids, sometimes known as souls.  To begin with the county in question.
fields.body:
In a country of a quarter of a billion people, 19,120 invalidated ballots in Palm Beach County, Florida, may decide who shall be the next global emperor, sovereign de facto if not de jure (not to mention by default) of the planet"s six billion biped humanoids, sometimes known as souls. To begin with the county in question.

Palm Beach is a synonym for Old Money, a winter base for the patriciate for over a hundred years. Here President Kennedy"s father bought a house when he began his ascent of the social ladder, and here his numerous descendants have had all sorts of exciting adventures.

The film director Preston Sturges called one of his finest comedies The Palm Beach Story (1942). Palm Beach. Wealth. Beauty. White silken beaches. Yes. But Palm Beach County contains a great many people who are not in the least bit rich.

There is some poverty but most of the county tends to be middle class - retired Jews from the North-east and black descendants of slaves freed 135 years ago. It is their county that now rivets the world"s attention.

Although television, by its very nature, is not conducive to reflection, it can, through sheer numbing repetition, impress images on the mind. We have seen the elderly white gentleman with glossy black dyed hair and his young lady lawyer, prepared to sue the county for giving out ballots that did not clearly list the names of the candidates.

One waited half a day for this couple to reappear but no one, apparently, was in the mood to bring any part of our electoral process into court. The courts, said the New York Times with its usual understatement, are not eager to set foot in even the tiniest vestibule of that vast Augean stable known as the American electoral system.

The principals have kept their profiles high but ambiguous. Bush had nearly formed a government, to hear him tell it, when this unwelcome turbulence made a soft January landing in the electoral college moot. Gore has been a stickler for law and order, particularly law. One suspects that he is now contemplating a long judicial process with equanimity.

Much is at stake. Patronage. Thousands of jobs for the deserving. Mount Rushmore at the end. Why not?

Several omniscient newspapers have predicted that in the interest of national unity - always more desirable than disunity - even though Gore wins the popular vote he will abide, as indeed he must, by the electoral college, an institution bequeathed us by the founders so that we would never have a democracy - their deepest fear - or a dictator, a lesser fear as Lincoln and the second Roosevelt demonstrated.

But the machinery of the Republic did indeed strip a gear last Tuesday. Who benefits? First, we must forget about the people. They have long since been factored out of those elections provided for us by generous corporations, elections that will cost this year between two and three billion dollars. Elections without issues; without clearly differentiated candidates.

What is left? Well, above all there is the one per cent that owns the country and governs through the prosperous 20 per cent that keeps the not so prosperous 80 per cent reasonably subdued. Outside the boardrooms (where the power is) are the ambitious politicians. Bush believes he must avenge his father"s defeat at the hands of Clinton.

The Clintons themselves are in the most curious position of all. He is President until January. She is a new senator, with an eye on the White House. Allegedly, there is bad blood between the Gores and the Clintons.

If so, it is clearly in the Clintons" interest for Gore to be defeated, thus allowing the inept Bush four years as President under the firm guidance of the former Pentagon chief, Dick Cheney, pledged to governing in the name of corporate America.

Four years of Cheney will trigger a resurgence of nostalgia for the Clintons and thus make it possible for her to move to the White House in 2004 with her husband as campaign manager and - why not? - Vice President.

Eight years of them, with the right one, Hillary, as number one, could usher in, at last, a golden age. On the other hand, as Hollywood has never learnt from bitter experience, remakes of hit movies often go very wrong. The Palm Beach Story 2 could be a dog.

Meanwhile, it should be noted that in many states the balloting machinery is something over half a century old, as are once state-of-the-art electric chairs. Question: Can so old-fashioned a people, so wedded to the old ways, be persuaded to modernise? Quien sabe? as we say in California. Gore Vidal"s latest book, The Golden Age is published by Little, Brown.
