webTitle: Bush goes to court as US poll fears grow

fields.headline: Bush goes to court as US poll fears grow
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: George W. Bush launched a legal battle yesterday to prevent the manual recount of votes in Florida, amid growing Republican fears that he could lose the battle raging over the deadlocked presidential election.
fields.byline: Peter Preston in Miami  and Ed Vulliamy in Austin
fields.body:
George W. Bush launched a legal battle yesterday to prevent the manual recount of votes in Florida, amid growing Republican fears that he could lose the battle raging over the deadlocked presidential election.

James Baker, Bush's elder statesman in Tallahassee, announced that the Republi cans would now be seeking an 'emergency judge' - a Federal judge in chambers - to grant an injunction stopping the recounts. Republican lawyers will argue that the recounts are a 'public mischief'.

The Florida vote, at present won by Bush after a recount by a majority of only 327 votes, will decide the outcome of the razor-edge election. Baker insisted a manual recount would be more sus ceptible to error than a machine tally.

'Machines are neither Republicans nor Democrats and therefore can be neither consciously nor unconsciously biased,' he said.

Speaking yesterday at his ranch near Crawford, Texas, Bush was weary but sombre, fielding questions about his decision to litigate and passing on the response to Baker.

He admitted it was 'a strange time', and that 'we are all in limbo' - but insisted: 'There is a very good chance that Dick Cheney and I will be President and Vice President. We have got to be prepared'. Mr Cheney, however, added that appointments to any cabinet-in-waiting would be put on hold.

Earlier, calling for some 'finality' to the process which has frozen American politics for five days, Baker issued the veiled threat: 'We can't just sit on our hands - we will be forced to do what might be in our personal interest.'

He is widely taken to mean that Republicans could mount challenges to desperately narrow results in New Mexico, Oregon, Iowa and Wisconsin, where Gore is the assumed winner in at least three states, thus throwing the country into more weeks of chaos. But Democ rats here believe this is bluster, aimed at blocking the manual recounts now scheduled or under way in four key Florida counties.

The Bush team's move to seek injunctions against the hand counts means they are quitting the high ground of 'honouring the people's verdict' for the lower ground of courtroom wrangling in a complex game of propaganda manoeuvrings. So far, American public opinion seems relatively calm - only a third of voters are 'angry' about the situation in a CNN/ Time poll - but that mood will change if the affair drags on beyond this week, with heavy penalties for the side seen as responsible.

Gore has been under pressure from a few Democrats - including Bill Bradley, the man he beat for the nomination - not to indulge in legal warfare, but the prize of emerging as the good guy who won the ballot will help silence his critics for a time.

Yesterday President Clinton weighed in with a radio call for time and patience. 'The important thing for all of us to remember now is that a process for resolving the discrepancies and challenges to the election is in motion. The rest of us need to be patient and wait for the results.'

The battle for the White House became the battle of the 'hanging chad' in Florida yesterday. The chad is the tiny rectangle of paper punched out of the ballots by voters using the 50-year-old voting mechanisms in many Florida counties. If it leaves a clean hole the tabulating machinery registers a vote. If isn't fully detached and merely hangs in the slot, then the ballot may automatically be declared invalid. With Bush's lead over Gore in Florida now reckoned at a mere 327 votes, every change to the total matters.

The Democrats are running two arguments simultaneously. One is that the possibly illegal design of the ballot form in Palm Beach County confused over 20,000 voters, some of whom voted for the maverick right-winger Pat Buchanan rather than Gore and some of whom voted accidentally for two candidates, making their ballots invalid. But resorting to hand counts - of a sampling of all the votes in the county and of every vote in three heavily Democratic precincts - has a deeper purpose.

Hand counts are more accurate than machine counts and allow the tellers to examine the semi-detached chads and weight of indentations to interpret the voter's intention. Since Palm Beach voted heavily for Gore last Tuesday, it is a clear statistical calculation that more votes rescued from the invalid stack will be Democratic than Republican.

Meanwhile, three other counties here, including the giant Broward and Dade counties, are preparing their own hand counts tomorrow. Volusia county, which does not punch cards, also began to recount 196,000 ballots yesterday. All four recounting counties have a Democrat majority on the local election supervisory boards.

The gamble is that these hand recounts will produce a complete switch in the Florida total by the end of the week, making Gore the victor in both the national popular vote and the state-by-state Electoral College vote.

There are two vital dates this week. One is Tuesday, when Florida authorities are due to certify the election result - but that may prove impossible because as many as 7,000 absentee ballots remain to be counted on Friday, 10 days after the election.

Nor is there any sign that the manual recount battle on the ground won't turn tit-for-tat. It is reported from Jacksonville that 22,000 ballots were declared invalid, and Jacksonville is a Republican city. What's sauce for Palm Beach Democrats may yet be sauce for Jacksonville Republicans.

Volusia county, which does not punch cards, also began to recount 196,000 ballots yesterday. All four recounting counties have a Democrat majority on the local election supervisory boards. The gamble is that these hand recounts will produce a complete switch in the Florida total by the end of the week, making Gore the victor in both the national popular vote and the state-by-state Electoral College vote. There are two vital dates this week. One is Tuesday, when Florida authorities are due to certify the election result - but that may prove impossible because as many as 7,000 absentee ballots remain to be counted on Friday, 10 days after the election. It is reported from Jacksonville that 22,000 ballots were declared invalid, and Jacksonville is a Republican city. What's sauce for Palm Beach Democrats may yet be sauce for Jacksonville Republicans.

fields.headline: The economy
fields.standfirst:
The great US success has been built on hi-tech stocks and an unsustainable consumer boom. Now, just when the country need s a strong President, it will not have one, says Will Hutton
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Americans may have been equally divided on their presidential choice, but on one proposition they were united. The Great American Economic Success Story must continue. But this is precisely what may be impossible to deliver.
fields.body:
Americans may have been equally divided on their presidential choice, but on one proposition they were united. The Great American Economic Success Story must continue. But this is precisely what may be impossible to deliver.

Indeed the story of the next four years is much more likely to be one of failure, even of calamity. The US economic success has feet of clay. There may have been five years of 4 per cent growth, a pick-up in productivity, record lows in unemployment and above all the impact of the new economy.

But this has much less to do with native entrepreneurial zeal, go-getting capitalism, hire-and-fire labour markets and the wonders of technology than the propaganda from US cheerleaders and British eurosceptics would have us believe.

This is tribute to a consumer boom built on record credit, creating a monumental trade deficit that cannot be financed for ever. The projections that the government will generate a cumulative trillion dollar surplus over the next 10 years assume this impossible economic conjunction will last, so allowing George W. Bush to finance his proposed tax cuts.

In effect the Republicans plan to give away an illusory surplus, adding another twist to the coming debacle. The impact of IT and the new economy is still likely to be immense.

The high priests of IT - Bill Gates, Steve Jobs and others - have made fortunes the scale of which has not been seen since the beginning of the past century and which, like the railway and banking fortunes of the Rockefellers and Morgans, are a sign of their economic importance. The IT sector has been a hot spot of growth and productivity.

But the expectations riding on its impact may be a cause of the future economic turbulence. The level of share prices could be justified only if America grows like an Asian tiger for more than a decade, a prospect difficult to achieve.

When the bubble in hi-tech shares collapses to more normal levels, that alone could be a source of recession, because so much of the prosperity of the IT sector depends on high prices for hi-tech shares.

Because it is a bubble spun from a wider economic bubble, the implosion could spell worse, with not even the skills of Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan able to stop the process.

The riddle of the US economy is less its success than why it has wound up in such a precarious position. This is a continental economy that allows its producers enormous economies of scale.

Its workforce belongs to an individualistic culture in which the overwhelming majority recognise the importance of flexibility and mobility. Moreover, there is a ready supply of cheap immigrant labour to keep wage levels down.

Capitalism in the US is raw. Companies are ruthless in their quest for profitability. Wall Street and company boards have made common cause, with directors being given options to buy their own shares cheaply to benefit directly from a higher share price.

The value of share options is now close to a trillion dollars, up more than fifteenfold in a decade - one of the greatest wealth transfers in world history. Small wonder corporate giving to the Republicans and Democrats alike has reached such astronomic levels: nothing must rock this gravy train.

Yet the inequality this system has generated is increasingly dysfunctional, and also one proximate cause of its weakness. It has, as Professor Robert Frank details in his subtle and important book, Luxury Fever, been an important driver of almost baroque levels of personal spending that have taken the economy to the limits.

The first-round effect of this concentration of spending power at the top - the US now has more than three million millionaires - is that the rich spend increasingly on luxury items, splurging on everything from their ever-larger houses to their oversized, overpowered cars.

These become the benchmark for the middle class; for example, the average new American house now occupies 2,200 square feet compared with 1,500 square feet in 1970 as the middle class trades up to meet the new standards of opulence.

But, because hawkish companies are constraining wage growth, the scale of the spending can be financed only by debt. The stock of household debt now equals household income; the net annual flow of credit to consumers is a trillion dollars a year.

In the first three months of this year, US consumers not only did not save, they spent 7 per cent more than they earned by using their credit cards and borrowing capacity to the limit. The balance sheets of average middle-class Americans don't look too bad because the value of their investments in Wall Street has exploded, not to mention the rise in house prices, making them confident enough to sustain their borrowing.

Americans used to hold about a quarter of their savings in Wall Street; now it has risen to nearly three-quarters. As long as share and house prices keep on rising, the edifice works - but if there were a setback, consumers would be exposed. As they retrench their spending to try to reduce their debt, the consumption that has supported the economy would stop.

As consumers spend, so the US has sucked in imports on an epic scale. This year the US trade deficit will top $400 billion; next year, if the oil price stays around $30 a barrel, it could top $500bn.

Americans can square the financial circle without the dollar collapsing only because foreigners are prepared to invest in the US on an equally epic scale, spending more than $100bn a year buying US companies and more than $150bn a year buying US shares and bonds.

But that inflow is no less dependent on the expectation that the good times will continue to roll, and in any case is about to be dwarfed by the size of the deficit. If foreigners fear share prices might fall, the dollar will fall sharply.

At a get-together of central bankers in Jackson Hole this year the consensus was that a 30 per cent drop would be needed substantially to correct the trade deficit. As markets always overshoot, expect the dollar to fall further.

US interest rates will have to rise, but that will prick the stock market boom, with disastrous consequences.

Michael Mantel, the economics editor of Business Week who predicted the buoyant impact the new economy would have on stock prices, has just released his new book, The Coming Internet Depression.

He argues that just as the internet boom has rested on $100bn a year of venture capital finance launching start-ups because the companies could be floated on the crazy hopes of the stock market, now the process is set to go into reverse.

The New York Times reports 44 out of 274 newly floated dotcoms have gone bust this year; that would be a flood if Wall Street fell back. But the new economy feeds on itself, with dotcoms being a crucial market for each other, so each bust dotcom makes trading more difficult for those that are left.

New start-ups will cease; investment will fall back and the surge in productivity be arrested. The correct response is to cut interest rates to support the markets - but that is impossible given the size of the trade deficit and the impending collapse of the dollar. If the Republicans insist on tax cuts, built on assumptions of economic buoyancy that the markets will recognise are illusory, the loss of confidence will be complete.

As Americans watch prosperity slip away, the cry to protect America from imports will become almost unstoppable. America and the world needed a clear-sighted President who could tell it as it is and ride the political consequences without ill-judged interventions or giving in to America's worst instincts. That is precisely what we lack. It is a dangerous moment - perhaps more dangerous than we know.

webTitle: First Family's Next Steps

fields.headline: First Family's Next Steps
fields.standfirst:
Chelsea may go into medicine, Bill has a library to build, and Hillary has a new job - but could she be tempted to run for the White House next time, asks Edward Helmore

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: As the presidential election collapsed into chaos, Hillary Clinton claimed her senate seat last Tuesday night in New York looking less like a hard-bitten political fighter and more like a delighted wife and mother. Flanked by her husband and daughter, the family's mantle of extraordinary power slipped away and they appeared, if only for a moment, like any family buoyed by sudden good news; Bill Clinton, beaming with pride and biting his lip as if to hold back tears, clasped the hand of Chelsea Clinton, herself alight with emotion.
fields.body:
As the presidential election collapsed into chaos, Hillary Clinton claimed her senate seat last Tuesday night in New York looking less like a hard-bitten political fighter and more like a delighted wife and mother. Flanked by her husband and daughter, the family's mantle of extraordinary power slipped away and they appeared, if only for a moment, like any family buoyed by sudden good news; Bill Clinton, beaming with pride and biting his lip as if to hold back tears, clasped the hand of Chelsea Clinton, herself alight with emotion.

In taking centre stage, Mrs Clinton gave a victory address that at once catapulted her out of her husband's shadow where she has been for 26 years, first as an attorney general's wife in a small southern state, then as the governor's wife, and then for the past eight years as First Lady. No First Lady had ever run for elected office, much less in a newly adopted state, and emerged as her own woman in the world's most financially and culturally influential city.

Her win marks the end of one chapter and the beginning of another. At her victory celebration, friends said they could barely fathom the events of the past few years ending up this way. "Weird doesn't even begin to describe this,' said Clinton family lawyer David Kendall, who was the first to inform her that her husband had admitted his affair with White House intern Monica Lewinsky.

"The word is vindication,' said the Rev Donald Jones, Mrs Clinton's pastor in Park Ridge, Illinois, where she grew up. "I think the right wing conspired to knock down both Bill and Hillary, and now she gets to stand on her own two feet.'

On 3 January, when Bill steps down and his wife is sworn in, the transition of power, both personal and political, will be complete. "Put the politics down for a minute,' wrote NY Daily News columnist Jim Dwyer. "Hillary Rodham Clinton is 53 years old, her daughter is grown, her husband soon to be out of a job, and it turns out that F. Scott Fitzgerald had it wrong after all: There are second acts in American life.'

To Republicans, New York Senator Clinton is more than just a blow. Bill Clinton, like most former presidents, may fade in the background but his opponents must now learn to live with the reality of a new political torchbearer. More liberal than her husband, and just as ambitious, Mrs Clinton will keep the family name and the political style it spawned - Clintonism - in the public arena for years to come.

Worse still for the legions of Clinton haters, they face the prospect that she will some day run for President herself, an ambition she denied she held last week - at least until her six-year term runs out. "It's like any new job; you have to find your footing," she said of her new elected office. "You have to work hard to learn the ropes and the rules." Still, with a Gore defeat, Hillary would immediately emerge as the Democrats" brightest shining star and a potential walk-in for the 2004 party nomination.

But the structures of the next stage in the expansion of Bill and Hillary's family business are still hard to predict. "It'll be a role reversal between her and Bill,' predicts former adviser-turned-Clinton baiter Dick Morris. "He'll run her campaigns and life just as she ran his. She becomes his major project.'

On Tuesday, there was little evidence of the froideur that is often said to exist between the two: although she did not include him in her victory photo, she took her husband's hand as they left the stage. At a party later, co-hosted by the publisher Tina Brown, the President told his guests how proud he was of his wife, who leaned into him, nuzzling his neck as he stroked her green trouser-suited back. In her speech, she effusively thanked her husband, quelling speculation that the family would stay so only in name. "I would not have been standing there without the support and work of my husband," she said.

"It's not so much of a power struggle as a partnership. They are no different from any other couple except they share an interest in power,' says Joe Conason, columnist for the New York Observer. "He's the typical errant husband and she's the typical wife who hopes he'll change his ways. He's changed. She loves him. He loves her and doesn't want to lose her, and they're not going to get divorced.'

For two highly effective, highly intelligent people, the evidence of their affection lies in Chelsea who, by all accounts, has emerged from adolescence as a charming woman with no stated interest in following her parents into politics. But Dick Morris maintains: "President Clinton is going to stay with Hillary as her manager and consultant; that does not mean they are actively going to stay married." But for all the attention accorded to Bill and Hillary, it is bizarrely 20-year-old Chelsea who is the emergent star of the family. Just five years ago, when she visited the Taj Mahal with her mother, she was a shy 15-year-old struggling with her celebrity and kept firmly off limits to the press. Having taken a year off from Stanford, she's been travelling everywhere with her mother, appearing poised and confident, and sometimes introducing her at rallies.

Friends of the family say Chelsea is the Clintons" common interest and her father is noticeably buoyed when she is around. Friends say she's still leaning toward a career in paediatric medicine but has also expressed through her campaigning, if not directly, an interest in the family business. Asked what he would do if she said she was thinking of going into politics, Clinton has said he would encourage her.

But he would ask her three questions first: if she was prepared to lose, if she had some higher purpose in wanting to hold office, and "do you really want to pay the price to win, to really work hard and to take the lows? And if Chelsea can answer all three of those questions yes, then I would encourage her.'

And now that Hillary has won her job - one that may turn out to be less fun and productive than anticipated - the question remains: what kind of life will the Clintons carve for themselves in the naked city? Some observers believe the couple do not wish to stay in Chappaqua, the small dormitory town where they bought a house last year as a campaign launching pad. During the long campaign, she has been using Steven Spielberg's apartment and friends have reportedly been hunting for an apartment overlooking Central Park on their behalf. Others believe they will simply bypass the city and find a new home in Washington. Bill Clinton has said he plans to spend time in Arkansas, overseeing the construction of his presidential library in Little Rock.

There is no doubt that the Clintons are enamoured of the fluidity and glamour of Manhattan life. The city, fat on Wall Street profits, has experienced a resurgence in recent years and lower Manhattan has become, in effect, Europe in America. According to Newsweek, the traffic of people as well as money, ideas and culture between New York and London has created a new entity - the inelegantly named NY-LON, "a single city inconveniently separated by an ocean'. For the internationally minded Clintons New York offers the perfect nexus of opportunity and influence in a liberal city.

Taken under the wing of Miramax chief Harvey Weinstein and Lazard Freres's Steve Rattner, the couple have found themselves feted by Wall Street billionaires, media moguls, actors and actresses and celebrities of every description. In Florida a Weinstein-organised court of stars including Glenn Close, Robert De Niro, Ben Affleck, Jon Bon Jovi and Stevie Wonder was assembled to flank the President as he campaigned for Gore. Many of those same stars turned out for the Clintons for an election night party organised by Weinstein, Brown and financial news service chief Michael Bloomberg.

It was a signal, if any were needed, that the Clintons hold keys to at least the most conspicuously glitzy part of the city's life. "They like being in the spotlight and they like the artists, the entertainment and Wall Street people, those who are interested in issues but not necessarily politics,' says Conason. But, he says, there are many different levels of New York society, not all of them welcoming. "The old waspy society of the Upper East Side doesn't like them and that socialite stratum is probably not interesting to them either.'

Still, as much as Hillary and Bill appreciate the company of the media meritocracy, many doubt they are entirely at ease in that milieu. "They'll be in huge demand but she's so deadly serious, earnest and calculating - in the best possible way - that she's not going to get a reputation dining with the glitzocracy,' says veteran British publisher and writer Harold Evans.

"She certainly gets on with film stars but she's not into small talk, the price of property, who"s up and who"s down.' Evans doubts that establishing a library or playing golf or going to jazz clubs in Greenwich Village will be enough to keep the ex-President busy, especially as his wife is going to be spending most of her time in Washington. For a man who thrives on interaction with people, the aftermath of the first election in 20 years in which he has not campaigned for himself and won will be strange. "His great passion is the growing interdependence of the world. I think he'll find a position on some foreign affairs council, give speeches on Wall Street.' In an interview with Evans in Talk magazine, Clinton said that his years as President had made him more idealistic than when he was first elected. "The trick for a former President is to trade in all the power for influence and impact over a smaller number of things that are profoundly important, and do it in a way that does not get underfoot of the next President.'

As many have pointed out, Hillary Clinton has remained an essentially aloof and distant figure, carefully allying herself with her husband's achievements and side-stepping his failures. She may have won her own electoral identity through the long, tough New York campaign but the question remains what exactly it is she has won.

As junior senator from New York in a Republican-leaning Senate, she will chair no sub-committees and be unable to hire more than a bare-bones staff. Although she has said she wants to serve on the committees on foreign relations and appropriations [giving her a chance to funnel federal dollars to New York] Republicans will do their best to stall her efforts. She will climb aboard a shuttle flight to Washington every week to do the drudge work of a senator, attending hearings, grinning through photo opportunities, standing patiently at the back of press conferences, waiting to speak.

She will sit among senators who eagerly sought her husband's impeachment and she will instantly become the nation's best-known Democrat if Gore ultimately loses to Bush. "There's no way the First Lady is going to be just another freshman. She's going to be a magnet for media attention,' says political scholar Stephen Hess.

That may not only create difficulties with more senior Democrats, particularly Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, but attract the Republicans' bitter attentions. After eight, divisive years in the White House that is not new, but as an elected official she now stands to take the heat directly. "She may well replace Ted Kennedy as the poster child for Republican fundraising,' says former Reagan chief of staff Ken Duberstein.

Mrs Clinton now has her own elected platform from which to respond to criticism and has quashed accusations of being a carpetbagger. According to polls, half the voters said her lack of New York roots was of little or no consequence. In her victory speech, she was careful to emphasise how well versed she has become in local issues in thanking by name upstate party officials. As her first order of business she pledged to work to improve the economy of upstate New York, a region that has largely missed out on the national economic boom.

What is certain is that Al and Tipper Gore, President and First Lady or not, will not be welcome. Gore's exclusion of his boss from his election campaign deeply hurt Clinton and it's no secret that Hillary and Tipper have hardly spoken since she took such a judgmental line on Clinton's reckless dalliance, mumbling that Monica was younger than her own daughter. There are few people who do not believe Hillary Clinton's New York adventure is anything less than a prelude to her own White House run, if not in 2004 then in 2008. "Of course she'll run,' said Senator Daniel Moynihan, the man whose senate seat she assumed - at least temporarily.

Bill Clinton has said he plans to spend time in Arkansas, overseeing the construction of his presidential library in Little Rock. There is no doubt that the Clintons are enamoured of the fluidity and glamour of Manhattan life. The city, fat on Wall Street profits, has experienced a resurgence in recent years and lower Manhattan has become, in effect, Europe in America. According to Newsweek, the traffic of people as well as money, ideas and culture between New York and London has created a new entity - the inelegantly named NY-LON, "a single city inconveniently separated by an ocean'. For the internationally minded Clintons New York offers the perfect nexus of opportunity and influence in a liberal city. Taken under the wing of Miramax chief Harvey Weinstein and Lazard Freres's Steve Rattner, the couple have found themselves feted by Wall Street billionaires, media moguls, actors and actresses and celebrities of every description. In Florida a Weinstein-organised court of stars including Glenn Close, Robert De Niro, Ben Affleck, Jon Bon Jovi and Stevie Wonder was assembled to flank the President as he campaigned for Gore. Many of those same stars turned out for the Clintons for an election night party organised by Weinstein, Brown and financial news service chief Michael Bloomberg. It was a signal, if any were needed, that the Clintons hold keys to at least the most conspicuously glitzy part of the city's life. "They like being in the spotlight and they like the artists, the entertainment and Wall Street people, those who are interested in issues but not necessarily politics,' says Conason. But, he says, there are many different levels of New York society, not all of them welcoming. "The old waspy society of the Upper East Side doesn't like them and that socialite stratum is probably not interesting to them either.' Still, as much as Hillary and Bill appreciate the company of the media meritocracy, many doubt they are entirely at ease in that milieu. "They'll be in huge demand but she's so deadly serious, earnest and calculating - in the best possible way - that she's not going to get a reputation dining with the glitzocracy,' says veteran British publisher and writer Harold Evans. "She certainly gets on with film stars but she's not into small talk, the price of property, who"s up and who"s down.' Evans doubts that establishing a library or playing golf or going to jazz clubs in Greenwich Village will be enough to keep the ex-President busy, especially as his wife is going to be spending most of her time in Washington. For a man who thrives on interaction with people, the aftermath of the first election in 20 years in which he has not campaigned for himself and won will be strange. "His great passion is the growing interdependence of the world. I think he'll find a position on some foreign affairs council, give speeches on Wall Street.' In an interview with Evans in Talk magazine, Clinton said that his years as President had made him more idealistic than when he was first elected. "The trick for a former President is to trade in all the power for influence and impact over a smaller number of things that are profoundly important, and do it in a way that does not get underfoot of the next President.' As many have pointed out, Hillary Clinton has remained an essentially aloof and distant figure, carefully allying herself with her husband's achievements and side-stepping his failures. She may have won her own electoral identity through the long, tough New York campaign but the question remains what exactly it is she has won. As junior senator from New York in a Republican-leaning Senate, she will chair no sub-committees and be unable to hire more than a bare-bones staff. Although she has said she wants to serve on the committees on foreign relations and appropriations [giving her a chance to funnel federal dollars to New York] Republicans will do their best to stall her efforts. She will climb aboard a shuttle flight to Washington every week to do the drudge work of a senator, attending hearings, grinning through photo opportunities, standing patiently at the back of press conferences, waiting to speak. She will sit among senators who eagerly sought her husband's impeachment and she will instantly become the nation's best-known Democrat if Gore ultimately loses to Bush. "There's no way the First Lady is going to be just another freshman. She's going to be a magnet for media attention,' says political scholar Stephen Hess. That may not only create difficulties with more senior Democrats, particularly Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, but attract the Republicans' bitter attentions. After eight, divisive years in the White House that is not new, but as an elected official she now stands to take the heat directly. "She may well replace Ted Kennedy as the poster child for Republican fundraising,' says former Reagan chief of staff Ken Duberstein. Mrs Clinton now has her own elected platform from which to respond to criticism and has quashed accusations of being a carpetbagger. According to polls, half the voters said her lack of New York roots was of little or no consequence. In her victory speech, she was careful to emphasise how well versed she has become in local issues in thanking by name upstate party officials. As her first order of business she pledged to work to improve the economy of upstate New York, a region that has largely missed out on the national economic boom. What is certain is that Al and Tipper Gore, President and First Lady or not, will not be welcome. Gore's exclusion of his boss from his election campaign deeply hurt Clinton and it's no secret that Hillary and Tipper have hardly spoken since she took such a judgmental line on Clinton's reckless dalliance, mumbling that Monica was younger than her own daughter. There are few people who do not believe Hillary Clinton's New York adventure is anything less than a prelude to her own White House run, if not in 2004 then in 2008. "Of course she'll run,' said Senator Daniel Moynihan, the man whose senate seat she assumed - at least temporarily.

webTitle: Voters wanted the man who wasn't on the ticket

fields.headline: Voters wanted the man who wasn't on the ticket
fields.standfirst:
Clinton minus sleaze was the ideal candidate. But instead, the nation split the difference

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Clinton minus sleaze was the ideal candidate. But instead, the nation split the difference.
fields.body:
You would be wrong to conclude from the bizarre election of 2000 that America is sharply divided between two powerful ideologies tending in opposite directions - Republican conservativism, which celebrates individualism and worships the market, and Democratic liberalism, which extols social solidarity and reveres government.

The real meaning of this election is that most Americans are quite satisfied with the status quo, and like the direction in which the country is headed. What they dislike are the lies and scandals that marred Washington in recent years. So they cast their votes in 2000 for Bill Clinton without the sleaze, and for Congress without the nastiness. The prosperity of the Clinton years would have easily swept Al Gore into the presidency but for Gore"s odd tendency to bend the truth, which reminded Americans of Bill Clinton"s lies about Monica.

Americans were also attracted to George W. Bush"s schoolboy charm, which reminded them of Clinton's engaging personality. On the other hand, they wanted someone as bright and experienced as Clinton and didn't believe Bush was up to the job, which led them back to Gore. In short, Americans who voted last Tuesday wanted someone who embodied Clinton's formidable positives without his equally formidable negatives.

Since no such person was on the ballot, they split the difference, and came out smack in the middle. For much the same reason - because Americans approve of the overall direction Washington in which is taking them but hate the capital's nastiness - they allowed Republicans to retain formal control over both houses of Congress. But they gave Democrats enough additional seats in the House and the Senate to defang the Republican Right, a fitting punishment for the Republicans' partisan excesses since they took over control of Congress in 1994.

The narrow difference guarantees that neither party will have enough votes to accomplish much of anything on its own. So who will be in charge of the most powerful nation on Earth come January? Neither the newly-elected President (whomever that may be) nor congressional Republicans or Democrats. The new centre of power in Washington will lie with the moderates in both parties - liberal-leaning Republicans and conservative-leaning Democrats who together will be the only ones capable of setting Washington's agenda.

A President will occupy the Oval Office, but he will be dependent on the approval of congressional moderates for almost anything he'd like to accomplish. Forget Bush's proposal to use much of the government's projected budget surplus for a large tax cut. The congressional moderates will whittle it down. Similarly downsized will be Gore's proposals for an expensive new prescription-drug scheme for people who have retired and for a new government-subsidised savings plan on top of social security.

In fact, you can safely forget most of what the presidential candidates proposed during their interminable campaigns. None of it matters any longer. In the end, the moderates will likely cut the budget surplus into three approximately equal slices - one intended for a modest tax cut, the second dedicated to small spending increases for prescription drugs and healthcare, and the third to reduce the nation's debt. This isn't the result either Bush or Gore campaigned for, but it's a balance most Americans will be content with. Foreign policy will be guided by the same moderate coalition in Congress. This means America will continue to use its military muscle with great reluctance but will feel no qualms about using its economic muscle unilaterally when the nation"s economic interests are at stake.

The White House and Congress will continue to back free trade, while imposing duties on specific imports that undercut the prices of domestic producers. The Treasury (carefully overseen by Congress) will continue to tell the International Monetary Fund what to do. There will be scant support for foreign aid or debt relief for poor nations.

Meanwhile, the power to determine the pace of economic growth and the level of employment will shift entirely to the Federal Reserve Board. Years ago the economy's speed was regulated by two levers - one fiscal, run largely by the White House, and the other monetary, run by the Federal Reserve. But fiscal policy all but vanished with the Clinton administration's resolve to reduce the nation's deficit.

The government that takes control in January won't even remember where the fiscal lever can be found. Thus will Alan Greenspan, the Fed's powerful chairman, be in complete charge of the nation's economy, and indirectly of the global economy. Power to resolve any particularly controversial public issue will shift largely to the federal courts.

The weakened political branches will be neither willing nor able to deal with touchy questions involving privacy, abortion, the rights of employees or people with disabilities, or affirmative action. Nor will Congress or the White House be capable of determining the new contours of property rights in patents, copyrights, and trademarks - hot issues in a new economy where ideas are often more valuable than physical assets.

It is worth noting, by the way, that any new nominee to the bench will need to be acceptable to the congressional moderates, who will block potential judges espousing extreme views about the Constitution. Most importantly, no large-scale initiative will emanate from the White House or Congress. No large vision will be advanced, calling upon the people to alter the way they conduct their lives or understand the world.

The President will not be able to summon the public's resolve for such things, and congressional moderates will lack the authority to do so. Hence, the looming financial problems of America's giant retirement programmes, Social Security and Medicare, will remain unaddressed. Global warming and related environmental hazards will receive scant attention. The national disgraces of child poverty, homelessness, and hunger will endure. And inequalities of income and wealth - both inside the United States and around the world - will likely grow wider.

For good or ill, this is the government that most Americans now want. Despite the tensions and uncertainties of this unusual election, there is no great ideological divide in America. Whoever emerges as President will be part of a government that reflects the values of the great majority of American voters. They, in effect, sought a third Clinton term, minus Bill Clinton, and that's what they will get. The wonder of American democracy is how well it works. But is this the government that America most needs? It is of course possible that the economy will stay the course, that Alan Greenspan will successfully extend the current expansion for several years to come, and that no international crisis will intrude directly into the lives of most Americans.

Yet a steady state cannot be guaranteed. And if this most fortunate era of relative prosperity and relative peace should come to an abrupt end, America may not be prepared to cope. Last week, this nation chose the status quo. But it may come to discover that it does not really have that option. Robert Reich, former US Secretary of Labour under President Clinton, is professor of social and economic policy at Brandeis University in Massachusetts. His next book, 'The Future of Success', will be published in January.

webTitle: Dirty rotten scoundrels

fields.headline: Dirty rotten scoundrels
fields.standfirst:
This poll has exposed America"s biggest political secret. Corruption is endemic in the land of the unfree
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Here are some reasons to be glad that Ralph Nader put himself forward for the presidency:
fields.body:
Here are some reasons to be glad that Ralph Nader put himself forward for the presidency:

1. He broke America"s dirtiest and least-known secret, which is that the high-sounding "Electoral College" system is designed to keep the rabble from picking the President.

2. He broke America"s second-dirtiest and best-known secret, which is that the voting process in many states - especially the state of Carl Hiassen - is tainted by corruption and manipulation.

3. He exposed the pretensions of the two major party machines, both of which covertly agree on these "rules" as long as they can share the spoils.

4. He showed it is still possible to run an intelligent and articulate campaign, using free and informal rather than paid media, while refusing any donation of more than $1,000 in a year when $3 billion, in so-called "soft" but actually illegal money, was raised and spent by the two presumptive and dynastic nominees.

5. He made a fool of the commercial media networks, all of which take the aforementioned money in advertising revenue and all of which not only misrepresented the issues in the race but messed up the one thing they are supposed to get "right" - the foreordained and poll-driven result.

These, and some other things I"ll mention in a moment, make Nader the most successful and necessary American radical for decades. Yet all you hear from Al Gore"s outriders and dummy-ventriloquists is that he "spoilt" things for their man.

This is a ridiculous noise, compounded of self-pity and a "spoilt" sense of entitlement. Here are some obvious correctives to it:

1. In a year when the Democrats campaigned against an unpopular Republican Congress, they failed to retake either the Senate or the House. (And, in the most salient seats they did hold or take, they relied on a dead man on the ballot and on a man who spent a record $60 million of his own personal fortune.)

The Green Party was not running for Congress. But if it had been, the Democrats would still have blamed Nader rather than themselves for the defeat.

2. Gore lost several key states (including his own home state of Tennessee where the Nader vote was negligible) by several other "margins". These include:

(a) The almost 100 million Americans he could not get to vote for him.

(b) The number of people who are disenfranchised because of non-violent narcotics convictions (estimated in Florida and elsewhere to number 13 per cent of the adult black male population, alone).

(c) The number of people who voted for Pat Buchanan"s ill-named Reform Party.

Gore could not motivate the first group. He loudly approves of the "War on Drugs" that incarcerates and then disenfranchises the second. And nobody - certainly no Republican - ever said Buchanan had no business running on his own programme.

It is only in liberal circles that one hears party pluralism denounced as something akin to treason or sabotage. The Veep"s hacks ignore all the above factors and blame the crisis on those voters who decided to think for themselves (to vote for Nader, for example, because he is the only candidate who favours decriminalising marijuana and abolishing capital punishment).

A few months ago there was a convention of American political scientists in my home town of Washington. They unveiled a new "model" of the American electoral mindset, and announced confidently that in a year like this the Vice President could not be beaten.

No Republican challenger, they said, could hope to prevail at a time of huge prosperity at home and peace overseas. I thought this might be too complacent, but not by that much. And still Gore managed to blow it, and to make himself vulnerable to one of the most mediocre candidates in US history.

He cannot whine about this; not after failing in Tennessee. Yet in the tones of his partisans one can hear an aggrieved intolerance. On election night at a party thrown by Miramax, some were overheard by the Washington Post to say they would like to "kill", not Bush or Buchanan, but Ralph Nader.

The newly anointed Senatorial First Lady, in whose honour the party was thrown, echoed the thought. I have heard the same thing, in the same words, all over the airwaves and on my email, from clapped-out liberal journos and those who hoped for a job from Gore. These types ornamented the top-dollar "fundraising" events and "meet"n"greet" soirees with Hollywood"s deep thinkers; their annoyance is music to my ears.

They thought they had bought a share in "the process" and found the share (and much of the process) was worthless. High time. Take one example. For eight years Gore abased himself for Clinton and uttered abject defences he knew to be untrue.

Then on two occasions in the campaign, he announced he was suddenly "distanced" from all that and had miraculously become "my own man". Well, it"s one thing to say it, big boy, and another thing to be it.

Exit polls, most notably in Florida, discovered a huge number of voters who were disgusted by Clinton and Clintonism. These people have a right to vote, too. And what does Gore tell them? "Didn"t you hear me? I distinctly said I was "distanced"." Come on.

This would not be the only time this terrible candidate mistook his own spin for reality. After the Los Angeles convention he abruptly announced he was a foe of fat cats and big corporations and a friend of the "people" and the little guy.

But the logos and the donations of corporate America were displayed all over the convention and paid for his campaign. Who did he imagine he was fooling? As with his excruciating performance in the three public "debates", it was enough to irritate the Republicans, but it was also enough to make people in the centre feel embarrassed and people on the left feel sick.

And after this, to pose as if it"s simply your turn to be President. The achievement of Nader, however, is far more than the exposure of this phoney politics. From now on two crucial matters will be established in the American mind.

First, the Electoral College system must be reformed or abolished to give expression to the popular vote. This will also compel a reconsideration of the small state/swing state tyranny, whereby small and rural states outvote large, populous, urban and multi-ethnic ones. That is several decades overdue.

Second, the issue of ballot-rigging and voter fraud, almost undiscussed since Kennedy"s crimes in 1960, is now unavoidable. The next election will have to be "transparent". Neither major party would have mentioned either of these things if the vote had fallen "their" way, or either of their ways.

Again, Nader was the only man running who dared say the process itself was undemocratic. Now US citizens can begin to catch up with Mexico and Serbia by insisting on an open election instead of a pre-arranged and money-driven plebiscite. While the Florida factor remains in play, let us recall two things the Gore ticket did to try to take this bizarre state.

Earlier this year the US courts ruled that young Elian Gonzalez, survivor of a shipwreck that drowned his mother, should be returned to his father"s custody in Cuba. Some Cuban exile extremists then in effect kidnapped him, and the mayor of Miami announced in a crowd-pleasing way he would not comply with the court order.

It was the most flagrant assertion of "states" rights" against the federal government since the days of segregation. Gore"s contribution, as a senior member of that federal government, was to announce he sympathised with the kidnappers.

This gross irresponsibility and pandering was repeated last month when Senator Joseph Lieberman paid a visit to Miami, announced that a Gore administration would never open diplomatic relations with Cuba, and laid a wreath on the grave of Jorge Mas Canosa, a leading Miami Cuban mobster.

This put him and the Vice President in a position well to the right of the last Bush administration. But more important, it showed they are small-timers, cheap ward-heelers and unscrupulous opportunists.

There was a remark much-repeated at the beginning of this dismal campaign, when it became evident the large donors had already determined on the two nominees. "If only," people said "they could both lose." This wry comment was heard through the attenuated primaries, the fixed conventions and the scripted "debates".

Well, now they both have lost. And they are both looking, and acting, like the peevish third-raters they are. Confronted by two such pygmies it would be overstating matters to call Nader a giant-slayer. But the system for all its faults does allow for insurgent candidates to make a difference and one should be grateful rather than irritable that, in this respect at least, the system worked.

 Christopher Hitchens is a columnist for "Vanity Fair" and "The Nation". His latest book, "No One Left to Lie To: The Values of the Worst Family" is published in paperback by Verso.

Second, the issue of ballot-rigging and voter fraud, almost undiscussed since Kennedy"s crimes in 1960, is now unavoidable. The next election will have to be "transparent". Neither major party would have mentioned either of these things if the vote had fallen "their" way, or either of their ways. Again, Nader was the only man running who dared say the process itself was undemocratic. Now US citizens can begin to catch up with Mexico and Serbia by insisting on an open election instead of a pre-arranged and money-driven plebiscite. While the Florida factor remains in play, let us recall two things the Gore ticket did to try to take this bizarre state. Earlier this year the US courts ruled that young Elian Gonzalez, survivor of a shipwreck that drowned his mother, should be returned to his father"s custody in Cuba. Some Cuban exile extremists then in effect kidnapped him, and the mayor of Miami announced in a crowd-pleasing way he would not comply with the court order. It was the most flagrant assertion of "states" rights" against the federal government since the days of segregation. Gore"s contribution, as a senior member of that federal government, was to announce he sympathised with the kidnappers. This gross irresponsibility and pandering was repeated last month when Senator Joseph Lieberman paid a visit to Miami, announced that a Gore administration would never open diplomatic relations with Cuba, and laid a wreath on the grave of Jorge Mas Canosa, a leading Miami Cuban mobster. This put him and the Vice President in a position well to the right of the last Bush administration. But more important, it showed they are small-timers, cheap ward-heelers and unscrupulous opportunists. There was a remark much-repeated at the beginning of this dismal campaign, when it became evident the large donors had already determined on the two nominees. "If only," people said "they could both lose." This wry comment was heard through the attenuated primaries, the fixed conventions and the scripted "debates". Well, now they both have lost. And they are both looking, and acting, like the peevish third-raters they are. Confronted by two such pygmies it would be overstating matters to call Nader a giant-slayer. But the system for all its faults does allow for insurgent candidates to make a difference and one should be grateful rather than irritable that, in this respect at least, the system worked.  Christopher Hitchens is a columnist for "Vanity Fair" and "The Nation". His latest book, "No One Left to Lie To: The Values of the Worst Family" is published in paperback by Verso.

webTitle: Leader: the US voting system must go

fields.headline: By all that is right, Gore is President
fields.standfirst:
But the US voting system must go

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: By the conventional canons of pluralist democracy, Al Gore should be the next President. He has won the popular vote but may be denied the office that is morally his due by the arcane mechanism of the Electoral College.
fields.body:
By the conventional canons of pluralist democracy, Al Gore should be the next President. He has won the popular vote but may be denied the office that is morally his due by the arcane mechanism of the Electoral College. Designed as a compromise between state and federal power, its workings in this case may have the quixotic result not of protecting minorities but of opening the White House to a man of startling illiberality, determined to advance the sectional interests which funded his campaign. In such circumstances, any rhetorical commitment to a united nation, or to the modesty of ambition proper to a President elected by a minority of the popular vote, may wear thin. Mr Bush's friends will want their pound of flesh.

Yet the Electoral College, for all that it may confuse foreigners and baffle Americans, is legitimised by the US Constitution. For better or for worse, this is the system under which all the candidates fought and its rules cannot be abandoned because, in so close a contest, they may produce an unjust or illogical outcome.

The election has not only produced a quixotic result - it has cast a bright light on the strange and unexpected incompetence of a nation whose economy is the most powerful in the world and which stands at the cutting edge of technology. Yet here we have a weird picture, in Florida and perhaps elsewhere, of electoral mismanagement flowing not so much from corruption or partiality, thought neither can be excluded, as from mechanical flaws. There are reports of people voting twice, and being disqualified because they punched the machine too hard; of people, probably older, who failed to vote at all because they could not muster enough muscle power. In such circumstances, the offers of international supervision from such nations as Russia, Zimbabwe and Cuba seem less absurd than they might.

What Gore must do now is to fight until the last reasonable option has been exhausted, until the integrity of the result has been validated beyond reasonable doubt. Until then he should resist the pressure to concede victory to Bush in the name of national unity, good government and constitutional order. The American constitution is robust enough to take more than a little turbulence and Gore is within his rights to test its rules as vigorously as he can. The precedent advanced by the Bush camp - that, in 1960, Nixon behaved like a patriotic gentleman by conceding to Kennedy - is spurious. Nixon abandoned any thought of a challenge not out of a sense of national duty, but because he was advised that he had insufficient grounds to overturn the result.

But eventually the law of diminishing returns will apply and continued resistance will seem not only stubborn but petty and troublesome. But if they have to accept defeat the Democrats need not do so meekly. They must keep up a rhetorical barrage against the Republican oligarchy which may imagine it has inherited the Earth. They must remind Bush, if he is finally elected, that he has no mandate for substantial change and certainly no mandate for extreme social and economic programmes designed to fatten the rich and exclude the poor.

Above all, a serious campaign must begin for the abolition of the Electoral College. A majority in Congress sufficient to amend the Constitution will obviously not be immediately possible. Yet the fact that reform will be difficult does not invalidate the effort. In such circumstances, the Democrats would speak with the powerful moral authority of losers who should have won.

That same constitution devolved the detailed arrangements for the Electoral College on to the individual states. One of the reasons so few people understand the rules of the college is that the means of choosing electors differ from state to state. Some of the electors are mandated; some are not. On occasions in the past, 'faithless' electors have departed from their slate, though never with a decisive result. There is only a faint chance that the electors of the year 2000, when they meet in Washington next month, will have the courage to depart from their scripts. At most, only a few will do so and Bush will enter the White House. Al Gore should have been elected the forty-third President of the United States. But if he loses the work of the Democrats, to campaign for reform and keep the administration in the centre, where the electorate has placed it, will be of the highest importance.

webTitle: Floods of tears, gales of laughter

fields.headline: Floods of tears, gales of laughter
fields.standfirst:
John Sweeney travels the high streets and back gardens of underwater England by canoe

Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: John Sweeney travels the high streets and back gardens of underwater England by canoe.
fields.body:
A dazzling white, long, snaky 'S' emerged through a hole in the fence between where the herbaceous border and the compost heap used to be - followed by the rest of the swan. Magically it circled the bird table, its bilious yellow beak level with the bread platform, and then came to a dead stop.

As idle as a painted swan upon a painted ocean.

A bottle of Chilean chardonnay bobbed towards The Observer's canoe on the swollen Thames. This is Maidenhead, after all, so you won't find Blue Nun in the flotsam.

A window opened. 'Do you realise you are trespassing?' said the lady of the house.

She was right, of course. Like the swan, we were paddling in her back garden. Enter, stage right, a man with a beard, all but swimming into view, water tipping over the top of his gumboots. It was turning into a bad drawing-room farce - Waterworld meets Noël Coward.

'This is Peter, he's come to do the lawn,' said the lady of the house.

She looked out to where the lawn should be and saw water, water, everywhere. Faced with the surreal otherness which has transformed the most familiar thing in the world - her back garden - into a playground for passing canoes, swans and bottles, she burst into giggles. It was, indeed, thumpingly surreal.

Not waving but wading, Britain last week was no longer a sceptred isle set in a silver sea, but an archipelago floating in an ocean of shi...well, suspiciously brown water. And yet laughter, not wailing, was the most common response to the Great Flood.

The lady of the house then emerged and made as if to dive into the water. Her name was Elaine Batt and she is the mother of Mike, creator of the Wombles. The floods have caused financial misery, mess, despair, upheaval, inconvenience across the country. Elaine was behind her deadline to sew an Aston Villa strip for Great Uncle Bulgaria, but a neighbour's son had volunteered to wade across and transport her sewing machine to her car, so that she could finish off the job elsewhere.

She supplied us with tea and biscuits. The swan gracefully floated in and out of people's back gardens, paying scant attention to property rights, as we paddled in its wake. A man in an upstairs bathroom goggled at the swan being pursued by our canoe, then went back to brushing his teeth, treating the ocean-going garden invasion force as the most natural thing in the world.

The Thames proper was not navigable, its brown flow going like an express train - or, rather, trains being what they are these days, not going like an express train - but much faster, at nine knots an hour. But a few back streets of Maidenhead - if such a term as 'back street' can be used in Berkshire - parallel to the river and upstream of the bridge were awash. A BMW lay bonnet-deep in the muddy brown scum, sleek and black like a half-sunk U-boat. The temptation to laugh was irresistible. Rich people make poor victims. Maidenhead is not exactly Mozambique.

The most arresting qualities of a flooded landscape are the enigma variations on the normal. The ordinary, even the boring, becomes remarkable when out of place. A stop sign just above the waves. A park bench, its legs sunken, its slat inches above the slop.

For the hell of it, we lifted a couple without gumboots, Peter and Linda Jary, on to a bench for a few snaps. The bench was almost underwater in the foreground; in the background the Thames zoomed by. Then a local BBC TV crew saw the 'picture' and wanted to film it. Meanwhile, the water level was rising and the Jarys were getting cold. Then ITN turned up to observe the BBC filming an Observer joke.

Downstream of the bridge, three journalists from news agencies were doorstepping the riverside homes of Michael Parkinson and Rolf Harris, presumably hoping for the bloated white corpse of Parky's chequebook or a drowned didgeridoo to float by. They were out of luck. Maidenhead's tragedy is that there were too many journalists and not enough disaster victims to interview.

Up north it was grim. Selby in Yorkshire is surrounded by an inland sea bigger than Lake Windermere. The floodwaters in the North Yorkshire town of Malton, on the banks of the Derwent, have risen so high that RNLI lifeboatmen were called out to save two Environmental Agency men whose Land-Rover got waterlogged.

From the deep end of the town's swimming pool you can see a raging torrent sweep by: not the riverbed, but what used to be the railway. A tractor carries townsfolk across the bloated Derwent to the other bank. As we clattered past the torpedoed Land-Rover, a woman who works in the local estate agent pointed out a 'For Sale' sign floating in the murk: 'That house was sold, but they hadn't exchanged contracts.' How much is it worth now? 'Nothing,' she said. Insurance pays up for ruined fridges, but not for ruined hopes. She pointed to a petrol station: 'There's oil out there too, and sewage. All sorts.' Her face wrinkled in disgust. In the floodwater swam little twists of toilet paper.

Seventeenth-century Yorkshiremen were not fools. They did not build their homes in areas which would be regularly flooded up to 2ft. So the neighbouring village of Old Malton, which dates that far back and beyond, is evidence of profound climate change as troubling as the computer projections that see the North Pole ice-pack reduced to an ink-blot by 2080. The village has been flooded twice in the last 18 months. Last week it looked like the Lost City of Atlantis.

Canoeing down the main street was surreal: a red phone-box sunk above the handle, a footpath sign pointing to an ocean of water. Every now and then villagers would flag down our canoe, the Lady Molly, and we would give people rides, to check their homes, to see relatives, to save their feet getting wet.

'There is one old lady in the village who is 87. She has lived here all her life and she remembers the 1947 flood. The last one, 18 months ago, was worse than that. And this is worse than that one,' said one of the Royal Oak regulars manning an inflatable.

For Tricia Burr, 22, the disaster was real enough. Her sofa lay on plastic beer crates, an inch above cold, mucky, brown water. The menace of the water was real, an ever-present danger.

And still the jokes came thick and fast. One sign in the village boasted: 'Spring water for sale, only slightly cloudy'. And on the pub itself: 'Still open, and we haven't watered the beer down'.

Paddling around to the back of the Royal Oak - motto: 'We never close' - we passed a house on which was hung a lifebuoy bearing the legend SS Titanic. Cruelly, the water level in the pub was deeper than the level outside, so the horrible stuff came over our gumboots. Regular Simon Harris looked at the water and said, deadpan: 'I've seen cloudier beer.'

In a sunken pub in a sunken village in a sunken countryside, we stood on bar stools, our heads banging against the low ceiling, gumboots full of water, sipped our pints and discussed the utter daftness of the American electorate.

webTitle: Maria Scott: If we want real independence we may have to pay for it

fields.headline: If we want real independence we may have to pay for it
fields.trailText: With fuel protesters and pensioners to appease it was not surprising that Gordon Brown excluded from his pre-Budget statement the decision to revolutionise the way financial advice is dispensed in the UK.
fields.body:
With fuel protesters and pensioners to appease it was not surprising that Gordon Brown excluded from his pre-Budget statement the decision to revolutionise the way financial advice is dispensed in the UK.

But the reforms, announced afterwards, are radical. They overturn a system put in place more than a decade ago with the introduction of the Financial Services Act. At that time financial advisers had to decide whether to trade as independent advisers or as the agents for one brand. Many organisations had traded as half-way houses, selling the products of a few companies, often those that paid hefty commissions.

'Polarisation', as the new system was known, aimed to improve the quality of advice; advisers would be selecting products from across the whole market, or selling only one company's pensions and savings plans.

From next year, we will begin to return to the old system. As early as the spring, banks, building societies and other organisations will be able to start marketing and advising on products from different insurers and investment houses. The products will, in general, be 'fail-safe' ones with limits on charges: mainly stakeholder pensions and 'Catmarked' individual savings accounts. Later, polarisation is to be fully dismantled.

The aim, says the Financial Services Authority, is to improve choice, although some believe the real motivation is to sell as many stakeholder pensions as possible through banks and building societies.

Some of the FSA's arguments for dismantling polarisation have merit. In theory it will be easier for consumers to make decisions because they'll have access to information about charges and commission. The Government has also put the boot into the financial services industry by limiting charges on stakeholder pensions and introducing benchmarking on Isas.

Polarisation has also been undermined by developments in the market. The growth of 'execution-only' business, where companies offer a variety of products, but no advice, has muddied the waters.

The good intentions of polarisation have also been thwarted by the commission system that dominates the selling of investment products in the UK. Commission leads to biased advice among independent advisers as well as 'tied' ones. Any regulator trying to control it will find that as soon as one hole is plugged, another appears.

The system now proposed need not be a disaster for consumers, but a new period of confusion looms. To make it effective, there need to be improvements to the way commission is disclosed to potential investors and the FSA is now looking at this. It also needs to consider how it might advertise the change to the public.

Sadly, the new system will undermine a decade of efforts to promote the principles of independent financial advice. Truly independent advice will still be available, but now that the term is to be undermined, the FSA should be looking at rules to ensure the term is confined to those who can demonstrate independence, depth of knowledge and competence. Ultimately it may have to be confined to those who shun commission in favour of fees.

webTitle: Diary of a nobody

fields.headline: Diary of a nobody
fields.trailText: One of the most stressful evenings of my life was spent in LA, hanging out with celebrities. Did I say 'hanging out'? I meant hanging on for dear life.
fields.body:
One of the most stressful evenings of my life was spent in LA, hanging out with celebrities. Did I say 'hanging out'? I meant hanging on for dear life. There was this motley bunch of rock stars, TV faces and minor-league movie stars, and then there was me and my friend. We'd been invited by another hanger-on to join them on a crawl around clubs, which sounded like fun, until you actually got there. Then it became like a real-life version of those photographs you see in OK! magazine, where there's a bunch of famous people, and a couple of sad 'nobodies' lurking around for no more useful reason than to make the club look slightly fuller.

If they do manage to get their picture into OK! , usually these non-celebrity interlopers suffer the indignity of having half their faces cut off. Which takes away even the slight thrill of having something to tell your grandchildren: 'Look, there's me, with half a face, being ignored by famous people.' Doesn't quite work, does it? But then, that seems to be the general deal with celebrity - the objective is to make the famous feel brilliant about themselves, not to enable ordinary mortals to feel anything as presumptuous as equal. Which certainly sums up our night in LA - my friend and I were forced to stand on the sidelines, barged, patronised and ignored. Meanwhile, the celebrities spent the evening falling on each other's necks, in the manner of cap-toothed vampires feasting on celebrity skin.

Tortuous though this experience was, it was also informative. If nothing else, my fondest prejudice was confirmed beyond all doubt - this being that celebrity is the third gender. A case of there being male, female, and then these strange, terrible creatures, like Jack Nicholson or Leonardo DiCaprio, Gwyneth Paltrow or Julia Roberts. While, every so often, one comes across a sane, agreeable famous person, there has to be some explanation for why the vast majority - from A-list right through to Z - are so crazy. Some are in denial, of course. Sting once said: 'I do what I do for free - I get paid for being famous.' And he is just one celebrity voice among many, those who claim that they'd much prefer to pursue their creative muse without the burden of fame. Very impressive, until you remember that there's plenty of people out there, doing just that - in celebrity circles, it's called being unsuccessful.

The truth is that famous people love being famous only slightly less than they love moaning about it. Actor Mark Wahlberg, formerly known as rapper Marky Mark, has had two shots at celebrity now, and he still can't seem to decide whether he likes it or not. He gave an interview last week, complaining that the hardest part of fame was not being able to meet some sweet young thing 'who's going to love me for me'. This is a constant lament from the famous - the way they tell it, they'd love to settle down with a waitress or a bus conductor, but they have to make do with romancing each other because they simply can't find that special 'normal person' who isn't over-awed by their celebrity. Poor things. But seriously, doesn't it seem a bit of a cheek for the famous to accuse ordinary people of being starstruck? After all, it stands to reason that the people most impressed by celebrity are celebrities themselves. Otherwise, why would they buy into it?

What most people don't seem to comprehend is that the noble art of 'star-fucking' cuts both ways. The traditional definition of an SF is a nobody who likes to hang out with celebrities, on a quasi or actively sexual level, and bask in the reflected glory. In reality, the term could just as easily be turned upside down and applied to those stars who like to hang out with nobodies to make themselves feel even more famous. In this context, ordinary people become like so much human wallpaper, whose only real use is to make the 'stars' shine brighter. The clever thing about all this is that by dismissing ordinary people as starstruck, the celebrity is successfully relieved of any responsibility for their happiness. Which must come in useful when you're in between starlets.

Stars are always moaning about how they are treated by ordinary people who 'kiss and tell', but you rarely get to hear how badly they are treating people. For, in truth, a lot of celebrities do have flings with ordinary people. What they don't generally do is have relationships with them, or treat them with any kind of respect. Why bother when you can pick them off for sport - the sexual equivalent of shooting fish in a Hollywood barrel - and save the serious lovey-dovey stuff for people who really understand you - like, say, other celebrities? Ultimately, it's not that 'ordinary people' are incapable of loving Marky Mark for who he is (in part, a homophobic ex-pants model), just that these finer feelings might be superfluous to requirements.

webTitle: Going with the flow

fields.headline: Going with the flow
fields.trailText: It's been such an Old Testament of a night meteorologically speaking that you'd think we'd be too busy offering thanks to the god of shallow-rooted trees for not tossing a big one through our bedroom window to start worrying about whether the postman's van has been sucked up by a typhoon with all my wife's birthday cards in it.
fields.body:
It's been such an Old Testament of a night meteorologically speaking that you'd think we'd be too busy offering thanks to the god of shallow-rooted trees for not tossing a big one through our bedroom window to start worrying about whether the postman's van has been sucked up by a typhoon with all my wife's birthday cards in it. Of course nobody expects bad weather on their special day so I cheer her up by pointing out that she can hardly complain, having just been presented with an unexpected day off work owing to the M11 having turned into Lake Tanganyika and all the trains being cancelled because of the wrong kind of garden furniture on the line, and that not to worry, she can start paying for her loss of earnings out of the handsome £25 cheque her parents have been sending her every year since 1979. Well, providing the postman can get his act together and stop being pathetic about a spot of rain.

Which just leaves the problem of ferrying the children to school. OK, admittedly John Humphrys is doing his scaremongering best by constantly introducing the subject of high winds, hazardous driving conditions and the worst floods since sales records of out-of-season frogman's outfits began, but is he talking to us or to someone trying to cross the Pennines in a 1964 Reliant Robin? I carefully weigh the question of whether our journey is really necessary against having all four of them at home when I'm trying to get some work done.

'Off we go,' I say. 'It'll be great fun.'

Needless to say, the power lines are down and I hate to leave a woman on the brink of late middle youth without central heating, so it's lucky that I have bought her a new green cardigan and a South Park mug from the children in case enough electricity turns up to fill the kettle. 'Happy birthday,' we chorus as we drive off into the teeth of the whirlwind. It is actually quite bad, and we are soon heading for our first stretch of what only yesterday we were perfectly content to think of as 'the road' but which has now taken on a much deeper, wetter meaning. 'Faster, Dad!' they cry from the back, understandably eager to experience the thrill of underwater travel. How they squeal with delight as we surge through the deluge showering oncoming ditherers in a Niagara of filth. How odd to see drivers - who in the normal run of events would be happily raising the friendly hand of motorly acknowledgement - now waving their fists at us through their muddy windscreens as though it is somehow my fault that our superior width allows us to occupy the less perilous stretches of the rural byway, obliging their smaller runabouts to use the perfectly serviceable ditch and submerged cowfield.

There's so much water to drive through that by the time we reach the picturesquely overflowing village duckpond, the car has grown gills and we are able to play a full part in irrigating the downstairs rooms of the honeysuckled thatched cottage opposite. Fortunately, country folk accept that being drowned is a small price to pay for the pleasure of having millions of cars taking a short cut past their house every morning.

I can't believe we're actually early for school, though obviously I have to send them scurrying up the path on their own. 'Hurry up, guys,' I say. 'No point all of us getting wet.'

Coming back takes hours, mainly because I make the big mistake of using the main road, thereby playing straight into the hands of a milkman who has tried to paddle his float across the roundabout and is now four feet up to his yogurts. Another enterprising driver has taken it upon himself to entertain everyone stuck in their cars with the impressive feat of crashing into a lamppost sideways, simply by climbing an embankment and cleverly using the mud as a toppling aid.

At last I'm home with my poor shivering wife. 'Come on, I'll take you out for a slap-up birthday brunch treat,' I say, and pretty soon we are struggling across the river and seated in the only café in town whose staff could be bothered to turn up, tucking into toasted bacon sandwiches, albeit without the bread, which is on its way by barge. Still, as the ancient mariner points out, everything comes to him who wades.
