webTitle: Heather Connon: Abbey a victim of its own ambition

fields.headline: Abbey a victim of its own ambition
fields.trailText: When one company makes a takeover approach to another, its share price usually falls. Investors fret about the risks of the takeover going wrong, and worry that the company will have to issue too many shares or take on too big a debt to pay for the deal.
fields.body:
When one company makes a takeover approach to another, its share price usually falls. Investors fret about the risks of the takeover going wrong, and worry that the company will have to issue too many shares or take on too big a debt to pay for the deal.

But when it was revealed that Abbey National was contemplating a bid for Bank of Scotland, Abbey's shares soared even faster than its proposed target, adding almost 10 per cent in a day.

The reason is simple. Although Ian Harley, Abbey's chief executive, fancies himself as the conqueror, the City believes he will end up as the con quered. By making its approach to Bank of Scotland Abbey has, in City parlance, put itself in play. And the City is much relieved. Investors have been desperate for more action in the banking sector since the Royal Bank of Scotland put NatWest shareholders out of their misery in February.

The trouble is too many banks are chasing too few customers. Add in supermarkets, gas companies, insurers, airlines and everyone else who is trying to muscle in on financial services and the pressure on banking profits is intense.

Worse, the banks are starting to take chunks out of their own profits: Halifax is increasing deposit rates and cutting overdraft charges for its existing customers; HSBC has cut mortgage rates across the board. Margins in retail banking have already fallen sharply - at Bank of Scotland, for example, they have tumbled from 2.85 to 2.47 per cent - and the City fears the worst is yet to come.

It believes the solution lies in consolidation. Royal Bank of Scotland, which is promising cost savings and revenue increases of £2 billion following its acquisition of NatWest, is showing the way. The mortgage banks, whose core mortgage and savings businesses are most at risk from competition, are under most pressure to act. Woolwich has already done so, succumbing to a bid from Barclays. Alliance & Leicester is the subject of constant speculation.

But Abbey is the favourite target because it is not large enough to survive on its own, like the Halifax, nor small enough to carve out a profitable niche, as Northern Rock has done. Add in a whispering campaign against chief executive Harley and you have a bank ripe for a deal.

Whispering campaign or no, Bank of Scotland's Peter Burt is certainly much more highly regarded in the City than Harley. So if Abbey makes the knock-out cash bid which would be needed to win BoS, it could leave Abbey vulnerable to a bid itself - just as NatWest's bid for Legal & General pushed it into the arms of RBS.

Everyone from BoS itself to Barclays is mooted as a possible buyer. The history of such takeover talks - look at the off-on deal between Glaxo and SmithKline - suggests that something will happen eventually.

webTitle: For Clinton, a well-timed exit

fields.headline: For Clinton, a well-timed exit
fields.standfirst: In my view: William Keegan
fields.trailText: My father was once stopped while walking down a street in Chicago during the 1930s and offered money to cast his vote for a certain candidate. 'I'm not even qualified to vote,' he said 'I'm English.' 'Oh, that doesn't matter,' came the reply. Some of the stories from Florida make one wonder whether much has changed.
fields.body:
My father was once stopped while walking down a street in Chicago during the 1930s and offered money to cast his vote for a certain candidate. 'I'm not even qualified to vote,' he said 'I'm English.' 'Oh, that doesn't matter,' came the reply. Some of the stories from Florida make one wonder whether much has changed.

Analysts around the world have for months now been comparing the various economic policies of George W Bush and Al Gore and looking for clues as to how each might affect the world economic scene. The answer from the polls is that there does not seem to be a majority for either.

It is astonishing to look back to 1991 and recall that senior Democrats did not stand for the presidency, because they thought George Bush senior would win; their reluctance let in someone unknown outside Arkansas by the name of Bill Clinton.

Clinton's presidency has overseen the biggest economic boom in America, indeed world history; but there were other aspects of his presidency that made Gore reluctant to associate himself with Clinton during the campaign. According to Mario Cuomo - one of the big Democratic figures who did not go forward in 1991-92 - this may have cost Gore the presidency.

Clinton's most famous explanation for his success was the phrase 'it's the economy, stupid' and George Bush senior's most famous, or infamous, remark on the economy was 'Watch my lips - no new taxes'. Although Clinton's heart was generally thought to be in the right place, he did not achieve as much for the poor by way of redistribution or health care as he had promised, but that was partly because he trimmed to the right to see off the threat from Newt Gingrich.

Clinton had already done a deal with Alan Greenspan, chairman of the US Federal Reserve, under which Greenspan would deliver what he could on interest rates if Clinton would do something about the budget deficit. Funny, isn't it, how Republicans in the US and Conservatives in the UK run up deficits, and Democrats and Labour eliminate them?

Clinton's ambitious social spending plans were revised, and this undoubtedly made its contribution to reducing the deficit. But the long period of rapid economic growth also did wonders for it.

Many factors contributed to the boom, which seems to have made the US electorate punch-drunk about where it goes from here. First and foremost was the flowering of the information technology seeds which had been planted during the 1980s - a time when the big complaint was that the mighty US was 'de-industrialising' and losing out to the perceived wonders of the Japanese economy.

The US entrepreneurial and financial systems were shown to their best advantage in exploiting the so-called 'new economy' boom. The Federal Reserve was lucky in that the general disinflationary climate around the world helped it to keep the boom going - as did the important distinction between its official brief and those of other central banks. It has to aim at price stability and maximum employment, and is not restricted to a published narrow inflation target - otherwise it would have had to apply the brakes more often that it did.

And in Greenspan the Fed has certainly had a chairman who actively looked at every piece of the evidence, and took the information technology revolution seriously. The irony is that Clinton's Democratic administration has presided over a long period of economic success and high employment with the assistance of a Fed chairman whose political instincts are said by friends to be to the right of Genghis Kahn.

The compromise with Greenspan and the reaction to the Gingrich threat meant that Clinton's achievements were full employment and improvement in the general standard of living (especially of the rich) rather than vast changes in the lot of the poor, or alterations in a US economic and social model that seems rather harsh to European eyes.

European leaders at the Denver, Colorado economic summit in 1997 remarked on the paradox that their hosts were lauding the virtues of American capitalism while warning them that the streets outside their hotel doors were unsafe.

But the US model has become the envy of large parts of the world, and certainly of New Labour. Larry Summers, the US Treasury Secretary, was singing the praises of his own system last week, and comparing it favourably with Japan's and Germany's. Yet one does feel the boasting gets a little out of control. Yes, the US led the information technology revolution; but where would it have been without a vast array of imported components from Japan?

The other thing about the Clinton era is that the success of American capitalism did rather depend on attracting, and in some cases draining, the savings of other parts of the world.

There was also a distasteful element of economic imperialism in the way Washington pushed financial globalisation in the interests of Wall Street investment houses (this has been well- documented by the New York Times ). There are many sober US commentators who believe the Asian financial crisis was made in the US.

The good news for the rest of the world was that under the consumer boom associated with Clinton and Greenspan the US certainly became 'importer of last resort' to most other economies, especially when these other countries were pursuing more restrictive economic policies themselves.

'Wolf ' has often been cried about a US hard landing; but in the fairy story the wolf eventually came. How is the world going to handle a sudden collapse of confidence in the US, and a refusal to go on funding its record trade deficit?

One has a feeling that Clinton is bowing out just in time, and that Greenspan's reputation could yet be sorely tested. If there is turbulence ahead, then Europe may finally have to get its economic act together.

webTitle: Game on again for ageing computer toys

fields.headline: Game on again for ageing computer toys
fields.trailText: Those thirtysomethings who spent their teenage years alone in the bedroom playing handheld computer games may be about to have the last laugh. Retro fashion is raiding the early 1980s with a vengeance, and collectors are prepared to pay hundreds of pounds for electronic gadgets and games from the era.
fields.body:
Those thirtysomethings who spent their teenage years alone in the bedroom playing handheld computer games may be about to have the last laugh. Retro fashion is raiding the early 1980s with a vengeance, and collectors are prepared to pay hundreds of pounds for electronic gadgets and games from the era.

In today's market a Pac-man or Simon game that was thrown into a cardboard box as rubbish and forgotten about 15 years ago might make the owner at least twice its original price. Some of the rarer games are worth an unlimited amount to serious collectors.

'You can always rely on nostalgia,' said Simon Gunning, a collector who runs his own software company in London. 'Everything comes around again if you hoard it. I am a bit of a hoarder. I have kept one of the first Apple computers in its box, which will be worth something one day. There is already a lot of demand for vintage arcade games, like Space Invaders, and for console games that you played at home on your television set, like Pong, the table tennis one.'

In celebration of the new burst of interest, a book called Electronic Plastic, by a Dutch handheld games enthusiast, is published in Britain this month. The book is selling fast in Europe and last week the author, Jaro Gielens, visited England to make a public appeal for a number of rare games he craves.

'Most of the buying in this market happens online,' he explained. 'Old Atari cartridges are really the only things that can be found in flea markets. But I have some good addresses in Japan, which is where most of the demand comes from.'

Gunning agrees. 'Once the Japanese become interested the prices go right up, because they really go for these things in a big way.'

Gielens, a former art student from Eindhoven, says he has never paid more than DM250 (£77) for a piece 'although rare objects can reach DM600 and DM800'. He started collecting two years ago, but already had several consoles including, for those who know, an Atari 2600, Intelivision and Vectrex.

'Sentimentality is definitely part of it,' Gielens admits. 'I never had those games myself as a child, they were too expensive. But I knew they existed because I looked around in toy stores to see what I would like.'

These superannuated games apparently appeal both to hardcore followers of fashion and middle-class professionals who refuse to grow up, a sociological group otherwise known as 'kidults'.

The Eighties design of these games obviously helps some collectors recapture their youth. Current fads for old Nike trainers, Star Wars toys, Beastie Boys' memorabilia and inflatable furniture fit into the same category.

For Gielens, the prototypes of the Gameboys and PlayStations of the 1990s remain a cut above other retro artefacts because each of these pioneering electronic games was individually designed. 'The most important criterion is the uniqueness - one game for one plastic shell. And everything fits together so perfectly,' he said. 'The chip is especially made for that one game and individual moulds are made for each shell.'

Gielens now hopes to set up a touring exhibition of his collection and perhaps even a T-shirt range. A one-off exhibition opened in Berlin on Friday and stars esoteric games such as Pinball, Race and Chase and Blockbuster.

Gielens's game collector site is at:
www.superselect.de/ep

Retro fashion is raiding the early 1980s with a vengeance, and collectors are prepared to pay hundreds of pounds for electronic gadgets and games from the era. webTitle: Explorers follow in Pole footsteps

fields.headline: Explorers follow in Pole footsteps
fields.standfirst: It was the most heroic bid for survival ever chronicled. Three men, dressed in gabardine wool suits, with a box of matches, an axe, a rope, a portable stove and no tent, set out on a hazardous journey across uncharted glaciers.
fields.trailText: Brave trio retrace historic Antarctic journey in authentic clothing
fields.body:
All they knew for sure was that, if they failed to make it to safety, their own lives and the lives of 28 of their fellow explorers would be lost.

Now, 84 years on, three British men are once more preparing to make that terrible journey.

Next week Jonathan Chastney, Jock Wishart and Duncan Nicoll will set out together for the island of South Georgia to retrace the steps of their hero, Sir Ernest Shackleton. They will risk death from exposure and icy winds of up to 100mph, but plan to wear authentic Burberry clothing as they re-create history for a television documentary. They will have no back-up if anything goes wrong.

Chastney, a 35-year-old property developer from Tamworth and member of the 1995 team who made the first ascent of Mount Katherine-Jane on Smith Island, Antarctica, is making the trip in tribute to Shackleton.

The crucial overland section is expected to take the three men up to four days.

'Shackleton did it in 36 hours,' said Chastney, 'but then he knew that might well be all the time they had.

'We will be wearing the original Burberry gear, although the undergarments, which were probably individually made by the wives and sweethearts of the crew, are proving a little more difficult. We will be "mix and match".'

Shackleton's original desperate journey came at the end of an 18-month attempt to cross Antarctica. On 23 October, 1915, he wrote: 'After long months of ceaseless anxiety and strain, after times when hope beat high and times when the outlook was black indeed, we have been compelled to abandon the ship, which is crushed beyond all hope of ever being righted...it is hard to write what I feel'

His ship, Endurance, had been smashed by icebergs. For six months Shackleton and his 27-man crew camped on ice-floes, dragging their lifeboats across the snow and shooting their dogs for food. As the ice thawed, they eventually made it to the remote Elephant Island.

There Shackleton chose five of the fittest men to set off in a 20ft open boat across 800 miles of ocean to reach South Georgia.

Although they survived the voyage, they landed on the wrong side of the island. Shackleton and two of his men set off again, leaving the three others to eke out an existence inside a cave. Against the odds, they reached the whaling station at Stromness and organised the safe rescue of all the marooned men.

Shackleton returned to Britain a hero, but until recently his name has been overshadowed by that of Captain Robert Falcon Scott.

'There has always been a great rivalry and emphasis on the difference between the two of them,' said Chastney. 'Scott became famous because he died. Thankfully, there has been more recognition recently of what Shackleton achieved. His men would have followed him anywhere.'

Next Monday they will fly to Argentina and travel by boat to South Georgia before starting the expedition proper a week later. They plan to reach Stromness Bay on Friday, 1 December.

If the £40,000 expedition succeeds, the team will be back in Britain 12 days later. Their return will mark the end of a year of unprecedented Shackletonmania.

In January, Culture Secretary Chris Smith blocked the export of the silk flag which the Dowager Queen Alexandra had presented to Shackleton on his departure in 1914. An American collector, Neil Silverman, had bought it at an auction for £64,342 and was determined to take it out of the country. The Government gave the National Maritime Museum in Greenwich a chance to match the bid.

In June, the first of two television documentaries on Shackleton reminded the British public of his achievements, and in July the actor Kenneth Branagh announced his intention to play Shackleton in a four-hour Channel 4 film. Sales of Lansing's book Endurance boomed over the summer months, and the National Maritime Museum announced that it would display the message that Shackleton had buried in tribute to three comrades who died on a later trip. 'Things done for gain are naught, but great things done endure,' it read.

In September, love letters to Elspeth Beardsmore, later Lady Invernairn, whose husband backed the 1907 Antarctica trip, were seen for the first time. The National Maritime Museum had received the letters in the Fifties from Lady Invernairn's lady-in-waiting, with instructions not to open them until 18 September, 2000.

Last week the television documentary Endurance: Shackleton And The Antarctic, was broadcast to great critical acclaim and the two exhibitions at Greenwich and Dulwich reported higher visitor numbers than predicted.

It seems the British are now prepared to give wider recognition to the man of whom it was said: 'For scientific leadership, give me Scott, for swift and efficient travel, Amundsen, but when you are in a hopeless situation, when there seems no way out, get down on your knees and pray for Shackleton.'

vanessa.thorpe@observer.co.uk

To follow the expedition:
www.shackletons-steps.com

webTitle: The nauseating truth behind man's evolution

fields.headline: The nauseating truth behind man's evolution
fields.trailText: Mankind's evolutionary secret has been revealed. And it's thoroughly disgusting. Scientists have found that our ability to sniff out all things loathsome, nauseous and repulsive may have propelled us to global domination.
fields.body:
Mankind's evolutionary secret has been revealed. And it's thoroughly disgusting. Scientists have found that our ability to sniff out all things loathsome, nauseous and repulsive may have propelled us to global domination.

This idea stems from research which has shown that each of us possesses a 'disgust' centre in our brains. This controls our ability not just to spot repugnant things like foul food, snakes and dangerous insects, but to pinpoint revolting behaviour in others. As US researcher Professor Paul Rozin of Pennsylvania University puts it: 'Disgust developed from a system to protect the body from harm to a system to protect the soul from harm.'

Those who possess strong centres tend to be well-behaved, respectable members of society, the John Majors of our world. Individuals without them end up like Les Patterson.

'All animals have a sense of distaste,' says psychologist Andrew Calder. However, in humans it has been enhanced to give us a centre for highlighting both disgusting things, and disgusting acts. We need to be able to spot such behaviour because it could threaten society unless rooted out quickly, he says.

The discovery of the centre stems from observations by Calder and his team at the Cambridge Brain Unit. They had noticed that patients who suffer from the nerve ailment Huntington's Disease failed to recognise anti-social acts such as spitting or belching, and could not detect expressions of disgust on other people's faces.

As the disease affects a region of the brain called the insula, the observation suggested that our disgust centre is based in this region of the cortex. 'The trouble is that other areas of the brain are damaged in Huntington's patients, so we could not be sure these were not involved,' added Calder. 'We needed a more specific approach to the problem.'

The team was provided with one in the case of a 25-year-old man suffering from a unique type of stroke damage, a blood clot that had affected his insula. The result was startling: when shown photographs of other people, the patient could spot when they had angry, frightened or happy expressions. But when he was presented with photographs of people displaying disgust, he failed to recognise the emotion.

More importantly, when the patient was presented with a list of disgusting ideas - faeces-shaped chocolates, or people who didn't wash - he again showed no reaction.

The discovery of a disgust centre provides critical support for the ideas of biologists such as Rozin who argues that the sense that we once used to spot rotting food has evolved to become the guardian of our behaviour. Disgust has evolved from the rejection of bad-tasting food to being a source of morality.

Developments in human responses to offensive chemicals led the US government to commission scientists to find a smell which everyone would consider disgusting, so they could use it for a universal stink bomb to replace tear gas.

webTitle: Gamblers put their health as well as wealth at stake

fields.headline: Gamblers put their health as well as wealth at stake
fields.trailText: Gambling is as addictive as smoking or drug-taking, say researchers who have monitored hormone levels in blackjack players in a casino.
fields.body:
Gambling is as addictive as smoking or drug-taking, say researchers who have monitored hormone levels in blackjack players in a casino.

The group - from Bremen University - discovered that games played for cash, produced a significant chemical reaction in participants. By contrast, when the same gamblers later played blackjack for points, not money, there was very little chemical response.

The discovery is the strongest indication to date that gambling is addictive behaviour which produces chemical changes in the body, which are more than a simple psychological response to a pleasurable habit.

News of the research comes as it was revealed that English footballers had indulged in high-stake late-night card games before big games. The German research suggests that by gambling, team members were producing chemical changes in their bodies as great as those triggered by drugs or drink. Hence their dismal record on the pitch.

'Gambling gives a real thrill; you can detect that chemically,' said project leader Gerhard Meyer. 'You get a buzz when you put down the bet. If you win you feel great, and want to do it again. If you lose, you know you can put down another bet very quickly, and hopefully win then. That is the great thing about casinos: speed of feedback.'

The Bremen group recruited 10 regular gamblers at a state-registered casino. Each had their heart rate monitored, and also provided saliva samples every half-hour during a two-hour gambling session. Each used their own money as stakes. 'The saliva was analysed for cortisol - a hormone released when a person comes under stress,' said Meyer. 'Gamblers' cortisol and heart rate levels both rose significantly under real casino conditions. By contrast, when we asked them to play for points, we found very little rise in heart beat or cortisol.'

In short, gambling for real stakes seems to produce chemical reactions that parallel those induced by nicotine, alcohol or cocaine. These drugs cause the brain to release substances such as dopamine and serotonin and these stimulate other nerve cells to produce responses that are experienced as pleasurable. Gambling acts as a behavioural surrogate for these drugs, creating euphoria but also triggering a biochemical cascade through the body. Meyer 's team have now successfully measured one of the products of that cascade: raised cortisol levels in saliva.

The team now plans to measure other hormones such as adrenaline in gamblers' blood.

Meyer said: 'As a result, we should be able to measure drugs that are released by brains of gamblers as they win or lose. The more that we find out about these pathways, the more chance we have of developing drugs that can block, and ultimately help gamblers kick the habit.'

webTitle: UK news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: PC Trevor Benson, of St Ives, Cambridgeshire, who was found asleep in his car, was forced to resign after 26 years' service.
fields.body:
Sleeping PC forced to quit

PC Trevor Benson, of St Ives, Cambridgeshire, who was found asleep in his car, was forced to resign after 26 years' service.

Literary lucre

Ninety-eight books have been entered for the world's richest literary prize, the Impac Dublin Award. British entrants include Doris Lessing, Michael Frayn, Alan Sillitoe and David Lodge.

No homes

A survey carried out for the homelessness charity Crisis has found there are about 100,000 homeless ex-servicemen in Britain.

Prince in soap?

The Prince of Wales, who will visit Coronation Street to mark the soap's fortieth anniversary next month, will be offered a cameo role.

Red and dead

Eighty-seven red squirrels were killed last year on the Isle of Wight, one of their last redoubts in England. Most died on the roads.

Safety alert over repairs to nuclear submarine

The European Commission is seeking safety assurances from Britain over repair work being carried out aboard the nuclear submarine Tireless in Gibraltar.

Paedophile is held

John McCormack, 23, a 'high risk' convicted paedophile who left a sex offenders' clinic in Epsom, Surrey, has been detained by West Midlands police after breaching his prison licence.

Teddy overboard

Emergency services rushed to Kingsmeadow in Cirencester, Gloucestershire, after reports of a body in the river. They found a teddy bear.

Arm op for brave Lisa

Former nursery nurse Lisa Potts, awarded the George Medal for shielding children in Wolverhampton from a machete attacker, is to have an operation to lengthen the tendons in her left arm.

Sophie's choice at 20/1

Bookmakers William Hill have given 20/1 odds with a maximum stake of £50 that Sophie Rhys Jones, Countess of Wessex, is pregnant.

McKenna convicted

Belfast human rights campaigner Vincent McKenna has been convicted of sexually abusing his daughter, who waived her right to anonymity. Sentencing was adjourned.

Boy, 16, on murder charge

A boy of 16 has been remanded in custody, charged with the murder of beautician Rachel Keily, found strangled near her home in Callincollig, Co Cork.

webTitle: Merchant Navy heroes honoured at last

fields.headline: Merchant Navy heroes honoured at last
fields.standfirst: The Red Duster's 35,000 dead are to be remembered at the Cenotaph for the first time, writes  John Sweeney
fields.trailText: The little black lad with a toy ship strapped to his legs, front and aft, waiting to take part in the Lord Mayor's Parade, stared up at the Red Duster flapping in the bitter wind yesterday at the 11th hour of the 11th day of the 11th month.
fields.body:
The little black lad with a toy ship strapped to his legs, front and aft, waiting to take part in the Lord Mayor's Parade, stared up at the Red Duster flapping in the bitter wind yesterday at the 11th hour of the 11th day of the 11th month.

In the silence - broken only by the soughing of the wind through the City's concrete canyons and the hooves of a police horse clattering against the asphalt - he just saw the red flag with the words 'Merchant Navy Association' and the small group of old men, there to honour the 35,000 comrades of the Merchant Navy who perished in the Second World War. For a child of our time, the memories of the old sailors, the stories of what they went through, are another world.

Today Britain is at last properly honouring the heroes of the Merchant Navy. For 55 years they have not been allowed to remember the dead with the same dignity as the other services at the Cenotaph: a demotion in honour not merited or comprehensible to their surviving comrades. Also at the Cenotaph today for the first time will be the supporters of Shot At Dawn - 'cowards' executed in the First World War, on the flimsiest evidence.

The modern generation should listen to sailors like Jim Perry of the Empire Hope, who ran the gauntlet between Sicily and the African coast to reach Malta - to replenish the besieged island fortress. His ship was bombed and sunk on the Pedestal Convoy to Malta, in 1942. Four of the 14 merchantmen did make it, saving the embattled island and the free world from surrender.

Even today, Perry's story makes one's heart sink. His ship, loaded to the gunwales with highly inflammable aviation fuel for Hurricanes and Spitfires left in Malta to combat the Axis squeeze, was a floating bomb. 'For us, it was just a job,' Perry says.

In mid-1942, the war was going badly for the Allies. During the first six months U-Boats sank 3,250,000 tons of Atlantic shipping. Rommel rolled through North Africa, threatening the Suez Canal, but stopped 35 miles short of Alexandria, Egypt, because of shortage of supplies.

The Pedestal Convoy was Britain's last throw to resupply Malta. The Empire Hope was sunk on 12 August, having been attacked by torpedo bombers, high-level bombers, middle level bombers and dive bombers. The merchantmen had seen other ships, including the aircraft carrier HMS Eagle, sunk and others, HMS Rodney and HMS Nelson, had turned for safety.

webTitle: Review: True confessions: Scenes from real life

fields.headline: Please sir, do you really have to live next door to me?
fields.trailText: True confessions: Scenes from real life
fields.body:
For some time now I've been watching my parents' new neighbour from the bathroom window. He is, in fact, an ex-biology teacher of mine called Mr Jenkins whom my parents have just moved next door to. They often talk to Mr Jenkins over the privet hedge. Knowing he was one of my teachers, they are keen to introduce him to me when I visit.

I recently gained a first at university and have just followed it with a Masters degree, even though for years I suffered from dyslexia and was consigned to a remedial class. Mr Jenkins is looking forward to meeting me, they say. He can't remember my name, but he never forgets a face.

Biology was never my forte at school. My grades were poor no matter how hard I tried and one day, after flicking an elastic band from the back of the class that landed on the teacher's desk, I was sent to Mr Jenkins's class. He was a tall, nervous man, known to live alone, who stuttered and blushed. He was in charge of the bottom set. But I didn't belong there.

On my first day, desperate to impress him with the complex thought processes I was struggling with as a teenager, and distinguish myself, a question came to me. I put up my hand. 'Sir, what's a clitoris?' Mr Jenkins seemed strangely lost for words. He was known to be a bit deaf and for this he was often the butt of cruel jokes. Good naturedly, I repeated the question, stressing each syllable. 'A clitoris, sir. It's like a black spot, my mum said. My aunt had hers operated on last year. They had to cut it out because it was starting to spread. She had about five of them in the end, and they were all joining up, so that it was getting dangerous for her to go to out... it's like a black spot and...' I trailed off only when I became aware of my classmates staring at me, and the colour flooding into Mr Jenkins's cheeks.

An unmistakable look of anguish had crept across his face. I don't remember anybody laughing. Laughter would have been reassuring in a way. There was just silence; a sudden, pin-pricking silence, and from the desk in front of me, Wendy Rogers, whom I had just started waiting for after school, looking around at me with the kind of tired, incredulous look on her face that has haunted my relations with women ever since. I had only meant to say cataract. Such a beautiful, evocative little word. Cataract. My aunt Joyce had just had hers removed. But there was no going back, no smoothing over the cracks. It was the malapropism to end all malapropisms. Perhaps the bell rang then; I have little recollection of what followed.

What I do remember is that not a single classmate joked with me about it afterwards, and Mr Jenkins didn't ask to see me after class. I will have to go down to him soon though, walk across the garden to the privet hedge where he stands chatting to my parents about his vegetables. He is retired now, still a bachelor, a tall shy man more comfortable with his leeks and brassicas than with people. My parents are dying for him to meet me. They've called me down several times now, from the bottom of the stairs. Come and meet Mr Jenkins, they say. He never forgets a face.

 Mr Jenkins is a pseudonym.

webTitle: Arts: Norman Foster's Great Court

fields.headline: The Bloomsbury coup
fields.standfirst: The British Museum's history is littered with accusations of architectural vandalism, but its latest addition - Norman Foster's Great Court, which opens next month - is a triumph, writes  Deyan Sudjic
fields.trailText: The British Museum's history is littered with accusations of architectural vandalism, but its latest addition - Norman Foster's Great Court, which opens next month - is a triumph, writes Deyan Sudjic.
fields.body:
With its mix architecture and urban design, and its confrontation of classicism with computer-generated design, the British Museum's Great Court is one of the defining buildings of Norman Foster's career.

But in public-relations terms, the museum's plans to open its £97 million project next month could not have got off to a worse start. The museum has been accused of just about everything from dereliction of duty to bad faith in its attempts to make good the hole torn out of its heart by the departure of the British Library for St Pancras. The project used the wrong stone; the museum was playing fast and loose with planning permission by building too high. There was even, so the London Evening Standard claims, a conspiracy to unload a consignment of inferior French stone on Britain's greatest museum at a premium price, followed by a witchhunt to find the mole who had been leaking confidential documents about the story.

With its unlikely pairing of rumpled academic Robert Anderson, as director, and the svelte City type Suzanna Taverne, as managing director, operating as a kind of dual monarchy, the museum is clearly carrying on its centuries-long tradition as a hotbed of internecine strife and intrigue. Then, last week, Jocelyn Stevens, the excitable former head of English Heritage joined the fight, calling for the resignation of Graham Greene, chairman of the trustees, over what he claimed was the failure of the museum to treat its building - Sir Robert Smirke's grade one-listed masterpiece - with sufficient respect.

The Millennium Bridge, an equally high-profile project also designed by Norman Foster, and opened by the Queen earlier this year, faced a wave of derision when it failed to meet expectations aroused by the pre-opening publicity and stubbornly refused to stop wobbling. What had been presented as a triumph suddenly turned into yet another millennium fiasco. Pre-opening expectations for the Great Court have been so low that, short of a technical disaster in the high-tech, glass-and-steel roof, the museum must be hoping that when the Queen finally declares the project open, exactly the opposite will happen.

From the ferocity of Stevens's attack, you could be forgiven for expecting the Great Court to turn out to be a piece of Disney-style conservation. But architecturally, the Great Court, already clearly visible to anybody who takes a stroll through the King's Library, is a triumph. As a public space, it is nothing short of magnificent. Yet with a wilful determination not to see the wood for the trees, Stevens has focused entirely on the newly constructed stone portico that is the centrepiece of the south side of the courtyard.

He claims that the trustees knew that the stone being used was not the Portland stone specified in the contract, but was, in fact, a cheaper French substitute, which might meet the letter of the specification but wasn't what Sir Robert Smirke had selected when he designed the museum in 1823.

Stevens wants the royal opening postponed for a year or two while the offending stone work is demolished and rebuilt using genuine Portland. Stevens is no stranger to multiple postponements. In all his years as the chairman of English Heritage, he singularly failed to resolve what he himself called the scandalous state of Britain's greatest archaeological treasure that was under his care, Stonehenge. He left behind a fiasco of abandoned architectural competitions and futile attempts at privately funded visitors' centres which were all scrapped by his successor at English Heritage. It is going to be at least another six years before the mess at Stonehenge is finally sorted out. In rather less time, the museum has raised the money to complete the huge restructuring that the Great Court has entailed.

Sooner or later, the stone episode will join the abundant lore of colourful tales that have always been part of the museum's history. The magnificent main façade, for example, was built in the 1840s by Baker and Sons, a firm that hadn't submitted the lowest tender for the job, but which, according to Jo Mordaunt Crook's riveting architectural history of the museum, did have the vital qualification of a managing director married to the architect's sister.

The arguments about authenticity simply do not stack up. The courtyard didn't get built in one go - it took almost 25 years to finish. It would never have been entirely uniform, and it isn't now. It shows the wear and the scars of the passing of time.

The courtyard only existed in its original state for the seven years from 1847 to 1854. Bigger than Hanover Square, at almost two acres, but according to Thomas Watts, assistant to the great librarian of the British Museum, Anthony Panizzi, 'a dead loss'. Another critic dubbed it the 'finest mason's yard in Europe'. The public were excluded from what was, by one account, 'a mere well of malaria, a pestilent congregation of vapours'.

The original portico was hacked about to insert the Reading Room, and when the museum was subject to the tender care of the Ministry of Public Building and Works there was constant damage of bodged alterations carried out with all the tenderness of an army of occupation. There was bomb damage during the Second World War from a hail of incendiaries, missiles and water penetration.

If you are rebuilding architecture with such a complex history, what do you restore? Smirke had wanted an open courtyard, so do you demolish the Reading Room - the cuckoo planted in the nest -in the interests of authenticity? Or do you plough it up and devote it to growing exotic botanical specimens, as Smirke had originally wanted; clearly not. Do you restore the porticoes around the courtyard to the way that they were actually built or do you rebuild them in the manner that Smirke would have built them had he got the chance and the cash? Until 1833, Smirke had intended the main quadrangle façades to carry fairly elaborate porticoes.

To get to the north wing, visitors would have come through the triumphant colonnade at the front of the museum, negotiated the entrance hall; gone out through the south portico, crossed the courtyard, and mounted an imposing flight of steps and pass through another, even more, impressive portico. Economy reduced them from the majestic to stage scenery.

The portico as built has been attacked for its materials and its workmanship. But it seems to have escaped the critics' attention that the portico itself is not a reconstruction of Smirke; it is a completely new design by Foster that has been produced to deal with the contemporary realities. Its deep, central opening, and the square light at the upper level to give museum visitors a glimpse into the space, have no historical precedent;

Historical accuracy has always been a two-edged sword in architectural restoration projects. In the nineteenth century, William Morris set up the Society for the Protection of Ancient Buildings to prevent over-enthusiastic restoration that took the form of demolishing perpendicular additions to early English gothic cathedrals, in order to reconstruct them more accurately as they ought to have been. To Morris, this would diminish the integrity of those fragments of the building that were genuine. And the strategy that he argued for was patching up, mending, but not pretending that the new work was anything but new. Perhaps, more by accident than by design, that is exactly what has happened at the British Museum.

Foster's Great Court is not what Smirke designed, but it will give visitors the kind of spatial thrills that Smike had intended. You will be able to move from the richly painted entrance hall into a sudden explosion of light and space beyond, under a remarkable, billowing glass-and-steel roof that deals with the extraordinarily difficult task of accommodating a rectangular courtyard at the same time as allowing the circular Reading Room to poke through it. No two of the triangular panels are exactly the same.

A mousehole entrance in the newly stone-faced Reading Room - this time it comes from Spain - takes you back a century into the most famous library in the world, its original bookstacks, desks and furniture intact. At the north side of the drum, the Reading Room sprouts a bustle to accommodate a series of curved terraces that cascade down from the top level. There are cafés, restaurants and shops here. Then, through the second portico, you move on into the old north Reading Room, put to use as a temporary exhibition space and out into the street. It is that route that creates the other great new meaning for the museum; the project is not just a question of patching up the aftermath of wrenching out the British Library, nor is it only a matter of creating a new circulation route that allows the 5.4 million visitors each year to negotiate the museum without turning the galleries into busy corridors.

The Great Court is a fundamentally urban project. It provides a new pedestrian route to move through London, from Bloomsbury down to Covent Garden, by way of the Great Court and the newly cleared forecourt to the museum. It gives a taste of what Foster's project for the traffic-free Trafalgar Square could be. As the museum and its architects wait with some anxiety for the public's response, it's worth remembering the reaction to the completion of the original museum.

The Architects Journal of 1841 tore into the project: 'Sir Robert Smirke may been an excellent warehouse builder; but let him stick to that task, and not foist upon the country such a dowdy design as the one concocted for the British Museum'. The Spectator , clearly edited by Jocelyn Stevens in a previous incarnation, simply called on Smirke to 'resign and abdicate'.

&#149 The Great Court opens 7 December.

webTitle: The Paul Taylor Dance Company returns to the UK

fields.headline: Raging hormones, kidnapped babies... it's quite a day in Chinatown
fields.standfirst: The Paul Taylor Dance Company returns to the UK after 10 years with a triple bill of rare depth and complexity
fields.trailText: The Paul Taylor Dance Company returns to the UK after 10 years with a triple bill of rare depth and complexity.
fields.body:
Paul Taylor, Sadler's Wells, London EC1

Trisha Brown, QEH, London SE1

London, thank goodness, is included in the Paul Taylor Dance Company's millennial tour of cultural capitals. We haven't seen the company for almost a decade. Dance Umbrella, which keeps us up to date with Merce Cunningham and Trisha Brown, for some reason omits Paul Taylor from its pantheon of great American choreographers.

As a result, we are so out of touch with the variety of his work that the triple bill at the Wells could be by three different companies. Dancers change shape and style for each piece - two recent creations with the middle one, Le Sacre du Printemps, a revival from 1981. They form a sequence of mating rituals, ranging from courtly love to a contemporary orgy.

In Cascade (1999), to Bach concertos, the dancers curve their limbs as taut as bows, bounding and darting on the arcs of the music (played live by the London Musici). Lisa Viola seems a sybil in her gravely beautiful solo, communicating with dark forces. Blithe couples exchange vows and the piece ends in a group pose: a family portrait.

Stravinsky's Rite of Spring inspires a black comedy, an anti-fertility ritual. The percussive rhythms, pounded out on two pianos in the pit, wind up the performers like cartoons or silent-movie characters: the plot jumps back and forth as if film reels were run in random order. A damsel in distress seeks out a private dick. Her baby is kidnapped, so he has to deal with villains in Chinatown and Keystone Kops. Corpses pile up, the baby gets it, and the mother launches into the dance of death.

Meanwhile, a rehearsal goes on in a parallel universe. The corps has served time with the Ballets Russes as well as Martha Graham. Their blunt, angular bodies, clad in clay-grey, are a sideways comment on modern dance history. They turn Sacre into a cubist ballet, pitiless and strange. You laugh, then gasp: the ending is a blow to the solar plexus.

Piazzolla Caldera, the closing piece from 1997, celebrates a mass rut to tango music. The stage is so charged with hormones that everyone locks horns and limbs in every possible combination. Taylor has translated the tango into his own idiom, making it a metaphor for the messy desires of otherwise disciplined dancers.

The only chance for people outside London to see the marvellous Taylor troupe is either on video or on Channel 4 next month.

Trisha Brown's company has been touring Britain (last performance in Bath tomorrow) since ending the Dance Umbrella festival last weekend. Brown has taken on the challenge of jazz music - unfortunately not played live on this tour. Highly analytical, she creates a dancing image of what the musicians are doing, while allowing her performers freedom to improvise.

In Five Part Weather Invention , with music by Dave Douglas, she sets a wave of motion going. A line of dancers has to follow the leader, their responses lag ging slightly or shadowing each other tightly. A unison group looks as mysteriously purposeful as a shoal of fish. Then one woman slips and falls, then another and another, disrupting the stream.

Rapture to Leon James starts out as minimalist jazz dance, with funky little steps and hand-jive gestures. In comes Keith Thompson to liven things up and the team boogies into extravagant lindy-hop inventions. They play games with counts and patterns, matching the forms the music takes.

Twelve Ton Rose is very different centrepiece, a riddle set to Webern's 12-tone music rows. It shapes the performers like mobile sculpture, presenting them as abstract visual art. Yet there is a disturbing emotional undercurrent that makes Brown's work as tantalising as Taylor's. We need to see them both regularly to read between their lines.

webTitle: Film of the week: Harry, He's Here To Help

fields.headline: Just wild about Harry
fields.standfirst: Dominik Moll's disturbing new thriller is a superb homage to Hitchcock
fields.trailText: Dominik Moll's disturbing new thriller is a superb homage to Hitchcock: Harry, He's Here To Help (117 mins, 15)
fields.body:
Harry, He's Here To Help (117 mins, 15)
Directed by Dominik Moll; starring Laurent Lucas, Mathilde Seigner, Sergi Lopez, Sophie Guillemin

As a film-maker, an influence and a physical presence (the only non-acting director to be recognisable the world over), Alfred Hitchcock has loomed over moviegoers for 70 years. The fascination with his life and work shows no signs of abating. When he was 60, there was just one book about him, written in French by Claude Chabrol and Eric Rohmer. There were half-a-dozen or so by the time of his death in 1980, and there's now a little library of studies, with extra space to be found on the shelves each year.

The massive publicity attending the centenary of his birth in 1999 did little to stem the flow of interest. Last month saw the publication by the BFI of Susan Smith's Hitchcock: Suspense, Humour and Tone, and the release of Robert Zemeckis's What Lies Beneath, a homage to Rear Window .

Later this month Faber will publish Peter Conrad's perceptive The Hitchcock Murders, and this week Dominik Moll's thriller Harry, He's Here to Help arrives in our cinemas, confirming that Hitchcock's legacy is in good hands down in the Auvergne.

The film begins with an edgy casualness. One hot summer day, the 34-year-old Michel Pape (Laurent Lucas), a good-looking teacher of French to Japanese students, is driving south from Paris in his clapped-out saloon with his sensible wife, Claire (Mathilde Seigner), and three fractious little daughters. Their destination is the dilapidated old farmhouse on the foothills of the Monts du Cantal that they've bought with the help of his overbearing dentist father and his querulous mother and are doing up a little at a time.

Like various Hitchcock characters, their lives are inviting intervention. In the men's lavatory at a motorway café, a good-looking, slightly flashy man introduces himself to Michel as an old friend he's not met for 20 years and who remembers their schooldays in astonishing detail. This stranger by a drain is called Harry Balestrero (Sergi Lopez), a name designed to set off alarm bells in the viewer's mind. Balestrero is the name of the innocent victim in The Wrong Man ; Harry is the corpse that causes trouble in Vermont in Hitchcock's most extended exercise in rural mayhem in The Trouble With Harry.

Harry, like Bruno in Strangers on a Train, is idle, aesthetically poised and independently wealthy, having inherited large sums from a despised father. Accompanied by his simple, sexy, patronised girlfriend (Sophie Guillemin), he insinuates himself into the lives of Michel, Claire and their children, sensing faultlines in their relationships and creating new ones. It begins with lollies for the kids, a lift in his air-conditioned Mercedes and a flattering concern for Michel having given up on the literary career that seemed to lie before him as a precocious schoolboy.

Harry's one of those people who knows more about you than you know yourself and is solicitous to an embarrassing degree. He believes 'every problem has a solution' and sets about reorgan ising Michel's life with advice and manipulative acts. Because Michel and Claire don't present a united front, he's able to become a murderous cuckoo in their nest.

As with Hitchcock and Fritz Lang, there's a deadly logic in the way one act leads plausibly to another on the escalator of will and desire, and with considerable subtlety Moll draws us into Harry's scheming mind. In the way he coolly thinks the unthinkable, Harry is as insidious and seductive as Patricia Highsmith's psychopathic Tom Ripley.

Harry, He's Here to Help is superbly performed by its central quartet, and by the actors playing Michel's somewhat disagreeable parents and his louche brother. A profoundly disturbing work, it's the best European movie in a Hitchcockian vein since George Sluizer's The Vanishing and is made with a confident grace and ironic wit. It also has one of the best mobile phone jokes, which will remind many viewers of a famous scene involving a corpse in Frenzy .

Two other motifs that Conrad's book draws attention to turn up in the film. Hitchcock found eggs abhorrent, but Harry eats them raw to improve his orgasms and Michel, when he resumes writing, produces a story called 'Les Oeufs'. Hitch also had a thing about teeth and Henry Fonda's troubles in The Wrong Man begin with his dental bills. The bridge Harry needed as a schoolboy after a sporting collision with Michel was fitted by Michel's father and had to be replaced in America after turning black.

LONDON FILM FESTIVAL

You could try to book in tonight for the Surprise Film (8.30pm, Odeon West End 2) and be surprised (that's guaranteed). Otherwise, my advice for sampling the festival's final week is...

SUNDAY
Les Marchands de sable Stylised French thriller by Pierre Salvadori (4pm, Odeon West End; tomorrow, 8.45pm Empire).

MONDAY
Liam Directed by Stephen Frears, this 1930s drama of Catholic Merseyside life centres on a child reacting to his unemployed father's attraction to fascism. (1.30pm, Odeon West End).

TUESDAY
Joe Gould's Secret Ian Holm impersonates Manhattan bohemian genius Joe Gould in a study of twentieth-century literary life (1pm, Odeon West End).

WEDNESDAY
Greed: a Reconstruction An attempt to use stills and existing footage to recreate something resembling the masterpiece that Erich von Stroheim delivered to MGM in 1924 and Irving Thalberg butchered (6pm, NFT2).

THURSDAY
Masterclass - Kathryn Bigelow Represented in the festival by The Weight of Water , Bigelow discusses her work and role in Hollywood. (11am, NFT2).

 For tickets contact www.Iff.org.uk or telephone: 020 7928 3232.

webTitle: Other films reviews: The Yards/Bedazzled/Pitch Black/Chuck and Buck/Disney's The Kid/Siam Sunset

fields.headline: Even a three-time loser sometimes comes up trumps
fields.standfirst: Other films: Philip French
fields.trailText: Other films: The Yards/Bedazzled/Pitch Black/Chuck and Buck/Disney's The Kid/Siam Sunset
fields.body:
The Yards (115 mins, 15)
Directed by James Gray; starring Mark Wahlberg, Joaquin Phoenix, James Caan, Charlize Theron

Bedazzled (93 mins, 12)
Directed by Harold Ramis; starring Brendan Fraser, Elizabeth Hurley

Pitch Black (108 mins, 15)
Directed by David Twohy; starring Vin Diesel, Cole Hauser

Chuck and Buck (95 mins, 15)
Directed by Miguel Arteta; starring Chris Weitz, Mike White

Disney's The Kid (100 mins, U)
Directed by Jon Turteltaub; starring Bruce Willis, Spencer Breslin, Emily Mortimer

Siam Sunset (91 mins, 15)
Directed by John Polson; starring Linus Roache, Danielle Cormack

One effect of the House Un-American Activities Committee's investigation of Hollywood was to impose on liberal moviemakers a code of silence comparable to the omerta of the Mafia and the anti-sneaking ethos of the English public-school system, thus leading to the condemnation of On the Waterfront as a defence of the informer.

Equally, The Godfather trilogy helped reinforce the ancient myth of honour among thieves. James Gray's The Yards, a downbeat crime movie every bit as sombre as his Little Odessa of five years ago, gives the lie to both notions.

The picture begins and ends with its 24-year-old protagonist, Leo (Mark Wahlberg), alone on a New York elevated railway, first heading home after serving 18 months for 'grand theft auto', later quitting his blue-collar Catholic community in Queen's for blowing the whistle on municipal corruption that involves local politicians, the police, transit officials, railroad contractors and the underworld.

His homecoming party is a small-scale affair, a parodic, anti-epic version of the wedding reception with which The Godfather starts. Leo is praised for taking the rap alone and not ratting on his glamorous chum, Willie (Joaquin Phoenix), and his aunt's new husband, a prosperous manufacturer of railway equipment, (James Caan), who suggests he take a mechanical apprenticeship for two years.

But Leo needs an immediate income to support his proud, ailing mother (Ellen Burstyn). So he's led once more off the straight and narrow by Willie, who han dles the rough stuff for Caan, paying off corrupt civil servants and sabotaging his rivals' rolling-stock.

Leo is that old American standby, the three-time loser, and - a little too rapidly - he's on the run, wanted for a murder he didn't commit. His supposed friends plan to kill him to save their own skins, and only his mother and his beautiful cousin (Charlize Theron) help him.

Ultimately, his survival depends on co-operating with the DA's department in trying to destroy the system, though his subsequent chances of securing life insurance at reasonable rates wouldn't be too strong. The movie is fairly predictable and towards the end a trifle perfunctory.

But there's no glamorous varnish on the events, the mood is doom-laden (the score includes a version of 'Saturn' from Holst's Planet Suite) and a formidable cast bury themselves in their unglamorous roles.

Devils or angels turn up in the cinema most weeks nowadays, the current offering, Bedazzled, being a re-make of Stanley Donen's moderately amusing 1967 British comedy, written by Peter Cook and Dudley Moore, that starred Cook as Mephistopheles offering seven wishes to Dud's lovestruck London nebbish.

The Devil is now a glamorous, confident Elizabeth Hurley who runs a Faust-aid post in San Francisco and darts hyperactively around town looking and talking like Nigella Lawson preparing dinner. Her principal client is a gauche computer programmer (Brendan Fraser) incapable of getting his wishes right and thus always getting what Marilyn Monroe (in Some Like It Hot ) called 'the fuzzy end of the lollipop'. The result is, like Ally McBeal, very thin and quite funny.

Pitch Black is a minimalist SF horror flick arriving belatedly in the slipstream of the Alien cycle. A space bus gets into a meteor storm and crashes on a deserted planet of seemingly permanent sunlight. Underground lurk hordes of blind, carnivorous, bat-like creatures who live off visiting earthlings during brief periods of solar eclipse.

The film was shot in uninviting parts of the Australian outback, and because there are no stars it isn't easy to predict the order in which the characters will die. The most striking presence, playing a psychopathic criminal equipped to see in the dark, is Vin Diesel, one of Tom Hanks's platoon in Saving Private Ryan .

The ultra-low budget Chuck and Buck is a curious, gay-stalker movie with a certain resemblance to the Film of the Week Harry, He's Here to Help.

Buck (Mike White), a 27-year-old with the behaviour patterns of a child, invites Chuck (Chris Weitz), the schoolfriend he hasn't seen for 15 years, to his mother's funeral. Chuck, after rejecting Buck's gay advances, returns to Los Angeles, where he's a successful pop music producer with a sympathetic fiancée. But he's then relentlessly pursued by the squirmingly embarrassing Buck. We anticipate acts of violence. Instead, Buck writes a fairy tale play called Hank and Frank and strikes up a benign friendship with the middle-aged Hispanic woman (Lupe Ontiveros) who produces it at a children's theatre.

Chuck and Buck is an oddity from some very clever writers, accompanied by a 12-minute short by some other clever people. Paul Merton's The Suicidal Dog is a misanthropic comedy about the revenge enacted on a dislikeable, lower-middle-class Londoner by his neglected wife and his neutered terrier. The film is photographed by Britain's greatest Technicolor cameraman, the 86-year-old Jack Cardiff, who made his screen debut 82 years ago at the age of four and makes a fleeting appearance here at a funfair.

After the phenomenal success of The Sixth Sense , Bruce Willis must have been looking for another mystical screenplay involving himself and a child, though his own sixth sense should have told him that Disney's The Kid wasn't what he needed.

Presumably named to prevent confusion with Chaplin's The Kid, this whimsical comedy involves a workaholic Los Angeles image consultant being confronted by his eight-year-old self on the eve of his fortieth birthday. The plump lad has travelled through time to tell him that for all his apparent worldly success he hasn't become what his earlier self wanted to be, ie a married jet pilot with a family and a dog called Chester. It's a trite, sentimental piece, both confused and unoriginal.

From Australia comes the black comedy Siam Sunset, the ruthless tale of a British industrial chemist (the personable Linus Roache) who finds himself surrounded by disasters and calamities after he's widowed by a fridge falling from the skies on to his beloved wife.

Obsessed with mixing the eponymous paint that matches the colour of her hair, he takes a holiday in Australia and is stranded in the outback with fellow passengers on a rundown charabanc. The jokes derive from, among other catastrophes, car crashes, a venomous snake, starvation, an earthquake, a suicide, floods, broken limbs, and a villain who undergoes burns on an English Patient scale before being electrocuted.

Sadistic kids thrilled by Home Alone might love this movie. The location photography by Brian Breheny, who shot Priscilla, Queen of the Desert, is enchanting.

The jokes derive from, among other catastrophes, car crashes, a venomous snake, starvation, an earthquake, a suicide, floods, broken limbs, and a villain who undergoes burns on an English Patient scale before being electrocuted. Sadistic kids thrilled by Home Alone might love this movie. The location photography by Brian Breheny, who shot Priscilla, Queen of the Desert, is enchanting.

webTitle: Comedy review: French and Saunders - Live in 2000

fields.headline: Live, but only just
fields.standfirst: You can take French and Saunders off TV, but you can't take TV out of their stage act. More's the pity
fields.trailText: French and Saunders - Live in 2000, Hammersmith Apollo
fields.body:
French and Saunders - Live in 2000
Hammersmith Apollo until 18 November, then touring

After a decade on television, Dawn French and Jennifer Saunders have burst out of the box. Half-way through a national tour, their stage show, French & Saunders - Live in 2000, is now at the Apollo in Hammersmith. To their credit, they don't pretend, like the washed-up film stars currently busking in West End theatres, to have made the change because they crave contact with the public. French brusquely explains why they have ventured out of the tube: 'We have conservatories to pay for.' And what's a conservatory but a glazed, impenetrable shield, like a television screen?

In the show, they appear in person only as a last resort. After introductory fanfares, a TV set is trundled on to the stage. An amoeboid French and an insect-like Saunders greet us from its insulating screen. They begin with a supercilious reminder that we're pathetically real while they enjoy the virtual existence of celebrities. 'We're on television,' snaps French, 'you're not.' Only when the TV set blows up are they hauled out of hiding, annoyed at having to confront us.

Throughout the evening, they seem to be longing for a chance to retreat into the safety of the box, where success is guaranteed by a sycophantic track of pre-recorded laughter. Most of the sketches parody tabloid television programmes like Big Brother or Who Wants to be a Millionaire?, and the show ends with a screened anthology of clips from their BBC series, featuring routines based on films like The Exorcist or Whatever Happened to Baby Jane? The best joke of the evening is about a film, and it's shown on video. French, a gawky, giggling Hollywood reporter for a breakfast TV programme, attempts to interview the star of the sequel to Gladiator, who turns out to be Ann Widdecombe (French herself again, of course), with armoured boobs and a stentorian manner even more belligerent than Russell Crowe's.

There's a single, brief excursion into the dangerous unpredictability of live performance, when French top-heavily clambers down into the audience, supposedly to root out illicit guzzlers of chocolate bars. Interestingly, Saunders upbraids her for breaking the rules by recognising our existence. 'Don't do this!' she barks, as her partner wobbles on the stepladder which leads to the stalls. People all around me shrank when French approached, tracked by video cameras.

But unlike Dame Edna on her predatory sorties into our lower depths, French doesn't engage with the paying public. She removes a suitcase-sized slab of Dairy Milk from an accomplice planted on an aisle, then scurries back onto the stage, which, painted white, comfortingly resembles a television studio.

Thanks to Simon McBurney's ingenious direction, French and Saunders are able to play a series of duets with larger-than-life video facsimiles of themselves, projected on to the set's blank walls. In the Casualty spoof, they commute between stage and screen. As a pair of extras, they huddle in the wings daubing themselves with gruesome wounds, then gatecrash a scene in the medical drama, to the consternation of the pre-recorded actors. The sketch with the gossip columnist's report from Hollywood is also an accident-prone exchange between Saunders on stage (supposedly in a TV studio) and French on screen (supposedly live in LA, though she's merely posed against a slide of palm trees). It ends as they deal with an impromptu emergency: 30 seconds of dead air, which they hadn't budgeted for.

As a digital clock slowly ticks in the corner of the screen, Saunders squirms and French yawns. A good joke, but it perhaps reveals how uninterested they are in responding to momentary mischances, which ought to be the enlivening energy of stand-up comedy.

The show's introversion, sealed inside its small televisual world, is confirmed by its electronic gimmickry. Near the end, the screen displays an emailed argument between the two women, which, with typically self-admiring allusiveness, requires you to know about French's cuddly persona in The Vicar of Dibley. She signs her letter 'First Lady of the Priesthood'; Saunders transmits a reply to 'the Vicar of Fattytown'. The dispute is about whether French can appear in a TV commercial for Gap, which she subsequently does, jiving on stage while a chorus of cardboard cut-out Frenches smiles down on her from the screen. Here we have boxes crammed inside boxes.

Perhaps TV is the only experience we share, the small remnant of that common human understanding on which humour relies. When their jokes aren't knowingly self-reverential, they have no other recourse but smut. In their Home Shopping Network parody, they sell tacky mementoes from their current tour. French extols the virtues of a coffee mug, praises its 'nice chunky bottom' and smarms: 'I love a good rim.'

But pretty soon the double-entendres revert to commentary on their own recent careers. French says that the little mug is reliable, and snarls at Saunders: 'It'll never go off and make a comedy series on its own with Joanna Lumley!'

The climax comes when the screen consumes and eliminates the stage. Saunders, who's tiresomely angry throughout, at last literally goes up the wall during a tirade against French. She ends suspended 20 feet above the floor. But in this position, she's menaced by a gargantuan video version of French, who waddles forward into close-up, opens a mouth which occupies the entire screen and gobbles her up.

Earlier, French claims that Saunders never was a real human being: as she treacherously confides to the camera during the Big Brother sketch: 'I grew her from a crystal.' Yes, I know they're on TV and I'm not, but I couldn't help being grateful for that. At least I'm live; I'm still not sure, even after spending two hours in the same cavernous room with them, that they are.

webTitle: Classical reviews: The Palace in the Sky/French Triple Bill

fields.headline: A packed night in Hackney - and that's before you count the audience
fields.trailText: Classical: The Palace in the Sky/French Triple Bill
fields.body:
The Palace in the Sky
ENO Studio & Baylis Programme, Hackney Empire, London E8

French Triple Bill
Guildhall School of Music and Drama, London EC2

In one of those gleeful calibrations of gloom, Hackney, like Southwark, has been officially designated one of the poorest boroughs in Europe. Each of these pockets of urban despair, as we are taught to regard them, have had cause to cheer this week. Peckham's library won the Stirling prize for architecture. Hackney Empire, a huge and once glorious Frank Matcham theatre now in desperate need of its proposed £15m facelift, witnessed the world premiere of a new opera by Jonathan Dove, The Palace in the Sky.

The cast of hundreds ranged from tiny to teenaged to tottering. Pint-sized funky butterfly dancers jostled with cheeky, bottom pinching OAPs for stage space. Off-stage an assortment of local bands filled every spare inch of the theatre not occupied by the audience. Players from the English National Opera orchestra shared pit space with children from Hackney's Saturday Music Centre. The haunting, tinkling metallic timbre of saz (long-necked Turkish lutes), played by the Alevi Cultural and Community Centre Saz Ensemble, gave a touch of Islamic exoticism to the start and finish of this eclectic work.

Watching the faces of those involved, you would have to be seriously churlish not to enter into the mood. Their unflagging energy and enthusiasm kept the piece ablaze, despite the logistical difficulties of marshalling so many performers on and off stage. Nick Dear's text tells how a rich businessman, Parlaine (Keel Watson), wants to build the highest ever skyscraper on a city's last area of wasteland. The Valhalla towers of Kuala Lumpur and Canary Wharf colour his dreams. His curvaceous, opera-singer mistress (sharply portrayed by Sally June Gain) demands her own concert hall in the sky. The willowy female architect (Diana Moore) imagines awards and medals awaiting her. Only the old-time gangster, Jericho (Robert Tear), curses the enterprise. Dreams turn sour and a different tower is invoked when a mysterious height sickness turns them all into dim-witted speakers of gibberish. Work comes to a halt, the opera ends in quiet bemusement.

This scenario usefully provides musical opportunities, grabbed by Dove, for the various guilds of builders. All parade their wares in song and dance, each bearing the tools of their trade: masons, ironworkers, pipe fitters, steeplejacks and so forth. Dove's exuberant score, conducted by Stuart Stratford and directed by Jo Davies, has Broadway-style appeal, with echoes of Bernstein and John Adams plus some tear-jerking full-company choruses. His mastery in weaving all together and creating a coherent work with its own voice deserves admiration. By whatever oblique means, Hackney's children are being exposed to music and thriving on the encounter. Doubtless a small handful of talented teachers sweep their pupils along on the wave of their enthusiasm. There were even musical reserves to call upon; when a piece of fallen scenery held up proceedings on stage, the Hackney Youth Jazz Orchestra spontaneously played a couple of sets to entertain us. Here the ENO Studio and Baylis Programme proved that 'outreach' doesn't have to mean 'fobbed off'.

A couple of miles down the road at Guildhall School of Music and Drama 'community action' may not be the relevant phrase. Yet the opera department there does provide a particular service, using its privileged status as a conservatoire to mount works which would never surface in a mainstream opera house. The rarities were three short French works, by Debussy and Massenet, staged deftly by Stephen Langridge and designed by Jessica Curtis. Debussy's L'enfant prodigue, earned him the Prix de Rome in 1884 (his second attempt). This lush, symbolic lament of a mother (an expressive Katarina Jovanovic) for her lost son (Breffni Horgan) was originally intended only for concert performance. Though the ritual elements were somewhat California meets Middle East the piece proved truly stageworthy.

Massenet's Le portrait de Manon (1894) provides a short coda to the composer's celebrated opera Manon, written 10 years earlier. Never having lost sleep over the fate of the young Des Grieux, I admit to a certain lack of curiosity about what happened to him in his dotage, but the work was neatly staged with the crusty old chevalier elegantly sung by Hakan Vramso albeit in odd French. In the thunderous third work, La Navarraise, Massenet moves into verismo territory. The setting is the Carlist wars of 1874. A large orchestra belts our noisy tunes, just heard above the sound effects of battle. Anita, a peasant girl, assassinates the enemy leader in order to secure money for a dowry to marry her lover, the now wounded Araquil. He assumes she has earned it with her body. Only as he dies does he realise the truth: she's merely a murderer, not an adulterer. Oh the relief. She goes mad, laughs raucously over his corpse and collapses. This was a showpiece for Gweneth-Ann Jeffers as Anita, an exciting dramatic soprano and a name to watch. Clive Timms conducted, and the Guildhall Orchestra played with agreeably unruly verve. Few operas by Massenet are so action packed, or so mercifully short.

webTitle: Observer review: Radio

fields.headline: That's Shaw business
fields.trailText: Radio: The Admiral of the Night/Dear Mr Shaw/The Devil's disciple/Invisible Trumpets/The Sunday Format
fields.body:
The Admiral of the Night R4

Dear Mr Shaw R4

The Devil's disciple R3

Invisible Trumpets R4

The Sunday Format R4

If you are wearing a poppy the chances are you didn't listen to Peter Tinniswood's powerful one-hander about Remembrance Day, The Admiral of the Night, last Friday.

'I don't want to remember. I want to forget,' says Mr Derbyshire who survived the Somme unlike the 785 other members of his regiment. 'I don't want poppies falling soft and silent over my shoulders. What I want is crows, black crows, pecking and stabbing, feasting, ripping out eyes and entrails, gorging on twitching rising guts. That's all a dead man needs for comfort.'

And when they play the slow march signifying the ritual procession of royals, clerics and Ministers past the Cenotaph, he fires off a long savage raspberry, and the parting salvo: 'Up yours, you bastards.'

Tinniswood is wittier than Alan Ayckbourn, broader than Alan Bennett and in his own way as poetic as Tony Harrison. This was a story simply told about one man's Great War and it's tragic consequences, a modern postscript to Wilfred Owen's 'Dulce Et Decorum' and equally memorable. I wish I felt the same about George Bernard Shaw whose plays such as The Devil's Disciple (Radio 3) I find depressingly dated. Did British army officers in 1777 when the play was set really come out with exclamations like 'Oh poo poo poo'? General Burgoyne sounded more like a character from Lady Windermere's Fan . Shaw himself described the play as a threadbare melodrama which was polite compared to some of the reviews he wrote in his night job as a music critic.

In Invisible Trumpets (Radio 4) we were treated to some of those crits. Here's one of a choral symphony: '... for the most part it was a horrible tissue of puffing and blowing and wheezing and groaning and buzzing and hissing and gargling and shrieking and splattering and grunting and generally making every sort of noise that is incidental to bad singing.'

Easily the best thing about Shaw Week to commemorate the half century since his death was listening to Lorcan Cranitch play GBS with that mixture or irascibility and charm that captured Ellen Terry's heart.

It's only a matter of time I suppose before television snaps up the best radio comedy series for years and just as they did with the League of Gentlemen , can The Sunday Format (Radio 4 ) turn into a small screen flop. Trust me, it won't work. It's too original, too wordy, too clever. It's on every Tuesday: suck it and see for yourself.

webTitle: Christopher Hitchens's perfect scandal

fields.headline: The perfect scandal
fields.trailText: Christopher Hitchens, columnist for  Vanity Fair.
fields.body:
It must have money. It must have high-level skullduggery. It must show the powers that be as hypocritical fools. (The Reaganites had always said that they would never, but NEVER, negotiate with terrorists.) It should have sex or, if that's not possible, it should have a sex symbol. It should also have a name.

The perfect name was, of course, Watergate, and since then the race has been on to add a 'gate' suffix to any old fiasco. The tactic was originally evolved by William Safire, once a Nixon speechwriter and now a columnist, who hoped to minimise his boss's crimes. So one ought to be careful. But the fact is that the 'gate' business is irresistible. And when it was discovered that Monica Lewinsky actually lived in the Watergate building, well, what can you do?

A scandal should also have what journalists call 'legs'. That is to say, staying power. Bishop caught in brothel, politician caught taking bribe, Russian spy found in massage parlour with expired Visa card - these are over in a day. So the best way to begin is with a whopping lie, told by the politician concerned, that has to be peeled away like an onion and which discloses other scandalous things that nobody was even looking for. Watergate began with a burglary and ended with the disclosure that every conversation in Nixon's Oval Office was taped. Those tapes are still being released bit by bit and getting nastier all the time. I know people who have made careers out of this one story. It's the gift that keeps on giving.

Most newspaper readers think of scandals as interruptions to the routine or disruptions of business as usual. But my friend Michael Kinsley, now editor of Slate magazine, came up with the best line on this. 'The scandal about Washington isn't about what's illegal,' he said. 'It's about what's legal.' An ideal scandal is the one that reveals to us what our leaders really think of us; the fools they take us to be and the ease with which they get away with things.

I still see Oliver North around the place: he's a talk-show host. Five US presidents attended Richard Nixon's funeral. Bill Clinton is the most complacent and successful figure in America. The small fry suffer a bit, but they can usually start a line of accessories or publish a diet book. So the perfect scandal, sweet as it can be, requires a sour note. It reminds us yet again that laws are like cobwebs - strong enough to catch only the weak. If we realised that scandals are revelations of business as usual, instead of interruptions to it, we'd be nearer to what we don't seem to want: to be responsible ourselves rather than to chuckle with glee at revelations of the irresponsibility of our masters.

 Christopher Hitchens is a columnist for Vanity Fair. His most recent book is No One Left To Lie To: The Values of the Worst Family (£7, Verso)
