But my friend Michael Kinsley, now editor of Slate magazine, came up with the best line on this. 'The scandal about Washington isn't about what's illegal,' he said. 'It's about what's legal.' An ideal scandal is the one that reveals to us what our leaders really think of us; the fools they take us to be and the ease with which they get away with things. I still see Oliver North around the place: he's a talk-show host. Five US presidents attended Richard Nixon's funeral. Bill Clinton is the most complacent and successful figure in America. The small fry suffer a bit, but they can usually start a line of accessories or publish a diet book. So the perfect scandal, sweet as it can be, requires a sour note. It reminds us yet again that laws are like cobwebs - strong enough to catch only the weak. If we realised that scandals are revelations of business as usual, instead of interruptions to it, we'd be nearer to what we don't seem to want: to be responsible ourselves rather than to chuckle with glee at revelations of the irresponsibility of our masters.  Christopher Hitchens is a columnist for Vanity Fair. His most recent book is No One Left To Lie To: The Values of the Worst Family (£7, Verso)

webTitle: The loafer's guide to Les McKeown

fields.headline: The loafer's guide...
fields.standfirst: Les McKeown
fields.trailText: Les McKeown
fields.body:
Er... who? He sang in one of the biggest bands of the mid-70s, the prototype for the boy bands to follow - the Bay City Rollers. They had it all: five pretty boys (well, four plus a drummer with too many teeth), incomprehensible accents, a distinctive fashion style, millions of screaming girls. Les was the bad boy: fast cars, cute baseball boots, less embarrassing bog-brush haircut than the others. The Robbie Williams of his day.

And why should we be interested now? Well, like all postmodern celebrities, Les is multi-media now, and branching out into fashion. He's launched his own sports shoe, the Bay City Runner, with ultra-cool trainer label Acupuncture. Robbie Williams has apparently already asked for a pair.

You cannot be serious! No, really. We quote from Acupunture's press release: 'This space-age sneaker is built onto an all-new ultra-white version of the the best-selling Kunda sole unit. The Runner plays up to its Bay City heritage with a white fabric and tartan upper and US baseball-styled circle logo with Les's signature embroidered by the heel. And like a teenage rampager, this baby kicks ass!'

They are being ironic, right? Who can say? The launch party was in trendy Brick Lane, with London's coolest swapping the regulation combat trousers for tartan, and dancing to a soundtrack of 70s club hits played by McKeown and his pal, top club promoter Sean McLusky.

But still, this is a one-off... Hardly. Interest in the band has been mounting. Guardian music critic Caroline Sullivan's tale of twisted obsession, Bye Bye Baby - My Tragic Love Affair With the Bay City Rollers, may even make it onto film. Courtney Love has apparently optioned the rights.

What kind of people will wear these shoes? According to McKeown at the launch party, 'People with two feet!' (Good to see that the sharp wit we so revered in the heady days of the Shang-A-Lang TV series hasn't been blunted by time.)

webTitle: The cost of...

fields.headline: The cost of...
fields.standfirst: A holiday in space
fields.trailText: ...A holiday in space
fields.body:
Imagine: you're locked inside a tiny capsule for days. There is no shower and no real food. If the atmosphere inside is tense, then outside it just isn't there at all. And should that computer be looking at you like that? For $98,000 you, too, can share the terror of going into space. An American company expects commercial space flights to be available from 2003 - but they are currently offering zero-gravity flights for $5,400.

It is hard to see how their sums add up, as the most recent shuttle, Endeavor, cost $1.7bn, and one launch can burn up $100m to $400m. It has two Solid Rocket Boosters and 500,000 gallons of liquid oxygen and liquid hydrogen in the tank to help it hit 17,500mph.

Mir, the dilapidated Russian space station, may also become a tourist destination, thanks to private owners MirCorp. Annual maintenance expenses are $125m (so they'll be looking for more 'Citizen Explorers'), while the International Space Station, four times the size of Mir, has a budget of $60bn. Don't forget your EMU (Extravehicular Mobility Unit, or spacesuit). It can withstand temperatures of +250 F or -250 F, and a glove alone costs $20,000.

As for possible aliens, just remember that neither astronauts nor cosmonauts carry weapons. And sound doesn't travel in space, so no one will hear you scream.

Nasa's annual budget $14bn

Shuttle launch from $100m

International Space Station $60bn

webTitle: Go buy... Playstation 2

fields.headline: Go buy...
fields.standfirst: ...Playstation 2
fields.trailText: ...Playstation 2
fields.body:
Even if you long ago ceded mastery of the games console to the nimble-fingered youngsters of the house, you'll have heard of the Sony PlayStation. Chances are you've actually got one. Because although the Nintendo 64 may be faster, and the Sega Dreamcast have internet access, the PlayStation has something far more important - games, and lots of them. Enough, in fact, to see it installed in nearly 6m UK homes since its launch five years ago.

In the console industry, though, even things that aren't broke get fixed, which means that 24 November sees the release of a new, improved PlayStation 2. A £299 price tag might sound hefty (it's twice the cost of a Dreamcast), but Sony is confident it will have plenty of takers. Though only 200,000 PS2s will be available in the UK in time for Christmas, the company expects to have sold three million in Europe by the end of the financial year.

Why the optimism? Like the original, it will have plenty of games (33 on the launch day, 50 by the end of the year) and be backed by an enviable network of outside developers (360 companies are committed to producing PS2 games). It also promises 'backwards compatibility', meaning all your old PlayStation games will work on it - often with improved graphics and faster loading times. Unlike the original, it's a fully functioning CD and DVD player and has a soon-to-be-utilised high-speed internet connection.

Most importantly, the PlayStation 2 will be 'by far the most powerful games machine ever made'. Not just powerful, mind you, but sensitive, too. Sony's new 'emotion engine' processor makes games characters look realistic and act more lifelike, creating real empathy between player and game character. 'It'll be more like watching a video than playing a computer game,' claims a spokesman. 'When your character gets killed, you'll feel a real sense of loss.' Especially if it's Lara Croft.

 Sony PlayStation 2 will be available on pre-order at all major high-street retailers from 24 November, priced £299. Games cost from £9.99-£39.99

webTitle: Food and drink special: introduction

fields.headline: The global kitchen
fields.standfirst: Nigella Lawson's Oriental steak and kidney pud, Nigel Slater's Spanish-style spuds, Sybil Kapoor's guide to ethnic stores... We celebrate the diversity of British food and drink. Claudia Roden remembers arriving here in the 50s, when food was inedible and the best roast beef came from Cairo
fields.trailText: Nigella Lawson's Oriental steak and kidney pud, Nigel Slater's Spanish-style spuds, Sybil Kapoor's guide to ethnic stores... We celebrate the diversity of British food and drink. Claudia Roden remembers arriving here in the 50s, when food was inedible and the best roast beef...
fields.body:
When I came to London in the mid-50s, the food was horrifyingly bad. It was not entirely a culture shock because in Cairo I had been to the English School, where the Egyptian cooks gave us roast beef with gravy and Yorkshire pudding, steak and kidney pie, and jelly with custard.

The British did not like foreign food. Lord Carnarvon had regular hampers sent over from Harrods to Egypt and the excavator Flinders Petry, who could not afford Harrods hampers, lived on tins. Because of the heat, these were dangerous. He would throw the tin at the wall, and if it exploded he would not eat it.

When I started working on A Book of Middle Eastern Food in the late 60s, people would ask: 'Is it about sheep's eyeballs and testicles?' Looking at the first edition, I see substitutes for everything: 'If you can't find chickpeas, use beans' and explanations such as: 'Courgettes are baby marrows.' Our greatest treat then was to eat spaghetti Bolognese in Soho coffee houses, and mezze and grills in Cypriot kebab houses in Camden Town.

Today, British tastes have changed. London is one of the food capitals of the world. Every type of restaurant and food shop is represented. Going to east London's Stoke Newington and Green Lanes is like stepping into Turkey or Cyprus. The East End, Southall and Wembley in north London are a little India and little Pakistan, and Chinatown in Soho keeps expanding its borders. You even have Japanese supermarkets in the suburbs. (It's hard to believe that only a decade ago hardly anyone here would let raw fish pass their lips.)

Britain is the country which has, more than any other, adopted and integrated its immigrant cuisines (compare it to France and Italy, which have not integrated foreign foods). And people here are the most adventurous cooks in the world. They will attempt anything, and they carry it off very well. You can find hundreds of cookery books on every kind of food. When an ethnic dish is demonstrated on television, you'll find it at hundreds of dinner parties in the following weeks.

From bulgur and couscous to lemon-grass, okra and all kinds of unusual pasta, our supermarkets have a huge variety of ingredients never seen before. The chilled-food range at my local Marks & Spencer is like an ethnic-food emporium. Italian is the biggest seller, then comes Chinese, and Indian chicken tikka masala - chargrilled chicken in a creamy sauce - is the most popular Indian dish here, though Waitrose doesn't do it because it's not authentic. After Indian comes Middle Eastern (my mother was surprised once to find, at a friend's house, that some of the bought savouries were like hers).

Not long ago the British found Indian cooking smells so nauseous that they would not consider living next to an Asian family. Now curry is the national dish and chicken tikka is the nation's favourite sandwich. Curry houses, balti restaurants and Indian takeaways account for £2.5bn of trade. The Indian meal has become part of the British way of life, with football fans singing, 'Vindaloo! Vindaloo!'

The Jews had an early influence on the cooking of Britain. Fish and chips is their legacy. In 1968, the National Federation of Fish Friers presented a commemorative plaque to Malin's of Bow in the East End. Joseph Malin, newly arrived from eastern Europe, was the first to sell chips with fried fish in 1860. Following his example, Jewish fish and chip shops opened all around the country. Smoked salmon was the prime Jewish delicacy in Britain at the turn of the century. It was immigrants from Russia who brought the smoking techniques to London. Soon after the Second World War, immigrants from Vienna and Hungary opened pastry shops and coffee houses that popularised apple strudel, cheesecake and Danish pastries.

Middle Eastern, too, has become part of our own eclectic cooking, partly as a result of the Lebanese civil war and the revolution in Iran. Star chefs such as Peter Gordon, Alastair Little and the Clarks at Moro in Clerkenwell, serve Egyptian lentil soup, Lebanese tabbouleh, Moroccan pastilla, and all kinds of tagines and brik.

Food seems to be that part of an immigrant culture that immigrants hold on to longest - when they have abandoned the traditional dress, the language, the music. Instead of marginalising it, Britain has absorbed it and made it its own. Our cooking has become a true melting pot - the joint heritage of our multicultural society.

webTitle: Why the Ford Capri still inspires fanatical support

fields.headline: Motor heads
fields.standfirst: It first arrived on the scene in 1969 and summed up Seventies naff before you could say Bodie and Doyle. So why does the Ford Capri still inspire fanatical support?
fields.trailText: It first arrived on the scene in 1969 and summed up Seventies naff before you could say Bodie and Doyle. So why does the Ford Capri still inspire fanatical support?
fields.body:
Gorgeous motors. That is what they are. Gorgeous. The blokes all agree. There's nothing to beat a Capri. Gary, (tattoos down both arms, packet of Lamberts) he's had a Camaro, but he still prefers the Capri. Simon (sideburns, Lancashire accent) has owned them all his life, right from the MK1 he had when he was 19. Boy, was it fast - well, it would have been if he had been able to afford to drive it. The car cost £395, the insurance £275, which left him with only enough money to drive it to and from work. So, on his days off, he would just sit in it and listen to Human League. Chris has got three in his garden in Hungerford; Nick bought his from a man in Windsor for £3,200. 'It sits right,' he says.

Sitting right is about knowing Capris - about the whole thing, rather than just specs or looks - but it refers, roughly, to the Capri's centre of gravity, which is very low. You can pretend to be at Le Mans in some of them - especially the later models. And there is the added bonus of the tail swinging out police-chase style, when the roads are wet. It's lethal or exciting, depending on how you look at it. The blokes agree that that's part of the Capri experience, negotiating the corners.

So there's Nigel from Tilehurst and Danny from Newbury and Kevin who is late, owing to a cracked head (car not Kevin). Most of them are in their thirties, and a lot of them are mechanics. The Newbury and Thatcham Capri Club meet in the Berkshire Arms on the A4 once a month to swap Capri stories and talk tips. Lasers and Calypsos, Ghias and Cabarets, how Ford tried to sell the Probe as the Capri Mark IV, and it just wasn't. Genuine miles and gearboxes, Skorpion frames and con rods. Speak Capri. Speak callipers and carb manifold. It's a cigarette, a Coke and half an hour on adjustable front units.

Naomi's dad bought her Laser for £250. 'I hit a deer the other day,' she says. 'I've hit quite a few things, actually.'

The cars are all parked outside in a polished parade of wide-boy excellence. They are mostly Mk 111s, the later models, marketed between 1978 and 1987 - fast-back and low-slung with those nosy bonnets and elliptical windows that have made them a design classic. I prefer the Mk 11s myself, the breed of the 70s, clumpier maybe, but also more charismatic. This is poo-pooed, they rust like hell I am told, that's why you don't see so many of them about.

The blokes rate the early and late models. The RS3100, for instance, has achieved respect. A 1973 model, its prestige is partly due to its rarity (only 248 were made) and partly because of its history as a competition model. Designed to race in the European Touring Car championships, it arrived in Modena green with a powerful engine, duck-tail spoilers (for aerodynamic efficiency) and flat-dish steering wheel. What more could you want?

'They go for megabucks,' says Tony Cooper. 'Six thousand pounds at least!'

The Brooklands 280 is the other must- have model - designated classic status by the fact that everyone wants one. The last Capri to come out of the Ford factory in 1986, there were 1,038 of them, they were all green, and they were all fitted with a high-spec V.6 engine and a lot of trimmings. They now cost from £3,000 upwards.

What is it about the Capri? Why has this humble sports coupé inspired a loyalty so long and lasting that men all over England have taken it upon themselves to preserve its heritage, forming themselves into chapters from Wirral to Wellingborough?

Capri Club International, launched in 1983 by Warwickshire car salesman John Hill, now has 8,000 members who are offered a monthly magazine (with a problem page for those suffering 'misfire trouble') and a range of merchandise that includes Brooklands coasters and MK11 key rings.

Nevertheless, the Capri is not, in the automotive order of things, a great car, on a par, for instance, with the engineering of the E-Type or the beauty of the Aston.

Capri Mk1 arrived in 1969 and summed up the 70s before you could say Kool and the Gang. It was always a flash git, two-toned with metallic sheens, checked interiors, stripes, power bulges and alloy wheels. It was the car equivalent of the kipper tie, and it smoothed easily into a culture of Angel Delight and disco, but it never had secret-agent élan - it was never seen winding down a hill outside Monaco chasing a blonde in a headscarf. It never had that casino pizzazz. But there it is, polished and proud, preserved in forecourts, receiving the love of men. And women.

'I have wanted one since I was four,' says Naomi Roberts, now 21. 'Trying to cram big blokes in the back is a bit difficult, but you do feel proud driving one.'

When called to explain themselves, the blokes puff on their Royals, shrug and say, 'It's a legend, innit?' Pressed further, they each tend to make similar points. The Ford Capri looks fabulous, it is affordable, (both to buy and maintain), it is simple to soup up, the parts are easily available and it makes a great noise.

'You feel as if you are going very fast at 40 or 60,' says Simon Winns, who has put a Rover Vitesse engine in his to ensure entertaining velocity.

'You can repair them with three spanners,' says Jim Allen, who owns an immaculately restored 1986 model. 'They are simple and robust and the bits are interchangeable.'

'It does still have a stigma,' says Tony. 'You get a lot of, "Oh, it's a Trev's car," and, "Where are the furry dice ?"'

The Capri was given a glamorous gloss in its early advertisements; it was the Maserati for the working man. Campaigns arrived with the prediction that it was 'the car that you always promised yourself', and promoted a sleek image that would surely melt the froideur of the frostiest new-town girl. A lot of dads hankered after this glinting dream-mobile, so their sons thought they were cool and wanted the toy version. Now they are grown up, they have gone after the real thing.

That is one side of the story; the other is a kitsch credibility rejuvenated by the fashionable affection for all things 70s - the Mk11 featured on the 1974 episode of the BBC2 series I Love the 70s - and a lot can be blamed on the immortal eminence of The Professionals.

It was badly written, badly acted, badly lit, but the reverence devoted to this police drama is more mystifying than the Bermuda Triangle. Its monosyllabic characters, Bodie and Doyle, are the figureheads of Capri cool. This is more easily understood when one realises that the car stands out as being a great deal more beautiful and talented than any actor who appears in this series, a fact that is unwittingly acknowledged by Dave Matthews, whose website, The Authorised Guide to The Professionals , lovingly describes the role of each car in each story - from the silver Mk11 driven by Doyle in 'Stakeout' to the more familiar oyster gold Mk111 that zapped around the episodes of the 80s.

The sensual mixture of Martin Shaw and a mint-condition model has inspired some strange affairs in auto-jumbling circles. Alan Jarvis of Nottingham hired a private detective to track down two Capris that were used in five episodes of the series in 1981; one was found underneath a pile of old tyres; the other had been resprayed. Jarvis is said to have spent £25,000 restoring them.

Simon watches The Professionals every night on cable; a lot of the blokes grew up with it, of course, watching it after school when they were 10. 'It definitely helps, seeing them on the TV,' he says.

Bodie and Doyle never had a laugh (it's difficult to be amused with a gob full of cliché), but the fact is that the Capri is fun. This much is apparent, spinning around Thatcham with Jim Allen in his 'Injection Special' - a car that has received £10,000 worth of love and modifications and now has new cylinder heads, new camshaft, Momo steering wheel (as found in Ferraris), low-profile tyres (also found in Ferraris), electric windows and dashing blue stripes.

'He should be married to that car,' notes his wife, Jane, who was amazed when she arrived home to find her husband sawing £400-worth of new exhaust pipe in half because, 'it didn't look meaningful'.

As he eases the car away from his council house, I note a moan. 'Hear that whine?' he says, 'that's the aluminium timing gear. I don't know if I can live with it.'

Jim Allen, at 55, earns £8 an hour as a mechanic, but he has never grown out of Formula One fantasy - one of the highlights of his life was helping the Porsche team at Silverstone. 'I get a lump in my throat talking about it.'

He likes the car to throw him back in his seat at 70 - and, though the Capri is already unfriendly to back-seat passengers (unless they are circus dwarves), he would like to fit a roll cage in the back of his, like the ones the racing drivers have to prevent the roof caving in on them in the event of an accident.

'I am in the process of fitting a turbo charger - brake horse power - that's what it's all about,' he says. 'It could quite easily go 150mph.'

We howl on to the M4, and now I can see what it is all about. The Capri shrieks like a racing car and behaves like one.

'I'm not a boy-racer, I'm a geriatric racer,' says Jim, chain-smoking Dorchesters. 'It keeps me sane in this crap world. After a shit day at work, you can spend five hours messing about and it takes the stress away - you just think, "I am going to think about this now and nothing else."

The car cost £395, the insurance £275, which left him with only enough money to drive it to and from work. So, on his days off, he would just sit in it and listen to Human League. Chris has got three in his garden in Hungerford; Nick bought his from a man in Windsor for £3,200. 'It sits right,' he says. Sitting right is about knowing Capris - about the whole thing, rather than just specs or looks - but it refers, roughly, to the Capri's centre of gravity, which is very low. You can pretend to be at Le Mans in some of them - especially the later models. And there is the added bonus of the tail swinging out police-chase style, when the roads are wet. It's lethal or exciting, depending on how you look at it. The blokes agree that that's part of the Capri experience, negotiating the corners. So there's Nigel from Tilehurst and Danny from Newbury and Kevin who is late, owing to a cracked head (car not Kevin). Most of them are in their thirties, and a lot of them are mechanics. The Newbury and Thatcham Capri Club meet in the Berkshire Arms on the A4 once a month to swap Capri stories and talk tips. Lasers and Calypsos, Ghias and Cabarets, how Ford tried to sell the Probe as the Capri Mark IV, and it just wasn't. Genuine miles and gearboxes, Skorpion frames and con rods. Speak Capri. Speak callipers and carb manifold. It's a cigarette, a Coke and half an hour on adjustable front units. Naomi's dad bought her Laser for £250. 'I hit a deer the other day,' she says. 'I've hit quite a few things, actually.' The cars are all parked outside in a polished parade of wide-boy excellence. They are mostly Mk 111s, the later models, marketed between 1978 and 1987 - fast-back and low-slung with those nosy bonnets and elliptical windows that have made them a design classic. I prefer the Mk 11s myself, the breed of the 70s, clumpier maybe, but also more charismatic. This is poo-pooed, they rust like hell I am told, that's why you don't see so many of them about. The blokes rate the early and late models. The RS3100, for instance, has achieved respect. A 1973 model, its prestige is partly due to its rarity (only 248 were made) and partly because of its history as a competition model. Designed to race in the European Touring Car championships, it arrived in Modena green with a powerful engine, duck-tail spoilers (for aerodynamic efficiency) and flat-dish steering wheel. What more could you want? 'They go for megabucks,' says Tony Cooper. 'Six thousand pounds at least!' The Brooklands 280 is the other must- have model - designated classic status by the fact that everyone wants one. The last Capri to come out of the Ford factory in 1986, there were 1,038 of them, they were all green, and they were all fitted with a high-spec V.6 engine and a lot of trimmings. They now cost from £3,000 upwards. What is it about the Capri? Why has this humble sports coupé inspired a loyalty so long and lasting that men all over England have taken it upon themselves to preserve its heritage, forming themselves into chapters from Wirral to Wellingborough? Capri Club International, launched in 1983 by Warwickshire car salesman John Hill, now has 8,000 members who are offered a monthly magazine (with a problem page for those suffering 'misfire trouble') and a range of merchandise that includes Brooklands coasters and MK11 key rings. Nevertheless, the Capri is not, in the automotive order of things, a great car, on a par, for instance, with the engineering of the E-Type or the beauty of the Aston. Capri Mk1 arrived in 1969 and summed up the 70s before you could say Kool and the Gang. It was always a flash git, two-toned with metallic sheens, checked interiors, stripes, power bulges and alloy wheels. It was the car equivalent of the kipper tie, and it smoothed easily into a culture of Angel Delight and disco, but it never had secret-agent élan - it was never seen winding down a hill outside Monaco chasing a blonde in a headscarf. It never had that casino pizzazz. But there it is, polished and proud, preserved in forecourts, receiving the love of men. And women. 'I have wanted one since I was four,' says Naomi Roberts, now 21. 'Trying to cram big blokes in the back is a bit difficult, but you do feel proud driving one.' When called to explain themselves, the blokes puff on their Royals, shrug and say, 'It's a legend, innit?' Pressed further, they each tend to make similar points. The Ford Capri looks fabulous, it is affordable, (both to buy and maintain), it is simple to soup up, the parts are easily available and it makes a great noise. 'You feel as if you are going very fast at 40 or 60,' says Simon Winns, who has put a Rover Vitesse engine in his to ensure entertaining velocity. 'You can repair them with three spanners,' says Jim Allen, who owns an immaculately restored 1986 model. 'They are simple and robust and the bits are interchangeable.' 'It does still have a stigma,' says Tony. 'You get a lot of, "Oh, it's a Trev's car," and, "Where are the furry dice ?"' The Capri was given a glamorous gloss in its early advertisements; it was the Maserati for the working man. Campaigns arrived with the prediction that it was 'the car that you always promised yourself', and promoted a sleek image that would surely melt the froideur of the frostiest new-town girl. A lot of dads hankered after this glinting dream-mobile, so their sons thought they were cool and wanted the toy version. Now they are grown up, they have gone after the real thing. That is one side of the story; the other is a kitsch credibility rejuvenated by the fashionable affection for all things 70s - the Mk11 featured on the 1974 episode of the BBC2 series I Love the 70s - and a lot can be blamed on the immortal eminence of The Professionals. It was badly written, badly acted, badly lit, but the reverence devoted to this police drama is more mystifying than the Bermuda Triangle. Its monosyllabic characters, Bodie and Doyle, are the figureheads of Capri cool. This is more easily understood when one realises that the car stands out as being a great deal more beautiful and talented than any actor who appears in this series, a fact that is unwittingly acknowledged by Dave Matthews, whose website, The Authorised Guide to The Professionals , lovingly describes the role of each car in each story - from the silver Mk11 driven by Doyle in 'Stakeout' to the more familiar oyster gold Mk111 that zapped around the episodes of the 80s. The sensual mixture of Martin Shaw and a mint-condition model has inspired some strange affairs in auto-jumbling circles. Alan Jarvis of Nottingham hired a private detective to track down two Capris that were used in five episodes of the series in 1981; one was found underneath a pile of old tyres; the other had been resprayed. Jarvis is said to have spent £25,000 restoring them. Simon watches The Professionals every night on cable; a lot of the blokes grew up with it, of course, watching it after school when they were 10. 'It definitely helps, seeing them on the TV,' he says. Bodie and Doyle never had a laugh (it's difficult to be amused with a gob full of cliché), but the fact is that the Capri is fun. This much is apparent, spinning around Thatcham with Jim Allen in his 'Injection Special' - a car that has received £10,000 worth of love and modifications and now has new cylinder heads, new camshaft, Momo steering wheel (as found in Ferraris), low-profile tyres (also found in Ferraris), electric windows and dashing blue stripes. 'He should be married to that car,' notes his wife, Jane, who was amazed when she arrived home to find her husband sawing £400-worth of new exhaust pipe in half because, 'it didn't look meaningful'. As he eases the car away from his council house, I note a moan. 'Hear that whine?' he says, 'that's the aluminium timing gear. I don't know if I can live with it.' Jim Allen, at 55, earns £8 an hour as a mechanic, but he has never grown out of Formula One fantasy - one of the highlights of his life was helping the Porsche team at Silverstone. 'I get a lump in my throat talking about it.' He likes the car to throw him back in his seat at 70 - and, though the Capri is already unfriendly to back-seat passengers (unless they are circus dwarves), he would like to fit a roll cage in the back of his, like the ones the racing drivers have to prevent the roof caving in on them in the event of an accident. 'I am in the process of fitting a turbo charger - brake horse power - that's what it's all about,' he says. 'It could quite easily go 150mph.' We howl on to the M4, and now I can see what it is all about. The Capri shrieks like a racing car and behaves like one. 'I'm not a boy-racer, I'm a geriatric racer,' says Jim, chain-smoking Dorchesters. 'It keeps me sane in this crap world. After a shit day at work, you can spend five hours messing about and it takes the stress away - you just think, "I am going to think about this now and nothing else."

webTitle: Interview: the government's drugs tsar Keith Hellawell

fields.headline: A man of substance
fields.standfirst: To some activists, he's the Princess Di of the chemical generation. To the Daily Mail, he's a waste of his six-figure salary. To Tony Blair, he's the main weapon in the war on drugs. In the week of Keith Hellawell's annual report, Sheryl Garratt goes on the road with the government's tsar
fields.trailText: To some activists, he's the Princess Di of the chemical generation. To the Daily Mail, he's a waste of his six-figure salary. To Tony Blair, he's the main weapon in the war on drugs. In the week of Keith Hellawell's annual report, Sheryl Garratt goes on the road with the government's tsar.
fields.body:
It's a blustery morning in a Liverpool suburb and I'm accompanying the government's drugs tsar Keith Hellawell into the centre of a major international drugs organisation. It's a bit disappointing, really. A small, cramped office with four tatty desks and headache-inducing strip lighting. Here, unpaid volunteers offer phone counselling to desperate people from all over the UK and abroad. The callers tell the familiar stories of addiction. The shame. The misery. The lies to friends and family. A volunteer shows Hellawell an entry in her log detailing one addict's prodigious chemical intake, and he shakes his head. 'It's amazing what the human body can put up with.' Another - a former addict himself - talks of people committing suicide due to sudden withdrawal.

But it isn't what you may think. This is the Council for Involuntary Tranquilliser Addiction, and the mind-altering substances they deal with are perfectly legal - given by doctors to help with sleeplessness or stress. It may surprise you that the government's Anti-Drugs Coordinator sees this as part of his remit. (He hates the term 'tsar', by the way, and gently corrects anyone who uses it.) But he is clear that it is. 'We shouldn't distinguish between substances,' he says. 'Just because it's prescribed and legal doesn't make it safe.'

Our first meeting a few days earlier hadn't gone particularly well. We'd met in his shabbily grand wood-panelled room in the Cabinet Office. Hellawell was running late, and my scheduled two hours had been whittled down to one. He was courteous, talkative, expounding on his 10-year plan for tackling drugs, but the whole thing felt like sliding on a polished surface without ever seeing what lay beneath. When I suggested following him around for a few days, he seemed almost boyishly keen. 'People are surprised at how the community takes to me. They think I sit in an office, but I'm always out.'

In Liverpool, it's easy to see why he was so enthusiastic. Imposing without ever being intimidating, Hellawell is good at the kind of bland jokes and pleasantries that put people at ease. He asks intelligent questions and listens carefully to the answers, making notes to take back to the relevant ministers. In the car afterwards, he feels this visit went well. Sometimes when he sees small voluntary groups, frustrations bubble over and he can feel like he's under attack. 'It's as if you should have gone in wearing body armour.'

Nonetheless, Hellawell feels that such visits are a crucial part of his job, to explain his strategies and show people that he is listening. In the media, his rather mild and sensible views are often portrayed as 'controversial'. To many in the drugs field, impatient for a more radical agenda, he's a patsy put in place by a government with no idea how to react to the fact that drugs have become just another leisure activity. 'He's the Princess Di of the chemical generation,' says one cynic, 'travelling around the country getting his picture taken and giving out sympathy.'

Drugs. A simple five-letter word, but one of our most emotive. Put it on the cover of a youth magazine, and you sell thousands more copies. Put it in a newspaper headline, and you have a story that thrills and frightens. Shout it out at the Tory conference with a promise of new penalties, and you have them eating out of your hand. (Although recent events may have changed that.) Hellawell himself rarely uses the word, preferring the more neutral 'substances'. The education programmes he plans for schools cover everything from the solvents that kill around 80 children a year to the biggest killers, alcohol and tobacco, as well as the illegal substances most people think of when they hear the word drugs. In his strategy documents, he stresses too that not all substances are equally bad: the emphasis is firmly on what he calls 'the drugs that actually do cause the pain and harm and criminality' - heroin and cocaine.

Hellawell recalls the first drugs deaths he saw. He was a raw young police officer then, and didn't even know what heroin was. They were a husband and wife from Huddersfield - both doctors, one of the few groups with access to the substance in the early 60s - and he remembers looking at their emaciated bodies, wondering why intelligent people might do this to themselves. We'd be wrong to read too much into it, he says; this wasn't a pivotal moment for him. Police officers see all kinds of things the rest of us don't.

Early in his police career, the consensus was that the best way to deal with drugs was to arrest everyone for everything. 'We were very intolerant,' he says. 'We'd take the contents of somebody's handbag or pockets and even tiny grains, if it could be proved that it was cannabis we would prosecute, feeling that we could criminalise it out of the system. Clearly, we didn't. And that doesn't address the issues of attraction to drugs, of people being destroyed by drugs.' He no longer believes that locking people up is the solution. Put an addict through successful treatment, he says, and you stop them committing crimes to finance their habit. Or dealing and creating new users. You improve their lives, but also the lives of their families and the community in which they live. He's negotiated more money for treatment than ever before. So much that he claims the problem now is not lack of funds for detox projects, but a shortage of trained staff to run them.

Sefton, Merseyside. The Independence Initiative is an innovative community detox project. As the director gives a presentation on their work, Hellawell sits on the edge of his seat, completely absorbed. Afterwards, he gives a speech. He always talks off the cuff, which worries his wife Brenda before big events. But he finds it easier that way, more natural. He stresses his continuing support for treatment but also explains new initiatives to seize drugs and the money made from selling them. As well as detecting drugs coming into the country, they've trained dogs to find large wads of money going out. In 12 weeks at Heathrow, two dogs helped customs confiscate £10m. Hellawell repeats this figure gleefully. 'Twelve weeks. One airport. Two dogs. Ten million.' All I can think is how much cash must be flowing out of other airports, as well as on ferries and trains, and how it could ever be possible to halt such a lucrative trade.

While Hellawell fields more questions about cannabis from local journalists, I talk to Dene, one of the project's successes. Until recently, he was in a wheelchair. He's been dead once - the hospital had to restart his heart. Dene was lucky. This flagship project didn't just help him detox. They encouraged him to join a gym, and build up his wasted muscles. He found an interest in photography. Before, his only friends were other junkies. But the project helped him forge a new social life, and even though his brother lived with him and was still using, he wasn't tempted back on to the gear. Now he's walking with a stick, enjoying his life, thinking of giving up cigarettes. 'My only remaining vice,' he says proudly.

Before leaving, Hellawell makes a point of coming over to shake Dene's hand. Someone later tells me that, on his first visits to Merseyside, he caused a stir by talking more with the drug users and their families than the assembled suits. Everywhere I saw him go, he made time for the addicts and their families. He didn't judge, he didn't patronise, he didn't gush with sympathy. He talks to them as people, he shrugs. 'That's just how I am.'

Keith Hellawell was born in Holmfirth, Huddersfield on 18 May 1942. He's uncomfortable talking about his background, though sometimes he'll mention it briefly, just to make sure people know he's not too grand. His dad was a baker, his mother a mill-worker who moonlighted as a singer. They separated when he was four, and he diplomatically describes his childhood as 'difficult'. He was left to fend for himself, and when pressured he'll describe a crowded tenement where violence and petty crime were routine, money was scarce and he learned survival skills early.

He went down the local pit at the age of 15, leaving school with a final report that said: 'Keith excelled at sport, and little else.' Five years later, he fulfilled his childhood ambition to become a police officer and soon after married Brenda, who has clearly been a great support. In the force, he seemed to find his calling. He excelled in exams to such a degree that at first he was accused of cheating; when it became obvious that he was a natural, he was fast-tracked through the ranks. By 1965, he was the youngest sergeant in the country; a year later, the youngest inspector. He studied for a degree in law and a MSc in social policy in his own time, and his inexorable rise continued. He was deputy chief constable of Humberside by 1985; chief constable of Cleveland by 1990; chief constable of West Yorkshire by 1993. When I ask if he encountered a lot of resentment as an ex-miner rising through the ranks, he answers without hesitation. 'Yes,' he says. 'But that's life.'

What his background seems to have given him was empathy, an understanding of those he policed. He hates what he calls 'inconsistencies', people being treated differently due to class, race or other differences. As chief constable, he closed down police-station bars, saying that if officers wanted to drink, they should go to a pub like everyone else. When the young were being demonised by a Tory government keen for scapegoats, he stated that most juvenile crime was committed by a handful of repeat offenders. He has called for the legalisation of brothels. But most of all, he has spoken about drugs. As early as 1969, he filed a report suggesting setting up a dedicated drugs squad. He spoke for the Association of Chief Police Officers on drugs issues, and was one of the first authority figures to acknowledge that most people took drugs recreationally not because they were weak or stupid, but because it was fun.

For a long time, all controlled substances were considered equal. There is a problem with this, Hellawell points out. All drugs are clearly not the same. And legal substances can often cause comparable harm. Although saying such things can be difficult: 'It's still a very highly charged political issue.'

But this, in the end, is the contradiction that sank Anne Widdecombe. Slurping champagne onstage after promising £100 fines for cannabis users was, perhaps, a hypocrisy too far. Hellawell will not be drawn into criticising her personally, though he says he can talk about the issues. 'The extreme zero-tolerance view just won't work.' Still, he sees the debate as a distraction from the real issues. 'Cannabis can't be legalised because the international community says it cannot.' Although some European countries are liberalising their laws, he argues that this isn't necessary in the UK. Most people now caught with cannabis here are simply cautioned. No one is sitting in prison simply for puffing a joint.

Later in the week, we drive from his first meeting of the day in Leeds on to Stockton on Tees. In the car with no government press officer present, he seems relaxed for the first time, chatting and sharing interesting facts from his briefing papers. He's still a good-looking man, tall with an affluent tan, a well-groomed moustache, sharp cheekbones and even sharper suits. Until he was 45, he stayed fit by running marathons, but he had to give it up after suffering a severe back injury in a car accident. He often jokes about putting on weight, but although I'm with him for two full days, I never see him eat. He tends to have only an evening meal, he explains, a habit picked up in his first job. If he ate down the pit, bending to work used to make him sick.

When the post of Anti-Drugs Coordinator was announced by the New Labour government, it seemed to have been created with Hellawell in mind. In fact, he says he didn't even apply until the last minute, and then only after long discussions with his wife. He was happy in West Yorkshire - it paid well and though the hours could be long, Brenda could accompany him to any evening social engagements he had to attend. But it seemed to both of them that if he could be of service, then he should. His critics carp about his big salary, his lack of real power. They tend to portray him as man addicted to junkets, travelling abroad at the slightest pretext, touring the country in search of publicity while waiting out his time until retirement and the inevitable knighthood. But he wearily tells me he finds the travelling tiring, and he obviously misses his home in the north. His life in London is fairly solitary - by choice, he is quick to add. He describes himself as 'reserved'. When he first took the job, he was invited to parties and functions, but he finds them difficult without his wife at his side. When he has to be in the capital he stays at his club, but whenever possible he goes home to his converted farmhouse with a swimming pool in the Yorkshire countryside.

He was 56 when he took the job. When I ask if he's planning to see his 10-year plan through, he laughs at the absurdity of the idea. He has a new three-year contract, but seems to hint that he may not finish it. He sees his job as opening up the debate, establishing budgets, getting the various agencies to work together, setting up structures so that others can take over the work and make it their own. Hellawell serves another useful purpose for the government, of course - he distances them from a difficult issue.

So, while the Shadow Cabinet confessed their youthful indiscretions after the Widdecombe debacle, Labour left Hellawell to do the talking. It was he who pointed out that cannabis doesn't always act as a gateway to other drugs, and he who took the resulting flak. The Sun lined up heroin addicts to say they had started on cannabis (which is a bit like an alcoholic insisting that a first sip of cider inevitably leads to meths); the Mail 's headline trumpeted his £107,000 salary and asked 'What is the point of this man?'. This kind of coverage upsets his family, he says, particularly his son, who often wonders why he doesn't just walk away.

He regrets not having more time for his son and two daughters. School plays, parents nights, sports days - Brenda did all of those, he says wistfully, he was never there. There are seven grandchildren now, with twins on the way in two weeks' time, and you get the feeling that he'd rather not be away in London while they grow up.

Friday. Stockton-on-Tees Town Hall. The 20 or so people clustered round the council table do not want to talk about cannabis. This area has a large number of heroin addicts, and few resources as yet to help them. 'My son has been on heroin for six years,' says one woman emotionally. 'In my extended family, there are another six on heroin. Their children are growing up now, and seeing it as a way of life. And that is where the dealers are going. They've already got our sons and daughters. Now they're going for our grandchildren.' Hellawell answers points made by GPs, councillors and police officers calmly and clearly. To the addicts' parents, all he can say is that the money is there, that treatment will come. 'It takes time. It just takes time.'

Later we drive out to a community centre in nearby Thornaby to listen to the worries of residents. They are quiet, respectable, concerned. The stories they tell are harrowing. Heroin use is epidemic here, and few families are untouched by it. A pretty 17-year-old girl stands up to beg for residential detox. They have no access to such facilities. She quickly dissolves into tears. Painfully thin, she's been on heroin since she was 14. Her boyfriend is also a user. She cannot look after their baby any more, and her mother has had to take over. 'I feel so guilty!' she sobs. 'I don't know why my family puts up with me.' Hellawell has nothing new to offer in the face of such misery. He repeats that the money is there, that treatment is coming. And acknowledges that this is little comfort to people who are living - and dying - with these problems. While the media trawl the toilets in Parliament for grains of cocaine, argue about cannabis, or pretend that Ecstasy is killing our young in droves, this is the reason Hellawell took this post, the real problem he has to address.

'Our children are committing slow suicide - we need more than just words,' says Tina Williams, one of the Thornaby mothers. 'Words aren't going to save a life. He might be a nice man, but he's got to deliver.'

Everywhere I saw him go, he made time for the addicts and their families. He didn't judge, he didn't patronise, he didn't gush with sympathy. He talks to them as people, he shrugs. 'That's just how I am.' Keith Hellawell was born in Holmfirth, Huddersfield on 18 May 1942. He's uncomfortable talking about his background, though sometimes he'll mention it briefly, just to make sure people know he's not too grand. His dad was a baker, his mother a mill-worker who moonlighted as a singer. They separated when he was four, and he diplomatically describes his childhood as 'difficult'. He was left to fend for himself, and when pressured he'll describe a crowded tenement where violence and petty crime were routine, money was scarce and he learned survival skills early. He went down the local pit at the age of 15, leaving school with a final report that said: 'Keith excelled at sport, and little else.' Five years later, he fulfilled his childhood ambition to become a police officer and soon after married Brenda, who has clearly been a great support. In the force, he seemed to find his calling. He excelled in exams to such a degree that at first he was accused of cheating; when it became obvious that he was a natural, he was fast-tracked through the ranks. By 1965, he was the youngest sergeant in the country; a year later, the youngest inspector. He studied for a degree in law and a MSc in social policy in his own time, and his inexorable rise continued. He was deputy chief constable of Humberside by 1985; chief constable of Cleveland by 1990; chief constable of West Yorkshire by 1993. When I ask if he encountered a lot of resentment as an ex-miner rising through the ranks, he answers without hesitation. 'Yes,' he says. 'But that's life.' What his background seems to have given him was empathy, an understanding of those he policed. He hates what he calls 'inconsistencies', people being treated differently due to class, race or other differences. As chief constable, he closed down police-station bars, saying that if officers wanted to drink, they should go to a pub like everyone else. When the young were being demonised by a Tory government keen for scapegoats, he stated that most juvenile crime was committed by a handful of repeat offenders. He has called for the legalisation of brothels. But most of all, he has spoken about drugs. As early as 1969, he filed a report suggesting setting up a dedicated drugs squad. He spoke for the Association of Chief Police Officers on drugs issues, and was one of the first authority figures to acknowledge that most people took drugs recreationally not because they were weak or stupid, but because it was fun. For a long time, all controlled substances were considered equal. There is a problem with this, Hellawell points out. All drugs are clearly not the same. And legal substances can often cause comparable harm. Although saying such things can be difficult: 'It's still a very highly charged political issue.' But this, in the end, is the contradiction that sank Anne Widdecombe. Slurping champagne onstage after promising £100 fines for cannabis users was, perhaps, a hypocrisy too far. Hellawell will not be drawn into criticising her personally, though he says he can talk about the issues. 'The extreme zero-tolerance view just won't work.' Still, he sees the debate as a distraction from the real issues. 'Cannabis can't be legalised because the international community says it cannot.' Although some European countries are liberalising their laws, he argues that this isn't necessary in the UK. Most people now caught with cannabis here are simply cautioned. No one is sitting in prison simply for puffing a joint. Later in the week, we drive from his first meeting of the day in Leeds on to Stockton on Tees. In the car with no government press officer present, he seems relaxed for the first time, chatting and sharing interesting facts from his briefing papers. He's still a good-looking man, tall with an affluent tan, a well-groomed moustache, sharp cheekbones and even sharper suits. Until he was 45, he stayed fit by running marathons, but he had to give it up after suffering a severe back injury in a car accident. He often jokes about putting on weight, but although I'm with him for two full days, I never see him eat. He tends to have only an evening meal, he explains, a habit picked up in his first job. If he ate down the pit, bending to work used to make him sick. When the post of Anti-Drugs Coordinator was announced by the New Labour government, it seemed to have been created with Hellawell in mind. In fact, he says he didn't even apply until the last minute, and then only after long discussions with his wife. He was happy in West Yorkshire - it paid well and though the hours could be long, Brenda could accompany him to any evening social engagements he had to attend. But it seemed to both of them that if he could be of service, then he should. His critics carp about his big salary, his lack of real power. They tend to portray him as man addicted to junkets, travelling abroad at the slightest pretext, touring the country in search of publicity while waiting out his time until retirement and the inevitable knighthood. But he wearily tells me he finds the travelling tiring, and he obviously misses his home in the north. His life in London is fairly solitary - by choice, he is quick to add. He describes himself as 'reserved'. When he first took the job, he was invited to parties and functions, but he finds them difficult without his wife at his side. When he has to be in the capital he stays at his club, but whenever possible he goes home to his converted farmhouse with a swimming pool in the Yorkshire countryside. He was 56 when he took the job. When I ask if he's planning to see his 10-year plan through, he laughs at the absurdity of the idea. He has a new three-year contract, but seems to hint that he may not finish it. He sees his job as opening up the debate, establishing budgets, getting the various agencies to work together, setting up structures so that others can take over the work and make it their own. So, while the Shadow Cabinet confessed their youthful indiscretions after the Widdecombe debacle, Labour left Hellawell to do the talking. It was he who pointed out that cannabis doesn't always act as a gateway to other drugs, and he who took the resulting flak. The Sun lined up heroin addicts to say they had started on cannabis (which is a bit like an alcoholic insisting that a first sip of cider inevitably leads to meths); the Mail 's headline trumpeted his £107,000 salary and asked 'What is the point of this man?'. This kind of coverage upsets his family, he says, particularly his son, who often wonders why he doesn't just walk away. He regrets not having more time for his son and two daughters. School plays, parents nights, sports days - Brenda did all of those, he says wistfully, he was never there. There are seven grandchildren now, with twins on the way in two weeks' time, and you get the feeling that he'd rather not be away in London while they grow up. Friday. Stockton-on-Tees Town Hall. The 20 or so people clustered round the council table do not want to talk about cannabis. This area has a large number of heroin addicts, and few resources as yet to help them. 'My son has been on heroin for six years,' says one woman emotionally. 'In my extended family, there are another six on heroin. Their children are growing up now, and seeing it as a way of life. And that is where the dealers are going. They've already got our sons and daughters. Now they're going for our grandchildren.' Hellawell answers points made by GPs, councillors and police officers calmly and clearly. To the addicts' parents, all he can say is that the money is there, that treatment will come. 'It takes time. It just takes time.' Later we drive out to a community centre in nearby Thornaby to listen to the worries of residents. They are quiet, respectable, concerned. The stories they tell are harrowing. Heroin use is epidemic here, and few families are untouched by it. A pretty 17-year-old girl stands up to beg for residential detox. They have no access to such facilities. She quickly dissolves into tears. Painfully thin, she's been on heroin since she was 14. Her boyfriend is also a user. She cannot look after their baby any more, and her mother has had to take over. 'I feel so guilty!' she sobs. 'I don't know why my family puts up with me.' Hellawell has nothing new to offer in the face of such misery. He repeats that the money is there, that treatment is coming. And acknowledges that this is little comfort to people who are living - and dying - with these problems. While the media trawl the toilets in Parliament for grains of cocaine, argue about cannabis, or pretend that Ecstasy is killing our young in droves, this is the reason Hellawell took this post, the real problem he has to address. 'Our children are committing slow suicide - we need more than just words,' says Tina Williams, one of the Thornaby mothers. 'Words aren't going to save a life. He might be a nice man, but he's got to deliver.'

webTitle: Food and drink special: Nigella Lawson

fields.headline: Like mother (never) used to make
fields.standfirst: Old-fashioned British cooking is alive and well. But there's no need to stick with tradition. Nigella Lawson gives four culinary classics a 21st-century twist
fields.trailText: Old-fashioned British cooking is alive and well. But there's no need to stick with tradition. Nigella Lawson gives four culinary classics a 21st-century twist.
fields.body:
Perhaps I'm being oversensitive, but sometimes when I extol the virtues of trad British cooking, I feel as if I might as well be suggesting we get together on a National Front march. People are embarrassed: I see that, but frankly I have no desire to be saddled with their embarrassment. In the kitchen, at least, I think it's time we got rid of our post-colonial guilt. The recipes below are all irreproachable in their orthodox state. I haven't fiddled out of a desire to improve or to impose self-conscious modernity, but simply because other, more newly available ingredients naturally offered themselves.

Whitebait with salsa

When I was a child, whitebait was the restaurant starter; now it seems to have disappeared. So much is this the case that I feel I need to explain what I'm talking about. Whitebait are small fish, indeed, the original 'small fry', and it's the size rather than the genus that's significant. The cooking is minimal: the fish are dredged in flour, plunged into hot fat and piled on to a pile of deep-fried parsley (the old, curly kind), a squeeze of lemon, and bread and butter.

The other day I substituted coriander for parsley (that's what I had in the fridge) and served a spiky, aromatic salsa alongside the fish. It works wonderfully. But using limes in place of lemon, chilli where it used to be cayenne, amplifies rather than alters the balance of the dish. Serves 2 as a main course (or 1, if am that one) or 4 as a starter.

Oil for frying (I used about 3 litres vegetable oil)
500g whitebait
100g plain flour
salt and pepper for seasoning the flour
Maldon salt for sprinkling over

for the salsa

3 long red chillies, de-seeded and finely chopped
4 spring onions, halved and finely chopped
12 small vine tomatoes, preferably Vittoria, seeded and chopped
juice of 2 limes
chopped leaves from 1 bunch of coriander (some of which will be used, above, for deep-frying)
salt to taste

This is a very quick operation, so get the oil on to heat up before you do anything else. I use my deep-fat fryer (heated to 190 C), but otherwise fill a suitable pan, with a basket, and put it on the hob. Meanwhile, combine all of the salsa ingredients together, and let the flavours develop while you do the fish. Remember to keep some coriander aside.

Put the fish and seasoned flour into a freezer bag and toss everything around to coat the fish. Shake off the excess flour by turning it all out into a sieve, then plunge the fish into the hot oil. Cook for about 3 minutes or until they look crispy and tempting.

Turn out on to kitchen towel, and while the whitebait is degreasing itself, throw a small handful of coriander into the hot fat to deep-fry. Pile the whitebait on to a plate and sprinkle over some Maldon salt. When the leaves have turned a very dark green, a mere minute or so, fish them out, drain on some kitchen towel and scatter over the whitebait . Put the salsa in a bowl on the table alongside, or else, dollop it on to the whitebait plate.

Steak and kidney pudding

You may think, first off, that a steak and kidney pudding made with a thick suet crust is not the sort of food you eat. All I can say is, cook it and you'll change your mind. The ridiculous thing is that one assume that anything made with suet will be dense and stodgy, but in fact it gives an almost ethereal lightness. That's only the case if it's eaten immediately - but eat fast, and you'll be safe by the time you get around to second helpings.

I always use vegetable suet, as I don't like eating meat stuff the derivation of which I do not know. While suet crust is easy to make (just stir together flour, suet and water and roll it out; it's naturally pliable), you must make it at the last minute: this is the only pastry that shouldn't be left to rest at all.

The stock I use is most often the fresh-tubbed sort made by Joubère, otherwise a cube, if it's a good one, is fine, and I might then consider using a mushroom-stock cube, or a few dried mushrooms and their soaking water, instead of a beef one.

As for equipment: life is very much easier if you buy a plastic pudding basin with a fitted lid than if you use a traditional basin, but if you are defter than I (not hard), feel free. You don't need to steam the pudding: simply immerse it in a large pan of boiling water. But if you have a steamer, then use it.

Traditionally, oysters were added to steak and kidney puddings; I thought a little oyster sauce might be an appropriate contemporary adaptation, and it was. I found some Oyster Stout, which seemed entirely right for it, but it's hardly essential. Serves 6.

1 medium onion, chopped
25g butter
2 tbsp olive oil
500g stewing steak cut into 2cm pieces
250g lambs kidney cut into chunks
2 tbsp flour
tsp mustard powder
150g flat mushrooms (ie 2 medium-sized)
150ml Oyster Stout, or any other
150ml beef stock
1 scant tbsp oyster sauce

for the suet crust

350g SR flour
175g suet
tsp mustard powder
3 litre pudding basin with lid, both buttered

I cook the meat filling a day or two in advance: this makes the flavours deepen and also makes the whole thing less of a performance.

Preheat the oven to 140 /gas mark 1 and season the flour with salt, pepper and mustard powder, and put it into a freezer bag. Put the steak and kidney into the bag, and sealing the end, toss it about to get an even coating of flour. Warm the butter and oil in a casserole and brown the meat (including the kidney) in batches, removing each batch as it's done. Fry the onion in the fat left in the pan over medium to low heat until softened. Peel and slice the mushrooms and fry them briefly in the pan, adding more oil if you need it. Put all the meat back into the casserole and, over a medium heat ,add the stock, stout and oyster sauce. Bring it to the boil, scraping any floury bits off the bottom. Cover with a lid, and cook in the preheated, but barely warm, oven for 1 hours. I cook this in the oven because it's the slow cooking on such a low heat that keeps the meat so meltingly tender. When it's cooked, check the seasoning, and put aside to cool.

About 2 to 3 hours before you want to eat, fill a large saucepan with water and bring to the boil. When it starts boiling, begin making the pastry, and not before. Mix flour, salt, suet and mustard powder in a big bowl, then, stirring with a wooden spoon, add enough cold water to make a firm dough. Roll out on a floured surface into a large circle, and cut away a segment from the circle to use as the lid. Ease the circle of pastry into your buttered pudding basin: you should have 3cm of overhang. Spoon the cold filling in, and do not let it come up higher than 2cm below the rim. Roll out the segment into a small circle to fit the top and seal it with the overhanging edges. Now clip on the basin's buttered lid and immerse in water or place in a steamer over water and leave the pudding there for 2 hours, checking water levels occasionally. Turn the pudding out on to a plate with a good lip, or a shallow bowl: there is a wonderful moment when, like a bulldozed building, your pudding crumples then cascades down; you need to make sure every thick, oozy bit of beefy liquid is safely contained.

Raspberry and lemongrass trifle

I came across the idea of using lemongrass for Britfood, indeed Britpud, while adapting a recipe for lemon balm and sauternes jelly (which is in How to Eat ). As always with trifles, it isn't entirely helpful to be too precise about quantities: think of layers rather than amounts - the dish you use will influence how much you need of what. Use the following, then, as a guide more than anything else. Serves 8-10.

600ml water
325g caster sugar
50g lemongrass (3-4 sticks) halved lengthways
16 trifle sponges (2 packets)
300g raspberries
3-4 tbsp vodka (to taste)
600ml single cream
8 egg yolks
75g caster sugar
500ml double cream

Put the water and caster sugar in a saucepan over medium heat and bring to the boil . Once it's bubbling, let the syrup boil for 5 minutes. Take the pan off the heat and add the lemongrass, pressing it first with the flat side of a knife to bruise it, and let it infuse for about 30 minutes. Strain the syrup into a measuring jug, and put the lemongrass back in the saucepan and put it to one side. Take out 200ml of the syrup and put it into a pan with the raspberries. Bring it to a rolling boil and let it thicken slightly, mashing the fruit to make a jamlike consistency. Dunk the trifle sponges in the raspberry mixture and arrange them in the bottom of a glass bowl, pouring over any syrupy raspberries that remain in the pan. Add the vodka and lemongrass syrup, reserving 200-300ml of syrup, depending on how much your sponges absorb. Reserve the rest of the syrup for later.

Meanwhile, to make the custard, heat the single cream in the syrup pan with the lemongrass until it is nearly boiling, take it off the heat and let it infuse for 15 minutes or so. Whisk the yolks and sugar and pour the cream (with the lemongrass) into the same bowl, then whisk again and put the custard back on the heat in the washed-out pan. Stir over medium heat until the custard thickens (5-7 minutes), then pour it over the trifle sponges. Leave it to cool; it is best left for 24 hours before the final stage and eating.

So, a day later, whip the double cream until thick but not stiff, and cover the custard layer with it. Using the remaining sugar syrup, about 200ml, make a caramel by heating it in a saucepan and letting it boil away until it turns a light gold. Drizzle the sugar syrup over the cream: think Jackson Pollock.

Ginger biscuits Ginger biscuits are traditional enough, but we've always made them with ground ginger. Now that fresh root ginger is widely available, it seemed to make more sense to use that instead. You don't need to eat these with the syllabub that follows, but they do go immensely well. Makes about 35 biscuits.

300g plain flour
1 tsp baking powder
2.5cm length root ginger
125g light muscavado sugar
100g butter
1 egg
75ml golden syrup

for the icing

100ml boiling water
1 cm root ginger
200g icing sugar, sieved, or enough to make a not-too-thick but spreadable glaze

Preheat the oven to 180 C/gas mark 4. Cream the butter and the sugar, and grate in the ginger (I recommend a fine Microplane grater which you can get by mail order from Divertimenti; call 020 7935 0689), as it gives you a juicy purée rather than shreds. Then beat in the flour and baking powder. Measure the golden syrup into a jug, and add the egg, whisking them together. Add this liquid to the mixture to form a dough, but do not overmix. Form it into two balls, wrap in clingfilm and put in the fridge for 20 minutes. Roll out half the dough on a floured surface to about .5cm in thickness and cut out the biscuits, using whatever cutter you like; I use a diamond-shaped cutter about 9.5cm long and 5.5cm wide. Arrange the biscuits on to non-stick or lined baking sheets and cook in the oven for 10-12 minutes, then let them harden for a few minutes on the baking sheet before transferring them to a rack. Use the second half of the dough in the same way.

To make the icing, grate the ginger - again using the fine Microplane - into the boiling water and leave to steep for 10 minutes. Strain on to the sieved icing sugar and whisk to form a smooth icing, then ice the cooled biscuits with the back of a spoon.

Whisky Mac syllabub

Syllabub, again, is traditional British fare, and Whisky Mac - that is, ginger wine and whisky - is a traditional British drink. All I've done that is unorthodox is to combine the two, adding fresh, grated ginger for peppery oomph. Serves 8.

12 tbsp ginger wine
4 tbsp whisky
2cm root ginger
4 tbsp runny honey
juice of an orange
600ml double cream

Put the ginger wine, whisky, root ginger (grated finely, as above), honey and orange juice into a bowl. Let it macerate for 15 minutes or until you are ready - give or take - to eat the finished syllabub.

Strain the liquid through a sieve and add the cream, whisking it all together until it reaches a soft peaked thickness. Spoon into 8 glasses of about 150ml capacity, letting the mixture peak bulkily over the tops, and serve with the ginger biscuits.

 Nigella Lawson's new book, How to be a Domestic Goddess , can be ordered through The Observer CultureShop for £20 (rrp £25) on 0800 3168 171

Cream the butter and the sugar, and grate in the ginger (I recommend a fine Microplane grater which you can get by mail order from Divertimenti; call 020 7935 0689), as it gives you a juicy purée rather than shreds. Then beat in the flour and baking powder. Measure the golden syrup into a jug, and add the egg, whisking them together. Add this liquid to the mixture to form a dough, but do not overmix. Form it into two balls, wrap in clingfilm and put in the fridge for 20 minutes. Roll out half the dough on a floured surface to about .5cm in thickness and cut out the biscuits, using whatever cutter you like; I use a diamond-shaped cutter about 9.5cm long and 5.5cm wide. Arrange the biscuits on to non-stick or lined baking sheets and cook in the oven for 10-12 minutes, then let them harden for a few minutes on the baking sheet before transferring them to a rack. Use the second half of the dough in the same way. To make the icing, grate the ginger - again using the fine Microplane - into the boiling water and leave to steep for 10 minutes. Strain on to the sieved icing sugar and whisk to form a smooth icing, then ice the cooled biscuits with the back of a spoon. Whisky Mac syllabub Syllabub, again, is traditional British fare, and Whisky Mac - that is, ginger wine and whisky - is a traditional British drink. All I've done that is unorthodox is to combine the two, adding fresh, grated ginger for peppery oomph. Let it macerate for 15 minutes or until you are ready - give or take - to eat the finished syllabub. Strain the liquid through a sieve and add the cream, whisking it all together until it reaches a soft peaked thickness. Spoon into 8 glasses of about 150ml capacity, letting the mixture peak bulkily over the tops, and serve with the ginger biscuits.  Nigella Lawson's new book, How to be a Domestic Goddess , can be ordered through The Observer CultureShop for £20 (rrp £25) on 0800 3168 171
