fields.headline: Sun-dried squid or jaggaray, anyone?
fields.standfirst: Hunt through this season's cookbooks and you will discover recipes crammed with exotic ingredients, from nigella seeds and blanchan to galangal and char siu sauce. But food writers don't always cross the globe for inspiration - instead, they visit their local ethnic store to plunder an alien but intriguing world
fields.trailText: Hunt through this season's cookbooks and you will discover recipes crammed with exotic ingredients, from nigella seeds and blanchan to galangal and char siu sauce. But food writers don't always cross the globe for inspiration - instead, they visit their local ethnic store to plunder an alien but intriguing world.
fields.body:
THE THAI EMPORIUM

For those more used to frequenting Japanese or Chinese supermarkets, a Thai shop will seem reassuringly familiar, though it is easy to wander off on a culinary tangent when confronted with curiosities such as crisp slices of canned toddy palm in syrup, fresh turmeric and medicinal-tasting pennywort drinks. Daydreamers should jot down a list of the ingredients they need.

Fresh spices such as galangal (a form of ginger), lime leaves and sweet Thai basil, along with little pots of palm sugar, fish sauce, coconut milk and packets of transparent rice noodles, perfect for laksa - all the ingredients you find you need and haven't got when halfway through a delicious-sounding Thai recipe. Buried in the fridge are unfamiliar long green nut-scented pandanus leaves (also known as screw pine) which are used to infuse scented rice or coconut puddings. Here you will also find freshly made rice noodles and Thai celery. Close by will be fresh wing beans, yard beans and, if you're lucky, green papaya for salads and curries. The latter has to be peeled, seeded and grated before you can use it. You may also find egg-sized yellow aubergine or small white and green aubergines, all begging to be grilled or stuffed and cooked. The fruit section is even better: lumpy kaffir limes and fat rambutans and, in March, peachy-tasting mangosteens.

Anyone keen on making their own Thai curry pastes should buy blachan (very pungent, sludge-coloured dried shrimp paste). This is made from rotted sun-dried shrimp and must be cooked in minuscule quantities to prevent it from making your kitchen smell ghastly. I write from experience. Here you will also find coriander roots - far more flavour than the leaves.

For guidance, opt for The Taste of Thailand by Vatcharin Bhumichitr (£12.99, Pavillion) or scour second-hand book shops for the excellent but out-of-print Thai Cooking by Jennifer Brennan (Jill Norman & Hobhouse). Alternatively, the American version, The Original Thai Cookbook (with US measurements), is available from Amazon.com.

 Tawana, 18-20 Chepstow Road, London W2 (020 7221 6316)

THE JAPANESE EMPORIUM

For the best beginner's guide to Japanese food, look no further than Japanese Cooking: A Simple Art by Shizuo Tsuji (£29.99, Kodansha). This brilliant book describes every imaginable ingredient, explains the philosophy behind the cooking and includes lots of recipes.

For the next step, the fruit and vegetable section at Oriental City - a Japanese equivalent of Tesco, in north London - will break you in gently, especially as everything is labelled in English. Little packets of lemony flavoured shiso leaves, heavenly in salads, vacuum-packed, conical bamboo shoots and long beige burdock roots are instantly tempting. The burdock should be scrubbed clean (not peeled) and added to stews or grated and tossed with soy sauce, sake and mirin - a form of sweet rice wine used solely for cooking - for a flavoursome accompaniment.

Both sake and mirin enhance the taste of fish, poultry and meat, especially when combined with soy sauce, either as a mar- inade or as a sauce. The warming sake is sold in a separate section with beer and plum wine (gorgeous chilled with fresh oranges for pudding).

Returning to more mundane foods, the refreshing and delicate Japanese rice vine-gar is well worth buying. You might also like to buy Sansho pepper, seven-spice powder and black sesame seeds. Sansho pepper is ground from the prickly pear pod and has a lovely lemony flavour. Seven-spice powder is like an aromatic version of cayenne pepper and should be sprinkled directly on to grilled foods or fish ptés. You can use either as a seasoning when cooking some of the many different forms of dried Japanese noodles such as buckwheat, green tea or udon.

Those inclined to experiment should also buy dried bonito flakes and dried kelp to make dashi, an essential stock in Japanese cooking. You can buy this ready-made, but it usually contain MSG. Even miso paste, once only made from fermented soy beans, grain and salt, now contains MSG. The only exception is shiro (white) miso. Luckily, this can be used for both soups and dressings and will live in the fridge for about a year. You will find a wide selection of dried seaweeds, ranging from nutty-flavoured arame to wavy wakame.

The design-conscious should indulge in some of the exquisite packaging available. Perhaps a silver-flecked envelope of green tea or a chunky block-printed bag of potato starch. Rice fanatics should, of course, also buy this season's Japanese rice (grown in California). You will have to buy a small sack, but at least they give clear cooking instructions for everyone who doesn't have a rice steamer. Since you will undoubtedly have to drive to Oriental City, you might like to pick up some toothsome glutenous rice and red-bean sweets from the chill cabinet. Reminiscent of chewy pear drops, these are decidedly moreish when you're driving home.

 Oriental City, 399 Edgware Road, London NW9 (020 8201 3819).

THE CHINESE EMPORIUM

The key to shopping successfully in Chinese stores is to maintain your cool. Admittedly this is hard when you're climbing over boxes of pomelos to reach a tempting array of luscious-looking banana leaves or fat bunches of Chinese garlic chives. It is often only after you have enthusiastically filled your basket with muddy-brown water chestnuts, fresh lotus root and green mouli that you realise you don't what to do with them. Not a problem - just buy The Chinese Kitchen by Deh-Ta Hsiung (£19.99, Kyle Cathie). Arranged by ingredient, this tells you everything you might need to know before giving a recipe or two. Fresh lotus root, for example, should be peeled and sliced before being eaten raw, stir-fried or candied (Hsiung also gives a useful listing of Chinese shops in Britain).

Having extricated yourself from the boxes of Chinese greens, bypass the stacks of pot noodles and head for the fridges. Here you will find duck and chicken feet - with or without black bean sauce - along with packets of dried squid, dried prawns, fresh white noodles, won-ton wrappers and bean curd. Lurking here, too, are the 1,000-year-old eggs - preserved in wood ash, slaked lime and salt for 40 days. Soak them in water, peel, cut into sections and eat with sesame oil and soy sauce - not that I have tried.

Squeamish shoppers may prefer to browse the shelves. There, you may find jade-green tapioca pearls or tinned grass jelly. Small packets of bitter almonds, poisonous if ingested in large quantities, are my temptation, perfect for 19th-century ice cream and pudding recipes. Then there are dried red dates (Chinese jujube) and black fungus (cloud ear) and a weird white fungus that looks like a sponge. Despite the lack of English instructions, the fungus can be washed and soaked before being added for texture to stir-fries, while the dates (according to Hsiung) can be simmered in an Oriental chicken stew. Look out for canned straw mushrooms and salted yellow or black beans. Once open, the beans will live in the fridge for months. Citrus-scented pink Sichuan peppercorns and ground licorice powder and star anise are irresistible. Beware, however, the large black and gold tins of Gourmet Powder. This is the raw form of monosodium glutamate, a pernicious taste enhancer that induces an allergic reaction in some people.

In common with all supermarkets, there is an array of nibbles close to the till. Toasted pumpkin seeds, rainbow-coloured sweets and, near the Chinese wines, wind-dried sausages. These should be steamed for eight minutes before being sliced and eaten with rice, presumably while you contemplate what to do with the flattened squid.

 S W Trading, 18-20 Lisle Street, London WC2 (020 7439 8325).

THE INDIAN EMPORIUM

You can, if you are strong, struggle on to the bus with Chinese shopping. Indian shop-fests, however, are another matter. You are going to need a car or an entourage of willing porters. It's not just that everything is irresistibly cheap, it is the fact that even the basics of rice, dhal and chapati flour are heavy - never mind the tempting green mangos begging to be pickled, or the metal tava (griddle pan) for making Indian bread.

The majority of Indian cash and carries concentrate on selling such dry goods and household items as stainless-steel spice boxes, huge saucepans for special-occasion curries and all the spices necessary for puja. Fresh produce is usually sold by neighbouring stores.

If you're unsure of where to start, trust the crowd and choose the busiest shop. It's like stepping into India, with the smell of joss sticks mixed with mothballs and every conceivable bag-size of pulses, rice, flour and spices: pale green and yellow split toor dhal for light spicy lentils; large oily yellow toovar dhal for a thick, rich dhal; tiny black gram urid beans for Kali dhal, a Punjabi dish made with kidney beans; and beige urid dhal (split and skinned black gram seeds) for spicy deep-fried dumplings soaked in yogurt. For guidance on ingredients, turn to Classic Indian Cookery by Julie Sahni (£20, Grub Street), otherwise turn to Madhur Jaffrey.

Flours are equally varied, ranging from gram (chickpea), chapati (wheat) and rice flour to ground millet and sorghum. Within minutes, you will convince yourself that you need the gram flour for pakoras and bhajis and that making chapatis and South Indian rice-flour pancakes is what you've always wanted to do. Perhaps it's the Indian film music.

The more you look, the more you find. Packets of fruity tamarind paste (better than the sour Thai variety), jaggary (a flavoursome Indian sugar made from dehydrated sugar cane juice) and fine golden threads of sev. This is a form of vermicelli, which is cooked into a milky pudding and further enriched with almonds or amazingly fresh-tasting green raisins from Afghanistan. A word of warning: before cooking any Indian dried fruit, rice or dhal, check for stones and wash thoroughly. The spice selection is alluring with its retro-looking packets of sour anardana powder, ground from wild pomegranate seeds, and mouth-puckering amchoor powder made from green mangos. There are grains of musky fenugreek and black cardamoms that look like cockroaches when added to rice. Bags of mild dry chillies from Kashmir and small hot chillies from the south for dhal. Nigella seeds for bread (Nigella Lawson uses them in her latest book), dark mustard seeds for stir-fried beans and pungent black Kashmiri cumin seeds for cauliflower and potato curry. All of which make one feel very hungry.

The only answer is to buy some tindori (akin to miniature courgettes) from a neighbouring Indian greengrocer, along with other exotic temptations such as fresh fenugreek and guavas, before seeking out an Indian chaat stall for instant satisfaction.

 Nita Cash & Carry, 137-139 Ealing Road, Wembley, Middlesex (020 8903 1541).

THE MIDDLE EASTERN EMPORIUM

If you wish to be au courant with the latest culinary trends, you are going to have to visit a Middle Eastern shop. It is here that you will find the finest quince, pomegranate syrup and pistachio nuts, all of which feature in this year's cookbooks. The best shops have an elegant, almost Parisian feel as you saunter past their immaculate pastry counters and pristine fish displays.

Fresh produce includes raw green olives, blushing Iranian pomegranates, delicately serrated green chicory leaves, tiny white moulis, fresh tamarind pods and long green stick beans. The grapes are so fat you feel like reclining on silk cushions and demanding that they be peeled. Keep an eye out for pickles, from the vivid turnips suspended in pink brine to pickled wild cucumber, mild green chillies, globe artichokes, salted lemons and dozens of different olives. Suddenly, the shopping basket feels rather small.

Dried beans range from big white butter beans to crinkled brown ful medames and crushed fava (broad) beans. Also, bags of dried mint, ultra-hot Berber spice mixtures from Ethiopia and large packets of sesame seeds. There are trays of sticky medjool dates, packets of energy-packed amber-coloured amretin (chewy, dried apricot sheets) perfect for gnawing when you're hungry, and plump almonds, pistachio nuts, walnut and pumpkin seeds.

As the air fills with the scent of freshly baked bread, it is impossible not to pick up some of the rose-petal and quince jams nestling beside the bottles of distilled orange-flower and rosewaters. Even the tamarind, rose, grape and blackberry cordials look tempting, as do the bottles of sour dark pomegranate syrup and sweet date syrup.

As you head for the door, your eyes are caught by a stunning array of Middle Eastern pastries and Turkish delight, while behind the till are fresh coffee beans waiting to be mixed with cardamom seeds. Above are eastern coffee sets and elaborate hubble bubbles.

There are two books that need to be studied to understand the subtleties of Middle Eastern cooking: The New Book of Middle Eastern Food by Claudia Roden (£14.99, Penguin) and The Legendary Cuisine of Persia by Margaret Shaida (£14.99, Grub Street). Armed with these, you will be able to choose the freshest-looking dried barberries to add a note of sourness to your saffron pilaf, sprinkle astringent brown sumac on to your lamb kebab with confidence and drop a dried lime into your stew (having first carefully washed and stabbed it, to ensure maximum flavour). Furthermore, you will understand the correct etiquette necessary to serve the Turkish coffee you have learned how to make.

 Green Valley, 37 Upper Berkeley Street, London W1 (020 7723 2545).
Books mentioned in this feature can be obtained from Books for Cooks, 4 Blenheim Crescent, London W11 (020 7221 1992)

fields.headline: Food fit for the gods
fields.standfirst: When Amandip Uppal does the catering for the exclusive London fashion store Browns of South Molton Street, she cooks up delicious sweetcorn and pepper fritters with a red onion, pomegranate and green mango relish. But that's nothing compared to the sumptuous offerings served up when Amandip and her family celebrate the Indian Diwali New Year feast
fields.trailText: When Amandip Uppal does the catering for the exclusive London fashion store Browns of South Molton Street, she cooks up delicious sweetcorn and pepper fritters with a red onion, pomegranate and green mango relish. But that's nothing compared to the sumptuous offerings served up when Amandip and her family celebrate the Indian Diwali New Year feast.
fields.body:
'You won't find food like this in an Indian restaurant,' Pushpaben Kotecha assures me as she puts two small, deep-fried dumplings on to my plate. They are straight from the pan, golden and crispy, and they smell delicious. They are called kachouri - balls of sweet and spicy crushed lentils with a samosa-like batter around the outside. Pushpaben is deftly shaping them in her hands and frying them for the next hungry guest. She does it without even thinking.

Amandip Uppal, Pushpaben's new daughter-in-law, is savouring hers. 'I didn't know about kachouri until I met Jaimin,' she says. They are a Gujarati snack; Amandip's family is Punjabi. She married Jaimin earlier this year, and has been living in the family house in north London, with mother-in-law and two brothers-in-law ever since. Mealtimes like this unite the family, and Amandip and Pushpaben are often to be found in the kitchen late at night, experimenting with some new recipe or idea. 'I don't even attempt to make kachouri yet,' says Amandip. 'Pushpaben has years of experience.'

Tonight is a special occasion. It's the beginning of Diwali, the Hindu Festival of Light, and the start of the new year - 2057. The day has been spent cleaning the house, and decorating it with flowers and candles. It's the family's first Diwali with their new temple, or mandir. Until recently, Pushpaben had a shrine in her bedroom. But in the summer, the family had the garage converted into their own place for prayer and meditation. The gods are all there -from Shiva and Krishna, to Laxmi, the goddess of prosperity and wealth to whom this festival is dedicated. The old shrine now forms part of a larger one -there is even space on the altar for a Mother Mary and a face of the Aga Khan. There is always a candle burning in the home-made temple. But during Diwali (which literally translates as 'row of lights'), they are every where, the first thing you see as you enter the house, twinkling away on a little shrine in the doorway. In the middle sits the elephant-headed god Ganesh, and on each side there is a tile which has been decorated with brightly coloured pigment powder. 'In India, you have to step over the shrine as you come inside,' explains Jaimin. For practical reasons, theirs is set to one side so visitors don't burn themselves on their way in.

Outside, there are fireworks exploding all around. But in the candle-lit temple, Pushpaben leads the prayers, and the rest of the family - Jaimin, Amandip, Hemal, Situl and his girlfriend Reshma - follow her lead. Pushpaben teaches Jaimin and Amandip how to do the ceremony so that in the future, the tradition will be carried on in the family. Before the gods, they have placed an offering of sweets fresh from the Pradip Sweet Mart in Kenton.

After prayers, the sweets will join the rest of the food on the kitchen table, ready for an informal feast. Hopefully, it will be an auspicious year for Amandip, who is launching her own business making Indian canapés for events and parties. 'Pushpaben and I talk about food all the time,' she says. 'A lot of girls in my generation resent cooking and resent getting married. There was a time when I would never have worn an Indian outfit like this, and to cook Indian food was like letting the sisters down.'

But Amandip, 30, is enjoying marriage and is an avid cook. 'When I first cooked for my mother-in-law, she burst into tears. She said, "Girls your generation don't cook like this anymore."' Yet Amandip learned from her parents as a teenager, growing up on a farm in Yorkshire. She watched how her mother did things, and especially her father, who tended to be more experimental with his cooking. 'I still think we have an unsophisticated attitude towards Indian food in this country,' she says. 'It's all about chicken tikka masala and a pint of beer. But I think attitudes will change.'

Recently she catered for a press day at the fashionable London clothes store, Browns of South Molton Street. When asked how many samosas she would be doing, she relished the fact that she wasn't doing samosas at all. Instead, her canapés might include spicy sweetcorn and red pepper fritters with a red onion; pomegranate and green mango relish (you can barely say it without your mouth watering); mini spicy roast potatoes, and fenugreek and onion seed biscuits. She is constantly experimenting and adapting flavours and tastes.

If she was to make samosas, they might be courtesy of her mother-in-law, and filled with grated carrots and nuts. Pushpaben is enthusiastic, too. 'Her strength is Gujarati food, and mine is Punjabi,' says Amandip. 'We have a meeting ground with vegetarianism. There are certain things she makes that are just perfect as they are. Indian food is not precious.'

Tonight's feast is a perfect example. A pan of Indian tea is on the cooker. From the fridge comes a bowl of Mung bean dhal eaten cold alongside another bowl of peas and tomatoes, rice, chapatis, home-made pickles and big, crunchy crisps made from flour and spices. Everybody sits or stands around the table and tucks in, while Pushpaben carries on cooking and adding dishes to the table.

For Amandip, a Sikh, this is her first Diwali. 'I wasn't brought up to eat like this. They combine sweet and savoury all together,' she says. 'And we wouldn't have rice - just bread.' But this is the day when sweets are eaten with abandon. As well as the brightly coloured condensed-milk based sweets bought earlier that day, there are the most delicious home-made cubes topped with grated carrot. They are made from carrot, saffron, butter, and lots of sugar - presumably one of Pushpaben's peaks of perfection. And she's absolutely right: you don't find food like this in a restaurant.

fields.headline: Urbane planning
fields.standfirst: No longer young, callow or unlucky in love, Michael Jackson still seeks sophistication in a bottle
fields.trailText: No longer young, callow or unlucky in love, Michael Jackson still seeks sophistication in a bottle.
fields.body:
Eighteen years old, and bursting with testosterone, I lusted after the girl in black who always perched provocatively on the bar stool. She had once given me a half-smile. This evening, I would find the boldness to offer her a drink. It couldn't be that difficult, surely. If I was lucky, she would ask for a half of lager. That was what most girls drank in those days.

What if she had been abroad? Girls who had been abroad sometimes drank wine. If that were the case, I might be in awkward territory. Mateus Rosé hadn't yet been discovered. The phrase 'dry white' was unknown. Who could have imagined that we would one day have blush Zinfandel, Chilean Cabernet or New Zealand Chardonnay?

Was Babycham wine? If so, it was already déclassé. Was Martini wine? The labels said vermouth, but I didn't know what that meant; it looked winey. Dry sherries, served in 'schooner' glasses, would soon have a fleeting fashionability, but not yet. No one would dream of drinking champagne to thank God it was Friday. In those days, champagne (always in a saucer glass) was strictly for weddings and Bar Mitzvahs, and neither of those was on my mind.

I was about to make my move when a suntanned sophisticate walked into the bar. He was middle-aged: at least 25. 'A Bacardi-and-Coke for me, and the same for Gina,' he smiled. She didn't even notice my hopes disintegrating like a smashed glass. If only I could become sophisticated, I thought.

Even in the days of a mild-and-bitter duopoly, lager was available in Britain (albeit only for girls). Nobody knew what lager was.Who does today? Drinking the right thing is more important than knowing what's in the bottle. At first, nobody asked for lager by brand. When they got round to doing so, it had to sound 'Continental' (specifically, Northern European). No Bud (Czech or American). No Corona or Sol. No Foster's. A pub would carry only one lager, and always in the bottle. It eventually had to go on draught so that macho men could drink it by the pint. Then back into the bottle so that it could become a labelled fashion accessory. Decades would pass before it was acceptable to drink beers with flavour... and they had to be Belgian.

Only the suntanned sophisticate knew about Bacardi, but pimply youths would be drinking it before long, without knowing what it was. Bacardi had a long run as a white rum before it begat a Breezer...

Someone once said that the only honest ad for an alcoholic drink would be: 'It gets you drunk.' Today's ads are even more candid: 'it gets her into bed' is the subtext, whether it's an alcopop or an expertly shaken cocktail. I gather that in these enlightened days, women even use alcohol to lead men astray, apparently without undue concern over its other properties.

In theory, the selection of love potion was easier in those days, with far fewer drinks from which to choose. Many of us already lived in multi-ethnic neighbourhoods, but those immigrants who drank alcohol had not brought anything significantly new and different to the table. I once snitched a bottle of Baltic Kümmel from my grandmother's drinks cupboard, but could not get any of my friends interested. What grandchild of immigrants would really want to drink something old-fashioned from the old country? My black friends didn't want to drink dark rum, either. Nobody wants to drink what their parents drank.

We later learned that there were other pale rums, and even golden ones, and more recently cachaça if we fancied a caipirinha. Tequila was soon to arrive on these shores, surfing on a silly Californian song. I had always thought drinking was fun, but Tequila made it official. Soon we were ordering sunrises and margaritas; now we are serious again, comparing reposado with anejo or demanding 100 per cent agave, estate-grown. After the first fumbles and fun, we want to be authentic seducers.

Whisky was blended. It said so on the label, but we didn't notice. I was about to discover single malts, but it was years before I found a woman who was prepared to be lie down in the heather with Glenfiddich. By then, I had moved on to Macallan and Talisker. These days, I have to produce a cask-strength Lagavulin with a Pedro Ximinez finish if I am to have the remotest hope of a second date.

When I started taking women out for dinner, we went to steak houses, and finished our meals with Irish coffee. Then along came Bailey's. This was as close as I got to Irish whiskey until I started drinking with an amateur poet called Seamus in the Fulham Road, and discovered Jameson. Now, you can buy it at your neighbourhood paper shop. Bushmills even has a single malt, matured in sherry butts, port pipes and bourbon barrels. We used to think Southern Comfort was American whiskey; now we are knowledgeable about the percentage of rye or wheat in our favourite small-batch bourbon.

Gin was always full of promise. Pink gin was something they drank in Mayfair, wherever that was. To a provincial teenager like me, the word 'Mayfair' suggested some kind of playful, adult, naughtiness. I thought it must be a very louche place. People there drank gin-and-French. It sounded like one of those sexual practices that only foreigners enjoyed. Then there was gin-and-It, which must surely be even worse, or better. We take our gin straighter these days: Bombay Sapphire, out of a blue bottle, ice-cold, with the briefest kiss of vermouth. Now that's a Martini...

Brandy had been 'for medicinal use', and always Cognac. Then people started talking about Armagnac, Calvados, Marc and the eaux-de-vie of Alsace. It's hard to stay ahead of the drinking game. You can find grappa among the outsize peppermills in your average high-street pasta restaurant; absinthe in respectable Waitrose; and I saw someone drinking mezcal in a bar in Leeds.

There was a Parisian-Russian romanticism to Pierre Smirnoff's breathless distillate when we first encountered Moscow Mules. Now vodka has to be made according to an ancient Siberian recipe and packaged in an etched glass bottle, hand-crafted by Venetian-American art-directors in a genuine Madison Avenue advertising agency. If you think vodka should taste of something, perhaps you can find one flavoured with sun-dried tomatoes.

fields.headline: A-Z of world food
fields.standfirst: From abalone to zampone... the ultimate consumer's guide to the global kitchen
fields.trailText: From abalone to zampone... the ultimate consumer's guide to the global kitchen.
fields.body:
Abalone The chic, Oriental answer to cockles and whelks, this millionaire's mollusc is also known as ormer in the Channel Islands. Californians pretend to be fond of it; Japanese will pay anything for it. (Oriental grocers; usually dried or canned.)

Akee Caribbean fruit which looks like a peach, but tastes disappointingly of scrambled eggs. (Caribbean grocers.)

Ancho chilies The days when 'chilli' was an abbreviation for the student slop 'con carne' are over. In fact, you not only have to be able to spell 'chili' correctly, you have to be able to distinguish between different varieties. Ancho chilies are essential to the famous mole poblano. (Bobby Flay's pure ancho chili powder, £3.85, Harvey Nichols.)

Anchovies No matter how tiny, anchovies pack such a punch, it's not surprising they turn up in everything from patum peperum (gentlemen's relish) to pissaladières (onion, anchovy and olive tarts from Nice.)

B antam A dwarf chicken, much prettier than regular hens and therefore favoured by armchair farmers. They produce tiny eggs, which are cute, but cost the same as chicken's eggs. (Farm shops/butchers.)

Barley Ancient cereal once used extensively for bread-making until leavened bread became common, as it doesn't respond well to the action of yeast. Now in vogue for risotto and other dishes usually reserved for rice, it makes a change, but incompetent cooking leads to a slimy texture.

Beans Cheap foodstuff raised to gourmet status by the proliferation of Lebanese cuisine. (Middle Eastern grocers; canned.)

Bottarga Like beluga and sévruga (caviar), a product made from roe, in this case of the grey mullet. (Food halls.)

Buffalo Vague reference to various bovines, including the American bison and the Asian water buffalo, both of which are now raised in the UK. Bison is useful for making the South African speciality, biltong, a chewy dried meat often given to children as a weaning device - but the flesh of almost any game animal can be used, including zebra. Water buffalo are usually used as dairy cattle to produce fresh mozzarella di bufala, though some meat will be available locally. (Biltong, Marcus Fine Foods.)

Bulgur wheat Cracked wheat, used for the famous Middle Eastern herb, tomato-and-cucumber salad tabbouleh.

Butternut squash Along with kabocha and spaghetti squashes, one of the most widely available cucurbits, and the tastiest. Don't believe everything you read on supermarket cooking-advice labels, however: boiling is for school dinners, roasting is for grown-ups. (Waitrose, £1.69 per kg.)

C allaloo Caribbean soup made from all sort of greens which are also commonly referred to as callaloo. Canned versions look like pondweed. (Caribbean grocers.)

Cardamom Fragrant seedpod used in the Middle East to turn coffee into heavenly elixir, in Indian desserts and masala chai (spiced tea), and in Scandinavia for baking biscuits, such as kardemuma kekse.

Cauliflower Mark Twain said cauliflower was just cabbage with a college education, so who knows what he would have thought of the new red or green (Romanesco) varieties. The latter has intricate spirals on the flower reminiscent of a Buddhist temple, but it still tastes like cauliflower.

Cavolo nero Funny how food tastes better in Italian. Cavoli are cabbages, and this one isn't black, it's dark green, with long leaves like rabbit ears. (Waitrose, 99p for 200g.)

Clamato Not an Italian condiment, but Mott's cult clam and tomato drink from Canada, which never seems to go out of style. (£1.09, Trustin The Foodfinders.)

D hal Simple Indian dish of lentils, split peas or chickpeas (channa dhal) with spices which anyone can make, but which posh people like to buy ready mixed. (Tiger Lily instant dhal mix, £2.25 for 200g, Harvey Nichols.)

Dim sum Cantonese hors d'oeuvres served in bamboo baskets for lunch (but never for dinner), nearly always including the westerner's favourite, pork dumplings.

Durian Also known as the stinkfruit, and not widely available outside Asian markets probably for this reason.

Eel Now so rare due to over-fishing that its price has risen to around £28 per kg, despite the popular contention that they are slimy and horrible. In fact, they are neither, but they are fatty, a quality best countered by smoking.

Ewe's milk Enjoying a renaissance after centuries of neglect due to higher yields of milk from dairy cows. (Cows produce 40 litres daily; goats 14; ewes 4.) Containing twice as much protein and more vitamins and minerals than cow's milk, and not known to produce the same allergic reactions, ewe's milk is the authentic ingredient of cheeses such as Wensleydale.

Exotic fruits We now expect fresh fruit from any part of the world at any time of the year (though they may not taste as good as they do in their native lands). Newcomers include kiwano (also known as horned cucumber or jelly melon) - a spiky, mottled orange fruit with edible seeds and a jelly-like flesh, and tomatillos - little green Mexican husk tomatoes required for authentic guacamole.

Filbert A name often used to refer to the freshly picked version of the cob or hazelnut, which to my mind ought to be left to dry, then roasted and concealed in a chocolate brownie; but the green sort have passionate admirers.

Goat Used to be only available in Caribbean grocers. It makes a festive Jamaican curry; uninitiated dinner guests will assume it's lamb.

Green tea Contains important antioxidants, perfect with oriental food, and non-alcoholic besides. Yamamotoyama green tea even comes complete with haiku and brown rice - so good for you, it makes you wince (£2.30 for 40g, Harvey Nichols.)

Harissa Fiery Moroccan pimento paste well known from couscous and now a popular British store- cupboard ingredient; not to be confused with Harira, the national bean soup served throughout Ramadan.

Horchata de chufa An as yet little known but irresistible Spanish drink made from pressed tigernuts, which is milky white and sweet, a little like drinking liquid marzipan. It is served by the ladle in Spanish cafés, or can be bought bottled. (P de la Fuente.)

I nsects Several bold aficionados have been trying to popularise insects as a food item recently, but they stubbornly show no sign of gaining true gourmet status. Still, ants dipped in chocolate would be a good start. (Harrods.)

Jalapeño Possibly the best known chilies in the world, now trapped in a lovely, golden jalapeño pepper jelly by Tabasco. (£3.45 for 283g, Harvey Nichols.) Jerusalem artichoke Tasty root with unfortunate social effects.

Jujube A fruit often taken to be a date.

Kaffir lime leaves Wonderfully scented leaf, a little like lemon grass, used in oriental cooking. Kimch'i Korean fermented cabbage and fish sauce, eaten with almost everything, which smells putrid in the bottle but tastes pleasant on food. (Oriental grocers.)

Latke Polish potato cakes also adopted by kosher cuisine. Lavender One of the few flowers we now tolerate as a food flavouring, largely derived from Provençal cooking.

Lingonberry A Scandinavian berry found mostly as juice.

Macadamia After pine kernels, these Australian nuts are the most expensive in the world. (Trustin the Foodfinders.)

Manna A honey-like substance that comes, mysteriously, not from Heaven, but through the agency of insects on certain plants. It may be a secretion of the infested leaf, or a secretion of the insects themselves; grateful Kurds often make it into a sort of halva.

Mostarda di frutta A curious sweet fruit pickle with mustard available from Italian delis. For an excellent version, try the Chatsworth Farm Shop.

Nasturtium Wasted in the garden, though its flowers are jolly; the leaves make good salad and the buds can be pickled, like capers.

Olé chimichurri A brand of potent chimichurri salsa made in Ecuador. Consumers might want to mix it with tomatoes and cucumber to avoid the sensation of their throat being ripped out. (£1.99, Sainsbury's.)

Panettone It's light, it keeps for ever, it has a heavenly aroma and you can eat it for breakfast; panettone is a Christmas cake for modernists. (£10.95 for 1kg, Harvey Nichols.)

Pasteis de nata Swoon inducing, super creamy Portuguese custard tarts. (Lisboa deli.)

Pickled lemons You may use only one of these Moroccan/Egyptian condiments once a year, but they look great on the kitchen shelf. (Ryad Halalway deli.)

Porcini The prince of wild mushrooms, also known as ceps and pennybuns. Their flavour is strongest when dried; they make such good stock that Knorr has brought out porcini cubes. Though, as the mushroom content is 1 per cent, you might try bricioloni (broken pieces of mushroom) from your local Italian deli, which should be half the price of whole pieces. (Knorr funghi porcini stock cubes, £1.40 for 110g, Harvey Nichols.)

Pink fir apple The most spectacular of all the newly revived, gourmet potatoes; pink and knobbly as a mandrake, with a delicate, nutty flavour - but hard to scrub. (Waitrose.)

Quince Ancient fruit overtaken by the apple (the golden apple given by Paris to Aphrodite was probably a quince), but now making a comeback, not so much as sweet jelly, but as quince paste to accompany cheese, known as membrillo. (Harvey Nichols, £9.95 per kg; food halls; specialist cheese stores.)

Quinoa Andean cereal used to make tortillas etc, which has a high protein value.

Rascasse A fish whose venom gives bouillabaisse its special flavour. Robiola 3 latti A much-admired, soft, white Italian cheese which aims to cover all bases with its blend of cow, sheep and goat's milk. (£5.90, Villandry.)

Saba Comes from the cooked grape juice of Modena. It's a sweet, thick juice good for desserts, savoury sauces and even cordial. (Fattorie Giacobazzi saba, £2.99 for 375ml, Sainsbury's.)

Sardines Apparently being bought by foodies in ever greater numbers, but only in the right tins, of course. (Connétable sardines, £1.80, Villandry; Sainbury's.)

Seaweed Has largely been a foodstuff of health nuts and sushi junkies in the past, but now Eco-Zone, a UK-based company, is packaging the fruit of the ocean in an way designed to appeal to western sensibilities. Seaweed salads come fresh instead of dried, and seaweed tartare, to spread on toast or over fish, is a tasty mix of seaweeds with olive and walnut oils, gherkins, capers, garlic. (Eco-Zone/Villandry.)

Tahini An oily paste made from crushed sesame seeds for use in hummus and other mezze. Tamarind Acidifying agent supplied as a sticky cake made from the pods of the tamarind tree, used in Indian cookery.

Tisane Herbal tea, an infusion much adulterated by health food companies and put into bags; but the real thing is much cheaper and better - ask for whole camomile flowers, vervain (lemon verbena leaves), tilleul (lime blossom), etc.

Turtle soup Sometimes modern farming techniques do us a favour. Take Real Turtle Soup by John Lusty (as opposed to Mock Turtle Soup, as sung about in Alice in Wonderland ), a lovely broth made with the meat of green turtles raised in California - the return of a Victorian luxury.

Udo A Japanese plant used much like parsley by the English, but rarely seen here, having been replaced in bento boxes by the more convenient plastic grass strip.

Verjuice More useful than saba, verjuice is another grape juice product, this time used as an acidulant which is milder than lemon juice or red wine vinegar and doesn't kill the flavours of the food. De-glazing a pan in which a sauce is to be made for an intensively reared chicken will, for example, elevate the humble bird to the status of festive fowl. In short, verjuice is said to be the new balsamic, and Aussie chef Maggie Beer's is the best. (Maggie Bare Verjuice, £3.99 for 250ml, Sainsbury's.)

Water lilies If you have ever wondered what those curious bulbs are outside Chinese grocers', they are probably water lilies, whose rhizomes, seeds, and stems are all eaten avidly. No need to scoff; after all, enviable waif Audrey Hepburn subsisted on tulip bulbs during the war years in Holland.

Wattleseed A rare spice from the wattle tree, which grows in the Australian outback. It tastes of coffee, hazelnuts and vanilla rolled into one and makes a great sauce for ice cream. (£2.69 for 30g, Sainsbury's.)

X'cutti Pronounced 'shakuti', this complex blend of spices in a base of coconut paste, based on a Goan recipe, it is an exceptional slop-on curry sauce (or marinade if you have time). One of the best I've ever found in a jar. (Geeta's, £1.99 for 275g, Sainsbury's.)

Yabby The sizeable Australian crayfish, whose name is derived from the Aboriginal yappée. Yam Almost any root vegetable you can find in a Caribbean shop, including taro, sweet potatoes, etc.

Yogurt Now gone the full loop in the western mind, from plain, to a thousand different fruit flavours, to plain again. It is appreciated for its individual lactic cultures and subtle taste - hence the artisanal return to terracotta pots and glass jars.

Za'atar A Middle Eastern spice allegedly based on wild thyme, but in many versions, such as the Al Wadi brand from Beirut, its principle ingredient is oregano, along with roasted sesame seeds, sumac and salt. Sprinkled on flatbreads or labne (strained yogurt). In the jar it smells like dessicated manure.

Zampone Italian pork sausage, for which the casing is made by boning out a pig's trotter; zampone means 'great paw'. (£10.95 per kg, Italian delis/salumerias.)

Zulu Fire Sauce Finally, a lesson for all of us foodies easily seduced by pretty packaging. In fact, Zulu Fire Sauce is one of four such products made and marketed by a company called Jock'n'Doris, in Mamble, UK. (£5.49 for 490ml, Sainsbury's.)

webTitle: Letter: Railways

fields.headline: Top gangers
fields.trailText: When I was young, in the 1930s, railways were continuously inspected for damage to the track (News, last week). Mainly elderly and knowledgeable railwaymen called 'gangers' walked their own allocated stretch of the line every day, checking sleepers, 'chairs' and lines.
fields.body:
When I was young, in the 1930s, railways were continuously inspected for damage to the track (News, last week). Mainly elderly and knowledgeable railwaymen called 'gangers' walked their own allocated stretch of the line every day, checking sleepers, 'chairs' and lines. Any unsound or loose wedges were replaced or made secure. If they found a major fault, they could put detonators on the line to stop the next train.

They were lowly paid, making a few bob extra from rabbits netted on their section of the embankments. But the ones I knew were proud to be there, and were dedicated to the safety of their bit of the railway. I doubt any would have understood 'increased shareholder value' as a reason for being.
John Preston,
FRICS
Winchester Hants

webTitle: Letters: Chris Woodhead

fields.headline: Woodhead left education in crisis
fields.trailText: You're right to locate responsibility for Chris Woodhead's reign of terror with Tony Blair (Leader, last week). Brazen political expediency has surely prevailed over the objective needs of education.
fields.body:
You're right to locate responsibility for Chris Woodhead's reign of terror with Tony Blair (Leader, last week). Brazen political expediency has surely prevailed over the objective needs of education. Our self-proclaimed champion of 'Education!' exposed our schools to Woodhead's approach to education policy in order to insulate New Labour from media criticism that they might be 'going soft' on teachers. The cynical politicisation of education under the unholy Woodhead-Blair-Blunkett alliance has traumatised a generation of teachers, leaving an education system exhausted and teetering on the brink of crisis, if not breakdown - a legacy which may take a generation to heal.
Dr Richard House
Norwich

 Your leader states that Woodhead was 'right in his refusal to tolerate mediocrity'. But the true defect from which Woodhead himself suffered was just that - mediocrity.

He taught at three schools but was careful to move on before any assessment of his teaching could be made because his ambition was to move into educational administration, which was much better paid. He returned to Shropshire as senior adviser for English. The courses he ran were on a par with the rest of his career - uninspiring and mediocre.

His translation into chief inspector for schools for the last six years has been marked by a pronounced dearth of any educational innovation stemming from him. He lived in the past, promoting selection and whole class teaching.

Woodhead has been more concerned with self-advancement than education. The damage that he has done to teachers and to 'education' as a civilising concept is incalculable.
Baldwyn ab Ithel Davies
Welshpool, Powys

webTitle: Letter: Tax on drugs

fields.headline: Tax drugs
fields.trailText: Those of us who do not use illicit drugs are getting a lousy deal out of drug prohibition. Cabinet Office Minister Mowlam's call for a 'sensible debate' on drugs policy (News, last week) is right on target.
fields.body:
Those of us who do not use illicit drugs are getting a lousy deal out of drug prohibition. Cabinet Office Minister Mowlam's call for a 'sensible debate' on drugs policy (News, last week) is right on target. People who smoke tobacco or drink alcohol pay taxes to compensate society for the collective health care costs that fall on all of us. It's not an ideal solution but it beats the alternative that Americans suffered during Alcohol Prohibition and that we chose for drugs other than alcohol and tobacco. We should learn the lesson from the failed experiment of Prohibition and legalise and tax currently illegal drugs, starting with cannabis. I'd rather see all that money go to the Chancellor than to unscrupulous criminals. Drug taxes would provide billions in funds for education and treatment, the only approaches to the drug problem that works.
Joe Wein
Yokohama, Japan

webTitle: Letter: Bill Gates

fields.headline: Open Gates
fields.trailText: Bill Gates has not 'renounced the machine that has made him the world's richest man' (News, last week). He has realised that one size does not fit all when it comes to solutions to the world's problems - and he is putting his money where his mouth is.
fields.body:
Bill Gates has not 'renounced the machine that has made him the world's richest man' (News, last week). He has realised that one size does not fit all when it comes to solutions to the world's problems - and he is putting his money where his mouth is. The idea of 'wiring the world's classrooms to the internet', as proposed by one of Mr Gates' critics, demonstrates a complete lack of understanding of the problems of the developing world. Most of the PCs involved would break down pretty quickly - a common problem with inappropriate technology. Listen to Bill Gates. He didn't get where he is today by not knowing what PCs were and were not capable of.
Bill Linton
London N13

webTitle: Floods warning

fields.headline: Floods warning
fields.trailText: We must learn to control our rivers, as others have done in many parts of the world. Flood control (Focus, last week) means dealing with excess water upstream, in the upper and lower headwaters, not in building more dykes and flood walls around urban areas.
fields.body:
We must learn to control our rivers, as others have done in many parts of the world. Flood control (Focus, last week) means dealing with excess water upstream, in the upper and lower headwaters, not in building more dykes and flood walls around urban areas. In recent years, we have come to realise that walling the lower reaches of our rivers is counter-productive as it speeds the flow making for more destructive floods where there is any weakness. In past times, control involved using controlled floods in the form of water meadows which were fed by sluices. We should use this system to take the power from the swollen river and divert it to flatter land where much of it can soak away to the depleted aquifers. What is needed are more weirs, low dams and sluices in the upper reaches of our rivers.
Brayan Taylor
Swansea

webTitle: Letter: Anne Robinson

fields.headline: Anne's the boss
fields.trailText: Anne Robinson's splendid matronly pose on the  Weakest Link  (Focus, last week), makes her seem like a woman who buys her knickers from Securicor.
fields.body:
Anne Robinson's splendid matronly pose on the Weakest Link (Focus, last week), makes her seem like a woman who buys her knickers from Securicor. It is a welcome gimmick to have a quiz show host sounding a little unfriendly. After all, when Forsyth or Monkhouse are jollying people along; they are getting the laughs, not the contestants. A quiz show in which the contestants called the shots, would arguably be firing blanks. Goodbye.
Max Nottingham
Lincoln
fields.bodyText: Anne Robinson's splendid matronly pose on the Weakest Link (Focus, last week), makes her seem like a woman who buys her knickers from Securicor. It is a welcome gimmick to have a quiz show host sounding a little unfriendly. After all, when Forsyth or Monkhouse are jollying people along; they are getting the laughs, not the contestants. A quiz show in which the contestants called the shots, would arguably be firing blanks. Goodbye. Max Nottingham Lincoln

webTitle: Letter: Socialism

fields.headline: A false ideal
fields.trailText: In his profile of Sir John Mortimer (Comment,last week), Tim Adams accepts without question that Mortimer should be a champagne socialist, one who embraces privilege and wealth while claiming to be a socialist.
fields.body:
In his profile of Sir John Mortimer (Comment,last week), Tim Adams accepts without question that Mortimer should be a champagne socialist, one who embraces privilege and wealth while claiming to be a socialist. This acceptance links well with New Labour for, in all the words written by its advocates, it is hard to find one sentence about how socialist principles should be applied to the way we live.

If socialism is about promoting equality, then our actions should reflect this aim. It is inconsistent with socialism to take huge incomes, reside in houses worth a fortune, to hold lucrative private directorships, to accept titles awarded by patronage. Inconsistent because such actions reinforce inequality. It is socialistic to receive no more than average income, to live modestly, to be in close fellowship with the poorest members of society.
Bob Holman
Easterhouse, Glasgow

webTitle: Letter: Air traffic control

fields.headline: Air traffic chaos
fields.trailText: Oliver Morgan missed the point about the public-private partnership for the UK's national Air Traffic Services and how it might affect the future of air traffic control in Europe (Business, 29 October).
fields.body:
Oliver Morgan missed the point about the public-private partnership for the UK's national Air Traffic Services and how it might affect the future of air traffic control in Europe (Business, 29 October).

The airspace over Europe is among the busiest in the world, yet remains divided amongst a host of national operators, and air traffic delays have been a serious problem. This is a sector crying out for enhanced co-operation - through joint ventures, alliances and, ultimately, consolidation. The airlines are in favour, as is the European Commission, which is currently working on proposals for a Single European Sky.
Sir Roy McNulty
Chairman NATS
London WC2

webTitle: Charitable army lost as Spain ends conscription

fields.headline: Charitable army lost as Spain ends conscription
fields.trailText: In the old days, conscientious objectors used to chain themselves to the gates of army headquarters in Madrid. Since 1985 they have simply worked their obligatory 1,100 hours by serving food to the elderly or disabled; in flood prevention or crowd control; giving first aid to drug addicts or legal assistance to refugees.
fields.body:
In the old days, conscientious objectors used to chain themselves to the gates of army headquarters in Madrid. Since 1985 they have simply worked their obligatory 1,100 hours by serving food to the elderly or disabled; in flood prevention or crowd control; giving first aid to drug addicts or legal assistance to refugees.

Spain has, for the last time, called up its young men for obligatory military service - or, in the case of conscientious objectors, to the civilian equivalent, social work with local governments or Non-Governmental Organisations. By the year 2002, Spain will have a professional army, and la mili will cease to exist - along with the concept of obligatory do-gooding.

Few will mourn its passing, but aid workers are concerned that some projects may go under without this large pool of free labour. 'It's so important to us that in the future, when we cannot make use of the objectors, we will have to change the whole way we work,' says Jesús Alonso of Banco de Alimentos, which provides food to the needy.

His branch, in Madrid, delivers four million kilos of donated food a year to around 40,000 people living in old people's homes, orphanages, drug rehabilitation centres and the like. The food bank has 40 older volunteers, 'but we cannot distribute the food because we are not fit enough - key to this network are the objectors,' Alonso continues.

Last year more than 165,000 Spanish men were named as objectors, eligible for 123,000 places offered by the Ministry of Justice in conjunction with local governments and charities. At present, about 82,000 men are working in civil protection, environmental schemes, social and health services, international aid, education, culture and peace projects - and providing invaluable help to many organisations and institutions that care for the poor and for the disadvantaged.

'It helped me because now I have a proper job for the same NGO,' says José Luis Serrano, an objector who found his calling at the Asamblea de Cooperación por la Paz and was subsequently hired as a staffer. 'But I am completely against the philosophy of coercing people, whether into the military or social work.'

The Ministry of Justice is drawing up plans to stimulate good works after 2001; it hopes to create a 'Civil Service', a volunteer army whose members would gain some kind of benefit - perhaps tax-related - in return for their labour. But a ministry spokesman acknowledged that, without 'the coercive factor... the numbers are likely to be reduced'. The Spanish Red Cross employs 8,000 objectors working with 148,000 volunteers. 'It means we will have to adapt. The objectors are immensely helpful, and they are able to work at times when volunteers are not available,' says Adela Moya of the Red Cross. 'But we don't see it as an insuper-able difficulty.'

On Wednesday the Ministry of Defence announced that 90,000 men, the youngest born on 31 December, 1982, the eldest born in 1971, had been called up to the military in 2001. Only a minority of those listed will actually join the army, navy or air force - the rest will seek a delay or declare themselves to be conscientious objectors.

At the time of the final call-up, there were, the Ministry of Defence said, more than 861,000 people who had postponed their service, 700,000 of them to study. What, journalists asked, would happen to them in 2002? There was no clear answer available - entry into the reserves was one option - but it seems likely they will be released from their obligations at the end of 2001.

By then, Spain hopes to have 100,000 men and women under arms, all professionals. But the armed forces are having difficulty recruiting enough soldiers.

The government has even dropped the IQ level required of professional soldiers, but there is no guarantee that it will even reach the proposed 2000 level of 85,000 soldiers. Fewer than 20,000 conscripts, earning around £7 per month, are likely to enter in 2001, the rest either delaying entry or objecting.

webTitle: Emu goes into mystery decline

fields.headline: Emu goes into mystery decline
fields.trailText: An icon of the Australian plains is in trouble. Figures show that more than half of the emu population has been wiped out in the past 20 years. Extinction is not feared yet, but the next few years could be crucial for the giant, flightless bird that has roamed Australia for millions of years.
fields.body:
An icon of the Australian plains is in trouble. Figures show that more than half of the emu population has been wiped out in the past 20 years. Extinction is not feared yet, but the next few years could be crucial for the giant, flightless bird that has roamed Australia for millions of years.

Ornithologists believe the bird, or an ancestor, was here when Australia broke away from the super-continent of Gondwana between 50 and 65 million years ago. Today it stands proudly on the country's coat of arms with a kangaroo. Like all native Australian animals it is protected, but until now has been classed as a low-category risk.

An environmental group, Birds Australia, compiled sightings from 8,000 volunteers nationwide which will eventually comprise part of a new bird atlas. And some conservationists believe that nearer 70 per cent of the birds have been lost, which could herald a slide to extinction.

A few sub-species - the emus of Kangaroo Island, King Island and Tasmania - are the only birds to have disappeared since the European arrivals 200 years ago.

Susan Grant, of Birds Australia, said it could be a year or two before the reasons for the decline can be fully investigated, during which time many more emus may die and the damage might become irreversible. 'Most bird declines can be attributed to habitat loss, but we really don't know yet with the emu,' Grant said.

Emus are hardy and have been known to survive seven or eight years of drought, but pollution, intensive farming and active hunting to prevent crop damage are suspected of adding to the decline.

The latest estimates put the total population somewhere between 600,000 and 700,000. There are 200,000 in Western Australia and around 500,000 in the rest of the country.

webTitle: Beware of Greeks driving taxi cabs... and smiling

fields.headline: Beware of Greeks driving taxi cabs... and smiling
fields.trailText: 'I had that Socrates in the back of my cab once. He didn't know where he wanted to go, but I took him there anyway. And then charged him double.'
fields.body:
'I had that Socrates in the back of my cab once. He didn't know where he wanted to go, but I took him there anyway. And then charged him double.'

For first-time visitors to Athens the ride from the airport in one of the city's 17,000 bright yellow taxis can be a torrid, edge-of-the-seat affair.

Greece has never produced a top Formula One racer. But as they weave through Athens's polluted, gridlocked streets, chain-smoking, hand pressed hard on the horn, muttering obscenities at fellow road users or talking to the girlfriend on the mobile phone, the capital's cabbies appear to pay surly homage to Michael Schumacher at the chicane.

And be warned: reaching for the seatbelt (if there is one) is taken as a slight on their driving skills.

If the meter is off, and you look gullible - the word is the Japanese are the softest touch, closely followed by elderly Americans - expect to be charged two, three, even four times the going rate (about 2,000-2,500 drachma or £4-5). If they have invested in 'the cabbie's friend' - a device that looks like a VCR remote control unit and sets the meter running on extra fast - your bill could be even greater.

Then there's the talk. Americans will be asked to account for the bombing of Serbia and the fall of Slobodan Milosevic (who's still something of a folk hero in Greece); Brits will be treated to a roll call of Manchester United players ('Ryan Geeegs, Daveed Beck-Ham, Denees Arween') and inquiries about Tony Blair's sex life ('Do they [he and Cherie] still do it?').

It is neither the most gracious, nor eloquent, introduction to Athens, the city of Socrates, Plato and Aristotle, and now, most importantly, host for the 2004 Olympic Games.

And government and municipal officials, aware that first impressions are hard to dispel, are determined to do something about it.

Elsewhere, the modern city is slowly being won back for the citizen. There is a crackdown on pollution (on bad days, the nefos - the yellow pall of exhaust fumes and factory emissions - hangs over the city like a shroud), the first lines of a sparkling new metro network are now open, and the ageing fleet of buses and trolleys is being replaced with more environmentally friendly models.

The city's mayor, Dimtiris Avramopoulos, has instigated a massive beautification programme. With the help of European Union money, streets are being cleaned, trees are being planted, and that old municipal standby, the ornamental fountain, is springing up throughout the downtown area.

But, in this brave new world, upgrading the capital's taxi service remains the most challenging task of all.

All hail, then, to the new taxi drivers' charter - a set of obligations and rights for cab drivers soon to be announced by Greece's Transport Minister, Christos Verelis. The government hopes it will install a new sense of discipline and duty in the capital's cabbies, please exasperated Athenians and provide a more user-friendly interface with the city for the hordes of foreign visitors.

Cab drivers must carry a local map in their vehicle and are expected to be familiar with basic arterial routes and common tourist sights. Nothing like ' the knowledge' exists in Athens, and it is still possible to find drivers who struggle to locate the Acropolis.

Drivers are not entitled to refuse a fair, unless a passenger is on drugs or drunk, and may not charge multiple fares or charge extra flagfall payments per customer. They must help load and unload luggage from the pavement to the cab and back, and accept domestic animals so long as they are accompanied by their owner, are clean and, in the case of dogs, wearing a collar and a muzzle.

The drivers themselves must also be clean and 'decently dressed' - though there is no stipulation as to muzzling - and they must not smoke or listen to music without the passenger's consent. The most important provision concerns road safety (Greece's roads are among the deadliest in Europe). Cabs must not drop off at intersections, turnings or main roads.

The new charter must be displayed in each taxi - though where the driver will find space among the nodding furry animals, the plastic coffee-cup holders, the photographs of his mother and the icons of the Virgin Mary, is not clear.

The Greek government has tried all this before. In 1997, the year Greece won the Olympic bid, it announced a tourism awareness campaign to encourage Athens's grouchy cab drivers to put on a friendly face for visitors.

A series of posters parodying cigarette ads stated: 'The Greek National Tourism Organisation Warns: Smiling is Good for our Health and for our Economy.' One ad pictured a taxi driver leaning out of his window with a happy grin on his face. True, the good taxi drivers outnumber the bad, but rarely, if ever, has an Athenian cabbie smiled so convincingly.

webTitle: World in brief

fields.headline: World in brief
fields.trailText:
Danes bid farewell to Queen Mother Ingrid
Thousands of Danes queued outside Christiansborg palace chapel in an icy wind to file past the body of Queen Mother Ingrid, who died on Tuesday aged 90. One 73-year-old paid tribute to '65 years of service to this country'. The funeral is on Tuesday.
fields.body:
Danes bid farewell to Queen Mother Ingrid
Thousands of Danes queued outside Christiansborg palace chapel in an icy wind to file past the body of Queen Mother Ingrid, who died on Tuesday aged 90. One 73-year-old paid tribute to '65 years of service to this country'. The funeral is on Tuesday.

War crime suspect Karadzic's wife votes
The wife of Bosnia's war crimes suspect Radovan Karadzic cast her ballot in the country's third national election since the end of the Bosnian war five years ago. She refused to say whether she voted for candidates of the Serb Democratic Party, which her husband once led. He remains at large despite the presence of 20,000 international peacekeepers.

Protest sparks deaths
A memorial service in honour of the Nigerian author Ken Saro-Wiwa, hanged five years ago, ended in a clash in Ogoniland with three people killed and three wounded. Fighting broke out when supporters excluded from the event began an angry protest march.

Veterans honoured
Five of the last French survivors of the First World War, all aged 103 or 104, attended Armistice Day ceremonies in Paris.

Sheltered from the wind and covered in blankets, they were saluted by President Jacques Chirac in their seats near the Arc de Triomphe.

Petula takes Lloyd Webber to California
Petula Clark is arriving in Pasadena, California, to star in a touring production of The Music of Andrew Lloyd Webber. The singer, 68 on Wednesday, appeared in the West End production of Sunset Boulevard from 1995-97, and on the show's US tour in 1998 and 1999.

Bomb injures 11 outside Basque police station
Nine policemen and two bystanders were injured in an explosion outside a police station in the northern Spanish city of San Sebastián in an attack blamed on Basque separatists. Grenades that were thrown at the base did little damage but when police ran to investigate the incident a bomb that had been hidden nearby went off.

Election death toll rises
The death toll in anti-government demonstrations in Mozambique has risen to 36. Opposition party supporters marched, erected roadblocks and took hostages. The demonstrations were in protest at election results, which the opposition alleges were rigged.

French ex-premier dies
Jacques Chaban-Delmas, French Prime Minister from 1969 to 1972 and remembered for his willingness to embrace social change despite the disapproval of fellow conservatives, has died at 85. He was a hero of the French Resistance who went on to serve as Bordeaux mayor for 48 years.

webTitle: Commune returns to the jungle of terror

fields.headline: Commune returns to the jungle of terror
fields.standfirst: Woman and girl trekked into Andes to negotiate with Colombian guerrillas
fields.trailText: When two of their youngest members were slaughtered by guerrillas, members of the Atlantis commune were forced to flee the paradise they had carved out of the Colombian jungle.
fields.body:
When two of their youngest members were slaughtered by guerrillas, members of the Atlantis commune were forced to flee the paradise they had carved out of the Colombian jungle.

But now the motley collection of English and Irish environmentalists, hippies, amateur psychotherapists and New Age travellers - notorious in the Seventies as 'The Screamers' - are heading back to the killing ground with just a verbal guarantee of their safety from the local guerrilla commanders.

In a newsletter emailed to The Observer - none of the commune members has regular access to telephones, fax or post - Anne Barr, one of its longest-serving members, describes a long trek through the forests and mountains of the Andes in search of information about the double murder. She describes how, at great risk, she contacted senior military officers in Armed Revolutionary Forces of Colombia (Farc) - one of the biggest and best armed guerrilla forces in the world - and negotiated a safe passage.

The 15-year-old daughter of another member of the commune joined her for the journey armed with a guitar and a series of songs to sing to the guerrilla commanders.

The murder that forced the exile of the group from the land they had farmed for 20 years took place last July. Tristan James, an 18-year-old from Co Donegal, and 19-year-old Xavier Nova, a Colombian, were stabbed, decapitated and then burnt by a guerrilla group who accused them of being spies.

In horrific scenes, drunken, gun-toting soldiers tied the young men's hands behind their backs in the centre of the small village of Hoya Grande and ordered the villagers to watch as they held a kangaroo court.

The soldiers then executed the pair.

The killing followed a period of worsening relations between the guerrillas and the commune, who had used their farm in Icononzo in the Tolima district of Colombia as a base to campaign for vegetarianism and environmentalism. Farc told the group to leave their land late last year. James, who planned to travel to Ireland this autumn, had returned with Nova to say a final goodbye to his younger brother who had been adopted by a Colombian couple in the village. The two men were walking to Nova's home when they were seized.

The Atlantis farm - where the group raised cattle, chicken and guinea fowl and grew organic vegetables - is more than a day's travel south of the capital, Bogotá, and deep in Farc territory.

Tensions between the group and the guerrillas had risen as the three-way war between the Colombian government, Farc and right-wing paramilitaries intensified. More than 30,000 people - mostly civilians - are estimated to have died in the fighting in the last 10 years.

Much of the violence has been sparked by a struggle for control of the country's massive cocaine industry.

The group was set up in the Seventies to promote primal scream therapy and communal living in a remote village in western Ireland. Allegations of drug abuse and promiscuous sex led to raids by the Garda. After 10 years, the leaders of the group moved to Colombia, where they found the freedom to live as they wanted.

Barr's email tells of a 'week- long odyssey through the mountains of Tolima in search of the commanders of the 25th Front of the Farc'.

'Our journey felt simple,' she writes. 'We were going to look for justice from the revolutionary authorities.'

Barr admits the journey was extremely dangerous. She was aware that it was her decision to allow James and Nova to go back to the Icononzo farm earlier in the year that led to their deaths. 'To our Colombian city friends, we were out of our heads, going to hell itself and would certainly be kidnapped if not worse, [but] we could find no fear or nervousness in our hearts.'

The pair travelled by bus for days before finding a senior guerrilla commander. The meeting, Barr says, was fruitful; the soldier apologised profusely for the deaths of the two young men.

'Laura sang him some very beautiful songs against the reign of fear and silence that is strangling this country. I sang some songs, and the commander recited poems about Che Guevara,' the commune's newsletter says.

A second meeting with a more senior commander resulted in the guarantee of safe passage.

Barr said that the group's aims were clear: 'We plan to go into the village where the boys were killed [and] attempt to create a new, more human way of dealing with the violence and pain caused by such horrific but commonplace brutality.'

webTitle: Inferno in the Alps

fields.headline: Inferno in the Alps
fields.standfirst:
• Over 150 killed in ski train tunnel disaster
• Children among the victims of fierce blaze
fields.trailText: UP TO 170 people were killed yesterday when fire engulfed an Austrian funicular train carrying skiers - many of them children - through a three-kilometre Alpine tunnel.
fields.body:
UP TO 170 people were killed yesterday when fire engulfed an Austrian funicular train carrying skiers - many of them children - through a three-kilometre Alpine tunnel.

Downing Street said last night that it feared that a number of British holidaymakers were among the dead, after Prime Minister Tony Blair spoke to Austria's Chancellor, Wolfgang Schuessel, yesterday by phone.

News of possible British fatalities came as Austria declared an official two day period of mourning and announced a criminal investigation into the tragedy. There was speculation that the blaze may have been started by an electrical fault.

The inferno, which reached temperatures of more than 1000 C, virtually vaporised the train. Up to 180 people were on board, but the exact death toll was not known last night in Europe's worst Alpine disaster.

The funicular was carrying people from the resort of Kaprun, near Salzburg, for a weekend of early season skiing and snowboarding.

Many of the young people who died had been travelling to a snowboarding competition.

Hospital staff in the town of Zell am See said they had treated up to 18 survivors, including a number who had managed to escape thanks to the heroic efforts of an unidentified man who managed to smash a rear window on the train with a ski pole.

The passengers perished when the train transporting them to a glacier skiing area caught fire, trapping them inside the smoke-filled tunnel.

Rescue co-ordinators said last night that many of the victims had apparently managed to escape from the compartment, but were quickly overcome by acrid smoke as they tried to flee by running upward on narrow stairs leading out of the tunnel.

Manfred Muller, head of cable car technical operations, said those who survived apparently ran the opposite way, thus evading most of the smoke being blown upward by strong drafts pushing through the tunnel.

Rescuers say the narrowness and steepness of the tunnel - which is used by tens of thousands of skiers from across Europe, including British holidaymakers - transformed it into a 'giant chimney', sucking in air to fuel the flames.

The resulting fire was so intense that when rescuers finally reached the site, only the train's twisted metal base remained.

'Two railway workers came directly from the tunnel and told us all they had found was the metal base of the train,' said state governor Franz Schuasberger. 'Everything else was burnt out. We have to deduce the sad news that none of the passengers survived.'

Three skiers who were waiting in a passenger area at the top of the tunnel also died from smoke inhalation. Also among the dead was the cable car attendant in the otherwise empty car returning down the mountain.

The tragedy raises serious questions about fire safety in Europe's road and rail tunnels. Last year, 40 people died in an inferno in the Mont Blanc road tunnel between France and Italy that started when a truck caught fire. Again the ferocity of the fire was blamed on the tunnel's ventilation.

Yesterday's fire is believed to have started in the front section of the train after one of the cables that pull the train up the mountain snapped, apparently starting the blaze beneath the train.

Mueller, the head of technical operations for the underground cable car system, said the car operator was told to open all doors in the five to 10 minutes that elapsed between the sounding of an alarm and the sudden break of radio contact with the cable car attendant.

He said he was mystified by how a fire could have started. The funicular had been inspected in September by safety inspectors who gave it a clean bill of health.

Salzburg Red Cross commander Gerhard Huber said there were between 150 and 170 victims, of whom half were Austrians. Among those missing were 23 Americans, including two children, from a ski club at the US military's Leighton Barracks in Würzburg, Germany.

'The fire engulfed two carriages in the middle of the tunnel,' said Huber. 'It was impossible for rescuers to reach them quickly. This is a truly shocking and horrific disaster.'

An unidentified employee of the cable car system spoke of choking 'beastly smoke' that forced him and others to run from their office at the mouth of the tunnel.

'Most of them [the dead] were teenagers,' a clearly shocked state governor Schausberger said. 'Today is a day of mourning.' Austria's president Thomas Klestil also expressed condolences.

Kitzsteinhorn glacier has long been a popular ski resort. Located 60 miles south of Salzburg at the end of an Alpine valley, the area serves many day skiers from neighbouring Germany. As the full horror of Austria's worst peacetime disaster emerged, authorities were asking how an allegedly 'fireproof' train had burst into flames.

Engineer Klaus Eisenkolb, who has inspected the train in the past, said that it was fitted with safety systems to bring the vehicle to an immediate halt if one of the cables snapped. 'It is not supposed to burn because the materials used are fire-resistant,' he added.

But burn it did, releasing poisonous fumes which quickly overcame the trapped skiers as temperatures soared to several hundred degrees.

Eyewitness Christian Wakolbinger described how the smoke had even affected people in the mountain station at the top of the railway, which is where three of the fatalities are believed to have occurred. 'The smoke swept up the tunnel so quickly that some people in the Alpine Centre were affected by smoke poisoning,' he said.

The tunnel was opened in 1974 with the present train installed in 1994.

Austrian chancellor Wolfgang Schussel told Tony Balir last night that he believed that Britons were among the dead. The Foreign Office has issued two hotline numbers for concerned relatives on 0043 654 720 000 and 0043 662 8144 300.

webTitle: Skier Bell tells of his fears

fields.headline: Skier Bell tells of his fears
fields.trailText: Martin Bell, the former British Olympic skier, spoke yesterday of his fears for former schoolfriends and racing colleagues who may have died in the tragedy.
fields.body:
Martin Bell, the former British Olympic skier, spoke yesterday of his fears for former schoolfriends and racing colleagues who may have died in the tragedy.

Bell, who spent much of his teenage years and twenties in the Austrian resort of Kaprun, said that the funicular railway may well have been carrying dozens of ski racers and their coaches up to the Kitzsteinhorn glacier for a day of early season training. After years spent in the resort, Bell says he knows many of those working in the Austrian skiing world. 'My first thought when I heard the news was were any of my friends in there?' he told The Observer yesterday.

'I am very worried about them. If it was early in the morning there would have been a lot of professional skiers on the train.'

Bell said he first took the train in 1976 - only two years after it opened - when training with the Kandahar ski club at the age of 11.

'It was the first such lift I had been on and I remember thinking it was amazing. It was all shining and metal and really futuristic,' he said.

Bell said that as he got older and saw other similar trains, the Kitzsteinhorn funicular seemed smaller and slower, and he was never worried about its safety. 'I can honestly say that I never thought "What would happen if the train caught fire?",' he said.

'I remember wondering what would happen if the cable broke but I was never concerned. When you are training as a racer you have better things to worry about. You just see time on the lift as wasted, like commuting.'

Nigel Lloyd, The Observer's skiing correspondent, first took the train 15 years ago. 'It was quite an impressive sight. This was in 1985 and it was the first time I had been on one of these things.

'We filed on and I remember feeling a little apprehensive. It was obviously a wonderful piece of engineering but it was pretty claustrophobic.

'We were all in there with our skis and everything and soon it was just like being on a crowded tube in the rush hour, heading up a steep hill. I remember it had staggered steps all the way through it to keep the floor level as it went up the incline.

'We all spilled out at the top station and the clear, cold mountain air felt great. It was a wonderful change to get out of the thing.

'We transferred on to the drag and chair lifts and had a great day's skiing. But then, of course, we had to get it back down again.'

Lloyd wrote at the time: 'At the end of the day you have to queue and crowd into the standing room-only mountain train to get back down.

'As it is a funicular, you often find yourself standing, unable to shift your position, with one ski boot on one step and the other cramped down about a foot below.'
