webTitle: 'A couple of breaths  and they were lost'

fields.headline: 'A couple of breaths  and they were lost'
fields.standfirst: Skiwear fed the flames and the world's safest train melted in seconds
fields.trailText: It was a perfect, clear morning for the start of the skiing season as the little cable train started its 12-minute journey towards the Alpine peak of Kitzsteinhorn. More than 2,000 young people had come to the resort for a weekend snowboarding event on a slope used for training by Austria's budding ski champions.
fields.body:
It was a perfect, clear morning for the start of the skiing season as the little cable train started its 12-minute journey towards the Alpine peak of Kitzsteinhorn. More than 2,000 young people had come to the resort for a weekend snowboarding event on a slope used for training by Austria's budding ski champions.

As 180 passengers boarded the modern train, reputed to be the safest in the world, sensors along the doorways recorded how many people were on board before the doors automatically slid shut. The short train journey was itself an exciting prospect and, although most of the three-kilometre ride was underground, the passengers had little reason to feel afraid.

Drawn by a five centimetre-thick steel cable, the train had no engine, but if the cable snapped a braking mechanism would be applied automatically, preventing the train from falling downhill. Only 600 metres into the journey, however, soon after the little vehicle entered the long mountain tunnel, a fire broke out at the back of the carriage and, within a few minutes, almost everyone on board was dead.

Last night relatives and friends began to gather below the tunnel's entrance, fearing the worst as emergency crews tried to determine who was dead and who was only unaccounted for.

Ashen-faced and crying, friends and relatives waited for word of where their loved ones were. On an Alpine slope in the heart of the Austrian Alps south of Salzburg, or dead inside a cable car demolished by fire as it was being pulled up to the glacier skiing area.

Road access to the tunnel was blocked by police, with even friends and relatives unable to get access to the site.

Instead, down the valley, in the resort town of Kaprun, they gathered in a sports hall to wait for lists to be produced of where who was: on the slopes; in hotels and hostels - or unaccounted for.

'It became very hot in the tunnel very quickly and a thick fog of smoke appeared,' according to Ulrich Cimolino, an expert in tunnel fires at the Duesseldorf fire service.

The two openings of the tunnel created the effect of an oven, raising the temperature inside close to 1000C.

Eight German passengers at the back of the carriage used their ski equipment to smash through the rear window and clambered out to safety. They were treated for smoke poisoning at a nearby hospital, along with some eyewitnesses who were standing almost a mile away uphill.

'The smoke moved through the tunnel so fast that some people inside the Alpine centre were affected by the smoke poisoning. The smoke coming out of the tunnel is terrible,' said Christian Wakolbinger, an eyewitness.

For the passengers who remained inside, death came quickly. Their heavy, cumbersome ski boots made any chance of escape slim.

'After a few intakes of breath, one would be unconscious and within 15 minutes the victims would be dead,' said Cimolino.

As rescue workers arrived at the scene, supported by 20 accident and emergency doctors attending a conference nearby, they were horrified by what they saw. As they fought their way through the smoke, they discovered that all that was left of the train was its steel frame.

'The whole train has melted,' said one rescue worker. Helicopters flew hundreds of rescue workers from other parts of Austria and Germany to the scene within minutes but it was almost five hours before the fire was finally put out. Fire experts said that the tunnel had functioned like a chimney, making survival almost impossible. By the time paramedics reached the train, the victims had been burnt beyond recognition.

Experts were last night investigating the cause of the fire but most agreed that the highly flammable ski clothing worn by the young passengers probably helped the fire to spread as quickly as it did. Cimolino believes that the passengers' escape options were limited, particularly if they attempted to run away from the fire and in the direction the smoke was blowing.

'The best thing would have been to run downwards through the flames, but who's going to know that?' he said.

Klaus Eisenkolb, an engineer who has inspected the train in the past, said he could not understand how the fire started because the vehicle was protected against such an eventuality. 'It is not supposed to burn because the materials used are fire-resistant,' he said.

The rescue operation was still under way last night with 13 helicopters flying overhead. Police asked motorists to avoid roads in the area to keep them free for ambulances and fire engines.

As emergency numbers were set up in Austria and Germany, the 2000 young snowboarders in the area were evacuated and asked to report details of any friends who were missing. Norbert Karlsboeck, mayor of the nearby village of Kaprun, said it remained unclear how many people were on board the train but he feared that at least 170 had died.

'It was probably full because it was a beautiful day for skiing,' he said.

Yesterday's disaster was the second tragedy to hit Kitzsteinhorn this year. Twelve people died in March when an avalanche engulfed a group of trainee ski instructors. Just 100 km south-west of Salzburg, the mountain is one of the most popular ski resorts in Austria and attracts visitors all year round.

Along with the neighbouring resort of Zell am See, it is billed to travellers as the 'Europa-Sportregion,' 130 km of slopes spread across the Hohe Tauern mountain range.

Kaprun's streets are lined by traditional stucco and wood chalet-style houses and hotels, their overhanging roofs iced in winter with a thick layer of snow.

The area is also a popular site for weekend skiers from Germany - the region is just a three-hour drive from Munich.

Many tourists are drawn to the area, which was made famous by the film The Sound of Music by the prospect of combining a ski holiday with a visit to Mozart's birthplace in Salzburg. Most of yesterday's victims are believed to have been Austrians and Germans, many of whom would have crossed the border yesterday morning for a day on the slopes.

The cable train at Kitzsteinhorn was regarded as a technical miracle when it was installed in 1974 and it soon became known as the 'Alpine Underground'. 3300 metres of its 4050-metre track runs underground and, although it runs on tracks like a conventional train, it is drawn by a cable. This combination of cable and track, allied with its emergency braking mechanism, has given the cable train an unrivalled reputation for safety.

Two new trains were added in 1994, reducing the journey time from the valley to the Alpine centre to just 12 minutes. The resort is used as a training area for Austria's junior national ski team but snowboarders have accounted for an ever greater number of the resort's visitors in recent years. Snow boarding has given a new lease of life to many Austrian ski resorts, as thousands of young people flock to weekend parties that combine snowboarding with techno music. Many such events are sponsored by clothing firms that target young snowboarders.

Yesterday's disaster was unprecedented in Europe, although dozens of people have lost their lives in cable car and mountain railway accidents in recent years. Thirteen people died last year when two trains crashed near Garmisch and 20 people were killed when a US military aircraft snapped the cable of a cable car in the Italian Dolomites in 1998. In June this year, 64 people were injured when two cog trains collided near Germany's highest mountain, the Zugspitze and dozens of people died last year in a fire in the Mont Blanc road tunnel when a truck caught fire.

As Austria went into mourning for the victims yesterday, the governor of Salzburg, Franz Schausberger, said that the entire region was in shock. 'We have not experienced such a tragedy within living memory. There are at least 150 people dead, primarily young people, who perhaps decided on the spur of the moment to do some winter sports.

'I have ordered mourning in the province. We cannot find the right words at the moment.'

Death in the Alps

1976: 42 people killed when lift system collapses in Italian Alps.

February 1998: 20 people killed when US military jet cut the cable of a ski-lift near Cavalese, Italy.

February 1999: Avalanche killed 12 people and swept away 23 chalets near Chamonix, France.

February 1999: 31 die in avalanche in Austrian village of Galtur.

March 1999: 45 people were killed in a fire in Mont Blanc tunnel linking France and Italy.

May 1999: Four killed in fire in Tauern Tunnel in the Austrian Alps.

July 1999: 20 killed in cable car accident in French alpine resort of St-Etienne-en-Devoluy.

August 2000: Four climbers die in avalanche in the French Alps.

October 2000: 35 people killed by mudslides in Valle d'Aosta in the Italian Alps.

Denis Staunton writes for the Irish Times.
fields.bodyText: It was a perfect, clear morning for the start of the skiing season as the little cable train started its 12-minute journey towards the Alpine peak of Kitzsteinhorn. More than 2,000 young people had come to the resort for a weekend snowboarding event on a slope used for training by Austria's budding ski champions. As 180 passengers boarded the modern train, reputed to be the safest in the world, sensors along the doorways recorded how many people were on board before the doors automatically slid shut. The short train journey was itself an exciting prospect and, although most of the three-kilometre ride was underground, the passengers had little reason to feel afraid. Drawn by a five centimetre-thick steel cable, the train had no engine, but if the cable snapped a braking mechanism would be applied automatically, preventing the train from falling downhill. Only 600 metres into the journey, however, soon after the little vehicle entered the long mountain tunnel, a fire broke out at the back of the carriage and, within a few minutes, almost everyone on board was dead. Last night relatives and friends began to gather below the tunnel's entrance, fearing the worst as emergency crews tried to determine who was dead and who was only unaccounted for. Ashen-faced and crying, friends and relatives waited for word of where their loved ones were. On an Alpine slope in the heart of the Austrian Alps south of Salzburg, or dead inside a cable car demolished by fire as it was being pulled up to the glacier skiing area. Road access to the tunnel was blocked by police, with even friends and relatives unable to get access to the site. Instead, down the valley, in the resort town of Kaprun, they gathered in a sports hall to wait for lists to be produced of where who was: on the slopes; in hotels and hostels - or unaccounted for. 'It became very hot in the tunnel very quickly and a thick fog of smoke appeared,' according to Ulrich Cimolino, an expert in tunnel fires at the Duesseldorf fire service. The two openings of the tunnel created the effect of an oven, raising the temperature inside close to 1000C. Eight German passengers at the back of the carriage used their ski equipment to smash through the rear window and clambered out to safety. They were treated for smoke poisoning at a nearby hospital, along with some eyewitnesses who were standing almost a mile away uphill. 'The smoke moved through the tunnel so fast that some people inside the Alpine centre were affected by the smoke poisoning. The smoke coming out of the tunnel is terrible,' said Christian Wakolbinger, an eyewitness. For the passengers who remained inside, death came quickly. Their heavy, cumbersome ski boots made any chance of escape slim. 'After a few intakes of breath, one would be unconscious and within 15 minutes the victims would be dead,' said Cimolino. As rescue workers arrived at the scene, supported by 20 accident and emergency doctors attending a conference nearby, they were horrified by what they saw. As they fought their way through the smoke, they discovered that all that was left of the train was its steel frame. 'The whole train has melted,' said one rescue worker. Helicopters flew hundreds of rescue workers from other parts of Austria and Germany to the scene within minutes but it was almost five hours before the fire was finally put out. Fire experts said that the tunnel had functioned like a chimney, making survival almost impossible. By the time paramedics reached the train, the victims had been burnt beyond recognition. Experts were last night investigating the cause of the fire but most agreed that the highly flammable ski clothing worn by the young passengers probably helped the fire to spread as quickly as it did. Cimolino believes that the passengers' escape options were limited, particularly if they attempted to run away from the fire and in the direction the smoke was blowing. 'The best thing would have been to run downwards through the flames, but who's going to know that?' he said. Klaus Eisenkolb, an engineer who has inspected the train in the past, said he could not understand how the fire started because the vehicle was protected against such an eventuality. 'It is not supposed to burn because the materials used are fire-resistant,' he said. The rescue operation was still under way last night with 13 helicopters flying overhead. Police asked motorists to avoid roads in the area to keep them free for ambulances and fire engines. As emergency numbers were set up in Austria and Germany, the 2000 young snowboarders in the area were evacuated and asked to report details of any friends who were missing. Norbert Karlsboeck, mayor of the nearby village of Kaprun, said it remained unclear how many people were on board the train but he feared that at least 170 had died. 'It was probably full because it was a beautiful day for skiing,' he said. Yesterday's disaster was the second tragedy to hit Kitzsteinhorn this year. Twelve people died in March when an avalanche engulfed a group of trainee ski instructors. Just 100 km south-west of Salzburg, the mountain is one of the most popular ski resorts in Austria and attracts visitors all year round. Along with the neighbouring resort of Zell am See, it is billed to travellers as the 'Europa-Sportregion,' 130 km of slopes spread across the Hohe Tauern mountain range. Kaprun's streets are lined by traditional stucco and wood chalet-style houses and hotels, their overhanging roofs iced in winter with a thick layer of snow. The area is also a popular site for weekend skiers from Germany - the region is just a three-hour drive from Munich. Many tourists are drawn to the area, which was made famous by the film The Sound of Music by the prospect of combining a ski holiday with a visit to Mozart's birthplace in Salzburg. Most of yesterday's victims are believed to have been Austrians and Germans, many of whom would have crossed the border yesterday morning for a day on the slopes. The cable train at Kitzsteinhorn was regarded as a technical miracle when it was installed in 1974 and it soon became known as the 'Alpine Underground'. 3300 metres of its 4050-metre track runs underground and, although it runs on tracks like a conventional train, it is drawn by a cable. This combination of cable and track, allied with its emergency braking mechanism, has given the cable train an unrivalled reputation for safety. Two new trains were added in 1994, reducing the journey time from the valley to the Alpine centre to just 12 minutes. The resort is used as a training area for Austria's junior national ski team but snowboarders have accounted for an ever greater number of the resort's visitors in recent years. Snow boarding has given a new lease of life to many Austrian ski resorts, as thousands of young people flock to weekend parties that combine snowboarding with techno music. Many such events are sponsored by clothing firms that target young snowboarders. Yesterday's disaster was unprecedented in Europe, although dozens of people have lost their lives in cable car and mountain railway accidents in recent years. Thirteen people died last year when two trains crashed near Garmisch and 20 people were killed when a US military aircraft snapped the cable of a cable car in the Italian Dolomites in 1998. In June this year, 64 people were injured when two cog trains collided near Germany's highest mountain, the Zugspitze and dozens of people died last year in a fire in the Mont Blanc road tunnel when a truck caught fire. As Austria went into mourning for the victims yesterday, the governor of Salzburg, Franz Schausberger, said that the entire region was in shock. 'We have not experienced such a tragedy within living memory. There are at least 150 people dead, primarily young people, who perhaps decided on the spur of the moment to do some winter sports. 'I have ordered mourning in the province. We cannot find the right words at the moment.' Death in the Alps 1976: 42 people killed when lift system collapses in Italian Alps. February 1998: 20 people killed when US military jet cut the cable of a ski-lift near Cavalese, Italy. February 1999: Avalanche killed 12 people and swept away 23 chalets near Chamonix, France. May 1999: Four killed in fire in Tauern Tunnel in the Austrian Alps. July 1999: 20 killed in cable car accident in French alpine resort of St-Etienne-en-Devoluy. August 2000: Four climbers die in avalanche in the French Alps. October 2000: 35 people killed by mudslides in Valle d'Aosta in the Italian Alps. Denis Staunton writes for the Irish Times.

webTitle: Safety fears as list of tragic accidents grows

fields.headline: Safety fears as list of tragic accidents grows
fields.trailText: The tragedy inside the Kitzsteinhorn mountain is probably the worst Alpine disaster ever, and the first involving a funicular railway. However, it follows an extraordinary series of catastrophes in the Alps that have claimed hundreds of lives in recent years, raising serious concerns about safety standards
fields.body:
The tragedy inside the Kitzsteinhorn mountain is probably the worst Alpine disaster ever, and the first involving a funicular railway. However, it follows an extraordinary series of catastrophes in the Alps that have claimed hundreds of lives in recent years, raising serious concerns about safety standards. Previous trag-edies include collapsing cable cars, tunnel fires, avalanches in residential areas and mud slides.

In March last year, 45 died in a fire in the 35-year-old Mont Blanc road tunnel that links France and Italy. There was no separate service tunnel in such an old structure and passengers took refuge in special shelters inside the tunnel that failed to protect them. Two telephones nearest the fire were out of order, preventing victims from calling for help. A ventilator was blocked, sending dense fumes back into the tunnel.

A few months previously, the French fire service had noted serious safety problems in the tunnel, but its report was ignored by the French authorities. The company which manages the tunnel had never carried out an evacuation exercise for fear of disrupting traffic.

A few months later an inferno in the Tauern Tunnel near Salzburg in the Austrian Alps killed four people and injured 67. The fire started when a lorry loaded with paint collided with an oncoming car. Traffic experts had repeatedly argued that a second tunnel should be dug to separate vehicles moving in opposite directions.

Two months later, in the French Alps, 20 people were killed as their cable car plunged 260 feet. The car was taking scientists, cleaners and maintenance workers to the astronomical observatory at St-Etienne-en-Devoluy. There were no survivors the worst cable car disaster in French history. It is thought the car became unhooked from the cable in the 20 -year-old system.

The death toll equalled that of the disaster in the Italian resort of Cavalese a year earlier when a US marine jet severed the cable of a ski gondola. Twenty tourists were killed when the gondola plunged to the ground. Cavalese was also the site of the Alps' worst cable car accident, when 42 people were killed in 1976.

There has also been a rising tide of death from natural disasters. Last year, more than 100 people were killed in avalanches in the Alps, one of the worst years on record. In February alone, avalanches killed 12 people near the ski resort of Chamonix, and 31 people near the Austrian village of Galtur. In both cases, residential areas that had been declared safe were swept away. In March this year, an avalanche killed 12 people south of Salzburg.

Unusually wet weather this year has caused mudslides and floods. Last month whole villages in the Valle d'Aosta were swept away by mud, rocks and water, killing more than 35 people.

webTitle: The coming of the Lottery changed the face of UK betting

fields.headline: A nation fond of a flutter
fields.standfirst: Jill Insley  on how  the coming of the Lottery changed the face of UK betting
fields.trailText: Jill Insley on how the coming of the Lottery changed the face of UK betting • Spread betting
fields.body:
The chance of becoming a Lottery millionaire is very slim - one in 14 million - although 1,053 have been created since the first draw, six years ago next weekend. But the sight of ordinary people winning enormous prizes has spurred a large proportion of the population to try every week.

Ticket sales for the Saturday Lottery alone over the past six years are more than £24.7 billion, and some 458,798,590 tickets have won prizes for their owners. Camelot, the company running the Lottery, estimates that there are 4 million winning tickets every week. Sixty-five per cent of the UK's adults play the Lottery at least once a month, and the average bet is £3.

The Lottery has managed what all other forms of gambling previously failed to achieve - to make gambling acceptable. It has crossed all social and economic barriers - the Daily Mirror speculated that the Queen Mother had bought a ticket, while one jackpot winner was found to be living out of the back of his car.

The Lottery initially hit the sales of other gaming and gambling institutions by attracting the money of their regular customers. But although very few of those people gambling for the first time through the Lottery have moved on to other 'harder' forms of gambling, many have been happy to bet on other lotteries and number-based games. Chris Butcher, leisure consultant for market research company Mintel, says: 'People don't view number-based games as hardcore betting; it's seen very much as 'soft' gambling, and some don't regard it as gambling at all.'

Betting shops and bingo halls have responded by playing the Lottery at its own game. Graham Sharpe, a spokesman for William Hill says: 'The Lottery made our business scatty for the first year or two, but it gave us a kick up the backside to compete more aggressively. We launched number-based games offering better odds, concentrating on getting three numbers. The payments for lower numbers are better - for three numbers you can win about £500. It's worked well for us.'

Custom & Excise figures show that although taxes levied on the pools have slumped from £342 million in the year the Lottery was launched to £69.8m in the 1998/99 tax year, taxes generated by most other forms of gambling have increased over the same period. Duty paid on fruit machines has grown from £106.1m to £156.5m; bingo duty has increased from £84.4m to £105m; and general betting duty from off-course bookmakers has increased from £6,563m to £7,109m.

Camelot has found that punters are more influenced by the size of the prize on offer, rather than the chances of winning it. Although people have a much better chance of winning the £250,000 Thunderball jackpot - one in 3,895,584 - only 16 per cent of those questioned by Mintel bought Thunderball tickets in the 12 months to November 1999, compared with 76 per cent taking part in the main Saturday draw. In contrast National Savings anticipated the launch of the Lottery by introducing a monthly £1m Premium Bond prize in April 1994 and the amount spent on bonds has increased from £831m in the first half of 1995 to £1,485m in the first half of this year.

But while bingo halls, betting shops, arcades and the Chancellor are doing nicely from this new enthusiasm, some punters are faring less well. Gamblers' Anonymous reports telephone inquires up 10 per cent year on year since the advent of the Lottery. A spokesman said: 'People's perception of gambling has changed. It's socially acceptable now because it's advertised on TV.'

A bet that let's you cut your losses? Spread's the word

Spread betting is a relatively new form of gambling for those who are really fanatical about numbers. Spread bets can be made on virtually anything, from the number of goals in a football match to the percentage share of votes for theUS President. They can also be made on any UK share, where the company has a market capitalisation of more than £30m, on any leading stock market index, on interest rates and bonds, exchange rates, commodities and options. For this reason spread betting has been most popular in the City.

Spread bets can be made either up or down. Take as an example the number of runs England skipper Nasser Hussein would make in a three-match one-day cricket series against Pakistan. The bookmaker may quote a spread of 80-90 for Hussein's runs. You make an imaginary £1-a-run up-bet from 90, gambling on Hussein enjoying a good series. After the third match ends, Hussein has scored a total of 135 runs. Your profits are £45 (135 minus 90, times £1). However, if Hussein scored just 45 runs, you would lose £35 (80 minus 45, times £1).

But spread bets can be much more complicated, with spreads moving during the course of the bet. Angus McCrone, an economics and financial journalist who has recently launched a spread betting information website - Onewaybet.com - says it can also prove a very flexible and exciting way to bet.

'Unlike traditional fixed-odds bets, spread bets can be 'closed out' or stopped at any time. This means the gambler can limit his losses, or take his profits while he's ahead.

'It's more exciting than traditional betting because you take a view based on your judgment, and if you are very right, you can make a lot more money than if you are a little right.'

The biggest win through financial spread betting is reputed to be £5 million, won by one punter betting on the sterling-French franc exchange rate in the late Nineties. However, Mc-Crone warns that losses can be hefty too, although bookmakers tend to close out bets if they think a client is going to be unable to pay the even tual losses. Bookmakers require a deposit upfront. McCrone recommends that only those with several thousand pounds in cash that they can afford to lose try this form of betting.

Details of bookmakers specialising in spread betting are provided on McCrone's website at www.onewaybet.com.

Ernie's nice little earner

Premium bonds must be the safest way to gamble. The scheme is run by the Government: your stake - the capital you spend on buying bonds - is entered into the prize draw every month and you can withdraw it whenever you want. The only risk you take is that you won't win any prizes, effectively losing out on any returns that you could have earned by investing your money elsewhere.

Each bond is worth £1 and the minimum purchase is £100. The maximum purchase allowed is £20,000.

Nearly 700,000 prizes are distributed by Ernie - the Electronic Random Number Indicator Equipment - every month. Most of these are £50 and £100 payments, but there are also nearly 2,000 payments worth £1,000, 160 of £5,000, about 80 of £10,000, 16 of £50,000, eight of £100,000 and the jackpot of £1m. Prize payouts are free of tax, and the average yield is 4.25 per cent, equal to 7.07 per cent for a higher-rate taxpayer. Bond holders can elect to have small wins - anything up to £1,000 - reinvested in further bonds.

As with any prize draw, the odds of winning depend on how many bonds you own. If you have just one bond (as people who have held bonds for many years may), you have a one in 23,721 chance of winning £50. But if your stake is worth £5,000, the odds are reduced to one in 5.3. The odds for the top prize are much longer - one in 712,995 if you have the full £20,000 invested, and one in 14.26 billion if you have just one premium bond.

Premium bonds may seem a staid way of gambling - the sort of thing that grandparents buy at Christmas and birthdays when they are short of ideas. But for those who have won big prizes they are anything but dull. Robert, a retired telecoms engineer who won £100,000 a few months ago, says: 'At first I thought it was one of my ex-colleagues winding me up, then I checked the letter again and found details that no one could possibly know. At this point I was ecstatic.'

Backing that winner made me a loser

Most people think the occasional bet is quite harmless, and that including their children in family-oriented occasions such as the Grand National and the Lottery is all part of the fun. But it can have devastating consequences.

George made his first bet when he was 11, backing the 1969 Grand National winner Highland Wedding: 'I felt wonderful. My horse won while my parents' and sisters' horses hadn't even got around.'

The following two years his horses came second and third - and it all seemed harmless and innocent. But by the time George moved to London to go to college, he thought he could be a success at gambling, and his visits to the bookies became more regular.

Like many gamblers, he started lying to his family and friends about what he was up to: 'I would nip into the bookies for half an hour on the way home and tell my girlfriend that the trains were held up.'

But his problems escalated after he started work as a company accountant. He began to use the company's petty cash to pay for bets, some weeks paying back what he owed, other weeks leaving a deficit. But after one particularly bad day, he ended up owing £3,200 that he could not repay.

'I rang up the company on the Saturday to tell them that money was missing. On the Monday when I arrived for work, the police were waiting.'

George was lucky: his parents paid his court fine. Even then he had to have one last gambling session. 'I had to cash my giro, and it lasted for all of half an hour,' he says.

webTitle: My money: Witold Rybczynski

fields.headline: You don't have to know about screws
fields.standfirst: But it helps when you're building your own house, Witold Rybczynski tells Natalie Sutton
fields.trailText: But it helps when you're building your own house, Witold Rybczynski tells Natalie Sutton
fields.body:
Being an architect and a professor of urban history can come in very handy when you want to build your own house - as can knowing one end of a screwdriver from the other. Witold Rybczynski, professor at the University of Pennsylvania,whose latest book is called One Good Turn: A Natural History of the Screwdriver and the Screw, did just that in the Eighties when he found the price of property in Canada too high.

He has since sold the 'house that Witold built', but remembers it with fondness. 'There was never a time when I had no money, but for many years, roughly between the ages of 30 and 45, I had relatively little. That was when we built our house. The motivation was largely economic - it was the only way we could afford. So it took a long time - about seven years - to complete. Several years later I wrote a book about it called The Most Beautiful House in The World. By then, the book advance was considerably larger than the money we had spent on the house.

'The house was about an hour south of Montreal, just on the US border. It was quite small, about 16ft by 38ft, on two floors. It was started as a workshop in which to build a boat. The boat was never started; instead we converted what looked like a small barn into a house and called it The Boathouse. The 15 acres of land cost $10,000; building materials cost around $25,000. We didn't take out a mortgage or a loan; we bought materials as we went along. We sold the house in 1993, for about $60,000, so we broke even, although of course we lived in the house for a dozen years.

'My wife and I, with the help of friends, did all the construction work [except electrical wiring, and laying a ceramic tile floor]: foundations, wood frame, roofing, plastering, plumbing - the whole thing. That is why it took so long.'

Work on the house laid the foundations for various books, the latest of which identifies the screwdriver and screw as tools that changed the course of civilisation. One Good Turn goes back to Archimedes and Leonardo da Vinci, demonstrating that without the simple screw, there would be no telescope, no microscope and no enlightenment science.

Rybczynski and his wife of 26 years use credit cards, but don't carry debt from one month to the next. 'I save via a tax-deferred pension plan, with the university making co-deposits. I also save as a self-employed writer into a similar account. We live in a house we bought last year, with a mortgage we are slowly paying off.'

As a writer Rybczynski spends a lot of time at home, so his surroundings are important to him. 'We have one expensive car. Part of the reason for choosing the location of our house was to be able to use a train to go to work at the university, and not require two cars.'

'I've always wanted a sailing boat,' he says a little wistfully, 'but now I can afford it, I no longer live near water.'

 One Good Turn : A Natural History of the Screwdriver and the Screw is published tomorrow by Simon & Schuster

webTitle: Wealthcheck: travellers look to the future

fields.headline: Travellers look to the future
fields.standfirst: Voluntary service left gaps in one couple's plans, writes  Margaret Dibben
fields.trailText: Voluntary service left gaps in one couple's plans, writes Margaret Dibben
fields.body:
Helen and Nic I'Anson

Ages 32 and 40

Live in Ringmer

Occupation Accountant and teacher

Earn £31,000 and approx £11,000

Mortgage £65,000

Debts None

Investments £6,000 Tessa; £1,000 building societies; endowments

Pensions Teachers' pensions and AVCs

Aims To sort out pensions and life insurance; and save for children

Helen and Nic I'Anson live between Lewes and Uckfield, two towns badly hit by flooding recently, but they suffered no more than a damp garage. Before buying this house, they had been living in Bhutan, where they met while working for Voluntary Service Overseas (VSO), Helen for two years as an accountant and Nic a teacher for three.

Going to Bhutan had been a culture shock, says Helen, but so was returning home in 1997: 'Bhutan is very cut off from the outside world and has a slow pace of life which gives you a different perspective when you come back here. Going into the supermarket for the first time was quite frightening.'

Helen is working for the Institute of Development Studies while Nic is a part-time primary school supply teacher and looks after their daughters Pema, two, and Maya, four months, for two days a week.

They intend working abroad again: 'Over the rest of our employment, we are likely to spend a considerable period abroad, probably in Asia.' The next trip is likely to be within five years: 'I think the children will benefit from experiencing different cultures but when they become teenagers we would want to come back to the UK or have a base in a big city where there is schooling.' While abroad, they will rent out their house.

Their finances have not been so well planned: 'We both had gaps in employment and basic irresponsibility means we do not have many years of pension contributions built up.' Now they are putting that right.

Nic has been a member of the Teachers' Pension Scheme for 10 years and Helen has contributed to the University Superannuation Scheme for two. Both make Additional Voluntary Contributions but cannot continue these while abroad.

They want to know whether they should buy more life insurance. Nic has a Scottish Amicable endowment policy costing £54 a month which is no longer needed for the mortgage and is thought to be worth about £30,000. For the past five years, they have both paid £20 a month into a Pearl endowment saver plan. They now have a couple of hundred pounds to spare each month: 'We would like to start saving for cars and things.' Wherever they invest, they prefer an ethical investment: 'We are interested in environmental issues. Social responsibility is close to our hearts. '

Adviser 1: Carolyn Corless

Plans to work abroad mean Helen and Nic's finances must be flexible. To work out how much life insurance they need, they should draw up a budget taking into account where and how they would work if one of them died. Because insurance is required only while the children are financially dependent, they should consider term assurance. Many insurers provide cover for expats, but intentions to work abroad should be disclosed at the outset.

As they have no substantial retirement plans, they should obtain forecasts from the DSS (form BR19) to see the state pension they might get. Any shortfall should be made up.

Paying AVCs is a sensi ble way of boosting retirement benefits. Stakeholder pensions are open to members of occupational pensions earning less than £30,000. As they include tax-free cash at retirement, unlike AVCs, this may be an attractive alternative for Nic.

The endowment policies should be retained as part of their retirement planning. Any other savings should be pure investment and flexible, such as an investment trust scheme. Foreign & Colonial's Private Investor Plan, minimum monthly contribution £50, offers a range of trusts. They can continue contributing while abroad.

Carolyn Corless works for Bideford-based Sully's Financial Planning.

Adviser 2: Julie Lord

Helen and Nic both have occupational pensions which pay up to 2.5 times annual salary so, if Helen were to die, the mortgage would almost be repaid. In Nic's case, the mortgage would almost be repaid by including the endowment. But neither of them would have any other money for bringing up the children.

If either were to fall ill, their finances would be severely compromised, so they should buy income protection or critical illness cover and increase their life insurance.

Their pension contributions to date are low. It is sensible to maximise contributions but not at the expense of protection or short-term savings. They should prepare for extra expense in October 2002, when their capped mortgage finishes and they have to pay the variable rate for a further two years.

They should start saving for the medium to long term through Isas, perhaps an ethical unit trust Isa such as the Framlington Health fund.

When saving for children, it is imperative that there is enough on deposit to pay for any immediate child requirements, but any more money, even theChild Benefit, should be invested in equity-related areas for the long term.

Julie Lord is a certified financial planner with Cavendish Financial Management in Cardiff.

webTitle: Money writes: Help me solve six-year repo impasse

fields.headline: Help me solve six-year repo impasse
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.body:
I was shocked to receive a letter from UCB Home Loan chasing a mortgage debt from a property I vacated in 1991 which was subsequently repossessed and sold in December 1992. The Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML) has said that from February this year lenders would not pursue debts if contact had not been made within six years of the sale.

UCB said the six years dates from the last contact, and they had contacted me in 1995. I deny receiving a letter, but UCB says it does not have to abide by the CML agreement. I've asked for information but they just chase me for the money.
SK, South Ockendon

Lenders have agreed to start recovery action within six years of repossessed property being sold; before they could have waited 12. UCB admits its letter was wrong, but the company claims it complies with the six-year limit because it started trying to recover the money through a tracing agency in 1994.

It is adamant that the tracing agency hand-delivered letters to an address where it believed you would receive them. It posted two more letters to the same address in 1995 but then waited until earlier this year to try again, when the tracing agency found your current address.

It is obviously a shock to be asked to repay so much so long after you left the property but you have reached an impasse. You could negotiate with UCB, which may be willing to agree a reduced sum. Or you could take your case to the Ombudsman (0845 7660902), who can investigate whether UCB handled properly the mechanics of debt recovery.'

Travel policies: I was robbed

On my way home from Argentina I was robbed at Buenos Aires Airport.

I claimed £1,621 on my Airmiles policy, run by Axa, but the amount paid out was £861. Airmiles points to limits on each section of the policy such as 'up to £500' for money, but this is different from the advertising leaflet that tempted me to buy the insurance, which says I can claim '£500'.
MD, Preston

Obviously, if you lost £50 cash you would not expect an insurer to pay you £500, and the insurer argues that you cannot expect to have the whole picture in a 'summary of cover'. But this clearly says 'Personal Money £500' or 'up to £500'. The small print, under Personal Money and Documents, says the most Axa will pay is £500, although further down, it says the maximum for bank notes, currency notes and coins is £200. Even if they read the small print, not everyone would realise that this dilutes the £500.

After looking closely at the documents, Axa agrees the wording of the advertising brochure and policy could be confusing and the underwriters are making future policies clearer.

Civil service: Widows pique

You wrote recently that members of the Civil Service AVC scheme benefited from the transfer of Scottish Widows to TSB. I did not.
JMcN, Edinburgh

Your situation is different from people who are contributing to the Civil Service AVC; you had already retired in 22 June 1999, the cut-off date for payments. You now have a Scottish Widows annuity, but this is not a with-profits version, and so not entitled to a payout.

Pension plus: Tax relief's not all

Can I invest in a stakeholder pension to take advantage of the tax relief? I will be 65 in a few months and am already receiving a company pension but have no other source of income. Can I use the 'carry-back' provisions which will be abolished in April?
LD, Maidenhead

You can put up to £3,600 a year into a stakeholder pension because, now you are drawing your pension, you are not a member of an occupational scheme.

You will get tax relief on stakeholder contributions, which can continue until you are 75, but don't be tempted by tax relief alone. Once you draw a stakeholder pension you have to buy an annuity with the proceeds. Annuity rates are low and likely to stay that way for some years yet. If you bought an Isa, there is no tax relief on the way in but you pay no tax on withdrawals and the money is not locked away.

You cannot use the 'carry back' or 'carry forward' facilities.

'They disappear as stakeholder pensions arrive, so you would have to buy a personal pension this tax year. You cannot do this because you have no earned income.

 Write to Margaret Dibben, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER and include a telephone number. Do not enclose SAEs or original documents. Letters are selected for publication and we cannot give personal replies. The newspaper accepts no legal responsibility for advice.

webTitle: Cashpoints

fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.body:
It's official: past is no guide to future

Investment companies' use of statistics on past investment profits in their advertising is to be scrutinised by a new task force.

Set up under the auspices of the Financial Services Authority, the task force will examine the 'wide body of evidence' that past performance in itself is not a useful guide to the future. An initial examination of the subject led to the decision not to include past performance in the FSA's product comparison tables, which will be launched next year.

Going critical

Most people understand the benefits of buying critical illness insurance, a policy that pays out if you develop one of a specified list of serious or life-threatening illnesses. But few people can afford it. The cheapest way to buy it is as an 'add-on' to a life policy, but it can still be costly. And most policies refuse to pay out a death benefit if you have claimed on developing a critical illness.

Online independent financial adviser Direct Lifeand Pensions allows you to buy critical illness cover equivalent in value to 10 per cent, 25 per cent, 50 per cent or 100 per cent of the life cover you have selected, thereby allowing you to match the monthly premium to what you can afford. The policy is also designed to pay out on both critical illness and death. Information from: www.payingtoomuch.com.

Double whammy

People who have taken early retirement but found other work may be hit with an unexpected £1,000 tax bill at the end of the financial year, the Association of Chartered Certified Accountants is warning.

Acca accountants have uncovered a number of cases where the Revenue has given separate allowances for pension and employment incomes, rather than combining them as they should. So people pay no tax until they reach double the normal allowance of £4,385.

The extra allowances are discovered only at the end of the tax year, when the unsuspecting person may face a hefty demand for back taxes.

Acca is urging those who think they may be affected to look closely at their PAYE codings to ensure they are paying the correct tax. If they are not, they should contact their tax office.

Gymslip tycoons

Schoolchildren can learn about the stock market with the ProShare National Investment programme. The programme, now in its ninth year, gets secondary school children to invest a notional £100,000 and make it grow as much as possible by January. The top team wins a £2,000 prize. Entry is open to all UK schools and colleges free of charge. Tel: 020 7220 1764.

Free money

Natwest is to abolish cash machine charges from 15 December. Cardholders will be able to use all of the UK's 30,000 cash machines without incurring a £1 charge from NatWest.

webTitle: BT set to sell £8bn French phone stake

fields.headline: BT set to sell £8bn French phone stake
fields.trailText: BT is looking to sell its stake in Cegetel, the French telecoms company, in a move that could net it up to £8 billion. BT has until now stayed quiet about suggestions that it would sell its 26 per cent holding in the company, which is 44 per cent owned by French media group Vivendi.
fields.body:
BT is looking to sell its stake in Cegetel, the French telecoms company, in a move that could net it up to £8 billion. BT has until now stayed quiet about suggestions that it would sell its 26 per cent holding in the company, which is 44 per cent owned by French media group Vivendi.

However, in an interview with The Observer, BT's chief executive, Sir Peter Bonfield, hinted that a sale was now under active consideration. 'We are its second-largest shareholder, it's unlikely we'll get control, it's produced good value, but we will now have to see what happens.'

A complicated shareholder structure means BT cannot sell the Cegetel stake until 2002. However, on Friday a court ruled that Vivendi could raise its stake by buying a 7.5 per cent share from mobile phone giant Vodafone and placing it in a holding company. Vivendi would then take direct control in 2002. The move paves the way for a similar sale by BT, which is keen to cut debt levels that have alarmed the City in recent months.

On Friday Vivendi chairman Jean-Marie Messier challenged BT to decide whether it wanted to be a long-term partner in Cegetel. 'If it's not the case, it is better to say so quickly. Vivendi is not forgetting that it is master of Cegetel's destiny with a right of first refusal [to buy BT's 26 per cent Cegetel stake],' Messier said.

Last week, BT unveiled its long-awaited strategic review. Despite unveiling plans to float two of its businesses - Yell, its directories unit and BT Wireless - and announcing plans to sell off minority stakes in some of its Asian interests, the company's shares slumped.

The City still has reservations about whether BT can implement its restructuring programme efficiently. This will be a worry for the company, which is planning an £8bn bond issue 'within the next two to three months', according to Bonfield.

However he said that the company would be prepared to pull the issue if market sentiment falters. 'We'll have to see what the marketplace looks like. We don't have to do it, but we expect the market conditions over the next two or three months to improve.'

Bonfield said that the restructuring programme now means that mergers are firmly off BT's agenda. Earlier this year it held talks with AT&T with a view to merging the two companies' business divisions.

'We have talked to AT&T about whether we should expand our business services but we're now concentrating on whether we can strengthen our link with them through Concert [the two companies' international venture],' Bonfield said.

webTitle: Barclays eyes £15bn bid for Abbey

fields.headline: Barclays eyes £15bn bid for Abbey
fields.trailText: Goldman Sachs, the world's biggest investment bank, is crunching the numbers this weekend for a possible £15 billion bid from Barclays for Abbey National.
fields.body:
Goldman Sachs, the world's biggest investment bank, is crunching the numbers this weekend for a possible £15 billion bid from Barclays for Abbey National.

Barclays is now the City's favourite to intervene ahead of rival Lloyds TSB after Abbey put itself in play with a spurned bid for Bank of Scotland 10 days ago.

This weekend, under pressure from big City institutions, City advisers to Abbey and BoS are trying to resurrect their £24bn merger.

Shareholders, however, prefer BoS chief executive Peter Burt to lead the bank. They expect to turn the screw increasingly on Abbey chairman Lord Tugendhat to rein in the former building society's chief executive Ian Harley, whose ambitions have so far scuppered a friendly deal.

'If there is to be a deal, it should be a nil premium merger, with BoS management running the show,' one of the biggest City institutions said this weekend. 'Nor should there be huge fees for hostile takeover activity which tends to destroy shareholder value.'

Barclays chief executive Matt Barrett tried to clinch a deal with Abbey before taking over the Woolwich for £5.6bn two weeks ago. Barclays has also previously been in talks with Burt and BoS.

Bankers at Goldman Sachs are now running the slide rule for Barclays over both banks and the rest of the consolidating banking sector.

The rise in Abbey's shares has now put the spotlight on the low valuation of the Halifax, its closest rival. At £13.5bn, Halifax is now worth some £1.5bn less than Abbey, even though it has similar profits and a bigger share of the mortgage market.

'Abbey and BoS may not be the only endgame in sight for consolidation. The bankers are calculating every possible combination,' one corporate financier said this weekend.

Last week, as predicted in The Observer a fortnight ago, Barclays replaced its finance director David Allvey in yet another boardroom shake-up. It declined, however, to comment on its bid ambitions. 'We have a long-standing relationship with CSFB (BoS's adviser) and Goldman Sachs. Nothing has changed,' a Barclays spokesperson said.

Abbey and BoS were also tight-lipped. Sources at Lloyds TSB, which is being advised by JP Morgan, said the bank was monitoring developments closely.

webTitle: Allied Domecq swallows Stolichnaya in spirits war

fields.headline: Allied Domecq swallows Stolichnaya in spirits war
fields.trailText: Drinks giant Allied Domecq is set to add Stolichnaya vodka to its cabinet this week, stealing a march on rival Diageo.
fields.body:
Drinks giant Allied Domecq is set to add Stolichnaya vodka to its cabinet this week, stealing a march on rival Diageo.

The deal, which clinches valuable US distribution rights currently held by Diageo, is the second major brand to fall to Allied in a matter of weeks.

Late last month it out-manoeuvered Diageo and other rivals in the bidding for Seagram's spirits division by striking a $1.5 billion deal with Destilería Serrallés, the Puerto Rican owner of the Captain Morgan rum label.

Stolichnaya is the world's biggest-selling spirits brand, ahead of Bacardi. All but 1.8 million cases, however, are sold in Russia by the brand's producer, the Kristall distillery in Moscow. This summer the vodka plant was occupied by two rival armed gangs in a stand-off between competing directors that only ended last month.

According to industry sources, Diageo lost the Stolichnaya rights because of Russian concern that it was promoting its own best-selling Smirnoff vodka brand more favourably in the US.

Concerns over who owns the brand also meant Diageo was reluctant to rebid for the rights. Ownership of all Russian vodka brands was vested in an old Soviet board, Soyuzplodoimport, which was pri vatised but went bust in 1997. The brands were then controversially taken over by a similarly named successor company, Soyuzplodimport, at a knockdown price. Since then, according to industry sources, amid the chaos in Russia certain brands have been transferred to offshore companies. Ownership is not only difficult to track, investigators say, but may lead to future legal disputes.

Seagram, meanwhile, is considering legal action to enforce its distribution rights to Captain Morgan. Allied has also been holding talks with Sweden's Absolut, which has threatened to retake control of its vodka rights from Seagram when the Canadian drinks company is sold.

So far Absolut has tied up with Bacardi and Jack Daniels' owner Brown Froman, while Pernod Ricard is partnering Diageo. Allied's move on Captain Morgan, however, has now thrown the auction into chaos.

webTitle: M&S first as bosses hit the floor

fields.headline: M&S first as bosses hit the floor
fields.trailText: The chairman of Marks & Spencer, Luc Vandevelde, is to find out for himself what customers think of his products by taking a turn on the shop floor this Christmas.
fields.body:
The chairman of Marks & Spencer, Luc Vandevelde, is to find out for himself what customers think of his products by taking a turn on the shop floor this Christmas.

The M&S boss is expected to spend much of December packing shoppers' bags or stacking shelves. Fellow di-rectors with experience of working in stores will take on more skilled jobs like manning the tills.

Vandevelde will join 2,000 of M&S's 3,500 head-office staff working in the stores over the festive season. The aim is not just to help out over the busiest trading period but, says marketing director Alan Mc-Walter, is also about 'empowering' people. 'The staff in the stores will tell us what they want us to do.' All store staff are also being promised a £75 bonus if their store achieves like-for-like sales growth over Christmas.

M&S will need all the help it can get. Last week, it stunned the City with news that clothing sales in the five weeks to 4 November were down more than 17 per cent, excluding store openings, compared with last year. Then, the group had been running promotions like discounted suits and giving gift vouchers on large purchases, which inflated sales. But Vandevelde admitted the clothing result was 'unacceptable'.

Senior executives of other retailers, like Tesco, already help out in the stores over Christmas but it's a first for M&S. The new culture has even extended to one of the most potent symbols of privilege: carpets. Floor coverings at M&S's Baker Street head office have traditionally been graded according to seniority, with the plushest pile reserved for the executives.

Last week, however, the executive carpet was torn up, to be replaced with standard issue. But the decorators discovered the carpet was hiding some rather nice parquet flooring and may refurbish that instead.

webTitle: Postal unions are threatening strike action

fields.headline: Back-pedal or we walk, say postal unions
fields.trailText: Postal unions are threatening strike action over joint venture plans which they say will cause the break-up of the Post Office's 5,000-strong IT and engineering division, lead to massive job losses and open the door to piecemeal sales of non-core PO activities.
fields.body:
Postal unions are threatening strike action over joint venture plans which they say will cause the break-up of the Post Office's 5,000-strong IT and engineering division, lead to massive job losses and open the door to piecemeal sales of non-core PO activities.

The unpublished plans for the Romec division are outlined in an internal briefing, dated 24 October. The Post Office executive board believes a joint venture would bring benefits including greater freedom to grow and reduced dependency on the Post Office as a customer. PricewaterhouseCoopers is advising it.

John Keggie, deputy general secretary of the Communication Workers Union, says he will oppose the 'car boot sale' of Romec and warns of strikes if the plans are not halted or radically revised.

Post Office sources confirmed that Romec was not seen as a core operation and that joint ventures were seen as the way forward. There were likely to be redundancies.

webTitle: Rocky road to new Wembley

fields.headline: Rocky road to new Wembley
fields.standfirst: Denis Campbell and  Nick Mathiason on fears that the national stadium will be the next Dome and, below, how Arsenal hopes to win with Highbury II
fields.trailText: Denis Campbell and Nick Mathiason on fears that the national stadium will be the next Dome and, below, how Arsenal hopes to win with Highbury II.
fields.body:
Football's top brass say England's national football stadium will be the 'world's greatest venue for the world's most popular sport'.

With its futuristic design, and horizon-grabbing illuminated arch, the new Wembley will certainly look spectacular. At £660 million, it will also be the most expensive sports complex the world has ever seen. But fears are growing that this controversial project could turn into a financial disaster.

Parallels with the Millennium Dome are strong. At Greenwich, over-optimistic visitor projections undermined the finances. At Wembley, assumptions about match-day attendances and revenue from corporate hospitality are key to paying back a £410m bank loan.

A growing army of financiers and Football Association personnel now believe that Wembley National Stadium Limited, the wholly owned subsidiary of the FA, will be not be able to make ends meet, leaving the stadium reliant on regular cash injections to keep it afloat.

'It may be English football's new home, but it's also football's biggest headache,' said a senior football figure who helped develop the plans. 'People just don't understand why it's costing so much. The price sticks in the throat. Where are they going to get all this money from? And how are they going to make it pay?'

So far, omens for the new national stadium have not been good. Costs have rocketed from an initial £240m, demolition of the old stadium has been delayed by several months and the project is already running a year behind schedule. In addition, there is an ongoing row about whether Wembley could host the Olympic Games if they ever returned to Britain.

But it is the combination of rising costs and question marks over meeting loan repayments that is causing most concern. One Wembley insider admitted that some of the figures given by Wembley National Stadium Limited seemed worryingly optimistic. 'I'm amazed WNSL is forecasting profits of up to £70m a year,' he said.

One figure nobody disputes is the £30m a year clear profit WNSL will need simply to repay interest on the £410m it is now trying to borrow in the City.

'I see £30m as achievable if everything goes well,' said the Wembley insider. 'But I would have thought £15m, Wembley's current profit, is a more likely guide to how much they will make.'

WNSL insists its business plan is 'astonishingly conservative' and says it will 'comfortably' hit its targets. But even financiers doubt whether WNSL's figures add up.

'I can't see the venue performing well beyond match days as a corporate hospitality venue,' said a source at one of the banks that Chase Manhattan - Wembley's lead banker - has approached to provide part of the £410m.

He believes that despite the historic appeal of Wembley, its location in an unglamorous, north London suburb with poor transport links may prove to be its Achilles' heel: 'If I was asked to go to a dinner at the new stadium, I wouldn't want to schlep all the way over there. They are being too optimistic about that facet of the business plan.'

One reason why Wembley is causing such jitters is the fact that the new stadium is planned to be far more than just a 90,000-seat sports and concert venue. It will also incorporate a 200-bed four-star hotel, an office block, three restaurants, three banqueting/conference halls and a museum.

WNSL spokesman Chris Palmer said: 'Yes, income from these additional facilities is integral to our business plan.'

Income from non-event days is expected to generate 10 per cent, or up to £7m, of the new Wembley's annual profit. But while London needs more good conference facilities, Wembley's location is far from ideal. In addition, the number of offices already lying empty around Wembley raises questions about whether WNSL's offices will suffer a similar fate.

WNSL admits the complex's viability relies on it selling 11,800 top-price seats to corporate clients. This seat category currently provides 10-15 per cent of Wembley's income. It has historically split corporate hospitality revenues with event managers.

But WNSL admits that it is expecting to make 50 per cent of its income from this source. Any miscalculations or underperformance in this area will jeopardise Wemb ley's viability. But Palmer says that the 50 per cent target should be easy to hit.

'Wembley now has only 1,500 corporate seats, whereas we will have 4,000 hospitality seats, 6,000 premium "club" seats and 1,800 seats in boxes. Crucially, we will keep all the income from these seats.' That is expected to work out at an average £120 per seat per event.

But this heavy reliance on football fatcats could prove unwise. Are there enough of them to justify 11,800 top-price seats? And while the FA Cup Final and England games will probably be over-subscribed, how many will fancy the Auto Windscreens Shield Final? An economic downturn, or football's bubble finally bursting, could leave many of these seats looking too expensive.

The only place in Britain where anything like the new multi-purpose Wembley has been tried before is the Chelsea Village complex off London's Fulham Road. It is run by Chelsea's pugnacious chairman Ken Bates. Bates is also the driving force behind the new Wembley. But Bates' Chelsea Village model does not inspire confidence. Only three of its 17 boxes on offer to blue chip firms at £1m a season have so far been sold.

Other projected revenue streams for WNSL are already petering out. The FA was meant to pay rent to Wembley by moving its HQ to the stadium's offices; it opted for Soho instead. And the hotel, which WNSL has always said was crucial to its overall profitability, may never happen. Hilton Hotels, which has exclusive rights to develop it, looks likely to take the cheaper option of redeveloping its existing Wembley Plaza instead.

Government officials now claim the Wembley development has become 'bloated, grandiose and alarmingly costly'. Leeds United recently abandoned plans to build a £65m indoor leisure arena, hosting sports events and concerts, next to its Elland Road ground.

If WNSL's predictions do prove misplaced, and it becomes insolvent, WNSL's bankers could end up owning the UK's national stadium - a humiliating prospect. Or the FA may have to bail Wembley out. It has already agreed to provide £100m in 'contingent support' if needed.

Alternatively, the Government may feel obliged to shore up what would be another Dome-sized national embarrassment, probably using Lottery money - as it has in Greenwich.

Wembley, London

Cost £660m and rising

Funding £120m Lottery cash to buy the site; £410m loan from the City; £100m fallback funding from the Football Association; £30m share of FA television deal

Capacity 90,000

Features Hotel, offices, museum, three restaurants and three banqueting/conference halls

Events FA Cup Final, England games, concerts

Stade de France, Paris

Cost £260m

Funding 40 per cent from French government and the rest from private consortium which has control until 2025

Capacity 80,000

Features Restaurants, shops, conference facilities

Events 1998 World Cup; bidding for 2008 Olympic Games

Stadium Australia, Sydney

C ost £260m but land provided free by the government

Funding Private consortium, which has 30 years to make a profit

Capacity 110,000

Features Two banqueting halls but no hotel

Events 2000 Olympics

Millennium Stadium, Cardiff

Cost £120m

Funding £47m from the Lottery and £73m from the Welsh Rugby Union

Capacity 72,500

Features 'No hotel or offices, nothing like Wembley,' says spokesman

Events 1999 Rugby World Cup, Wales soccer matches

Ground-breaking deal scores for Gunners

The cost of Arsenal's 60,000- seater stadium turns out - like Wembley - to be much greater than expected.

When plans were unveiled last week, it was reported that the stadium would cost £100 million. In fact, the final figure will be £250m, making it the most expensive club ground in the country. The price consists of £125m for stadium construction and £125m for acquisition of the land and moving existing tenants. The cost includes building a new municipal dump.

But Arsenal's new home at Ashburton Grove, 500 yards from its Highbury ground, is still far cheaper than Wembley on a cost per seat basis. Arsenal's stadium will work out at £4,100 per seat against £7,300 for Wembley. The difference is that Arsenal's stadium will not include a hotel and conference facilities.

Wembley also has to have a massive improvement in its public transport links, where-as there are three Tube stations close to Arsenal's new ground, which between them can cope with 80,000 passengers an hour. Wembley's two stations afford nothing near.

Arsenal are fortunate that a large part of the land at Ashburton Grove is owned by Islington Council, which is desperate to keep the club in its borough. Arsenal will finance the move with a £47m windfall from Granada (now a 5 per cent shareholder in the club) plus receipts from the sale of Highbury to housebuilders.

It was Anthony Spencer, a 40-year-old Arsenal-supporting surveyor, who persuaded the Arsenal board, dominated by Hatton Garden diamond dealer Danny Fiszman and Football Association luminary David Dein, that Ashburton Grove was the best option for Arsenal.

Scouring a map of north London and cutting out to scale the size of a 60,000-stadium on a piece of paper, Spencer worked out that a site little more than a goalkeeper's kick from Highbury could accommodate his club. Previous options included Wembley Stadium itself, land behind King's Cross station, Finsbury Park and greenfield sites out of London, which Spencer believed weren't suitable.

When he did a title search at Ashburton, Spencer found that 80 per cent of it was owned by the council, Railtrack and Sainsbury's. Once he had persuaded the board that Ashburton Grove should be investigated, Spencer approached the few other landowners on the site pretending he was planning a leisure development.

The reaction, he said, was ecstatic. 'One bloke said: "It's not every day someone asks you to sell them their property when you're sitting next to a rubbish dump. Come in, let's get the kettle on".'

The only place in Britain where anything like the new multi-purpose Wembley has been tried before is the Chelsea Village complex off London's Fulham Road. It is run by Chelsea's pugnacious chairman Ken Bates. Bates is also the driving force behind the new Wembley. But Bates' Chelsea Village model does not inspire confidence. Only three of its 17 boxes on offer to blue chip firms at £1m a season have so far been sold. Other projected revenue streams for WNSL are already petering out. The FA was meant to pay rent to Wembley by moving its HQ to the stadium's offices; it opted for Soho instead. And the hotel, which WNSL has always said was crucial to its overall profitability, may never happen. Hilton Hotels, which has exclusive rights to develop it, looks likely to take the cheaper option of redeveloping its existing Wembley Plaza instead. Government officials now claim the Wembley development has become 'bloated, grandiose and alarmingly costly'. Leeds United recently abandoned plans to build a £65m indoor leisure arena, hosting sports events and concerts, next to its Elland Road ground. If WNSL's predictions do prove misplaced, and it becomes insolvent, WNSL's bankers could end up owning the UK's national stadium - a humiliating prospect. Or the FA may have to bail Wembley out. It has already agreed to provide £100m in 'contingent support' if needed. Alternatively, the Government may feel obliged to shore up what would be another Dome-sized national embarrassment, probably using Lottery money - as it has in Greenwich. When plans were unveiled last week, it was reported that the stadium would cost £100 million. In fact, the final figure will be £250m, making it the most expensive club ground in the country. The price consists of £125m for stadium construction and £125m for acquisition of the land and moving existing tenants. The cost includes building a new municipal dump. But Arsenal's new home at Ashburton Grove, 500 yards from its Highbury ground, is still far cheaper than Wembley on a cost per seat basis. Arsenal's stadium will work out at £4,100 per seat against £7,300 for Wembley. The difference is that Arsenal's stadium will not include a hotel and conference facilities. Wembley also has to have a massive improvement in its public transport links, where-as there are three Tube stations close to Arsenal's new ground, which between them can cope with 80,000 passengers an hour. Wembley's two stations afford nothing near. Arsenal are fortunate that a large part of the land at Ashburton Grove is owned by Islington Council, which is desperate to keep the club in its borough. Arsenal will finance the move with a £47m windfall from Granada (now a 5 per cent shareholder in the club) plus receipts from the sale of Highbury to housebuilders. It was Anthony Spencer, a 40-year-old Arsenal-supporting surveyor, who persuaded the Arsenal board, dominated by Hatton Garden diamond dealer Danny Fiszman and Football Association luminary David Dein, that Ashburton Grove was the best option for Arsenal. Scouring a map of north London and cutting out to scale the size of a 60,000-stadium on a piece of paper, Spencer worked out that a site little more than a goalkeeper's kick from Highbury could accommodate his club. Previous options included Wembley Stadium itself, land behind King's Cross station, Finsbury Park and greenfield sites out of London, which Spencer believed weren't suitable. When he did a title search at Ashburton, Spencer found that 80 per cent of it was owned by the council, Railtrack and Sainsbury's. Once he had persuaded the board that Ashburton Grove should be investigated, Spencer approached the few other landowners on the site pretending he was planning a leisure development. The reaction, he said, was ecstatic. 'One bloke said: "It's not every day someone asks you to sell them their property when you're sitting next to a rubbish dump. Come in, let's get the kettle on".'

webTitle: The Motown missionary

fields.headline: The Motown missionary
fields.standfirst: His great-grandfather invented the Model T; now Bill Ford says any colour you like so long as it's green.  Terry Slavin reports
fields.trailText: His great-grandfather invented the Model T; now Bill Ford says any colour you like so long as it's green.
fields.body:
There's a saying in the US: 'What's good for Detroit is good for America.'

But William Clay Ford Jr turns that kind of logic on its head. For him, what's good for America, and indeed the planet, is good for Detroit.

Ford is an unlikely person to have his feet under the top table of the second-biggest car manufacturer in the world - even if his great-grandfather was Henry, the man who started it all with the Model T.

Despite the sharp grey suits, gleaming manicure and soft boyish looks that shout thrusting corporate high-flyer, Ford Motor Company's iconoclastic 43-year-old chairman has more in common with Greenpeace activists than Wall Street analysts. His great-grandfather was a major cog in the industrial revolution, he says; what's needed this century is a 'clean' revolution.

'I believe very strongly that corporations could and should be a major force for resolving social and environmental concerns in the twentyfirst century,' he told a Greenpeace conference last month. 'As chairman of one of the world's largest corporations I am in a unique position to be a catalyst for change.'

Not your usual mission statement from a car company boss, but Bill Ford is not your usual car company boss. 'There are people who think I'm a Bolshevik, and this is all a major distraction at best and heresy at worst,' he has said. 'But I really don't care. I'm in this for my children [he has four] and my grandchildren. I want them to inherit a legacy they're proud of. I don't want anybody, whether it's my grandchildren or any of our employees' grandchildren, to have to apologise for working for Ford Motor Company. In fact, I want the opposite. I want them to look and say, "What a difference we made!".'

Fortune magazine said Ford was blazing new ground at the steering wheel of an old-economy company: 'Here comes an entirely new old-economy boss. A nice guy with a politician's keen instinct.'

And a nice guy he plainly is. When news reached the company of a catastrophic explosion at the Rouge factory in Dearborn, Michigan in February 1999, Ford immediately went to the scene, despite strenuous advice not to do so by lieutenants, who warned he could be eaten alive by the media.

Without an entourage he visited the injured and dying in hospital until late into the night (six people died), and was on television describing it as the 'worst day of my life'.

Three months later Ford ordered an environmental makeover of the plant, which his great-grandfather built, vowing to turn it into the world's first closed-loop car production facility - producing cars whose component parts are so many 'technical nutrients' that will be recy cled one day in new cars.

A self-described 'life-long environmentalist' who began fraternising with environmental groups during his student days at Princeton and MIT, Ford has painted the executive suite an electrifying shade of green since he became chairman two years ago.

Ford Motor Company has since become the first and only car maker to certify all 140 plants around the world under ISO 14001, the international management standard that audits environmental performance.

Bill Ford also courted controversy on Wall Street by pulling his company out of the Global Climate Coalition and lobbying for higher petrol taxes. Last summer he initiated discussions between environmental groups and senior Ford managers. At the Greenpeace conference he went further and took up the environmental groups' challenge to follow BP's John Browne in accepting climate change as reality - heresy in corporate America.

'Anyone who disagrees is, in my view, still in denial. We at Ford Motor Company have moved on,' he says.

The remarks are bound to have caused ructions in Detroit. But being a renegade is nothing new for Ford. When he joined the family firm 20 years ago he was asked to stop associating with green groups and told it would damage his career. 'I wonder what they'd think of me now,' he says with a smirk. 'I'd ask them, but they are no longer with the company.'

But the climb up the corporate ladder was not an easy one - even for a Ford. He has worked his way up through 17 positions in the 20 years since joining the company straight from university. At first he called himself Bill Clay. Before he became chairman in 1998 he had to battle hardline opposition from some on the board - including the former CEO - to his environmental agenda. His relationship with new chief executive Jacques Nasser, is said by some insiders to be rocky.

But Ford has doggedly pursued his ideals, maintaining that what is good for the planet is good for Ford. He points to ISO 14001. 'It's saving us millions of dollars a year in energy, water, materials and waste-handling costs.'

The company is also repositioning itself as a purveyor of mobility. 'The day will come when the notion of car ownership becomes antiquated. If you live in a city, you don't need to own a car.' He sees a future where Ford owns vehicles and makes them available to motorists as and when they need access to transport.

In the shorter term Ford is spending $1billion to put a family car on the road by 2004 that runs on hydrogen, emitting only water from its exhaust. Ford says the P2000 will be the Model T of the twentyfirst century, setting the standard for others to follow. Ford also promises to have a hybrid-electric sports utility vehicle, powered by a conventional engine as well as electric motor, on the market by 2003.

But it's with the sports utility vehicles, those tank-like four-wheel drives beloved of America's baseball moms, where Ford's 'cleaner, safer, sooner' rhetoric runs smack into uncomfortable reality.

The problem for Bill Ford is that sports utes are hugely profitable - the company earns about $8,000 profit for each Explorer sold in the US. Which may go some way to explaining how an even petrol-thirstier behemoth like the Excursion, which does 10 miles to the gallon, must be accommodated in Bill Ford's clean, green future.

Ford tries to reconcile this by making the 'greenest' sports utes in the industry. More than 80 per cent of the Explorer is recyclable and all Ford sports utes sold in the US and Canada are certified as low-emission vehicles.

'As long as gas is cheaper than bottled water, we can't be in a position of dictating to the consumer what to buy,' says Bill Ford.

Geoff Lye, director of SustainAbility, the UK environmental consultancy that has been working with Ford, says: 'I don't think any other major automotive manufacturer has that passion and commitment to the environment at the top.'
