webTitle: Comment: Jamie Doward: BT's revival plan is not just pie in the sky

fields.headline: BT's revival plan is not just pie in the sky
fields.standfirst: Comment: Jamie Doward
fields.trailText: Sir Peter Bonfield's favourite song is American Pie by Don MacLean. We know this be-cause the chief executive of BT appeared on Desert Island Discs earlier this year and told Sue Lawley that if he ever found himself as a castaway the track would be his toppermost of the poppermost.
fields.body:
Sir Peter Bonfield's favourite song is American Pie by Don MacLean. We know this be-cause the chief executive of BT appeared on Desert Island Discs earlier this year and told Sue Lawley that if he ever found himself as a castaway the track would be his toppermost of the poppermost.

Currently, Bonfield could be forgiven for wishing he was listening to the eight-minute track on his own desert island, far away from baying analysts and fund managers.

The market's reaction to BT's long-awaited strategic review suggested that the City no longer trusts the company to deliver on its promises. There was general agreement that BT's restructuring programme was the right option, but the City still marked the company's shares down 5 per cent on the day of the announcement, such was its scepticism about the plan ever being realised. The shares continued to slide on Friday, and are now valued at less than half their value just under a year ago.

Yet BT had gone a long way to giving the City what it wanted. There will be listings for the Wireless and Yellow Pages divisions; Ignite, the internet and business services arm, could also get a quo-tation in the not-so-distant future. The conventional in-frastructure of the BT phone network is to be rehoused in a new company, NetCo, which will also be floated, while some of the company's minority stakes are to be hived off. The moves are designed to knock around £10 billion off its debt mountain.

But rival incumbent telcos such as Deutsche Telekom and Telefónica of Spain had embarked on this sort of radicalism several years ago - and besides, much of the restructuring had been flagged back in April. Since then, BT has suffered a series of body blows: there were persistent suggestions that senior directors were split over the company's direction; an on-off merger of BT and AT&T's business services divisions was on and then most definitely off; and as BT was taking a beating from competitors for having Oftel in its pocket, it took a pasting from the watchdog for stifling competition.

Bonfield points out that all telecom stocks have suffered over the year. True, but BT shares have underperformed the telecoms sector by nearly 30 per cent in the past 12 months. It is now one of the cheapest telecom operators around, and the sorry conclusion is that Bonfield and chairman Sir Iain Vallance are largely responsible for this state of affairs.

There are mutterings that both men, who between them have clocked up nearly 20 years at BT, should seek alternative employment. After all, at the start of this year the company was in merger talks with Telefónica. Now it wants to make like Garbo and be alone - Bonfield says mergers are firmly off the agenda.

Such ambivalence is difficult to square, but neither man should go. The company has set out its direction, and this would be jeopardised if the management changed in the middle of the journey. The presence of new finance director Philip Hampton, who was given a rapturous reception by the City, has yet to be truly felt.

In addition, Bonfield still has a number of white rabbits up his sleeve, notably sales of stakes in French telecoms company Cégétel, and Blu, the Italian mobile phone consortium. Both of these will help further reduce debt and boost market sentiment. Supertankers can be turned around, but it does take time. The problem for Bonfield is that the City is not known for its patience.

webTitle: Bewdley's wet warning to Britain

fields.headline: Bewdley's wet warning to Britain
fields.standfirst: Oliver Morgan  on the arguments over where the billions needed to renew our sewerage system will come from
fields.trailText: Oliver Morgan on the arguments over where the billions needed to renew our sewerage system will come from.
fields.body:
It was certainly not 'belle' weather. But was it a bellwether? When Tony Blair visited the Worcestershire town of Bewdley to console its drenched residents, he was setting foot in a place that has not only become renowned for the regular soakings it receives from the River Severn, but one that is likely to become a miserable yardstick for the effects of climate change in Britain.

Severn Trent, the water giant responsible for the Midlands and South West region that has taken such a beating, is working with the Meteorological Office to try to predict the effect of future rainfall patterns on floods.

Bewdley is central to what it has found - the Severn could break its banks there an average 6.4 times by 2020, compared with 5.5 now.

The research indicates that the severe storms currently occuring every five years will soon be hitting us every two. It has also found that the 15-minute cloudbursts that can overcome drainage systems will intensify - from an average 12mm to 19mm of rain now to an average 15mm to 24mm in five years' time.

This chimes with Environment Agency research that says storms bad enough to happen once a century will happen once a decade instead.

But what is a water company doing researching flooding, a problem the industry has spent the best part of a month saying is not its fault? After all, the problems of the past few weeks - largely caused by rivers invading houses built close to their banks or on flood plains - cannot be blamed on water companies.

Nevertheless, companies admit that when sewerage systems become filled to capacity in a flood, a number of difficulties exacerbate the situation. Brian Duckworth, managing director of Severn Trent, says: 'We are seeing massive changes in weather events. We are relying on nineteenth-century systems to deal with new millennium weather conditions. The pipelines are simply not wide enough to deal with these amounts of water.'

John Reynolds of the department of civil engineering at Portsmouth University, who has studied the UK sewer system, says there are two distinct problems caused by different types of system. Newer systems, which operate on about 20 per cent of the network, have separate pipes for surface and foul water. Surface water sewers drain into nearby rivers. But when a river rises it covers the overflow outlets, and the river can flow back up the pipes and into the streets. This means that the area hit by flooding is extended along the sewerage network.

Older systems combine surface and foul water sewers. These also have emergency overflows into rivers, which can become backed up, pushing sewage back into homes.

Some companies have already acted. Anglian Water, for example, had to deal with catastrophic floods in Northampton in 1998. It installed flaps on river overflows to prevent water flooding back into the town - at minimal cost.

But such simple solutions are of a different order to the massive renewal and infrastructure work some in the industry are saying will be needed if global warming continues to wreak havoc.

Industry experts say there is a need for radical engineering answers. Reynolds says massive tanks could contain sewer overflows. Once floods pass and river levels drop, these tanks could be released into the rivers.

Anglian recently spent £20m on a 5-metre wide emergency sewer under Ipswich. Southern Water has a 3km tunnel between Brighton and Hove. Southern, which experiences a lot of flooding, says new infrastructure does work. For example, in Folkestone, a £120m new pumping station introduced as part of its beach scheme has protected parts of the town from the recent floods.

But for such schemes to play an effective part in helping water companies cope with floods, they will have to be far more common. The problem is they are expensive. Which is why the water companies are trying to make their case publicly.

They are no strangers to bad publicity - taking the brunt of the fat cat headlines in the Nineties - and are in no mood to be blamed for environmental disasters.

This may be what lies behind their enlistment of the riverside dwellers of Bewdley - whose plight, ironically, is probably beyond rescue by improved sewerage - to make their point.

The companies will need to recoup investment for better sewers from somewhere - which, they claim, means from customers' bills. That will require the permission of regulator Ofwat, whose attention has been concentrated on ensuring household bills go down, not up. Without such a concession, there is little evidence that the companies will pay for work themselves.

Reynolds's work at Portsmouth University shows that the industry spent an average of £169m a year on maintaining the 301,400 km of sewers in England and Wales from 1991 to 1999 - about an eighth of what is required.

Work progressed at 213 km a year - at which rate it will take 1,400 years to replace the network. Interestingly, Reynolds also finds that the state of the network has deteriorated since privatisation while water bills have risen.

Barrie Clarke of Water UK, the body representing the water industry, admits: 'We have carried out research which shows that expenditure is not as good as it should be.'

Water UK says the regulator has not allowed companies to pass on to their customers as much maintenance spending as they would like for the next five-year period.

During last year's review, companies proposed total maintenance and enhancements of £8.3 billion and were allowed £6.4bn. Of the proposed figure £4 .06bn was for sewerage - both below-ground infrastructure and above-ground facilities. Of this, £3.02bn was allowed. For actual underground spending on sewers £890m was granted of a requested £1.05bn - barely above Reynolds's £169m a year average.

Companies and Ofwat point out that the EU has directed that they must spend most of their maintenance budget on improving drinking water systems and beaches, rather than on upgrading sewers.

But Ofwat also wants efficiencies. So while most companies have lists of streets or houses that are regularly flooded by sewage - a problem they have a duty to remedy - Ofwat allowed £137m for work on 4,500 sites, while companies asked for £370m to cover 7,200

Duckworth insists flooding is only one half of the problem. Remember that five years ago the problem was drought. Dry summers and wetter winters mean the excess needs to be stored for use during scarcity. And that means a new programme of reservoirs - environmentally contentious and taking years to build - which can also help deal with overflows.

Companies indicate that getting the billions needed will be a major priority next time they negotiate with the regulator over prices. But Water UK says last time round the regulator did not consider such schemes. Ofwat says if companies put a case, it will be considered.

Opponents of privatisation would say that shareholders have gorged on double-digit dividend growth for a decade and should now stump up. Water companies point to the collapse in water stocks since the last price review, and say the break-up of the industry into mutuals, as is happening in Wales, is a consequence of this. The mutuals, they argue, will never be able to fund the work.

Meanwhile, the residents of Bewdley are living upstairs.

We are relying on nineteenth-century systems to deal with new millennium weather conditions. The pipelines are simply not wide enough to deal with these amounts of water.' John Reynolds of the department of civil engineering at Portsmouth University, who has studied the UK sewer system, says there are two distinct problems caused by different types of system. Newer systems, which operate on about 20 per cent of the network, have separate pipes for surface and foul water. Surface water sewers drain into nearby rivers. But when a river rises it covers the overflow outlets, and the river can flow back up the pipes and into the streets. This means that the area hit by flooding is extended along the sewerage network. Older systems combine surface and foul water sewers. These also have emergency overflows into rivers, which can become backed up, pushing sewage back into homes. Some companies have already acted. Anglian Water, for example, had to deal with catastrophic floods in Northampton in 1998. It installed flaps on river overflows to prevent water flooding back into the town - at minimal cost. But such simple solutions are of a different order to the massive renewal and infrastructure work some in the industry are saying will be needed if global warming continues to wreak havoc. Industry experts say there is a need for radical engineering answers. Reynolds says massive tanks could contain sewer overflows. Once floods pass and river levels drop, these tanks could be released into the rivers. Anglian recently spent £20m on a 5-metre wide emergency sewer under Ipswich. Southern Water has a 3km tunnel between Brighton and Hove. Southern, which experiences a lot of flooding, says new infrastructure does work. For example, in Folkestone, a £120m new pumping station introduced as part of its beach scheme has protected parts of the town from the recent floods. But for such schemes to play an effective part in helping water companies cope with floods, they will have to be far more common. The problem is they are expensive. Which is why the water companies are trying to make their case publicly. They are no strangers to bad publicity - taking the brunt of the fat cat headlines in the Nineties - and are in no mood to be blamed for environmental disasters. This may be what lies behind their enlistment of the riverside dwellers of Bewdley - whose plight, ironically, is probably beyond rescue by improved sewerage - to make their point. The companies will need to recoup investment for better sewers from somewhere - which, they claim, means from customers' bills. That will require the permission of regulator Ofwat, whose attention has been concentrated on ensuring household bills go down, not up. Without such a concession, there is little evidence that the companies will pay for work themselves. Reynolds's work at Portsmouth University shows that the industry spent an average of £169m a year on maintaining the 301,400 km of sewers in England and Wales from 1991 to 1999 - about an eighth of what is required. Work progressed at 213 km a year - at which rate it will take 1,400 years to replace the network. Interestingly, Reynolds also finds that the state of the network has deteriorated since privatisation while water bills have risen. Barrie Clarke of Water UK, the body representing the water industry, admits: 'We have carried out research which shows that expenditure is not as good as it should be.' Water UK says the regulator has not allowed companies to pass on to their customers as much maintenance spending as they would like for the next five-year period. During last year's review, companies proposed total maintenance and enhancements of £8.3 billion and were allowed £6.4bn. Of the proposed figure £4 .06bn was for sewerage - both below-ground infrastructure and above-ground facilities. Of this, £3.02bn was allowed. For actual underground spending on sewers £890m was granted of a requested £1.05bn - barely above Reynolds's £169m a year average. Companies and Ofwat point out that the EU has directed that they must spend most of their maintenance budget on improving drinking water systems and beaches, rather than on upgrading sewers. But Ofwat also wants efficiencies. So while most companies have lists of streets or houses that are regularly flooded by sewage - a problem they have a duty to remedy - Ofwat allowed £137m for work on 4,500 sites, while companies asked for £370m to cover 7,200 Duckworth insists flooding is only one half of the problem. Remember that five years ago the problem was drought. Dry summers and wetter winters mean the excess needs to be stored for use during scarcity. And that means a new programme of reservoirs - environmentally contentious and taking years to build - which can also help deal with overflows. Companies indicate that getting the billions needed will be a major priority next time they negotiate with the regulator over prices. But Water UK says last time round the regulator did not consider such schemes. Ofwat says if companies put a case, it will be considered. Opponents of privatisation would say that shareholders have gorged on double-digit dividend growth for a decade and should now stump up. Water companies point to the collapse in water stocks since the last price review, and say the break-up of the industry into mutuals, as is happening in Wales, is a consequence of this. The mutuals, they argue, will never be able to fund the work. Meanwhile, the residents of Bewdley are living upstairs.

webTitle: Diary of a dotcom

fields.headline: Diary of a dotcom
fields.body:
The story so far. Flametree.co.uk, an internet portal aimed at helping busy women balance their lives, launched five months ago. The company, founded by Jayne Buxton and Rosemary Leith, raised nearly £1 million in private financing and intends to make a profit within two years of launch.

Five months is a long time in the dotcom world, and Jayne and Rosemary are in reflective mood. A lot of water has already passed under the bridge. The company has moved premises, changed its technology partner, adapted its business model and taken on more staff. In addition Chris, the site's content and technical manager, has sported numerous attempts at facial hair in a bid to ride the dotcom zeitgeist.

Despite the frantic pace the pair are happy with the way things are going. 'What we're starting to see, which is wonderful, is that the brand is well recognised. We go to conferences and people will know who we are before we get there,' Jayne says.

The pair feel the company has benefited from an increasing media focus on work/life balance issues.

'The topic we're dealing with is probably the number one issue spoken about today,' Jayne says. 'Hardly a day goes by when someone isn't writing about stress at work or how you parent and work at the same time. We are fortunate to be here at the right time,'

Feedback from users has so far been very positive. Earlier this month Flametree received an email from an online reader which said: 'I just wanted you to know that you've changed my life.' The woman felt, having read lots of articles on the company's site, that she was able to renegotiate her contract with her employer so that she had more time to devote to her family.

Page impressions have jumped from 20,000 a week a few months ago to 60,000 now. More importantly, users are spending an average of 15 minutes a time on the site - way above the industry average.

Traffic flow hasn't always been smooth, however. 'You have to have your website up. You can't have a service provider that is not able to deliver,' Rosemary says. She recalls one frustrating experience - a Friday afternoon when the server went down - with horror. 'We were down for the weekend because no one was able to return our calls. That was a very stressful weekend.' Flametree now has a new technology partner as a result.

Recently the firm has started to develop a business-to-business model - linking up with a number of professional service companies to offer their staff help and advice on managing their lives. This wasn't the original intention but the company, which now boasts 11 staff, having started out with two, has had to adapt its business strategy as sentiment towards business-to-consumer models has changed for the worse.

Likewise a plan to charge a subscription fee to access the site has had to be jettisoned for now as the pair look to draw in more eyeballs.

'The goalposts have completely changed over the time we've been in business,' Rosemary says. 'The internet seems to devalue content. People pay a premium for something which isn't on the internet, but they don't want to pay for it online.'

Nevertheless, and despite the gloom in the dotcom sector, the two are still optimistic. Rosemary says: 'We all love coming to work each day. We get to work and we're so happy to be here.'

webTitle: The Networker:  John Naughton on the e-envoy

fields.headline: The e-envoy is dead; long live the e-envoy
fields.standfirst: The Networker:  John Naughton
fields.trailText: I think it was Lord Northcliffe who defined journalism as the art of relaying the news 'Lord Smith dead' to people who didn't even know he had been alive. Much the same might be said for the soi-disant 'e-envoy', the hapless official who was charged by the Prime Minister with the task of making Britain the most e-friendly country in Europe by 2002.
fields.body:
I think it was Lord Northcliffe who defined journalism as the art of relaying the news 'Lord Smith dead' to people who didn't even know he had been alive. Much the same might be said for the soi-disant 'e-envoy', the hapless official who was charged by the Prime Minister with the task of making Britain the most e-friendly country in Europe by 2002.

The first occupant of the office, Alex Allan, resigned for family reasons in September, but I have yet to meet anyone who has noticed his absence. Most people, indeed, hadn't been aware of his existence.

Allan took up his post just over a year ago. His brief included: galvanising British firms to take up the challenges of e-commerce; pushing forward the 'Modernising Government' agenda; representing UK e-commerce interests internationally; working to ensure that the benefits of e-commerce are available to all sectors of society; and ensuring effective co-ordina tion between government departments.

During his short time in office, Allan had built up a small but perfectly formed bureaucratic empire of some 60 persons - who are all kept so busy that the job of managing their office website had to be contracted to an outside organisation. Anxious that these industrious bees not be left leaderless for too long, the Government is now engaged upon the task of recruiting a new e-envoy.

Expensive headhunters have been retained, an appointment panel is in place, references are being taken up and the whole grisly pantomime is gearing up to appoint another bureaucratic eunuch.

The very term 'e-envoy' is revealing. It sounds like something dreamed up in a focus group. Perhaps it was. According to Chambers Dictionary an envoy is 'a messenger, esp. one sent to transact business with a foreign government'. This suggests that the Government sees cyberspace as some kind of alien territory - which to most of them it is.

Alternatively, Chambers defines envoy as 'a diplomatic minister of the second order'. This goes right to the heart of what was wrong with Allan's job and illustrates why anyone who succeeds him will find the job a poisoned chalice.

The problem is that the tasks of modernising government and fostering e-commerce are profoundly political ones, but the e-envoy is a mere civil servant, and as such largely impotent. One of the sadder sights of the past year has been that of Allan having to stand idly by while Jack Straw and his goons forced the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Bill through Parliament - in the process alienating those ISPs and e-commerce companies whose co-operation the envoy desperately needed in order to achieve his objectives on the e-business front.

As a civil servant, Allan cannot be blamed for the RIP catastrophe: he could do nothing to stop it. It would have required a senior Minister to take on the Home Office on its home territory. As it happens, there is a Minister responsible for e-business, one Patricia Hewitt, but she uttered not a peep of protest about what the Bill would do to her bailiwick. Why not?

Simply this: Hewitt is a Minister in the DTI, which is the parliamentary equivalent of a Soviet labour camp. It is a killing ground for political reputations: the aim of its internees is merely to survive in the hope that the next reshuffle will lift them out of DTI purgatory and into mainstream political office.

Hewitt is an ambitious woman who hopes one day to be in the Cabinet. And the way to get on in New Labour is not to annoy the Home Secretary and the security boys.

So she kept mum and let e-commerce go to hell, which was doubtless good for her, but very bad for the country.

John.Naughton@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Stockwatch

fields.headline: Stockwatch
fields.body:
Buyback bites

So who's going to be next to satisfy City institutions' hunger for cash with the next big share buyback?

In their latest circular, broker Schroder Salomon Smith Barney's equity strategy team come up with a few likely candidates. So take note firstly of Diageo, which is due to receive £3.4 billion at the end of the year from the sale of Pillsbury.

In media, WPP is already off the blocks with a £100 million programme, and United News & Media may be next after its TV disposal and, possibly, Express newspapers.

In construction, BPB and Blue Circle are among firms on whom institutional pressure may tell. The oil industry looks to be on the brink of a major buyback programme, the broker thinks, to return record profits to shareholders. So, over here, watch out for BP and Shell. Look, too, to property - Land Securities, Great Portland and Hammerson particularly - where cashbacks may narrow discounts to net asset value.

Finally, the unwinding of Anglo American's cross-holdings with De Beers may see reams of cash for investors, including the Oppenheimers.

Do the Strand

There's a new online research site in town - www.equityinvestigator.com a specialist in high-technology stocks. One of the first notes that wings our way takes an in-depth look at Strand Technology, which is quoted on the Ofex market.

Strand provides network installation, Lotus Notes and Microsoft software development services. Two off-the-peg products for which it also has great hopes are TeamNotes - to help sales teams - and CareNotes, for mental health hospitals.

At 79p, the firm is rated at just eight times Strand's forecast earnings for 2002 and at a significant discount to fully quoted rivals. Ofex shares are always more risky, but Strand may be worth a look. Equityinvestigator's target share price is 190p.

Value added

Shareholders patient enough to hang on to shares in Ellis & Everard, the chemicals distribution company, have finally been well rewarded. We recommended the stock a year ago at 240p and last week Dutch transport giant Vopak (the merged Van Ommeren and Pakhoed tanker outfits) made a 310p bid valuing E&E at £310m.

The firm's roller-coaster ride over the past 12 months is no better highlighted than by the whacking great premium Vodak is paying. That, in turn, puts the spotlight on the derisory valuations still knocking around on 'out of fashion' sectors.

Value investing will become increasingly in vogue if the mismatch endures. If firms are more valuable to someone else than the market, a bid or management buyout will inevitably come.

Cash therapy

A fortnight ago, Stockwatch emerged from its 'old economy' shell to take a punt on biotech firm Biocompatibles.

At 383p then, the shares have done nicely since, closing at 421p on Friday.

Buoyed by this success, this week we recommend you take look at PPL Therapeutics, which has recently been awarded a $1.9m US government grant for stem cell research. PPL is a world leader in 'transgenics', producing human proteins in other animals such as pigs.

German drugs giant Bayer is partnering its lead compound, AAT, as a possible treatment for emphysema and cystic fibrosis.

Under the deal, PPL receives stage payments of up to $25m; Bayer has also taken a $15m equity stake at 215p a share.

At 173p, the stock has slipped back of late. However, broker Seymour Pierce, for one, is a strong supporter and reckons the company is 'significantly undervalued'.

webTitle: Media diary

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.body:
Big brothers' decision awaited

So who looks likely to succeed Jeff Randall as editor of Sunday Business ? Four candidates, we hear, are heading the field. Deputy editor Richard Northedge and news editor Frank Kane were the first to declare, but a dark horse has come up on the rails: none other than Jonathan Fenby, erstwhile editor of The Observer . Fenby returned from exile in Hong Kong to write for the pink paper and has since been involved in secret 'special projects'. Patience Wheatcroft, business editor of the Times , is thought to be the outsider on the racecard.

Randall, meanwhile, is understood to spitting blood at the UK Press Gazette - and diaries less scrupulous than ours - for stating that he favours Kane over Northedge. Far from it. Randall has been keen to be even-handed and the choice will come down to Sunday Business's taskmaster Andrew Neil and his paymasters, the Barclay Brothers. Watch out for pink smoke from the twins' eerie castle on Brecqhou...

Dying for a new audience

Like the Daily Mail , Radio 4 suffers from an aging audience who have an annoying habit of dying, reducing audience share. In an effort to attract younger listeners, Radio 4 ran a workshop for comedy writers recently but not everything went to plan. Most of the writers had not listened to the station - some even thought it was the radio equivalent of Channel 4 - and when their ideas were rejected as too young, one replied: 'Well, that's OK, cos most of your listeners will die soon anyway.' A frustrated Radio 4 boss returned to Broadcasting House to tell her bosses: 'It's hopeless. They seem to think we should sack the audience and get a new one.'

Down, down, deeper down

This Morning with Richard & Judy has rightly drawn attention for having the most inane cash quiz in broadcasting history. So dumbed down are its questions that it makes Family Fortunes seem like a Wittgenstein discourse. But last week the quiz dropped to a new low. A competitor was stumped when asked to say the opposite of over. Another was unable to spell the word trousers.

Mad as a hatter

Mind you, US broadcasters don't seem to be too bright either. One of NBC's anchors likened the US election chaos last week to scenes from Alice in Wonderland , saying things were getting 'stranger and stranger'. Curious.

Abroad cross section

The publisher of Marie Claire has told us that, contrary to last week's Diary, it has no plans to drop its award-winning foreign reportage section. While no one likes to be wrong we are glad - the last thing we would encourage is dumbing down. Roll on more awards, we say.

Spot the link

Is Auntie engaged in a subtle form of product placement for her own programmes? An edition of The Weakest Link , hosted by Ann Robinson (left) last week contained no fewer than five questions about television programmes on the Beeb. There was even a plug for Ceefax.

webTitle: Luc is honest - but can he refit Marks & Sparks?

fields.headline: Luc is honest - but can he refit Marks & Sparks?
fields.standfirst: Throg Street: Heather Connon
fields.trailText: The wrong products, poor availability of those that are selling well, unattractive stores and a slow, inflexible and costly supply chain. Luc Vandevelde's analysis of Marks & Spencer's problems was spot-on. The trouble is, anyone could have told him that when he took over as chairman in February. What M&S desperately needs is solutions to those problems - and there was little in the first-half results to suggest they have been found.
fields.body:
The wrong products, poor availability of those that are selling well, unattractive stores and a slow, inflexible and costly supply chain. Luc Vandevelde's analysis of Marks & Spencer's problems was spot-on. The trouble is, anyone could have told him that when he took over as chairman in February. What M&S desperately needs is solutions to those problems - and there was little in the first-half results to suggest they have been found.

The most depressing part of the results was the current trading. We may have been through floods, petrol famine and a plague of sales at C&A but, even so, a 17 per cent drop in clothing sales, after allowing for the impact of new space, is abysmal.

As worrying were the supply problems in lingerie, knit-wear and footwear - three of M&S's core areas - which had partly caused the drop. That suggests the move to overseas suppliers has not been trouble-free, which is even more worrying given that M&S now intends to buy as much as half of its supplies much closer to the start of the season.

More encouraging is the progress on store refits. Perhaps recognising that there is no point getting an interior designer to deck out your lounge when the rest of the house is falling apart, the group is shifting its focus away from total revamps under the Concept programme and is now concentrating on getting the most successful bits of the programme into as many stores as possible as quickly as possible.

Thus all stores will get some improvements to layout and design by Christmas. Out will go the racks and racks of trousers, skirts and blouses displayed in separate areas. In its place will come co-ordinated displays and, following the realisation from the re-vamp at its Kensington branch that less can be more, the stores will be less crowded, giving customers space to see what is actually on offer.

Local cataloguing - M&S-speak for the realisation that shoppers in Bath do not want to buy the same as shoppers in Bootle - will be in all stores by next spring. Electrical power cords and computer cables may not be a very glamorous business, but for those lucky enough to be shareholders in Volex - the leading independent producer of such equipment - it has been extremely lucrative. In the past 18 months, its shares have more than quad-rupled in value, now standing at 2100p. And, unlike with the technology stocks that have managed the same feat, there has been almost no turbulence on the way.

Last week's interim results to September go some way to explaining why. Sales rose by 51 per cent to £217m, and its operating profits all but doubled, to £16.1m. Volex's success in turning a commodity business into a fast-growing profit machine owes much to the fact that it has beaten its customers in the race to go global. Companies such as Lucent, Nortel, Compaq and Black & Decker - all on Volex's books - increasingly want to use the same supplier everywhere.

In a fragmented market, Volex is gaining business at the expense of small local firms. It is, of course, also benefiting from the explosive growth in the telecoms and data-processing markets, where sales doubled in the six-month period.

But even if, as some predict, demand here slows, Volex should still benefit from the continued move to global suppliers - Lucent, for example, is cutting its supplier base from 142 to 30 - of which Volex is one. Nokia, for example, uses outside suppliers for only 10 per cent of its components.

As cost pressures on these businesses grow, so the trend to outsourcing should accelerate. In the meantime, Volex continues to win market share in the more traditional areas of its business, such as consumer and electrical, which also enjoyed respectable growth in the first half.

The higher volumes pushed margins up from 7.3 to 8.3 per cent, despite continual pressure to cut prices. Molloy believes that can continue, and expects to be able to keep margins at around the current level.

The sharp rise in its shares has pushed Volex's rating well ahead of the average for its engineering sector. Based on forecasts of £33.5m profit before tax for the full year, it stands on a rating of about 25 times expected earnings. That sounds high but it is not expensive compared with some of its international rivals and is justified for a company that should be increasing profits by about 20 per cent a year for at least the next couple of years. webTitle: DIY's changing boardrooms

fields.headline: DIY's changing boardrooms
fields.standfirst: TV shows and a strong housing market have fuelled the battle for top spot.  Nick Mathiason reports
fields.trailText: For many people, Do It Yourself are the three most dreaded words in the English language but, for the City, DIY spells major growth opportunity.
fields.body:
For many people, Do It Yourself are the three most dreaded words in the English language but, for the City, DIY spells major growth opportunity.

While most retailers battle to survive cutthroat competition and falling prices, big DIY businesses are thriving.

This year, consumer trends company Mintel forecasts that the UK will spend £10.4 billion on home improvements - up £2.26bn on last year's estimated figure. The increase can be explained by a booming housing market, expansion by retailers into 'soft goods' for the kitchen and bathroom, big profits from garden products and high margins for electrical tools and lawn mowers.

Television programmes such as Home Front and Changing Rooms, which regularly attract 11 million viewers, fire the market by persuading an increasingly style- conscious population to feather their nests more adventurously - and more regularly. In addition, analysts say an ageing homeowning population who do not move house often is a recipe for fat DIY profits.

As the UK becomes more obsessed with power tools and parquet flooring, the City is driving the creation of big ger DIY operations that can carry larger numbers of products under one roof, yielding increased cost efficiencies through stronger buying power and enabling the giants to compete in a global market.

'In 1995, there were seven big DIY retailers,' said Mike Godliman, a director with retail analyst Verdict Research. 'Now there are essentially just three. It's about scale and buying power: this enables them to have the huge stores that attract more customers.' Last September, Wickes, the country's third-largest DIY retailer, was bought by Focus Do It All, with backing from Duke Street Capital, for £289m. The deal was worth 495p per share.

The agreed merger represented a triumph for Wickes' former chief executive, biker Bill Grimsey. Earlier this year Grimsey successfully fought off a hostile bid from Focus worth 430p per share.

Duke Street Capital, headed by Edmund Truell, is now poised to buy Great Mills - a trade hardware outfit with 96 stores based mainly in provincial towns - for around £260m. RMC, the current owner, wants to focus on heavy building materials.

If Duke Street completes the deal, it will have invested more than £544m and at a stroke become the UK's second-biggest DIY operation, overtaking Homebase.

Owned by Sainsbury's, Homebase is itself up for sale as part of chief executive Sir Peter Davis's drive to focus the UK's second-largest supermarket on its core food retailing business.

But over the past three months, a host of bidders have pulled out of the auction. These include Duke Street; a consortium led by Jim Hodkinson - the man sacked earlier this year by clothing retailer New Look for sexual harassment but credited with building B&Q into the UK's biggest DIY chain; US leveraged buyout group KKR; and French DIY group LeRoy Merlin.

LeRoy Merlin wants a joint venture with Sainsbury's, but this would be as unwelcome as peeling wallpaper in the City, which wants Davis to use sale proceeds to invest in its supermarkets.

Other bidders have not been prepared to pay more than £900m for the 297-store business, which during the last financial year generated sales of £1.43bn - up £130m on last year. Bidders are said to be concerned at the contracts to open 25 large stores over the next four years, at a cost of £300m.

It is understood that Sains bury's adviser, investment bank UBS Warburg, is in negotiations with just one financial buyer prepared to pay more than £1bn.

Rumours in the City suggest that buyer is Phildrew Ventures, the London-based venture capital arm of UBS, but this has been roundly denied by Phildrew. Sainsbury's is refusing to confirm or deny the rumours.

B&Q, with a 23 per cent market share, is by far the biggest player in the market, and it is also heading for a period of change. Parent company Kingfisher is aiming to split B&Q and Comet early next year from its other companies, which include Superdrug and Woolworths.

The move will interest the biggest DIY company in the world, Home Depot of the US. It is the Wal-Mart of DIY: the buying power provided by its 930 stores, which last year generated £25.6bn, allows it to force down suppliers' prices.

Despite issuing third- and fourth-quarter profits warnings in the US - brought about by cheaper lumber prices and a slowing of consumer demand - Home Depot is intent on expanding into South America and Europe.

'Europe is an area we're definitely looking at,' said Home Depot's Jerry Shields. 'It's a long-term aspiration, and the profit warnings we've issued do not affect our long-term business model.'

B&Q would be an ideal fit. The Kingfisher company has modelled itself on Home Depot. B&Q's store opening programme will give it 17 new 150,000 sq ft warehouses by February 2002 - exactly the same size as a standard Home Depot store. By 2003, there will be 430 B&Qs.

But the Americans need to wait for the demerger to avoid a messy deal. If they were to make a move prior to demerger they would have to sell on all the other Kingfisher outlets.

On the basis that Kingfisher's latest results showed that B&Q achieved total sales of £2.59bn, Home Depot would have to pay close to £3bn for it. Add in Kingfisher's French DIY giant, Castorama, and that figure will have to rise by another billion.

But while DIY executives are sealing their consolidation and expansion plans, the next three months are expected to see disappointing sales for the sector.

'The housing market and big-ticket consumer demand have dropped off,' said Nick Bubb, influential retail analyst at SG Securities. 'The transport crisis means it's harder to get anywhere, and the weather has clearly dampened outdoor activity.'

This is bad news according to one former Wickes board member: 'It couldn't have come at a worse time: B&Q wants to look good ahead of its demerger; Duke Street has spent nearly £600m on becom ing number two; and Sainsbury's wants to get shot of Homebase. There is nothing fundamentally wrong with the market. It's just that this blip may cause a few headaches.'

And when you consider that 30 years ago, despite the Black and Decker 'Workmate' and the Dulux dog, DIY retailing scarcely existed, short-term fears should probably be glossed over.

Pots and pots of essentials

In one year, Homebase, the UK's second-largest DIY retailer, sells:

 About 1.2 million garden chairs - equivalent to 16 Wembley Cup Final crowds

 Enough ceramic tiles to cover 190 football pitches

 Sufficient paint to paint a line 6 inches wide around the world

 Miles of electric cable - enough to go around the Crystal Palace running track 15,000 times

In one year, B&Q, the UK's largest DIY retailer, sells:

 Enough laminate flooring to cover 1,000 football pitches. If the laminate sheets were laid end to end, they would cover 25,000 miles

 Last Easter, B&Q sold 100,000 lawnmowers

 In one year, B&Q sells a mountain of toilet seats that if stacked one on top of each other would be three times the height of Ben Nevis

 Enough masking tape to wrap around the world twice

 More than 5 million paving slabs

 Around 2.3 million shelving kits

webTitle: Pop: Doves, Manchester

fields.headline: When Pavarotti rode a milk-float
fields.trailText: Doves, Manchester
fields.body:
Doves, Manchester

'We haven't got a clue what it means, so don't ask us,' shouted Jimi Goodwin, frontman for Doves, as he took to the stage at the Ritz in Manchester. He was referring to a short film shot by a friend which preceded their homecoming gig, in which he and non-identical twin brothers Andy and Jez Williams (drums and lead guitar) drive on to the Moors in a milk-float and accept a mysterious sack from someone wearing a Pavarotti mask.

The crowd at the front cheered and chanted, and I wondered whether the film was a joke at the band's expense - the sack might contain big money, Pavarotti could be a thinly veiled reference to major record labels (in this case, Heavenly/EMI, through which the band released its debut album, Lost Souls, earlier this year).

The implication is that the band, for so long denizens of the Manchester underground, has sold out. Which they clearly haven't. They played a storming set - and they made it look easy. For some of the numbers, Jimi and Andy, a decent vocalist and no mean harmonica player, effortlessly swapped roles and places.

The music is a hybrid of mournful (and, in the studio at least, mellow) indie and psychedelia, new-wave rock and pop. Jimi and Andy's vocals sit on a rich bed of guitar and non-yob-rock drumming, betraying the band's roots in the early Nineties house scene. The already full sound was complemented by occasional sequenced beats and atmospheric samples.

If anything, the set had more power than the group's self-produced album, an understated affair which taps a bleak vein only Mancunian bands seem able to mine. By the time the mid-set rocker 'Catch the Sun' kicked in, the crowd were jumping in jubilation; one individual even managed a stage-dive. It's not the kind of response I had expected, given set opener 'Firesuite', a loose cousin to the Smiths' 'The Draize Train', and the melancholic 'Break Me Gently'; nor had the band, who said this home-turf gig had been the best on the tour.

I was impressed to hear the audience singing along to 'A House', which hints at the night the group's studio (containing all their master tapes) was destroyed by fire in 1995. The crowd stopped short of holding lighters aloft, but only just.

After the gig, I talked to the group about their meeting as devotees of house at the Hacienda and their number three chart success as Sub Sub in 1993 with the anthemic 'Ain't No Love [Ain't No Use]'. We talked about the state of the British music scene: 'It's healthy, it's vibrant - there's loads of good bands out there,' argued Jimi. 'Maybe we should be questioning more what's being played over the airwaves,' countered Jez. 'It's all getting a bit one-sided - crap, basically. The charts are shit [Doves' new single, 'The Man Who Told Everything', charted at number 32 last week] but people have been fed it and soon they start to digest it.'

Not that Doves disapprove of pop; they insist they're a pop band too, and, as Jimi said: 'There's a place for it - if you're 12 years old. We've all been there, so I can't diss Britney - it's just irrelevant to me.'

Irrelevant, too, perhaps, to the 100,000 people who have bought the band's album since its release. Doves' nomination for the Mercury Music Prize alongside fellow thirtysomething Mancunian Badly Drawn Boy - and the latter's triumph at the award ceremony - might seem a good omen for such talent. According to Jimi: 'The record companies are signing bands like us, who are in it for the long haul.' It's just, they say, a question of A&R departments leaving well alone. 'A lot of bands get pushed on and they're not quite sure where they're going,' said Jez. 'We've got ideas and we know what we want to do.'

Jimi agreed: 'You can't A&R bands like us - you've just got to let them get on with it.' And so, it would seem, Pavarotti has served his purpose and Doves' milk- float is free to speed on to the next venue.

 Doves play Brighton Centre, East Wing (tonight) and London Shepherd's Bush Empire (Mon, Tues).

fields.headline: What a Lulu
fields.standfirst: Ken Tynan flared with wit and opinion. He met his match in Louise Brooks
fields.trailText:
Smoking With Lulu, West Yorkshire Playhouse
In Extremis and De Profundis, Cottesloe
The Force of Change, Royal Court
fields.body:
Smoking With Lulu
West Yorkshire Playhouse, Leeds

In Extremis and De Profundis
Cottesloe, London SE1

The Force of Change
Royal Court, London SW1

The life of a theatre critic isn't what it was. Who would take an episode from the career of a drama reviewer and put it on the stage? That's what Janet Munsil has done, in imagining the 1978 encounter between the elusive, reclusive, bob-headed, sharp-witted actress Louise Brooks, and my influential predecessor, Kenneth Tynan.

Where was Tynan when he decided to write about Brooks? Lounging in the heat of Santa Monica. Where was I when I set off to write about Tynan? Crawling through a north of England sodden with lakes of floodwater.

Smoking With Lulu brings to dramatic life the New Yorker profile that Tynan wrote about Brooks 40 years after she'd made her last movie. When they met, Brooks was in her seventies, bedridden with osteoarthritis and emphysema. Tynan was 51, a torrent of opinion, evocation and wordplay; he was also a stammerer: 'You hardly notice it when I write.' He was to die six years later - of emphysema.

The play floats on Brooks's wit as well as Tynan's: she dismissed Dietrich as 'that contraption' and wanted to call her autobiography Naked on My Goat (a quote from Goethe's Faust). Munsil makes one strategic mistake: she incarnates Tynan's fantasies about Brooks.

Sophie Millett is obliged to scamper gracefully across the stage, variously got up in Ziegfeld plumes or as Dorothy in The Wizard of Oz, while footage of Brooks's movies is flashed behind her. Prancing and bouncing wither an audience's capacity to collude in any dream. And no news is broken by this: Tynan's bottom-spanking tendencies, much diarised by the spanker, are less of a surprise than his breast-beating.

The play scores as a sketch of what it is to feel glamorous, and threatened. Thelma Barlow, once Mavis in Coronation Street, makes the most unlikely career change since Shirley Temple became an ambassador. She's always enticing and intelligent, but not yet hard-boiled enough for the wilful talent who wanted to be a 'writer's moll'.

It's Peter Eyre who provides the crucial moment of the evening when he appears, puffing on a cigarette, glowering down a nose that he seems eerily to have elongated for the occasion, and discoursing fluently, with little breaks for a stammer, on the allure of the burning stick which ends up as ash. Just as you're deciding whether to write this up as brilliance or off as pretentiousness, he pauses, and nods: 'I'm creating... atmosphere.' At its best, that's what Smoking With Lulu supplies.

It's been a week of wits and dandies and strange meetings. The National kicked off a round of Oscar Wilde celebrations with a double bill featuring the playwright before and after his downfall. First, Corin Redgrave presents Wilde the fastidious aesthete - grey suit, languorous speech, neck arched like a cat's - in In Extremis, a short, two-hander by Neil Bartlett. Then, in De Profundis, he becomes the prisoner and lover, passionate in a crumpled brown uniform, delivering a shortened version of the rollercoaster love-letter Wilde wrote to Lord Alfred Douglas from Reading jail.

The occasion has an Edwardian flavour: sedate and melancholy, with a reproving biographical arc. Redgrave's performance in De Profundis , by turns Bosie-blaming and self-condemning, is impressive, though his Irish cadences see-saw repetitively. But the production has a whiff of recitation. Tasteful evocative touches - a distant clanging of metal doors, a picture of sky and clouds dangling over the bare stage (the 'tent of blue' described by Wilde) - give an air not of claustrophobic terror but of artfulness.

Bartlett's In Extremis is an intriguing sliver, a reconstruction of a meeting between Wilde and a palm-reader he described as 'the Sybil of Mortimer Street... whom mortals term Mrs Robinson'. Wilde consults Mrs R, a nicely canny Sheila Hancock, shortly before he's due to stand trial, when friends are urging him to leave the country. She provides a carefully catch-all prediction; he interprets this as a promise that things will go well.

All this is plausible; some of it took place. There was such a meeting, and Wilde was cheered, though puzzled, by what he heard: 'Why did the Sybil say fair things?' he asked Ada Leverson, whom he called his 'Sphinx'. Well, presumably it was, as Bartlett suggests, more than her job was worth to do otherwise. More interesting questions are provoked, but not tackled. Was Wilde's belief in palmistry tinged with irony? And why was he compelled to think of women as riddling oracles?

The great wave of Irish talent that has hit the London stage since Wilde has been largely Catholic, rural and funny-lyrical. But there's an odd man out. Gary Mitchell is Protestant, urban and casts his plays in the form of thrillers. He's not so much a phrase-maker as a trail-blazer. His plays are set alight by their urgency. You sometimes see the bones sticking through the plot, but you always feel the dramatist racing to map another new area of the territory he's made his own.

In the case of The Force of Change, which galvanised the Royal Court Upstairs in the spring, this area is the RUC under pressure: pressure from the peace process and pressure from UDA sympathisers; pressure to reform, and pressure not to cave in.

Three officers - one a woman, one corrupt, one (the superb Stuart Graham) harsh and effective - interrogate two suspects, and each other, to explosive effect. In Simon Higlett's original design, the play was staged in a long strip, with the actors pacing like laboratory animals in a cage; the audience, banked on either side, were the walls of the trap.

This sensation is lost in the larger, less malleable space of the Theatre Downstairs: at preview, the voltage dropped slightly. But, under Robert Delamere's direction, the prickly complications of the constabulary's psychology are still forcefully projected. And this makes The Force of Change a minor revelation.

webTitle: Arts: William Blake, Tate Britain, London

fields.headline: Blake's heaven
fields.standfirst: Visionary or anti-enlightenment scourge? The 'Cockney nutcase' was both - and much more besides
fields.trailText: Visionary or anti-enlightenment scourge? The 'Cockney nutcase' was both - and much more besides
fields.body:
William Blake
Tate Britain, London SW1 until 11 February

William Blake has been seen - in our time, if not his - as the patron saint of outsiders: an idealist working in complete defiance of establishment tastes who would rather cut off his hand than accept tainted money. He is born in Soho, refuses to go to church or school and never leaves the inner city except for a single trip during which he is charged with sedition.

An autodidact, trained only as a hack engraver, he develops the most original fusion of word and image in the history of art. Yet nobody comes to his first and last show - at the age of 53 - and his reputation is mainly for madness. Critics deride him as a lunatic, libertarian and nudist. Even fans like Wordsworth pity his afflicted visions, launching the myth of the Cockney nutcase.

The visions, of course, are amazing. Saints diving through the firmament, devils skating on water, angels backcrawling through seas of gossamer cloud. Blake imagined insects reincarnated as titans, tulips making love, Newton doing his maths at the bottom of the ink-blue ocean.

In his cosmos, the Queen of Heaven might hold an admiring mirror to her face and God might turn out a tyrant, wrenching Adam like a weed from the earth. To say that Blake turned the world upside down is no more than an understatement. That he persisted for more than 50 years, with no bosses and very few patrons, buried at 69 in an unknown grave: this is the crux of his heroism.

Tate Britain does not attempt to dislodge this popular image. How could it? With over 500 works, its Blake show is the largest ever mounted and the biggest event ever held at the Tate.

The sheer scale of Blake's reputation will make it almost impossible to get up close to the paintings - often no bigger than playing cards - and the punishing £8 entry fee means that most people won't be able to go twice. But these paper dreams are so fragile that there may never be another chance to see Blake at full stretch - and to see him anew as an artist.

Everything familiar is here: God in his chariot of fire, the Ancient of Days with his compasses, the Tyger, Newton, Jerusalem, the Songs of Innocence and Experience. There are the streaming bodies - words made flesh - the long hair, loose robes, rainbows and stars that made Blake such a hit with the hippies. But right away things start to look a little different. It's not just that Newton turns out to be fully as large as the Athena poster he became in the Seventies; nor that the Tyger, beneath Blake's burning words, is the size of a postage stamp. Two items in the very first room should scupper for good the cliché of Blake as a sky-gazing dreamer forever tripping over the curb.

The first is a tiny engraving from 1820, made around the time of his disastrous show. It's a drawing of an ancient sculpture: Laocoon and his sons tangled in a knot of serpents. Blake has tendentiously renamed the figures Jehovah, Adam and Satan. More than that, he has imprisoned them in a dense graffiti of slogans - 'Christianity is art: money its curse', 'Science is the tree of death' and so forth.

It's a full-scale rant, put there to remind you that Blake could be a denunciatory scourge. The text seems religious, but is planted with anti-enlightenment gibes against Newton and Locke, sly stabs at Joshua Reynolds, president of the RA, whose death Blake applauded in gleeful verse. Proud, sardonic, spiky, Blake held record grudges and regarded himself as the equal of Raphael and Dürer. Look at his illustrations to The Divine Comedy and you see Dante reproved, time and again.

The figures in those great watercolours are dressed appropriately in medieval robes, but the same garb looks shockingly anachro nistic when Blake is imagining revolutionary America or France. That's why the other object in that first room - a replica of Queen Eleanor's tomb in Westminster Abbey - is crucial. Blake made it the origin of his faux-Gothic figures with their hieratic faces, super-long bodies and drapes. He is a radical antiquarian, ransacking the past for the spirit of a better future. Skip a century and you see the same ambition in the Statue of Liberty.

Liberty, with her spiked diadem and triumphant arms, would be the woman for Blake if she wasn't so massy. His bodies are lithe, liable to levitate or fly. To see so many together is to realise just how far Blake departs from reality: prehensile toes, supernatural limbs, fingers that touch distant planets. Shape-shifters who can look like wraiths, sky-divers, even Spiderman, their every tendon is revealed beneath transparent robes and skin. The look is strenuous, never Romantically effete; yet each figure is airy, a figment of outline and wash that lives in the page.

Blake pioneered a printing technique - relief etching, in which everything but his images and words (written backwards) was corroded from the plate. Even this was a dig at Locke, whose concept of the mind as a tabula rasa waiting to be inscribed like a conventional engraving, disgusted Blake, who believed in innate ideas. The texts are handwritten, the images hand-touched so that they look more like watercolours. Blake freed his art from the tyranny of printers and typeface.

No matter where they're set - 1,000 leagues beneath the sea or outer space - his scenes are all choreographed in terms of the illuminated page. The figures merge with the words, sometimes passing over them in fireballs or spiral gusts. Pose is personality. Apollo performs an arabesque, Satan an Egyptian schmooze; Death takes a bow, arms imperiously outstretched. Blake can be corny: David delivered from the waves is like some Cecil B. DeMille finale. He can also be comic, tipping the damned into a tank of winking fish.

But you always know what's happening in these extreme, dynamic ballets. Or do you? Take Newton. Does anyone now interpret this superb figure, hunched over his sums, as a massive attack on Sir Isaac and all his works? Or recognise the Ancient of Days, with his wind-blown beard and lightning dividers, as Urizen, Blake's satirical personification of Reason? The later poems, with their druidical, Swedenborgian, occultist mythology, are as incomprehensible now as they probably ever were.

Tate Britain's attempts at interpretation are brave, but futile. Blake wasn't interested anyway: 'That which can be made explicit to the idiot is not worth my care.' The more obscure his texts, as this marvellous show reveals, the stronger the images - Urizen adrift, his beard floating across the waters; Albion rising in a blaze of glory; Jerusalem and Albion conceived as lovers, their twined embrace one of the supreme images of sexual love in art. 'The eye,' as Blake said, 'sees more than the heart knows.'

Apart from the occasional Regency curl and sideburn, these figures are timeless, their context eternal. To see them is to be taken out of yourself, removed to a fearless, liberated world.

If Blake was no more than official stenographer to the saints, as he mischievously claimed, then his best self-portrait is the late Recording Angel, pen in hand and seated, visions sparking above his head in a halo of stars.

What to focus on if you've only got an hour to spare

Nebuchadnezzar (1795) King Nebuchadnezzar, architect of Babylon, is a warning to the proud: 'those that walk in pride, the Lord can abase.' Blake's king crawls like a beast on the earth, beard trailing, toes turning to talons, naked skin like matted hide.

Newton (1805) Newton, a naked muscleman bent over his diagram, is so deeply absorbed that he doesn't notice the wonders of the coral-reefed ocean in which he is plunged. One of the 12 so-called large prints.

The Ghost of a Flea (1819) The flea is reincarnated as a creepy titan, holding the bowl in which he collects blood. Supposedly a vision transcribed for Blake's friend, the astrologer John Varley; possibly a tease at the credulous Varley.

The Tyger (1794) The poem from Songs of Innocence and Experience, famous as Wordsworth's 'Daffodils', with the big cat painted in fearful miniature below: religion, revolution and animal grandeur.

Jerusalem (1821) Not the national football anthem, later given that title, but the long poem in 100 magnificent plates. See especially the last, in which Jerusalem and Albion are united in erotic love within the petals of a lily.

Oh! Flames of Furious Desires (1796) From the First Book of Urizen, one of Blake's made-up mythologies. Incredibly tensile drawing of a figure leaping like Nijinsky through a veil of fire. Bear in mind Blake's belief that 'All is not sinful that Satan calls so'.

Capaneus the Blasphemer (1824) From Blake's illustrations to Dante's Divine Comedy. Capaneus, nude but still coiffed like a Regency dandy, reclines in the third circle of hell. His face is lit from beneath by flames, lightning strikes at his molten body.

The Ancient of Days (1824) The divine, reaching down from his burning disc, to measure the earth below with his lightning-bright dividers. Despite the force, and the white, windswept beard, this is not God but Blake's Urizen, the despised personification of Reason and Science.

fields.headline: What's your boeuf?
fields.standfirst:
How a cheese maker from South West France smashed a local McDonald's, took on the World Trade Organisation, become a national hero and is now being seen by some as a president

The globalisation debate - Observer special

Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: How a cheese maker from South West France smashed a local McDonalds, took on the World Trade Organisation and become a national hero.
fields.body:
José Bové smooths his luxuriant Asterix moustache, lights his rustic pipe and walks up to the TV cameras. He looks like a peasant, but he talks like a well-briefed government Minister. The rest of France may be in a panic about mad cow disease, but he at least is calm, convincing, coolly analytical.

The real problem, he says, is this: Between 1993 and 1996, unscrupulous people in France illegally imported diseased animal feed from Britain. That's why France has a BSE problem. More than 14,000 tonnes of feed was smuggled into the country and entered the alimentary chain, poisoning France's livestock and threatening the health of her people. All this despite the fact that British meat and bone meal was banned in France as long ago as August 1989.

So it's all Britain's fault? Bové glances at me dismissively. 'Not at all. It goes far beyond apportioning blame to the British. It was an aberrant system, and those who are responsible for it should be brought to book. That's happening in Britain, but in France no one has been brought to account yet.'

The leader of the Confédération Paysanne, a militant French anti-globalisation group that represents the interests of many of France's more environmentally-conscious small farmers, is standing outside the opulent Justice Ministry in the Place Vendôme in Paris. He and some colleagues have just been in to see the Justice Minister Marylise Lebranchu and her officials to protest against government and judicial inaction over the scandal of illegally imported feed.

He didn't have an appointment, but that didn't matter: when Bové arrives unannounced at the heart of French government these days, diaries are juggled, apologetic phone calls made and a scruffily dressed small man with a big dossier is ushered briskly into the corridors of power.

The French press has called him the Robin Hood of peasants, fighting against multinational agro-industry Sheriffs of Nottingham, but the laborious comparison is bogus: there is nothing like Jose Bové in Britain, and there never has been.

Rather, he is an utterly French symbol who has appropriated the facial hair of the country's most famous ancient Gaul and the bucolic manner of a true Gallic peasant. He's been hailed by the National Front and the Gaullists, the Socialists and the Greens. He has managed to achieve this remarkable appeal not only because of his ability to develop a critique of globalisation, but because his image and his lifestyle evoke a nostalgic vision of rural France. His is a France of wonderful cheeses, thumping great red wines and starry skies seen from rolling fields. All this, plus the fact that he vandalised a McDonald's burger joint - that icon of soulless Anglo-Saxon grub and destructive farming methods - has made him a French hero.

The son of two university researchers, Bové was a child of May 1968 - left-wing, hairy, and committed to overthrowing the capitalist order. But even when he and his future wife, Alice, dropped out of Bordeaux university after the student riots, he was, as he recalls now, 'more Gandhi than Guevara'. Appropriately, in 1972 he refused to do military service and holed up at the farm of a market gardener in the Gironde.

By now a member of the radical back-to-the-land movement, Bové went to the beautifully rugged Larzac plateau in the South-West of France to join a fight against the extension of a military camp. 'The peasants of the plateau had decided to install young farmers around the perimeter,' he remembers. 'And I became one of them.' In this way, they hoped to stop a firing range being built.

Bové, then, put himself on the front line against the military-industrial complex. There was no road to his house, no electricity, no water. There was, however, a baby to look after. But he knew he had found his spiritual home, and there he settled to raise sheep and make Roquefort cheese from their milk. 'When I arrived at the Larzac, I immediately sensed a coherence between the place and my aspirations. I had seen too many extreme left-wing militants blow a gasket. But at the Larzac I have something concrete. I'm not a bird on a branch, I am in the real world.'

Bové is a great champion of community spirit in an age of individualism. 'The opposition to the military camp created an extraordinary solidarity. Zapata, Cesar Chavez or even the Chouans [the Breton peasants who fought against the French Revolution] - the struggles of the peasants throughout history and throughout the world have always been a collective adventure.' That adventure put him at the forefront of every left-wing militant battle in France for 30 years, from nuclear tests to highway extensions.

But he became internationally known last year when he was imprisoned for leading a commando raid on a McDonald's under construction in the town of Millau, not far from his farm. The United States government, incensed that Europe had banned its hormone-injected beef, had slapped huge duties on French food imports - including Roquefort, such as that made by Bové. In revenge, he and group of local peasants descended on the McDonald's with hammers and screwdrivers, after warning the local police what they were up to.

It was a highly symbolic target. For the cheesemakers, goat farmers, fruit growers and poultry raisers of rural South-West France, McDonald's exemplified the grim march of globalisation. Bové was jailed, but hundreds of well-wishers from around France paid his £10,500 bail.

'For 20 years now, we've been fighting for a peasant, non-polluting agriculture,' Bové told TV cameras on his triumphant release in September last year. 'Today, for the first time, there's a national consensus about bad food. People realise we need a different international logic than the economic, social and environmental dumping of modern agriculture.'

Just over a year later, Bové is outside the Ministry of Justice in front of another set of TV cameras, still railing against globalisation, GM crops and a world that has lost its soul. But now he is an international figure who has taken his campaigns to Seattle and to Brazil, a cunning media manipulator and the author of two best-selling books. He's only spent about a month on his farm all year, he says.

Some people in France want him to stand for president and, given the unpopularity of the leading contenders Jospin and Chirac in the opinion polls, it's not an entirely barmy suggestion. True, in the New Year an appeal court in Montpellier may confirm his jail sentence for the McDonald's attack. True, his wife denounced him earlier this year in the Confédération Paysanne magazine as a 'macho' man who had left her for another woman. But today he is a respected figure and Bové's intervention in France's BSE scandal had been eagerly awaited. And here it is. Bové brandishes a dossier before the TV cameras that contains the Confederation Paysanne's report based on information procured from the customs officers in Toulouse. It demonstrates, he argues, the culpability not only of certain French beef farmers, but of successive Agriculture Ministers and administrators in illegally importing infected animal feed. The authorities had all this information in 1996, he says angrily.

'Since then, though, nothing has been done. An investigating magistrate appointed to look into the affair in 1996 still hasn't opened the file and the Minister of Agriculture has covered up outrageous practices. There are people who are ready to testify, employees who can reveal the facts. But they must be protected, because they could be menaced.'

It's a brilliant coup de thétre, to go to one part of the government to indict another, and to stand up for the little guys on the receiving end of a corrupt and inhuman international conspiracy. But it would be trite to suggest Bové is merely a silver-tongued media manipulator. That said, there aren't many peasants who could command the attention of Ministers and journalists alike, without diluting his radical message.

'What must we do?', pipes up one journalist. 'There are three things,' says Bové quick as a flash. 'First, meat and bone meal must be banned immediately. Second, M. Jospin [the French Prime Minister] must work to get a European-wide policy on how to feed our animals. Third, beef farmers must be indemnified against the catastrophic fall in beef sales in France. Instead of producing a panic about beef, we must ensure that all cows more than two years old should be tested for the disease when sent for slaughter. Otherwise, we are going to destroy our beef farmers.'

Clear stuff, and policies which the French President, Jacques Chirac, endorsed last week. Admittedly, there is a slight problem and one that Le Monde seized on last week. If meat and bone meal were banned, a vegetable-based replacement would have to be imported to replace it. But, according to the Blair House accords signed in 1992, European Community member states are obliged to buy a great deal of soya-based feeds from the US, most of which are made from genetically modified crops. It's a solution that Bové detests and which for him typifies the mess of unsustainable farming.

'This is why we have to see the Prime Minister to get a new European policy on these matters. We have to sort out this mess of how to feed our animals.' He shakes my hand (for a farmer his hand is surprisingly soft), lights his pipe once more and strides purposefully off. He probably hasn't got an appointment but M. Jospin will doubtless receive him.
