webTitle: Interview: Naomi Klein

fields.headline: Look, no brands...
fields.standfirst:
Her surprise bestseller No Logo has propelled 30-year-old Naomi Klein to the forefront of the radical anti-corporate movement. But can boycotting Gap really change the world?

The globalisation debate - Observer special
fields.trailText: Naomi Klein interview: Her surprise bestseller No Logo has propelled 30-year-old Naomi Klein to the forefront of the radical anti-corporate movement. But can boycotting Gap really change the world?
fields.body:
Imagine a world designed by Disney, marketed by Nike, and described by Franz Kafka. When you wake up in this world, you think you are putting your clothes and shoes on, grabbing a coffee, getting in your car and filling it up with petrol; you think you are switching on your computer when you get to work and maybe having a cigarette or a soft drink at about 11. But you are sadly mistaken.

What you are actually doing is buying into a lifestyle, having a 'deep emotional connection' with fitness or coffee. Of course, the clothes, the car, etc. really exist, but the plane on which you are experiencing them is a higher one, of ideas and aspirations. And behind the scenes of this enclosed, almost sci-fi universe of concepts and intangibilities is another, horrific one, in which you are exploiting people in sweatshops as you put on your shoes, working them to their deaths, and you are supporting the murder of a Nobel Peace Prizewinner as you fill up your car. We are all already living in this world. And for many the only way out seems to be to listen to Naomi Klein.

Klein is the 30 year-old author of No Logo, a book which came out in Britain at the beginning of this year to rapturous reviews, and which has since developed a life of its own. It has been called a manifesto, 'the Das Kapital of the growing anti-corporate movement', and it set out to document the aims and rationale of the group that demonstrated at Seattle and Prague, before those events had even happened. Over the course of this year, No Logo has had a burgeoning, massive success, recommended by word of mouth; all over the world, people are sending loop emails to their friends, telling them how it has changed their life, how something they had felt but not understood has suddenly become clear. Klein now gives talks so often she jokes that she'll 'never write again', though she has a regular column in Canada's national newspaper, The Globe and Mail . This week she is in England, and speaking publicly every night. However, she rejects the idea that No Logo is a manifesto.

'There is no Das Kapital for the anti-corporate movement,' she says. 'One of the best things about this movement is that no one is handing down a manifesto from on high.' Klein is extremely articulate both in writing and in conversation, but even so, in order to understand her and understand what's going on, you have to be able to embrace anarchy, to see how the chaos is organised. None of the old rules apply, and this is instantly in evidence when we meet.

We have coffee at a private club in London, where Klein has been put up by her publisher. 'Are you part of this scene?' she whispers, still looking slightly dazed from last night's performance at the bar: Robbie Williams swanning around with paparazzi at his feet. 'No,' I mutter, 'I object to private clubs on principle.' She smiles sympathetically, and I interpret a tinge of pity for my unsophisticated view of left and right. As she makes clear in her book, we have to redefine our enemies, and, obviously, no one's going to change the world by not joining the Groucho Club.

Klein is poised. She has a soft, pretty face and a sweet, unstrident Canadian voice. She wears glasses some of the time, and can look studious or glamorous, very noticeable or usefully hidden. You can imagine her travelling the world for her book, interviewing sweatshop workers in South-east Asia and schoolchildren in Canada; but you can see just as easily that she is the person you've read, who knows her Marx and her Guy Debord, and the person you've seen on stage, voicing the beliefs of an international political movement.

No Logo is exhaustively researched - it's full of facts and figures, it contains tables and diagrams - but it's not dry. Klein illustrates points with her own experiences, and has conducted what must be hundreds of interviews. What the book does best, I think, is to conjure up a world view that seems paranoid but is in fact appropriately worried.

In the 1980s, Klein explains, there was a shift in focus from manufacturing to marketing. The goods themselves became unimportant, and branding was what mattered. As production moved to the Third World, thousands of jobs were lost in the First, and meanwhile, the power of the brand was unstoppable. In 1998, Coca-Cola ran a competition in American schools to see who could come up with the best marketing strategy for distributing Coke coupons: one school staged an official Coke day, and when a rebel turned up in a Pepsi T-shirt, he was suspended.

Klein quotes advertising executives, whose language is dizzyingly illogical: at Nike, for example, the product is nothing but 'the most important marketing tool'; Polaroid made the fatal marketing mistake of 'thinking they were a camera' (sic) - really, Polaroid is a 'social lubricant'. 'Products are made in the factory,' one adman says, 'but brands are made in the mind.'

It is this mind-play that is so frightening. Exploitation of workers in sweatshops is bad enough, but when big corporations are promoting a lifestyle, it is all the more horrendous that the 'lifestyle' of production, behind the branding curtain, is no life at all. And perhaps the canniest corporate technique is the appropriation of politically aware language. At Nike, Tiger Woods blares from billboards: 'There are still courses in the US where I am not allowed to play, because of the color of my skin'. The revolution of identity politics has come to serve capitalism: what better mask for corruption could there be than an apparent battle against corruption? Corporations, as the anti-corporate movement is saying, are more powerful than governments, and they can turn anything to their advantage.

For instance, 'culture jammers' replace billboard ads with scathing parodies of the same. 'A good jam,' Klein explains, 'is an X-ray of the subconscious of a campaign, uncovering not an opposite meaning but the deeper truth hiding beneath the layers of advertising euphemisms.'

But then the advertisers see these adaptations as good jokes in themselves, and in a nightmarishly post-modern move adopt the idiom of the culture jam for their own ends. Over time, it seems barely noticeable: what was Situationist in the Sixties is Absolut Vodka in the Nineties. Marketing continues to absorb its opposition, and, as one activist in the book puts it, 'this generation wants their brains back'.

Klein, however, tells me that 'this is not a youth movement. There's a great deal of co-operation going on - for instance, in the States, college-age students against sweatshops are working with labour leaders their parents' age. There isn't that vanguardist, don't-trust-anyone-over-30 bullshit that was so much a part of the Sixties'.

But although Klein claims that the movement is not about a generation, a large number of those who have found guidance in her book are of a particular age. Many of us now in our twenties and thirties feel left behind by the political movements of the past century, too late for everything. It's become a cliché to say that the Left has lost its way and that there is nothing to fight for. (Perhaps it's just that, as she puts it, 'it's a classic symptom of teenage narcissism to believe that the end of history coincides exactly with your arrival on Earth'.) Her book undoubtedly appeals to many more, but this is the group to whom it has given direction.

And Klein seems perfectly placed to offer answers, since the history of her family is like a history of the Left. Philip Klein, her grandfather, was an animator at Disney, and organised the first strike there, as a result of which he was sacked and blacklisted. He taught her to 'always look for the dirt behind the shine'. Her parents left the United States in protest against the Vietnam war, and Naomi grew up in Canada, a child enamoured of the shiny symbols of capitalism: Barbie, Shell, McDonald's. Her mother made a controversial and influential documentary in 1980 called Not A Love Story, an anti-porn film about the life of a stripper. The backlash, or just the ordinary course, of her teenage life was to love the brands.

But now, she says, 'what we're finding out is that our parents raised a bunch of really radical kids'. Although she says she can see a line, or rather many lines, from then to now, this movement is not inherited in quite the way the family story implies. 'You know,' she tells me, 'I object to any characterisation of this movement as somehow emerging from scratch. But I also equally object to characterisations that it's just the same old thing - you know, the Socialist Workers Party line, which is sort of, "finally, the kids have realised the revolution is nigh".'

This movement (it is usually just 'this movement', without a longer name) is, Klein says, 'reserving the right to come up with solutions that are new. And that basically means taking a little bit from Marxism, a little bit from socialism, from environmentalism, from anarchism, and also a lot of inspiration is coming from even older places, and more indigenous theories about self-determination.

'For example, the Zapatistas in Chiapas [Mexico] have been a real source of inspiration. But people often compare the movement to the Sixties, and I think that's not the right comparison - I think a much more interesting and appropriate parallel is with the Thirties, when there was a cross-generational, cross-sectoral, strong coalition.

'The difference between then and now is that this is happening at a time of great prosperity. So I think it's somewhere in the middle,' she concludes. 'This is part of a history, but it is new, and the reason I think it's new is that I don't think it has articulated yet where it's going to go.'

The unarticulated aims of the movement are, surely, what leaves it open to criticism, though? Klein responds by referring to the World Bank and the IMF: 'One thing to say to that is that an extraordinarily coherent vision can be really dangerous, and people get so attached to it and seduced by it that they force the world into it. And the other thing is that some of the people who have criticised this movement from the left don't remember how disorganised they were in their heyday.'

When Klein wrote No Logo , she wasn't sure what the issues she was writing about would turn into. Now she is being hailed as a prophet. 'I wrote the book because I thought there was a movement, but it was an act of faith - I wanted there to be, but I knew at every stage that I could very well be wrong, that these little pockets that I was following could just be that. So I was surprised by Seattle - I'm constantly surprised. I was surprised that despite 11,000 police officers in Prague, protesters still made it into the conference centre and danced on the walls!'

Things have changed since then, and she has clear views on what should be done next. 'I do a lot of speaking on university campuses and at activist gatherings and what I find now is that there is an amazing consensus - that we had the mass demonstrations, we've proved we exist, and in some ways we got a little bit ahead of ourselves, and this is a moment to take a step back and do some of that communications work and theoretical work. Which doesn't mean writing a movement manifesto that everybody's going to agree to. It means identifying what the core shared beliefs are across borders, and then organising it based on that.

'I believe that the most fundamental core belief of this movement is self-determination, which actually means that the whole idea of coming up with a one-size-fits-all theory of how to run the world is completely antithetical to the process. So what you do is you think about mechanisms for real self-determination to take place.

'You know, we hear about the militancy of Seattle or Prague but there's also a wave of direct action in native communities all over the place. Not just Chiapas, but where - rather than seeing their natural resources being depleted by logging companies or commercial fisheries - people are taking it into their own hands and creating blockades. It's happening more and more, and it's part of the same process of reclaiming things.'

It's interesting to see the way Klein says 'we' when she refers to the movement. When she wrote her book, she set out to document something, and yet it has been received as a call to arms by those who were ready for one. What exactly is her relationship with her subject, I wonder?

'Well,' she reflects, 'I do think it's strange that sometimes people call it a manifesto, because it's not. But I didn't do it purely as an act of journalism. I did it knowing how I'd become involved in it. I did understand my own relationship to politics, which is that the thing that sways me most is argument. I wanted it to be a journey where at the end you would be onside, and you would think it was inevitable.'

The evening after our conversation, Klein gives a talk at a meeting of the World Development Movement, to launch the campaign against Gats (the General Agreement on Trade in Services), an agreement of the World Trade Organisation; 1,000 people are in attendance, and more than a hundred others are turned away. She speaks with great lucidity about how they should not see themselves as anti-trade, only as against the damaging conditions and strings attached to trade. She refers to the movement's roots in colonialism and resistance, and comes back, again and again, to the concept of self-determination. No jargon is resorted to, no issues are fudged.

At one point, a Bolivian woman stands up to ask a question. 'Our services have been privatised.' she says. 'Is a riot enough to get our water back?' Klein looks straight at her and leans into the mike. 'No. It's not enough,' she admits, and offers other strategies for getting organised. 'Can we agree on what we're for?' Klein finally asks. 'How can we move from symbolic victories to deeper, more long-lasting change?'

Over the course of the evening it becomes clear that Klein can and has made a difference because she is commentator, activist, and guide all at once. 'Our task is not to create a movement from scratch,' she proclaims to a rapt audience. 'Our task is to recognise the movement we already have.'

Like the good witch in the Wizard of Oz who tells Dorothy that, in the form of ruby slippers, she has been wearing the means to her end all along, Klein is a prophet who sees the present. She just sees it better than anyone else.

 Naomi Klein will be speaking at the V&A in London today. For tickets call 020 7942 2209. To order No Logo at the special price of £11.99 plus 99p p&p, call 0800 3168 171.

ANTI-CORPORATE MCNUGGETS (FIVE THINGS THE MOVEMENT IS AGAINST)

1 The conquest of cool by big business (Richard Branson, Bill Gates and other rock'n'roll billionaires).

2 Branding, advertising and marketing (the triumph of concept over product).

3 Charles Handy, Tom Peters and all other business school gurus who preach downsizing and outsourcing.

4 The exploitation of Third World labour by groovy capitalists who pretend they're 'concerned'.

5 Anita Roddick.
fields.bodyText: Imagine a world designed by Disney, marketed by Nike, and described by Franz Kafka. When you wake up in this world, you think you are putting your clothes and shoes on, grabbing a coffee, getting in your car and filling it up with petrol; you think you are switching on your computer when you get to work and maybe having a cigarette or a soft drink at about 11. But you are sadly mistaken. What you are actually doing is buying into a lifestyle, having a 'deep emotional connection' with fitness or coffee. Of course, the clothes, the car, etc. really exist, but the plane on which you are experiencing them is a higher one, of ideas and aspirations. And behind the scenes of this enclosed, almost sci-fi universe of concepts and intangibilities is another, horrific one, in which you are exploiting people in sweatshops as you put on your shoes, working them to their deaths, and you are supporting the murder of a Nobel Peace Prizewinner as you fill up your car. We are all already living in this world. And for many the only way out seems to be to listen to Naomi Klein. Klein is the 30 year-old author of No Logo, a book which came out in Britain at the beginning of this year to rapturous reviews, and which has since developed a life of its own. It has been called a manifesto, 'the Das Kapital of the growing anti-corporate movement', and it set out to document the aims and rationale of the group that demonstrated at Seattle and Prague, before those events had even happened. Over the course of this year, No Logo has had a burgeoning, massive success, recommended by word of mouth; all over the world, people are sending loop emails to their friends, telling them how it has changed their life, how something they had felt but not understood has suddenly become clear. Klein now gives talks so often she jokes that she'll 'never write again', though she has a regular column in Canada's national newspaper, The Globe and Mail . This week she is in England, and speaking publicly every night. However, she rejects the idea that No Logo is a manifesto. 'There is no Das Kapital for the anti-corporate movement,' she says. 'One of the best things about this movement is that no one is handing down a manifesto from on high.' Klein is extremely articulate both in writing and in conversation, but even so, in order to understand her and understand what's going on, you have to be able to embrace anarchy, to see how the chaos is organised. None of the old rules apply, and this is instantly in evidence when we meet. We have coffee at a private club in London, where Klein has been put up by her publisher. 'Are you part of this scene?' she whispers, still looking slightly dazed from last night's performance at the bar: Robbie Williams swanning around with paparazzi at his feet. 'No,' I mutter, 'I object to private clubs on principle.' She smiles sympathetically, and I interpret a tinge of pity for my unsophisticated view of left and right. As she makes clear in her book, we have to redefine our enemies, and, obviously, no one's going to change the world by not joining the Groucho Club. Klein is poised. She has a soft, pretty face and a sweet, unstrident Canadian voice. She wears glasses some of the time, and can look studious or glamorous, very noticeable or usefully hidden. You can imagine her travelling the world for her book, interviewing sweatshop workers in South-east Asia and schoolchildren in Canada; but you can see just as easily that she is the person you've read, who knows her Marx and her Guy Debord, and the person you've seen on stage, voicing the beliefs of an international political movement. No Logo is exhaustively researched - it's full of facts and figures, it contains tables and diagrams - but it's not dry. Klein illustrates points with her own experiences, and has conducted what must be hundreds of interviews. What the book does best, I think, is to conjure up a world view that seems paranoid but is in fact appropriately worried. In the 1980s, Klein explains, there was a shift in focus from manufacturing to marketing. The goods themselves became unimportant, and branding was what mattered. As production moved to the Third World, thousands of jobs were lost in the First, and meanwhile, the power of the brand was unstoppable. In 1998, Coca-Cola ran a competition in American schools to see who could come up with the best marketing strategy for distributing Coke coupons: one school staged an official Coke day, and when a rebel turned up in a Pepsi T-shirt, he was suspended. Klein quotes advertising executives, whose language is dizzyingly illogical: at Nike, for example, the product is nothing but 'the most important marketing tool'; Polaroid made the fatal marketing mistake of 'thinking they were a camera' (sic) - really, Polaroid is a 'social lubricant'. 'Products are made in the factory,' one adman says, 'but brands are made in the mind.' It is this mind-play that is so frightening. Exploitation of workers in sweatshops is bad enough, but when big corporations are promoting a lifestyle, it is all the more horrendous that the 'lifestyle' of production, behind the branding curtain, is no life at all. And perhaps the canniest corporate technique is the appropriation of politically aware language. At Nike, Tiger Woods blares from billboards: 'There are still courses in the US where I am not allowed to play, because of the color of my skin'. The revolution of identity politics has come to serve capitalism: what better mask for corruption could there be than an apparent battle against corruption? Corporations, as the anti-corporate movement is saying, are more powerful than governments, and they can turn anything to their advantage. For instance, 'culture jammers' replace billboard ads with scathing parodies of the same. 'A good jam,' Klein explains, 'is an X-ray of the subconscious of a campaign, uncovering not an opposite meaning but the deeper truth hiding beneath the layers of advertising euphemisms.' But then the advertisers see these adaptations as good jokes in themselves, and in a nightmarishly post-modern move adopt the idiom of the culture jam for their own ends. Over time, it seems barely noticeable: what was Situationist in the Sixties is Absolut Vodka in the Nineties. Marketing continues to absorb its opposition, and, as one activist in the book puts it, 'this generation wants their brains back'. Klein, however, tells me that 'this is not a youth movement. There's a great deal of co-operation going on - for instance, in the States, college-age students against sweatshops are working with labour leaders their parents' age. There isn't that vanguardist, don't-trust-anyone-over-30 bullshit that was so much a part of the Sixties'. But although Klein claims that the movement is not about a generation, a large number of those who have found guidance in her book are of a particular age. Many of us now in our twenties and thirties feel left behind by the political movements of the past century, too late for everything. It's become a cliché to say that the Left has lost its way and that there is nothing to fight for. (Perhaps it's just that, as she puts it, 'it's a classic symptom of teenage narcissism to believe that the end of history coincides exactly with your arrival on Earth'.) Her book undoubtedly appeals to many more, but this is the group to whom it has given direction. And Klein seems perfectly placed to offer answers, since the history of her family is like a history of the Left. Philip Klein, her grandfather, was an animator at Disney, and organised the first strike there, as a result of which he was sacked and blacklisted. He taught her to 'always look for the dirt behind the shine'. Her parents left the United States in protest against the Vietnam war, and Naomi grew up in Canada, a child enamoured of the shiny symbols of capitalism: Barbie, Shell, McDonald's. Her mother made a controversial and influential documentary in 1980 called Not A Love Story, an anti-porn film about the life of a stripper. The backlash, or just the ordinary course, of her teenage life was to love the brands. But now, she says, 'what we're finding out is that our parents raised a bunch of really radical kids'. Although she says she can see a line, or rather many lines, from then to now, this movement is not inherited in quite the way the family story implies. 'You know,' she tells me, 'I object to any characterisation of this movement as somehow emerging from scratch. But I also equally object to characterisations that it's just the same old thing - you know, the Socialist Workers Party line, which is sort of, "finally, the kids have realised the revolution is nigh".' This movement (it is usually just 'this movement', without a longer name) is, Klein says, 'reserving the right to come up with solutions that are new. And that basically means taking a little bit from Marxism, a little bit from socialism, from environmentalism, from anarchism, and also a lot of inspiration is coming from even older places, and more indigenous theories about self-determination. 'For example, the Zapatistas in Chiapas [Mexico] have been a real source of inspiration. But people often compare the movement to the Sixties, and I think that's not the right comparison - I think a much more interesting and appropriate parallel is with the Thirties, when there was a cross-generational, cross-sectoral, strong coalition. 'The difference between then and now is that this is happening at a time of great prosperity. So I think it's somewhere in the middle,' she concludes. 'This is part of a history, but it is new, and the reason I think it's new is that I don't think it has articulated yet where it's going to go.' The unarticulated aims of the movement are, surely, what leaves it open to criticism, though? Klein responds by referring to the World Bank and the IMF: 'One thing to say to that is that an extraordinarily coherent vision can be really dangerous, and people get so attached to it and seduced by it that they force the world into it. And the other thing is that some of the people who have criticised this movement from the left don't remember how disorganised they were in their heyday.' When Klein wrote No Logo , she wasn't sure what the issues she was writing about would turn into. Now she is being hailed as a prophet. 'I wrote the book because I thought there was a movement, but it was an act of faith - I wanted there to be, but I knew at every stage that I could very well be wrong, that these little pockets that I was following could just be that. So I was surprised by Seattle - I'm constantly surprised. I was surprised that despite 11,000 police officers in Prague, protesters still made it into the conference centre and danced on the walls!' Things have changed since then, and she has clear views on what should be done next. 'I do a lot of speaking on university campuses and at activist gatherings and what I find now is that there is an amazing consensus - that we had the mass demonstrations, we've proved we exist, and in some ways we got a little bit ahead of ourselves, and this is a moment to take a step back and do some of that communications work and theoretical work. Which doesn't mean writing a movement manifesto that everybody's going to agree to. It means identifying what the core shared beliefs are across borders, and then organising it based on that. 'I believe that the most fundamental core belief of this movement is self-determination, which actually means that the whole idea of coming up with a one-size-fits-all theory of how to run the world is completely antithetical to the process. So what you do is you think about mechanisms for real self-determination to take place. 'You know, we hear about the militancy of Seattle or Prague but there's also a wave of direct action in native communities all over the place. Not just Chiapas, but where - rather than seeing their natural resources being depleted by logging companies or commercial fisheries - people are taking it into their own hands and creating blockades. It's happening more and more, and it's part of the same process of reclaiming things.' It's interesting to see the way Klein says 'we' when she refers to the movement. When she wrote her book, she set out to document something, and yet it has been received as a call to arms by those who were ready for one. What exactly is her relationship with her subject, I wonder? 'Well,' she reflects, 'I do think it's strange that sometimes people call it a manifesto, because it's not. But I didn't do it purely as an act of journalism. I did it knowing how I'd become involved in it. I did understand my own relationship to politics, which is that the thing that sways me most is argument. I wanted it to be a journey where at the end you would be onside, and you would think it was inevitable.' The evening after our conversation, Klein gives a talk at a meeting of the World Development Movement, to launch the campaign against Gats (the General Agreement on Trade in Services), an agreement of the World Trade Organisation; 1,000 people are in attendance, and more than a hundred others are turned away. She speaks with great lucidity about how they should not see themselves as anti-trade, only as against the damaging conditions and strings attached to trade. She refers to the movement's roots in colonialism and resistance, and comes back, again and again, to the concept of self-determination. No jargon is resorted to, no issues are fudged. At one point, a Bolivian woman stands up to ask a question. 'Our services have been privatised.' she says. 'Is a riot enough to get our water back?' Klein looks straight at her and leans into the mike. 'No. It's not enough,' she admits, and offers other strategies for getting organised. 'Can we agree on what we're for?' Klein finally asks. 'How can we move from symbolic victories to deeper, more long-lasting change?' Over the course of the evening it becomes clear that Klein can and has made a difference because she is commentator, activist, and guide all at once. 'Our task is not to create a movement from scratch,' she proclaims to a rapt audience. 'Our task is to recognise the movement we already have.' Like the good witch in the Wizard of Oz who tells Dorothy that, in the form of ruby slippers, she has been wearing the means to her end all along, Klein is a prophet who sees the present. She just sees it better than anyone else.  Naomi Klein will be speaking at the V&A in London today. For tickets call 020 7942 2209. webTitle: Review: Moral muse: Margaret Cook

fields.headline: Should I give up work to have a baby?
fields.standfirst: Moral muse: Margaret Cook
fields.trailText: Moral muse: Margaret Cook
fields.body:
My partner and I have a three-year-old daughter and he wants another baby. As I only work part-time, the cost of childcare would exceed my earnings. He is happy to compensate me, and I would not find it hard to live without my career. The dilemma I have is becoming financially dependent on somebody else. Should I give up my independence for the sake of my family?

E.H. of Cambridgeshire

It is an interesting comment on the attitudes of the times that you should assume the cost of childcare is rightfully and exclusively yours. Though you are not married to your partner, he still shares in the creation of, and therefore responsibility for, your children. How generous to offer to compensate you!

Yet I believe your instincts are justified, to avoid becoming financially dependent on a man who presumably does not feel his family necessitates permanent ties, or even some gesture of intent. In any case, marriage certificates these days are barely worth the paper they are printed on.

Giving up your job will make you vulnerable in more ways than just a pecuniary one. My opinion on this issue is understandably a biased one, having been abandoned by a high-flying spouse when it suited him. The many supportive letters I received from women similarly placed drove the message home that a traditional non-working wife and mother, dependent on a male breadwinner, is tragically exposed. So many of my correspondents had no career, no skills, none of the self-confidence that comes with these things, no circle of personal friends, no income and often no home. And no voice that could be heard by anyone empowered to help.

If I had a daughter I would encourage her with all my powers of persuasion not to lean too heavily on a man, no matter how much she loved him. These days, with nearly half of all marriages coming to an untimely end, all women should be capable of going it alone, most especially when they have dependent children.

If I have reinforced your misgivings, so much the better. Why not consider expanding the work you do to a full-time job, when you might find it easier to afford childcare? There is plenty of evidence now that benign separation of child from mother does no harm and may even be beneficial. Provided you are in overall control as their chief carer, available at each end of the day, weekends, holiday times and periods of illness, and that the mother-substitute is appropriate, the children will not be disadvantaged. Maybe your laconic lover might help too.

I'm not sure whether this thought ought to be brought into the equation, but some men get twitchy if they see their responsibilities piling up. He may be more likely to stay if he sees your determination to be independent.

Reader's response

Be as sure as you possibly can before taking such an important decision. It can be a huge step to move into what could be a more confin ing relationship with no outside job. It sounds as if the impact of childcare will fall squarely upon you and that may be why your partner is keener. Share your anxieties with him because you need emotional support as much as financial support.

N.G. of Swindon

Next week's problem

My fiancé has always had a problem snoring but recently it has become worse. It is making my life a misery. He is not overweight but he does smoke and refuses to give up or go to the doctor to seek help. Consequently I often sleep in the spare room. We are due to be married next year and I don't feel it is a good way to start married life.

webTitle: My fears over getting to work late

fields.headline: My fears over getting to work late
fields.standfirst:
Agony Aunt: Neasa MacErlean

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Agony Aunt: Neasa MacErlean
fields.body:
I have been arriving late at work over the past few weeks for the same reason as everyone else - the flooding and the delays on the trains. No one at work has made an issue out of it but I am conscious that I have only been working 3 or 4 hours some days instead of the seven that I am meant to do. Could our employers start docking our pay if the transport problems continue?

Your employers would be within their rights to dock your pay. If you cannot do your job then your employer could reduce your pay or even terminate your contract.

However, very few employers will want to do this. It is not just that they realise that such treatment would damage the working relationship with all employees. They could also be left with very few employees if they started docking their pay or sacking them - and the senior management, who are equally affected by delayed trains and flooded roads, would also have to take a tough line with themselves.

The people who might really suffer, however, are those who are paid by the hour. A company may feel little moral obligation to help the temp stuck in a train.

 Legal advice from Hammond Suddards Edge.

webTitle: Work: Simon Caulkin on art

fields.headline: Arts for art's - and business's - sake
fields.standfirst:
Management: Now more than ever, the UK needs to draw on the cultural side of life, argues Simon Caulkin

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Management: Now more than ever, the UK needs to draw on the cultural side of life, argues Simon Caulkin.
fields.body:
In the furore about the dumbing-down of the UK, one aspect that hasn't had enough attention is its effect on business. It is commonly agreed that the shortcomings of the UK's schooling system are reflected in its poor economic and managerial performance. But the situation is no better higher up the learning scale. All the country's colleges and universities face a crisis of morale, funding and - increasingly - staffing, as real budgets are relentlessly cut and pressures to raise student numbers intensify.

Particularly dispirited are humanities departments, bludgeoned week by week about becoming more vocational and less 'academic'. Another telling cultural indicator is UK language learning: never a strong suit, it has recently fallen to new lows. Just 13,000 students took French A-level this year and, in schools and universities, German as a subject hardly exists.

The UK's cultural institutions are similarly misprized. According to a recent report, the UK spends just over £1 billion every year on the arts - around 0.15 per cent of GDP - including Lottery money. France spends twice as much. There are huge disparities in almost every area. Even in private-sector sponsorship, where the UK likes to think it is a leader, France is more generous: in 1998, French companies spent £125 mil lion on the arts, compared with £115m spent by their UK counterparts.

Does this matter? Should businesses give a toss (as it were) about Tracey Emin's soiled sheets, whether the Royal Court can put on experimental plays, the state of Shakespeare studies? The answer is yes - a more resounding yes than they think. Management's greatest commentator and philosopher, Peter Drucker, maintains that management is a liberal art - a humanity, not a science. It is primarily about people, and advancing the art of management (making better decisions) is not a matter of more number crunching, as IT companies would have firms believe, but of amplifying human effort and imagination to solve dilemmas, turn problems into opportunities and make sense of complex issues.

That requires creativity of a special kind. Wealth creation emerges from finding inventive ways to reconcile apparent opposites - mass appeal and customisation, quality and price leadership, speed and safety. To adapt the poet William Empson: business involves maintaining oneself between contradictions that can't be solved by analysis.

Scientific research and development is part of this dynamic. (The UK is bad at that, too, notoriously lagging European and US rivals in research spending across almost every industry except pharmaceuticals.) But that's hard, logical, left-brain stuff. Even more important, to succeed in the new economy business needs to kickstart its dismally atrophied, imaginative, right brain.

The creative arts have something that business craves: imagination. The information economy is an abstract economy, where words, ideas and symbols do the heavy lifting, not machinery. In a striking reversal of roles, the regeneration of a run-down area may in the new economy depend more on the buzz in the coffee bars, theatres and concert halls than on industrial infrastructure. Take the London borough of Southwark, neglected and decrepit for years: its new-found trendiness has been achieved courtesy not of inward commercial investment but of Messrs Shakespeare (the Globe theatre), Picasso and Matisse (Tate Modern).

Companies, too, are ripe for emotional regeneration. Piers Ibbotson, a director of the Royal Shakespeare Company who has done theatre-based consultancy work with several firms, argues that the century-long attempt of managers to make organisations fit a scientific metaphor is to blame for today's diminished corporate sperm count. Science, he says, is a crippling model to impose on emotional, contradictory, diverse people, and the attempt to graft creativity on to this unpromising rootstock is as hopeless as a jumbled metaphor - a recipe for dismal science and worse art.

Meanwhile, he says, managers are perversely ignoring what the arts can offer: a massive treasure trove of case studies on the human relationships and moral trade-offs that make up the raw material of business.

Some companies are getting the message, however. Firms as diverse as McKinsey, WPP, Dell Computer and Diageo have used theatre and other arts events to build teams and stir the embers of imagination. Others use orchestras to get the juices flowing. Shakespeare's tragedies have proved a rich source of case studies about pride, greed and ambition to discuss as business dilemmas with senior executives.

In this context, companies should be as worried about the UK's impoverished culture as any struggling theatre troupe or starving poet. They should be worried, for instance, that in a knowledge-based, ideas-driven economy British colleges and universities (like the rest of the public sector) are perversely being frogmarched back into an earlier age of bureaucratic, numbers-driven management and their energies channelled from building precious intellectual capital to competing with each other to climb arbi trary league tables. Far from being a source of radical new ideas, they are in danger of becoming a creative desert.

They should also be concerned at the UK's appalling ignorance of other languages. The pervasiveness of English as a business language is a long-term weakness masquerading as a strength. Languages, George Steiner once pointed out, provide different windows on the world. Like eyes, one gives vision, but two add perspective. Already those who speak English as a second language outnumber native speakers. Soon everyone in the world except Anglophones will speak at least two languages - and have two sets of ideas and cultural resources to draw on.

The arts and business are another pair of opposites that urgently require reconciling. Instead of occupying different compartments (or planets, as it has sometimes appeared), they are part of the same continuum. Culture isn't a luxury to be paid for - or not - out of business profits; business needs the arts as much as the arts need business, and the strength or weakness of one is reflected in the other. As another poet put it 400 years ago: 'No man is an island, entire of itself. Every man is a part of the continent, a piece of the main.' If the bell tolls for culture, it tolls for business, too.

(The UK is bad at that, too, notoriously lagging European and US rivals in research spending across almost every industry except pharmaceuticals.) But that's hard, logical, left-brain stuff. Even more important, to succeed in the new economy business needs to kickstart its dismally atrophied, imaginative, right brain. The creative arts have something that business craves: imagination. The information economy is an abstract economy, where words, ideas and symbols do the heavy lifting, not machinery. In a striking reversal of roles, the regeneration of a run-down area may in the new economy depend more on the buzz in the coffee bars, theatres and concert halls than on industrial infrastructure. Take the London borough of Southwark, neglected and decrepit for years: its new-found trendiness has been achieved courtesy not of inward commercial investment but of Messrs Shakespeare (the Globe theatre), Picasso and Matisse (Tate Modern). Companies, too, are ripe for emotional regeneration. Piers Ibbotson, a director of the Royal Shakespeare Company who has done theatre-based consultancy work with several firms, argues that the century-long attempt of managers to make organisations fit a scientific metaphor is to blame for today's diminished corporate sperm count. Science, he says, is a crippling model to impose on emotional, contradictory, diverse people, and the attempt to graft creativity on to this unpromising rootstock is as hopeless as a jumbled metaphor - a recipe for dismal science and worse art. Meanwhile, he says, managers are perversely ignoring what the arts can offer: a massive treasure trove of case studies on the human relationships and moral trade-offs that make up the raw material of business. Some companies are getting the message, however. Firms as diverse as McKinsey, WPP, Dell Computer and Diageo have used theatre and other arts events to build teams and stir the embers of imagination. Others use orchestras to get the juices flowing. Shakespeare's tragedies have proved a rich source of case studies about pride, greed and ambition to discuss as business dilemmas with senior executives. In this context, companies should be as worried about the UK's impoverished culture as any struggling theatre troupe or starving poet. They should be worried, for instance, that in a knowledge-based, ideas-driven economy British colleges and universities (like the rest of the public sector) are perversely being frogmarched back into an earlier age of bureaucratic, numbers-driven management and their energies channelled from building precious intellectual capital to competing with each other to climb arbi trary league tables. Far from being a source of radical new ideas, they are in danger of becoming a creative desert. They should also be concerned at the UK's appalling ignorance of other languages. The pervasiveness of English as a business language is a long-term weakness masquerading as a strength. Languages, George Steiner once pointed out, provide different windows on the world. Like eyes, one gives vision, but two add perspective. Already those who speak English as a second language outnumber native speakers. Soon everyone in the world except Anglophones will speak at least two languages - and have two sets of ideas and cultural resources to draw on. The arts and business are another pair of opposites that urgently require reconciling. Instead of occupying different compartments (or planets, as it has sometimes appeared), they are part of the same continuum. Culture isn't a luxury to be paid for - or not - out of business profits; business needs the arts as much as the arts need business, and the strength or weakness of one is reflected in the other. As another poet put it 400 years ago: 'No man is an island, entire of itself. Every man is a part of the continent, a piece of the main.' If the bell tolls for culture, it tolls for business, too. simon.caulkin@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Housing associations may help you onto the property ladder

fields.headline: Ray of hope for those off the ladder
fields.standfirst: Help is at hand, says  Tracey Boles
fields.trailText: If you despair of ever getting your foot on the property ladder, housing associations may be able to give you a leg up.
fields.body:
If you despair of ever getting your foot on the property ladder, housing associations may be able to give you a leg up.

They offer shared ownership schemes for anyone unable to afford a suitable home on the open market - as many as 25 per cent of us. And they will be pivotal in providing affordable housing through the Government's new initiative to help key workers who have been priced out of the market.

However, demand for housing association accommodation still outstrips supply so you may have to wait for up to a year. In 72 per cent of counties outside London, you need a salary of more than £20,000 to buy an average house, according to National Housing Federation research.

In London the problem is worse. The cheapest borough is Barking and Dagenham, where you need to be earning more than £22,000 before you can think about buying. The most expensive borough is Kensington & Chelsea, where you have to be bringing home £106,240 to buy.

The Government has grown so concerned at the inability of key workers such as teachers and nurses to afford accommodation that it has proposed the starter home initiative to subsidise the purchase of homes.

The initiative may use existing schemes run by housing associations. These are independent, non-profit-making organisations that provide homes intended to be affordable, both to rent and to buy.

There are three shared ownership schemes: traditional shared ownership, homebuy and DIY share ownership, which is being phased out.

Traditional shared ownership involves buying 50 per cent of the property and renting the other 50 per cent from the association at a discounted rate. The buyer is able to increase the share owned as time progresses. These homes tend to be new and built by the association. You can sell them back to the association or on the open market if you move.

Homebuy is where you raise a mortgage worth 75 per cent of a property's value. The association pays the rest. DIY shared ownership entails buying a share of a property that is on the open market.

To join a scheme, you should contact your local authority housing department, which can advise you on schemes in your area. Most housing association tenants are plucked from council housing lists but you can apply direct and anyone can join the lists.

London-based housing association Metropolitan says it gives priority to council and housing association tenants who want to move out of rented homes. But it says it will also welcome applications from first-time buyers, people living with parents or relatives, those living in private rented accommodation and people who need to move for work.

You will need to able to cover some start-up costs such as legal fees and also the subsequent payments.

You could be in for a long wait. The Chartered Institute of Housing warns there is still a big difference between supply and demand in East Anglia, the South East, and parts of the South West. The problem is resources. Housing associations can only build 29,000 homes a year.

John Curry, of the Chartered Institute of Housing, says: 'The starter initiative is going to help but not solve the problem - only £250m has been earmarked for it over the next three years.'

The latest proposals about how the initiative will operate will be unveiled in the next month.

Find London housing associations on www.lhog.co.uk.

webTitle: Will pension credit help the aged?

fields.headline: Will pension credit help the aged?
fields.standfirst:
Critics say new system is confusing, and may prove difficult to administer. Maria Scott reports
Special report: the Budget
fields.trailText: Critics say new system is confusing, and may prove difficult to administer. Maria Scott reports.
fields.body:
The state pensions system will change almost beyond recognition if the proposals announced last week are implemented.

Measures sketched out by Ministers have the potential to improve living standards for many pensioners. But the package is fiendishly complex and will leave many of those it is designed to help bewildered. Much of the success of the new system will rely on pensioners' claiming what is due to them under the new system.

The Government is promising a new dedicated pensions office to administer a key element of the new system, and automatic calculations for pensioners as they retire. But a spokeswoman for Help the Aged pointed out: 'There has been so much confusion already [over pension calculations] and the computers are not reliable. We want to be sure the infrastructure will deliver.'

Age Concern is disappointed that there is no commitment by the Government to regularly review the amounts pensioners need to live on. A spokeswoman added that pensions will remain at the mercy of political whim and economic circumstances.

Last week's announcements have implications for younger people as well as today's pensioners.

The changes will ensure that the basic state pension, a non-means-tested benefit available to everyone with a relatively stable record of National Insurance contributions, will play an ever-smaller role in providing retirement income in the future. Increasingly, the basic state pension will be supplemented by means-tested top-ups.

Young and middle-aged people should be under no illusion that last week's concessions to pensioners, angry at the paltry recent rises in the state pensions, will create a system that takes the pressure off individuals to save privately for retirement.

In 2003, when the new Pension Credit is introduced as the centrepiece of long-term reform - assuming, of course, that the Labour Party wins a second term in office - the state will offer two types of top-up to the basic state pension.

The first will provide a minimum income, as is the case now, based on means testing. The aim will be to ensure that no single person has an income below £100 a week in 2003 (£5,200 a year), and no couple will have less than £154 a week (£8008 a year).

Those without savings or private pensions will receive no further state income, although they will usually be entitled to other state help, such as housing benefit.

The second top-up will come from the new Pension Credit, for pensioners with savings. But even so, there will be no extra state money for those with incomes of more than £135 a week (£7,020 a year). For couples, the cut-off level for state assistance will be £201 a week, or £10,452.

Many pensioners are now denied means-tested supplements to their basic pensions because they have modest private incomes. They may be only a couple of pounds better off than a neighbour supported entirely by the state who has saved nothing.

For those who qualify for Pensions Credit, every £1 of savings will earn a credit of 60p. Pensioners' entitlement will not be affected by the amount of capital they have; the capital limits that govern today's means testing will be abolished. Nor will the Government assume - as it does now when means testing - that pensioners' savings earn 20 per cent interest. However, it has not yet been decided how pensioners' income from savings will be calculated.

Under the new Pension Credit, a single man on the basic state pension of £77, the level projected by the Government for 2003, plus £20 from part-time work, will have an income of £97 a week. The Government will top this up to £100, its minimum income guarantee. The pensioner will then receive an extra £12 from the pension credit (20 x 60p), so his total income will be £112 a week.

A single woman on the basic state pension receiving £23 a week from a former employer, would already have a large enough income to meet the Government's £100 minimum income level. But she would receive a top-up because of her private pension. This would work out at £13.80 a week (23 x 60p).

The new system will continue to require that pensioners claim for top-ups to the basic state pension.

To help pensioners before the introduction of the new system, the Government is planning a series of significant increases to the basic state pension and the minimum income guarantee.

Copies of the Government's paper on the Pension Credit are available by calling 020 8867 3201. The paper is also available on the internet at www.dss.gov.uk.

webTitle: Tax bonanza for Isa investors

fields.headline: Tax bonanza for Isa investors
fields.standfirst:
Jill Insley looks at changes that will help savers
Special report: the Budget
fields.trailText: Jill Insley looks at changes that will help savers.
fields.body:
Investors are expected to save hundreds of millions of pounds in tax and will be able to manage their savings more easily following changes to individual savings account rules announced in the Pre-Budget Report.

The extension of the current £7,000 Isa contribution limit, including the £3,000 cash allowance, for a further five years until April 2006 will cost the Exchequer £20 million in the first year, rising to £275m a year after six years.

The total investment limit was due to fall to £5,000 from next April, with the limit on cash savings dropping from £3,000 to just £1,000. Savers will particularly welcome the extension of the current £3,000 maximum limit for cash savings. Cash Isas have proved the most popular form of tax-free saving, with more than £4.72 billion invested in the first quarter of the 2000-01 tax year alone.

Young people aged 16 and 17 will be also able to invest up to £3,000 in a cash Isa from 6 April next year. Economic secretary Melanie Johnson said this would enable 100,000 under-18s who work and pay tax to benefit from tax-free savings.

However, this will not enable parents to avoid tax by giving money to their children to invest. Children who are given sufficient money to earn more than £100 a year in income or interest will have the investment income taxed at their parents' highest rate.

The Chancellor has also made it easier for about 5.5 million investors to manage their stocks and shares Isas alongside their personal equity plans by applying the same rules on investment, transfers and administrative procedures to both types of scheme from 6 April next year.

This ends the distinction between single-company Peps, which could hold the shares of just one company, and general Peps, which could hold a wide variety of investments.

The 'non-qualifying' Pep rule, which prevented people transferring more than 25 per cent of their Pep investments into funds mainly invested outside the European Union, is also being abolished. People who have invested for several years in a row with the same Pep provider may also benefit from being allowed to make part-transfers of Peps for the first time.

webTitle: Work: Career decisions start at a tender age

fields.headline: I like ER. I'll be a doctor
fields.standfirst:
Career decisions start at a tender age, reports Caroline Palmer

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Career decisions start at a tender age, reports Caroline Palmer.
fields.body:
The extra £177 million pledged by the Government to expand the careers service for 13-to-19-year-olds may be very laudable. But if it really is to help young people into a job they enjoy, rather than just getting them into employment, it will have to take on board research on the factors that influence how we choose our careers. Recent studies show that British workers do not score very highly in European league tables on job satisfaction.

Education Secretary David Blunkett's new initiative, Connexions, will start to take shape next April when 16 partnerships will be funded to run the service, available to all young people in England.

Malcolm Wicks, the minister for lifelong learning, says: 'The choices teenagers make clearly affect the rest of their lives. They need all possible help and support to make the most of their opportunities. It is simply not good enough that one in 11 young people is not in work or in education.'

Yet while this is certainly the case, the process of deciding what job to do and the factors that lead us into our chosen fields are very complex.

And research carried out at Southampton University indicates that children should be helped from a much younger age. Once people have reached their teens many doors have already closed.

Professor Nick Foskett, director of the Centre for Research in Education Marketing at Southampton University's School of Education, has carried out a number of research projects in this area over the past five years. 'We have tracked how children make career choices from primary school right through to higher education,' he says, 'and what we have found is that choices form over many years and are often based on ideas that have developed in early childhood. By the age of 11 children have gone a long way to ruling out a lot of career fields.

'Traditionally, career guidance in schools tends to be for 14- and 15-year-olds and our research says this is far too late. By this stage the teenager is merely seeking information to bolster the choice they have already made, rather than making a real choice.'

The researchers found that these choices were based on an image of the job that built up in the child's mind - the kind of lifestyle they thought went with a particular job, the social status of the job, the time spent doing it, the amount of money they would get paid. They built up these images from direct experiences, such as visiting the doctor, going to the shops, or from what adults told them about different jobs.

But one of the most significant influences they found on children is the media: television programmes, news coverage and children's books. It seems it really can make a difference if children have books that are careful not to reinforce gender stereotypes, for instance.

And if the evidence of one recruiter from a large European law firm is to be believed, this media influence carries on to a stage when young people should have become a bit more discerning. Hopeful graduates applying for a job at the firm have been known to mention the fact that watching Ally McBeal had inspired them to consider corporate law as a career.

Foskett's own researches for the NHS into how young people perceived nursing as a career showed that many of their opinions had been formed from watching programmes such as ER and Casualty .

'What came out of the research was that the most attractive careers to young people in the medical world was being a doctor in an accident and emergency department or an ambulanceman - jobs associated with exciting, life-saving images. Nurses were perceived in a more negative way as mere helpers who worked for doctors.'

But parents and teachers do also have an important influence on young people and their career choices. One of the most significant findings to come out of Foskett's research is the importance of primary school teachers.

Their influence is great and Foskett believes this should be built on, with primary school teachers being trained to help children build up a realistic idea of the world of work; not to offer specific career guidance as such, but to help children keep their options open and counter prejudices that may exist against certain professions and towards jobs that may be seen as just for boys or girls.

Inevitably when looking at the influ ences on children when making decisions about their future careers, social class is likely to play an important part. Foskett has just completed a piece of research for the deans of medical schools who are concerned that they are not attracting applicants from a wide enough social spectrum.

'This work highlighted the attitude of working-class children to medicine as a profession. They see it as an important career and a high-status job but one not done by people like them.

Another issue is that working-class children tend to view work purely as a means to generate income, rather than as a profession or lifestyle choice. Also the NHS's bad press means that medicine is often equated with working hard and not getting very well paid.'

 Research carried out by the Centre for Research in Education Marketing at the School of Education, Southampton University, is to be published by Falmer Press, under the title Choosing Futures, in the spring.

webTitle: Work: How to ... pick up on stress

fields.headline: How to ...
fields.standfirst: ...pick up early signs of stress
fields.trailText: ...pick up early signs of stress.
fields.body:
1 RECOGNISE that your body is probably more intelligent than your mind and that it is designed to provide an early warning system on stress. Headaches and migraines are very common symptoms of mental overload. Skin rashes or other problems are also good indicators since the same hormones relate to both stress and skin. All sorts of other physical problems will develop if you are under serious pressure, including digestion difficulties and chest pain. Remember that there is growing evidence relating persistent long hours at work to heart attacks and premature death.

2 LOOK at how your parents coped with stress and see if you are following any similar patterns. 'If the dad comes home and reaches for a glass of beer, the chances are that one of the kids will one day start doing that as well,' says Dr Malcolm VandenBurg of stress consultancy Positive at Work.

3 EXAMINE your environment. Your susceptibility to stress is likely to increase if, for instance, you are worried about getting the sack; if you don't have access to natural light at work; if you work unsocial hours; or if your workplace is noisy or uncomfortable.
