webTitle: You needn't be wedded to one bank, but divorce is still tricky

fields.headline: Till death do you part?
fields.standfirst: You needn't be wedded to one bank, says  Andrew Bibby,  though divorce is still tricky
fields.trailText: You needn't be wedded to one bank, says Andrew Bibby, though divorce is still tricky.
fields.body:
Planning to be faithful for the rest of your life to just one bank? Don't be surprised if your bank doesn't feel obliged to reciprocate. The major banks long ago abandoned the idea that they had anything more than a business relationship with their customers. Unfortunately, it's taken time for most of us to realise that the rules have changed and that these days, sadly, loyalty counts for little.

Take interest rates, for example. When interest payments on credit balances were first introduced, the step was seen as a major advance for consumers. But interest payments have been all but abolished. Barclays, NatWest, HSBC and Lloyds have all reduced the interest on standard current accounts to a pitiful 0.1 per cent before tax.

Why blame the banks, however, when customers seem prepared to stay put? A recent Consumers Association survey of 10,000 Which? readers found, for example, that NatWest customers on average had held their accounts for 22 years. Yet only 15 per cent said they would choose the same bank a second time, giving their own bank the worst report of the 14 banks surveyed.

According to Melanie Green, CA senior researcher , only a small percentage of people actually get round to moving accounts. 'People's perception is that there is not that much difference between banks. It's a lot of effort to move accounts, so what's the point? But there is quite a lot of difference, in terms of both costs and customer satisfaction,' she says.

The logic of the banking industry today is that we should probably consider changing our bank accounts about as frequently as we change our cars. This won't happen. Nevertheless, the major banks are anxiously aware that they will not be able to rely indefinitely on customer inertia.

Competition is intensifying, and there is increasing pressure among banks to merge. Mergers can lead to reduced competition - but not always. Had merger talks between Bank of Scotland and Abbey National succeeded, the combined group could have been in a better position to attack the current account custom of the big four. The Abbey/Bank of Scotland deal may have faltered, but there will be more to come in this crowded industry.

Halifax's announcement last month that it would be increasing the standard interest rate from 0.25 per cent to 4 per cent from January for many of its current account customers may prove to be the start of a new battle for customers. The Halifax has about 5 per cent of the British current account market, and its sights are set on doubling this within five years. The traditional big four, with 80 per cent of the current account market, are the target.

The Halifax initiative anticipates a radical change in the way the industry will handle the transfer of standing orders and direct debits when customers decide to move banks. This remains for many people the biggest single obstacle to switching, as Don Cruickshank pointed out in his damning report on the banking industry, which was published last spring.

The banks, which have hardly rushed in the past to tackle this issue, now plan to introduce an automated direct debit transfer system through the bank clearing system, Bacs - but not until the end of next year.

In the meantime, under the revised voluntary banking code of conduct, banks are supposed to co-operate to ensure their customers can move their accounts as smoothly as possible. Some, but not all, banks are going a step further and, under a Bacs-sponsored pilot programme, are offering to handle the transfer arrangements for direct debits and standing orders for new customers.

The Bacs pilot, which is based on the old-fashioned exchange of paper-based records, initially involved the Abbey National, Co-op, Halifax, Nationwide, RBS, Ulster Bank, Virgin One and Woolwich, and has more recently been joined by Barclays, Bank of Scotland and Clydesdale/Yorkshire/Northern group. However, in some cases only particular branches are participating. 'It's fiddly to move accounts, especially if you've got a busy current account with lots of standing orders and direct debits,' says Green of the CA. However she adds: 'Those who do it generally say that it wasn't as bad as they'd thought.'

The main problem is not standing orders, which are relatively straightforward, but direct debits, since these allow other organisations the right to dip into individual bank accounts to remove money. On the positive side, changing banks does allow you the chance to review your existing arrangements, checking whether they all remain appropriate to your needs.

Splitting up with your existing bank is all very well, but how do you decide where to move to? The past 10 years has seen increasing segmentation as banks attempt to identify their more profitable customers and spend proportionately less effort on the rest. The segmentation process is being extended downwards by the introduction (initially by NatWest and Lloyds TSB) of basic bank accounts and the proposed creation of a Post Office-based universal bank account service, primarily designed for the estimated 3.5 million people without a current account.

Leaving aside both basic bank accounts and, at the other end of the scale, the bespoke personal bank services available for the seriously rich, there are broadly four choices of bank account now available.

One is the packaged bank account, where standard current account facilities are bundled together with other financial and non-financial services. A typical packaged bank account is likely to offer such things as automatic card protection insurance, discounts on car hire and insurance and possibly other travel and shopping special offers.

However, these extra services cost money (sometimes dressed up as a 'membership subscription'): £4 a month for Lloyds' Select account, for example, £6 a month for Barclays Additions and £9 a month for RBS's Royalties Gold. The number of packaged bank accounts, which appear to appeal par ticularly to middle-aged professionals, has doubled to an estimated 3 million since 1998.

For the best interest rates, however, look to the new online bank accounts. Abbey National's e-bank, Cahoot, is currently ahead of the field, paying 4.9 per cent gross on all credit balances (Cahoot pays even more if you are prepared to do without a cheque book). The Irish-based First-e pays 4.88 per cent, while the Co-op's Smile bank is close behind, offering 4.75 per cent.

Some of the industry's enthusiasm for internet banking subsidiaries has disappeared in recent months, partly as a result of well-publicised security problems and partly because of the general fall from favour of new dotcom businesses. It is also not as easy to set up a standalone internet bank as some people thought initially, as the Halifax's teething problems in launching Intelligent Finance (IF) testify.

Nevertheless, the extremely low costs involved in administering online transactions mean that Internet-based banks should continue to be able to offer good rates of interest.

Halifax's IF straddles two categories of bank account, copying the Virgin One idea of combining a bank account and mortgage loan in a single product. The idea is an enticing one: why pay a high rate of interest on your mortgage and, separately, receive a low rate of interest on your current account balances? By combining what you owe with what you are lending back to your bank via your current account, the theory is that you can pay interest only on the net amount you are borrowing.

Combined bank and mortgage accounts are offered by a number of other institutions, including the Woolwich, Yorkshire Bank and First Active.

Moving to a combined account does, however, limit your choice of mortgage borrower and locks you into a very close relationship with your chosen company. In practice, these sorts of accounts are likely to remain niche products.

The vast majority of us, it seems, are still happy to make do with a traditional branch-based current account, operating in the usual way.

The Halifax's decision to attack the big four banks' dominance of this market next January is a tacit recognition of this fact. By increasing the interest rate to 4 per cent and reducing the overdraft rate to 10 per cent, the Halifax is also looking to squeeze considerably the traditional profit margins enjoyed on current account banking business

However the Halifax's Shane O'Riordain argues that the rates are sustainable. 'Current accounts, together with credit cards and personal loans, are the areas in personal banking with the most generous margins, and they're also the least competitive ones,' he says.

'Traditional banks make more than twice as much on current accounts as we do on mortgages. Our own research suggests that people are becoming more price-sensitive, and that there is a major shift in the way people are looking at current accounts.'

The Halifax's 4 per cent headline rate takes it substantially above the current high street market leader, the Nationwide, which pays 1.45 per cent on balances up to £5,000, and tiered rates up to 2.75 per cent above that.

However, the Halifax's new rates will only apply automatically where at least £1,000 is credited each month to the account. Less well-off customers will find the account terms less generous.

Arguably, too, high interest on credit balances is not necessarily the most important feature of a current account - canny customers with money in their accounts should transfer any excess into a higher-rate savings account at the first opportunity.

Green from the Consumers' Association also advises caution when comparing overdraft interest rates.

'The really big difference on overdraft costs is whether an overdraft fee is charged,' she says. Some banks add a usage fee, typically £5 a month (though £7 at Northern Rock and £8 at the Co-operative), even when overdrafts have been authorised in advance. Others charge an arrangement fee when overdraft facilities are first set up.

Among the big players, Nationwide, Abbey National, Halifax, Lloyds TSB, and Yorkshire Bank commendably make only interest charges on arranged overdrafts. However, the situation changes markedly for unauthorised overdrafts, where almost all banks maintain the right to impose swingeing penalties.

Less easy to assess than interest rates and overdraft charges are the customer service on offer. There has been a move away from the centrality of the local branch in customer relations with banks. Branches have been redefined as primarily marketing centres; routine administration has been removed to centralised back-offices; and telephone calls from customers are routed to call-handling centres.

In its recent Which? survey, the Consumers Association reported an astonishing contrast between First Direct and Nationwide customers, two-thirds of whom said they would definitely choose the same bank again, and those people banking with Clydesdale, the Halifax and NatWest, where less than one in five said they would stay loyal.

Also near the bottom of the table were Lloyds TSB, Barclays and Abbey National. The moral, according to Green, is that changing your bank really can make a difference.

Forty years - and not a backwards glance

John Fletcher was a loyal Barclays customer for over 40 years, with an affection for the company based on a family connection: his father had been employed as an assistant branch manager with Barclays. But his link with Barclays has now gone. Earlier this year, John and his wife Sylvia took the major step of moving their current account away from Barclays, in their case choosing to go to the Halifax.

The immediate impetus for change was Barclays' announcement that they were closing the Fletchers' nearest branch, at Roade near Northampton. But the Fletchers had other dissatisfactions.

'They didn't seem interested in you as a customer,' John says. 'Also I took exception to some of the things they were doing, such as the excessive salaries being paid to the chairman and chief executive. I decided there was no point writing to anyone - the only thing I could do was to move.'

As he explains, however, the idea of moving current accounts was not one he was relishing. A past career move had meant that he had transferred his Barclays account from a branch in Derbyshire to one in Northants, and this internal transfer, he says, had not been without problems. The idea of moving banks altogether caused him some apprehension.

In practice, however, his worries were unfounded. 'The Halifax asked us to sign a form and they then sorted out all the direct debits and standing orders. Everything slipped into place, and as far as we were concerned it was painless.'

How do you decide where to take your custom if, like the Fletchers you have remained with one bank for many years? John and Sylvia did not pore over interest rate comparison tables or weigh up competing overdraft deals; instead they opted for the old-fashioned personal approach, the plan being to shop around in Northampton to see which bank seemed competent in handling the transfer. They began, and ended, at the Halifax, where they already held an investment.

John remains irritated by his treatment at the hands of Barclays. 'What has really annoyed me is that, after 40 years, Barclays never asked me why I moved. They never approached me at all. And there's another thing: I was never offered interest in my current account before.

'I knew some Barclays customers did get interest, but I was never offered it,' he says.

Not surprisingly, he is looking forward to the 4 per cent interest promised by the Halifax after January.

Barclays has admitted that its recent branch closure programme and its Big Bank advertising has lost it friends, and has announced that it will be more sensitive to public opinion in future. But other big clearing banks may need to take note of people like the Fletchers, if they are to keep their current strong customer base.

It's not only current account business that's at stake: the big four also dominate credit cards in Britain on the back of their personal banking business.

'I changed my credit card from Barclays at the same time as moving my account,' John says.

What's on offer

Interest paid
Internet banks pay the best interest. But there is movement on traditional accounts. From January, the Halifax's 4 per cent will be highly competitive, but only for accounts receiving £1,000 a month (or other accounts when the balance is above £1,000.) Best of the rest is the Nationwide.

Overdraft arrangements
Only of concern if you expect to be in the red. Choose a bank which only charges interest, not fees. Fee-free overdraft 'buffers' are normally available to customers from, among others, Smile (£500), First Direct (£500), Cahoot (£250), Co-op (£250), HSBC (£50), Woolwich (£50) and NatWest (£50). Barclays offers a paltry £20 buffer, Lloyds TSB £10. (Information from Moneyfacts).

Online banking
With HSBC offering internet banking as an option this summer, almost all the major banks have online facilities. Telephone banking is also routinely available. No internet option at Yorkshire Bank, RBS, Northern Rock or Clydesdale.

Branch location
Three-quarters of bank customers continue to rely on high street branches. Lloyds TSB has the largest number of branches, thanks to its takeover of TSB, with just over 2,200 branches at the end of last year. Barclays was in second place at 1,899 before its unpopular branch closure programme this year. The trend is firmly downwards. Do not assume that existing branches in small towns, estates or inner-cities will necessarily survive much longer.

ATMs
British cash machines are now effectively all linked, but not every bank offers free use of all machines. Government pressure earlier this year forced banks such as Barclays, which had considered imposing ATM charges on non-customers, to think again. The best bet for continuing free use of the network looks most likely at those institutions which have taken a principled stand: try Nationwide and RBS.

Travelling abroad
The best deal is from the Nationwide, which offers commission-free access to cash abroad, through all Visa branded cash machines.
